
       
Oliver
Twist
,
or
The
Parish
Boy
's
Progress
Oliver
Twist
 
Charles
Dickens
  
1837
<EOS>
-
-1839
  
<EOS>
Information
about
the
source
     
Chapter
1
.
<EOS>
Treats
of
the
place
where
Oliver
Twist
was
born
and
of
the
circumstances
attending
his
birth
.
 
<EOS>
Among
other
public
buildings
in
a
certain
town
,
which
for
many
reasons
it
will
be
prudent
to
refrain
from
mentioning
,
and
to
which
I
will
assign
no
fictitious
name
,
there
is
one
anciently
common
to
most
towns
,
great
or
small
:
 
to
wit
,
a
workhouse
;
and
in
this
workhouse
was
born
;
on
a
day
and
date
which
I
need
not
trouble
myself
to
repeat
,
inasmuch
as
it
can
be
of
no
possible
consequence
to
the
reader
,
in
this
stage
of
the
business
at
all
events
;
the
item
of
mortality
whose
name
is
prefixed
to
the
head
of
this
chapter
.
   
<EOS>
For
a
long
time
after
it
was
ushered
into
this
world
of
sorrow
and
trouble
,
by
the
parish
surgeon
,
it
remained
a
matter
of
considerable
doubt
whether
the
child
would
survive
to
bear
any
name
at
all
;
in
which
case
it
is
somewhat
more
than
probable
that
these
memoirs
would
never
have
appeared
;
or
,
if
they
had
,
that
being
comprised
within
a
couple
of
pages
,
they
would
have
possessed
the
inestimable
merit
of
being
the
most
concise
and
faithful
specimen
of
biography
,
extant
in
the
literature
of
any
age
or
country
.
   
<EOS>
Although
I
am
not
disposed
to
maintain
that
the
being
born
in
a
workhouse
,
is
in
itself
the
most
fortunate
and
enviable
circumstance
that
can
possibly
befall
a
human
being
,
I
do
mean
to
say
that
in
this
particular
instance
,
it
was
the
best
thing
for
Oliver
Twist
that
could
by
possibility
have
occurred
.
 
<EOS>
The
fact
is
,
that
there
was
considerable
difficulty
in
inducing
Oliver
to
take
upon
himself
the
office
of
respiration
,
---
a
troublesome
practice
,
but
one
which
custom
has
rendered
necessary
to
our
easy
existence
;
and
for
some
time
he
lay
gasping
on
a
little
flock
mattress
,
rather
unequally
poised
between
this
world
and
the
next
:
 
the
balance
being
decidedly
in
favour
of
the
latter
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
if
,
during
this
brief
period
,
Oliver
had
been
surrounded
by
careful
grandmothers
,
anxious
aunts
,
experienced
nurses
,
and
doctors
of
profound
wisdom
,
he
would
most
inevitably
and
indubitably
have
been
killed
in
no
time
.
 
<EOS>
There
being
nobody
by
,
however
,
but
a
pauper
old
woman
,
who
was
rendered
rather
misty
by
an
unwonted
allowance
of
beer
;
and
a
parish
surgeon
who
did
such
matters
by
contract
;
<EOS>
Oliver
and
Nature
fought
out
the
point
between
them
.
 
<EOS>
The
result
was
,
that
,
after
a
few
struggles
,
Oliver
breathed
,
sneezed
,
and
proceeded
to
advertise
to
the
inmates
of
the
workhouse
the
fact
of
a
new
burden
having
been
imposed
 
upon
the
parish
,
by
setting
up
as
loud
a
cry
as
could
reasonably
have
been
expected
from
a
male
infant
who
had
not
been
possessed
of
that
very
useful
appendage
,
a
voice
,
for
a
much
longer
space
of
time
than
three
minutes
and
a
quarter
.
   
<EOS>
As
Oliver
gave
this
first
proof
of
the
free
and
proper
action
of
his
lungs
,
the
patchwork
coverlet
which
was
carelessly
flung
over
the
iron
bedstead
,
rustled
;
the
pale
face
of
a
young
woman
was
raised
feebly
from
the
pillow
;
and
a
faint
voice
imperfectly
articulated
the
words
<EOS>
,
"
Let
me
see
the
child
,
and
die
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
surgeon
had
been
sitting
with
his
face
turned
towards
the
fire
:
 
giving
the
palms
of
his
hands
a
warm
and
a
rub
alternately
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
young
woman
spoke
,
he
rose
,
and
advancing
to
the
bed
's
head
,
said
,
with
more
kindness
than
might
have
been
expected
of
him
:
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
you
must
not
talk
about
dying
yet
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Lor
bless
her
dear
heart
,
no
!
"
<EOS>
interposed
the
nurse
,
hastily
depositing
in
her
pocket
a
green
glass
bottle
,
the
contents
of
which
she
had
been
tasting
in
a
corner
with
evident
satisfaction
.
   
<EOS>
"
Lor
bless
her
dear
heart
,
when
she
has
lived
as
long
as
I
have
,
sir
,
and
had
thirteen
children
of
her
own
,
and
all
on
'em
dead
except
two
,
and
them
in
the
wurkus
with
me
<EOS>
,
she
'll
know
better
than
to
take
on
in
that
way
,
bless
her
dear
heart
!
 
<EOS>
Think
what
it
is
to
be
a
mother
,
there
's
a
dear
young
lamb
do
.
"
   
<EOS>
Apparently
this
consolatory
perspective
of
a
mother
's
prospects
failed
in
producing
its
due
effect
.
 
<EOS>
The
patient
shook
her
head
,
and
stretched
out
her
hand
towards
the
child
.
   
<EOS>
The
surgeon
deposited
it
in
her
arms
.
 
<EOS>
She
imprinted
her
cold
white
lips
passionately
on
its
forehead
;
passed
her
hands
over
her
face
;
gazed
wildly
round
;
shuddered
;
fell
back
---
and
died
.
<EOS>
They
chafed
her
breast
,
hands
,
and
temples
;
but
the
blood
had
stopped
forever
.
 
<EOS>
They
talked
of
hope
and
comfort
.
<EOS>
They
had
been
strangers
too
long
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
over
,
Mrs
Thingummy
!
"
said
the
surgeon
at
last
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
,
poor
dear
,
so
it
is
!
"
said
the
nurse
,
picking
up
the
cork
of
the
green
bottle
,
which
had
fallen
out
on
the
pillow
,
as
she
stooped
to
take
up
the
child
.
 
<EOS>
"
Poor
dear
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
need
n't
mind
sending
up
to
me
,
if
the
child
cries
,
nurse
,
"
said
the
surgeon
,
putting
on
his
gloves
with
great
deliberation
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
very
likely
it
WILL
be
troublesome
.
 
<EOS>
Give
it
a
little
gruel
if
it
is
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
put
on
his
hat
,
and
,
pausing
by
the
bed
-
side
on
his
way
to
the
door
,
added
,
"
She
was
a
good
-
looking
girl
,
too
;
<EOS>
where
did
she
come
from
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
was
brought
here
last
night
,
"
replied
the
old
woman
,
"
by
the
overseer
's
order
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
found
lying
in
the
street
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
walked
some
distance
,
for
her
shoes
<EOS>
were
worn
to
pieces
;
but
where
she
came
from
,
or
where
she
was
going
to
,
nobody
knows
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
The
surgeon
leaned
over
the
body
,
and
raised
the
left
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
old
story
,
"
he
said
,
shaking
his
head
:
 
"
no
wedding
-
ring
<EOS>
,
I
see
.
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
Good
-
night
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
The
medical
gentleman
walked
away
to
dinner
;
and
the
nurse
,
having
once
more
applied
herself
to
the
green
bottle
,
sat
down
on
a
low
chair
before
the
fire
,
and
proceeded
to
dress
the
infant
.
   
<EOS>
What
an
excellent
example
of
the
power
of
dress
,
young
Oliver
Twist
was
!
 
<EOS>
Wrapped
in
the
blanket
which
had
hitherto
formed
his
only
covering
,
he
might
have
been
the
child
of
a
nobleman
or
a
beggar
;
it
would
have
been
hard
for
the
haughtiest
stranger
to
have
assigned
him
his
proper
station
in
society
.
 
<EOS>
But
now
that
he
was
enveloped
in
the
old
calico
robes
which
had
grown
yellow
in
the
same
service
,
he
was
badged
and
ticketed
,
and
fell
into
his
place
at
once
---
a
parish
child
---
the
orphan
of
a
workhouse
---
the
humble
,
half
-
starved
drudge
---
to
be
cuffed
and
buffeted
through
the
world
---
despised
by
all
,
and
pitied
by
none
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
cried
lustily
.
<EOS>
If
he
could
have
known
that
he
was
an
orphan
,
left
to
the
tender
mercies
of
church
-
wardens
and
overseers
,
perhaps
he
would
have
cried
the
louder
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
2
.
<EOS>
Treats
of
Oliver
Twist
's
growth
,
education
,
and
board
.
 
<EOS>
For
the
next
eight
or
ten
months
,
Oliver
was
the
victim
of
a
systematic
course
of
treachery
and
deception
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
brought
up
by
hand
.
 
<EOS>
The
hungry
and
destitute
situation
of
the
infant
orphan
was
duly
reported
by
the
workhouse
authorities
to
the
parish
authorities
.
 
<EOS>
The
parish
authorities
inquired
with
dignity
of
the
workhouse
authorities
,
whether
there
was
no
female
then
domiciled
in
"
the
house
"
who
was
in
a
situation
to
impart
to
Oliver
Twist
,
the
consolation
and
nourishment
of
which
he
stood
in
need
.
 
<EOS>
The
workhouse
authorities
replied
with
humility
,
that
there
was
not
.
<EOS>
Upon
this
,
the
parish
authorities
magnanimously
and
humanely
resolved
,
that
Oliver
should
be
"
farmed
,
"
or
,
in
other
words
,
that
he
should
be
dispatched
to
a
branch
-
workhouse
some
three
miles
off
,
where
twenty
or
thirty
other
juvenile
offenders
against
the
poor
-
laws
,
rolled
about
the
floor
all
day
,
without
the
inconvenience
of
too
much
food
or
too
much
clothing
,
under
the
parental
superintendence
of
an
elderly
female
,
who
received
the
culprits
at
and
for
the
consideration
of
sevenpence
-
halfpenny
per
small
head
per
week
.
 
<EOS>
Sevenpence
-
halfpenny
's
worth
per
week
is
a
good
round
diet
for
a
child
;
a
great
deal
may
be
got
for
sevenpence
-
halfpenny
,
quite
enough
to
overload
its
stomach
,
and
make
it
uncomfortable
.
<EOS>
The
elderly
female
was
a
woman
of
wisdom
and
experience
;
she
knew
what
was
good
for
children
;
and
she
had
a
very
accurate
perception
of
what
was
good
for
herself
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
she
appropriated
the
greater
part
of
the
weekly
stipend
to
her
own
use
,
and
consigned
the
rising
parochial
generation
to
even
a
shorter
allowance
than
was
originally
provided
for
them
.
 
<EOS>
Thereby
finding
in
the
lowest
depth
a
deeper
still
;
and
proving
herself
a
very
great
experimental
philosopher
.
   
<EOS>
Everybody
knows
the
story
of
another
experimental
philosopher
who
had
a
great
theory
about
a
horse
being
able
to
live
without
eating
,
and
who
demonstrated
it
so
well
,
that
he
had
got
his
own
horse
down
to
a
straw
a
day
,
and
would
unquestionably
have
rendered
him
a
very
spirited
and
rampacious
animal
on
nothing
at
all
,
if
he
had
not
died
,
four
-
and
-
twenty
hours
before
he
was
to
have
had
his
first
comfortable
bait
of
air
.
 
<EOS>
Unfortunately
for
,
the
experimenal
philosophy
of
the
female
to
whose
protecting
care
Oliver
Twist
was
delivered
over
,
a
similar
result
usually
attended
the
operation
of
HER
system
;
for
at
the
very
moment
when
the
child
had
contrived
to
exist
upon
the
smallest
possible
portion
of
the
weakest
possible
food
,
it
did
perversely
happen
in
eight
and
a
half
cases
out
of
ten
,
either
that
it
sickened
from
want
and
cold
,
or
fell
into
the
fire
from
neglect
,
or
got
half
-
smothered
by
accident
;
in
any
one
of
which
cases
,
the
miserable
little
being
was
usually
summoned
into
another
world
,
and
there
gathered
to
the
fathers
it
had
never
known
in
this
.
   
<EOS>
Occasionally
,
when
there
was
some
more
than
usually
interesting
inquest
upon
a
parish
child
who
had
been
overlooked
in
turning
up
a
bedstead
,
or
inadvertently
scalded
to
death
when
there
happened
to
be
a
washing
---
though
the
latter
accident
was
very
scarce
,
anything
approaching
to
a
washing
being
of
rare
occurance
in
the
farm
---
the
jury
would
take
it
into
their
heads
to
ask
troublesome
questions
,
or
the
parishioners
would
rebelliously
affix
their
signatures
to
a
remonstrance
.
 
<EOS>
But
these
impertinences
were
speedily
checked
by
the
evidence
of
the
surgeon
,
and
the
testimony
of
the
beadle
;
the
former
of
whom
had
always
opened
the
body
and
found
nothing
inside
(
which
was
very
probable
indeed
)
,
and
the
latter
of
whom
invariably
swore
whatever
the
parish
wanted
;
which
was
very
self
-
devotional
.
 
<EOS>
Besides
,
the
board
made
periodical
pilgrimages
to
the
farm
,
and
always
sent
the
beadle
the
day
before
,
to
say
they
were
going
.
 
<EOS>
The
children
were
neat
and
clean
to
behold
,
when
THEY
went
;
and
what
more
would
the
people
have
!
   
<EOS>
It
can
not
be
expected
that
this
system
of
farming
would
produce
any
very
extraordinary
or
luxuriant
crop
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
Twist
's
ninth
birthday
found
him
a
pale
thin
child
,
somewhat
diminutive
in
stature
,
and
decidely
small
in
circumference
.
 
<EOS>
But
nature
or
inheritance
had
implanted
a
good
sturdy
spirit
in
Oliver
's
breast
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
had
plenty
of
room
to
expand
,
thanks
to
the
spare
diet
of
the
establishment
;
and
perhaps
to
this
circumstance
may
be
attributed
his
having
any
ninth
birth
-
day
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
Be
this
as
it
may
<EOS>
,
however
,
it
was
his
ninth
birthday
;
and
he
was
keeping
it
in
the
coal
-
cellar
with
a
select
party
of
two
other
young
gentleman
,
who
,
after
participating
with
him
in
a
sound
thrashing
,
had
been
locked
up
for
atrociously
presuming
to
be
hungry
,
when
Mrs
Mann
,
the
good
lady
of
the
house
,
was
unexpectedly
startled
by
the
apparition
of
Mr
Bumble
,
the
beadle
,
striving
to
undo
the
wicket
of
the
garden
-
gate
.
   
<EOS>
"
Goodness
gracious
!
 
<EOS>
Is
that
you
,
Mr
Bumble
,
sir
?
"
said
Mrs
Mann
,
thrusting
her
head
out
of
the
window
in
well
-
affected
ecstasies
of
joy
.
 
<EOS>
"
(
Susan
,
take
Oliver
and
them
two
brats
upstairs
,
and
wash
'em
directly
.
)
<EOS>
---
My
heart
alive
!
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
,
<EOS>
how
glad
I
am
to
see
you
,
sure
-
ly
!
"
   
<EOS>
Now
,
Mr
Bumble
was
a
fat
man
,
and
a
choleric
;
so
,
instead
of
responding
to
this
open
-
hearted
salutation
in
a
kindred
spirit
,
he
gave
the
little
wicket
a
tremendous
shake
,
and
then
bestowed
upon
it
a
kick
which
could
have
emanated
from
no
leg
but
a
beadle
's
.
   
<EOS>
"
Lor
,
only
think
,
"
said
Mrs
Mann
,
running
out
,
---
for
the
three
boys
had
been
removed
by
this
time
,
---
"
only
think
of
that
!
 
<EOS>
That
I
should
have
forgotten
that
the
gate
was
bolted
on
the
inside
,
on
account
of
them
<EOS>
dear
children
!
 
<EOS>
Walk
in
sir
;
walk
in
,
pray
,
Mr
Bumble
,
do
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Although
this
invitation
was
accompanied
with
a
curtsey
that
might
have
softened
the
heart
of
a
church
-
warden
,
it
by
no
means
mollified
the
beadle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
this
respectful
or
proper
conduct
,
Mrs
Mann
,
"
inquired
Mr
Bumble
,
grasping
his
cane
,
"
to
keep
the
parish
officers
a
waiting
at
your
garden
-
gate
,
when
they
come
here
upon
porochial
business
with
the
porochial
orphans
?
 
<EOS>
Are
you
aweer
,
Mrs
Mann
,
that
you
are
,
as
I
may
say
,
a
porochial
delegate
,
and
a
stipendiary
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
sure
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
,
that
I
was
only
a
telling
one
or
two
of
the
dear
children
as
is
so
fond
of
you
,
that
it
was
you
a
coming
,
"
replied
Mrs
Mann
with
great
humility
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
had
a
great
idea
of
his
oratorical
powers
and
his
importance
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
displayed
the
one
,
and
vindicated
the
other
.
<EOS>
He
relaxed
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
well
,
Mrs
Mann
,
"
he
replied
in
a
calmer
tone
;
"
it
may
be
as
you
say
;
it
may
be
.
 
<EOS>
Lead
the
way
in
,
Mrs
Mann
,
for
I
come
on
business
,
and
have
something
to
say
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Mann
ushered
the
beadle
into
a
small
parlour
with
a
brick
floor
;
placed
a
seat
for
him
;
and
officiously
deposited
his
cocked
hat
and
can
on
the
table
before
him
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
wiped
from
his
forehead
the
perspiration
which
his
walk
had
engendered
,
glanced
complacently
at
the
cocked
hat
,
and
smiled
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
he
smiled
.
 
<EOS>
Beadles
are
but
men
:
and
Mr
Bumble
smiled
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
do
n't
you
be
offended
at
what
I
'm
a
going
to
say
,
"
observed
Mrs
Mann
,
with
captivating
sweetness
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
've
had
a
long
walk
,
you
know
,
or
I
would
n't
mention
it
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
will
you
take
a
little
drop
of
somethink
,
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
Not
a
drop
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
a
drop
,
"
said
Mr
Bumble
,
waving
his
right
hand
in
a
dignified
,
but
placid
manner
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
you
will
,
"
said
Mrs
Mann
,
who
had
noticed
the
tone
of
the
refusal
,
and
the
gesture
that
had
accompanied

.
 
<EOS>
"
Just
a
leetle
drop
,
with
a
little
cold
water
,
and
a
lump
of
sugar
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
coughed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
just
a
leetle
drop
,
"
said
Mrs
Mann
persuasively
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
the
beadle
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Why
,
it
's
what
I
'm
obliged
to
keep
a
little
of
in
the
house
,
to
put
into
the
blessed
infants
'
Daffy
,
when
they
ai
n't
well
,
Mr
Bumble
,
"

Mrs
Mann
as

opened
a
corner

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
gin
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
not
deceive
you
,
<EOS>
Mr
B.
 
It
's
gin
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
give
the
children
Daffy
,
Mrs
Mann
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Bumble
,
following
with
this

the
interesting
process
of
mixing
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
bless
'em
,
that
I
do
,
dear
as
it
is
,
"
replied
the
nurse
.
<EOS>
"
I
could
n't
see
'em
suffer
before
my
very
eyes
,
you
know
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
"
;
said
Mr
Bumble
approvingly
;
"
no
,
you
could
not
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
a
humane
woman
,
Mrs
Mann
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
(
Here
she
set
down
the
glass
.
)
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
take
a
early
opportunity
of
mentioning
it
to
the
board
,
Mrs
Mann
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
(
He
drew
it
towards
him
.
)
 
<EOS>
"
You
feel
as
a
mother
,
Mrs
Mann
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
(
He
stirred
the
gin
-
and
-
water
.
)
<EOS>
"
I
---
I
drink
your
health
with
cheerfulness
,
Mrs
Mann
"
;
and
he
swallowed
half
of
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
now
about
business
,
"
said
the
beadle
,
taking
out
a

.
 
<EOS>
"
The
child
that
was
half
-
baptized
Oliver
Twist
,
is
nine
year
old
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
;
   
"
Bless

!
"
<EOS>
interposed
Mrs
Mann
,
inflaming

with

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
notwithstanding
a
offered

of
ten
pound
,
which
was
afterwards
increased
to
twenty

.
 
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
the
most
superlative
,
and
,
I

say
,
supernat'ral

on
the

of
this
parish
,
"
said
Bumble
,
<EOS>
"
we
have
never

able

discover
who
is
his
father
,
or
what
was
his
mother
's
settlement
,
name
,
or
con
---
dition
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Mann
raised
her
hands
in

;
but
added
,
after

moment
's

,
"
How
comes
he
to
have
any
name
at
all
,
then
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
beadle
drew
himself
up
with
great
pride
,
and
said
,
"
I
inwented
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
,
Mr
Bumble
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
,
Mrs
Mann
.
 
<EOS>
We
name
our
fondlings
in
alphabetical
order
.
<EOS>
The
last
was
a
S^
,
---
<EOS>
Swubble
,
I
named
him
.
<EOS>
This
was
a
T^
,
---
<EOS>
Twist
,
I
named
HIM
.
 
<EOS>
The
next
one
comes
will
be
Unwin
,
and
the
next
Vilkins
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
got
names
ready
made
to
the
end
of
the
alphabet
,
and
all
the
way
through
it
again
,
when
we
come
to
Z^.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
're
quite
a
literary
character
,
sir
!
"
said
Mrs
Mann
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
"
said
the
beadle
,
evidently
gratified
with
the
compliment
;
"
perhaps
I
may
be
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
I
may
be
,
Mrs
Mann
.
"
<EOS>
He
finished
the
gin
-
and
-
water
,
and
added
,
"
Oliver
being
now
too
old
to
remain
here
,
the
board
have
determined
to
have
him
back
into
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
come
out
myself
to
take
him
there
.
 
<EOS>
So
let
me
see
him
at
once
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
fetch
him
directly
,
"
said
Mrs
Mann
,
leaving
the
room
for
that
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
,
having
had
by
this
time
as
much
of
the
outer
coat
of
dirt
which
encrusted
his
face
and
hands
,
removed
,
as
could
be
scrubbed
off
in
one

,
was
led
into
the
room
by
his
benevolent
protectress
.
   
<EOS>
"
Make
a
bow
to
the
gentleman
,
Oliver
,
"
said
Mrs
Mann
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
made
a
bow
,
which
was
divided
between
the
beadle
on
the
chair
,
and
the
cocked
hat
on
the
table
.
   
<EOS>
"
Will
you
go
along
with
me
,
Oliver
?
"
said
Mr
Bumble
,
in
a
majestic
voice
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
was
about
to
say
that
he
would
go
along
with
anybody
with
great
readiness
,
when
,
glancing
upward
,
he
caught
sight
of
Mrs
Mann
,
who
had
got
behind
the
beadle
's
chair
,
and
was
shaking
her
fist
at
him
with
a
furious
countenance
.
 
<EOS>
He
took
the
hint
at
once
,
for
the
fist
had
been
too
often
impressed
upon
his
body
not
to
be
deeply
impressed
upon
his
recollection
.
   
<EOS>
"
Will
she
go
with
me
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
poor
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
she
ca
n't
,
"
replied
Mr
Bumble
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
she
'll
come
and
see
you
sometimes
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
no
very
great
consolation
to
the
child
.
 
<EOS>
Young
as
he
was
,
however
,
he
had
sense
enough
to
make
a
feint
of
feeling
great
regret
at
going
away
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
no
very
difficult
matter
for
the
boy
to
call
tears
into
his
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
Hunger
and
recent
ill
-
usage
are
great
assistants
if
you
want
to
cry
;
and
Oliver
cried
very
naturally
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Mann
gave
him
a
thousand
embraces
,
and
what
Oliver
wanted
a
great
deal
more
,
a
piece
of
bread
and
butter
,
less
he
should
seem
too
hungry
when
he
got
to
the
workhouse
.
 
<EOS>
With
the
slice
of
bread
in
his
hand
,
and
the
little
brown
-
cloth
parish
cap
on
his
head
,
Oliver
was
then
led
away
by
Mr
Bumble
from
the
wretched
home
where
one
kind
word
or
look
had
never
lighted
the
gloom
of
his
infant
years
.
 
<EOS>
And
yet
he
burst
into
an
agony
of
childish
grief
,
as
the
cottage
-
gate
closed
after
him
.
 
<EOS>
Wretched
as
were
the
little
companions
in
misery
he
was
leaving
behind
<EOS>
,
they
were
the
only
friends
he
had
ever
known
;
and
a
sense
of
his
loneliness
in
the
great
wide
world
,
sank
into
the
child
's
heart
for
the
first
time
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
walked
on
with
long
strides
;
little
Oliver
,
firmly
grasping
his
gold
-
laced
cuff
,
trotted
beside
him
,
inquiring
at
the
end
of
every
quarter
of
a
mile
whether
they
were
"
nearly
there
.
"
<EOS>
To
these
interrogations
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
returned
very
brief
and
snappish
replies
;
for
the
temporary
blandness
which
gin
-
and
-
water
awakens
in
some
bosoms
had
by
this
time
evaporated
;
and
he
was
once
again
a
beadle
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
had
not
been
within
the
walls
of
the
workhouse
a
quarter
of
an
hour
,
and
had
scarcely
completed
the
demolition
of
a
second
slice
of
bread
,
when
Mr
Bumble
,
who
had
handed
him
over
to
the
care
of
an
old
woman
,
returned
;
and
,
telling
him
it
was
a
board
night
,
informed
him
that
the
board
had
said
he
was
to
appear
before
it
forthwith
.
   
<EOS>
Not
having
a
very
clearly
defined
notion
of
what
a
live
board
was
,
Oliver
was
rather
astounded
by
this
intelligence
,
and
was
not
quite
certain
whether
he
ought
to
laugh
or
cry
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
no
time
to
think
about
the
matter
,
however
;
for
Mr
Bumble
gave
him
a
tap
on
the
head
,
with
his
cane
,
to
wake
him
up
:
and
another
on
the
back
to
make
him
lively
:
 
and
bidding
him
to
follow
,
conducted
him
into
a
large
white
-
washed
room
,
where
eight
or
ten
fat
gentlemen
were
sitting
round
a
table
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
top
of
the
table
,
seated
in
an
arm
-
chair
rather
higher
than
the
rest
,
was
a
particularly
fat
gentleman
with
a
very
round
,
red
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bow
to
the
board
,
"
said
Bumble
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
brushed
away
two
or
three
tears
that
were
lingering
in
his
eyes
;
and
seeing
no
board
but
the
table
,
fortunately
bowed
to
that
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
your
name
,
boy
?
"
said
the
gentleman
in
the
high
chair
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
was
frightened
at
the
sight
of
so
many
gentlemen
,
which
made
him
tremble
:
 
and
the
beadle
gave
him
another
tap
behind
,
which
made
him
cry
.
 
<EOS>
These
two
causes
made
him
answer
in
a
very
low
and
hesitating
voice
;
whereupon
a
gentleman
in
a
white
waistcoat
said
he
was
a
fool
.
 
<EOS>
Which
was
a
capital
way
of
raising
his
spirits
,
and
putting
him
quite
at
his
ease
.
   
<EOS>
"
Boy
,
"
said
the
gentleman
in
the
high
chair
,
"
listen
to
me
.
<EOS>
You
know
you
're
an
orphan
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
that
,
sir
?
"
inquired
poor
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
boy
IS
a
fool
---
I
thought
he
was
,
"
said
the
gentleman
in
the
white
waistcoat
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
gentleman
who
had
spoken
first
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
know
you
've
got
no
father
or
mother
,
and
that
you
were
brought
up
by
the
parish
,
do
n't
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
replied
Oliver
,
weeping
bitterly
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
are
you
crying
for
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
the
gentleman
in
the
white
waistcoat
.
 
<EOS>
And
to
be
sure
it
was
very
extraordinary
.
 
<EOS>
What
COULD
the
boy
be
crying
for
?
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
say
your
prayers
every
night
,
"
said
another
gentleman
in
a
gruff
voice
;
"
and
pray
for
the
people
who
feed
you
,
and
take
care
of
you
---
like
a
Christian
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
stammered
the
boy
.
 
<EOS>
The
gentleman
who
spoke
last
was
unconsciously
right
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
have
been
very
like
a
Christian
,
and
a
marvellously
good
Christian
too
,
if
Oliver
had
prayed
for
the
people
who
fed
and
took
care
of
HIM
.
<EOS>
But
he
had
n't
,
because
nobody
had
taught
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
You
have
come
here
to
be
educated
,
and
taught
a
useful
trade
,
"
said
the
red
-
faced
gentleman
in
the
high
chair
.
   
<EOS>
"
So
you
'll
begin
to
pick
oakum
to
-
morrow
morning
at
six
o'clock
,
"
added
the
surly
one
in
the
white
waistcoat
.
   
<EOS>
For
the
combination
of
both
these
blessings
in
the
one
simple
process
of
picking
oakum
,
Oliver
bowed
low
by
the
direction
of
the
beadle
,
and
was
then
hurried
away
to
a
large
ward
;
where
,
on
a
rough
,
hard
bed
,
he
sobbed
himself
to
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
What
a
novel
illustration
of
the
tender
laws
of
England
!
 
<EOS>
They
let
the
paupers
go
to
sleep
!
   
<EOS>
Poor
Oliver
!
 
<EOS>
He
little
thought
,
as
he
lay
sleeping
in
happy
unconsciousness
of
all
around
him
,
that
the
board
had
that
very
day
arrived
at
a
decision
which
would
exercise
the
most
material
influence
over
all
his
future
fortunes
.
 
<EOS>
But
they
had
.
 
<EOS>
And
this
was
it
:
   
<EOS>
The
members
of
this
board
were
very
sage
,
deep
,
philosophical
men
;
and
when
they
came
to
turn
their
attention
to
the
workhouse
,
they
found
out
at
once
,
what
ordinary
folks
would
nver
have
discovered
---
the
poor
people
liked
it
!
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
regular
place
of
public
entertainment
for
the
poorer
classes
;
a
tavern
where
there
was
nothing
to
pay
;
a
public
breakfast
,
dinner
,
tea
,
and
supper
all
the
year
round
;
a
brick
and
mortar
elysium
,
where
it
was
all
play
and
no
work
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oho
!
"
said
the
board
,
looking
very
knowing
;
"
we
are
the
fellows
to
set
this
to
rights
;
we
'll
stop
it
all
,
in
no
time
.
"
 
<EOS>
So
,
they
established
the
rule
,
that
all
poor
people
should
have
the
alternative
(
for
they
would
compel
nobody
,
not
they
)
,
of
being
starved
by
a
gradual
process
in
the
house
,
or
by
a
quick
one
out
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
With
this
view
,
they
contracted
with
the
water
-
works
to
lay
on
an
unlimited
supply
of
water
;
and
with
a
corn
-
factor
to
supply
periodically
small
quantities
of
oatmeal
;
and
issued
three
meals
of
thin
gruel
a
day
,
with
an
onion
twice
a
week
,
and
half
a
roll
of
Sundays
.
 
<EOS>
They
made
a
great
many
other
wise
and
humane
regulations
,
having
reference
to
the
ladies
,
which
it
is
not
necessary
to
repeat
;
kindly
undertook
to
divorce
poor
married
people
,
in
consequence
of
the
great
expense
of
a
suit
in
Doctors
'
Commons
;
and
,
instead
of
compelling
a
man
to
support
his
family
,
as
they
had
theretofore
done
,
took
his
family
away
from
him
,
and
made
him
a
bachelor
!
 
<EOS>
There
is
no
saying
how
many
applicants
for
relief
,
under
these
last
two
heads
,
might
have
started
up
in
all
classes
of
society
,
if
it
had
not
been
coupled
with
the
workhouse
;
but
the
board
were
long
-
headed
men
,
and
had
provided
for
this
difficulty
.
 
<EOS>
The
relief
was
inseparable
from
the
workhouse
and
the
gruel
;
and
that
frightened
people
.
   
<EOS>
For
the
first
six
months
after
Oliver
Twist
was
removed
,
the
system
was
in
full
operation
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
rather
expensive
at
first
,
in
consequence
of
the
increase
in
the
undertaker
's
bill
,
and
the
necessity
of
taking
in
the
clothes
of
all
the
paupers
,
which
fluttered
loosely
on
their
wasted
,
shrunken
forms
,
after
a
week
or
two
's
gruel
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
number
of
workhouse
inmates
got
thin
as
well
as
the
paupers
;
and
the
board
were
in
ecstasies
.
   
<EOS>
The
room
in
which
the
boys
were
fed
,
was
a
large
stone
hall
,
with
a
copper
at
one
end
:
 
out
of
which
the
master
,
dressed
in
an
apron
for
the
purpose
,
and
assisted
by
one
or
two
women
,
ladled
the
gruel
at
mealtimes
.
 
<EOS>
Of
this
festive
composition
each
boy
had
one
porringer
,
and
no
more
---
except
on
occasions
of
great
public
rejoicing
,
when
he
had
two
ounces
and
a
quarter
of
bread
besides
.
   
<EOS>
The
bowls
never
wanted
washing
.
 
<EOS>
The
boys
polished
them
with
their
spoons
till
they
shone
again
;
and
when
they
had
performed
this
operation
(
which
never
took
very
long
,
the
spoons
being
nearly
as
large
as
the
bowls
)
,
they
would
sit
staring
at
the
copper
,
with
such
eager
eyes
,
as
if
they
could
have
devoured
the
very
bricks
of
which
it
was
composed
;
employing
themselves
,
meanwhile
,
in
sucking
their
fingers
most
assiduously
,
with
the
view
of
catching
up
any
stray
splashes
of
gruel
that
might
have
been
cast
thereon
.
 
<EOS>
Boys
have
generally
excellent
appetites
.
<EOS>
Oliver
Twist
and
his
companions
suffered
the
tortures
of
slow
starvation
for
three
months
:
 
<EOS>
at
last
they
got
so
voracious
and
wild
with
hunger
,
that
one
boy
,
who
was
tall
for
his
age
,
and
had
n't
been
used
to
that
sort
of
thing
(
for
his
father
had
kept
a
small
cook
-
shop
)
,
hinted
darkly
to
his
companions
,
that
unless
he
had
another
basin
of
gruel
per
diem
,
he
was
afraid
he
might
some
night
happen
to
eat
the
boy
who
slept
next
him
,
who
happened
to
be
a
weakly
youth
of
tender
age
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
wild
,
hungry
eye
;
and
they
implicitly
believed
him
.
<EOS>
A
council
was
held
;
lots
were
cast
who
should
walk
up
to
the
master
after
supper
that
evening
,
and
ask
for
more
;
and
it
fell
to
Oliver
Twist
.
   
<EOS>
The
evening
arrived
;
the
boys
took
their
places
.
 
<EOS>
The
master
,
in
his
cook
's
uniform
,
stationed
himself
at
the
copper
;
his
pauper
assistants
ranged
themselves
behind
him
;
the
gruel
was
served
out
;
and
a
long
grace
was
said
over
the
short
commons
.
 
<EOS>
The
gruel
disappeared
;
the
boys
whispered
each
other
,
and
winked
at
Oliver
;
while
his
next
neighbours
nudged
him
.
 
<EOS>
Child
<EOS>
as
he
was
,
he
was
desperate
with
hunger
,
and
reckless
with
misery
.
 
<EOS>
He
rose
from
the
table
;
and
advancing
to
the
master
,
basin
and
spoon
in
hand
,
said
:
 
somewhat
alarmed
at
his
own
temerity
:
   
<EOS>
"
Please
,
sir
,
I
want
some
more
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
master
was
a
fat
,
healthy
man
;
but
he
turned
very
pale
.
<EOS>
He
gazed
in
stupified
astonishment
on
the
small
rebel
for
some
seconds
,
and
then
clung
for
support
to
the
copper
.
 
<EOS>
The
assistants
were
paralysed
with
wonder
;
the
boys
with
fear
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
!
"
said
the
master
at
length
,
in
a
faint
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
Please
,
sir
,
"
replied
Oliver
,
"
I
want
some
more
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
master
aimed
a
blow
at
Oliver
's
head
with
the
ladle
;
pinioned
him
in
his
arm
;
and
shrieked
aloud
for
the
beadle
.
   
<EOS>
The
board
were
sitting
in
solemn
conclave
,
when
Mr
Bumble
rushed
into
the
room
in
great
excitement
,
and
addressing
the
gentleman
in
the
high
chair
,
said
,
   
"
<EOS>
Mr
Limbkins
,
I
beg
your
pardon
,
sir
!
 
<EOS>
Oliver
Twist
has
asked
for
more
!
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
general
start
.
 
<EOS>
Horror
was
depicted
on
every
countenance
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
For
MORE
!
"
said
Mr
Limbkins
.
 
<EOS>
"
Compose
yourself
,
Bumble
,
and
answer
me
distinctly
.
 
<EOS>
Do
I
understand
that
he
asked
for
more
,
after
he
had
eaten
the
supper
allotted
by
the
dietary
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
did
,
sir
,
"
replied
Bumble
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
boy
will
be
hung
,
"
said
the
gentleman
in
the
white
waistcoat
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
that
boy
will
be
hung
.
"
   
<EOS>
Nobody
controverted
the
prophetic
gentleman
's
opinion
.
 
<EOS>
An
animated
discussion
took
place
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
was
ordered
into
instant
confinement
;
and
a
bill
was
next
morning
pasted
on
the
outside
of
the
gate
,
offering
a
reward
of
five
pounds
to
anybody
who
would
take
Oliver
Twist
off
the
hands
of
the
parish
.
 
<EOS>
In
other
words
,
five
pounds
and
Oliver
Twist
were
offered
to
any
man
or
woman
who
wanted
an
apprentice
to
any
trade
,
business
,
or
calling
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
never
was
more
convinced
of
anything
in
my
life
,
"
said
the
gentleman
in
the
white
waistcoat
,
as
he
knocked
at
the
gate
and
read
the
bill
next
morning
:
 
<EOS>
"
I
never
was
more
convinced
of
anything
in
my
life
,
than
I
am
that
that
boy
will
come
to
be
hung
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
I
purpose
to
show
in
the
sequel
whether
the
white
waistcoated
gentleman
was
right
or
not
,
I
should
perhaps
mar
the
interest
of
this
narrative
(
supposing
it
to
possess
any
at
all
)
,
if
I
ventured
to
hint
just
yet
,
whether
the
life
of
Oliver
Twist
had
this
violent
termination
or
no
.
    
Chapter
3
.
<EOS>
Relates
how
Oliver
Twist
was
very
near
getting
a
place
which
Would
not
have
been
a
sinecure
.
 
<EOS>
For
a
week
after
the
commission
of
the
impious
and
profane
offence
of
asking
for
more
,
Oliver
remained
a
close
prisoner
in
the
dark
and
solitary
room
to
which
he
had
been
consigned
by
the
wisdom
and
mercy
of
the
board
.
 
<EOS>
It
appears
,
at
first
sight
not
unreasonable
to
suppose
,
that
,
if
he
had
entertained
a
becoming
feeling
of
respect
for
the
prediction
of
the
gentleman
in
the
white
waistcoat
,
he
would
have
established
that
sage
individual
's
prophetic
character
,
once
and
for
ever
,
by
tying
one
end
of
his
pocket
-
handkerchief
to
a
hook
in
the
wall
,
and
attaching
himself
to
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
To
the
performance
of
this
feat
,
however
,
there
was
one
obstacle
:
 
<EOS>
namely
,
that
pocket
-
handkerchiefs
being
decided
articles
of
luxury
,
had
been
,
for
all
future
times
and
ages
,
removed
from
the
noses
of
paupers
by
the
express
order
of
the
board
,
in
council
assembled
:
 
solemnly
given
and
pronounced
under
their
hands
and
seals
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
still
greater
obstacle
in
Oliver
's
youth
and
childishness
.
 
<EOS>
He
only
cried
bitterly
all
day
;
and
,
when
the
long
,
dismal
night
came
on
,
spread
his
little
hands
before
his
eyes
to
shut
out
the
darkness
,
and
crouching
in
the
corner
,
tried
to
sleep
:
 
ever
and
anon
waking
with
a
start
and
tremble
,
and
drawing
himself
closer
and
closer
to
the
wall
,
as
if
to
feel
even
its
cold
hard
surface
were
a
protection
in
the
gloom
and
loneliness
which
surrounded
him
.
   
<EOS>
Let
it
not
be
supposed
by
the
enemies
of
"
the
system
,
"
that
,
during
the
period
of
his
solitary
incarceration
,
Oliver
was
denied
the
benefit
of
exercise
,
the
pleasure
of
society
,
or
the
advantages
of
religious
consolation
.
 
<EOS>
As
for
exercise
,
it
was
nice
cold
weather
,
and
he
was
allowed
to
perform
his
ablutions
every
morning
under
the
pump
,
in
a
stone
yard
,
in
the
presence
of
Mr
Bumble
,
who
prevented
his
catching
cold
,
and
caused
a
tingling
sensation
to
pervade
his
frame
,
by
repeated
applications
of
the
cane
.
 
<EOS>
As
for
society
,
he
was
carried
every
other
day
into
the
hall
where
the
boys
dined
,
and
there
sociably
flogged
as
a
public
warning
and
example
.
 
<EOS>
And
so
for
from
being
denied
the
advantages
of
religious
consolation
,
he
was
kicked
into
the
same
apartment
every
evening
at
prayer
-
time
,
and
there
permitted
to
listen
to
,
and
console
his
mind
with
,
a
general
supplication
of
the
boys
,
containing
a
special
clause
,
therein
inserted
by
authority
of
the
board
,
in
which
they
entreated
to
be
made
good
,
virtuous
,
contented
,
and
obedient
,
and
to
be
guarded
from
the
sins
and
vices
of
Oliver
Twist
:
 
whom
the
supplication
distinctly
set
forth
to
be
under
the
exclusive
patronage
and
protection
of
the
powers
of
wickedness
,
and
an
article
direct
from
the
manufactory
of
the
very
Devil
himself
.
   
<EOS>
It
chanced
one
morning
,
while
Oliver
's
affairs
were
in
this
auspicious
and
confortable
state
,
that
Mr
Gamfield
,
chimney
-
sweep
,
went
his
way
down
the
High
Street
,
deeply
cogitating
in
his
mind
his
ways
and
means
of
paying
certain
arrears
of
rent
,
for
which
his
landlord
had
become
rather
pressing
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Gamfield
's
most
sanguine
estimate
of
his
finances
could
not
raise
them
within
full
five
pounds
of
the
desired
amount
;
and
,
in
a
species
of
arthimetical
desperation
,
he
was
alternately
cudgelling
his
brains
and
his
donkey
,
when
passing
the
workhouse
,
his
eyes
encountered
the
bill
on
the
gate
.
   
<EOS>
"
Wo
---
o
!
"
said
Mr
Gamfield
to
the
donkey
.
   
<EOS>
The
donkey
was
in
a
state
of
profound
abstraction
:
 
wondering
,
probably
,
whether
he
was
destined
to
be
regaled
with
a
cabbage
-
stalk
or
two
when
he
had
disposed
of
the
two
sacks
of
soot
with
which
the
little
cart
was
laden
;
so
,
without
noticing
the
word
of
command
,
he
jogged
onward
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Gamfield
growled
a
fierce
imprecation
on
the
donkey
generally
,
but
more
particularly
on
his
eyes
;
and
,
running
after
him
,
bestowed
a
blow
on
his
head
,
which
would
inevitably
have
beaten
in
any
skull
but
a
donkey
's
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
catching
hold
of
the
bridle
,
he
gave
his
jaw
a
sharp
wrench
,
by
way
of
gentle
reminder
that
he
was
not
his
own
master
;
and
by
these
means
turned
him
round
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
gave
him
another
blow
on
the
head
,
just
to
stun
him
till
he
came
back
again
.
 
<EOS>
Having
completed
these
arrangements
,
he
walked
up
to
the
gate
,
to
read
the
bill
.
   
<EOS>
The
gentleman
with
the
white
waistcoat
was
standing
at
the
gate
with
his
hands
behind
him
,
after
having
delivered
himself
of
some
profound
sentiments
in
the
board
-
room
.
 
<EOS>
Having
witnessed
the
little
dispute
between
Mr
Gamfield
and
the
donkey
,
he
smiled
joyously
when
that
person
came
up
to
read
the
bill
,
for
he
saw
at
once
that
Mr
Gamfield
was
exactly
the
sort
of
master
Oliver
Twist
wanted
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Gamfield
smiled
,
too
,
as
he
perused
the
document
;
for
five
pounds
was
just
the
sum
he
had
been
wishing
for
;
and
,
as
to
the
boy
with
which
it
was
encumbered
,
Mr
Gamfield
,
knowing
what
the
dietary
of
the
workhouse
was
<EOS>
,
well
knew
he
would
be
a
nice
small
pattern
,
just
the
very
thing
for
register
stoves
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
he
spelt
the
bill
through
again
,
from
beginning
to
end
;
and
then
,
touching
his
fur
cap
in
token
of
humility
,
accosted
the
gentleman
in
the
white
waistcoat
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
This
here
boy
,
sir
,
wot
the
parish
wants
to
'
prentis
,
"
said
Mr
Gamfield
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
my
man
,
"
said
the
gentleman
in
the
white
waistcoat
,
with
a

.
 
<EOS>
"
What
of
him
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
the
parish
vould
like

to
learn
a
right
pleasant
trade
,
in
a
good
'
spectable
chimbley
-
sweepin
'
bisness
,
"
said

Gamfield
,
"
I
wants
a
'
prentis
,
and
I

ready
to

him
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Walk
in
,
"
said
the
gentleman
in
the
white
waistcoat
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Gamfield
having
lingered
behind
,
to
give
the
donkey
another
blow
on
the
head
,
and
another
wrench
of
the
jaw
,
as
a
caution
not
to
run
away
in

absence
,
followed
the
gentleman
with
the
white
waistcoat
into
the
room
where
Oliver
had
first
seen

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
nasty
trade
,
"
said
Mr
Limbkins
,
when
Gamfield
had
again
stated

.
   
<EOS>
"
Young
boys
have
been
smothered
in
chimneys
before
now
,
"
said
another

.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
acause
they
damped
the
straw
afore
<EOS>
they
lit
it
in
the
chimbley
to
make
'em

down

,
"
said

;
"
that
's
all
smoke
,
and
no
blaze
;
vereas
smoke
ai
n't
o
'
no
use
at
all
in
making
a
boy
come
down
,
for
it
only
sinds
him
to
sleep
,
and
that
's
wot
<EOS>
he

.
 
<EOS>
Boys
is
wery
obstinit
,
and
wery
lazy
,
Gen'l'men
,
and
<EOS>
there
's
nothink
like
a
good
hot
blaze
to
make
'em
come
down
vith

.
 
<EOS>
It
's
humane
too
,
gen'l'men
,
acause
,
even
if
they
've
stuck
in
the
chimbley
,
roasting
their
feet
makes
'em
struggle
to
hextricate
theirselves
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
gentleman
in
the
white
waistcoat
appeared
very
much
amused
by
this
explanation
;
but
his
mirth
was
speedily
checked
by
a
look
from
Mr
Limbkins
.
 
<EOS>
The
board
then
procedded
to
converse
among
themselves
for
a
few
minutes
,
but
in
so
low
a
tone
,
that
the
words
"
saving
of
expenditure
,
"
"
looked
well
in

,
"
"
have

printed
report
published
,
"
were
alone
audible
.
 
<EOS>
These
only
chanced
to
be
heard
,
indeed
,
or
account
of
their
being
very
frequently
repeated
with
great
emphasis
.
   
<EOS>
At
length
the

ceased
;
and
the

of
the
board
,
having
resumed
their
seats
and

,
Mr
Limbkins
said
:
   
"
We
have
considered
your
proposition
,
and
we
do
n't
approve
of
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
at
all
,
"
said
the
gentleman
in
the
white
waistcoat
.
   
<EOS>
"
Decidedly
not
,
"
added
the
other
members
.
   
<EOS>
As
Mr
Gamfield
did
happen
to
labour
under
the
slight
imputation
of
having
bruised
three
or
four
boys
to
death
already
,
it
occurred
to
him
that
the
board
had
,
perhaps
,
in
some
unaccountable
freak
,
taken
it
into
their
heads
that
this
extraneous
circumstance
ought
to
influence
their
proceedings
.
<EOS>
It
was
very
unlike
their
general
mode
of
doing
business
,
if
they
had
;
but
still
,
as
he
had
no
particular

to
revive
the
rumour
,
he
twisted
his
cap
in
his
hands
,
and
walked
slowly
from

.
   
<EOS>
"
So
you
wo
n't
let
me
have
him
,
gen'l'men
?
"
said
Mr
Gamfield
,
pausing
near
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
Mr
Limbkins
;
"
at
least
,
as
it
's
a
nasty
business
,
we
think
you
ought
to
take
something
less
than
the
premium
we

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Gamfield
's

brightened
,
as
,
with

,
he
returned
to
the

,
and

,
   
"
What
'll

,
gen'l'men
?
 
<EOS>
Come
!
 
<EOS>
Do
n't

too
hard

.
 
<EOS>
What
'll

give
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
say
,
three
pound
ten
was

,
"
said
Mr
Limbkins
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ten
shillings
too

,
"
said
the

in
the
white

.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
!
"
<EOS>
said
Gamfield
;
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
Say

,

.
 
<EOS>
There
!
"
   
"
Three
pound
ten
,
"

Limbkins
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
!
 
<EOS>
I
'll
split

diff'erence
,
gen'l'men
,
urged
Gamfield
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Three

fifteen
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not

farthing
more
,
"
was
the
firm

of
Mr
Limbkins
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
desperate
hard
upon
me
,
gen'l'men
,
said
Gamfield
,
wavering
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pooh
!
 
<EOS>
pooh
!
 
<EOS>
nonsense
!
<EOS>
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
'd

cheap

,

.
<EOS>
Take

,

!
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

<EOS>
and

:
 
it

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
Ha
!
 
<EOS>
ha
!
 
<EOS>
ha
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Gamfield
gave
an
arch
look
at
the
faces
round
the
table
,
and
,
observing
a
smile
on
all

,
gradually
broke
into
a
smile
himself
.
 
<EOS>
The
bargain
was
made
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
,
was
at
once
instructed
that
Oliver
Twist
and
his
indentures
were
to
be
conveyed
before
the
magistrate
,
for

,
that

.
   
<EOS>
In

of
this
determination
,
little
Oliver
,
to
his

,
was
released
from

,
and
ordered
to
put
himself
into
a
clean

.
 
<EOS>
He
had
hardly
achieved
this
very
unusual

,
when
Mr
Bumble
brought

,
with

,
a
basin
of
gruel
,
and
the
holiday
allowance
of
two
ounces
and
a
quarter

.
<EOS>
At
this
tremendous
sight
,
Oliver
began
to
cry
very
piteously
:
 
thinking
,
not
unnaturally
,
that
the
board
must
have
determined

kill
him
for
some

,
or
they
never
would

.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
make

red
,
Oliver
,
but
eat

and
be

,
"
said
Mr
Bumble
,
in

.
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
going
to
be
made
a
'
prentice
of
,
Oliver
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
prentice
,
sir
!
<EOS>
"
said

child
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Oliver
,
"

Mr
Bumble
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
kind

which
is
so
amny
parents

,
Oliver
,
when
you

none

:
 
are
a
going
to
'

:
 
and
to

,
and

man

:
 
although

three
pound

!
<EOS>
---
three
pound
ten
,
Oliver
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
seventy
shillins
---
one
hundred
and
forty
sixpences
!
<EOS>
---
and
all
for
a
naughty
orphan
which
noboday
ca
n't
love
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
Mr
Bumble
paused
to
take

,
after
delivering
this
address
in
an
awful

,
the
tears
rolled
down
the
poor
child
's

,
and
he
sobbed

.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,
"
said
Mr
Bumble
,
somewhat
less

,
for
it
was
gratifying

his

to
observe
the
effect
his
eloquence
had
produced
;
"
Come
,
Oliver
!
 
<EOS>
Wipe
your

with

,
and
do
n't
cry
into
your
gruel
<EOS>
;
that
's
a
very
foolish
action
,
Oliver
.
"
 
<EOS>
It
certainly
was
,
for
there
was
quite
enough
water
in
it
already
.
   
<EOS>
On
their

to
the
magistrate
,
Mr
Bumble
instructed

that
all

to

,

,
and
say
,
when

,
that
he

like
it
very
much

;
both

which

Oliver
promised
to
obey
:
 
the
rather
as
Mr

threw
in

,
that
if
he
failed
in
either

,
there

no
telling
what
would

.
<EOS>
When

arrived
at
the
office
,
he
was

a
little
room
by
himself
,
and
admonished

Mr
Bumble
to

,
until
he

to

.
   
<EOS>
There
the
boy
remained
,
with

,
for
half

hour
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
expiration
of
which

Mr
Bumble
thrust
in
his

,
unadorned
with
the
cocked

,
and
said

:
   
"
Now
,
Oliver
,
my
dear
,
come
to
the
gentleman
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
Mr
Bumble
said

,
he
put

a
grim
and

,
and
added
,
in
a
low

,
"
<EOS>
Mind
<EOS>
what
I
told
you
,
you
young
rascal
!
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver
stared
innocently
in
Mr
Bumble
's
face
at
this
somewhat
contradictory
style
of
address
;
but
that

prevented

any
remark
thereupon
,
by
leading
him
at
once
into
an
adjoining
room
:
 
the
door
of
which
was
open
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
large
room
,
with
a
great
window
.
 
<EOS>
Behind
a
desk
,
sat
two
old
gentleman
with
powdered
heads
:
 
one
of
whom
was
reading
the
newspaper
;
while
the
other
was
perusing
,
with
the
aid
of
a
pair
of
tortoise
-
shell
spectacles
,
a
small
piece
of
parchment
which
lay
before
him
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Limbkins
was
standing
in
front
of
the
desk
on
one
side
;
and
Mr
Gamfield
,
with
a
partially
washed
face
,
on
the
other
;
while
two
or
three
bluff
-
looking
men
,
in
top
-

,

about
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
gentleman
with
the
spectacles
gradually
dozed
off
,
over
the
little
bit
of
parchment
;
and
there
was
a
short
pause
,
after
Oliver
had
been
stationed
by
Mr
Bumble
in
front
of
the
desk
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
the
boy
,
your
worship
,
"
said
Mr
Bumble
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
gentleman
who
was
reading
the
newspaper
raised
his
head
for
a
moment
,
and
pulled
the
other
old
gentleman
by

;
whereupon
,
the
last
-
mentioned
old
gentleman
woke
up
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
is
this
the
boy
?
"
said

old

.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
him
,

,
"
replied
Mr
Bumble
.
 
<EOS>
"
Bow
to
the
magistrate
,
my
dear
.
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver
roused
himself
,
and
made
his
best

.
 
<EOS>
He
had
been
wondering
,
with
his

fixed
on
the

'
powder
,
whether
all
boards
were
born
with
that
white
stuff
on

,
and
were
boards
from
thenceforth

that

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
"
said

old

,
"
I

's
fond
of
chimney
-

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
doats
on
it
,
your
worship
,
"
replied
Bumble
;
giving
Oliver
a
sly

,
to

that
he
had
better
not
say

did
n't
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
he
WILL
be
a
sweep
,

?
"
inquired

.
   
<EOS>
"
If

-

,

'd

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
this
man

's

---
you
,

---

,
