,
will
you
?
"
said
the
old
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
I
says
I
will
,
I
means
I
will
,
"
replied
Mr
Gamfield
doggedly
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
rough
speaker
,
my
friend
,
but
you
look
an
honest
,
open
-
hearted
man
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
:
 
turning
his
spectacles
in
the
direction
of
the
candidate
for
Oliver
's
premium
,
<EOS>
whose
villainous
countenance
was
a
regular
stamped
receipt
for
cruelty
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
magistrate
was
half
blind
and
half
childish
,
so
he
could
n't
reasonably
be
expected
to
discern
what
other
people
did
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
I
am
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Gamfield
,
with
an
ugly
leer
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
doubt
you
are
,
my
friend
,
"
replied
the
old
gentleman
:
fixing
his
spectacles
more
firmly
on
his
nose
,
and
looking
about
him
for
the
inkstand
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
the
critical
moment
of
Oliver
's
fate
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
inkstand
had
been
where
the
old
gentleman
though
it
was
,
he
would
have
dipped
his
pen
into
it
,
and
signed
the
indentures
,
and
Oliver
would
have
been
straightway
hurried
off
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
as
it
chanced
to
be
immediately
under
his
nose
,
it
followed
,
as
a
matter
of
course
,
that
he
looked
all
over
his
desk
for
it
,
without
finding
it
;
and
happening
in
the
course
of
his
search
to
look
straight
before
him
,
his
gaze
encountered
the
pale
and
terrified
face
of
Oliver
Twist
:
 
<EOS>
who
,
despite
all
the
admonitory
looks
and
pinches
of
Bumble
,
was
regarding
the
repulsive
countenance
of
his
future
master
,
with
a
mingled
expression
of
horror
and
fear
,
too
palpable
to
be
mistaken
,
even
by
a
half
-
blind
magistrate
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
gentleman
stopped
,
laid
down
his
pen
,
and
looked
from
Oliver
to
Mr
Limbkins
;
who
attempted
to
take
snuff
with
a
cheerful
and
unconcerned
aspect
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
boy
!
"
said
the
old
gentleman
,
"
you
look
pale
and
alarmed
.
<EOS>
What
is
the
matter
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Stand
a
little
away
from
him
,
Beadle
,
"
said
the
other
magistrate
:
 
laying
aside
the
paper
,
and
leaning
forward
with
an
expression
of
interest
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,
boy
,
tell
us
what
's
the
matter
:
do
n't
be
afraid
.
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver
fell
on
his
knees
,
and
clasping
his
hands
together
,
prayed
that
they
would
order
him
back
to
the
dark
room
---
 
that
they
would
starve
him
---
beat
him
---
kill
him
if
they
pleased
---
rather
than
send
him
away
with
that
dreadful
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
said
Mr
Bumble
,
raising
his
hands
and
eyes
with
most
impressive
solemnite
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
!
of
all
the
artful
and
designing
orphans
that
ever
I
see
,
Oliver
,
you
are
one
of
the
most
bare
-
facedest
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hold
your
tongue
,
Beadle
,
"
said
the
second
old
gentleman
,
when
Mr
Bumble
had
given
vent
to
this
compound
adjective
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
worship
's
pardon
,
"
said
Mr
Bumble
,
incredulous
of
having
heard
aright
.
 
<EOS>
"
Did
your
worship
speak
to
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
Hold
your
tongue
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
was
stupefied
with
astonishment
.
 
<EOS>
A
beadle
ordered
to
hold
his
tongue
!
 
<EOS>
A
moral
revolution
!
   
<EOS>
The
old
gentleman
in
the
tortoise
-
shell
spectacles
looked
at
his
companion
,
he
nodded
significantly
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
refuse
to
sanction
these
indentures
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
:
   
tossing
aside
the
piece
of
parchment
as
he
spoke
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
,
"
stammered
Mr
Limbkins
:
 
"
I
hope
the
magistrates
will
not
form
the
opinion
that
the
authorities
have
been
guilty
of
any
improper
conduct
,
on
the
unsupported
testimony
of
a
child
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
magistrates
are
not
called
upon
to
pronounce
any
opinion
on
the
matter
,
"
said
the
second
old
gentleman
sharply
.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
the
boy
back
to
the
workhouse
,
and
treat
him
kindly
.
 
<EOS>
He
seems
to
want
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
That
same
evening
,
the
gentleman
in
the
white
waistcoat
most
positively
and
decidedly
affirmed
,
not
only
that
Oliver
would
be
hung
,
but
that
he
would
be
drawn
and
quartered
into
the
bargain
.
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
shook
his
head
with
gloomy
mystery
,
and
said
he
wished
he
might
come
to
good
;
whereunto
Mr
Gamfield
replied
,
that
he
wished
he
might
come
to
him
;
which
,
although
he
agreed
with
the
beadle
in
most
matters
,
would
seem
to
be
a
wish
of
a
totally
opposite
description
.
   
<EOS>
The
next
morning
,
the
public
were
once
informed
that
Oliver
Twist
was
again
To
Let
,
and
that
five
pounds
would
be
paid
to
anybody
who
would
take
possession
of
him
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
4
.
<EOS>
Oliver
,
being
offered
another
place
,
makes
his
first
entry
into
public
life
.
 
<EOS>
In
great
families
,
when
an
advantageous
place
can
not
be
obtained
,
either
in
possession
,
reversion
,
remainder
,
or
expectancy
,
for
the
young
man
who
is
growing
up
,
it
is
a
very
general
custom
to
send
him
to
sea
.
 
<EOS>
The
board
,
in
imitation
of
so
wise
and
salutary
an
example
,
took
counsel
together
on
the
expediency
of
shipping
off
Oliver
Twist
,
in
some
small
trading
vessel
bound
to
a
good
unhealthy
port
.
 
<EOS>
This
suggested
itself
as
the
very
best
thing
that
could
possibly
be
done
with
him
:
the
probability
being
,
that
the
skipper
would
flog
him
to
death
,
in
a
playful
mood
,
some
day
after
dinner
,
or
would
knock
his
brains
out
with
an
iron
bar
;
both
pastimes
being
,
as
is
pretty
generally
known
,
very
favourite
and
common
recreations
among
gentleman
of
that
class
.
 
<EOS>
The
more
the
case
presented
itself
to
the
board
,
in
this
point
of
view
,
the
more
manifold
the
advantages
of
the
step
appeared
;
so
,
they
came
to
the
conclusion
that
the
only
way
of
providing
for
Oliver
effectually
,
was
to
send
him
to
sea
without
delay
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
had
been
despatched
to
make
various
preliminary
inquiries
,
with
the
view
of
finding
out
some
captain
or
other
who
wanted
a
cabin
-
boy
without
any
friends
;
and
was
returning
to
the
workhouse
to
communicate
the
result
of
his
mission
;
when
he
encountered
at
the
gate
,
no
less
a
person
than
Mr
Sowerberry
,
the
parochial
undertaker
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Sowerberry
was
a
tall
gaunt
,
large
-
jointed
man
,
attired
in
a
suit
of
threadbare
black
,
with
darned
cotton
stockings
of
the
same
colour
,
and
shoes
to
answer
.
 
<EOS>
His
features
were
not
naturally
intended
to
wear
a
smiling
aspect
,
but
he
was
in
general
rather
given
to
professional
jocosity
.
 
<EOS>
His
step
was
elastic
,
and
his
face
betokened
inward
pleasantry
,
as
he
advanced
to
Mr
Bumble
,
and
shook
him
cordially
by
the
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
taken
the
measure
of
the
two
women
that
died
last
night
,
Mr
Bumble
,
"
said
the
undertaker
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
'll
make
your
fortune
,
Mr
Sowerberry
,
"
said
the
beadle
,
as
he
thrust
his
thumb
and
forefinger
into
the
proferred
snuff
-
box
of
the
undertaker
:
 
which
was
an
ingenious
little
model
of
a
patent
coffin
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
say
you
'll
make
your
fortune
,
Mr
Sowerberry
,
"
repeated
Mr
Bumble
,
tapping
the
undertaker
on
the
shoulder
,
in
a
friendly
manner
,
with
his
cane
.
   
<EOS>
"
Think
so
?
<EOS>
"
said
the
undertaker
in
a
tone
which
half
admitted
and
half
disputed
the
probability
of
the
event
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
prices
allowed
by
the
board
are
very
small
,
Mr
Bumble
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
are
the
coffins
,
"
replied
the
beadle
:
 
with
precisely
as
near
an
approach
to
a
laugh
as
a
great
official
ought
to
indulge
in
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Sowerberry
was
much
tickled
at
this
:
 
as
of
course
he
ought
to
be
;
and
laughed
a
long
time
without
cessation
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
Mr
Bumble
,
"
he
said
at
length
,
"
there
's
no
denying
that
,
since
the
new
system
of
feeding
has
come
in
,
the
coffins
are
something
narrower
and
more
shallow
than
they
used
to
be
;
but
we
must
have
some
profit
,
Mr
Bumble
.
 
<EOS>
Well
-
seasoned
timber
is
an
expensive
article
,
sir
;
and
all
the
iron
handles
come
,
by
canal
,
from
Birmingham
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
"
said
Mr
Bumble
,
"
<EOS>
every
trade
has
its
drawbacks
.
<EOS>
A
fair
profit
is
,
of
course
,
allowable
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
,
of
course
,
"
replied
the
undertaker
;
"
and
if
I
do
n't
get
a
profit
upon
this
or
that
particular
article
,
why
,
I
make
it
up
in
the
long
-
run
,
you
see
---
he
!
<EOS>
he
!
<EOS>
he
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Just
so
,
"
said
Mr
Bumble
.
   
<EOS>
"
Though
I
must
say
,
"
continued
the
undertaker
,
resuming
the
current
of
observations
which
the
beadle
had
interrupted
:
"
though
I
must
say
,
Mr
Bumble
,
that
I
have
to
contend
against
one
very
great
disadvantage
:
 
which
is
,
that
all
the
stout
people
go
off
the
quickest
.
 
<EOS>
The
people
who
have
been
better
off
,
and
have
paid
rates
for
many
years
,
are
the
first
to
sink
when
they
come
into
the
house
;
and
let
me
tell
you
,
Mr
Bumble
,
that
three
or
four
inches
over
one
's
calculation
makes
a
great
hole
in
one
's
profits
:
especially
when
one
has
a
family
to
provide
for
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
Mr
Sowerberry
said
this
,
with
the
becoming
indignation
of
an
ill
-
used
man
;
and
as
Mr
Bumble
felt
that
it
rather
tended
to
convey
a
reflection
on
the
honour
of
the
parish
;
the
latter
gentleman
thought
it
advisable
to
change
the
subject
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
Twist
being
uppermost
in
his
mind
,
he
made
him
his
theme
.
   
<EOS>
"
By
the
bye
,
"
said
Mr
Bumble
,
"
you
do
n't
know
anybody
who
wants
a
boy
,
do
you
?
 
<EOS>
A
porochial
'
prentis
,
who
is
at
present
a
dead
-
weight
;
a
millstone
,
as
I
may
say
,
round
the
porochial
throat
?
 
<EOS>
Liberal
terms
,
Mr
Sowerberry
,
liberal
terms
?
"
 
<EOS>
As
Mr
Bumble
spoke
,
he
raised
his
cane
to
the
bill
above
him
,
and
gave
three
distinct
raps
upon
the
words
"
five
pounds
"
:
 
which
were
printed
thereon
in
Roman
capitals
of
gigantic
size
.
   
<EOS>
"
Gadso
!
"
said
the
undertaker
:
 
taking
Mr
Bumble
by
the
gilt
-
edged
lappel
of
his
official
coat
;
"
that
's
just
the
very
thing
I
wanted
to
speak
to
you
about
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
---
<EOS>
dear
me
,
what
a
very
elegant
button
this
is
,
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
!
 
<EOS>
I
never
noticed
it
before
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
think
it
rather
pretty
,
"
said
the
beadle
,
glancing
proudly
downwards
at
the
large
brass
buttons
which
embellished
his
coat
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
die
is
the
same
as
the
porochial
seal
---
<EOS>
the
Good
Samaritan
healing
the
sick
and
bruised
man
.
<EOS>
The
board
presented
it
to
me
on
Newyear
's
morning
,
Mr
Sowerberry
.
 
<EOS>
I
put
it
on
<EOS>
,
I
remember
,
for
the
first
time
,
to
attend
the
inquest
on
that
reduced
tradesman
,
who
died
in
a
doorway
at
midnight
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
recollect
,
"
said
the
undertaker
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
jury
brought
it
in
,
"
Died
from
exposure
to
the
cold
,
and
want
of
the
common
necessaries
of
life
,
"
did
n't
they
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
nodded
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
they
made
it
a
special
verdict
<EOS>
,
I
think
,
"
said
the
undertaker
,
"
by
adding
some
words
to
the
effect
,
<EOS>
that
if
the
relieving
officer
had
---
"
   
"
Tush
!
 
Foolery
!
"
interposed
the
beadle
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
the
board
attended
to
all
the
nonsense
that
ignorant
jurymen
talk
,
they
'd
have
enough
to
do
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
true
,
"
said
the
undertaker
;
"
they
would
indeed
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Juries
,
"
said
Mr
Bumble
,
grasping
his
cane
tightly
,
as
was
his
wo
nt
when
working
into
a
passion
:
 
<EOS>
"
juries
is
ineddicated
,
vulgar
,
grovelling
wretches
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
they
are
,
"
said
the
undertaker
.
   
<EOS>
"
They
have
n't
no
more
philosophy
nor
political
economy
about
'em
than
that
,
"
said
the
beadle
,
snapping
his
fingers
contemptuously
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
more
they
have
,
"
acquiesced
the
undertaker
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
despise
'
em
,
"
said
the
beadle
,
growing
very
red
in
the
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
So
do
I
,
"
rejoined
the
undertaker
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
only
wish
we
'd
a
jury
of
the
independent
sort
,
in
the
house
for
a
week
or
two
,
"
said
the
beadle
;
"
the
rules
and
regulations
of
the
board
would
soon
bring
their
spirit
down
for
'
em
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Let
'em
alone
for
that
,
"
replied
the
undertaker
.
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
smiled
,
approvingly
:
 
to
calm
the
rising
wrath
of
the
indignant
parish
officer
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
lifted
off
his
cocked
hat
;
took
a
handkerchief
from
the
inside
of
the
crown
;
wiped
from
his
forehead
the
perspiration
which
his
rage
had
engendered
;
fixed
the
cocked
hat
on
again
;
and
,
turning
to
the
undertaker
,
said
in
a
calmer
voice
:
   
"
<EOS>
Well
;
what
about
the
boy
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
replied
the
undertaker
;
why
,
you
know
,
Mr
Bumble
,
I
pay
a
good
deal
towards
the
poor
's
rates
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hem
!
"
said
Mr
Bumble
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
replied
the
undertaker
,
"
I
was
thinking
that
if
I
pay
so
much
towards
'em
,
I
've
a
right
to
get
as
much
out
of
'em
as
I
can
,
Mr
Bumble
;
and
so
<EOS>
---
I
think
I
'll
take
the
boy
myself
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
grasped
the
undertaker
by
the
arm
,
and
led
him
into
the
building
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Sowerberry
was
closeted
with
the
board
for
five
minutes
;
and
it
was
arranged
that
Oliver
should
go
to
him
that
evening
"
upon
liking
"
---
a
phrase
which
means
,
in
the
case
of
a
parish
apprentice
,
that
if
the
master
find
,
upon
a
short
trial
,
that
he
can
get
enough
work
out
of
a
boy
without
putting
too
much
food
into
him
,
he
shall
have
him
for
a
term
of
years
,
to
do
what
he
likes
with
.
   
<EOS>
When
little
Oliver
was
taken
before
"
the
gentlemen
"
that
evening
;
and
informed
that
he
was
to
go
,
that
night
,
as
general
house
-
lad
to
a
coffin
-
maker
's
;
and
that
if
he
complained
of
his
situation
,
or
ever
came
back
to
the
parish
again
,
he
would
be
sent
to
sea
,
there
to
be
drowned
,
or
knocked
on
the
head
,
as
the
case
might
be
,
he
evinced
so
little
emotion
,
that
they
by
common
consent
pronounced
him
a
hardened
young
rascal
,
and
orered
Mr
Bumble
to
remove
him
forthwith
.
   
<EOS>
Now
,
although
it
was
very
natural
that
the
board
,
of
all
people
in
the
world
,
should
feel
in
a
great
state
of
virtuous
astonishment
and
horror
at
the
smallest
tokens
of
want
of
feeling
on
the
part
of
anybody
,
they
were
rather
out
,
in
this
particular
instance
.
 
<EOS>
The
simple
fact
was
,
that
Oliver
,
instead
of
possessing
too
little
feeling
,
possessed
rather
too
much
;
and
was
in
a
fair
way
of
being
reduced
,
for
life
,
to
a
state
of
brutal
stupidity
and
sullenness
by
the
ill
usage
he
had
received
.
 
<EOS>
He
heard
the
news
of
his
destination
,
in
perfect
silence
;
and
,
having
had
his
luggage
put
into
his
hand
---
which
was
not
very
difficult
to
carry
,
inasmuch
as
it
was
all
comprised
within
the
limits
of
a
brown
paper
parcel
,
about
half
a
foot
square
by
three
inches
deep
---
he
pulled
his
cap
over
his
eyes
;
and
once
more
attaching
himself
to
Mr
Bumble
's
coat
cuff
,
was
led
away
by
that
dignitary
to
a
new
scene
of
suffering
.
   
<EOS>
For
some
time
,
Mr
Bumble
drew
Oliver
along
,
without
notice
or
remark
;
for
the
beadle
carried
his
head
very
erect
,
as
a
beadle
always
should
:
 
and
,
it
being
a
windy
day
,
little
Oliver
was
completely
enshrouded
by
the
skirts
of
Mr
Bumble
's
coat
as
they
blew
open
,
and
disclosed
to
great
advantage
his
flapped
waistcoat
and
drab
plush
knee
-
breeches
.
 
<EOS>
As
they
drew
near
to
their
destination
,
however
,
Mr
Bumble
thought
it
expedient
to
look
down
,
and
see
that
the
boy
was
in
good
order
for
inspection
by
his
new
master
:
 
which
he
accordingly
did
,
with
a
fit
and
becoming
air
of
gracious
patronage
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oliver
!
"
 
<EOS>
said
Mr
Bumble
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
replied
Oliver
,
in
a
low
,
tremulous
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pull
that
cap
off
your
eyes
,
and
hold
up
your
head
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
Although
Oliver
did
as
he
was
desired
,
at
once
;
and
passed
the
back
of
his
unoccupied
hand
briskly
across
his
eyes
,
he
left
a
tear
in
them
when
he
looked
up
at
his
conductor
.
 
<EOS>
As
Mr
Bumble
gazed
sternly
upon
him
,
it
rolled
down
his
cheek
.
<EOS>
It
was
followed
by
another
,
and
another
.
 
<EOS>
The
child
made
a
strong
effort
,
but
it
was
an
unsuccessful
one
.
 
<EOS>
Withdrawing
his
other
hand
from
Mr
Bumble
's
he
covered
his
face
with
both
;
and
wept
until
the
tears
sprung
out
from
between
his
chin
and
bony
fingers
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
exclaimed
Mr
Bumble
,
stopping
short
,
and
darting
at
his
little
charge
a
look
of
intense
malignity
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
 
Of
ALL
the
ungratefullest
,
and
worst
-
disposed
boys
as
ever
<EOS>
I
see
,
Oliver
,
you
are
the
---
"
   
"
No
,
no
,
sir
,
"
sobbed
Oliver
,
<EOS>
clinging
to
the
hand
which
held
the
well
-
known
cane
;
"
no
,
no
,
sir
;
I
will
be
good
indeed
;
indeed
,
indeed
I
will
,
sir
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
a
very
little
boy
,
sir
;
and
it
is
so
---
<EOS>
so
---
"
   
"
So
what
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Bumble
in
amazement
.
   
<EOS>
"
So
lonely
,
sir
!
 
<EOS>
So
very
lonely
!
"
cried
the
child
.
 
<EOS>
"
Everybody
hates
me
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
sir
,
do
n't
,
do
n't
pray
be
cross
to
me
!
"
 
<EOS>
The
child
beat
his
hand
upon
his
heart
;
and
looked
in
his
companion
's
face
,
with
tears
of
real
agony
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
regarded
Oliver
's
piteous
and
helpless
look
,
with
some
astonishment
,
for
a
few
seconds
;
hemmed
three
or
four
times
in
a
husky
manner
;
and
after
muttering
something
about
"
that
troublesome
cough
,
"
bade
Oliver
dry
his
eyes
and
be
a
good
boy
.
<EOS>
Then
once
more
taking
his
hand
,
he
walked
on
with
him
in
silence
.
   
<EOS>
The
undertaker
,
who
had
just
putup
the
shutters
of
his
shop
,
was
making
some
entries
in
his
day
-
book
by
the
light
of
a
most
appropriate
dismal
candle
,
when
Mr
Bumble
entered
.
   
<EOS>
"
Aha
!
"
said
the
undertaker
;
looking
up
from
the
book
,
and
pausing
in
the
middle
of
a
word
;
"
is
that
you
,
Bumble
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
one
else
,
Mr
Sowerberry
,
"
replied
the
beadle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
!
I
've
brought
the
boy
.
"
 
<EOS>
Oliver
made
a
bow
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
that
's
the
boy
,
is
it
?
"
said
the
undertaker
:
 
raising
the
candle
above
his
head
,
to
get
a
better
view
of
Oliver
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mrs
Sowerberry
,
will
you
have
the
goodness
to
come
here
a
moment
,
my
dear
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Sowerberry
emerged
from
a
little
room
behind
the
shop
,
and
presented
the
form
of
a
short
,
then
,
squeezed
-
up
woman
,
with
a
vixenish
countenance
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
,
"
said
Mr
Sowerberry
,
deferentially
,
"
this
is
the
boy
from
the
workhouse
that
I
told
you
of
.
"
 
<EOS>
Oliver
bowed
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
"
said
the
undertaker
's
wife
,
"
he
's
very
small
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
he
IS
rather
small
,
"
replied
Mr
Bumble
:
 
looking
at
Oliver
as
if
it
were
his
fault
that
he
was
no
bigger
;
"
he
is
small
.
<EOS>
There
's
no
denying
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
'll
grow
,
Mrs
Sowerberry
---
he
'll
grow
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
I
dare
say
he
will
,
"
replied
the
lady
pettishly
,
"
on
our
victuals
and
our
drink
.
 
<EOS>
I
see
no
saving
in
parish
children
,
not
I
;
for
they
always
cost
more
to
keep
,
than
they
're
worth
.
<EOS>
However
,
men
always
think
they
know
best
.
<EOS>
There
!
 
<EOS>
Get
downstairs
,
little
bag
o
'
bones
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
,
the
undertaker
's
wife
opened
a
side
door
,
and
pushed
Oliver
down
a
steep
flight
of
stairs
into
a
stone
cell
,
damp
and
dark
:
 
forming
the
ante
-
room
to
the
coal
-
cellar
,
and
denominated
"
kitchen
"
;
wherein
sat
a
slatternly
girl
,
in
shoes
down
at
heel
,
and
blue
worsted
stockings
very
much
out
of
repair
.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
,
Charlotte
,
"
said
Mr
Sowerberry
,
who
had
followed
Oliver
down
,
"
give
this
boy
some
of
the
cold
bits
that
were
put
by
for
Trip
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
n't
come
home
since
the
morning
,
so
he
may
go
without
'em
.
 
<EOS>
I
dare
say
the
boy
is
n't
too
dainty
to
eat
'em
---
are
you
,
boy
?
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver
,
whose
eyes
had
glistened
at
the
mention
of
meat
,
and
who
was
trembling
with
eagerness
to
devour
it
,
replied
in
the
negative
;
and
a
plateful
of
coarse
broken
victuals
was
set
before
him
.
   
<EOS>
I
wish
some
well
-
fed
philosopher
,
whose
meat
and
drink
turn
to
gall
within
him
;
whose
blood
is
ice
,
whose
heart
is
iron
;
could
have
seen
Oliver
Twist
clutching
at
the
dainty
viands
that
the
dog
had
neglected
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
he
could
have
witnessed
the
horrible
avidity
with
which
Oliver
tore
the
bits
asunder
with
all
the
ferocity
of
famine
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
only
one
thing
I
should
like
better
;
and
that
would
be
to
see
the
Philosopher
making
the
same
sort
of
meal
himself
,
with
the
same
relish
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
"
said
the
undertaker
's
wife
,
when
Oliver
had
finished
his
supper
:
 
which
she
had
regarded
in
silent
horror
,
and
with
fearful
auguries
of
his
future
appetite
:
 
"
have
you
done
?
"
   
<EOS>
There
being
nothing
eatable
within
his
reach
,
Oliver
replied
in
the
affirmative
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
come
with
me
,
"
said
Mrs
Sowerberry
:
 
taking
up
a
dim
and
dirty
lamp
,
and
leading
the
way
upstairs
;
"
your
bed
's
under
the
counter
.
 
<EOS>
You
do
n't
mind
sleeping
among
the
coffins
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
But
it
does
n't
much
matter
whether
you
do
or
do
n't
,
for
you
ca
n't
sleep
anywhere
else
.
 
<EOS>
Come
;
do
n't
keep
me
here
all
night
!
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver
lingered
no
longer
,
but
meekly
followed
his
new
mistress
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
5
.
<EOS>
Oliver
mingles
with
new
associates
.
 
<EOS>
Going
to
a
funeral
for
the
First
time
,
he
forms
an
unfavourable
notion
of
his
master
's
Business
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
,
being
left
to
himself
in
the
undertaker
's
shop
,
set
the
lamp
down
on
a
workman
's
bench
,
and
gazed
timidly
about
him
with
a
feeling
of
awe
and
dread
,
which
many
people
a
good
deal
older
than
he
will
be
at
no
loss
to
understand
.
 
<EOS>
An
unfinished
coffin
on
black
tressels
,
which
stood
in
the
middle
of
the
shop
,
looked
so
gloomy
and
death
-
like
that
a
cold
tremble
came
over
him
,
every
time
his
eyes
wandered
in
the
direction
of
the
dismal
object
:
from
which
he
almost
expected
to
see
some
frightful
form
slowly
rear
its
head
,
to
drive
him
mad
with
terror
.
 
<EOS>
Against
the
wall
were
ranged
,
in
regular
array
,
a
long
row
of
elm
boards
cut
in
the
same
shape
:
looking
in
the
dim
light
,
like
high
-
shouldered
ghosts
with
their
hands
in
their
breeches
pockets
.
<EOS>
Coffin
-
plates
,
elm
-
chips
,
bright
-
headed
nails
,
and
shreds
of
black
cloth
,
lay
scattered
on
the
floor
;
and
the
wall
behind
the
counter
was
ornamented
with
a
lively
representation
of
two
mutes
in
very
stiff
neckcloths
,
on
duty
at
a
large
private
door
,
with
a
hearse
drawn
by
four
black
steeds
,
approaching
in
the
distance
.
<EOS>
The
shop
was
close
and
hot
.
 
<EOS>
The
atmosphere
seemed
tainted
with
the
smell
of
coffins
.
 
<EOS>
The
recess
beneath
the
counter
in
which
his
flock
mattress
was
thrust
,
looked
like
a
grave
.
   
<EOS>
Nor
were
these
the
only
dismal
feelings
which
depressed
Oliver
.
<EOS>
He
was
alone
in
a
strange
place
;
and
we
all
know
how
chilled
and
desolate
the
best
of
us
will
sometimes
feel
in
such
a
situation
.
<EOS>
The
boy
had
no
friends
to
care
for
,
or
to
care
for
him
.
 
<EOS>
The
regret
of
no
recent
separation
was
fresh
in
his
mind
;
the
absence
of
no
loved
and
well
-
remembered
face
sank
heavily
into
his
heart
.
   
<EOS>
But
his
heart
was
heavy
,
notwithstanding
;
and
he
wished
,
as
he
crept
into
his
narrow
bed
,
that
that
were
his
coffin
,
and
that
he
could
be
lain
in
a
calm
and
lasting
sleep
in
the
churchyard
ground
,
with
the
tall
grass
waving
gently
above
his
head
,
and
the
sound
of
the
old
deep
bell
to
soothe
him
in
his
sleep
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
was
awakened
in
the
morning
,
by
a
loud
kicking
at
the
outside
of
the
shop
-
door
:
 
which
,
before
he
could
huddle
on
his
clothes
,
was
repeated
,
in
an
angry
and
impetuous
manner
,
about
twenty
-
five
times
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
began
to
undo
the
chain
,
the
legs
desisted
,
and
a
voice
began
.
   
<EOS>
"
Open
the
door
,
will
yer
?
"
<EOS>
cried
the
voice
which
belonged
to
the
legs
which
had
kicked
at
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
,
directly
,
sir
,
"
replied
Oliver
:
 
undoing
the
chain
,
and
turning
the
key
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
yer
the
new
boy
,
ai
n't
yer
?
"
said
the
voice
through
the
key
-
hole
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
replied
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
old
are
yer
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
the
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ten
,
sir
,
"
replied
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
I
'll
whop
yer
when
I
get
in
,
"
said
the
voice
;
"
you
just
see
if
I
do
n't
,
that
's
all
,
my
<EOS>
work'us
brat
!
"
<EOS>
and
having
made
this
obliging
promise
,
the
voice
began
to
whistle
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
had
been
too
often
subjected
to
the
process
to
which
the
very
expressive
monosyllable
just
recorded
bears
reference
,
to
entertain
the
smallest
doubt
that
the
owner
of
the
voice
,
whoever
he
might
be
,
would
redeem
his
pledge
,
most
honourably
.
<EOS>
He
drew
back
the
bolts
with
a
trembling
hand
,
and
opened
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
For
a
second
or
two
,
Oliver
glanced
up
the
street
,
and
down
the
street
,
and
over
the
way
:
 
impressed
with
the
belief
that
the
unknown
,
who
had
addressed
him
through
the
key
-
hole
,
had
walked
a
few
paces
off
,
to
warm
himself
;
for
nobody
did
he
see
but
<EOS>
a
big
charity
-
boy
,
sitting
on
a
post
in
front
of
the
house
,
eating
a
slice
of
bread
and
butter
:
 
which
he
cut
into
wedges
,
the
size
of
his
mouth
,
with
a
clasp
-
knife
,
and
then
consumed
with
great
dexterity
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
sir
,
"
said
Oliver
at
length
:
 
<EOS>
seeing
that
no
other
visitor
made
his
appearance
;
"
did
you
knock
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
kicked
,
"
replied
the
charity
-
boy
.
   
<EOS>
"
Did
you
want
a
coffin
,
sir
?
"
inquired
Oliver
,
innocently
.
   
<EOS>
At
this
,
the
charity
-
boy
looked
monstrous
fierce
;
and
said
that
Oliver
would
want
one
before
long
,
if
he
cut
jokes
with
his
superiors
in
that
way
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yer
do
n't
know
who
I
am
,
I
suppose
,
Work'us
?
"
said
the
charity
-
boy
,
in
continuation
:
 
descending
from
the
top
of
the
post
,
meanwhile
,
with
edifying
gravity
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
,
"
rejoined
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
Mister
Noah
Claypole
,
"
said
the
charity
-
boy
,
"
and
you
're
under
me
.
 
<EOS>
Take
down
the
shutters
,
yer
idle
young
ruffian
!
"
<EOS>
With
this
,
Mr
Claypole
administered
a
kick
to
Oliver
,
and
entered
the
shop
with
a
dignified
air
,
which
did
him
great
credit
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
difficult
for
a
large
-
headed
,
small
-
eyed
youth
,
of
lumbering
make
and
heavy
countenance
,
to
look
dignified
under
any
circumstances
;
but
it
is
more
especially
so
,
when
superadded
to
these
personal
attractions
are
a
red
nose
and
yellow
smalls
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
,
having
taken
down
the
shutters
,
and
broken
a
pane
of
glass
in
his
effort
to
stagger
away
beneath
the
weight
of
the
first
one
to
a
small
court
at
the
side
of
the
house
in
which
they
were
kept
during
the
day
,
was
graciously
assisted
by
Noah
:
 
who
having
consoled
him
with
the
assurance
that
"
he
'd
catch
it
,
"
condescended
to
help
him
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Sowerberry
came
down
soon
after
.
<EOS>
Shortly
afterwards
,
Mrs
Sowerberry
appeared
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
having
"
caught
it
,
"
in
fulfilment
of
Noah
's
prediction
,
followed
that
young
gentleman
down
the
stairs
to
breakfast
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
near
the
fire
,
Noah
,
"
said
Charlotte
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
saved
a
nice
little
bit
of
bacon
for
you
from
master
's
breakfast
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
,
shut
that
door
at
Mister
Noah
's
back
,
and
take
them
bits
that
I
've
put
out
on
the
cover
of
the
bread
-
pan
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
your
tea
;
take
it
away
to
that
box
,
and
drink
it
there
,
and
make
haste
,
for
they
'll
want
you
to
mind
the
shop
.
 
<EOS>
D'ye
hear
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
D'ye
hear
,
Work'us
?
"
said
Noah
Claypole
.
   
<EOS>
"
Lor
,
Noah
!
"
said
Charlotte
,
"
what
a
rum
creature
you
are
!
 
<EOS>
Why
do
n't
you
let
the
boy
alone
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Let
him
alone
!
"
said
Noah
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
everybody
lets
him
alone
enough
,
for
the
matter
of
that
.
 
<EOS>
Neither
his
father
nor
his
mother
will
ever
interfere
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
All
his
relations
let
him
have
his
own
way
pretty
well
.
 
<EOS>
Eh
,
Charlotte
?
 
<EOS>
He
!
<EOS>
he
!
<EOS>
he
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
you
queer
soul
!
"
said
Charlotte
,
bursting
into
a
hearty
laugh
,
in
which
she
was
joined
by
Noah
;
after
which
they
both
looked
scornfully
at
poor
Oliver
Twist
,
as
he
sat
shivering
on
the
box
in
the
coldest
corner
of
the
room
,
and
ate
the
stale
pieces
which
had
been
specially
reserved
for
him
.
   
<EOS>
Noah
was
a
charity
-
boy
,
but
not
a
workhouse
orphan
.
 
<EOS>
No
chance
-
child
was
he
,
for
he
could
trace
his
genealogy
all
the
way
back
to
his
parents
,
who
lived
hard
by
;
his
mother
being
a
washerwoman
,
and
his
father
a
drunken
soldier
,
discharged
with
a
wooden
leg
,
and
a
diurnal
pension
of
twopence
-
halfpenny
and
an
unstateable
fraction
.
 
<EOS>
The
shop
-
boys
in
the
neighbourhood
had
long
been
in
the
habit
of
branding
Noah
in
the
public
streets
,
with
the
ignominious
epithets
of
"
leathers
,
"
"
charity
,
"
and
the
like
;
and
Noah
<EOS>
had
bourne
them
without
reply
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
now
that
fortune
had
cast
in
his
way
<EOS>
a
nameless
orphan
,
at
whom
even
the
meanest
could
point
the
finger
of
scorn
,
he
retorted
on
him
with
interest
.
 
<EOS>
This
affords
charming
food
for
contemplation
.
 
<EOS>
It
shows
us
what
a
beautiful
thing
human
nature
may
be
made
to
be
;
and
how
impartially
the
same
amiable
qualities
are
developed
in
the
finest
lord
and
the
dirtiest
charity
-
boy
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
had
been
sojourning
at
the
undertaker
's
some
three
weeks
or
a
month
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
and
Mrs
Sowerberry
---
the
shop
being
shut
up
---
were
taking
their
supper
in
the
little
back
-
parlour
,
when
Mr
Sowerberry
,
after
several
deferential
glances
at
his
wife
,
said
,
   
"
<EOS>
My
dear
---
"
 
He
was
going
to
say
more
;
but
,
Mrs
Sowerberry
looking
up
,
with
a
peculiarly
unpropitious
aspect
,
he
stopped
short
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
"
said
Mrs
Sowerberry
,
sharply
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
my
dear
,
nothing
,
"
said
Mr
Sowerberry
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ugh
,
you
brute
!
"
said
Mrs
Sowerberry
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Not
at
all
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mr
Sowerberry
humbly
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
thought
you
did
n't
want
to
hear
,
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
only
going
to
say
---
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
do
n't
tell
me
what
you
were
going
to
say
,
"
interposed
Mrs
Sowerberry
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
nobody
;
do
n't
consult
me
,
pray
.
 
<EOS>
\
<EOS>
I
\
do
n't
want
to
intrude
upon
your
secrets
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
As
Mrs
Sowerberry
said
this
,
she
gave
an
hysterical
laugh
,
which
threatened
violent
consequences
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Sowerberry
,
"
I
want
to
ask
your
advice
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
do
n't
ask
mine
,
"
replied
Mrs
Sowerberry
,
in
an
affecting
manner
:
 
"
ask
somebody
else
's
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Here
,
there
was
another
hysterical
laugh
,
which
frightened
Mr
Sowerberry
very
much
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
a
very
common
and
much
-
approved
matrimonial
course
of
treatment
,
which
is
often
very
effective
<EOS>
It
at
once
reduced
Mr
Sowerberry
to
begging
,
as
a
special
favour
,
to
be
allowed
to
say
what
Mrs
Sowerberry
was
most
curious
to
hear
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
short
duration
,
the
permission
was
most
graciously
conceded
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
only
about
young
Twist
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mr
Sowerberry
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
very
good
-
looking
boy
,
that
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
need
be
,
for
he
eats
enough
,
"
observed
the
lady
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
an
expression
of
melancholy
in
his
face
,
my
dear
,
"
resumed
Mr
Sowerberry
,
"
which
is
very
interesting
.
 
<EOS>
He
would
make
a
delightful
mute
,
my
love
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Sowerberry
looked
up
with
an
expression
of
considerable
wonderment
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Sowerberry
remarked
it
and
,
without
allowing
time
for
any
observation
on
the
good
lady
's
part
,
proceeded
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
mean
a
regular
mute
to
attend
grown
-
up
people
,
my
dear
,
but
only
for
children
's
practice
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
be
very
new
to
have
a
mute
in
proportion
,
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
You
may
depend
upon
it
,
it
would
have
a
superb
effect
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Sowerberry
,
who
had
a
good
deal
of
taste
in
the
undertaking
way
,
was
much
struck
by
the
novelty
of
this
idea
;
but
,
as
it
would
have
been
compromising
her
dignity
to
have
said
so
,
under
existing
circumstances
,
she
merely
inquired
,
with
much
sharpness
,
why
such
an
obvious
suggestion
had
not
presented
itself
to
her
husband
's
mind
before
?
 
<EOS>
Mr
Sowerberry
rightly
construed
this
,
as
an
acquiescence
in
his
proposition
;
it
was
speedily
determined
,
therefore
,
that
Oliver
should
be
at
once
initiated
into
the
mysteries
of
the
trade
;
and
,
with
this
view
,
that
he
should
accompany
his
master
on
the
very
next
occasion
of
his
services
being
required
.
   
<EOS>
The
occasion
was
not
long
in
coming
.
 
<EOS>
Half
an
hour
after
breakfast
next
morning
,
Mr
Bumble
entered
the
shop
;
and
supporting
his
cane
against
the
counter
,
drew
forth
his
large
leathern
pocket
-
book
:
 
from
which
he
selected
a
small
scrap
of
paper
,
which
he
handed
over
to
Sowerberry
.
   
<EOS>
"
Aha
!
"
said
the
undertaker
,
glancing
over
it
with
a
lively
countenance
;
"
an
order
for
a
coffin
,
eh
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
For
a
coffin
first
,
and
a
porochial
funeral
afterwards
,
"
replied
Mr
Bumble
,
fastening
the
strap
of
the
leathern
pocket
-
book
:
which
,
like
himself
,
was
very
corpulent
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bayton
,
"
said
the
undertaker
,
looking
from
the
scrap
of
paper
to
Mr
Bumble
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
never
heard
the
name
before
.
"
   
<EOS>
Bumble
shook
his
head
,
as
he
replied
,
"
Obstinate
people
,
Mr
Sowerberry
;
very
obstinate
.
 
<EOS>
Proud
,
too
,
I
'm
afraid
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Proud
,
eh
?
"
exclaimed
Mr
Sowerberry
with
a
sneer
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
,
that
's
too
much
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
it
's
sickening
,
"
replied
the
beadle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Antimonial
,
Mr
Sowerberry
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
it
is
,
"
asquiesced
the
undertaker
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
only
heard
of
the
family
the
night
before
last
,
"
said
the
beadle
;
"
and
we
should
n't
have
known
anything
about
them
,
then
,
only
a
woman
who
lodges
in
the
same
house
made
an
application
to
the
porochial
committee
for
them
to
send
the
porochial
surgeon
to
see
a
woman
as
was
very
bad
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
gone
out
to
dinner
;
but
his
'
prentice
(
which
is
a
very
clever
lad
)
sent
'em
some
medicine
in
a
blacking
-
bottle
,
offhand
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
there
's
promptness
,
"
said
the
undertaker
.
   
<EOS>
"
Promptness
,
indeed
!
"
replied
the
beadle
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
what
's
the
consequence
;
what
's
the
ungrateful
behaviour
of
these
rebels
,
sir
?
 
<EOS>
Why
,
the
husband
sends
back
word
that
the
medicine
wo
n't
suit
his
wife
's
complaint
,
and
so
she
sha
n't
take
it
<EOS>
---
says
she
sha
n't
take
it
,
sir
!
 
<EOS>
Good
,
strong
,
wholesome
medicine
,
as
was
given
with
great
success
to
two
Irish
labourers
and
a
coal
-
heaver
,
ony
a
week
before
---
sent
'em
for
nothing
,
with
a
blackin'-bottle
in
,
---
and
he
sends
back
word
that
she
sha
n't
take
it
,
sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
As
the
atrocity
presented
itself
to
Mr
Bumble
's
mind
in
full
force
,
he
struck
the
counter
sharply
with
his
cane
,
and
became
flushed
with
indignation
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
"
said
the
undertaker
,
"
<EOS>
I
ne
---
<EOS>
ver
---
did
---
"
   
"
Never
did
,
sir
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
the
beadle
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
nor
nobody
never
did
;
but
now
she
's
dead
,
we
've
got
to
bury
her
;
and
that
's
the
direction
;
and
the
sooner
it
's
done
,
the
better
.
"
   
<EOS>
Thus
saying
,
Mr
Bumble
put
on
his
cocked
hat
wrong
side
first
,
in
a
fever
of
parochial
excietment
;
and
flounced
out
of
the
shop
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
he
was
so
angry
,
Oliver
,
that
he
forgot
even
to
ask
after
you
!
"
said
Mr
Sowerberry
,
looking
after
the
beadle
as
he
strode
down
the
street
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
replied
Oliver
,
who
had
carefully
kept
himself
out
of
sight
,
during
the
interview
;
and
who
was
shaking
from
head
to
foot
at
the
mere
recollection
of
the
sound
of
Mr
Bumble
's
voice
.
   
<EOS>
He
need
n't
haven
taken
the
trouble
to
shrink
from
Mr
Bumble
's
glance
,
however
;
for
that
functionary
,
on
whom
the
prediction
of
the
gentleman
in
the
white
waistcoat
had
made
a
very
strong
impression
,
thought
that
now
the
undertaker
had
got
Oliver
upon
trial
the
subject
was
better
avoided
,
until
such
time
as
he
should
be
firmly
bound
for
seven
years
,
and
all
danger
of
his
being
returned
upon
the
hands
of
the
parish
should
be
thus
effectually
and
legally
overcome
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
"
said
Mr
Sowerberry
,
taking
up
his
hat
.
 
<EOS>
"
the
sooner
this
job
is
done
,
the
better
.
 
<EOS>
Noah
,
look
after
the
shop
.
<EOS>
Oliver
,
put
on
your
cap
,
and
come
with
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
Oliver
obeyed
,
and
followed
his
master
on
his
professional
mission
.
   
<EOS>
They
walked
on
,
for
some
time
,
through
the
most
crowded
and
densely
inhabited
part
of
the
town
;
and
then
,
striking
down
a
narrow
street
more
dirty
and
miserable
than
any
they
had
yet
passed
through
,
paused
to
look
for
the
house
which
was
the
object
of
their
search
.
 
<EOS>
The
houses
on
either
side
were
high
and
large
,
but
very
old
,
and
tenanted
by
people
of
the
poorest
class
:
 
as
their
neglected
appearance
would
have
sufficiently
dentoed
,
without
the
concurrent
testimony
afforded
by
the
squalid
looks
of
the
few
men
and
women
who
,
with
folded
arms
and
bodies
half
doubled
,
occasionally
skulked
along
.
 
<EOS>
A
great
many
of
the
tenements
had
shop
-
fronts
;
but
these
were
fast
closed
,
and
mouldering
away
;
only
the
upper
rooms
being
inhabited
.
 
<EOS>
Some
houses
which
had
become
insecure
from
age
and
decay
,
were
prevented
from
falling
into
the
street
,
by
huge
beams
of
wood
reared
against
the
walls
,
and
firmly
planted
in
the
road
;
but
even
these
crazy
dens
seemed
to
have
been
selected
as
the
nightly
haunts
of
some
houseless
wretches
,
for
many
of
the
rough
boards
which
supplied
the
place
of
door
and
window
,
were
wrenched
from
their
positions
,
to
afford
an
aperture
wide
enough
for
the
passage
of
a
human
body
.
 
<EOS>
The
kennel
was
stagnant
and
filthy
.
<EOS>
The
very
rats
,
which
here
and
there
lay
putrefying
in
its
rottenness
,
were
hideous
with
famine
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
neither
knocker
nor
bell
-
handle
at
the
open
door
where
Oliver
and
his
master
stopped
;
so
,
groping
his
way
cautiously
through
the
dark
passage
,
and
bidding
Oliver
keep
close
to
him
and
not
be
afraid
the
undertaker
mounted
to
the
top
of
the
first
flight
of
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
Stumbling
against
a
door
on
the
landing
,
he
rapped
at
it
with
his
knuckles
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
opened
by
a
young
girl
of
thirteen
or
fourteen
.
 
<EOS>
The
undertaker
at
once
saw
enough
of
what
the
room
contained
,
to
know
it
was
the
apartment
to
which
he
had
been
directed
.
 
<EOS>
He
stepped
in
;
Oliver
followed
him
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
no
fire
in
the
room
;
but
a
man
was
crouching
,
mechanically
,
over
the
empty
stove
.
 
<EOS>
An
old
woman
,
too
,
had
drawn
a
low
stool
to
the
cold
hearth
,
and
was
sitting
beside
him
.
<EOS>
There
were
some
ragged
children
in
another
corner
;
and
in
a
small
recess
,
opposite
the
door
,
there
lay
upon
the
ground
,
something
covered
with
an
old
blanket
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
shuddered
as
he
cast
his
eyes
toward
the
place
,
and
crept
involuntarily
closer
to
his
master
;
for
though
it
was
covered
up
,
the
boy
felt
that
it
was
a
corpse
.
   
<EOS>
The
man
's
face
was
thin
and
very
pale
;
his
hair
and
beard
were
grizzly
;
his
eyes
were
blookshot
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
woman
's
face
was
wrinkled
;
her
two
remaining
teeth
protruded
over
her
under
lip
;
and
her
eyes
were
bright
and
piercing
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
was
afriad
to
look
at
either
her
or
the
man
.
 
<EOS>
They
seemed
so
like
the
rats
he
had
seen
outside
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nobody
shall
go
near
her
,
"
said
the
man
,
starting
fiercely
up
,
as
the
undertaker
approached
the
recess
.
 
<EOS>
"
Keep
back
!
<EOS>
Damn
you
,
keep
back
,
if
you
've
a
life
to
lose
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nonsense
,
my
good
man
,
"
said
the
undertaker
,
who
was
pretty
well
used
to
misery
in
all
its
shapes
.
 
<EOS>
"
Nonsense
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
,
"
said
the
man
:
 
clenching
his
hands
,
and
stamping
furiously
on
the
floor
,
---
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
I
wo
n't
have
her
put
into
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
She
could
n't
rest
there
.
 
<EOS>
The
worms
would
worry
her
---
not
eat
her
---
<EOS>
she
is
so
worn
away
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
undertaker
offered
no
reply
to
this
raving
;
but
producing
a
tape
from
his
pocket
,
knelt
down
for
a
moment
by
the
side
of
the
body
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
man
:
 
bursting
into
tears
,
and
sinking
on
his
knees
at
the
feet
of
the
dead
woman
;
"
kneel
down
,
kneel
down
 
---
kneel
round
her
,
every
one
of
you
,
and
mark
my
words
!
 
<EOS>
I
say
she
was
starved
to
death
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
knew
how
bad
she
was
,
till
the
fever
came
upon
her
;
and
then
her
bones
were
starting
through
the
skin
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
neither
fire
nor
candle
;
she
died
in
the
dark
---
in
the
dark
!
 
<EOS>
She
could
n't
even
see
her
children
's
faces
,
though
we
heard
her
gasping
out
their
names
.
<EOS>
I
begged
for
her
in
the
streets
:
 
and
they
sent
me
to
prison
.
<EOS>
When
I
came
back
,
she
was
dying
;
and
all
the
blood
in
my
heart
has
dried
up
,
for
they
starved
her
to
death
.
 
<EOS>
I
swear
it
before
the
God
that
saw
it
!
<EOS>
They
starved
her
!
"
 
<EOS>
He
twined
his
hands
in
his
hair
;
and
,
with
a
loud
scream
,
rolled
grovelling
upon
the
floor
:
 
his
eyes
fixed
,
and
the
foam
covering
his
lips
.
   
<EOS>
The
terrified
children
cried
bitterly
;
but
the
old
woman
,
who
had
hitherto
remained
as
quiet
as
if
she
had
been
wholly
deaf
to
all
that
passed
,
menaced
them
into
silence
.
 
<EOS>
Having
unloosened
the
cravat
of
the
man
who
still
remained
extended
on
the
ground
,
she
tottered
towards
the
undertaker
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
was
my
daughter
,
"
said
the
old
woman
,
nodding
her
head
in
the
direction
of
the
corpse
;
and
speaking
with
an
idiotic
leer
,
more
ghastly
than
even
the
presence
of
death
in
such
a
place
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Lord
,
Lord
!
 
<EOS>
Well
,
it
IS
strange
that
I
who
gave
birth
to
her
,
and
was
a
woman
then
,
should
be
alive
and
merry
now
,
and
she
lying
ther
:
 
so
cold
and
stiff
!
 
<EOS>
Lord
,
Lord
!
<EOS>
---
to
think
of
it
;
it
's
as
good
as
a
play
---
as
good
as
a
play
!
"
   
<EOS>
As
the
wretched
creature
mumbled
and
chuckled
in
her
hideous
merriment
,
the
undertaker
turned
to
go
away
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stop
,
stop
!
"
said
the
old
woman
in
a
loud
whisper
.
 
<EOS>
"
Will
she
be
buried
to
-
morrow
,
or
next
day
,
or
to
-
night
?
 
<EOS>
I
laid
her
out
;
and
I
must
walk
,
you
know
.
 
<EOS>
Send
me
a
large
cloak
:
a
good
warm
one
:
for
it
is
bitter
cold
.
 
<EOS>
We
should
have
cake
and
wine
,
too
,
before
we
go
!
 
<EOS>
Never
mind
;
send
some
bread
---
only
a
loaf
of
bread
and
a
cup
of
water
.
 
<EOS>
Shall
we
have
some
bread
,
dear
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
said
eagerly
:
   
catching
at
the
undertaker
's
coat
,
as
he
once
more
moved
towards
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
,
"
said
the
undertaker
,
"
of
course
.
 
<EOS>
Anything
you
like
!
"
<EOS>
He
disengaged
himself
from
the
old
woman
's
grasp
;
and
,
drawing
Oliver
after
him
,
hurried
away
.
   
<EOS>
The
next
day
,
(
the
family
having
been
meanwhile
relieved
with
a
half
-
quartern
loaf
and
a
piece
of
cheese
,
left
with
them
by
Mr
Bumble
himself
,
)
<EOS>
Oliver
and
his
master
returned
to
the
miserable
abode
;
where
Mr
Bumble
had
already
arrived
,
accompanied
by
four
men
from
the
workhouse
,
who
were
to
act
as
bearers
.
 
<EOS>
An
old
black
cloak
had
been
thrown
over
the
rags
of
the
old
woman
and
the
man
;
and
the
bare
coffin
having
been
screwed
down
,
was
hoisted
on
the
shoulders
of
the
bearers
,
and
carried
into
the
street
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
you
must
put
your
best
leg
foremost
,
old
lady
!
"
<EOS>
whispered
Sowerberry
in
the
old
woman
's
ear
;
"
we
are
rather
late
;
and
it
wo
n't
do
,
to
keep
the
clergyman
waiting
.
 
<EOS>
Move
on
,
my
men
,
---
as
quick
as
you
like
!
"
   
<EOS>
Thus
directed
,
the
bearers
trotted
on
under
their
light
burden
;
and
the
two
mourners
kept
as
near
them
,
as
they
could
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
and
Sowerberry
walked
at
a
good
smart
pace
in
front
;
and
Oliver
,
whose
legs
were
not
so
long
as
his
master
's
,
ran
by
the
side
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
not
so
great
a
necessity
for
hurrying
as
Mr
Sowerberry
had
anticipated
,
however
;
for
when
they
reached
the
obscure
corner
of
the
churchyard
in
which
the
nettles
grew
,
and
where
the
parish
graves
were
made
,
the
clergyman
had
not
arrived
;
and
the
clerk
,
who
was
sitting
by
the
vestry
-
room
fire
,
seemed
to
think
it
by
no
means
improbable
that
it
might
be
an
hour
or
so
,
before
he
came
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
they
put
the
bier
on
the
brink
of
the
grave
;
and
the
two
mourners
waited
patiently
in
the
damp
clay
,
with
a
cold
rain
drizzling
down
,
while
the
ragged
boys
whom
the
spectacle
had
attracted
into
the
churchyard
played
a
noisy
game
at
hide
-
and
-
seek
among
the
tombstones
,
or
varied
their
amusements
by
jumping
backwards
and
forwards
over
the
coffin
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Sowerberry
and
Bumble
,
being
personal
friends
of
the
clerk
,
sat
by
the
fire
with
him
,
and
read
the
paper
.
   
<EOS>
At
length
,
after
a
lapse
of
something
more
than
an
hour
,
Mr
Bumble
,
and
Sowerberry
,
and
the
clerk
,
were
seen
running
towards
the
grave
.
 
<EOS>
Immediately
afterwards
,
the
clergyman
appeared
:
putting
on
his
surplice
as
he
came
along
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
then
thrashed
a
boy
or
two
,
to
keep
up
appearances
;
and
the
reverend
gentleman
,
having
read
as
much
of
the
burial
service
as
could
be
compressed
into
four
minutes
,
gave
his
surplice
to
the
clerk
,
and
walked
away
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Bill
!
"
said
Sowerberry
to
the
grave
-
digger
.
 
<EOS>
"
Fill
up
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
no
very
difficult
task
,
for
the
grave
was
so
full
,
that
the
uppermost
coffin
was
within
a
few
feet
of
the
surface
.
 
<EOS>
The
grave
-
digger
shovelled
in
the
earth
;
stamped
it
loosely
down
with
his
feet
:
 
shouldered
his
spade
;
and
walked
off
,
followed
by
the
boys
,
who
murmured
very
loud
complaints
at
the
fun
being
over
so
soon
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,
my
good
fellow
!
"
<EOS>
said
Bumble
,
tapping
the
man
on
the
back
.
   
<EOS>
"
They
want
to
shut
up
the
yard
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
man
who
had
never
once
moved
,
since
he
had
taken
his
station
by
the
grave
side
,
started
,
raised
his
head
,
stared
at
the
person
who
had
addressed
him
,
walked
forward
for
a
few
paces
;
and
fell
down
in
a
swoon
.
 
<EOS>
The
crazy
old
woman
was
too
much
occupied
in
bewailing
the
loss
of
her
cloak
(
which
the
undertaker
had
taken
off
)
,
to
pay
him
any
attention
;
so
they
threw
a
can
of
cold
water
over
him
;
and
when
he
came
to
,
saw
him
safely
out
of
the
churchyard
,
locked
the
gate
,
and
departed
on
their
different
ways
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Oliver
,
"
said
Sowerberry
,
as
they
walked
home
,
"
how
do
you
like
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pretty
well
,
thank
you
,
sir
"
replied
Oliver
,
with
considerable
hesitation
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
very
much
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
you
'll
get
used
to
it
in
time
,
Oliver
,
"
said
Sowerberry
.
<EOS>
"
Nothing
when
you
ARE
used
to
it
,
my
boy
.
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver
wondered
,
in
his
own
mind
,
whether
it
had
taken
a
very
long
time
to
get
Mr
Sowerberry
used
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
thought
it
better
not
to
ask
the
question
;
and
walked
back
to
the
shop
:
thinking
over
all
he
had
seen
and
heard
.
      
<EOS>
Chapter
6
.
<EOS>
Oliver
,
being
goaded
by
the
taunts
of
Noah
,
rouses
into
action
,
and
rather
astonishes
him
.
 
<EOS>
The
month
's
trial
over
,
Oliver
was
formally
apprenticed
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
nice
sickly
season
just
at
this
time
.
 
<EOS>
In
commercial
phrase
,
coffins
were
looking
up
;
and
,
in
the
course
of
a
few
weeks
,
Oliver
acquired
a
great
deal
of
experience
.
 
<EOS>
The
success
of
Mr
Sowerberry
's
ingenious
speculation
,
exceeded
even
his
most
sanguine
hopes
.
 
<EOS>
The
oldest
inhabitants
recollected
no
period
at
which
measles
had
been
so
prevalent
,
or
so
fatal
to
infant
existence
;
and
many
were
the
mournful
processions
which
little
Oliver
headed
,
in
a
hat
-
band
reaching
down
to
his
knees
,
to
the
indescribable
admiration
and
emotion
of
all
the
mothers
in
the
town
.
 
<EOS>
As
Oliver
accompanied
his
master
in
most
of
his
adult
expeditions
too
,
in
order
that
he
might
acquire
that
equanimity
of
demeanour
and
full
command
of
nerve
which
was
essential
to
a
finished
undertaker
,
he
had
many
opportunities
of
observing
the
beautiful
resignation
and
fortitude
with
which
some
strong
-
minded
people
bear
their
trials
and
losses
.
   
<EOS>
For
instance
;
when
Sowerberry
had
an
order
for
the
burial
of
some
rich
old
lady
or
gentleman
,
who
was
surrounded
by
a
great
number
of
nephews
and
nieces
,
who
had
been
perfectly
inconsolable
during
the
previous
illness
,
and
whose
grief
had
been
wholly
irrepressible
even
on
the
most
public
occasions
,
they
would
be
as
happy
among
themselves
as
need
be
---
quite
cheerful
and
contented
---
conversing
together
with
as
much
freedom
and
gaiety
,
as
if
nothing
whatever
had
happened
to
disturb
them
.
 
<EOS>
Husbands
,
too
,
bore
the
loss
of
their
wives
with
the
most
heroic
calmness
.
<EOS>
Wives
,
again
,
put
on
weeds
for
their
husbands
,
as
if
,
so
far
from
grieving
in
the
garb
of
sorrow
,
they
had
made
up
their
minds
to
render
it
as
becoming
and
attractive
as
possible
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
observable
,
too
,
that
ladies
and
gentlemen
who
were
in
passions
of
anguish
during
the
ceremony
of
interment
,
recovered
almost
as
soon
as
they
reached
home
,
and
became
quite
composed
before
the
tea
-
drinking
was
over
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
was
very
pleasant
and
improving
to
see
;
and
Oliver
beheld
it
with
great
admiration
.
   
<EOS>
That
Oliver
Twist
was
moved
to
resignation
by
the
example
of
these
good
people
,
I
can
not
,
although
I
am
his
biographer
,
undertake
to
affirm
with
any
degree
of
confidence
;
but
I
can
most
distinctly
say
,
that
for
many
months
he
continued
meekly
to
submit
to
the
domination
and
ill
-
treatment
of
Noah
Claypole
:
 
who
used
him
far
worse
than
before
,
now
that
his
jealousy
was
roused
by
seeing
the
new
boy
promoted
to
the
black
stick
and
hatband
,
while
he
,
the
old
one
,
remained
stationary
in
the
muffin
-

and
leathers
.
 
<EOS>
Charlotte
treated
him
ill
,
because
Noah
did
;
and
Mrs
Sowerberry
was
his
decided
enemy
,
because
Mr
Sowerberry
was
disposed
to
be
his
friend
;
so
,
between
these
three
on
one
side
,
and
a
glut
of
funerals
on
the
other
,
Oliver
was
not
altogether
as
comfortable
as
the
hungry
pig
was
,
when
he
was
shut
up
,
by
mistake
,
in
the
grain
department
of
a
brewery
.
   
<EOS>
And
now
,
I
come
to
a
very
important
passage
in
Oliver
's
history
;
for
I
have
to
record
an
act
,
slight
and
unimportant
perhaps
in
appearance
,
but
which
indirectly
produced
a
material
change
in
all
his
future
prospects
and
proceedings
.
   
<EOS>
One
day
,
Oliver
and
Noah
had
descended
into
the
kitchen
at
the
usual
dinner
-
hour
,
to
banquet
upon
a
small
joint
of
mutton
---
a
pound
and
a
half
of
the
worst
end
of
the
neck
---
when
Charlotte
being
called
out
of
the
way
,
there

a
brief

of
time
,
which
Noah
Claypole
,
being

,
considered
he
could
not

a

than
aggravating
and

Oliver

.
   
<EOS>
Intent

,
Noah
put
his

on
the

;
and
pulled
Oliver
's

;
and

his

;
and
expressed

that
he
was
a
"
sneak
"
;
and
furthermore
announced
his
intention
of
coming
to
see

,
whenever
that
desirable

should
take

;
and
entered
upon
various

of
petty

,
like
a
malicious
and
ill
-
conditioned
charity
-
boy
as
he
was
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
making
Oliver
cry
,
Noah
attempted
to
be
more
facetious
still
;
and
in
his
attempt
,
did
what
many
sometimes
do
to
this
day
,
when
they
want
to
be
funny
.
 
<EOS>
He
got
rather
personal
.
   
<EOS>
"
Work'us
,
"
said
Noah
,
"
how
's
your
mother
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
's
dead
,
"
replied
Oliver
;
"
do
n't
you
say
anything
about
her
to
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver
's
colour
rose
as
he
said
this
;
he
breathed
quickly
;
and
there
was
a
curious
working
of
the
mouth
and
nostrils
,
which
Mr
Claypole
thought
must
be
the
immediate
precursor
of
a
violent

of

.
 
<EOS>
Under
this
impression
he
returned
to
the
charge
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
did
she
die
of
,
Work'us
?
"
said
Noah
.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
a
broken

,
some

,
"

:
 
more

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Tol
de
rol
<EOS>
lol

,

,
<EOS>

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
What
's

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

;

.
<EOS>

;

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Better

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
Better

!
 
<EOS>
Work'us
,

.
 
<EOS>
YOUR

,

!
 
<EOS>
She
was

nice
'
un
<EOS>
she

.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
Lor
!
"
 
<EOS>

,

;
and

as

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Yer

,
Work'us
,
"

,

,

:

<EOS>

:
 
"
Yer

,
Work'us
,

ca

;

;

<EOS>

,

,
yer

regular

-

bad
'

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

?
"
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
A
regular

-
down
bad
'
un
,
Work'us
,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

's

,
Work'us
,
that

,

Bridewell
,

,

;
which
is

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
Crimson

,
Oliver
started
up
;
overthrew
the
chair

;
seized
Noah
by

;
shook

,
in
the

,
till

in

;
and

into

,

to

.
   
<EOS>
A
minute
ago
,
the
boy
had
looked
the
quiet
child
,
mild
,
dejected
creature
that
harsh
treatment
had
made
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
his
spirit
was
roused
at
last
;
the
cruel
insult
to
his
dead
mother
had
set
his
blood
on
fire
.
 
<EOS>
His
breast
heaved
;
his
attitude
was
erect
;
his
eye
bright
and
vivid
;
his
whole
person
changed
,
as
he
stood

over
the
cowardly

who
now
lay
crouching
at
his
feet
;
and
defied
him
with
an
energy
he
had
never
known
before
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
'll
murder
me
!
"
<EOS>
blubbered

.
 
<EOS>
"
Charlotte
!
 
<EOS>
missis
!
 
<EOS>
Here
's
the
new
boy
a
murdering
of
me
!
 
<EOS>
Help
!
<EOS>
help
!
 
<EOS>
Oliver
's
gone
mad
!
<EOS>
Char
---
lotte
!
"
   
<EOS>
Noah
's

were
responded
to
,
by
a

Charlotte
,
and
a

from
Mrs
Sowerberry
;
the
former

into
the

a

,
while
the
latter
paused
on
the

till
she
was
quite
certain
that
it
was
consistent
with
the
preservation
of
human
life
,
to
come
further
down
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
you
little
wretch
!
"
<EOS>
screamed
Charlotte
:
 
seizing
Oliver
with
her
utmost
force
,
which
was
about
equal
to
that
of
a
moderately
strong
man
in
particularly
good

.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
you
little
un
-
grate
-
ful
,
mur
-
de
-
rous
,
hor
-
rid
villain
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
between
every

,
Charlotte
gave
Oliver
a
blow
with
all

:
accompanying
it
with
a

,
for

of

.
   
<EOS>
Charlotte
's
fist
was
by
no

a
light

;
but
,
lest

not

effectual
in
calming
Oliver
's

,
Mrs

plunged
into

,
and
assisted

,
while
she
scratched

face
with

.
<EOS>
In
this
favourable
position

affairs
,
Noah
rose
from
the
ground
,
and
pommelled
him
behind
.
   
<EOS>
This
was
rather
too
violent
exercise
to
last
long
.
 
<EOS>
When
they
were
all
wearied
out
,
and
could
tear
and
beat
no

,
they
dragged
Oliver
,
struggling
and
shouting
,
but
nothing
daunted
,
into
the
dust

,
and
there

him
up
.
 
<EOS>
This
being
done
,
Mrs
Sowerberry
sunk
into
a

,
and
burst

.
   
<EOS>
"
Bless
her
,
she
's

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
A
glass
of

,
Noah
,

.
 
<EOS>
Make

!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
Charlotte
,
"
said
Mrs
Sowerberry
:
 
speaking

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

!
Charlotte
,
what

!
"
   
<EOS>
"

!

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
   
<EOS>
Poor

!
 
<EOS>
He

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Poor

!
"

:
 
looking

-

.
   
<EOS>
Noah
,
whose
top

-

might

of

's

,

<EOS>
"

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Your

;

,

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Oliver

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
,

!
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
It

.
"
   
<EOS>

;

<EOS>
Chapter
7
.
<EOS>
Oliver
continues
refractory
.
 
<EOS>
Noah
Claypole
ran
along
the
streets
at
his
swiftest
pace
,
and
paused
not
once
for
breath
,
until
he
reached
the
workhouse
-
gate
.
<EOS>
Having
rested
here
,
for
a
minute
or
so
,
to
collect
a
good
burst
of
sobs
and
an
imposing
show
of
tears
and
terror
,
he
knocked
loudly
at
the
wicket
;
and
presented
such
a
rueful
face
to
the
aged
pauper
who
opened
it
,
that
even
he
,
who
saw
nothing
but
rueful
faces
about
him
at
the
best
of
times
,
started
back
in
astonishment
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Why
,
what
's
the
matter
with
the
boy
!
"
said
the
old
pauper
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Bumble
!
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
!
"
cried
Noah
,
wit
well
-
affected
dismay
:
and
in
tones
so
loud
and
agitated
,
that
they
not
only
caught
the
ear
of
Mr
Bumble
himself
,
who
happened
to
be
hard
by
,
but
alarmed
him
so
much
that
he
rushed
into
the
yard
without
his
cocked
hat
,
 
---
which
is
a
very
curious
and
remarkable
circumstance
:
 
as
showing
that
even
a
beadle
,
acted
upon
a
sudden
and
powerful
impulse
,
may
be
afflicted
with
a
momentary
visitation
of
loss
of
self
-
possession
,
and
forgetfulness
of
personal
dignity
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
Mr
Bumble
,
sir
!
"
said
Noah
:
 
<EOS>
"
Oliver
,
sir
,
 
---
Oliver
has
---
<EOS>
"
   
"
What
?
 
<EOS>
What
?
<EOS>
"
interposed
Mr
Bumble
:
 
with
a
gleam
of
pleasure
in
his
metallic
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
run
away
;
he
has
n't
run
away
,
has
he
,
Noah
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
,
no
.
 
<EOS>
Not
run
away
,
sir
,
but
he
's
turned
wicious
,
"
replied
Noah
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
tried
to
murder
me
,
sir
;
and
then
he
tried
to
murder
Charlotte
;
and
then
missis
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
what
dreadful
pain
it
is
!
   
<EOS>
Such
agony
,
please
,
sir
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
here
,
Noah
writhed
and
twisted
his
body
into
an
extensive
variety
of
eel
-
like
positions
;
thereby
giving
Mr
Bumble
to
understand
that
,
from
the
violent
and
sanguinary
onset
of
Oliver
Twist
,
he
had
sustained
severe
internal
injury
and
damage
,
from
which
he
was
at
that
moment
suffering
the
acutest
torture
.
   
<EOS>
When
Noah
saw
that
the
intelligence
he
communicated
perfectly
paralysed
Mr
Bumble
,
he
imparted
additional
effect
thereunto
,
by
bewailing
his
dreadful
wounds
ten
times
louder
than
before
;
and
when
he
observed
a
gentleman
in
a
white
waistcoat
crossing
the
yard
,
he
was
more
tragic
in
his
lamentations
than
ever
:
 
rightly
conceiving
it
highly
expedient
to
attract
the
notice
,
and
rouse
the
indignation
,
of
the
gentleman
aforesaid
.
   
<EOS>
The
gentleman
's
notice
was
very
soon
attracted
;
for
he
had
not
walked
three
paces
,
when
he
turned
angrily
round
,
and
inquired
what
that
young
cur
was
howling
for
,
and
why
Mr
Bumble
did
not
favour
him
with
something
which
would
render
the
series
of
vocular
exclamations
so
designated
,
an
involuntary
process
?
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
poor
boy
from
the
free
-
school
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Bumble
,
"
who
has
been
nearly
murdered
---
<EOS>
all
but
murdered
,
sir
,
 
---
by
young
Twist
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
By
Jove
!
"
exclaimed
the
gentleman
in
the
white
waistcoat
,
stopping
short
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
knew
it
!
 
<EOS>
I
felt
a
strange
presentiment
from
the
very
first
,
that
that
audacious
young
savage
would
come
to
be
hung
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
has
likewise
attempted
,
sir
,
to
murder
the
female
servant
,
"
said
Mr
Bumble
,
with
a
face
of
ashy
paleness
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
his
missis
,
"
interposed
Mr
Claypole
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
his
master
,
too
,
I
think
you
said
,
Noah
?
"
added
Mr
Bumble
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
!
<EOS>
he
's
out
,
or
he
would
have
murdered
him
,
"
replied
Noah
.
"
<EOS>
He
said
he
wanted
to
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
Said
he
wanted
to
<EOS>
,
did
he
,
my
boy
?
"
inquired
the
gentleman
in
the
white
waistcoat
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
replied
Noah
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
please
,
sir
,
missis
wants
to
know
whether
Mr
Bumble
can
spare
time
to
step
up
there
,
directly
,
and
flog
him
---
 
'cause
master
's
out
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
my
boy
;
certainly
,
"
said
the
gentleman
in
the
white
waistcoat
:
 
<EOS>
smiling
benignly
,
and
patting
Noah
's
head
,
which
was
about
three
inches
higher
than
his
own
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
good
boy
---
a
very
good
boy
.
 
<EOS>
Here
's
a
penny
for
you
.
 
<EOS>
Bumble
,
just
step
up
to
Sowerberry
's
with
your
cane
,
and
seed
<EOS>
what
's
best
to
be
done
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
spare
him
,
Bumble
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
will
not
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
beadle
.
 
<EOS>
And
the
cocked
hat
and
cane
having
been
,
by
this
time
,
adjusted
to
their
owner
's
satisfaction
,
Mr
Bumble
and
Noah
Claypole
betook
themselves
with
all
speed
to
the
undertaker
's
shop
.
   
<EOS>
Here
the
position
of
affairs
had
not
at
all
improved
.
 
<EOS>
Sowerberry
had
not
yet
returned
,
and
Oliver
continued
to
kick
,
with
undiminished
vigour
,
at
the
cellar
-
door
.
 
<EOS>
The
accounts
of
his
ferocity
as
related
by
Mrs
Sowerberry
and
Charlotte
,
were
of
so
startling
a
nature
,
that
Mr
Bumble
judged
it
prudent
to
parley
,
before
opening
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
With
this
view
he
gave
a
kick
at
the
outside
,
by
way
of
prelude
;
and
,
then
,
applying
his
mouth
to
the
keyhole
,
said
,
in
a
deep
and
impressive
tone
:
   
"
Oliver
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Come
;
you
let
me
out
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Oliver
,
from
the
inside
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
this
here
voice
,
Oliver
?
"
said
Mr
Bumble
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
replied
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ai
n't
you
afraid
of
it
,
sir
?
 
<EOS>
Ai
n't
you
a
-
trembling
while
I
speak
,
sir
?
"
said
Mr
Bumble
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
replied
Oliver
,
boldly
.
   
<EOS>
An
answer
so
different
from
the
one
he
had
expected
to
elicit
,
and
was
in
the
habit
of
receiving
,
staggered
Mr
Bumble
not
a
little
.
 
<EOS>
He
stepped
back
from
the
keyhole
;
drew
himself
up
to
his
full
height
;
and
looked
from
one
to
another
of
the
three
bystanders
,
in
mute
astonishment
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
you
know
,
Mr
Bumble
,
he
must
be
mad
,
"
said
Mrs
Sowerberry
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
boy
in
half
his
senses
could
venture
to
speak
so
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
Madness
,
ma'am
,
"
replied
Mr
Bumble
,
after
a
few
moments
of
deep
meditation
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
Meat
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
?
"
exclaimed
Mrs
Sowerberry
.
   
<EOS>
"
Meat
,
ma'am
,
meat
,
"
replied
Bumble
,
with
stern
emphasis
.
<EOS>
"
You
've
over
-
fed
him
,
ma'am
.
 
<EOS>
You
've
raised
a
artificial
soul
and
spirit
in
him
,
ma'am
unbecoming
a
person
of
his
condition
:
as
the
board
,
Mrs
Sowerberry
,
who
are
practical
philosophers
,
will
tell
you
.
 
<EOS>
What
have
paupers
to
do
with
soul
or
spirit
?
 
<EOS>
It
's
quite
enough
that
we
let
'em
have
live
bodies
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
had
kept
the
boy
on
gruel
,
ma'am
,
this
would
never
have
happened
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
,
dear
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Mrs
Sowerberry
,
piously
raising
her
eyes
to
the
kitchen
ceiling
:
 
<EOS>
"
this
comes
of
being
liberal
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
liberality
of
Mrs
Sowerberry
to
Oliver
,
had
consisted
of
a
profuse
bestowal
upon
him
of
all
the
dirty
odds
and
ends
which
nobody
else
would
eat
;
so
there
was
a
great
deal
of
meekness
and
self
-
devotion
in
her
voluntarily
remaining
under
Mr
Bumble
's
heavy
accusation
.
 
<EOS>
Of
which
,
to
do
her
justice
,
she
was
wholly
innocent
,
in
thought
,
word
,
or
deed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
said
Mr
Bumble
,
when
the
lady
brought
her
eyes
down
to
earth
again
;
"
the
only
thing
that
can
be
done
now
,
that
I
know
of
,
is
to
leave
him
in
the
cellar
for
a
day
or
so
,
till
he
's
a
little
starved
down
;
and
then
to
take
him
out
,
and
keep
him
on
gruel
all
through
the
apprenticeship
.
 
<EOS>
He
comes
of
a
bad
family
.
<EOS>
Excitable
natures
,
Mrs
Sowerberry
!
 
<EOS>
Both
the
nurse
and
doctor
said
,
that
that
mother
of
his
made
her
way
here
,
against
difficulties
and
pain
that
would
have
killed
any
well
-
disposed
woman
,
weeks
before
.
"
   
<EOS>
At
this
point
of
Mr
Bumble
's
discourse
,
Oliver
,
just
hearing
enough
to
know
that
some
allusion
was
being
made
to
his
mother
,
recommenced
kicking
,
with
a
violence
that
rendered
every
other
sound
inaudible
.
 
<EOS>
Sowerberry
returned
at
this
juncture
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
's
offence
having
been
explained
to
him
,
with
such
exaggerations
as
the
ladies
thought
best
calculated
to
rouse
his
ire
,
he
unlocked
the
cellar
-
door
in
a
twinkling
,
and
dragged
his
rebellious
apprentice
out
,
by
the
collar
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
's
clothes
had
been
torn
in
the
beating
he
had
received
;
his
face
was
bruised
and
scratched
;
and
his
hair
scattered
over
his
forehead
.
 
<EOS>
The
angry
flush
had
not
disappeared
,
however
;
and
when
he
was
pulled
out
of
his
prison
,
he
scowled
boldly
on
Noah
,
and
looked
quite
undismayed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
you
are
a
nice
young
fellow
,
ai
n't
you
?
"
<EOS>
said
Sowerberry
;
giving
Oliver
a
shake
,
and
a
box
on
the
ear
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
called
my
mother
names
,
"
replied
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
and
what
if
he
did
,
you
little
ungrateful
wretch
?
"
said
Mrs
Sowerberry
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
deserved
what
he
said
,
and
worse
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
did
n't
"
said
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
did
,
"
said
Mrs
Sowerberry
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
lie
!
"
said
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Sowerberry
burst
into
a
flood
of
tears
.
   
<EOS>
This
flood
of
tears
left
Mr
Sowerberry
no
alternative
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
had
hesitated
for
one
instant
to
punish
Oliver
most
severely
,
it
must
be
quite
clear
to
every
experienced
reader
that
he
would
have
been
,
according
to
all
precedents
in
disputes
of
matrimony
established
,
a
brute
,
an
unnatural
husband
,
an
insulting
creature
,
a
base
imitation
of
a
man
,
and
various
other
agreeable
characters
too
numerous
for
recital
within
the
limits
of
this
chapter
.
 
<EOS>
To
do
him
justice
,
he
was
,
as
far
as
his
power
went
---
it
was
not
very
extensive
---
kindly
disposed
towards
the
boy
;
perhaps
,
because
it
was
his
interest
to
be
so
;
perhaps
,
because
his
wife
disliked
him
.
<EOS>
The
flood
of
tears
,
however
,
left
him
no
resource
;
so
he
at
once
gave
him
a
drubbing
,
which
satisfied
even
Mrs
Sowerberry
herself
,
and
rendered
Mr
Bumble
's
subsequent
application
of
the
parochial
cane
,
rather
unnecessary
.
 
<EOS>
For
the
rest
of
the
day
,
he
was
shut
up
in
the
back
kitchen
,
in
company
with
a
pump
and
a
slice
of
bread
;
and
at
night
,
Mrs
Sowerberry
,
after
making
various
remarks
outside
the
door
,
by
no
means
complimentary
to
the
memory
of
his
mother
,
looked
into
the
room
,
and
,
amidst
the
jeers
and
pointings
of
Noah
and
Charlotte
,
ordered
him
upstairs
to
his
dismal
bed
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
not
until
he
was
left
alone
in
the
silence
and
stillness
of
the
gloomy
workshop
of
the
undertaker
,
that
Oliver
gave
way
to
the
feelings
which
the
day
's
treatment
may
be
supposed
likely
to
have
awakened
in
a
mere
child
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
listened
to
their
taunts
with
a
look
of
contempt
;
he
had
borne
the
lash
without
a
cry
:
for
he
felt
that
pride
swelling
in
his
heart
which
would
have
kept
down
a
shriek
to
the
last
,
though
they
had
roasted
him
alive
.
 
<EOS>
But
now
,
when
there
were
none
to
see
or
hear
him
,
he
fell
upon
his
knees
on
the
floor
;
and
,
hiding
his
face
in
his
hands
,
wept
such
tears
as
,
God
send
for
the
credit
of
our
nature
,
few
so
young
may
ever
have
cause
to
pour
out
before
him
!
   
<EOS>
For
a
long
time
,
Oliver
remained
motionless
in
this
attitude
.
<EOS>
The
candle
was
burning
low
in
the
socket
when
he
rose
to
his
feet
.
<EOS>
Having
gazed
cautiously
round
him
,
and
listened
intently
,
he
gently
undid
the
fastenings
of
the
door
,
and
looked
abroad
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
cold
,
dark
night
.
 
<EOS>
The
stars
seemed
,
to
the
boy
's
eyes
,
farther
from
the
earth
than
he
had
ever
seen
them
before
;
there
was
no
wind
;
and
the
sombre
shadows
thrown
by
the
trees
upon
the
ground
,
looked
sepulchral
and
death
-
like
,
from
being
so
still
.
<EOS>
He
softly
reclosed
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
Having
availed
himself
of
the
expiring
light
of
the
candle
to
tie
up
in
a
handkerchief
the
few
articles
of
wearing
apparel
he
had
,
sat
himself
down
upon
a
bench
,
to
wait
for
morning
.
   
<EOS>
With
the
first
ray
of
light
that
struggled
through
the
crevices
in
the
shutters
,
Oliver
arose
,
and
again
unbarred
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
One
timid
look
around
---
<EOS>
one
moment
's
pause
of
hesitation
<EOS>
---
he
had
closed
it
behind
him
,
and
was
in
the
open
street
.
   
<EOS>
He
looked
to
the
right
and
to
the
left
,
uncertain
whither
to
fly
.
   
<EOS>
He
remembered
to
have
seen
the
waggons
,
as
they
went
out
,
toiling
up
the
hill
.
 
<EOS>
He
took
the
same
route
;
and
arriving
at
a
footpath
across
the
fields
:
 
which
he
knew
,
after
some
distance
,
led
out
again
into
the
road
;
struck
into
it
,
and
walked
quickly
on
.
   
<EOS>
Along
this
same
footpath
,
Oliver
well
-
remembered
he
had
trotted
beside
Mr
Bumble
,
when
he
first
carried
him
to
the
workhouse
from
the
farm
.
 
<EOS>
His
way
lay
directly
in
front
of
the
cottage
.
<EOS>
His
heart
beat
quickly
when
he
bethought
himself
of
this
;
and
he
half
resolved
to
turn
back
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
come
a
long
way
though
,
and
should
lose
a
great
deal
of
time
by
doing
so
.
 
<EOS>
Besides
,
it
was
so
early
that
there
was
very
little
fear
of
his
being
seen
;
so
he
walked
on
.
   
<EOS>
He
reached
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
appearance
of
its
inmates
stirring
at
that
early
hour
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
stopped
,
and
peeped
into
the
garden
.
 
<EOS>
A
child
was
weeding
one
of
the
little
beds
;
as
he
stopped
,
he
raised
his
pale
face
and
disclosed
the
features
of
one
of
his
former
companions
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
felt
glad
to
see
him
,
before
he
went
;
for
,
though
younger
than
himself
,
he
had
been
his
little
friend
and
playmate
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
been
beaten
,
and
starved
,
and
shut
up
together
,
many
and
many
a
time
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
,
Dick
!
"
said
Oliver
,
as
the
boy
ran
to
the
gate
,
and
thrust
his
thin
arm
between
the
rails
to
greet
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
any
one
up
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nobody
but
me
,
"
replied
the
child
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
musn't
say
you
saw
me
,
Dick
,
"
said
Oliver
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
running
away
.
 
<EOS>
They
beat
and
ill
-
use
me
,
Dick
;
and
I
am
going
to
seek
my
fortune
,
some
long
way
off
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
where
.
 
<EOS>
How
pale
you
are
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
heard
the
doctor
tell
them
I
was
dying
,
"
replied
the
child
with
a
faint
smile
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
glad
to
see
you
,
dear
;
but
do
n't
stop
,
do
n't
stop
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
,
I
will
,
to
say
good
-
b'ye
to
you
,
"
replied
Oliver
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
see
you
again
,
Dick
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
I
shall
!
 
<EOS>
You
will
be
well
and
happy
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
so
,
"
replied
the
child
.
 
<EOS>
"
After
I
am
dead
,
but
not
before
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
the
doctor
must
be
right
,
Oliver
,
because
I
dream
so
much
of
Heaven
,
and
Angels
,
and
kind
faces
that
I
never
see
when
I
am
awake
.
 
<EOS>
Kiss
me
,
"
said
the
child
,
 
climbing
up
the
low
gate
,
and
flinging
his
little
arms
round
Oliver
's
neck
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Good
-
b'ye
,
dear
!
 
<EOS>
God
bless
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
blessing
was
from
a
young
child
's
lips
,
but
it
was
the
first
that
Oliver
had
ever
heard
invoked
upon
his
head
;
and
through
the
struggles
and
sufferings
,
and
troubles
and
changes
,
of
his
after
life
,
he
never
once
forgot
it
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
8
.
<EOS>
Oliver
walks
to
London
.
 
<EOS>
He
encounters
on
the
road
a
strange
sort
of
young
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
reached
the
stile
at
which
the
by
-
path
terminated
;
and
once
more
gained
the
high
-
road
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
eight
o'clock
now
.
<EOS>
Though
he
was
nearly
five
miles
away
from
the
town
,
he
ran
,
and
hid
behind
the
hedges
,
by
turns
,
till
noon
:
 
fearing
that
he
might
be
pursued
and
overtaken
.
 
<EOS>
Then
he
sat
down
to
rest
by
the
side
of
the
milestone
,
and
began
to
think
,
for
the
first
time
,
where
he
had
better
go
and
try
to
live
.
   
<EOS>
The
stone
by
which
he
was
seated
,
bore
,
in
large
characters
,
an
intimation
that
it
was
just
seventy
miles
from
that
spot
to
London
.
<EOS>
The
name
awakened
a
new
train
of
ideas
in
the
boy
's
mind
.
   
<EOS>
London
!
<EOS>
---
that
great
place
!
<EOS>
---
nobody
---
not
even
Mr
Bumble
---
could
ever
find
him
there
!
 
<EOS>
He
had
often
heard
the
old
men
in
the
workhouse
,
too
,
say
that
no
lad
of
spirit
need
want
in
London
;
and
that
there
were
ways
of
living
in
that
vast
city
,
which
those
who
had
been
bred
up
in
country
parts
had
no
idea
of
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
very
place
for
a
homeless
boy
,
who
must
die
in
the
streets
unless
some
one
helped
him
.
<EOS>
As
these
things
passed
through
his
thoughts
,
he
jumped
upon
his
feet
,
and
again
walked
forward
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
diminished
the
distance
between
himself
and
London
by
full
four
miles
more
,
before
he
recollected
how
much
he
must
undergo
ere
he
could
hope
to
reach
his
place
of
destination
.
<EOS>
As
this
consideration
forced
itself
upon
him
,
he
slackened
his
pace
a
little
,
and
meditated
upon
his
means
of
getting
there
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
crust
of
bread
,
a
coarse
shirt
,
and
two
pairs
of
stockings
,
in
his
bundle
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
penny
too
---
a
gift
of
Sowerberry
's
after
some
funeral
in
which
he
had
acquitted
himself
more
than
ordinarily
well
---
in
his
pocket
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
clean
shirt
,
"
thought
Oliver
,
"
is
a
very
comfortable
thing
;
and
so
are
two
pairs
of
darned
stockings
;
and
so
is
a
penny
;
but
they
small
helps
to
a
sixty
-
five
miles
'
walk
in
winter
time
.
"
 
<EOS>
But
Oliver
's
thoughts
,
like
those
of
most
other
people
,
although
they
were
extremely
ready
and
active
to
point
out
his
difficulties
,
were
wholly
at
a
loss
to
suggest
any
feasible
mode
of
surmounting
them
;
so
,
after
a
good
deal
of
thinking
to
no
particular
purpose
,
he
changed
his
little
bundle
over
to
the
other
shoulder
,
and
trudged
on
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
walked
twenty
miles
that
day
;
and
all
that
time
tasted
nothing
<EOS>
but
the
crust
of
dry
bread
,
and
a
few
draughts
of
water
,
which
he
begged
at
the
cottage
-
doors
by
the
road
-
side
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
night
came
,
he
turned
into
a
meadow
;
and
,
creeping
close
under
a
hay
-
rick
,
determined
to
lie
there
,
till
morning
.
 
<EOS>
He
felt
frightened
at
first
,
for
the
wind
moaned
dismally
over
the
empty
fields
:
 
and
he
was
cold
and
hungry
,
and
more
alone
than
he
had
ever
felt
before
.
 
<EOS>
Being
very
tired
with
his
walk
,
however
,
he
soon
fell
asleep
and
forgot
his
troubles
.
   
<EOS>
He
felt
cold
and
stiff
,
when
he
got
up
next
morning
,
and
so
hungry
that
he
was
obliged
to
exchange
the
penny
for
a
small
loaf
,
in
the
very
first
village
through
which
he
passed
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
walked
no
more
than
twelve
miles
,
when
night
closed
in
again
.
<EOS>
His
feet
were
sore
,
and
his
legs
so
weak
that
they
trembled
beneath
him
.
 
<EOS>
Another
night
passed
in
the
bleak
damp
air
,
made
him
worse
;
when
he
set
forward
on
his
journey
next
morning
he
could
hardly
crawl
along
.
   
<EOS>
He
waited
at
the
bottom
of
a
steep
hill
till
a
stage
-
coach
came
up
,
and
then
begged
of
the
outside
passengers
;
but
there
were
very
few
who
took
any
notice
of
him
:
 
and
even
those
told
him
to
wait
till
they
got
to
the
top
of
the
hill
,
and
then
let
them
see
how
far
he
could
run
for
a
halfpenny
.
 
<EOS>
Poor
Oliver
tried
to
keep
up
with
the
coach
a
little
way
,
but
was
unable
to
do
it
,
by
reason
of
his
fatigue
and
sore
feet
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
outsides
saw
this
,
they
put
their
halfpence
back
into
their
pockets
again
,
declaring
that
he
was
an
idle
young
dog
,
and
did
n't
deserve
anything
;
and
the
coach
rattled
away
and
left
only
a
cloud
of
dust
behind
.
   
<EOS>
In
some
villages
,
large
painted
boards
were
fixed
up
:
warning
all
persons
who
begged
within
the
district
,
that
they
would
be
sent
to
jail
.
 
<EOS>
This
frightened
Oliver
very
much
,
and
made
him
glad
to
get
out
of
those
villages
with
all
possible
expedition
.
 
<EOS>
In
others
,
he
would
stand
about
the
inn
-
yards
,
and
look
mournfully
at
every
one
who
passed
:
a
proceeding
which
generally
terminated
in
the
landlady
's
ordering
one
of
the
post
-
boys
who
were
lounging
about
,
to
drive
that
strange
boy
out
of
the
place
,
for
she
was
sure
he
had
come
to
steal
something
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
begged
at
a
farmer
's
house
,
ten
to
one
<EOS>
but
they
threatened
to
set
the
dog
on
him
;
and
when
he
showed
his
nose
in
a
shop
,
they
talked
about
the
beadle
---
which
brought
Oliver
's
heart
into
his
mouth
,
---
very
often
the
only
thing
he
had
there
,
for
many
hours
together
.
   
<EOS>
In
fact
,
if
it
had
not
been
for
a
good
-
hearted
turnpike
-
man
,
and
a
benevolent
old
lady
,
Oliver
's
troubles
would
have
been
shortened
by
the
very
same
process
which
had
put
an
end
to
his
mother
's
;
in
other
words
,
he
would
most
assuredly
have
fallen
dead
upon
the
king
's
highway
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
turnpike
-
man
gave
him
a
meal
of
bread
and
cheese
;
and
the
old
lady
,
who
had
a
shipwrecked
grandson
wandering
barefoot
in
some
distant
part
of
the
earth
,
took
pity
upon
the
poor
orphan
,
and
gave
him
what
little
she
could
afford
---
and
more
---
with
such
kind
and
gently
words
,
and
such
tears
of
sympathy
and
compassion
,
that
they
sank
deeper
into
Oliver
's
soul
,
than
all
the
sufferings
he
had
ever
undergone
.
   
<EOS>
Early
on
the
seventh
morning
after
he
had
left
his
native
place
,
Oliver
limped
slowly
into
the
little
town
of
Barnet
.
<EOS>
The
window
-
shutters
were
closed
;
the
street
was
empty
;
not
a
soul
had
awakened
to
the
business
of
the
day
.
 
<EOS>
The
sun
was
rising
in
all
its
splendid
beauty
;
but
the
light
only
served
to
show
the
boy
his
own
lonesomeness
and
desolation
,
as
he
sat
,
with
bleeding
feet
and
covered
with
dust
,
upon
a
door
-
step
.
   
<EOS>
By
degrees
,
the
shutters
were
opened
;
the
window
-
blinds
were
drawn
up
;
and
people
began
passing
to
and
fro
.
 
<EOS>
Some
few
stopped
to
gaze
at
Oliver
for
a
moment
or
two
,
or
turned
round
to
stare
at
him
as
they
hurried
by
;
but
none
relieved
him
,
or
troubled
themselves
to
inquire
how
he
came
there
.
<EOS>
He
had
no
heart
to
beg
.
<EOS>
And
there
he
sat
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
been
crouching
on
the
step
for
some
time
:
 
wondering
at
the
great
number
of
public
-
houses
(
every
other
house
in
Barnet
was
a
tavern
,
large
or
small
)
,
gazing
listlessly
at
the
coaches
as
they
passed
through
,
and
thinking
how
strange
it
seemed
that
they
could
do
,
with
ease
,
in
a
few
hours
,
what
it
had
taken
him
a
whole
week
of
courage
and
determination
beyond
his
years
to
accomplish
:
 
when
he
was
roused
by
observing
that
a
boy
,
who
had
passed
him
carelessly
some
minutes
before
,
had
returned
,
and
was
now
surveying
him
most
earnestly
from
the
opposite
side
of
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
He
took
little
heed
of
this
at
first
;
but
the
boy
remained
in
the
same
attitude
of
close
observation
so
long
,
that
Oliver
raised
his
head
,
and
returned
his
steady
look
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
this
,
the
boy
crossed
over
;
and
walking
close
up
to
Oliver
,
said
   
"
Hullo
,
my
covey
!
 
<EOS>
What
's
the
row
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
boy
who
addressed
this
inquiry
to
the
young
wayfarer
,
was
about
his
own
age
:
 
but
one
of
the
queerest
looking
boys
that
Oliver
had
even
seen
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
snub
-
nosed
,
flat
-
browed
,
common
-
faced
boy
enough
;
and
as
dirty
a
juvenile
as
one
would
wish
to
see
;
but
he
had
about
him
all
the
airs
and
manners
of
a
man
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
short
of
his
age
:
 
with
rather
bow
-
legs
,
and
little
,
sharp
,
ugly
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
His
hat
was
stuck
on
the
top
of
his
head
so
lightly
,
that
it
threatened
to
fall
off
every
moment
---
and
would
have
done
so
,
very
often
,
if
the
wearer
had
not
had
a
knack
of
every
now
and
then
giving
his
head
a
sudden
twitch
,
which
brought
it
back
to
its
old
place
again
.
 
<EOS>
He
wore
a
man
's
coat
,
which
reached
nearly
to
his
heels
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
turned
the
cuffs
back
,
half
-
way
up
his
arm
,
to
get
his
hands
out
of
the
sleeves
:
apparently
with
the
ultimated
view
of
thrusting
them
into
the
pockets
of
his
corduroy
trousers
;
for
there
he
kept
them
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
,
altogether
,
as
roystering
and
swaggering
a
young
gentleman
as
ever
stood
four
feet
six
,
or
something
less
,
in
the
bluchers
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hullo
,
my
covey
!
 
<EOS>
What
's
the
row
?
"
said
this
strange
young
gentleman
to
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
hungry
and
tired
,
"
replied
Oliver
:
 
<EOS>
the
tears
standing
in
his
eyes
as
he
spoke
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
walked
a
long
way
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
walking
these
seven
days
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Walking
for
sivin
days
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
young
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
I
see
.
<EOS>
Beak
's
order
,
eh
?
 
<EOS>
But
,
"
he
added
,
noticing
Oliver
's
look
of
surprise
,
"
I
suppose
you
do
n't
know
what
a
beak
is
,
my
flash
com
-
pan
-
i
-
on
.
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver
mildly
replied
,
that
he
had
always
heard
a
bird
's
mouth
described
by
the
term
in
question
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
eyes
,
how
green
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
young
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
a
beak
's
a
madgst'rate
;
and
when
you
walk
by
a
beak
's
order
,
it
's
not
straight
forerd
,
but
always
agoing
up
,
and
niver
a
coming
down
agin
.
 
<EOS>
Was
you
never
on
the
mill
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
mill
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
mill
!
 
<EOS>
Why
,
THE
