mill
---
the
mill
as
takes
up
so
little
room
that
it
'll
work
inside
a
Stone
Jug
;
and
always
goes
better
when
the
wind
's
low
with
people
,
than
when
it
's
high
;
acos
then
they
ca
n't
get
workmen
.
 
<EOS>
But
come
,
"
said
the
young
gentleman
;
"
you
want
grub
,
and
you
shall
have
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
at
low
-
water
-
mark
myself
---
<EOS>
only
one
bob
and
a
magpie
;
but
,
as
far
as
it
goes
,
I
'll
fork
out
and
stump
.
 
<EOS>
Up
with
you
on
your
pins
.
 
<EOS>
There
!
 
<EOS>
Now
then
!
   
<EOS>
Morrice
!
"
   
<EOS>
Assisting
Oliver
to
rise
,
the
young
gentleman
took
him
to
an
adjacent
chandler
's
shop
,
where
he
purchased
a
sufficiency
of
ready
-
dressed
ham
and
a
half
-
quartern
loaf
,
or
,
as
he
himself
expressed
it
,
"
a
fourpenny
bran
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
the
ham
being
kept
clean
and
preserved
from
dust
,
by
the
ingenious
expedient
of
making
a
hole
in
the
loaf
by
pulling
out
a
portion
of
the
crumb
,
and
stuffing
it
therein
.
 
<EOS>
Taking
the
bread
under
his
arm
,
the
young
gentlman
turned
into
a
small
public
-
house
,
and
led
the
way
to
a
tap
-
room
in
the
rear
of
the
premises
.
<EOS>
Here
,
a
pot
of
beer
was
brought
in
,
by
direction
of
the
mysterious
youth
;
and
Oliver
,
falling
to
,
at
his
new
friend
's
bidding
,
made
a
long
and
hearty
meal
,
during
the
progress
of
which
the
strange
boy
eyed
him
from
time
to
time
with
great
attention
.
   
<EOS>
"
Going
to
London
?
<EOS>
"
said
the
strange
boy
,
when
Oliver
had
at
length
concluded
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
   
"
Got
any
lodgings
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
   
"
Money
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
strange
boy
whistled
;
and
put
his
arms
into
his
pockets
,
as
far
as
the
big
coat
-
sleeves
would
let
them
go
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
live
in
London
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
,
when
I
'm
at
home
,
"
replied
the
boy
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
you
want
some
place
to
sleep
in
to
-
night
,
do
n't
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
indeed
,
"
answered
Oliver
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
slept
under
a
roof
since
I
left
the
country
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Do
n't
fret
your
eyelids
on
that
score
.
<EOS>
"
said
the
young
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
've
got
to
be
in
London
to
-
night
;
and
I
know
a
'
spectable
old
gentleman
as
lives
there
,
wot'll
give
you
lodgings
for
nothink
,
and
never
ask
for
the
change
---
that
is
,
if
any
genelman
he
knows
interduces
you
.
 
<EOS>
And
do
n't
he
know
me
?
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
no
!
   
<EOS>
Not
in
the
least
!
 
<EOS>
By
no
means
.
 
<EOS>
Certainly
not
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
young
gentelman
smiled
,
as
if
to
intimate
that
the
latter
fragments
of
discourse
were
playfully
ironical
;
and
finished
the
beer
as
he
did
so
.
   
<EOS>
This
unexpected
offer
of
shelter
was
too
tempting
to
be
resisted
;
especially
as
it
was
immediately
followed
up
,
by
the
assurance
that
the
old
gentleman
referred
to
,
would
doubtless
provide
Oliver
with
a
comfortable
place
,
without
loss
of
time
.
 
<EOS>
This
led
to
a
more
friendly
and
confidential
dialogue
;
from
which
Oliver
discovered
that
his
friend
's
name
was
Jack
Dawkins
,
and
that
he
was
a
peculiar
pet
and
protege
of
the
elderly
gentleman
before
mentioned
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dawkin
's
appearance
did
not
say
a
vast
deal
in
favour
of
the
comforts
which
his
patron
's
interest
obtained
for
those
whom
he
took
under
his
protection
;
but
,
as
he
had
a
rather
flightly
and
dissolute
mode
of
conversing
,
and
furthermore
avowed
that
among
his
intimate
friends
he
was
better
known
by
the
sobriquet
of
"
The
Artful
Dodger
,
"
<EOS>
Oliver
concluded
that
,
being
of
a
dissipated
and
careless
turn
,
the
moral
precepts
of
his
benefactor
had
hitherto
been
thrown
away
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
Under
this
impression
,
he
secretly
resolved
to
cultivate
the
good
opinion
of
the
old
gentleman
as
quickly
as
possible
;
and
,
if
he
found
the
Dodger
incorrigible
,
as
he
more
than
half
suspected
he
should
,
to
decline
the
honour
of
his
farther
acquaintance
.
   
<EOS>
As
John
Dawkins
objected
to
their
entering
London
before
nightfall
,
it
was
nearly
eleven
o'clock
when
they
reached
the
turnpike
at
Islington
.
 
<EOS>
They
crossed
from
the
Angel
into
St
John
's
Road
;
struck
down
the
small
street
which
terminates
at
Sadler
's
Wells
Theatre
;
through
Exmouth
Street
and
Coppice
Row
;
down
the
little
court
by
the
side
of
the
workhouse
;
across
the
classic
ground
which
once
bore
the
name
of
Hockley
-
in
-
the
-
Hole
;
thence
into
Little
Saffron
Hill
;
and
so
into
Saffron
Hill
the
Great
:
 
along
which
the
Dodger
scudded
at
a
rapid
pace
,
directing
Oliver
to
follow
close
at
his
heels
.
   
<EOS>
Although
Oliver
had
enough
to
occupy
his
attention
in
keeping
sight
of
his
leader
,
he
could
not
help
bestowing
a
few
hasty
glances
on
either
side
of
the
way
,
as
he
passed
along
.
 
<EOS>
A
dirtier
or
more
wretched
place
he
had
never
seen
.
 
<EOS>
The
street
was
very
narrow
and
muddy
,
and
the
air
was
impregnated
with
filthy
odours
.
   
<EOS>
There
were
a
good
many
small
shops
;
but
the
only
stock
in
trade
appeared
to
be
heaps
of
children
,
who
,
even
at
that
time
of
night
,
were
crawling
in
and
out
at
the
doors
,
or
screaming
from
the
inside
.
 
<EOS>
The
sole
places
that
seemed
to
prosper
amid
the
general
blight
of
the
place
,
were
the
public
-
houses
;
and
in
them
,
the
lowest
orders
of
Irish
were
wrangling
with
might
and
main
.
<EOS>
Covered
ways
and
yards
,
which
here
and
there
diverged
from
the
main
street
,
disclosed
little
knots
of
houses
,
where
drunken
men
and
women
were
positively
wallowing
in
filth
;
and
from
several
of
the
door
-
ways
,
great
ill
-
looking
fellows
were
cautiously
emerging
,
bound
,
to
all
appearance
,
on
no
very
well
-
disposed
or
harmless
errands
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
was
just
considering
whether
he
had
n't
better
run
away
,
when
they
reached
the
bottom
of
the
hill
.
 
<EOS>
His
conductor
,
catching
him
by
the
arm
,
pushed
open
the
door
of
a
house
near
Field
Lane
;
and
drawing
him
into
the
passage
,
closed
it
behind
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
then
!
"
cried
a
voice
from
below
,
in
reply
to
a
whistle
from
the
Dodger
.
   
<EOS>
"
Plummy
and
slam
!
<EOS>
"
was
the
reply
.
   
<EOS>
This
seemed
to
be
some
watchword
or
signal
that
all
was
right
;
for
the
light
of
a
feeble
candle
gleamed
on
the
wall
at
the
remote
end
of
the
passage
;
and
a
man
's
face
peeped
out
,
from
where
a
balustrade
of
the
old
kitchen
staircase
had
been
broken
away
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
two
on
you
,
"
said
the
man
,
thrusting
the
candle
farther
out
,
and
shielding
his
eyes
with
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
's
the
t'other
one
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
new
pal
,
"
replied
Jack
Dawkins
,
pulling
Oliver
forward
.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
did
he
come
from
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Greenland
.
 
<EOS>
Is
Fagin
upstairs
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
he
's
a
sortin
'
the
wipes
.
 
<EOS>
Up
with
you
!
"
 
<EOS>
The
candle
was
drawn
back
,
and
the
face
disappeared
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
,
groping
his
way
with
one
hand
,
and
having
the
other
firmly
grasped
by
his
companion
,
ascended
with
much
difficulty
the
dark
and
broken
stairs
:
 
<EOS>
which
his
conductor
mounted
with
an
ease
and
expedition
that
showed
he
was
well
acquainted
with
them
.
   
<EOS>
He
threw
open
the
door
of
a
back
-
room
,
and
drew
Oliver
in
after
him
.
   
<EOS>
The
walls
and
ceiling
of
the
room
were
perfectly
black
with
age
and
dirt
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
deal
table
before
the
fire
:
 
upon
which
were
a
candle
,
stuck
in
a
ginger
-
beer
bottle
,
two
or
three
pewter
pots
,
a
loaf
and
butter
,
and
a
plate
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
frying
-
pan
,
which
was
on
the
fire
,
and
which
was
secured
to
the
mantelshelf
by
a
string
,
some
sausages
were
cooking
;
and
standing
over
them
,
with
a
toasting
-
fork
in
his
hand
,
was
a
very
old
shrivelled
Jew
,
whose
villainous
-
looking
and
repulsive
face
was
obscured
by
a
quantity
of
matted
red
hair
.
<EOS>
He
was
dressed
in
a
greasy
flannel
gown
,
with
his
throat
bare
;
and
seemed
to
be
dividing
his
attention
between
the
frying
-
pan
and
the
clothes
-
horse
,
over
which
a
great
number
of
silk
handkerchiefsl
were
hanging
.
 
<EOS>
Several
rough
beds
made
of
old
sacks
,
were
huddled
side
by
side
on
the
floor
.
<EOS>
Seated
round
the
table
were
four
or
five
boys
,
none
older
than
the
Dodger
,
smoking
long
clay
pipes
,
and
drinking
spirits
with
the
air
of
middle
-
aged
men
.
 
<EOS>
These
all
crowded
about
their
associate
as
he
whispered
a
few
words
to
the
Jew
;
and
then
turned
round
and
grinned
at
Oliver
.
 
<EOS>
So
did
the
Jew
himself
,
toasting
-
fork
in
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
him
,
Fagin
,
"
said
Jack
Dawkins
;
"
my
friend
Oliver
Twist
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
Jew
grinned
;
and
,
making
a
low
obeisance
to
Oliver
,
took
him
by
the
hand
,
and
hoped
he
should
have
the
honour
of
his
intimate
acquaintance
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
this
,
the
young
gentleman
with
the
pipes
came
round
him
,
and
shook
both
his
hands
very
hard
---
especially
the
one
in
which
he
held
his
little
bundle
.
 
<EOS>
One
young
gentleman
was
very
anxious
to
hang
up
his
cap
for
him
;
and
another
was
so
obliging
as
to
put
his
hands
in
his
pockets
,
in
order
that
,
as
he
was
very
tired
,
he
might
not
have
the
trouble
of
emptying
them
,
himself
,
when
he
went
to
bed
.
 
<EOS>
These
civilities
would
probably
be
extended
much
farther
,
but
for
a
liberal
exercise
of
the
Jew
's
toasting
-
fork
on
the
heads
and
shoulders
of
the
affectionate
youths
who
offered
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
are
very
glad
to
see
you
,
Oliver
,
very
,
"
said
the
Jew
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Dodger
,
take
off
the
sausages
;
and
draw
a
tub
near
the
fire
for
Oliver
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
,
you
're
a
-
staring
at
the
pocket
-
handkerchiefs
!
<EOS>
eh
,
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
a
good
many
of
'em
,
ai
n't
there
?
<EOS>
We
've
just
looked
'em
out
,
ready
for
the
wash
;
that
's
all
,
Oliver
;
that
's
all
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
latter
part
of
this
speech
,
was
hailed
by
a
boisterous
shout
from
all
the
hopeful
pupils
of
the
merry
old
gentleman
.
<EOS>
In
the
midst
of
which
they
went
to
supper
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
ate
his
share
,
and
the
Jew
then
mixed
him
a
glass
of
hot
gin
-
and
-
water
:
 
<EOS>
telling
him
he
must
drink
it
off
directly
,
because
another
gentleman
wanted
the
tumbler
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
did
as
he
was
desired
.
 
<EOS>
Immediately
afterwards
he
felt
himself
gently
lifted
on
to
one
of
the
sacks
;
and
then
he
sunk
into
a
deep
sleep
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
9
.
<EOS>
Containing
further
particulars
concerning
the
pleasant
old
gentleman
,
and
his
hopeful
pupils
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
late
next
morning
when
Oliver
awoke
,
from
a
sound
,
long
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
other
person
in
the
room
but
the
old
Jew
,
who
was
boiling
some
coffee
in
a
saucepan
for
breakfast
,
and
whistling
softly
to
himself
as
he
stirred
it
round
and
round
,
with
an
iron
spoon
.
 
<EOS>
He
would
stop
every
now
and
then
to
listen
when
there
was
the
least
noise
below
:
and
when
he
had
satistified
himself
,
he
would
go
on
whistling
and
stirring
again
,
as
before
.
   
<EOS>
Although
Oliver
had
roused
himself
from
sleep
,
he
was
not
thoroughly
awake
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
a
drowsy
state
,
between
sleeping
and
waking
,
when
you
dream
more
in
five
minutes
with
your
eyes
half
open
,
and
yourself
half
conscious
of
everything
that
is
passing
around
you
,
than
you
would
in
five
nights
with
your
eyes
fast
closed
,
and
your
senses
wrapt
in
perfect
unconsciousness
.
 
<EOS>
At
such
time
,
a
mortal
knows
just
enough
of
what
his
mind
is
doing
,
to
form
some
glimmering
conception
of
its
mighty
powers
,
its
bounding
from
earth
and
spurning
time
and
space
,
when
freed
from
the
restraint
of
its
corporeal
associate
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
was
precisely
in
this
condition
.
 
<EOS>
He
saw
the
Jew
with
his
half
-
closed
eyes
;
heard
his
low
whistling
;
and
recognised
the
sound
of
the
spoon
grating
against
the
saucepan
's
sides
:
 
and
yet
the
self
-
same
senses
were
mentally
engaged
,
at
the
same
time
,
in
busy
action
with
almost
everybody
he
had
ever
known
.
   
<EOS>
When
the
coffee
was
done
,
the
Jew
drew
the
saucepan
to
the
hob
.
<EOS>
Standing
,
then
in
an
irresolute
attitude
for
a
few
minutes
,
as
if
he
did
not
well
know
how
to
employ
himself
,
he
turned
round
and
looked
at
Oliver
,
and
called
him
by
his
name
.
 
<EOS>
He
did
not
answer
,
and
was
to
all
appearances
asleep
.
   
<EOS>
After
satisfiying
himself
upon
this
head
,
the
Jew
stepped
gently
to
the
door
:
 
which
he
fastened
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
drew
forth
:
 
as
it
seemed
to
Oliver
,
from
some
trap
in
the
floor
:
 
a
small
box
,
which
he
placed
carefully
on
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
His
eyes
glistened
as
he
raised
the
lid
,
and
looked
in
.
 
<EOS>
Dragging
an
old
chair
to
the
table
,
he
sat
down
;
and
took
from
it
a
magnificent
gold
watch
,
sparkling
with
jewels
.
   
<EOS>
"
Aha
!
"
said
the
Jew
,
shrugging
up
his
shoulders
,
and
distorting
every
feature
with
a
hideous
grin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Clever
dogs
!
 
<EOS>
Clever
dogs
!
<EOS>
Staunch
to
the
last
!
 
<EOS>
Never
told
the
old
parson
where
they
were
.
<EOS>
Never
poached
upon
old
Fagin
!
 
<EOS>
And
why
should
they
?
 
<EOS>
It
would
n't
have
loosened
the
knot
,
or
kept
the
drop
up
,
a
minute
longer
.
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
no
!
 
<EOS>
Fine
fellows
!
 
<EOS>
Fine
fellows
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
these
,
and
other
muttered
reflections
of
the
like
nature
,
the
Jew
once
more
deposited
the
watch
in
its
place
of
safety
.
 
<EOS>
At
least
half
a
dozen
more
were
severally
drawn
forth
from
the
same
box
,
and
surveyed
with
equal
pleasure
;
besides
rings
,
brooches
,
bracelet
,
and
other
articles
of
jewellery
,
of
such
magnificent
materials
,
and
costly
workmanship
,
that
Oliver
had
no
idea
,
even
of
their
names
.
   
<EOS>
Having
replaced
these
trinkets
,
the
Jew
took
out
another
:
 
so
small
that
it
lay
in
the
palm
of
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
There
seemed
to
be
some
very
minute
inscription
on
it
;
for
the
Jew
laid
it
flat
upon
the
table
,
and
shading
it
with
his
hand
,
pored
over
it
,
long
and
earnestly
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
he
put
it
down
,
as
if
despairing
of
success
;
and
,
leaning
back
in
his
chair
,
muttered
:
   
"
What
a
fine
thing
capital
punishment
is
!
 
<EOS>
Dead
men
never
repent
;
dead
men
never
bring
awkward
stories
to
light
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
,
it
's
a
fine
thing
for
the
trade
!
 
<EOS>
Five
of
'em
strung
up
in
a
row
,
and
none
left
to
play
booty
,
or
turn
white
-
livered
!
"
   
<EOS>
As
the
Jew
uttered
these
words
,
his
bright
dark
eyes
,
which
had
been
staring
vacantly
before
him
,
fell
on
Oliver
's
face
;
the
boy
's
eyes
were
fixed
on
his
in
mute
curiousity
;
and
although
the
recognition
was
only
for
an
instant
---
for
the
briefest
space
of
time
that
can
possibly
be
conceived
---
it
was
enough
to
show
the
old
man
that
he
had
been
observed
.
   
<EOS>
He
closed
the
lid
of
the
box
with
a
loud
crash
;
and
,
laying
his
hand
on
a
bread
knife
which
was
on
the
table
,
started
furiously
up
.
 
<EOS>
He
trembled
very
much
though
;
for
,
even
in
his
terror
,
Oliver
could
see
that
the
knife
quivered
in
the
air
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
that
?
"
said
the
Jew
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
watch
me
for
?
 
<EOS>
Why
are
you
awake
?
 
<EOS>
What
have
you
seen
?
 
<EOS>
Speak
out
,
boy
!
<EOS>
Quick
---
quick
!
<EOS>
for
your
life
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
n't
able
to
sleep
any
longer
,
sir
,
"
replied
Oliver
,
meekly
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
sorry
if
I
have
disturbed
you
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
were
not
awake
an
hour
ago
?
"
said
the
Jew
,
scowling
fiercely
on
the
boy
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
!
 
<EOS>
No
,
indeed
!
"
replied
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
sure
?
<EOS>
"
cried
the
Jew
:
 
with
a
still
fiercer
look
than
before
:
 
and
a
threatening
attitude
.
   
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
word
I
was
not
,
sir
,
"
replied
Oliver
,
earnestly
.
<EOS>
"
I
was
not
,
indeed
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Tush
,
tush
,
my
dear
!
"
said
the
Jew
,
abruptly
resuming
his
old
manner
,
and
playing
with
the
knife
a
little
,
before
he
laid
it
down
;
as
if
to
induce
the
belief
that
he
had
caught
it
up
,
in
mere
sport
.
 
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
know
that
,
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
I
only
tried
to
frighten
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
're
a
brave
boy
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
you
're
a
brave
boy
,
Oliver
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
Jew
rubbed
his
hands
with
a
chuckle
,
but
glanced
uneasily
at
the
box
,
notwithstanding
.
   
<EOS>
"
Did
you
see
any
of
these
pretty
things
,
my
dear
?
"
said
the
Jew
,
laying
his
hand
upon
it
after
a
short
pause
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
replied
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
Jew
,
turning
rather
pale
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
---
they
're
mine
,
Oliver
;
my
little
property
.
 
<EOS>
All
I
have
to
live
upon
,
in
my
old
age
.
 
<EOS>
The
folks
call
me
a
miser
,
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
Only
a
miser
;
that
's
all
.
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver
thought
the
old
gentleman
must
be
a
decided
miser
to
live
in
such
a
dirty
place
,
with
so
many
watches
;
but
,
thinking
that
perhaps
his
fondness
for
the
Dodger
and
the
other
boys
,
cost
him
a
good
deal
of
money
,
he
only
cast
a
deferential
look
at
the
Jew
,
and
asked
if
he
might
get
up
.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
my
dear
,
certainly
,
"
replied
the
old
gentleman
.
"
<EOS>
Stay
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
a
pitcher
of
water
in
the
corner
by
the
door
.
<EOS>
Bring
it
here
;
and
I
'll
give
you
a
basin
to
wash
in
,
my
dear
.
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver
got
up
;
walked
across
the
room
;
and
stooped
for
an
instant
to
raise
the
pitcher
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
turned
his
head
,
the
box
was
gone
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
scarcely
washed
himself
,
and
made
everything
tidy
,
by
emptying
the
basin
out
of
the
window
,
agreeably
to
the
Jew
's
directions
,
when
the
Dodger
returned
:
 
accompanied
by
a
very
sprightly
young
friend
,
whom
Oliver
had
seen
smoking
on
the
previous
night
,
and
who
was
now
formally
introduced
to
him
as
Charley
Bates
.
 
<EOS>
The
four
sat
down
,
to
breakfast
,
on
the
coffee
,
and
some
hot
rolls
and
ham
which
the
Dodger
had
brought
home
in
the
crown
of
his
hat
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
"
said
the
Jew
,
glancing
slyly
at
Oliver
,
and
addressing
himself
to
the
Dodger
,
"
I
hope
you
've
been
at
work
this
morning
,
my
dears
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hard
,
"
replied
the
Dodger
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
nails
,
"
added
Charley
Bates
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
boys
,
good
boys
!
"
said
the
Jew
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
have
you
got
,
Dodger
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
couple
of
pocket
-
books
,
"
replied
that
young
gentlman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Lined
?
"
inquired
the
Jew
,
with
eagerness
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pretty
well
,
"
replied
the
Dodger
,
producing
two
pocket
-
books
;
one
green
,
and
the
other
red
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
so
heavy
as
they
might
be
,
"
said
the
Jew
,
after
looking
at
the
insides
carefully
;
"
but
very
neat
and
nicely
made
.
 
<EOS>
Ingenious
workman
,
ai
n't
he
,
Oliver
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
indeed
,
sir
,
"
said
Oliver
.
 
<EOS>
At
which
Mr
Charles
Bates
laughed
uproariously
;
very
much
to
the
amazement
of
Oliver
,
who
saw
nothing
to
laugh
at
,
in
anything
that
had
passed
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
what
have
you
got
,
my
dear
?
"
said
Fagin
to
Charley
Bates
.
   
<EOS>
"
Wipes
,
"
replied
Master
Bates
;
at
the
same
time
producing
four
pocket
-
handkerchiefs
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
"
said
the
Jew
,
inspecting
them
closely
;
"
they
're
very
good
ones
,
very
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
n't
marked
them
well
,
though
,
Charley
;
so
the
marks
shall
be
picked
out
with
a
needle
,
and
we
'll
teach
Oliver
how
to
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
Shall
us
,
Oliver
,
eh
?
 
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
please
,
sir
,
"
said
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
'd
like
to
be
able
to
make
pocket
-
handkerchiefs
as
easy
as
Charley
Bates
,
would
n't
you
,
my
dear
?
"
said
the
Jew
.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
much
,
indeed
,
if
you
'll
teach
me
,
sir
,
"
replied
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
Master
Bates
saw
something
so
exquisitely
ludicrous
in
this
reply
,
that
he
burst
into
another
laugh
;
which
laugh
,
meeting
the
coffee
he
was
drinking
,
and
carrying
it
down
some
wrong
channel
,
very
nearly
terminated
in
his
premature
suffocation
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
so
jolly
green
!
"
said
Charley
when
he
recovered
,
as
an
apology
to
the
company
for
his
unpolite
behaviour
.
   
<EOS>
The
Dodger
said
nothing
,
but
he
smoothed
Oliver
's
hair
over
his
eyes
,
and
said
he
'd
know
better
,
by
and
by
;
upon
which
the
old
gentleman
,
observing
Oliver
's
colour
mounting
,
changed
the
subject
by
asking
whether
there
had
been
much
of
a
crowd
at
the
execution
that
morning
?
 
<EOS>
This
made
him
wonder
more
and
more
;
for
it
was
plain
from
the
replies
of
the
two
boys
that
they
had
both
been
there
;
and
Oliver
naturally
wondered
how
they
could
possibly
have
found
time
to
be
so
very
industrious
.
   
<EOS>
When
the
breakfast
was
cleared
away
;
the
merry
old
gentlman
and
the
two
boys
played
at
a
very
curious
and
uncommon
game
,
which
was
performed
in
this
way
.
 
<EOS>
The
merry
old
gentleman
,
placing
a
snuff
-
box
in
one
pocket
of
his
trousers
,
a
note
-
case
in
the
other
,
and
a
watch
in
his
waistcoat
pocket
,
with
a
guard
-
chain
round
his
neck
,
and
sticking
a
mock
diamond
pin
in
his
shirt
<EOS>
:
buttoned
his
coat
tight
round
him
,
and
putting
his
spectacle
-
case
and
handkerchief
in
his
pockets
,
trotted
up
and
down
the
room
with
a
stick
,
in
imitation
of
the
manner
in
which
old
gentlmen
walk
about
the
streets
any
hour
in
the
day
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
he
stopped
at
the
fire
-
place
,
and
sometimes
at
the
door
,
making
believe
that
he
was
staring
with
all
his
might
into
shop
-
windows
.
 
<EOS>
At
such
times
,
he
would
look
constantly
round
him
,
for
fear
of
thieves
,
and
would
keep
slapping
all
his
pockets
in
turn
,
to
see
that
he
had
n't
lost
anything
,
in
such
a
very
funny
and
natural
manner
,
that
Oliver
laughed
till
the
tears
ran
down
his
face
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
time
,
the
two
boys
followed
him
closely
about
:
 
getting
out
of
his
sight
,
so
nimbly
,
every
time
he
turned
round
,
that
it
was
impossible
to
follow
their
motions
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
,
the
Dodger
trod
upon
his
toes
,
or
ran
upon
his
boot
accidentally
,
while
Charley
Bates
stumbled
up
against
him
behind
;
and
in
that
one
moment
they
took
from
him
,
with
the
most
extraordinary
rapidity
,
snuff
-
box
,
note
-
case
,
watch
-
guard
,
chain
,
shirt
-
pin
,
pocket
-
handkerchief
,
even
the
spectacle
-
case
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
old
gentlman
felt
a
hand
in
any
one
of
his
pockets
,
he
cried
out
where
it
was
;
and
then
the
game
began
all
over
again
.
   
<EOS>
When
this
game
had
been
played
a
great
many
times
,
a
couple
of
young
ladies
called
to
see
the
young
gentleman
;
one
of
whom
was
named
Bet
,
and
the
other
Nancy
.
 
<EOS>
They
wore
a
good
deal
of
hair
,
not
very
neatly
turned
up
behind
,
and
were
rather
untidy
about
the
shoes
and
stockings
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
not
exactly
pretty
,
perhaps
;
but
they
had
a
great
deal
of
colour
in
their
faces
,
and
looked
quite
stout
and
hearty
.
 
<EOS>
Being
remarkably
free
and
agreeable
in
their
manners
<EOS>
,
Oliver
thought
them
very
nice
girls
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
As
there
is
no
doubt
they
were
.
   
<EOS>
The
visitors
stopped
a
long
time
.
 
<EOS>
Spirits
were
produced
,
in
consequence
of
one
of
the
young
ladies
complaining
of
a
coldness
in
her
inside
;
and
the
conversation
took
a
very
convivial
and
improving
turn
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
Charley
Bates
expressed
his
opinion
that
it
was
time
to
pad
the
hoof
.
 
<EOS>
This
,
it
occurred
to
Oliver
,
must
be
French
for
going
out
;
for
directly
afterwards
,
the
Dodger
,
and
Charley
,
and
the
two
young
ladies
,
went
away
together
,
having
been
kindly
furnished
by
the
amiable
old
Jew
with
money
to
spend
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Fagin
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
a
pleasant
life
,
is
n't
it
?
   
<EOS>
They
have
gone
out
for
the
day
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Have
they
done
work
,
sir
?
"
inquired
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
the
Jew
;
<EOS>
"
that
is
,
unless
they
should
unexpectedly
come
across
any
,
when
they
are
out
;
and
they
wo
n't
neglect
it
,
if
they
do
,
my
dear
,
depend
upon
it
.
 
<EOS>
Make
'em
your
models
,
my
dear
.
   
<EOS>
Make
'em
your
models
,
"
tapping
the
fire
-
shovel
on
the
hearth
to
add
force
to
his
words
;
"
do
everything
they
bid
you
,
and
take
their
advice
in
all
matters
---
especially
the
Dodger
's
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
He
'll
be
a
great
man
himself
,
and
will
make
you
one
too
,
if
you
take
pattern
by
him
.
<EOS>
---
Is
my
handkerchief
hanging
out
of
my
pocket
,
my
dear
?
"
said
the
Jew
,
stopping
short
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
said
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
See
if
you
can
take
it
out
,
without
my
feeling
it
;
as
you
saw
them
do
,
when
we
were
at
play
this
morning
.
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver
held
up
the
bottom
of
the
pocket
with
one
hand
,
as
he
had
seen
the
Dodger
hold
it
,
and
drew
the
handkerchief
lighty
out
of
it
with
the
other
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
gone
?
"
cried
the
Jew
.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
it
is
,
sir
,
"
said
Oliver
,
showing
it
in
his
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
clever
boy
,
my
dear
,
"
said
the
playful
old
gentleman
,
patting
Oliver
on
the
head
approvingly
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
never
saw
a
sharper
lad
.
 
<EOS>
Here
's
a
shilling
for
you
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
go
on
,
in
this
way
,
you
'll
be
the
greatest
man
of
the
time
.
 
<EOS>
And
now
come
here
,
and
I
'll
show
you
how
to
take
the
marks
out
of
the
handkerchiefs
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver
wondered
what
picking
the
old
gentleman
's
pocket
in
play
,
had
to
do
with
his
chances
of
being
a
great
man
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
thinking
that
the
Jew
,
being
so
much
his
senior
,
must
know
best
,
he
followed
him
quietly
to
the
table
,
and
was
soon
deeply
involved
in
his
new
study
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
10
.
<EOS>
Oliver
becomes
better
acquainted
with
the
characters
of
his
new
associates
;
and
purchases
experience
at
a
high
price
.
<EOS>
Being
a
short
,
but
very
important
chapter
,
in
this
history
.
 
<EOS>
For
many
days
,
Oliver
remained
in
the
Jew
's
room
,
picking
the
marks
out
of
the
pocket
-
handkerchief
,
(
of
which
a
great
number
were
brought
home
,
)
and
sometimes
taking
part
in
the
game
already
described
:
 
which
the
two
boys
and
the
Jew
played
,
regularly
,
every
morning
.
<EOS>
At
length
,
he
began
to
languish
for
fresh
air
,
and
took
many
occasions
of
earnestly
entreating
the
old
gentleman
to
allow
him
to
go
out
to
work
with
his
two
companions
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
was
rendered
the
more
anxious
to
be
actively
employed
,
by
what
he
had
seen
of
the
stern
morality
of
the
old
gentleman
's
character
.
 
<EOS>
Whenever
the
Dodger
or
Charley
Bates
came
home
at
night
,
empty
-
handed
,
he
would
expatiate
with
great
vehemence
on
the
misery
of
idle
and
lazy
habits
;
and
would
enforce
upon
them
the
necessity
of
an
active
life
,
by
sending
them
supperless
to
bed
.
 
<EOS>
On
one
occasion
,
indeed
,
he
even
went
so
far
as
to
knock
them
both
down
a
flight
of
stairs
;
but
this
was
carrying
out
his
virtuous
precepts
to
an
unusual
extent
.
   
<EOS>
At
length
,
one
morning
,
Oliver
obtained
the
permission
he
had
so
eagerly
sought
.
 
<EOS>
There
had
been
no
handkerchiefs
to
work
upon
,
for
two
or
three
days
,
and
the
dinners
had
been
rather
meagre
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
these
were
reasons
for
the
old
gentleman
's
giving
his
assent
;
but
,
whether
they
were
or
no
,
he
told
Oliver
he
might
go
,
and
placed
him
under
the
joint
guardianship
of
Charley
Bates
,
and
his
friend
the
Dodger
.
   
<EOS>
The
three
boys
sallied
out
;
the
Dodger
with
his
coat
-
sleeves
tucked
up
,
and
his
hat
cocked
,
as
usual
;
Master
Bates
sauntering
along
with
his
hands
in
his
pockets
;
and
Oliver
between
them
,
wondering
where
they
were
going
,
and
what
branch
of
manufacture
he
would
be
instructed
in
,
first
.
   
<EOS>
The
pace
at
which
they
went
,
was
such
a
very
lazy
,
ill
-
looking
saunter
,
that
Oliver
soon
began
to
think
his
companions
were
going
to
deceive
the
old
gentleman
,
by
not
going
to
work
at
all
.
<EOS>
The
Dodger
had
a
vicious
propensity
,
too
,
of
pulling
the
caps
from
the
heads
of
small
boys
and
tossing
them
down
areas
;
while
Charley
Bates
exhibited
some
very
loose
notions
concerning
the
rights
of
property
,
by
pilfering
divers
apples
and
onions
from
the
stalls
at
the
kennel
sides
,
and
thrusting
them
into
pockets
which
were
so
surprisingly
capacious
,
that
they
seemed
to
undermine
his
whole
suit
of
clothes
in
every
direction
.
 
<EOS>
These
things
looked
so
bad
,
that
Oliver
was
on
the
point
of
declaring
his
intention
of
seeking
his
way
back
,
in
the
best
way
he
could
;
when
his
thoughts
were
suddenly
directed
into
another
channel
,
by
a
very
mysterious
change
of
behaviour
on
the
part
of
the
Dodger
.
   
<EOS>
They
were
just
emerging
from
a
narrow
court
not
far
from
the
open
square
in
Clerkenwell
,
which
is
yet
called
,
by
some
strange
perversion
of
terms
,
"
The
Green
"
:
 
when
the
Dodger
made
a
sudden
stop
;
and
,
laying
his
finger
on
his
lip
,
drew
his
companions
back
again
,
with
the
greatest
caution
and
circumspection
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
?
"
demanded
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
"
replied
the
Dodger
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
see
that
old
cove
at
the
book
-
stall
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
old
gentleman
over
the
way
?
<EOS>
"
said
Oliver
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
see
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
'll
do
,
"
said
the
Doger
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
prime
plant
,
"
observed
Master
Charley
Bates
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
looked
from
one
to
the
other
,
with
the
greatest
surprise
;
but
he
was
not
permitted
to
make
any
inquiries
;
for
the
two
boys
walked
stealthily
across
the
road
,
and
slunk
close
behind
the
old
gentleman
towards
whom
his
attention
had
been
directed
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
walked
a
few
paces
after
them
;
and
,
not
knowing
whether
to
advance
or
retire
,
stood
looking
on
in
silent
amazement
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
gentleman
was
a
very
respectable
-
looking
personage
,
with
a
powdered
head
and
gold
spectacles
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
dressed
in
a
bottle
-
green
coat
with
a
black
velvet
collar
;
wore
white
trousers
;
and
carried
a
smart
bamboo
cane
under
his
arm
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
taken
up
a
book
from
the
stall
,
and
there
he
stood
,
reading
away
,
as
hard
as
if
he
were
in
his
elbow
-
chair
,
in
his
own
study
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
very
possible
that
he
fancied
himself
there
,
indeed
;
for
it
was
plain
,
from
his
abstraction
,
that
he
saw
not
the
book
-
stall
,
nor
the
street
,
nor
the
boys
,
nor
,
in
short
,
anything
but
the
book
itself
:
 
which
he
was
reading
straight
through
:
 
turning
over
the
leaf
when
he
got
to
the
bottom
of
a
page
,
beginning
at
the
top
line
of
the
next
one
,
and
going
regularly
on
,
with
the
greatest
interest
and
eagerness
.
   
<EOS>
What
was
Oliver
's
horror
and
alarm
as
he
stood
a
few
paces
off
,
looking
on
with
his
eyelids
as
wide
open
as
they
would
possibly
go
,
to
see
the
Dodger
plunge
his
hand
into
the
old
gentleman
's
pocket
,
and
draw
from
thence
a
handkerchief
!
 
<EOS>
To
see
him
hand
the
same
to
Charley
Bates
;
and
finally
to
behold
them
,
both
running
away
round
the
corner
at
full
speed
!
   
<EOS>
In
an
instant
the
whole
mystery
of
the
hankerchiefs
,
and
the
watches
,
and
the
jewels
,
and
the
Jew
,
rushed
upon
the
boy
's
mind
.
   
<EOS>
He
stood
,
for
a
moment
,
with
the
blood
so
tingling
through
all
his
veins
from
terror
,
that
he
felt
as
if
he
were
in
a
burning
fire
;
then
,
confused
and
frightened
,
he
took
to
his
heels
;
and
,
not
knowing
what
he
did
,
made
off
as
fast
as
he
could
lay
his
feet
to
the
ground
.
   
<EOS>
This
was
all
done
in
a
minute
's
space
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
very
instant
when
Oliver
began
to
run
,
the
old
gentleman
,
putting
his
hand
to
his
pocket
,
and
missing
his
handkerchief
,
turned
sharp
round
.
 
<EOS>
Seeing
the
boy
scudding
away
at
such
a
rapid
pace
,
he
very
naturally
concluded
him
to
be
the
depredator
;
and
shouting
"
Stop
thief
!
"
<EOS>
with
all
his
might
,
made
off
after
him
,
book
in
hand
.
   
<EOS>
But
the
old
gentleman
was
not
the
only
person
who
raised
the
hue
-
and
-
cry
.
 
<EOS>
The
Dodger
and
Master
Bates
,
unwilling
to
attract
public
attention
by
running
down
the
open
street
,
had
merely
retured
into
the
very
first
doorway
round
the
corner
.
<EOS>
They
no
sooner
heard
the
cry
,
and
saw
Oliver
running
,
than
,
guessing
exactly
how
the
matter
stood
,
they
issued
forth
with
great
promptitude
;
and
,
shouting
"
Stop
thief
!
"
<EOS>
too
,
joined
in
the
pursuit
like
good
citizens
.
   
<EOS>
Although
Oliver
had
been
brought
up
by
philosophers
,
he
was
not
theoretically
acquainted
with
the
beautiful
axiom
<EOS>
that
self
-
preservation
is
the
first
law
of
nature
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
had
been
,
perhaps
he
would
have
been
prepared
for
this
.
 
<EOS>
Not
being
prepared
,
however
,
it
alarmed
him
the
more
;
so
away
he
went
like
the
wind
,
with
the
old
gentleman
and
the
two
boys
roaring
and
shouting
behind
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stop
thief
!
 
<EOS>
Stop
thief
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
There
is
a
magic
in
the
sound
.
<EOS>
The
tradesman
leaves
his
counter
,
and
the
car
-
man
his
waggon
;
the
butcher
throws
down
his
tray
;
the
baker
his
basket
;
the
milkman
his
pail
;
the
errand
-
boy
his
parcels
;
the
school
-
boy
his
marbles
;
the
paviour
his
pickaxe
;
the
child
his
battledore
.
 
<EOS>
Away
they
run
,
pell
-
mell
,
helter
-
skelter
,
<EOS>
slap
-
dash
:
 
<EOS>
tearing
,
yelling
,
screaming
,
knocking
down
the
passengers
as
they
turn
the
corners
,
rousing
up
the
dogs
,
and
astonishing
the
fowls
:
 
and
streets
,
squares
,
and
courts
,
re
-
echo
with
the
sound
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stop
thief
!
 
<EOS>
Stop
thief
!
"
 
<EOS>
The
cry
is
taken
up
by
a
hundred
voices
,
and
the
crowd
accumulate
at
every
turning
.
 
<EOS>
Away
they
fly
,
splashing
through
the
mud
,
and
rattling
along
the
pavements
:
   
up
<EOS>
go
the
windows
,
out
run
the
people
,
onward
bear
the
mob
,
a
whole
audience
desert
Punch
in
the
very
thickest
of
the
plot
,
and
,
joining
the
rushing
throng
,
swell
the
shout
,
and
lend
fresh
vigour
to
the
cry
,
"
Stop
thief
!
<EOS>
Stop
thief
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Stop
thief
!
 
<EOS>
Stop
thief
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
There
is
a
passion
FOR
HUNTING
SOMETHING
deeply
implanted
in
the
human
breast
.
 
<EOS>
One
wretched
breathless
child
,
panting
with
exhaustion
;
terror
in
his
looks
;
agaony
in
his
eyes
;
large
drops
of
perspiration
streaming
down
his
face
;
strains
every
nerve
to
make
head
upon
his
pursuers
;
and
as
they
follow
on
his
track
,
and
gain
upon
him
every
instant
,
they
hail
his
decreasing
strength
with
joy
.
 
<EOS>
"
Stop
thief
!
"
 
<EOS>
Ay
,
stop
him
for
God
's
sake
,
were
it
only
in
mercy
!
   
<EOS>
Stopped
at
last
!
 
<EOS>
A
clever
blow
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
down
upon
the
pavement
;
and
the
crowd
eagerly
gather
round
him
:
 
each
new
comer
,
jostling
and
struggling
with
the
others
to
catch
a
glimpse
.
 
<EOS>
"
Stand
aside
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Give
him
a
little
air
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Nonsense
!
<EOS>
he
do
n't
deserve
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Where
's
the
gentleman
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Here
his
is
,
coming
down
the
street
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Make
room
there
for
the
gentleman
!
"
<EOS>
"
Is
this
the
boy
,
sir
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
   
Oliver
lay
,
covered
with
mud
and
dust
,
and
bleeding
from
the
mouth
,
looking
wildly
round
upon
the
heap
of
faces
that
surrounded
him
,
when
the
old
gentleman
was
officiously
dragged
and
pushed
into
the
circle
by
the
foremost
of
the
pursuers
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
"
said
the
gentleman
,
"
I
am
afraid
it
is
the
boy
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Afraid
!
"
<EOS>
murmured
the
crowd
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
a
good
'
un
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Poor
fellow
!
"
said
the
gentleman
,
"
he
has
hurt
himself
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
\
<EOS>
I
\
did
that
,
sir
,
"
said
a
great
lubberly
fellow
,
stepping
forward
;
"
and
preciously
I
cut
my
knuckle
agin
'
his
mouth
.
 
<EOS>
I
stopped
him
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
follow
touched
his
hat
with
a
grin
,
expecting
something
for
his
pains
;
but
,
the
old
gentleman
,
eyeing
him
with
an
expression
of
dislike
,
look
anxiously
round
,
as
if
he
contemplated
running
away
himself
:
 
which
it
is
very
possible
he
might
have
attempted
to
do
,
and
thus
have
afforded
another
chase
,
had
not
a
police
officer
(
who
is
generally
the
last
person
to
arrive
in
such
cases
)
at
that
moment
made
his
way
through
the
crowd
,
and
seized
Oliver
by
the
collar
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,
get
up
,
"
said
the
man
,
roughly
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
n't
me
indeed
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
,
indeed
,
it
was
two
other
boys
,
"
said
Oliver
,
clasping
his
hands
passionately
,
and
looking
round
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
are
here
somewhere
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
no
,
they
ai
n't
,
"
said
the
officer
.
 
<EOS>
He
meant
this
to
be
ironical
,
but
it
was
true
besides
;
for
the
Dodger
and
Charley
Bates
had
filed
off
down
the
first
convenient
court
they
came
to
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,
get
up
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
hurt
him
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
,
compassionately
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
no
,
I
wo
n't
hurt
him
,
"
replied
the
officer
,
tearing
his
jacket
half
off
his
back
,
in
proof
thereof
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
,
I
know
you
;
it
wo
n't
do
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
stand
upon
your
legs
,
you
young
devil
?
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver
,
who
could
hardly
stand
,
made
a
shift
to
raise
himself
on
his
feet
,
and
was
at
once
lugged
along
the
streets
by
the
jacket
-
collar
,
at
a
rapid
pace
.
 
<EOS>
The
gentleman
walked
on
with
them
by
the
officer
's
side
;
and
as
many
of
the
crowd
as
could
achieve
the
feat
,
got
a
little
ahead
,
and
stared
back
at
Oliver
from
time
to
time
.
 
<EOS>
The
boys
shouted
in
triumph
;
and
on
they
went
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
11
.
<EOS>
Treats
of
Mr
Fang
the
police
magistrate
;
and
furnishes
a
slight
specimen
of
his
mode
of
administering
justice
.
 
<EOS>
The
offence
had
been
committed
within
the
district
,
and
indeed
in
the
immediate
neighborhood
of
,
a
very
notorious
metropolitan
police
office
.
 
<EOS>
The
crowd
had
only
the
satisfaction
of
accompanying
Oliver
through
two
or
three
streets
,
and
down
a
place
called
Mutton
Hill
,
when
he
was
led
beneath
a
low
archway
,
and
up
a
dirty
court
,
into
this
dispensary
of
summary
justice
,
by
the
back
way
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
small
paved
yard
into
which
they
turned
;
and
here
they
encountered
a
stout
man
with
a
bunch
of
whiskers
on
his
face
,
and
a
bunch
of
keys
in
his
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
's
the
matter
now
?
"
said
the
man
carelessly
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
young
fogle
-
hunter
,
"
replied
the
man
who
had
Oliver
in
charge
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
the
party
that
's
been
robbed
,
sir
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
the
man
with
the
keys
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
am
,
"
replied
the
old
gentleman
;
"
but
I
am
not
sure
that
this
boy
actually
took
the
handkerchief
.
 
<EOS>
I
---
I
would
rather
not
press
the
case
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Must
go
before
the
magistrate
now
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
man
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
His
worship
will
be
disengaged
in
half
a
minute
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
young
gallows
!
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
an
invitation
for
Oliver
to
enter
through
a
door
which
he
unlocked
as
he
spoke
,
and
which
led
into
a
stone
cell
.
 
<EOS>
Here
he
was
searched
;
and
nothing
being
found
upon
him
,
locked
up
.
   
<EOS>
This
cell
was
in
shape
and
size
something
like
an
area
cellar
,
only
not
so
light
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
most
intolerably
dirty
;
for
it
was
Monday
morning
;
and
it
had
been
tenanted
by
six
drunken
people
,
who
had
been
locked
up
,
elsewhere
,
since
Saturday
night
.
 
<EOS>
But
this
is
little
.
 
<EOS>
In
our
station
-
houses
,
men
and
women
are
every
night
confined
on
the
most
trivial
charges
---
the
word
is
worth
noting
---
in
dungeons
,
compared
with
which
,
those
in
Newgate
,
occupied
by
the
most
atrocious
felons
,
tried
,
found
guilty
,
and
under
sentence
of
death
,
are
palaces
.
<EOS>
Let
any
one
who
doubts
this
,
compare
the
two
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
gentleman
looked
almost
as
rueful
as
Oliver
when
the
key
grated
in
the
lock
.
 
<EOS>
He
turned
with
a
sigh
to
the
book
,
which
had
been
the
innocent
cause
of
all
this
disturbance
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
something
in
that
boy
's
face
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
to
himself
as
he
walked
slowly
away
,
tapping
his
chin
with
the
cover
of
the
book
,
in
a
thoughtful
manner
;
"
something
that
touches
and
interests
me
.
 
<EOS>
CAN
he
be
innocent
?
 
<EOS>
He
looked
like
---
<EOS>
Bye
the
bye
,
"
exclaimed
the
old
gentleman
,
halting
very
abruptly
,
and
staring
up
into
the
sky
<EOS>
,
"
Bless
my
soul
!
<EOS>
---
where
have
I
seen
something
like
that
look
before
?
"
   
<EOS>
After
musing
for
some
minutes
,
the
old
gentleman
walked
,
with
the
same
meditative
face
,
into
a
back
anteroom
opening
from
the
yard
;
and
there
,
retiring
into
a
corner
,
called
up
before
his
mind
's
eye
a
vast
amphitheatre
of
faces
over
which
a
dusky
curtain
had
hung
for
many
years
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
,
shaking
his
head
;
"
it
must
be
imagination
.
   
<EOS>
He
wandered
over
them
again
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
called
them
into
view
,
and
it
was
not
easy
to
replace
the
shroud
that
had
so
long
concealed
them
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
the
faces
of
friends
,
and
foes
,
and
of
many
that
had
been
almost
strangers
peering
intrusively
from
the
crowd
;
there
were
the
faces
of
young
and
blooming
girls
that
were
now
old
women
;
there
were
faces
that
the
grave
had
changed
and
closed
upon
,
but
which
the
mind
,
superior
to
its
power
,
still
dressed
in
their
old
freshness
and
beauty
,
calling
back
the
lustre
of
the
eyes
,
the
brightness
of
the
smile
,
the
beaming
of
the
soul
through
its
mask
of
clay
,
and
whispering
of
beauty
beyond
the
tomb
,
changed
but
to
be
heightened
,
and
taken
from
earth
only
to
be
set
up
as
a
light
,
to
shed
a
soft
and
gentle
glow
upon
the
path
to
Heaven
.
   
<EOS>
But
the
old
gentleman
could
recall
no
one
countenance
of
which
Oliver
's
features
bore
a
trace
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
he
heaved
a
sigh
over
the
recollections
he
awakened
;
and
being
,
happily
for
himself
,
an
absent
old
gentleman
,
buried
them
again
in
the
pages
of
the
musty
book
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
roused
by
a
touch
on
the
shoulder
,
and
a
request
from
the
man
with
the
keys
to
follow
him
into
the
office
.
 
<EOS>
He
closed
his
book
hastily
;
and
was
at
once
ushered
into
the
imposing
presence
of
the
renowned
Mr
Fang
.
   
<EOS>
The
office
was
a
front
parlour
,
with
a
panelled
wall
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Fang
sat
behind
a
bar
,
at
the
upper
end
;
and
on
one
side
the
door
was
a
sort
of
wooden
pen
in
which
poor
little
Oliver
was
already
deposited
;
trembling
very
much
at
the
awfulness
of
the
scene
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Fang
was
a
lean
,
long
-
backed
,
stiff
-
necked
,
middle
-
sized
man
,
with
no
great
quantity
of
hair
,
and
what
he
had
,
growing
on
the
back
and
sides
of
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
His
face
was
stern
,
and
much
flushed
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
were
really
not
in
the
habit
of
drinking
rather
more
than
was
exactly
good
for
him
,
he
might
have
brought
action
against
his
countenance
for
libel
,
and
have
recovered
heavy
damages
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
gentleman
bowed
respectfully
;
and
advancing
to
the
magistrate
's
desk
,
said
suiting
the
action
to
the
word
,
"
That
is
my
name
and
address
,
sir
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
then
withdrew
a
pace
or
two
;
and
,
with
another
polite
and
gentlemanly
inclination
of
the
head
,
waited
to
be
questioned
.
   
<EOS>
Now
,
it
so
happened
that
Mr
Fang
was
at
that
moment
perusing
a
leading
article
in
a
newspaper
of
the
morning
,
adverting
to
some
recent
decision
of
his
,
and
commending
him
,
for
the
three
hundred
and
fiftieth
time
,
to
the
special
and
particular
notice
of
the
Secretary
of
State
for
the
Home
Department
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
out
of
temper
;
and
he
looked
up
with
an
angry
scowl
.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
are
you
?
"
said
Mr
Fang
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
gentleman
pointed
,
with
some
surprise
,
to
his
card
.
   
<EOS>
"
Officer
!
<EOS>
"
said
Mr
Fang
,
tossing
the
card
contemptuously
away
with
the
newspaper
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
is
this
fellow
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
name
,
sir
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
,
speaking
LIKE
a
gentleman
,
"
my
name
,
sir
,
is
Brownlow
.
 
<EOS>
Permit
me
to
inquire
the
name
of
the
magistrate
who
offers
a
gratuitous
and
unprovoked
insult
to
a
respectable
person
,
under
the
protection
of
the
bench
.
"
 
<EOS>
Saying
this
,
Mr
Brownlow
looked
around
the
office
as
if
in
search
of
some
person
who
would
afford
him
the
required
information
.
   
<EOS>
"
Officer
!
<EOS>
"
said
Mr
Fang
,
throwing
the
paper
on
one
side
,
"
what
's
this
fellow
charged
with
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
not
charged
at
all
,
your
worship
,
"
replied
the
officer
.
"
<EOS>
He
appears
against
this
boy
,
your
worship
.
"
   
<EOS>
His
worshp
knew
this
perfectly
well
;
but
it
was
a
good
annoyance
,
and
a
safe
one
.
   
<EOS>
"
Appears
against
the
boy
,
does
he
?
"
said
Mr
Fang
,
surveying
Mr
Brownlow
contemptuously
from
head
to
foot
.
 
<EOS>
"
Swear
him
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Before
I
am
sworn
,
I
must
beg
to
say
one
word
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
;
"
and
that
is
,
that
I
really
never
,
without
actual
experience
,
could
have
believed
<EOS>
---
"
   
"
Hold
your
tongue
,
sir
!
"
<EOS>
said
Mr
Fang
,
peremptorily
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
,
sir
!
"
replied
the
old
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hold
your
tongue
this
instant
,
or
<EOS>
I
'll
have
you
turned
out
of
the
office
!
"
said
Mr
Fang
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
're
an
insolent
impertinent
fellow
.
 
<EOS>
How
dare
you
bully
a
magistrate
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
the
old
gentleman
,
reddening
.
   
<EOS>
"
Swear
this
person
!
"
<EOS>
said
Fang
to
the
clerk
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
not
hear
another
word
.
 
<EOS>
Swear
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Brownlow
's
indignaton
was
greatly
roused
;
but
reflecting
perhaps
,
that
he
might
only
injure
the
boy
by
giving
vent
to
it
,
he
suppressed
his
feelings
and
submitted
to
be
sworn
at
once
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
said
Fang
,
"
what
's
the
charge
against
this
boy
?
 
<EOS>
What
have
you
got
to
say
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
standing
at
a
bookstall
---
"
Mr
Brownlow
began
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hold
your
tongue
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Fang
.
 
<EOS>
"
Policeman
!
 
<EOS>
Where
's
the
policeman
?
 
<EOS>
Here
,
swear
this
policeman
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
policeman
,
what
is
this
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
policeman
,
with
becoming
humility
,
related
how
he
had
taken
the
charge
;
how
he
had
searched
Oliver
,
and
found
nothing
on
his
person
;
and
how
that
was
all
he
knew
about
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
there
any
witnesses
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Fang
.
   
<EOS>
"
None
,
your
worship
,
"
replied
the
policeman
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Fang
sat
silent
for
some
minutes
,
and
then
,
turning
round
to
the
prosecutor
,
said
in
a
towering
passion
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
to
state
what
your
complaint
against
this
boy
is
,
man
,
or
do
you
not
?
 
<EOS>
You
have
been
sworn
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
if
you
stand
there
,
refusing
to
give
evidence
,
I
'll
punish
you
for
disrespect
to
the
bench
;
I
will
,
by
---
"
   
<EOS>
By
what
,
or
by
whom
,
nobody
knows
,
for
the
clerk
and
jailor
coughed
very
loud
,
just
at
the
right
moment
;
and
the
former
dropped
a
heavy
book
upon
the
floor
,
thus
preventing
the
word
from
being
heard
---
accidentally
,
of
course
.
   
<EOS>
With
many
interruptions
,
and
repeated
insults
,
Mr
Brownlow
contrived
to
state
his
case
;
 
observing
that
,
in
the
surprise
of
the
moment
,
he
had
run
after
the
boy
because
he
had
saw
him
running
away
;
and
expressing
his
hope
that
,
if
the
magistrate
should
believe
him
,
although
not
actually
the
thief
,
to
be
connected
with
the
thieves
,
he
would
deal
as
leniently
with
him
as
justice
would
allow
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
has
been
hurt
already
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
in
conclusion
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
fear
,
"
he
added
,
with
great
energy
,
looking
towards
the
bar
,
"
I
really
fear
that
he
is
ill
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
yes
,
I
dare
say
!
"
said
Mr
Fang
,
with
a
sneer
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
,
none
of
your
tricks
here
,
<EOS>
you
young
vagabond
;
they
wo
n't
do
.
<EOS>
What
's
your
name
?
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver
tried
to
reply
but
his
tongue
failed
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
deadly
pale
;
and
the
whole
place
seemed
turning
round
and
round
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
your
name
,
you
hardened
scoundrel
?
"
demanded
Mr
Fang
.
<EOS>
"
Officer
,
what
's
his
name
?
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
addressed
to
a
bluff
old
fellow
,
in
a
striped
waistcoat
,
who
was
standing
by
the
bar
.
 
<EOS>
He
bent
over
Oliver
,
and
repeated
the
inquiry
;
but
finding
him
really
incapable
of
understanding
the
question
;
and
knowing
that
his
not
replying
would
only
infuriate
the
magistrate
the
more
,
and
add
to
the
severity
of
his
sentence
;
he
hazarded
a
guess
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
says
his
name
's
Tom
White
,
your
worship
,
"
said
the
kind
-
hearted
thief
-
taker
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
he
wo
n't
speak
out
,
wo
n't
he
?
"
said
Fang
.
 
<EOS>
"
Very
well
,
very
well
.
 
<EOS>
Where
does
he
live
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Where
he
can
,
your
worship
<EOS>
,
"
replied
the
officer
;
again
pretending
to
receive
Oliver
's
answer
.
   
<EOS>
"
Has
he
any
parents
?
"
inquired
Mr
Fang
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
says
they
died
in
his
infancy
,
your
worship
,
"
replied
the
officer
:
 
hazarding
the
usual
reply
.
   
<EOS>
At
this
point
of
the
inquiry
,
Oliver
raised
his
head
;
and
,
looking
round
with
imploring
eyes
,
murmured
a
feeble
prayer
for
a
draught
of
water
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stuff
and
nonsense
!
<EOS>
"
said
Mr
Fang
:
 
"
do
n't
try
to
make
a
fool
of
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
he
really
is
ill
,
your
worship
,
"
remonstrated
the
officer
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
better
,
"
said
Mr
Fang
.
   
<EOS>
"
Take
care
of
him
,
officer
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
,
raising
his
hands
instinctively
;
"
he
'll
fall
down
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Stand
away
,
officer
,
"
cried
Fang
;
 
"
let
him
,
if
he
likes
.
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver
availed
himself
of
the
kind
permission
,
and
fell
to
the
floor
in
a
fainting
fit
.
 
<EOS>
The
men
in
the
office
looked
at
each
other
,
but
no
one
dared
to
stir
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
knew
he
was
shamming
,
"
said
Fang
,
as
if
this
were
incontestable
proof
of
the
fact
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
him
lie
there
;
he
'll
soon
be
tired
of
that
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
propose
to
deal
with
the
case
,
sir
?
"
 
<EOS>
inquired
the
clerk
in
a
low
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
Summarily
,
"
replied
Mr
Fang
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
stands
committed
for
three
months
---
hard
labour
of
course
.
 
<EOS>
Clear
the
office
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
door
was
opened
for
this
purpose
,
and
a
couple
of
men
were
preparing
to
carry
the
insensible
boy
to
his
cell
;
when
an
elderly
man
of
decent
but
poor
appearance
,
clad
in
an
old
suit
of
black
,
rushed
hastily
into
the
office
,
and
advanced
towards
the
bench
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stop
,
stop
!
 
<EOS>
do
n't
take
him
away
!
 
<EOS>
For
Heaven
's
sake
stop
a
moment
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
new
comer
,
breathless
with
haste
.
   
<EOS>
Although
the
presiding
Genii
in
such
an
office
as
this
,
exercise
a
summary
and
arbitrary
power
over
the
liberties
,
the
good
name
,
the
character
,
almost
the
lives
,
of
Her
Majesty
's
subjects
,
expecially
of
the
poorer
class
;
and
although
,
within
such
walls
,
enough
fantastic
tricks
are
daily
played
to
make
the
angels
blind
with
weeping
;
they
are
closed
to
the
public
,
save
through
the
medium
of
the
daily
press.(Footnote
:
 
Or
were
virtually
,
then
.
)
<EOS>
Mr
Fang
was
consequently
not
a
little
indignant
to
see
an
unbidden
guest
enter
in
such
irreverent
disorder
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
this
?
 
<EOS>
Who
is
this
?
 
<EOS>
Turn
this
man
out
.
 
<EOS>
Clear
the
office
!
"
cried
Mr
Fang
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
WILL
speak
,
"
cried
the
man
;
"
I
will
not
be
turned
out
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
it
all
.
 
<EOS>
I
keep
the
book
-
stall
.
 
<EOS>
I
demand
to
be
sworn
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
be
put
down
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Fang
,
you
must
hear
me
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
not
refuse
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
man
was
right
.
 
<EOS>
His
manner
was
determined
;
and
the
matter
was
growing
rather
too
serious
to
be
hushed
up
.
   
<EOS>
"
Swear
the
man
,
"
growled
Mr
Fang
.
<EOS>
with
a
very
ill
grace
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Now
,
man
,
what
have
you
got
to
say
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
This
,
"
said
the
man
:
 
<EOS>
"
I
saw
three
boys
:
 
two
others
and
the
prisoner
here
:
 
loitering
on
the
opposite
side
of
the
way
,
when
this
gentleman
was
reading
.
 
<EOS>
The
robbery
was
committed
by
another
boy
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
it
done
;
and
I
saw
that
this
boy
was
perfectly
amazed
and
stupified
by
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
Having
by
this
time
recovered
a
little
breath
,
the
worthy
book
-
stall
keeper
proceeded
to
relate
,
in
a
more
coherent
manner
the
exact
circumstances
of
the
robbery
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
did
n't
you
come
here
before
?
"
<EOS>
said
Fang
,
after
a
pause
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
had
n't
a
soul
to
mind
the
shop
,
"
replied
the
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
Everybody
who
could
have
helped
me
,
had
joined
in
the
pursuit
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
get
nobody
till
five
minutes
ago
;
and
I
've
run
here
all
the
way
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
prosecutor
was
reading
,
was
he
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Fang
,
after
another
pause
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
replied
the
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
very
book
he
has
in
his
hand
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
that
book
,
eh
?
<EOS>
"
said
Fang
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
it
paid
for
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
it
is
not
,
"
replied
the
man
,
with
a
smile
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
,
I
forgot
all
about
it
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
absent
old
gentleman
,
innocently
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
nice
person
to
prefer
a
charge
against
a
poor
boy
!
"
said
Fang
,
with
a
comical
effort
to
look
humane
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
consider
,
sir
,
that
you
have
obtained
possession
of
that
book
,
under
very
suspicious
and
disreputable
circumstances
;
and
you
may
think
yourself
very
fortunate
that
the
owner
of
the
property
declines
to
prosecute
.
<EOS>
Let
this
be
a
lesson
to
you
,
my
man
,
or
the
law
will
overtake
you
yet
.
 
<EOS>
The
boy
is
discharged
.
 
<EOS>
Clear
the
office
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
D####n
me
!
"
cried
the
old
gentleman
,
bursting
out
with
the
rage
he
had
kept
down
so
long
,
"
d####n
me
!
  
<EOS>
I
'll
---
"
   
"
Clear
the
office
!
"
said
the
magistrate
.
 
<EOS>
"
Officers
,
do
you
hear
?
   
<EOS>
Clear
the
office
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
mandate
was
obeyed
;
and
the
indignant
Mr
Brownlow
was
conveyed
out
,
with
the
book
in
one
hand
,
and
the
bamboo
cane
in
the
other
:
 
in
a
perfect
phrenzy
of
rage
and
defiance
.
 
<EOS>
He
reached
the
yard
;
and
his
passion
vanished
in
a
moment
.
 
<EOS>
Little
Oliver
Twist
lay
on
his
back
on
the
pavement
,
with
his
shirt
unbuttoned
,
and
his
temples
bathed
with
water
;
his
face
a
deadly
white
;
and
a
cold
tremble
convulsing
his
whole
frame
.
   
<EOS>
"
Poor
boy
,
poor
boy
!
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
,
bending
over
him
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Call
a
coach
,
somebody
,
pray
.
 
<EOS>
Directly
!
"
   
A
coach
was
obtained
,
and
Oliver
having
been
carefully
laid
on
the
seat
,
the
old
gentleman
got
in
and
sat
himself
on
the
other
.
   
<EOS>
"
May
I
accompany
you
?
"
said
the
book
-
stall
keeper
,
looking
in
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bless
me
,
yes
,
my
dear
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
quickly
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
forgot
you
.
 
<EOS>
Dear
,
dear
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
this
unhappy
book
still
!
<EOS>
Jump
in
.
 
<EOS>
Poor
fellow
!
 
<EOS>
There
's
no
time
to
lose
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
book
-
stall
keeper
got
into
the
coach
;
and
away
they
drove
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
12
.
<EOS>
In
which
Oliver
is
taken
better
care
of
than
he
ever
was
before
.
<EOS>
And
in
which
the
narrative
reverts
to
the
merry
old
gentleman
and
his
youthful
friends
.
 
<EOS>
The
coach
rattled
away
,
over
nearly
the
same
ground
as
that
which
Oliver
had
traversed
when
he
first
entered
London
in
company
with
the
Dodger
;
and
,
turning
a
different
way
when
it
reached
the
Angel
at
Islington
,
stopped
at
length
before
a
neat
house
,
in
a
quiet
shady
street
near
Pentonville
.
 
<EOS>
Here
,
a
bed
was
prepared
,
without
loss
of
time
,
in
which
Mr
Brownlow
saw
his
young
charge
carefully
and
comfortably
deposited
;
and
here
,
he
was
tended
with
a
kindness
and
solicitude
that
knew
no
bounds
.
   
<EOS>
But
,
for
many
days
,
Oliver
remained
insensible
to
all
the
goodness
of
his
new
friends
.
 
<EOS>
The
sun
rose
and
sank
,
and
rose
and
sank
again
,
and
many
times
after
that
;
and
still
the
boy
lay
stretched
on
his
uneasy
bed
,
dwindling
away
beneath
the
dry
and
wasting
heat
of
fever
.
 
<EOS>
The
worm
does
not
work
more
surely
on
the
dead
body
,
than
does
this
slow
creeping
fire
upon
the
living
frame
.
   
<EOS>
Weak
,
and
thin
,
and
pallid
,
he
awoke
at
last
from
what
seemed
to
have
been
a
long
and
troubled
dream
.
 
<EOS>
Feebly
raising
himself
in
the
bed
,
with
his
head
resting
on
his
trembling
arm
,
he
looked
anxiously
around
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
room
is
this
?
 
<EOS>
Where
have
I
been
brought
to
?
"
said
Oliver
.
<EOS>
"
This
is
not
the
place
I
went
to
sleep
in
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
uttered
these
words
in
a
feeble
voice
,
being
very
faint
and
weak
;
but
they
were
overheard
at
once
.
 
<EOS>
The
curtain
at
the
bed
's
head
was
hastily
drawn
back
,
and
a
motherly
old
lady
,
very
neatly
and
precisely
dressed
,
rose
as
she
undrew
it
,
from
an
arm
-
chair
close
by
,
in
which
she
had
been
sitting
at
needle
-
work
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
,
my
dear
,
"
said
the
old
lady
softly
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
must
be
very
quiet
,
or
you
will
be
ill
again
;
and
you
have
been
very
bad
,
---
as
bad
as
bad
could
be
,
pretty
nigh
.
 
<EOS>
Lie
down
again
;
there
's
a
dear
!
"
 
<EOS>
With
those
words
,
the
old
lady
very
gently
placed
Oliver
's
head
upon
the
pillow
;
and
,
smoothing
back
his
hair
from
his
forehead
,
looked
so
kindly
and
loving
in
his
face
,
that
he
could
not
help
placing
his
little
withered
hand
in
hers
,
and
drawing
it
round
his
neck
.
   
<EOS>
"
Save
us
!
"
said
the
old
lady
,
with
tears
in
her
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
a
grateful
little
dear
it
is
.
 
<EOS>
Pretty
creetur
!
 
<EOS>
What
would
his
mother
feel
if
she
had
sat
by
him
as
I
have
,
and
could
see
him
now
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
she
does
see
me
,
"
whispered
Oliver
,
folding
his
hands
together
;
"
perhaps
she
has
sat
by
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
almost
feel
as
if
she
had
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
was
the
fever
,
my
dear
,
"
said
the
old
lady
mildly
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
it
was
,
"
replied
Oliver
,
"
because
heaven
is
a
long
way
off
;
and
they
are
too
happy
there
,
to
come
down
to
the
bedside
of
a
poor
boy
.
 
<EOS>
But
if
she
knew
I
was
ill
,
she
must
have
pitied
me
,
even
there
;
for
she
was
very
ill
herself
before
she
died
.
 
<EOS>
She
ca
n't
know
anything
about
me
though
,
"
added
Oliver
after
a
moment
's
silence
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
she
had
seen
me
hurt
,
it
would
have
made
here
sorrowful
;
and
her
face
has
always
looked
sweet
and
happy
,
when
I
have
dreamed
of
her
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
old
lady
made
no
reply
to
this
;
but
wiping
her
eyes
first
,
and
her
spectacles
,
which
lay
on
the
counterpane
,
afterwards
,
as
if
they
were
part
and
parcel
of
those
features
,
brought
some
cool
stuff
for
Oliver
to
drink
;
and
then
,
patting
him
on
the
cheek
,
told
him
he
must
lie
very
quiet
,
or
he
would
be
ill
again
.
   
<EOS>
So
,
Oliver
kept
very
still
;
partly
because
he
was
anxious
to
obey
the
kind
old
lady
in
all
things
;
and
partly
,
to
tell
the
truth
,
because
he
was
completely
exhausted
with
what
he
had
already
said
.
 
<EOS>
He
soon
fell
into
a
gentle
doze
,
from
which
he
was
awakened
by
the
light
of
a
candle
:
 
which
,
being
brought
near
the
bed
,
showed
him
a
gentleman
with
a
very
large
and
loud
-
ticking
gold
watch
in
his
hand
,
who
felt
his
pulse
,
and
said
he
was
a
great
deal
better
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
ARE
a
great
deal
better
,
are
you
not
,
my
dear
?
"
said
the
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
thank
you
,
sir
,
"
replied
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
 
I
know
you
are
,
"
said
the
gentleman
:
 
<EOS>
"
You
're
hungry
too
,
an't
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
,
"
answered
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hem
!
"
said
the
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
know
you
're
not
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
not
hungry
,
Mrs
Bedwin
,
"
said
the
gentleman
:
 
looking
very
wise
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
lady
made
a
respectful
inclination
of
the
head
,
which
seemed
to
say
that
she
thought
the
doctor
was
a
very
clever
man
.
<EOS>
The
doctor
appeared
much
of
the
same
opinion
himself
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
feel
sleepy
,
do
n't
you
,
my
dear
?
"
said
the
doctor
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
,
"
replied
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
the
doctor
,
with
a
very
shrewd
and
satisfied
look
.
<EOS>
"
You
're
not
sleepy
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
thirsty
.
 
<EOS>
Are
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
rather
thirsty
,
"
answered
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
Just
as
I
expected
,
Mrs
Bedwin
,
"
said
the
doctor
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
very
natural
that
he
should
be
thirsty
.
 
<EOS>
You
may
give
him
a
little
tea
,
ma'am
,
and
some
dry
toast
without
any
butter
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
keep
him
too
warm
,
ma'am
;
but
be
careful
that
you
do
n't
let
him
be
too
cold
;
will
you
have
the
goodness
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
old
lady
dropped
a
curtsey
.
 
<EOS>
The
doctor
,
after
tasting
the
cool
stuff
,
and
expressing
a
qualified
approval
of
it
,
hurried
away
:
 
his
boots
creaking
in
a
very
important
and
wealthy
manner
as
he
went
downstairs
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
dozed
off
again
,
soon
after
this
;
when
he
awoke
,
it
was
nearly
twelve
o'clock
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
lady
tenderly
bade
him
good
-
night
shortly
afterwards
,
and
left
him
in
charge
of
a
fat
old
woman
who
had
just
come
:
 
bringing
with
her
,
in
a
little
bundle
,
a
small
Prayer
Book
and
a
large
nightcap
.
<EOS>
Putting
the
latter
on
her
head
and
the
former
on
the
table
,
the
old
woman
,
after
telling
Oliver
that
she
had
come
to
sit
up
with
him
,
drew
her
chair
close
to
the
fire
and
went
off
into
a
series
of
short
naps
,
chequered
at
frequent
intervals
with
sundry
tumblings
forward
,
and
divers
moans
and
chokings
.
<EOS>
These
,
however
,
had
no
worse
effect
than
causing
her
to
rub
her
nose
very
hard
,
and
then
fall
asleep
again
.
   
<EOS>
And
thus
the
night
crept
slowly
on
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
lay
awake
for
some
time
,
counting
the
little
circles
of
light
<EOS>
which
the
reflection
of
the
rushlight
-
shade
threw
upon
the
ceiling
;
or
tracing
with
his
languid
eyes
the
intricate
pattern
of
the
paper
on
the
wall
.
<EOS>
The
darkness
and
the
deep
stillness
of
the
room
were
very
solemn
;
as
they
brought
into
the
boy
's
mind
the
thought
that
death
had
been
hovering
there
,
for
many
days
and
nights
,
and
might
yet
fill
it
with
the
gloom
and
dread
of
his
awful
presence
,
he
turned
his
face
upon
the
pillow
,
and
fervently
prayed
to
Heaven
.
   
<EOS>
Gradually
,
he
fell
into
that
deep
tranquil
sleep
which
ease
from
recent
suffering
alone
imparts
;
that
calm
and
peaceful
rest
which
it
is
pain
to
wake
from
.
 
<EOS>
Who
,
if
this
were
death
,
would
be
roused
again
to
all
the
struggles
and
turmoils
of
life
;
to
all
its
cares
for
the
present
;
its
anxieties
for
the
future
;
more
than
all
,
its
weary
recollections
of
the
past
!
   
<EOS>
It
had
been
bright
day
,
for
hours
,
when
Oliver
opened
his
eyes
;
he
felt
cheerful
and
happy
.
 
<EOS>
The
crisis
of
the
disease
was
safely
past
.
 
<EOS>
He
belonged
to
the
world
again
.
   
<EOS>
In
three
days
'
time
he
was
able
to
sit
in
an
easy
-
chair
,
well
propped
up
with
pillows
;
and
,
as
he
was
still
too
weak
to
walk
,
Mrs
Bedwin
had
him
carried
downstairs
into
the
little
housekeeper
's
room
,
which
belonged
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
Having
him
set
,
here
,
by
the
fire
-
side
,
the
good
old
lady
sat
herself
down
too
;
and
,
being
in
a
state
of
considerable
delight
at
seeing
him
so
much
better
<EOS>
,
forthwith
began
to
cry
most
violently
.
   
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
me
,
my
dear
,
"
said
the
old
lady
;
"
I
'm
only
having
a
regular
good
cry
.
 
<EOS>
There
;
it
's
all
over
now
;
and
I
'm
quite
comfortable
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
very
,
very
kind
to
me
,
ma'am
,
"
said
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
never
you
mind
that
,
my
dear
,
"
said
the
old
lady
;
"
that
's
got
nothing
to
do
with
your
broth
;
and
it
's
full
time
you
had
it
;
for
the
doctor
says
Mr
Brownlow
may
come
in
to
see
you
this
morning
;
and
we
must
get
up
our
best
looks
,
because
the
better
we
look
,
the
more
he
'll
be
pleased
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
And
with
this
,
the
old
lady
applied
herself
to
warming
up
,
in
a
little
saucepan
,
a
basin
full
of
broth
:
 
strong
enough
,
Oliver
thought
,
to
furnish
an
ample
dinner
,
when
reduced
to
the
regulation
strength
,
for
three
hundred
and
fifty
paupers
,
at
the
lowest
computation
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
fond
of
pictures
,
dear
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
the
old
lady
,
seeing
that
Oliver
had
fixed
his
eyes
,
most
intently
,
on
a
portrait
which
hung
against
the
wall
;
just
opposite
his
chair
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
quite
know
,
ma'am
,
"
said
Oliver
,
without
taking
his
eyes
from
the
canvas
;
"
I
have
seen
so
few
that
I
hardly
know
.
 
<EOS>
What
a
beautiful
,
mild
face
that
lady
's
is
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
old
lady
,
"
painters
always
make
ladies
out
prettier
than
they
are
,
or
they
would
n't
get
any
custom
,
child
.
<EOS>
The
man
that
invented
the
machine
for
taking
likenesses
might
have
known
that
would
never
succeed
;
it
's
a
deal
too
honest
.
 
<EOS>
A
deal
,
"
said
the
old
lady
,
laughing
very
heartily
at
her
own
acuteness
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
---
is
that
a
likeness
,
ma'am
?
"
said
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
the
old
lady
,
looking
up
for
a
moment
from
the
broth
;
"
that
's
a
portrait
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Whose
,
ma'am
?
"
asked
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
really
,
my
dear
,
I
do
n't
know
,
"
answered
the
old
lady
in
a
good
-
humoured
manner
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
a
likeness
of
anybody
that
you
or
I
know
,
I
expect
.
 
<EOS>
It
seems
to
strike
your
fancy
,
dear
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
so
pretty
,
"
replied
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
sure
you
're
not
afraid
of
it
?
"
said
the
old
lady
:
observing
in
great
surprise
,
the
look
of
awe
with
which
the
child
regarded
the
painting
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
no
,
no
,
"
returned
Oliver
quickly
;
"
but
the
eyes
look
so
sorrowful
;
and
where
I
sit
<EOS>
,
they
seem
fixed
upon
me
.
 
<EOS>
It
makes
my
heart
beat
,
"
added
Oliver
in
a
low
voice
,
"
as
if
it
was
alive
,
and
wanted
to
speak
to
me
,
but
could
n't
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Lord
save
us
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
old
lady
,
starting
;
"
do
n't
talk
in
that
way
,
child
.
 
<EOS>
You
're
weak
and
nervous
after
your
illness
.
<EOS>
Let
me
wheel
your
chair
round
to
the
other
side
;
and
then
you
wo
n't
see
it
.
 
<EOS>
There
!
"
said
the
old
lady
,
suiting
the
action
to
the
word
;
"
you
do
n't
see
it
now
,
at
all
events
.
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver
DID
see
it
in
his
mind
's
eye
as
distinctly
as
if
he
had
not
altered
his
position
;
but
he
thought
it
better
not
to
worry
the
kind
old
lady
;
so
he
smiled
gently
when
she
looked
at
him
;
and
Mrs
Bedwin
,
satisfied
that
he
felt
more
comfortable
,
salted
and
broke
bits
of
toasted
bread
into
the
broth
,
with
all
the
bustle
befitting
so
solemn
a
preparation
.
<EOS>
Oliver
got
through
it
with
extraordinary
expedition
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
scarcely
swallowed
the
last
spoonful
,
when
there
came
a
soft
rap
at
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
in
,
"
said
the
old
lady
;
and
in
walked
Mr
Brownlow
.
   
<EOS>
Now
,
the
old
gentleman
came
in
as
brisk
as
need
be
;
but
,
he
had
no
sooner
raised
his
spectacles
on
his
forehead
,
and
thrust
his
hands
behind
the
skirts
of
his
dressing
-
gown
to
take
a
good
long
look
at
Oliver
,
than
his
countenance
underwent
a
very
great
variety
of
odd
contortions
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
looked
very
worn
and
shadowy
from
sickness
,
and
made
an
ineffectual
attempt
to
stand
up
,
out
of
respect
to
his
benefactor
,
which
terminated
in
his
sinking
back
into
the
chair
again
;
and
the
fact
is
,
if
the
truth
must
be
told
,
that
Mr
Brownlow
's
heart
,
being
large
enough
for
any
six
ordinary
old
gentlemen
of
humane
disposition
,
forced
a
supply
of
tears
into
his
eyes
,
by
some
hydraulic
process
which
we
are
not
sufficiently
philosophical
to
be
in
a
condition
to
explain
.
   
<EOS>
"
Poor
boy
,
poor
boy
!
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
,
clearing
his
throat
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
rather
hoarse
this
morning
,
Mrs
Bedwin
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
afraid
I
have
caught
cold
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
not
,
sir
,
"
said
Mrs
Bedwin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Everything
you
have
had
,
has
been
well
aired
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
Bedwin
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
;
<EOS>
"
I
rather
think
I
had
a
damp
napkin
at
dinner
-
time
yesterday
;
but
never
mind
that
.
 
<EOS>
How
do
you
feel
,
my
dear
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
happy
,
sir
,
"
replied
Oliver
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
very
grateful
indeed
,
sir
,
for
your
goodness
to
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
by
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
,
stoutly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
you
given
him
any
nourishment
,
Bedwin
?
 
<EOS>
Any
slops
,
eh
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
has
just
had
a
basin
of
beautiful
strong
broth
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mrs
Bedwin
:
 
drawing
herself
up
slightly
,
and
laying
strong
emphasis
on
the
last
word
:
 
to
intimate
that
between
slops
,
and
broth
will
compounded
,
there
existed
no
affinity
or

.
   
<EOS>
"
Ugh
!
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
,
with
a
slight

;
"
a
couple
of
glasses
of
port
wine
would
have
done
him
a
great

more
good
.
<EOS>
Would

,
Tom

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
My

,

,
"

:
 
with

.
   
<EOS>
"
Oliver
,
"

;
"
Oliver
<EOS>
what
?
 
<EOS>
Oliver
White
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,

,

,
Oliver
Twist
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Queer

!
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
What

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>
This

.
 
<EOS>
It

;
there

.
   
<EOS>
"
Some

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
But
,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"

!
<EOS>
what
's

?
 
<EOS>
Bedwin
,

!
"
   
<EOS>
As

's

.
 
<EOS>
There

its

.
<EOS>
The

,
the

,

.
<EOS>
The

was
,

,
so

,
that
the

seemed
copied

!
   
<EOS>
Oliver
knew

;
for
,
not

strong
enough
to

,

away
.
 
<EOS>
A
weakness
on
his
part
,
which
affords
the
narrative
an

of
relieving
the
reader
from

,
in
behalf
of
the
two
young

of
the
Merry
Old

;
and
of

---
    
That
when
the
Dodger
,
and
his

Master
Bates
,
joined
in
the
hue
-
and
-

Oliver
's

,
in

of

an

of
Mr

's

,
as
has
been
already
described
<EOS>
,
they
were
actuated
by
a
very
laudable
and
becoming
regard
for
themselves
;
and
forasmuch
as
the
freedom
of
the
subject
and
the

of
the
individual
are
among
the
first
and
proudest
boasts
of
a
true
-
hearted
Englishman
,
so
,
I
need
hardly
beg
the
reader
to
observe
,
that
this
action
should
tend
to
exalt
them
in
the
opinion
of
all
public
and
patriotic
men
,
in
almost
as
great
a
degree
as
this
strong
proof
of
their
anxiety
for
their
own
preservation
and
safety
goes
to
corroborate
and
confirm
the
little
code
of
laws
which
certain
profound
and
sound
-
judging

have
laid
down
as
the
main
-

of
all
Nature
's

:
 
the
said
philosophers
very

reducing
the
good

's

to

of

and

:
 
and
,
by
a
very
neat

pretty

to
her

,
putting
entirely
out

,

.
<EOS>
For
,
these
are
matters
totally
beneath
a
female
who
is
acknowledged
by
universal

to
be
far
above
the

of

.
   
<EOS>
If
I
wanted
any
further
proof
of
the
strictly
philosophical
nature
of
the
conduct
of
these
young
gentlemen
in
their
very

,
I
should
at
once
find
it
in
the
fact
<EOS>
(
also

this

)
,

,
when
the

was
fixed
upon
Oliver
;
and
making

for

by

.
 
<EOS>
Although
I
do
not
mean
to
assert
that
it
is
usually
the
practice
of
renowned
and
learned
sages
,
to
shorten
the
road
to
any
great
conclusion
(
their
course
indeed
being
rather
to

,

,
like
unto

in

under

too

,

)
;
still
,
I
do
mean

say
,
and
do

,
that
it
is
the
invariable
practice
of
many
mighty

,
in
carrying

,
to

great

in

against
every
possible

which
can
be

at
all

.
 
<EOS>
Thus
,
to
do
a
great
right
,
you
may
do
a
little
wrong
;
and
you
may
take
any
means
which
the
end
to
be
attained
,
will
justify
;
the
amount

,

the

the

,

between

,

and

by

,

.
   
<EOS>
It

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Having

,
just

,
Master

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's

?
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
"

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Do

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't

,
"

"
I
ca

!
 
<EOS>
To

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
What

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

:
 
<EOS>

;

<EOS>
"
What

?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dawkins

;
then
,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
What

?
"

<EOS>
"
Toor

,

the

,

,

:

<EOS>
This

,

.
 
<EOS>
Master

felt

;
and

,
"
What

?
"
   
<EOS>
The

.
 
<EOS>
Master
Bates

,

.
   
<EOS>
The

on

,

,

as

;
a

;

.
 
<EOS>
There

,

<EOS>
"
Why
,

's

?
<EOS>
"

:
 
changing

;
"
only

?
 
<EOS>
Where

?
 
<EOS>
They
ca
n't

.
 
<EOS>
Hark
!
"
   
<EOS>
The

;

.
<EOS>
The

;

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
13
.
<EOS>
Some
new

are
introduced
to
the
intelligent
reader
,
connected

various

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
's
Oliver
?
"
said
the
Jew
,
rising

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Where
's

boy
?
"
   
<EOS>
The

thieves
eyed

as
if

;

.
 
<EOS>
But

.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's

of

boy
?
"
said
the
Jew
,
seizing

Dodger

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
"
Speak
out
,
or
I
'll
throttle

!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Fagin
looked
so
very
much
in

,
that
Charley
Bates
,
who
deemed
it
prudent
in
all

,
and
who

by

,

---
something

.
   
<EOS>
"
Will
you
speak
?
<EOS>
"
thundered

Jew
:
 
shaking

Dodger
so
much
that

in

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

,

's

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
Come
,

me
,

!
"
 
<EOS>
And

;

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
The
Jew
stepped

in
this

,
with
more

than
could

in
a

;
and
,

,

's

.
 
<EOS>
But
Charley
Bates
,
at

,

by

,
he

altered

,
and
flung

full

that

.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
the
blazes
is
in

wind
now
!
<EOS>
"
growled
a
deep

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Who
pitched
that
'
ere
at
me
?
 
<EOS>
It
's
well
<EOS>
it
's
the
beer
,
and

the
pot
,
as
hit

,

I
'd

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

,

,

old
Jew
could

water
---

,

done

.
 
<EOS>
Wot
's

,
Fagin
?
 
<EOS>
D
---
 
me
,
if
my
neck
-

an't
lined

!
 
<EOS>
Come
in
,

warmint
;
wot

for
,

!
 
<EOS>
Come
in
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
man
who

,
was
a

-

of

-

,

,

,

,

,

;
---
the

,
which
in

,
always
look
in
an
unfinished
and

state
without
a

.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
brown

on
his

,
and
a

round

:
 
with
the

of

as

.
 
<EOS>
He
disclosed
,

,
a

with

three
days
'

,

;
<EOS>
one

which
displayed
various

-

of
