been
recently
damaged
by
a
blow
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
in
,
d'ye
hear
?
<EOS>
"
growled
this
engaging
ruffian
.
   
<EOS>
A
white
shaggy
dog
,
with
his
face
scratched
and
torn
in
twenty
different
places
,
skulked
into
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
did
n't
you
come
in
afore
?
"
said
the
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
're
getting
too
proud
to
own
me
afore
company
,
are
you
?
 
<EOS>
Lie
down
!
"
   
<EOS>
This
command
was
accompanied
with
a
kick
,
which
sent
the
animal
to
the
other
end
of
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
He
appeared
well
used
to
it
,
however
;
for
he
coiled
himself
up
in
a
corner
very
quietly
,
without
uttering
a
sound
,
and
winking
his
very
ill
-
looking
eyes
twenty
times
in
a
minute
,
appeared
to
occupy
himself
in
taking
a
survey
of
the
apartment
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
are
you
up
to
?
 
<EOS>
Ill
-
treating
the
boys
,
you
covetous
,
avaricious
,
in
-
sa
-
ti
-
a
-
ble
old
fence
?
"
said
the
man
,
seating
himself
deliberately
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
they
do
n't
murder
you
!
 
<EOS>
I
would
if
I
was
them
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
'd
been
your
'
prentice
,
I
'd
have
done
it
long
ago
,
and
---
<EOS>
no
,
I
could
n't
have
sold
you
afterwards
,
for
you
're
fit
for
nothing
but
keeping
as
a
curiousity
of
ugliness
in
a
glass
bottle
,
and
I
suppose
they
do
n't
blow
glass
bottles
large
enough
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
hush
!
<EOS>
Mr
Sikes
,
"
said
the
Jew
,
trembling
;
"
do
n't
speak
so
loud
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
None
of
your
mistering
,
"
replied
the
ruffian
;
"
you
always
mean
mischief
when
you
come
that
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
my
name
:
 
out
with
it
!
 
<EOS>
I
sha
n't
disgrace
it
when
the
time
comes
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
then
---
Bill
Sikes
,
"
said
the
Jew
,
with
abject
humility
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
seem
out
of
humour
,
Bill
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
I
am
,
"
replied
Sikes
;
"
I
should
think
you
was
rather
out
of
sorts
too
,
unless
you
mean
as
little
harm
when
you
throw
pewter
pots
about
,
as
you
do
when
you
blab
and
<EOS>
---
"
   
"
Are
you
mad
?
"
said
the
Jew
,
catching
the
man
by
the
sleeve
,
and
pointing
towards
the
boys
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Sikes
contented
himself
with
tying
an
imaginary
knot
under
his
left
ear
,
and
jerking
his
head
over
on
the
right
shoulder
;
a
piece
of
dumb
show
which
the
Jew
appeared
to
understand
perfectly
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
,
in
ca
nt
terms
,
with
which
his
whole
conversation
was
plentifully
besprinkled
,
but
which
would
be
quite
unintelligible
if
they
were
recorded
here
,
demanded
a
glass
of
liquor
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
mind
you
do
n't
poison
it
,
"
said
Mr
Sikes
,
laying
his
hat
upon
the
table
.
   
<EOS>
This
was
said
in
jest
;
but
if
the
speaker
could
have
seen
the
evil
leer
with
which
the
Jew
bit
his
pale
lip
as
he
turned
round
to
the
cupboard
,
he
might
have
thought
the
caution
not
wholly
unnecessary
,
or
the
wish
(
at
all
events
)
to
improve
upon
the
distiller
's
ingenuity
not
very
far
from
the
old
gentleman
's
merry
heart
.
   
<EOS>
After
swallowing
two
of
three
glasses
of
spirits
,
Mr
Sikes
condescended
to
take
some
notice
of
the
young
gentlemen
;
which
gracious
act
led
to
a
conversation
,
in
which
the
cause
and
manner
of
Oliver
's
capture
were
circumstantially
detailed
,
with
such
alterations
and
improvements
on
the
truth
,
as
to
the
Dodger
appeared
most
advisable
under
the
circumstances
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
afraid
,
"
said
the
Jew
,
"
that
he
may
say
something
which
will
get
us
into
trouble
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
very
likely
,
"
returned
Sikes
with
a
malicious
grin
.
<EOS>
"
You
're
blowed
upon
,
Fagin
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
'm
afraid
<EOS>
,
you
see
,
added
the
Jew
,
speaking
as
if
he
had
not
noticed
the
interruption
;
and
regarding
the
other
closely
as
he
did
so
,
---
"
I
'm
afraid
that
,
if
the
game
was
up
with
us
,
it
might
be
up
with
a
good
many
more
,
and
that
it
would
come
out
rather
worse
for
you
than
it
would
for
me
,
my
dear
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
man
started
,
and
turned
round
upon
the
Jew
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
old
gentleman
's
shoulders
were
shrugged
up
to
his
ears
;
and
his
eyes
were
vacantly
staring
on
the
opposite
wall
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
long
pause
.
<EOS>
Every
member
of
the
respectable
coterie
appeared
plunged
in
his
own
reflections
;
not
excepting
the
dog
,
who
by
a
certain
malicious
licking
of
his
lips
seemed
to
be
meditating
an
attack
upon
the
legs
of
the
first
gentleman
or
lady
he
might
encounter
in
the
streets
when
he
went
out
.
   
<EOS>
"
Somebody
must
find
out
wot
's
been
done
at
the
office
,
"
said
Mr
Sikes
in
a
much
lower
tone
than
he
had
taken
since
he
came
in
.
   
<EOS>
The
Jew
nodded
assent
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
he
has
n't
peached
,
and
is
committed
,
there
's
no
fear
till
he
comes
out
again
,
"
said
Mr
Sikes
,
"
and
then
he
must
be
taken
care
on
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
get
hold
of
him
somehow
.
"
   
<EOS>
Again
the
Jew
nodded
.
   
<EOS>
The
prudence
of
this
line
of
action
,
indeed
,
was
obvious
;
but
,
unfortunately
,
there
was
one
very
strong
objection
to
its
being
adopted
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
,
that
the
Dodger
,
and
Charley
Bates
,
and
Fagin
,
and
Mr
William
Sikes
,
happened
,
one
and
all
,
to
entertain
a
violent
and
deeply
-
rooted
antipathy
to
going
near
a
police
-
office
on
any
ground
or
pretext
whatever
.
   
<EOS>
How
long
they
might
have
sat
and
looked
at
each
other
,
in
a
state
of
uncertainty
<EOS>
not
the
most
pleasant
of
its
kind
<EOS>
,
it
is
difficult
to
guess
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
necessary
to
make
any
guesses
on
the
subject
,
however
;
for
the
sudden
entrance
of
the
two
young
ladies
whom
Oliver
had
seen
on
a
former
occasion
,
caused
the
conversation
to
flow
afresh
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
very
thing
!
"
said
the
Jew
.
 
<EOS>
"
Bet
will
go
;
wo
n't
you
,
my
dear
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Where
s
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
the
young
lady
.
   
<EOS>
"
Only
just
up
to
the
office
,
my
dear
,
"
said
the
Jew
coaxingly
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
due
to
the
young
lady
to
say
that
she
did
not
positively
affirm
that
she
would
not
,
but
that
she
merely
expressed
an
emphatic
and
earnest
desire
to
be
"
blessed
"
if
she
would
;
a
polite
and
delicate
evasion
of
the
request
,
which
shows
the
young
lady
to
have
been
possessed
of
that
natural
good
breeding
which
can
not
bear
to
inflict
upon
a
fellow
-
creature
,
the
pain
of
a
direct
and
pointed
refusal
.
   
<EOS>
The
Jew
's
countenance
fell
.
 
<EOS>
He
turned
from
this
young
lady
,
who
was
gaily
,
not
to
say
gorgeously
attired
,
in
a
red
gown
,
green
boots
,
and
yellow
curl
-
papers
,
to
the
other
female
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nancy
,
my
dear
,
"
said
the
Jew
in
a
soothing
manner
,
"
what
do
YOU
say
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
it
wo
n't
do
;
so
it
's
no
use
a
-
trying
it
on
,
Fagin
,
"
replied
Nancy
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
by
that
?
"
said
Mr
Sikes
,
looking
up
in
a
surly
manner
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
I
say
,
Bill
,
"
replied
the
lady
collectedly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
're
just
the
very
person
for
it
,
"
reasoned
Mr
Sikes
:
"
nobody
about
here
knows
anything
of
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
as
I
do
n't
want
'em
to
,
neither
,
"
replied
Nancy
in
the
same
composed
manner
<EOS>
,
"
it
's
rather
more
no
than
yes
with
me
,
Bill
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
'll
go
,
Fagin
,
"
said
Sikes
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
she
wo
n't
,
Fagin
,
"
said
Nancy
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
she
will
,
Fagin
,
"
said
Sikes
.
   
<EOS>
And
Mr
Sikes
was
right
.
 
<EOS>
By
dint
of
alternate
threats
,
promises
,
and
bribes
,
the
lady
in
question
was
ultimately
prevailed
upon
to
undertake
the
commission
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
not
,
indeed
,
withheld
by
the
same
considerations
as
her
agreeable
friend
;
for
,
having
recently
removed
into
the
neighborhood
of
Field
Lane
from
the
remote
but
genteel
suburb
of
Ratcliffe
,
she
was
not
under
the
same
apprehension
of
being
recognised
by
any
of
her
numerous
acquaintance
.
   
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
with
a
clean
white
apron
tied
over
her
gown
,
and
her
curl
-
papers
tucked
up
under
a
straw
bonnet
,
---
both
articles
of
dress
being
provided
from
the
Jew
's
inexhaustible
stock
,
---
<EOS>
Miss
Nancy
prepared
to
issue
forth
on
her
errand
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stop
a
minute
,
my
dear
,
"
said
the
Jew
,
producing
,
a
little
covered
basket
.
 
<EOS>
"
Carry
that
in
one
hand
.
 
<EOS>
It
looks
more
respectable
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Give
her
a
door
-
key
to
carry
in
her
t'other
one
,
Fagin
,
"
said
Sikes
;
"
it
looks
real
and
genivine
like
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
,
my
dear
,
so
it
does
,
"
said
the
Jew
,
hanging
a
large
street
-
door
key
on
the
forefinger
of
the
young
lady
's
right
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
;
very
good
!
 
<EOS>
Very
good
indeed
,
my
dear
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
Jew
,
rubbing
his
hands
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
my
brother
!
 
<EOS>
My
poor
,
dear
,
sweet
,
innocent
little
brother
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Nancy
,
bursting
into
tears
,
and
wringing
the
little
basket
and
the
street
-
door
key
in
an
agony
of
distress
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
has
become
of
him
!
 
<EOS>
Where
have
they
taken
him
to
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
do
have
pity
,
and
tell
me
what
's
been
done
with
the
dear
boy
,
gentlemen
;
do
,
gentlemen
,
if
you
please
,
gentlemen
!
"
   
<EOS>
Having
uttered
those
words
in
a
most
lamentable
and
heart
-
broken
tone
:
 
to
the
immeasurable
delight
of
her
hearers
:
 
Miss
Nancy
paused
,
winked
to
the
company
,
nodded
smilingly
round
,
and
disappeared
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
,
she
's
a
clever
girl
,
my
dears
,
"
said
the
Jew
,
turning
round
to
his
young
friends
,
and
shaking
his
head
gravely
,
as
if
in
mute
admonition
to
them
to
follow
the
bright
example
they
had
just
beheld
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
's
a
honour
to
her
sex
,
"
said
Mr
Sikes
,
filling
his
glass
,
and
smiting
the
table
with
his
enormous
fist
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
's
her
health
,
and
wishing
they
was
all
like
her
!
"
   
<EOS>
While
these
,
and
many
other
encomiums
,
were
being
passed
on
the
accomplished
Nancy
,
that
young
lady
made
the
best
of
her
way
to
the
police
-
office
;
whither
,
notwithstanding
a
little
natural
timidity
consequent
upon
walking
through
the
streets
alone
and
unprotected
,
she
arrived
in
perfect
safety
shortly
afterwards
.
   
<EOS>
Entering
by
the
back
way
,
she
tapped
softly
with
the
key
at
one
of
the
cell
-
doors
,
and
listened
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
sound
within
:
 
<EOS>
so
she
coughed
and
listened
again
.
 
<EOS>
Still
there
was
no
reply
:
 
so
she
spoke
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nolly
,
dear
?
"
murmured
Nancy
in
a
gentle
voice
;
"
Nolly
?
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
nobody
inside
but
a
miserable
shoeless
criminal
,
who
had
been
taken
up
for
playing
the
flute
,
and
who
,
the
offence
against
society
having
been
clearly
proved
,
had
been
very
properly
committed
by
Mr
Fang
to
the
House
of
Correction
for
one
month
;
with
the
appropriate
and
amusing
remark
that
since
he
had
so
much
breath
to
spare
,
it
would
be
more
wholesomely
expended
on
the
treadmill
than
in
a
musical
instrument
.
 
<EOS>
He
made
no
answer
:
being
occupied
mentally
bewailing
the
loss
of
the
flute
,
which
had
been
confiscated
for
the
use
of
the
county
:
 
<EOS>
so
Nancy
passed
on
to
the
next
cell
,
and
knocked
there
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
"
cried
a
faint
and
feeble
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
there
a
little
boy
here
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Nancy
,
with
a
preliminary
sob
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
the
voice
;
"
God
forbid
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
a
vagrant
of
sixty
-
five
,
who
was
going
to
prison
for
NOT
playing
the
flute
;
or
,
in
other
words
,
for
begging
in
the
streets
,
and
doing
nothing
for
his
livelihood
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
next
cell
was
another
man
,
who
was
going
to
the
same
prison
for
hawking
tin
saucepans
without
license
;
thereby
doing
something
for
his
living
,
in
defiance
of
the
Stamp
-
office
.
   
<EOS>
But
,
as
neither
of
these
criminals
answered
to
the
name
of
Oliver
,
or
knew
anything
about
him
,
Nancy
made
straight
up
to
the
bluff
officer
in
the
striped
waistcoat
;
and
with
the
most
piteous
wailings
and
lamentations
,
rendered
more
piteous
by
a
prompt
and
efficient
use
of
the
street
-
door
key
and
the
little
basket
,
demanded
her
own
dear
brother
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
n't
got
him
,
my
dear
,
"
said
the
old
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
is
he
?
"
<EOS>
screamed
Nancy
,
in
a
distracted
manner
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
the
gentleman
's
got
him
,
"
replied
the
officer
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
gentleman
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
gracious
heavens
!
 
<EOS>
What
gentleman
?
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Nancy
.
   
<EOS>
In
reply
to
this
incoherent
questioning
,
the
old
man
informed
the
deeply
affected
sister
that
Oliver
had
been
taken
ill
in
the
office
,
and
discharged
in
consequence
of
a
witness
having
proved
the
robbery
to
have
been
committed
by
another
boy
,
not
in
custody
;
and
that
the
prosecutor
had
carried
him
away
,
in
an
insensible
condition
,
to
his
own
residence
:
 
of
and
concerning
which
,
all
the
informant
knew
was
,
that
it
was
somewhere
in
Pentonville
<EOS>
,
he
having
heard
that
word
mentioned
in
the
directions
to
the
coachman
.
   
<EOS>
In
a
dreadful
state
of
doubt
and
uncertainty
,
the
agonised
young
woman
staggered
to
the
gate
,
and
then
,
exchanging
her
faltering
walk
for
a
swift
run
,
returned
by
the
most
devious
and
complicated
route
she
could
think
of
,
to
the
domicile
of
the
Jew
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bill
Sikes
no
sooner
heard
the
account
of
the
expedition
delivered
,
than
he
very
hastily
called
up
the
white
dog
,
and
,
putting
on
his
hat
,
expeditiously
departed
:
 
without
devoting
any
time
to
the
formality
of
wishing
the
company
good
-
morning
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
must
know
where
he
is
,
my
dears
;
he
must
be
found
,
"
said
the
Jew
greatly
excited
.
 
<EOS>
"
Charley
,
do
nothing
but
skulk
about
,
till
you
bring
home
some
news
of
him
!
 
<EOS>
Nancy
,
my
dear
,
I
must
have
him
found
.
 
<EOS>
I
trust
to
you
,
my
dear
,
---
to
you
and
the
Artful
for
everything
!
 
<EOS>
Stay
,
stay
,
"
added
the
Jew
,
unlocking
a
drawer
with
a
shaking
hand
;
"
there
's
money
,
my
dears
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
shut
up
this
shop
to
-
night
.
 
<EOS>
You
'll
know
where
to
find
me
!
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
stop
here
a
minute
.
 
<EOS>
Not
an
instant
,
my
dears
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
these
words
,
he
pushed
them
from
the
room
:
 
and
carefully
double
-
locking
and
barring
the
door
behind
them
,
drew
from
its
place
of
concealment
the
box
which
he
had
unintentionally
disclosed
to
Oliver
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
he
hastily
proceeded
to
dispose
the
watches
and
jewellery
beneath
his
clothing
.
   
<EOS>
A
rap
at
the
door
startled
him
in
this
occupation
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
's
there
?
"
<EOS>
he
cried
in
a
shrill
tone
.
   
<EOS>
"
Me
!
"
replied
the
voice
of
the
Dodger
,
through
the
key
-
hole
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
now
?
"
cried
the
Jew
impatiently
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
he
to
be
kidnapped
to
the
other
ken
,
Nancy
says
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
the
Dodger
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
replied
the
Jew
,
"
wherever
she
lays
hands
on
him
.
 
<EOS>
Find
him
,
find
him
out
,
that
's
all
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
know
what
to
do
next
;
never
fear
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
boy
murmured
a
reply
of
intelligence
:
 
and
hurried
downstairs
after
his
companions
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
has
not
peached
so
far
,
"
said
the
Jew
as
he
pursued
his
occupation
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
he
means
to
blab
us
among
his
new
friends
,
we
may
stop
his
mouth
yet
.
"
    
Chapter
14
.
<EOS>
Comprising
further
particulars
of
Oliver
's
stay
at
Mr
Brownlow
's
,
with
the
remarkable
prediction
which
one
Mr
Grimwig
uttered
concerning
him
,
when
he
went
out
on
an
errand
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
soon
recovering
from
the
fainting
-
fit
into
which
Mr
Brownlow
's
abrupt
exclamation
had
thrown
him
,
the
subject
of
the
picture
was
carefully
avoided
,
both
by
the
old
gentleman
and
Mrs
Bedwin
,
in
the
conversation
that
ensued
:
 
which
indeed
bore
no
reference
to
Oliver
's
history
or
prospects
,
but
was
confined
to
such
topics
as
might
amuse
without
exciting
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
still
too
weak
to
get
up
to
breakfast
;
but
,
when
he
came
down
into
the
housekeeper
's
room
next
day
,
his
first
act
was
to
cast
an
eager
glance
at
the
wall
,
in
the
hope
of
again
looking
on
the
face
of
the
beautiful
lady
.
 
<EOS>
His
expectations
were
disappointed
,
however
,
for
the
picture
had
been
removed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
housekeeper
,
watching
the
direction
of
Oliver
's
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
gone
,
you
see
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
see
it
is
ma'am
,
"
replied
Oliver
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
have
they
taken
it
away
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
has
been
taken
down
,
child
,
because
Mr
Brownlow
said
,
that
as
it
seemed
to
worry
you
,
perhaps
it
might
prevent
your
getting
well
,
you
know
,
"
rejoined
the
old
lady
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
no
,
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
It
did
n't
worry
me
,
ma'am
,
"
said
Oliver
.
<EOS>
"
I
liked
to
see
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
quite
loved
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
!
"
said
the
old
lady
,
good
-
humouredly
;
<EOS>
"
you
get
well
as
fast
as
ever
you
can
,
dear
,
and
it
shall
be
hung
up
again
.
<EOS>
There
!
 
<EOS>
I
promise
you
that
!
 
<EOS>
Now
,
let
us
talk
about
something
else
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
all
the
information
Oliver
could
obtain
about
the
picture
at
that
time
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
old
lady
had
been
so
kind
to
him
in
his
illness
,
he
endeavoured
to
think
no
more
of
the
subject
just
then
;
so
he
listened
attentively
to
a
great
many
stories
she
told
him
,
about
an
amiable
and
handsome
daughter
of
hers
,
who
was
married
to
an
amiable
and
handsome
man
,
and
lived
in
the
country
;
and
about
a
son
,
who
was
clerk
to
a
merchant
in
the
West
Indies
;
and
who
was
,
also
,
such
a
good
young
man
,
and
wrote
such
dutiful
letters
home
four
times
a
-
year
,
that
it
brought
the
tears
into
her
eyes
to
talk
about
them
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
old
lady
had
expatiated
,
a
long
time
,
on
the
excellences
of
her
children
,
and
the
merits
of
her
kind
good
husband
besides
,
who
had
been
dead
and
gone
,
poor
dear
soul
!
<EOS>
just
six
-
and
-
twenty
years
,
it
was
time
to
have
tea
.
<EOS>
After
tea
she
began
to
teach
Oliver
cribbage
:
which
he
learnt
as
quickly
as
she
could
teach
:
 
and
at
which
game
they
played
,
with
great
interest
and
gravity
,
until
it
was
time
for
the
invalid
to
have
some
warm
wine
and
water
,
with
a
slice
of
dry
toast
,
and
then
to
go
cosily
to
bed
.
   
<EOS>
They
were
happy
days
,
those
of
Oliver
's
recovery
.
 
<EOS>
Everything
was
so
quiet
,
and
neat
,
and
orderly
;
<EOS>
everybody
so
kind
and
gentle
;
that
after
the
noise
and
turbulence
in
the
midst
of
which
he
had
always
lived
,
it
seemed
like
Heaven
itself
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
no
sooner
strong
enough
to
put
his
clothes
on
,
properly
,
than
Mr
Brownlow
caused
a
complete
new
suit
,
and
a
new
cap
,
and
a
new
pair
of
shoes
,
to
be
provided
for
him
.
 
<EOS>
As
Oliver
was
told
that
he
might
do
what
he
liked
with
the
old
clothes
,
he
gave
them
to
a
servant
who
had
been
very
kind
to
him
,
and
asked
her
to
sell
them
to
a
Jew
,
and
keep
the
money
for
herself
.
 
<EOS>
This
she
very
readily
did
;
and
,
as
Oliver
looked
out
of
the
parlour
window
,
and
saw
the
Jew
roll
them
up
in
his
bag
and
walk
away
,
he
felt
quite
delighted
to
think
that
they
were
safely
gone
,
and
that
there
was
now
no
possible
danger
of
his
ever
being
able
to
wear
them
again
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
sad
rags
,
to
tell
the
truth
;
and
Oliver
had
never
had
a
new
suit
before
.
   
<EOS>
One
evening
,
about
a
week
after
the
affair
of
the
picture
,
as
he
was
sitting
talking
to
Mrs
Bedwin
,
there
came
a
message
down
from
Mr
Brownlow
,
that
if
Oliver
Twist
felt
pretty
well
,
he
should
like
to
see
him
in
his
study
,
and
talk
to
him
a
little
while
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bless
us
,
and
save
us
!
 
<EOS>
Wash
your
hands
,
and
let
me
part
your
hair
nicely
for
you
,
child
,
"
said
Mrs
Bedwin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dear
heart
alive
!
 
<EOS>
If
we
had
known
he
would
have
asked
for
you
,
we
would
have
put
you
a
clean
collar
on
,
and
made
you
as
smart
as
sixpence
!
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver
did
as
the
old
lady
bade
him
;
and
,
although
she
lamented
grievously
,
meanwhile
,
that
there
was
not
even
time
to
crimp
the
little
frill
that
bordered
his
shirt
-
collar
;
he
looked
so
delicate
and
handsome
,
despite
that
important
personal
advantage
,
that
she
went
so
far
as
to
say
:
 
looking
at
him
with
great
complacency
from
head
to
foot
,
that
she
really
did
n't
think
it
would
have
been
possible
,
on
the
longest
notice
,
to
have
made
much
difference
in
him
for
the
better
.
   
<EOS>
Thus
encouraged
,
Oliver
tapped
at
the
study
door
.
 
<EOS>
On
Mr
Brownlow
calling
to
him
to
come
in
,
he
found
himself
in
a
little
back
room
,
quite
full
of
books
,
with
a
window
,
looking
into
some
pleasant
little
gardens
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
table
drawn
up
before
the
window
,
at
which
Mr
Brownlow
was
seated
reading
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
saw
Oliver
,
he
pushed
the
book
away
from
him
,
and
told
him
to
come
near
the
table
,
and
sit
down
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
complied
;
marvelling
where
the
people
could
be
found
to
read
such
a
great
number
of
books
as
seemed
to
be
written
to
make
the
world
wiser
.
 
<EOS>
Which
is
still
a
marvel
to
more
experienced
people
than
Oliver
Twist
,
every
day
of
their
lives
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
are
a
good
many
books
,
are
there
not
,
my
boy
?
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
,
observing
the
curiosity
with
which
Oliver
surveyed
the
shelves
that
reached
from
the
floor
to
the
ceiling
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
great
number
,
sir
,
"
replied
Oliver
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
never
saw
so
many
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
shall
read
them
,
if
you
behave
well
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
kindly
;
"
and
you
will
like
that
,
better
than
looking
at
the
outsides
,
---
that
is
,
some
cases
;
because
there
are
books
of
which
the
backs
and
covers
are
by
far
the
best
parts
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
they
are
those
heavy
ones
,
sir
,
"
said
Oliver
,
pointing
to
some
large
quartos
,
with
a
good
deal
of
gilding
about
the
binding
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
always
those
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
,
patting
Oliver
on
the
head
,
and
smiling
as
he
did
so
;
"
there
are
other
equally
heavy
ones
,
though
of
a
much
smaller
size
.
 
<EOS>
How
should
you
like
to
grow
up
a
clever
man
,
and
write
books
,
eh
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
would
rather
read
them
,
sir
,
"
replied
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
!
<EOS>
would
n't
you
like
to
be
a
book
-
writer
?
<EOS>
"
said
the
old
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
considered
a
little
while
;
and
at
last
said
,
he
should
think
it
would
be
a
much
better
thing
to
be
a
book
-
seller
;
upon
which
the
old
gentleman
laughed
heartily
,
and
declared
he
had
said
a
very
good
thing
.
 
<EOS>
Which
Oliver
felt
glad
to
have
done
,
though
he
by
no
means
knew
what
it
was
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
,
composing
his
features
.
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
afraid
!
 
<EOS>
We
wo
n't
make
an
author
of
you
,
while
there
's
an
honest
trade
to
be
learnt
,
or
brick
-
making
to
turn
to
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
sir
,
"
said
Oliver
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
earnest
manner
of
his
reply
,
the
old
gentleman
laughed
again
;
and
said
something
about
a
curious
instinct
,
which
Oliver
,
not
understanding
,
paid
no
very
great
attention
to
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
,
speaking
if
possible
in
a
kinder
,
but
at
the
same
time
in
a
much
more
serious
manner
,
than
Oliver
had
ever
known
him
assume
yet
,
"
I
want
you
to
pay
great
attention
,
my
boy
,
to
what
I
am
going
to
say
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
talk
to
you
without
any
reserve
;
because
I
am
sure
you
are
well
able
to
understand
me
,
as
many
older
persons
would
be
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
do
n't
tell
you
are
going
to
send
me
away
,
sir
,
pray
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Oliver
,
alarmed
at
the
serious
tone
of
the
old
gentleman
's
commencement
!
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
turn
me
out
of
doors
to
wander
in
the
streets
again
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
stay
here
,
and
be
a
servant
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
send
me
back
to
the
wretched
place
I
came
from
.
 
<EOS>
Have
mercy
upon
a
poor
boy
,
sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
child
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
,
moved
by
the
warmth
of
Oliver
's
sudden
appeal
;
"
you
need
not
be
afraid
of
my
deserting
you
,
unless
you
give
me
cause
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
never
,
never
will
,
sir
,
"
interposed
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
not
,
"
rejoined
the
old
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
think
you
ever
will
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
deceived
,
before
,
in
the
objects
whom
I
have
endeavoured
to
benefit
;
but
I
feel
strongly
disposed
to
trust
you
,
nevertheless
;
and
I
am
more
interested
in
your
behalf
than
I
can
well
account
for
,
even
to
myself
.
 
<EOS>
The
persons
on
whom
I
have
bestowed
my
dearest
love
,
lie
deep
in
their
graves
;
but
,
although
the
happiness
and
delight
of
my
life
lie
buried
there
too
<EOS>
,
I
have
not
made
a
coffin
of
my
heart
,
and
sealed
it
up
,
forever
,
on
my
best
affections
.
 
<EOS>
Deep
affliction
has
but
strengthened
and
refined
them
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
the
old
gentleman
said
this
in
a
low
voice
:
 
more
to
himself
than
to
his
companion
:
 
and
as
he
remained
silent
for
a
short
time
afterwards
:
 
Oliver
sat
quite
still
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
well
!
"
said
the
old
gentleman
at
length
,
in
a
more
cheerful
tone
,
"
<EOS>
I
only
say
this
,
because
you
have
a
young
heart
;
and
knowing
that
I
have
suffered
great
pain
and
sorrow
,
you
will
be
more
careful
,
perhaps
,
not
to
wound
me
again
.
 
<EOS>
You
say
you
are
an
orphan
,
without
a
friend
in
the
world
;
all
the
inquiries
I
have
been
able
to
make
,
confirm
the
statement
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
hear
your
story
;
where
you
come
from
;
who
brought
you
up
;
and
how
you
got
into
the
company
in
which
I
found
you
.
 
<EOS>
Speak
the
truth
,
and
you
shall
not
be
friendless
while
I
live
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver
's
sobs
checked
his
utterance
for
some
minutes
;
when
he
was
on
the
point
of
beginning
to
relate
how
he
had
been
brought
up
at
the
farm
,
and
carried
to
the
workhouse
by
Mr
Bumble
,
a
peculiarly
impatient
little
double
-
knock
was
heard
at
the
street
-
door
:
 
and
the
servant
,
running
upstairs
,
announced
Mr
Grimwig
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
he
coming
up
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Brownlow
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
servant
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
asked
if
there
were
any
muffins
in
the
house
;
and
,
when
I
told
him
yes
,
he
said
he
had
come
to
tea
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Brownlow
smiled
;
and
,
turning
to
Oliver
,
said
that
Mr
Grimwig
was
an
old
friend
of
his
,
and
he
must
not
mind
his
being
a
little
rough
in
his
manners
;
for
he
was
a
worthy
creature
at
bottom
,
as
he
had
reason
to
know
.
   
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
go
downstairs
,
sir
?
"
inquired
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
Mr
Brownlow
,
"
I
would
rather
you
remained
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
At
this
moment
,
there
walked
into
the
room
:
 
supporting
himself
by
a
thick
stick
:
 
<EOS>
a
stout
old
gentleman
,
rather
lame
in
one
leg
,
who
was
dressed
in
a
blue
coat
,
striped
waistcoat
,
nankeen
breeches
and
gaiters
,
and
a
broad
-
brimmed
white
hat
,
with
the
sides
turned
up
with
green
.
 
<EOS>
A
very
small
-
plaited
shirt
frill
stuck
out
from
his
waistcoat
;
and
a
very
long
steel
watch
-
chain
,
with
nothing
but
a
key
at
the
end
,
dangled
loosely
below
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
ends
of
his
white
neckerchief
were
twisted
into
a
ball
about
the
size
of
an
orange
;
the
variety
of
shapes
into
which
his
countenance
was
twisted
,
defy
description
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
manner
of
screwing
his
head
on
one
side
when
he
spoke
;
and
of
looking
out
of
the
corners
of
his
eyes
at
the
same
time
:
 
which
irresistibly
reminded
the
beholder
of
a
parrot
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
attitude
,
he
fixed
himself
,
the
moment
he
made
his
appearance
;
and
,
holding
out
a
small
piece
of
orange
-
peel
at
arm
's
length
,
exclaimed
,
in
a
growling
,
discontented
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
Look
here
!
<EOS>
do
you
see
this
!
 
<EOS>
Is
n't
it
a
most
wonderful
and
extraordinary
thing
that
I
ca
n't
call
at
a
man
's
house
<EOS>
but
I
find
a
piece
of
this
poor
surgeon
's
friend
on
the
staircase
?
<EOS>
I
've
been
lamed
with
orange
-
peel
once
,
and
I
know
orange
-
peel
will
be
my
death
,
or
I
'll
be
content
to
eat
my
own
head
,
sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
the
handsome
offer
with
which
Mr
Grimwig
backed
and
confirmed
nearly
every
assertion
he
made
;
and
it
was
the
more
singular
in
his
case
,
because
,
even
admitting
for
the
sake
of
argument
,
the
possibility
of
scientific
improvements
being
brought
to
that
pass
which
will
enable
a
gentleman
to
eat
his
own
head
in
the
event
of
his
being
so
disposed
,
Mr
Grimwig
's
head
was
such
a
particularly
large
one
,
that
the
most
sanguine
man
alive
could
hardly
entertain
a
hope
of
being
able

get
through
it
at
a
sitting
---
to
put
entirely
out
of
the
question
,
a
very
thick
coating
of
powder
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
eat
my
head
,
sir
,
"
repeated
Mr
Grimwig
,
striking
his
stick
upon
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hallo
!
<EOS>
what
's
that
!
"
<EOS>
looking
at
Oliver
,
and
retreating
a
pace
or
two
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
young
Oliver
Twist
,
whom
we
were
speaking
about
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
bowed
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
mean
to
say
that
's
the
boy
who
had
the
fever
,
I
hope
?
"
said
Mr
Grimwig
,
recoiling
a
little
more
.
 
<EOS>
"
Wait
a
minute
!
<EOS>
Do
n't
speak
!
 
<EOS>
Stop
---
"
continued
Mr
Grimwig
,
abruptly
,
losing
all
dread
of
the
fever
in
his
triumph
at
the
discovery
;
"
that
's
the
boy
who
had
the
orange
!
 
<EOS>
If
that
's
not
the
boy
,
sir
,
who
had
the
orange
,
and
threw
this
bit
of
peel
upon
the
staircase
,
I
'll
eat
my
head
,
and
his
too
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
he
has
not
had
one
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
,
laughing
.
<EOS>
"
Come
!
 
<EOS>
Put
down
your
hat
;
and
speak
to
my
young
friend
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
feel
strongly
on
this
subject
,
sir
,
"
said
the
irritable
old
gentleman
,
drawing
off
his
gloves
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
's
always
more
or
less
orange
-
peel
on
the
pavement
in
our
street
;
and
I
KNOW
it
's
put
there
by
the
surgeon
's
boy
at
the
corner
.
 
<EOS>
A
young
woman
stumbled
over
a
bit
last
night
,
and
fell
against
my
garden
-
railings
;
directly
she
got
up
<EOS>
I
saw
her
look
towards
his
infernal
red
lamp
with
the
pantomime
-
light
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
go
to
him
,
"
<EOS>
I
called
out
of
the
window
,
"
he
's
an
assassin
!
 
<EOS>
A
man
-
trap
!
"
 
<EOS>
So
he
is
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
is
not
---
"
 
Here
the
irascible
old
gentleman
gave
a
great
knock
on
the
ground
with
his
stick
;
which
was
always
understood
,
by
his
friends
,
to
imply
the
customary
offer
,
whenever
it
was
not
expressed
in
words
.
<EOS>
Then
,
still
keeping
his
stick
in
his
hand
,
he
sat
down
;
and
,
opening
a
double
eye
-
glass
,
which
he
wore
attached
to
a
broad
black
riband
,
took
a
view
of
Oliver
:
 
who
,
seeing
that
he
was
the
object
of
inspection
,
coloured
,
and
bowed
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
boy
,
is

?
"
said
Mr
Grimwig
,
at
length
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
boy
,
"
replied
Mr
Brownlow
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
are
you
,
boy
?
"
said
Mr
Grimwig
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
great
deal
better
,
thank
you
,
sir
,
"
replied
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Brownlow
,
seeming
to
apprehend
that
his
singular
friend
was
about
to
say
something
disagreeable
,
asked
Oliver
to
step

and
tell
Mrs
Bedwin
they
were
ready
for
tea
;
which
,
as
he
did
not
half
like
the
visitor
's
manner
,
he
was
very
happy
to
do
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
is
a
nice
-
looking
boy
,
is
he
not
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Brownlow
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
"
replied
Mr
Grimwig
,
pettishly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
know
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
see
any
difference
in
boys
.
 
<EOS>
I
only
knew
two
sort
of
boys
.
 
<EOS>
Mealy
boys
,
and
beef
-
faced
boys
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
which
is
Oliver
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mealy
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
a
friend
who
has
a
beef
-
faced
boy
;
a
fine
boy
<EOS>
,
they
call
him
;
with
a
round
head
,
and
red
cheeks
,
and
glaring

;
a
horrid
boy
;
with
a
body
and
limbs
that
appear
to
be
swelling
out
of
the
seams
of
his
blue
clothes
;
with
the
voice
of
a
pilot
,
and
the
appetite
of
a
wolf
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
him
!
 
<EOS>
The
wretch
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
,
"
these
are
not
the
characteristics
of
young
Oliver
Twist
;
so
he
need
n't
excite
your
wrath
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
They
are
not
,
"
replied
Mr
Grimwig
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
may
have
worse
.
"
   
<EOS>
Here
,
Mr
Brownlow
coughed
impatiently
;
which
appeared
to
afford
Mr
Grimwig
the
most
exquisite
delight
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
may
have
worse
,
I
say
,
"
repeated
Mr
Grimwig
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
does
he
come
from
!
 
<EOS>
Who
is
he
?
 
<EOS>
What
is
he
?
 
<EOS>
He
has
had
a
fever
.
 
<EOS>
What
of
that
?
 
<EOS>
Fevers
are
not
peculiar
to
good
peope
;
are
they
?
 
<EOS>
Bad
people
have
fevers
sometimes
;
have
n't
they
,
eh
?
 
<EOS>
I
knew
a
man
who
was
hung
in
Jamaica
for
murdering
his
master
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
had
a
fever
six
times
;
he
was
n't
recommended
to
mercy
on
that
account
.
 
<EOS>
Pooh
!
<EOS>
nonsense
!
"
   
<EOS>
Now
,
the
fact
was
,
that
in
the
inmost
recesses
of
his
own
heart
,
Mr
Grimwig
was
strongly
disposed
to
admit
that
Oliver
's
appearance
and
manner
were
unusually
prepossessing
;
but
he
had
a
strong
appetite
for
contradiction
,
sharpened
on
this
occasion
by
the
finding
of
the
orange
-
peel
;
and
,
inwardly
determining
that
no
man
should
dictate
to
him
whether
a
boy
was
well
-
looking
or
not
,
he
had
resolved
,
from
the
first
,
to
oppose
his
friend
.
 
<EOS>
When
Mr
Brownlow
admitted
that
on
no
one
point
of
inquiry
could
he
yet
return
a
satisfactory
answer
;
and
that
he
had
postponed
any
investigation
into
Oliver
's
previous
history
until
he
thought
the
boy
was
strong
enough
to
hear
it
;
Mr
Grimwig
chuckled
maliciously
.
 
<EOS>
And
he
demanded
,
with
a
sneer
,
whether
the
housekeeper
was
in
the
habit
of
counting
the
plate
at
night
;
because
if
she
did
n't
find
a
table
-
spoon
or
two
missing
some
sunshiny
morning
,
why
,
he
would
be
content
to
---
and
so
forth
.
   
<EOS>
All
this
,
Mr
Brownlow
,
although
himself
somewhat
of
an
impetuous
gentleman
:
 
knowing
his
friend
's
peculiarities
,
bore
with
great
good
humour
;
as
Mr
Grimwig
,
at
tea
,
was
graciously
pleased
to
express
his
entire
approval
of
the
muffins
<EOS>
,
matters
went
on
very
smoothly
;
and
Oliver
,
who
made
one
of
the
party
,
began
to
feel
more
at
his
ease
than
he
had
yet
done
in
the
fierce
old
gentleman
's
presence
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
when
are
you
going
to
hear

full
,
true
,
and
particular
account
of
the
life
and

of
Oliver
Twist
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Grimwig
of
Mr
Brownlow
,
at
the
conclusion
of
the
meal
;
looking

at
Oliver
,
as
he

his

.
   
<EOS>
"
To
-
morrow
morning
,
"
replied
Mr
Brownlow
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
would
rather
he
was
alone
with
me
at
the
time
.
 
<EOS>
Come
up
to
me
to
-
morrow
morning
at
ten
o'clock
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
replied
Oliver
.
 
<EOS>
He
answered
with
some
hesitation
,
because
he
was
confused
by
Mr
Grimwig
's
looking
so
hard
at
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
tell
you
<EOS>
what
,
"
whispered
that
gentleman
to
Mr
Brownlow
;
"
he
wo
n't
come
up
to
you
to
-
morrow

.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
him
hesitate
.
<EOS>
He
is
deceiving
you
,
my
good
friend
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
swear
he
is
not
,
"
replied
Mr
Brownlow
,
warmly
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
he
is
not
,
"
said
Mr
Grimwig
,
"
I
'll
---
"
and
down
went
the
stick
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
answer
for
that
boy
's
truth
with
my
life
!
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
,
knocking
the
table
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
for
his
falsehood
with
my
head
!
"
rejoined
Mr
Grimwig
,
knocking
the
table
also
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
shall
see
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
,
checking
his
rising
anger
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
will
,
"
replied
Mr
Grimwig
,
with
a
provoking
smile
;
 
"
we
will
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
fate
would
have
it
,
Mrs
Bedwin
chanced
to
bring
in
,
at
this
moment
,
a
small
parcel
of
books
,
which
Mr
Brownlow
had
that
morning
purchased
of
the
identical
bookstall
-
keeper
,
who
has
already
figured
in
this
history
;
having
laid
them
on
the
table
,
she
prepared
to
leave
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stop
the
boy
,
Mrs
Bedwin
!
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
;
"
there
is
something
to
go
back
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
has
gone
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mrs
Bedwin
.
   
<EOS>
"
Call
after
him
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
;
<EOS>
"
it
's
particular
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
a
poor
man
,
and
they
are
not
paid
for
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
some
books
to
be
taken
back
,
too
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
street
-
door
was
opened
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
ran
one
way
;
and
the
girl
ran
another
;
and
Mrs
Bedwin
stood
on
the
step
and
screamed
for
the
boy
;
but
there
was
no
boy
in
sight
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
and
the
girl
returned
,
in
a
breathless
state
,
to
report
that
there
were
no
tidings
of
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
,
I
am
very
sorry
for
that
,
"
exclaimed
Mr
Brownlow
;
"
I
particularly
wished
those
books
to
be
returned
to
-
night
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Send
Oliver
with
them
,
"
said
Mr
Grimwig
,
with
an
ironical
smile
;
"
he
will
be
sure
to
deliver
them
safely
,
you
know
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
do
let
me
take
them
,
if
you
please
,
sir
,
"
said
Oliver
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
run
all
the
way
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
old
gentleman
was
just
going
to
say
that
Oliver
should
not
go
out
on
any
account
;
when
a
most
malicious
cough
from
Mr
Grimwig
determined
him
that
he
should
;
and
that
,
by
his
prompt
discharge
of
the
commission
,
he
should
prove
to
him
the
injustice
of
his
suspicions
:
 
on
this
head
at
least
:
 
at
once
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
SHALL
go
,
my
dear
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
books
are
on
a
chair
by
my
table
.
 
<EOS>
Fetch
them
down
.
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver
,
delighted
to
be
of
use
,
brought
down
the
books
under
his
arm
in
a
great
bustle
;
and
waited
,
cap
in
hand
,
to
hear
what
message
he
was
to
take
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
to
say
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
,
glancing
steadily
at
Grimwig
;
"
you
are
to
say
that
you
have
brought
those
books
back
;
and
that
you
have
come
to
pay
the
four
pound
ten
I
owe
him
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
a
five
-
pound
note
,
so
you
will
have
to
bring
me
back
,
ten
shillings
change
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
wo
n't
be
ten
minutes
,
sir
,
"
said
Oliver
,
eagerly
.
 
<EOS>
Having
buttoned
up
the
bank
-
note
in
his
jacket
pocket
,
and
placed
the
books
carefully
under
his
arm
,
he
made
a
respectful
bow
,
and
left
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Bedwin
followed
him
to
the
street
-
door
,
giving
him
many
directions
about
the
nearest
way
,
and
the
name
of
the
bookseller
,
and
the
name
of
the
street
:
 
all
of
which
Oliver
said
he
clearly
understood
.
 
<EOS>
Having
superadded
many
injunctions
to
be
sure
and
not
take
cold
,
the
old
lady
at
length
permitted
him
to
depart
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bless
his
sweet
face
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
old
lady
,
looking
after
him
.
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
bear
,
somehow
,
to
let
him
go
out
of
my
sight
.
"
   
<EOS>
At
this
moment
,
Oliver
looked
gaily
round
,
and
nodded
before
he
turned
the
corner
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
lady
smilingly
returned
his
salutation
,
and
,
closing
the
door
,
went
back
,
to
her
own
room
.
   
<EOS>
"
Let
me
see
;
he
'll
be
back
in
twenty
minutes
,
at
the
longest
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
,
pulling
out
his
watch
,
and
placing
it
on
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
will
be
dark
by
that
time
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
you
really
expect
him
to
come
back
,
do
you
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Grimwig
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Mr
Brownlow
,
smiling
.
   
<EOS>
The
spirit
of
contradiction
was
strong
in
Mr
Grimwig
's
breast
,
at
the
moment
;
and
it
was
rendered
stronger
by
his
friend
's
confident
smile
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
he
said
,
smiting
the
table
with
his
fist
,
"
I
do
not
.
<EOS>
The
boy
has
a
new
suit
of
clothes
on
his
back
,
a
set
of
valuable
books
under
his
arm
,
and
a
five
-
pound
note
in
his
pocket
.
 
<EOS>
He
'll
join
his
old
friends
the
thieves
,
and
laugh
at
you
.
 
<EOS>
If
ever
that
boy
returns
to
this
house
,
sir
,
I
'll
eat
my
head
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
these
words
he
drew
his
chair
closer
to
the
table
;
and
there
the
two
friends
sat
,
in
silent
expectation
,
with
the
watch
between
them
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
worthy
of
remark
,
as
illustrating
the
importance
we
attach
to
our
own
judgments
,
and
<EOS>
the
pride
with
which
we
put
forth
our
most
rash
and
hasty
conclusions
,
that
,
although
Mr
Grimwig
was
not
by
any
means
a
bad
-
hearted
man
,
and
though
he
would
have
been
unfeignedly
sorry
to
see
his
respected
friend
duped
and
deceived
,
he
really
did
most
earnestly
and
strongly
hope
at
that
moment
,
that
Oliver
Twist
might
not
come
back
.
   
<EOS>
It
grew
so
dark
,
that
the
figures
on
the
dial
-
plate
were
scarcely
discernible
;
but
there
the
two
old
gentlemen
continued
to
sit
,
in
silence
,
with
the
watch
between
them
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
15
.
<EOS>
Showing
how
very
fond
of
Oliver
Twist
,
the
merry
old
Jew
and
Miss
Nancy
were
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
obscure
parlour
of
a
low
public
-
house
,
in
the
filthiest
part
of
Little
Saffron
Hill
;
a
dark
and
gloomy
den
,
where
a
flaring
gas
-
light
burnt
all
day
in
the
winter
-
time
;
and
where
no
ray
of
sun
ever
shone
in
the
summer
:
 
there
sat
,
brooding
over
a
little
pewter
measure
and
a
small
glass
,
strongly
impregnated
with
the
smell
of
liquor
,
a
man
in
a
velveteen
coat
,
drab
shorts
,
half
-
boots
and
stockings
,
whom
even
by
that
dim
light
no
experienced
agent
of
the
police
would
have
hesitated
to
recognise
as
Mr
William
Sikes
.
 
<EOS>
At
his
feet
,
sat
a
white
-
coated
,
red
-
eyed
dog
;
who
occupied
himself
,
alternately
,
in
winking
at
his
master
with
both
eyes
at
the
same
time
;
and
in
licking
a
large
,
fresh
cut
on
one
side
of
his
mouth
,
which
appeared
to
be
the
result
of
some
recent
conflict
.
   
<EOS>
"
Keep
quiet
,
you
warmint
!
 
<EOS>
Keep
quiet
!
"
said
Mr
Sikes
,
suddenly
breaking
silence
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
his
meditations
were
so
intense
as
to
be
disturbed
by
the
dog
's
winking
,
or
whether
his
feelings
were
so
wrought
upon
by
his
reflections
that
they
required
all
the
relief
derivable
from
kicking
an
unoffending
animal
to
allay
them
,
is
matter
for
argument
and
consideration
.
 
<EOS>
Whatever
was
the
cause
,
the
effect
was
a
kick
and
a
curse
,
bestowed
upon
the
dog
simultaneously
.
   
<EOS>
Dogs
are
not
generally
apt
to
revenge
injuries
inflicted
upon
them
by
their
masters
;
but
Mr
Sikes
's
dog
,
having
faults
of
temper
in
common
with
his
owner
,
and
labouring
,
perhaps
,
at
this
moment
,
under
a
powerful
sense
of
injury
,
made
no
more
ado
but
at
once
fixed
his
teeth
in
one
of
the
half
-
boots
.
 
<EOS>
Having
given
in
a
hearty
shake
,
he
retired
,
growling
,
under
a
form
;
just
escaping
the
pewter
measure
which
Mr
Sikes
levelled
at
his
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
would
,
would
you
?
"
said
Sikes
,
seizing
the
poker
in
one
hand
,
and
deliberately
opening
with
the
other
a
large
clasp
-
knife
,
which
he
drew
from
his
pocket
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
here
,
you
born
devil
!
 
<EOS>
Come
here
!
 
<EOS>
D'ye
hear
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
dog
no
doubt
heard
;
because
Mr
Sikes
spoke
in
the
very
harshest
key
of
a
very
harsh
voice
;
but
,
appearing
to
entertain
some
unaccountable
objection
to
having
his
throat
cut
,
he
remained
where
he
was
,
and
growled
more
fiercely
than
before
:
 
at
the
same
time
grasping
the
end
of
the
poker
between
his
teeth
,
and
biting
at
it
like
a
wild
beast
.
   
<EOS>
This
resistance
only
infuriated
Mr
Sikes
the
more
;
who
,
dropping
on
his
knees
,
began
to
assail
the
animal
most
furiously
.
 
<EOS>
The
dog
jumped
from
right
to
left
,
and
from
left
to
right
;
snapping
,
growling
,
and
barking
;
the
man
thrust
and
swore
,
and
struck
and
blasphemed
;
and
the
struggle
was
reaching
a
most
critical
point
for
one
or
other
;
when
,
the
door
suddenly
opening
,
the
dog
darted
out
:
 
leaving
Bill
Sikes
with
the
poker
and
the
clasp
-
knife
in
his
hands
.
   
<EOS>
There
must
always
be
two
parties
to
a
quarrel
,
says
the
old
adage
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Sikes
,
being
disappointed
of
the
dog
's
participation
,
at
once
transferred
his
share
in
the
quarrel
to
the
new
comer
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
the
devil
do
you
come
in
between
me
and
my
dog
for
?
<EOS>
"
said
Sikes
,
with
a
fierce
gesture
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
know
,
my
dear
,
I
did
n't
know
,
"
replied
Fagin
,
humbly
;
for
the
Jew
was
the
new
comer
.
   
<EOS>
"
Did
n't
know
,
you
white
-
livered
thief
!
"
<EOS>
growled
Sikes
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Could
n't
you
hear
the
noise
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a
sound
of
it
,
as
I
'm
a
living
man
,
Bill
,
"
replied
the
Jew
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
no
!
 
<EOS>
You
hear
nothing
,
you
do
n't
,
"
retorted
Sikes
with
a
fierce
sneer
.
 
<EOS>
"
Sneaking
in
and
out
,
so
as
nobody
hears
how
you
come
or
go
!
 
<EOS>
I
wish
you
had
been
the
dog
,
Fagin
,
half
a
minute
ago
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
?
"
inquired
the
Jew
with
a
forced
smile
.
   
<EOS>
"
'Cause
the
government
,
as
cares
for
the
lives
of
such
men
as
you
,
as
have
n't
half
the
pluck
of
curs
,
lets
a
man
kill
a
dog
how
he
likes
,
"
replied
Sikes
,
shutting
up
the
knife
with
a
very
expressive
look
;
"
that
's
why
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
Jew
rubbed
his
hands
;
and
,
sitting
down
at
the
table
,
affected
to
laugh
at
the
pleasantry
of
his
friend
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
obviously
very
ill
at
ease
,
however
.
   
<EOS>
"
Grin
away
,
"
said
Sikes
,
replacing
the
poker
,
and
surveying
him
with
savage
contempt
;
"
grin
away
.
 
<EOS>
You
'll
never
have
the
laugh
at
me
,
though
,
unless
it
's
behind
a
nightcap
.
 
<EOS>
I
've
got
the
upper
hand
over
you
,
Fagin
;
and
<EOS>
,
d
---
 
me
,
<EOS>
I
'll
keep
it
.
 
<EOS>
There
!
 
<EOS>
If
I
go
,
you
go
;
so
take
care
of
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
my
dear
,
"
said
the
Jew
,
"
I
know
all
that
;
we
---
we
---
have
a
mutual
interest
,
Bill
,
---
a
mutual
interest
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Humph
,
"
said
Sikes
,
as
if
he
though
the
interest
lay
rather
more
on
the
Jew
's
side
than
on
his
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
what
have
you
got
to
say
to
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
passed
safe
through
the
melting
-
pot
,
"
replied
Fagin
,
"
and
this
is
your
share
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
rather
more
than
it
ought
to
be
,
<EOS>
my
dear
;
<EOS>
but
as
I
know
you
'll
do
me
a
good
turn
another
time
,
and
---
"
   
"
Stow
that
gammon
,
"
interposed
the
robber
,
impatiently
.
<EOS>
"
Where
is
it
?
 
<EOS>
Hand
over
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
yes
,
Bill
;
give
me
time
,
give
me
time
,
"
replied
the
Jew
,
soothingly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
it
is
!
 
<EOS>
All
safe
!
"
 
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
,
he
drew
forth
an
old
cotton
handkerchief
from
his
breast
;
and
untying
a
large
knot
in
one
corner
,
produced
a
small
brown
-
paper
packet
.
 
<EOS>
Sikes
,
snatching
it
from
him
,
hastily
opened
it
;
and
proceeded
to
count
the
sovereigns
it
contained
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
all
,
is
it
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Sikes
.
   
<EOS>
"
All
,
"
replied
the
Jew
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
n't
opened
the
parcel
and
swallowed
one
or
two
as
you
come
along
,
have
you
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Sikes
,
suspiciously
.
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
put
on
an
injured
look
at
the
question
;
you
've
done
it
many
a
time
.
<EOS>
Jerk
the
tinkler
.
"
   
<EOS>
These
words
,
in
plain
English
,
conveyed
an
injunction
to
ring
the
bell
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
answered
by
another
Jew
:
 
younger
than
Fagin
,
but
nearly
as
vile
and
repulsive
in
appearance
.
   
<EOS>
Bill
Sikes
merely
pointed
to
the
empty
measure
.
 
<EOS>
The
Jew
,
perfectly
understanding
the
hint
,
retired
to
fill
it
:
 
previously
exchanging
a
remarkable
look
with
Fagin
,
who
raised
his
eyes
for
an
instant
,
as
if
in
expectation
of
it
,
and
shook
his
head
in
reply
;
so
slightly
that
the
action
would
have
been
almost
imperceptible
to
an
observant
third
person
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
lost
upon
Sikes
,
who
was
stooping
at
the
moment
to
tie
the
boot
-
lace
which
the
dog
had
torn
.
 
<EOS>
Possibly
,
if
he
had
observed
the
brief
interchange
of
signals
,
he
might
have
thought
that
it
boded
no
good
to
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
anybody
here
,
Barney
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Fagin
;
speaking
,
now
that
that
Sikes
was
looking
on
,
without
raising
his
eyes
from
the
ground
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dot
a
shoul
,
"
replied
Barney
;
whose
words
:
 
whether
they
came
from
the
heart
or
not
:
 
made
their
way
through
the
nose
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nobody
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Fagin
,
in
a
tone
of
surprise
:
 
which
perhaps
might
mean
that
Barney
was
at
liberty
to
tell
the
truth
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dobody
but
Biss
Dadsy
,
"
replied
Barney
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nancy
!
"
exclaimed
Sikes
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
?
 
<EOS>
Strike
me
blind
,
if
I
do
n't
honour
that
'
ere
girl
,
for
her
native
talents
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
's
bid
havid
a
plate
of
boiled
beef
<EOS>
i
d
the
bar
,
"
replied
Barney
.
   
<EOS>
"
Send
her
here
,
"
said
Sikes
,
pouring
out
a
glass
of
liquor
.
<EOS>
"
Send
her
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
Barney
looked
timidly
at
Fagin
,
as
if
for
permission
;
the
Jew
reamining
silent
,
and
not
lifting
his

from
the
ground
,
he
retired
;
and
presently
returned
,
ushering
in
Nancy
;
who
was
decorated
with
the
bonnet
,
apron
,
basket
,
and
street
-
door
key
,
complete
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
on
the
scent
,
are
you
,
Nancy
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Sikes
,
proffering
the
glass
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
am
,
Bill
,
"
replied
the
young
lady
,
disposing
of
its
contents
;
"
and
tired
enough
of
it
I
am
,
too
.
 
<EOS>
The
young
brat
's
been
ill
and
confined
to
the
crib
;
and
---
"
   
"
Ah
,
Nancy
,
dear
!
"
said
Fagin
,
looking
up
.
   
<EOS>
Now
,
whether
a
peculiar
contraction
of
the
Jew
's
red
eye
-
brows
,
and
a
half
closing
of
his
deeply
-

,
warned
Miss
Nancy
that
she
was
disposed
to
be
too
communicative
,
is
not
a
matter
of
much
importance
.
 
<EOS>
The
fact
is
all
we
need
care
for
here
;
and
the
fact
is
,
that
she
suddenly
checked
herself
,
and
with
several
gracious
smiles
upon
Mr
Sikes
,
turned
the
conversation
to
other
matters
.
<EOS>
In
about
ten
minutes
'
time
,
Mr
Fagin
was
seized
with
a
fit
of
coughing
;
upon
which
Nancy
pulled
her
shawl
over
her
shoulders
,
and
declared
it
was
time
to
go
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Sikes
,
finding
that
he
was
walking
a
short
part
of
her
way
himself
,
expressed
his
intention
of
accompanying
her
;
they
went
away
together
,
followed
,
at
a
little
distant
,
by
the
dog
,
who
slunk
out
of
a
back
-
yard
as
soon
as
his
master
was
out
of
sight
.
   
<EOS>
The
Jew
thrust
his
head
out
of
the
room
door
when
Sikes
had
left
it
;
looked
after
him
as
we
walked
up
the
dark
passage
;
shook
his
clenched
fist
;
muttered
a
deep

;
and
then
,
with
a

,
reseated
himself
at
the
table
;
where
he
was
soon
deeply
absorbed
in
the
interesting
pages
of
the
Hue
-
and
-
Cry
.
   
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
Oliver
Twist
,
little
dreaming
that
he
was
within
so
very
short
a
distance
of
the
merry
old
gentleman
,
was
on
his
way
to
the
book
-
stall
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
got
into
Clerkenwell
,
he
accidentally
turned
down
a
by
-
street
which
was
not
exactly
in
his
way
;
but
not
discovering
his
mistake
until
he
had
got
half
-
way
down
it
,
and
knowing
it
must
lead
in
the
right
direction
,
he
did
not
think
it
worth
while
to
turn
back
;
and
so
marched
on
,
as
quickly
as
he
could
,
with
the
books
under
his
arm
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
walking
along
,
thinking
how
happy
and
contented
he
ought
to
feel
;
and
how
much
he
would
give
for
only
one
look
at
poor
little
Dick
,
who
,
starved
and
beaten
,
might
be
weeping
bitterly
at
that
very
moment
;
when
he
was
startled
by
a
young
woman
screaming
out
very
loud
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
my
dear
brother
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
he
had
hardly
looked
up
,
to
see
what
the
matter
was
,
when
he
was
stopped
by
having
a
pair
of
arms
thrown
tight
round
his
neck
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
,
"
cried
Oliver
,
struggling
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
go
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
Who
is
it
?
<EOS>
What
are
you
stopping
me
for
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
only
reply
to
this
,
was
a
great
number
of
loud
lamentations
from
the
young
woman
who
had
embraced
him
;
and
who
had
a
little
basket
and
a
street
-
door
key
in
her
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
my
gracious
!
"
said
the
young
woman
,
"
I
have
found
him
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
Oliver
!
 
<EOS>
Oliver
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
<EOS>
you
naughty
boy
,
to
make
me
suffer
such
distress
on
your
account
!
 
<EOS>
Come
home
,
dear
,
come
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
I
've
found
him
.
 
<EOS>
Thank
gracious
goodness
heavins
<EOS>
,
I
've
found
him
!
"
 
<EOS>
With
these
incoherent

,
the
young
woman
burst
into
another

of

,
and
got
so

,
that
a

women
who
came

asked
a
butcher
's
boy
with

of

with

,
who
was
also
looking
on
,
whether
he
did
n't

had

for

.
 
<EOS>
To

,
the
butcher
's
boy
:
 
who
appeared
of
a

,
not
to
say
indolent

:
 
<EOS>
replied
,
that
he
thought
not
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
no
,
no
,
never

,
"
said
the
young
woman
,
grasping
Oliver
's

;
"
I
'm
better
now
.
 
<EOS>
Come
home
directly
,
you
cruel
boy
!
<EOS>
Come
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

,
"
replied

,
"
he
ran
away
,
near
a

,
from

,

are

;
and
went

;
and
almost

his
mother
's

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Young
wretch
!
"
said
one

.
   
<EOS>
"
Go
home
,
do
,
you
little

,
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

Oliver
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
her
.
<EOS>
I
have
n't
any

,

mother

.
 
<EOS>
I
'm

;
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Only
hear

,
how
he
braves

!
"
cried

young
woman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
it
's
Nancy
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Oliver
;
who
now
saw
her
face
for
the
first

;
and
started
back
,
in
irrepressible

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
see
he
knows
me
!
"
cried
Nancy
,
appealing
to
the
bystanders
.
<EOS>
"
He
ca
n't
help
himself
.
 
<EOS>
Make
him
come
home
,
there
's
good
people
,
or
he
'll
kill
his
dear
mother
and
father
,
and
break
my
heart
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
the
devil
's
this
?
"
said
a
man
,
bursting
out

-

,
with
a
white

at

;
"
young
Oliver
!
<EOS>
Come
home
to
your
poor
mother
,
you
young
dog
!
 
<EOS>
Come
home
directly
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
belong
to
them
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
them
.
 
<EOS>
Help
!
<EOS>
help
!
<EOS>
cried
Oliver
,
struggling
in
the
man
's
powerful
grasp
.
   
<EOS>
"
Help
!
"
repeated
the
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
I
'll
help
you
,
you
young
rascal
!
   
<EOS>
What
books
are
these
?
 
<EOS>
You
've
been
a
stealing
'em
,
have
you
?
<EOS>
Give
'em
here
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
these
words
,
the
man
tore
the
volumes
from
his
grasp
,
and
struck
him
on
the
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
right
!
"
<EOS>
cried
a

-

,

-

.
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
only

of
bringing
him
to

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
!
<EOS>
"
cried
a
sleepy
-

carpenter
,
casting
an
approving
look
at
the
garret
-
window
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
'll
do
him
good
!
"
said
the
two
women
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
he
shall
have
it
,
too
!
"
<EOS>
rejoined
the
man
,
administering
another
blow
,
and
seizing
Oliver
by
the
collar
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
on
,
you
young
villain
!
 
<EOS>
Here
,
Bull's
-
eye
,
mind
him
,
boy
!
 
<EOS>
Mind
him
!
"
   
<EOS>
Weak
with
recent
illness
;
stupified
by
the
blows
and
the
suddenness
of
the
attack
;
terrified
by
the
fierce
growling
of
the
dog
,
and
the
brutality
of
the
man
;
overpowered
by
the
conviction
of
the
bystanders
that
he
really
was
the
hardened
little
wretch
he
was
described
to
be
;
what
could
one
poor
child
do
!
 
<EOS>
Darkness
had
set
in
;
it
was
a
low
neighborhood
;
no
help
was
near
;
resistance
was
useless
.
 
<EOS>
In
another
moment
he
was
dragged
into
a
labyrinth
of
dark
narrow
courts
,
and
was
forced
along
them
at
a
pace
which
rendered
the
few
cries
he
dared
to
give
utterance
to
,
unintelligible
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
of
little
moment
,
indeed
,
whether
they
were
intelligible
or
no
;
for
there
was
nobody
to
care
for
them
,
<EOS>
had
they
been
ever
so
plain
.
   
<EOS>
The
gas
-
lamps
were
lighted
;
Mrs
Bedwin
was
waiting
anxiously
at
the
open
door
;
the
servant
had
run
up
the
street
twenty
times
to
see
if
there
were
any
traces
of
Oliver
;
and
still
the
two
old
gentlemen
sat
,
perseveringly
,
in
the
dark
parlour
,
with
the
watch
between
them
.
    
Chapter
16
.
<EOS>
Relates
what
became
of
Oliver
Twist
,
after
he
had
been
claimed
by
Nancy
.
 
<EOS>
The
narrow
streets
and
courts
,
at
length
,
terminated
in
a
large
open
space
;
scattered
about
which
,
were
pens
for
beasts
,
and
other
indications
of
a
cattle
-
market
.
 
<EOS>
Sikes
slackened
his
pace
when
they
reached
this
spot
:
 
the
girl
being
quite
unable
to
support
any
longer
,
the
rapid
rate
at
which
they
had
hitherto
walked
.
 
<EOS>
Turning
to
Oliver
,
he
roughly
commanded
him
to
take
hold
of
Nancy
's
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
hear
?
<EOS>
"
growled
Sikes
,
as
Oliver
hesitated
,
and
looked
round
.
   
<EOS>
They
were
in
a
dark
corner
,
quite
out
of
the
track
of
passengers
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
saw
,
but
too
plainly
,
that
resistance
would
be
of
no
avail
.
 
<EOS>
He
held
out
his
hand
,
which
Nancy
clasped
tight
in
hers
.
   
<EOS>
"
Give
me
the
other
,
"
said
Sikes
,
seizing
Oliver
's
unoccupied
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
,
Bull's
-
Eye
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
dog
looked
up
,
and
growled
.
   
<EOS>
"
See
here
,
boy
!
"
<EOS>
said
Sikes
,
putting
his
other
hand
to
Oliver
's
throat
;
"
if
he
speaks
ever
so
soft
a
word
,
hold
him
!
 
<EOS>
D'ye
mind
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
dog
growled
again
;
and
licking
his
lips
,
eyed
Oliver
as
if
he
were
anxious
to
attach
himself
to
his
windpipe
without
delay
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
as
willing
as
a
Christian
,
strike
me
blind
if
he
is
n't
!
"
<EOS>
said
Sikes
,
regarding
the
animal
with
a
kind
of
grim
and
ferocious
approval
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,
you
know
what
you
've
got
to
expect
,
master
,
so
call
away
as
quick
as
you
like
;
the
dog
will
soon
stop
that
game
.
 
<EOS>
Get
on
,
young'un
!
"
   
<EOS>
Bull's
-
eye
wagged
his
tail
in
acknowledgment
of
this
unusually
endearing
form
of
speech
;
and
,
giving
vent
to
another
admonitory
growl
for
the
benefit
of
Oliver
,
led
the
way
onward
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
Smithfield
that
they
were
crossing
,
although
it
might
have
been
Grosvenor
Square
,
for
anything
Oliver
knew
to
the
contrary
.
<EOS>
The
night
was
dark
and
foggy
.
 
<EOS>
The
lights
in
the
shops
could
scarcely
struggle
through
the
heavy
mist
,
which
thickened
every
moment
and
shrouded
the
streets
and
houses
in
gloom
;
rendering
the
strange
place
still
stranger
in
Oliver
's
eyes
;
and
making
his
uncertainty
the
more
dismal
and
depressing
.
   
<EOS>
They
had
hurried
on
a
few
paces
,
when
a
deep
church
-
bell
struck
the
hour
.
 
<EOS>
With
its
first
stroke
,
his
two
conductors
stopped
,
and
turned
their
heads
in
the
direction
<EOS>
whence
the
sound
proceeded
.
   
<EOS>
"
Eight
o'clock
,
Bill
,
"
said
Nancy
,
when
the
bell
ceased
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
good
of
telling
me
that
;
I
can
hear
it
,
ca
n't
I
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Sikes
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
whether
THEY
can
hear
it
,
"
said
Nancy
.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
they
can
,
"
replied
Sikes
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
Bartlemy
time
when
I
was
shopped
;
and
there
warn't
<EOS>
a
penny
trumpet
in
the
fair
,
as
I
could
n't
hear
the
squeaking
on
.
 
<EOS>
Arter
I
was
locked
up
for
the
night
,
the
row
and
din
outside
made
the
thundering
old
jail
so
silent
,
that
I
could
almost
have
beat
my
brains
out
against
the
iron
plates
of
the
door
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Poor
fellow
!
<EOS>
"
said
Nancy
,
who
still
had
her
face
turned
towards
the
quarter
in
which
the
bell
had
sounded
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Bill
,
such
fine
young
chaps
as
them
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
that
's
all
you
women
think
of
,
"
answered
Sikes
.
 
<EOS>
"
Fine
young
chaps
!
 
<EOS>
Well
,
they
're
as
good
as
dead
,
so
it
do
n't
much
matter
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
this
consolation
,
Mr
Sikes
appeared
to
repress
a
rising
tendency
to
jealousy
,
and
,
clasping
Oliver
's
wrist
more
firmly
,
told
him
to
step
out
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
Wait
a
minute
!
"
<EOS>
said
the
girl
:
 
<EOS>
"
I
would
n't
hurry
by
,
if
it
was
you
that
was
coming
out
to
be
hung
,
the
next
time
eight
o'clock
struck
,
Bill
.
 
<EOS>
I
'd
walk
round
and
round
the
place
till
I
dropped
,
if
the
snow
was
on
the
ground
,
and
I
had
n't
a
shawl
to
cover
me
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
what
good
would
that
do
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
the
unsentimental
Mr
Sikes
.
 
<EOS>
"
Unless
you
could
pitch
over
a
file
and
twenty
yards
of
good
stout
rope
,
you
might
as
well
be
walking
fifty
mile
off
,
or
not
walking
at
all
,
for
all
the
good
it
would
do
me
.
 
<EOS>
Come
on
,
and
do
n't
stand
preaching
there
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
girl
burst
into
a
laugh
;
drew
her
shawl
more
closely
round
her
;
and
they
walked
away
.
 
<EOS>
But
Oliver
felt
her
hand
tremble
,
and
,
looking
up
in
her
face
as
they
passed
a
gas
-
lamp
,
saw
that
it
had
turned
a
deadly
white
.
   
<EOS>
They
walked
on
,
by
little
-
frequented
and
dirty
ways
,
for
a
full
half
-
hour
:
 
<EOS>
meeting
very
few
people
,
and
those
appearing
from
their
looks
to
hold
much
the
same
position
in
society
as
Mr
Sikes
himself
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
they
turned
into
a
very
filthy
narrow
street
,
nearly
full
of
old
-
clothes
shops
;
the
dog
running
forward
,
as
if
conscious
that
there
was
no
further
occasion
for
his
keeping
on
guard
,
stopped
before
the
door
of
a
shop
that
was
closed
and
apparently
untenanted
;
the
house
was
in
a
ruinous
condition
,
and
on
the
door
was
nailed
a
board
,
intimating
that
it
was
to
let
:
 
which
looked
as
if
it
had
hung
there
for
many
years
.
   
<EOS>
"
All
right
,
"
cried
Sikes
,
glancing
cautiously
about
.
   
<EOS>
Nancy
stooped
below
the
shutters
,
and
Oliver
heard
the
sound
of
a
bell
.
 
<EOS>
They
crossed
to
the
opposite
side
of
the
street
,
and
stood
for
a
few
moments
under
a
lamp
.
 
<EOS>
A
noise
,
as
if
a
sash
window
were
gently
raised
,
was
heard
;
and
soon
afterwards
the
door
softly
opened
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Sikes
then
seized
the
terrified
boy
by
the
collar
with
very
little
ceremony
;
and
all
three
were
quickly
inside
the
house
.
   
<EOS>
The
passage
was
perfectly
dark
.
 
<EOS>
They
waited
,
while
the
person
who
had
let
them
in
,
chained
and
barred
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
Anybody
here
?
"
inquired
Sikes
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
a
voice
,
which
Oliver
thought
he
had
heard
before
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
the
old
'
un
here
?
"
asked
the
robber
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
replied
the
voice
,
"
and
precious
down
in
the
mouth
he
has
been
.
 
<EOS>
Wo
n't
he
be
glad
to
see
you
?
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
no
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
style
of
this
reply
,
as
well
as
the
voice
which
delivered
it
,
seemed
familiar
to
Oliver
's
ears
:
 
but
it
was
impossible
to
distinguish
even
the
form
of
the
speaker
in
the
darkness
.
   
<EOS>
"
Let
's
have
a
glim
,
"
said
Sikes
,
"
or
we
shall
go
breaking
our
necks
,
or
treading
on
the
dog
.
 
<EOS>
Look
after
your
legs
if
you
do
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Stand
still
a
moment
,
and
I
'll
get
you
one
,
"
replied
the
voice
.
<EOS>
The
receding
footsteps
of
the
speaker
were
heard
;
and
,
in
another
minute
,
the
form
of
Mr
John
Dawkins
,
otherwise
the
Artful
Dodger
,
appeared
.
 
<EOS>
He
bore
in
his
right
hand
a
tallow
candle
stuck
in
the
end
of
a
cleft
stick
.
   
<EOS>
The
young
gentleman
did
not
stop
to
bestow
any
other
mark
of
recognition
upon
Oliver
than
a
humourous
grin
;
but
,
turning
away
,
beckoned
the
visitors
to
follow
him
down
a
flight
of
stairs
.
<EOS>
They
crossed
an
empty
kitchen
;
and
,
opening
the
door
of
a
low
earthy
-
smelling
room
,
which
seemed
to
have
been
built
in
a
small
back
-
yard
,
were
received
with
a
shout
of
laughter
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
my
wig
,
my
wig
!
<EOS>
"
cried
Master
Charles
Bates
,
from
whose
lungs
the
laughter
had
proceeded
:
 
"
here
he
is
!
<EOS>
oh
,
cry
,
here
he
is
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
Fagin
,
look
at
him
!
 
<EOS>
Fagin
,
do
look
at
him
!
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
bear
it
;
it
is
such
a
jolly
game
,
I
ca
nt
"
bear
it
.
 
<EOS>
Hold
me
,
somebody
,
while
I
laugh
it
out
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
this
irrepressible
ebullition
of
mirth
,
Master
Bates
laid
himself
flat
on
the
floor
:
and
kicked
convulsively
for
five
minutes
,
in
an
ectasy
of
facetious
joy
.
 
<EOS>
Then
jumping
to
his
feet
,
he
snatched
the
cleft
stick
from
the
Dodger
;
and
,
advancing
to
Oliver
,
viewed
him
round
and
round
;
while
the
Jew
,
taking
off
his
nightcap
,
made
a
great
number
of
low
bows
to
the
bewildered
boy
.
 
<EOS>
The
Artful
,
meantime
,
who
was
of
a
rather
saturnine
disposition
,
and
seldom
gave
way
to
merriment
when
it
interfered
with
business
,
rifled
Oliver
's
pockets
with
steady
assiduity
.
   
<EOS>
"
Look
at
his
togs
,
Fagin
!
"
said
Charley
,
putting
the
light
so
close
to
his
new
jacket
as
nearly
to
set
him
on
fire
.
 
<EOS>
"
Look
at
his
togs
!
 
<EOS>
Superfine
cloth
,
and
the
heavy
swell
cut
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
my
eye
,
what
a
game
!
 
<EOS>
And
his
books
,
too
!
 
<EOS>
Nothing
but
a
gentleman
,
Fagin
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Delighted
to
see
you
looking
so
well
,
my
dear
,
"
said
the
Jew
,
bowing
with
mock
humility
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
Artful
shall
give
you
another
suit
,
my
dear
,
<EOS>
for
fear
you
should
spoil
that
Sunday
one
.
 
<EOS>
Why
did
n't
you
write
,
my
dear
,
and
say
you
were
coming
?
 
<EOS>
We
'd
have
got
something
warm
for
supper
.
"
   
<EOS>
At
his
,
Master
Bates
roared
again
:
so
loud
,
that
Fagin
himself
relaxed
,
and
even
the
Dodger
smiled
;
but
as
the
Artful
drew
forth
the
five
-
pound
note
at
that
instant
,
it
is
doubtful
whether
the
sally
of
the
discovery
awakened
his
merriment
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hallo
,
what
's
that
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Sikes
,
stepping
forward
as
the
Jew
seized
the
note
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
mine
,
Fagin
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
my
dear
,
"
said
the
Jew
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mine
,
Bill
,
mine
.
 
<EOS>
You
shall
have
the
books
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
that
ai
n't
mine
!
"
said
Bill
Sikes
,
putting
on
his
hat
with
a
determined
air
;
"
mine
and
Nancy
's
that
is
<EOS>
;
I
'll
take
the
boy
back
again
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
Jew
started
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
started
too
,
though
from
a
very
different
cause
;
for
he
hoped
that
the
dispute
might
really
end
in
his
being
taken
back
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
!
 
<EOS>
Hand
over
,
will
you
?
"
said
Sikes
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
hardly
fair
,
Bill
;
hardly
fair
,
is
it
,
Nancy
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
the
Jew
.
   
<EOS>
"
Fair
,
or
not
fair
,
"
retorted
Sikes
,
"
hand
over
,
I
tell
you
!
<EOS>
Do
you
think
Nancy
and
me
has
got
nothing
else
to
do
with
our
precious
time
but
to
spend
it
in
scouting
arter
,
and
kidnapping
,
every
young
boy
as
gets
grabbed
through
you
?
 
<EOS>
Give
it
here
,
you
avaricious
old
skeleton
,
give
it
here
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
this
gentle
remonstrance
,
Mr
Sikes
plucked
the
note
from
between
the
Jew
's
finger
and
thumb
;
and
looking
the
old
man
coolly
in
the
face
,
folded
it
up
small
,
and
tied
it
in
his
neckerchief
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
for
our
share
of
the
trouble
,
"
said
Sikes
;
"
and
not
half
enough
,
neither
.
 
<EOS>
You
may
keep
the
books
,
if
you
're
fond
of
reading
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
ai
n't
,
sell
'
em
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
They
're
very
pretty
,
"
said
Charley
Bates
:
who
,
with
sundry
grimaces
,
had
been
affecting
to
read
one
of
the
volumes
in
question
;
"
beautiful
writing
,
is
n't
is
,
Oliver
?
"
 
<EOS>
At
sight
of
the
dismayed
look
with
which
Oliver
regarded
his
tormentors
,
Master
Bates
,
who
was
blessed
with
a
lively
sense
of
the
ludicrous
,
fell
into
another
ectasy
,
more
boisterous
than
the
first
.
   
<EOS>
"
They
belong
to
the
old
gentleman
,
"
said
Oliver
,
wringing
his
hands
;
"
to
the
good
,
kind
,
old
gentleman
who
took
me
into
his
house
,
and
had
me
nursed
,
when
I
was
near
dying
of
the
fever
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
pray
send
them
back
;
send
him
back
the
books
and
money
.
 
<EOS>
Keep
me
here
all
my
life
long
;
but
pray
,
pray
send
them
back
.
 
<EOS>
He
'll
think
I
stole
them
;
the
old
lady
:
 
all
of
them
who
were
so
kind
to
me
:
will
think
I
stole
them
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
do
have
mercy
upon
me
,
and
send
them
back
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
these
words
,
which
were
uttered
with
all
the
energy
of
passionate
grief
,
Oliver
fell
upon
his
knees
at
the
Jew
's
feet
;
and
beat
his
hands
together
,
in
perfect
desperation
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
boy
's
right
,
"
remarked
Fagin
,
looking
covertly
round
,
and
knitting
his
shaggy
eyebrows
into
a
hard
knot
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
're
right
<EOS>
,
Oliver
,
you
're
right
;
they
WILL
think
you
have
stolen
'em
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
"
chuckled
the
Jew
,
rubbing
his
hands
,
"
it
could
n't
have
happened
better
,
if
we
had
chosen
our
time
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
it
could
n't
,
"
replied
Sikes
;
"
I
know'd
<EOS>
that
,
directly
I
see
him
coming
through
Clerkenwell
,
with
the
books
under
his
arm
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
all
right
enough
.
 
<EOS>
They
're
soft
-
hearted
psalm
-
singers
,
or
they
would
n't
have
taken
him
in
at
all
;
and
they
'll
ask
no
questions
after
him
,
fear
they
should
be
obliged
to
prosecute
,
and
so
get
him
lagged
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
safe
enough
.
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver
had
looked
from
one
to
the
other
,
while
these
words
were
being
spoken
,
as
if
he
were
bewildered
,
and
could
scarcely
understand
what
passed
;
but
when
Bill
Sikes
concluded
,
he
jumped
suddenly
to
his
feet
,
and
tore
wildly
from
the
room
:
 
uttering
shrieks
for
help
,
which
made
the
bare
old
house
echo
to
the
roof
.
   
<EOS>
"
Keep
back
the
dog
,
Bill
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Nancy
,
springing
before
the
door
,
and
closing
it
,
as
the
Jew
and
his
two
pupils
darted
out
in
pursuit
.
 
<EOS>
"
Keep
back
the
dog
;
he
'll
tear
the
boy
to
pieces
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Serve
him
right
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Sikes
,
struggling
to
disengage
himself
from
the
girl
's
grasp
.
 
<EOS>
"
Stand
off
from
me
,
or
I
'll
split
your
head
against
the
wall
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do

care
for
that
,
Bill
,
I
do

,
"

,

with

man
,
"
the
child
sha
n't
be
torn
down
by
the
dog
,

you
kill

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sha
n't
he
!
"
said
Sikes
,
setting
his

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
soon
do

,
if
you
do
n't

.
"
   
<EOS>
The
housebreaker
flung
the
girl
from
him
to

room
,
just

Jew

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
's

!
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
The
girl
's

,

,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,

has

,
"

,

;
"
no
,
she
has
n't
,

;
do

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then

?
"
said

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
I
wo
n't
do

,
neither
,
"

Nancy
,
speaking

.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
!
 
<EOS>
What

think

?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Fagin
was
sufficiently
well

of
that

to

,
to

,

.
 
<EOS>
With

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
So

,

,

?
"

,

which
law
in

;
"
eh
?
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver
made

.
 
<EOS>
But

's

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Wanted
to

;
called

;
did

?
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
The

;
and
was

,
when

girl
,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
wo

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

,

.
"
   
<EOS>

;

other

:
<EOS>
her

from

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

!
"

,

;

;
"
you
,
---
you
're
more

than

to
-
night
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
my
dear
,
you
are
acting
beautifully
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Am
I
!
"
said

girl
.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
care
<EOS>
I
do
n't

.
 
<EOS>
You

,
Fagin
,
if

;
and
so
I
tell

.
"
   
<EOS>
There

something
about

:
especially

add
to
all
her
other

,
the
fierce

of

;
which

.
<EOS>
The
Jew
saw
that

would

to
affect
any

mistake
regarding
the
reality
of
Miss
Nancy
's

;
and
,

back

,

,

:
as

to
hint
that

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Sikes
,
thus
mutely

to
;
and
possibly
feeling

personal
pride
and

interested
in

of

to

;
gave

about

,
the

reflected

.
<EOS>
As

no

on

.
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
by
this
?
"

;
backing

with

concerning
the
most

of

:
which
,

above
,
only

that

,
would

:
"
what

?
 
<EOS>
Burn

!
 
<EOS>
Do

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

!
 
<EOS>

,

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"

"

"

,

them

<EOS>
"
   
"

,

<EOS>
"
Civil

!
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

"

"

;

;

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

's

"

.
<EOS>
"
She
's

,

's

.
"
   
<EOS>
The

:

to

;
but

,

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's

,
"

,

;
"

,

we
ca
n't

,
in

,

'em
.
 
<EOS>
Charley
,
show
Oliver
to
bed
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

'd
better
not

tomorrow
,
Fagin
,
had

?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Charley
Bates
.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly

,
"
replied
the
Jew
,
reciprocating

with

put

.
   
<EOS>
Master
Bates
,
apparently
much

with
his

,
took
the
cleft
stick
:
and
led
Oliver
into
an
adjacent

,
where

two
or
three
of

on
which
he
had

before
;
and
here
,
with

,
he
produced
the
identical
old

of

which
Oliver
had
so
much

upon
leaving
off
at
Mr
Brownlow
's
;
and
the

display
of
which
,
to
Fagin
,
by
the
Jew
who

,
had
been
the
very
first
clue
received
,
of
his
whereabout
.
   
<EOS>
"
Put
off

smart
ones
,
"
said
