,
"
and
I
'll
give
'em
to
Fagin
to
take
care
of
<EOS>
.
 
<EOS>
What
fun
it
is
!
"
   
<EOS>
Poor
Oliver
unwillingly
complied
.
 
<EOS>
Master
Bates
rolling
up
the
new
clothes
under
his
arm
,
departed
from
the
room
,
leaving
Oliver
in
the
dark
,
and
locking
the
door
behind
him
.
   
<EOS>
The
noise
of
Charley
's
laughter
,
and
the
voice
of
Miss
Betsy
,
who
opportunely
arrived
to
throw
water
over
her
friend
,
and
perform
other
feminine
offices
for
the
promotion
of
her
recovery
,
might
have
kept
many
people
awake
under
more
happy
circumstances
than
those
in
which
Oliver
was
placed
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
was
sick
and
weary
;
and
he
soon
fell
sound
asleep
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
17
.
<EOS>
Oliver
's
destiny
continuing
unpropitious
,
brings
a
great
man
to
London
to
injure
his
reputation
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
the
custom
on
the
stage
,
in
all
good
murderous
melodramas
,
to
present
the
tragic
and
the
comic
scenes
,
in
as
regular
alternation
,
as
the
layers
of
red
and
white
in
a
side
of
streaky
bacon
.
 
<EOS>
The
hero
sinks
upon
his
straw
bed
,
weighed
down
by
fetters
and
misfortunes
;
in
the
next
scene
,
his
faithful
but
unconscious
squire
regales
the
audience
with
a
comic
song
.
 
<EOS>
We
behold
,
with
throbbing
bosoms
,
the
heroine
in
the
grasp
of
a
proud
and
ruthless
baron
:
her
virtue
and
her
life
alike
in
danger
,
drawing
forth
her
dagger
to
preserve
the
one
at
the
cost
of
the
other
;
and
just
as
our
expectations
are
wrought
up
to
the
highest
pitch
,
a
whistle
is
heard
,
and
we
are
straightway
transported
to
the
great
hall
of
the
castle
;
where
a
grey
-
headed
seneschal
sings
a
funny
chorus
with
a
funnier
body
of
vassals
,
who
are
free
of
all
sorts
of
places
,
from
church
vaults
to
palaces
,
and
roam
about
in
company
,
carolling
perpetually
.
   
<EOS>
Such
changes
appear
absurd
;
but
they
are
not
so
unnatural
as
they
would
seem
at
first
sight
.
 
<EOS>
The
transitions
in
real
life
from
well
-
spread
boards
to
death
-
beds
,
and
from
mourning
-
weeds
to
holiday
garments
,
are
not
a
whit
less
startling
;
only
,
there
,
we
are
busy
actors
,
instead
of
passive
lookers
-
on
,
which
makes
a
vast
difference
.
 
<EOS>
The
actors
in
the
mimic
life
of
the
theatre
,
are
blind
to
violent
transitions
and
abrupt
impulses
of
passion
or
feeling
,
which
,
presented
before
the
eyes
of
mere
spectators
,
are
at
once
condemned
as
outrageous
and
preposterous
.
   
<EOS>
As
sudden
shiftings
of
the
scene
,
and
rapid
changes
of
time
and
place
,
are
not
only
sanctioned
in
books
by
long
usage
,
but
are
by
many
considered
as
the
great
art
of
authorship
:
an
author
's
skill
in
his
craft
being
,
by
such
critics
,
chiefly
estimated
with
relation
to
the
dilemmas
in
which
he
leaves
his
characters
at
the
end
of
every
chapter
:
this
brief
introduction
to
the
present
one
may
perhaps
be
deemed
unnecessary
.
 
<EOS>
If
so
,
let
it
be
considered
a
delicate
intimation
on
the
part
of
the
historian
that
he
is
going
back
to
the
town
in
which
Oliver
Twist
was
born
;
the
reader
taking
it
for
granted
that
there
are
good
and
substantial
reasons
for
making
the
journey
,
or
he
would
not
be
invited
to
proceed
upon
such
an
expedition
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
emerged
at
early
morning
from
the
workhouse
-
gate
,
and
walked
with
portly
carriage
and
commanding
steps
,
up
the
High
Street
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
in
the
full
bloom
and
pride
of
beadlehood
;
his
cocked
hat
and
coat
were
dazzling
in
the
morning
sun
;
he
clutched
his
cane
with
the
vigorous
tenacity
of
health
and
power
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
always
carried
his
head
high
;
but
this
morning
it
was
higher
than
usual
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
an
abstraction
in
his
eye
,
an
elevation
in
his
air
,
which
might
have
warned
an
observant
stranger
that
thoughts
were
passing
in
the
beadle
's
mind
,
too
great
for
utterance
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
stopped
not
to
converse
with
the
small
shopkeepers
and
others
who
spoke
to
him
,
deferentially
,
as
he
passed
along
.
 
<EOS>
He
merely
returned
their
salutations
with
a
wave
of
his
hand
,
and
relaxed
not
in
his
dignified
pace
,
until
he
reached
the
farm
where
Mrs
Mann
tended
the
infant
paupers
with
parochial
care
.
   
<EOS>
"
Drat
that
beadle
!
"
said
Mrs
Mann
,
hearing
the
well
-
known
shaking
at
the
garden
-
gate
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
it
is
n't
him
at
this
time
in
the
morning
!
 
<EOS>
Lauk
,
Mr
Bumble
,
only
think
of
its
being
you
!
 
<EOS>
Well
,
dear
me
,
it
IS
a
pleasure
,
this
is
!
 
<EOS>
Come
into
the
parlour
,
sir
,
please
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
first
sentence
was
addressed
to
Susan
;
and
the
exclamations
of
delight
were
uttered
to
Mr
Bumble
:
as
the
good
lady
unlocked
the
garden
-
gate
:
and
showed
him
,
with
great
attention
and
respect
,
into
the
house
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Mann
,
"
said
Mr
Bumble
;
not
sitting
upon
,
or
dropping
himself
into
a
seat
,
as
any
common
jackanapes
would
:
but
letting
himself
gradually
and
slowly
down
into
a
chair
;
"
Mrs
Mann
,
ma'am
,
good
morning
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
and
good
morning
to
YOU
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mrs
Mann
,
with
many
smiles
;
"
and
hoping
you
find
yourself
well
,
sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
<EOS>
-
so
,
Mrs
Mann
,
"
replied
the
beadle
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
porochial
life
is
not
a
bed
of
roses
,
Mrs
Mann
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
that
it
is
n't
indeed
,
Mr
Bumble
,
"
rejoined
the
lady
.
<EOS>
And
all
the
infant
paupers
might
have
chorussed
the
rejoinder
with
great
propriety
,
if
they
had
heard
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
porochial
life
,
ma'am
<EOS>
,
"
continued
Mr
Bumble
,
striking
the
table
with
his
cane
,
"
is
a
life
of
worrit
,
and
vexation
,
and
hardihood
;
but
all
public
characters
,
as
I
may
say
,
must
suffer
prosecution
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Mann
,
not
very
well
knowing
what
the
beadle
meant
,
raised
her
hands
with
a
look
of
sympathy
,
and
sighed
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
You
may
well
sigh
,
Mrs
Mann
!
"
said
the
beadle
.
   
<EOS>
Finding
she
had
done
right
,
Mrs
Mann
sighed
again
:
 
evidently
to
the
satisfaction
of
the
public
character
:
 
who
,
repressing
a
complacent
smile
by
looking
sternly
at
his
cocked
hat
,
said
,
   
"
<EOS>
Mrs
Mann
,
I
am
going
to
London
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Lauk
,
Mr
Bumble
!
"
cried
Mrs
Mann
,
starting
back
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
To
London
,
ma'am
,
"
resumed
the
inflexible
beadle
,
"
by
coach
.
 
<EOS>
I
and
two
paupers
,
Mrs
Mann
!
 
<EOS>
A
legal
action
is
a
coming
on
,
about
a
settlement
;
and
the
board
has
appointed
me
---
me
,
Mrs
Mann
---
to
dispose
to
the
matter
before
the
quarter
-
sessions
at
Clerkinwell
.
   
<EOS>
And
I
very
much
question
,
"
added
Mr
Bumble
,
drawing
himself
up
,
"
whether
the
Clerkinwell
Sessions
will
not
find
themselves
in
the
wrong
box
before
they
have
done
with
me
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
you
must
n't
be
too
hard
upon
them
,
sir
,
"
said
Mrs
Mann
,
coaxingly
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
Clerkinwell
Sessions
have
brought
it
upon
themselves
,
ma'am
,
"
replied
Mr
Bumble
;
"
and
if
the
Clerkinwell
Sessions
find
that
they
come
off
rather
worse
than
they
expected
,
the
Clerkinwell
Sessions
have
only
themselves
to
thank
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
so
much
determination
and
depth
of
purpose
about
the
menacing
manner
in
which
Mr
Bumble
delivered
himself
of
these
words
,
that
Mrs
Mann
appeared
quite
awed
by
them
.
<EOS>
At
length
she
said
,
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
going
by
coach
,
sir
?
 
<EOS>
I
thought
it
was
always
usual
to
send
them
paupers
in
carts
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
when
they
're
ill
,
Mrs
Mann
,
"
said
the
beadle
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
put
the
sick
paupers
into
open
carts
in
the
rainy
weather
,
to
prevent
their
taking
cold
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
said
Mrs
Mann
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
opposition
coach
contracts
for
these
two
;
and
takes
them
cheap
,
"
said
Mr
Bumble
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
are
both
in
a
very
low
state
,
and
we
find
it
would
come
two
pound
cheaper
to
move
'em
than
to
bury
'em
---
<EOS>
that
is
,
if
we
can
throw
'em
upon
another
parish
,
which
I
think
we
shall
be
able
to
do
,
if
they
do
n't
die
upon
the
road
to
spite
us
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
"
   
<EOS>
When
Mr
Bumble
had
laughed
a
little
while
,
his
eyes
again
encountered
the
cocked
hat
;
and
he
became
grave
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
are
forgetting
business
,
ma'am
,
"
said
the
beadle
;
"
here
is
your
porochial
stipend
for
the
month
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
produced
some
silver
money
rolled
up
in
paper
,
from
his
pocket
-
book
;
and
requested
a
receipt
:
 
which
Mrs
Mann
wrote
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
very
much
blotted
,
sir
,
"
said
the
farmer
of
infants
;
"
but
<EOS>
it
's
formal
enough
,
I
dare
say
.
 
<EOS>
Thank
you
,
Mr
Bumble
,
sir
,
I
am
very
much
obliged
to
you
,
<EOS>
I
'm
sure
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
nodded
,
blandly
,
in
acknowledgment
of
Mrs
Mann
's
curtsey
;
and
inquired
how
the
children
were
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bless
their
dear
little
hearts
!
"
said
Mrs
Mann
with
emotion
,
"
they
're
as
well
as
can
be
,
the
dears
!
 
<EOS>
Of
course
,
except
the
two
that
died
last
week
.
 
<EOS>
And
little
Dick
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
n't
that
boy
no
better
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Bumble
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Mann
shook
her
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
a
ill
-
conditioned
,
wicious
,
bad
-
disposed
porochial
child
that
,
"
said
Mr
Bumble
angrily
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
is
he
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
bring
him
to
you
in
one
minute
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mrs
Mann
.
<EOS>
"
Here
,
you
Dick
!
"
   
<EOS>
After
some
calling
,
Dick
was
discovered
.
 
<EOS>
Having
had
his
face
put
under
the
pump
,
and
dried
upon
Mrs
Mann
's
gown
,
he
was
led
into
the
awful
presence
of
Mr
Bumble
,
the
beadle
.
   
<EOS>
The
child
was
pale
and
thin
;
his
cheeks
were
sunken
;
and
his
eyes
large
and
bright
.
 
<EOS>
The
scanty
parish
dress
,
the
livery
of
his
misery
,
hung
loosely
on
his
feeble
body
;
and
his
young
limbs
had
wasted
away
,
like
those
of
an
old
man
.
   
<EOS>
Such
was
the
little
being
who
stood
trembling
beneath
Mr
Bumble
's
glance
;
not
daring
to
lift
his
eyes
from
the
floor
;
and
dreading
even
to
hear
the
beadle
's
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ca
n't
you
look
at
the
gentleman
,
you
obstinate
boy
?
"
said
Mrs
Mann
.
   
<EOS>
The
child
meekly
raised
his
eyes
,
and
encountered
those
of
Mr
Bumble
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
with
you
,
porochial
Dick
?
"
inquired
Mr
Bumble
,
with
well
-
timed
jocularity
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
child
faintly
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
think
not
,
"
said
Mrs
Mann
,
who
had
of
course
laughed
very
much
at
Mr
Bumble
's
humour
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
want
for
nothing
,
I
'm
sure
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
---
<EOS>
"
faltered
the
child
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hey
-
day
!
"
<EOS>
interposed
Mr
Mann
,
"
I
suppose
you
're
going
to
say
that
you
DO
want
for
something
,
now
?
 
<EOS>
Why
,
you
little
wretch
<EOS>
---
"
   
"
Stop
,
Mrs
Mann
,
stop
!
"
said
the
beadle
,
raising
his
hand
with
a
show
of
authority
.
 
<EOS>
"
Like
what
,
sir
,
eh
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
,
"
said
the
child
,
"
to
leave
my
dear
love
to
poor
Oliver
Twist
;
and
to
let
him
know
how
often
I
have
sat
by
myself
and
cried
to
think
of
his
wandering
about
in
the
dark
nights
with
nobody
to
help
him
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
should
like
to
tell
him
,
"
said
the
child
pressing
his
small
hands
together
,
and
speaking
with
great
fervour
,
"
that
I
was
glad
to
die
when
I
was
very
young
;
for
,
perhaps
,
if
I
had
lived
to
be
a
man
,
and
had
grown
old
,
my
little
sister
who
is
in
Heaven
,
might
forget
me
,
or
be
unlike
me
;
and
it
would
be
so
much
happier
if
we
were
both
children
there
together
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
surveyed
the
little
speaker
,
from
head
to
foot
,
with
indescribable
astonishment
;
and
,
turning
to
his
companion
,
said
,
"
They
're
all
in
one
story
,
Mrs
Mann
.
 
<EOS>
That
out
-
dacious
Oliver
had
demogalized
them
all
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
could
n't
have
believed
it
,
sir
"
said
Mrs
Mann
,
holding
up
her
hands
,
and
looking
malignantly
at
Dick
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
never
see
such
a
hardened
little
wretch
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Take
him
away
,
ma'am
!
"
said
Mr
Bumble
imperiously
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
must
be
stated
to
the
board
,
Mrs
Mann
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
the
gentleman
will
understand
that
it
is
n't
my
fault
,
sir
?
"
said
Mrs
Mann
,
whimpering
pathetically
.
   
<EOS>
"
They
shall
understand
that
,
ma'am
;
they
shall
be
acquainted
with
the
true
state
of
the
case
,
"
said
Mr
Bumble
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
;
take
him
away
,
I
ca
n't
bear
the
sight
on
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
Dick
was
immediately
taken
away
,
and
locked
up
in
the
coal
-
cellar
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
shortly
afterwards
took
himself
off
,
to
prepare
for
his
journey
.
   
<EOS>
At
six
o'clock
next
morning
,
Mr
Bumble
:
 
having
exchanged
his
cocked
hat
for
a
round
one
,
and
encased
his
person
in
a
blue
great
-
coat
with
a
cape
to
it
:
 
took
his
place
on
the
outside
of
the
coach
,
accompanied
by
the
criminals
whose
settlement
was
disputed
;
with
whom
,
in
due
course
of
time
,
he
arrived
in
London
.
   
<EOS>
He
experienced
no
other
crosses
on
the
way
,
than
those
which
originated
in
the
perverse
behaviour
of
the
two
paupers
,
who
persisted
in
shivering
,
and
complaining
of
the
cold
,
in
a
manner
which
,
Mr
Bumble
declared
,
caused
his
teeth
to
chatter
in
his
head
,
and
made
him
feel
quite
uncomfortable
;
although
he
had
a
great
-
coat
on
.
   
<EOS>
Having
disposed
of
these
evil
-
minded
persons
for
the
night
,
Mr
Bumble
sat
himself
down
in
the
house
at
which
the
coach
stopped
;
and
took
a
temperate
dinner
of
steaks
,
oyster
sauce
,
and
porter
.
<EOS>
Putting
a
glass
of
hot
gin
-
and
-
water
on
the
chimney
-
piece
,
he
drew
his
chair
to
the
fire
;
and
,
with
sundry
moral
reflections
on
the
too
-
prevalent
sin
of
discontent
and
complaining
,
composed
himself
to
read
the
paper
.
   
<EOS>
The
very
first
paragraph
upon
which
Mr
Bumble
's
eye
rested
,
was
the
following
advertisement
.
                    
<EOS>
"
FIVE
GUINEAS
REWARD
   
<EOS>
"
Whereas
a
young
boy
,
named
Oliver
Twist
,
absconded
,
or
was
enticed
,
on
Thursday
evening
last
,
from
his
home
,
at
Pentonville
;
and
has
not
since
been
heard
of
.
 
<EOS>
The
above
reward
will
be
paid
to
any
person
who
will
give
such
information
as
will
lead
to
the
discovery
of
the
said
Oliver
Twist
,
or
tend
to
throw
any
light
upon
his
previous
history
,
in
which
the
advertiser
is
,
for
many
reasons
,
warmly
interested
.
"
   
<EOS>
And
then
followed
a
full
description
of
Oliver
's
dress
,
person
,
appearance
,
and
disappearance
:
 
with
the
name
and
address
of
Mr
Brownlow
at
full
length
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
opened
his
eyes
;
read
the
advertisement
,
slowly
and
carefully
,
three
several
times
;
and
in
something
more
than
five
minutes
was
on
his
way
to
Pentonville
:
having
actually
,
in
his
excitement
,
left
the
glass
of
hot
gin
-
and
-
water
,
untasted
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
Mr
Brownlow
at
home
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Bumble
of
the
girl
who
opened
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
To
this
inquiry
the
girl
returned
the
not
uncommon
,
but
rather
evasive
reply
of
"
I
do
n't
know
;
where
do
you
come
from
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
no
sooner
uttered
Oliver
's
name
,
in
explanation
of
his
errand
,
than
Mrs
Bedwin
,
who
had
been
listening
at
the
parlour
door
,
hastened
into
the
passage
in
a
breathless
state
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
in
,
come
in
,
"
said
the
old
lady
:
"
<EOS>
I
knew
we
should
hear
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
Poor
dear
!
 
<EOS>
I
knew
we
should
!
 
<EOS>
I
was
certain
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
Bless
his
heart
!
 
<EOS>
I
said
so
all
along
.
"
   
<EOS>
Having
heard
this
,
the
worthy
old
lady
hurried
back
into
the
parlour
again
;
and
seating
herself
on
a
sofa
,
burst
into
tears
.
<EOS>
The
girl
,
who
was
not
quite
so
susceptible
,
had
run
upstairs
meanwhile
;
and
now
returned
with
a
request
that
Mr
Bumble
would
follow
her
immediately
:
 
which
he
did
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
shown
into
the
little
back
study
,
where
sat
Mr
Brownlow
and
his
friend
Mr
Grimwig
,
with
decanters
and
glasses
before
them
.
 
<EOS>
The
latter
gentleman
at
once
burst
into
the
exclamation
:
   
"
A
beadle
.
 
<EOS>
A
parish
beadle
,
or
<EOS>
I
'll
eat
my
head
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
do
n't
interrupt
just
now
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
a
seat
,
will
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
sat
himself
down
;
quite
confounded
by
the
oddity
of
Mr
Grimwig
's
manner
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Brownlow
moved
the
lamp
,
so
as
to
obtain
an
uninterrupted
view
of
the
beadle
's
countenance
;
and
said
,
with
a
little
impatience
,
   
"
Now
,
sir
,
you
come
in
consequence
of
having
seen
the
advertisement
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Bumble
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
you
ARE
a
beadle
,
are
you
not
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Grimwig
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
a
porochial
beadle
,
gentlemen
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Bumble
proudly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
,
"
observed
Mr
Grimwig
aside
to
his
friend
,
"
<EOS>
I
knew
he
was
.
 
<EOS>
A
beadle
all
over
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Brownlow
gently
shook
his
head
to
impose
silence
on
his
friend
,
and
resumed
:
   
"
<EOS>
Do
you
know
where
this
poor
boy
is
now
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
more
than
nobody
,
"
replied
Mr
Bumble
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
what
DO
you
know
of
him
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
the
old
gentleman
.
"
<EOS>
Speak
out
,
my
friend
,
if
you
have
anything
to
say
.
 
<EOS>
What
DO
you
know
of
him
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
happen
to
know
any
good
of
him
,
do
you
?
"
said
Mr
Grimwig
,
caustically
;
after
an
attentive
perusal
of
Mr
Bumble
's
features
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
,
catching
at
the
inquiry
very
quickly
,
shook
his
head
with
portentous
solemnity
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
see
?
"
said
Mr
Grimwig
,
looking
triumphantly
at
Mr
Brownlow
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Brownlow
looked
apprehensively
at
Mr
Bumble
's
pursed
-
up
countenance
;
and
requested
him
to
communicate
what
he
knew
regarding
Oliver
,
in
as
few
words
as
possible
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
put
down
his
hat
;
unbuttoned
his
coat
;
folded
his
arms
;
inclined
his
head
in
a
retrospective
manner
;
and
,
after
a
few
moments
'
reflection
,
commenced
his
story
.
   
<EOS>
It
would
be
tedious
if
given
in
the
beadle
's
words
:
 
occupying
,
as
it
did
,
some
twenty
minutes
in
the
telling
;
but
the
sum
and
substance
of
it
was
,
that
Oliver
was
a
foundling
,
born
of
low
and
vicious
parents
.
 
<EOS>
That
he
had
,
from
his
birth
,
displayed
no
better
qualities
than
treachery
,
ingratitude
,
and
malice
.
 
<EOS>
That
he
had
terminated
his
brief
career
in
the
place
of
his
birth
,
by
making
a
sanguinary
and
cowardly
attack
on
an
unoffending
lad
,
and
running
away
in
the
night
-
time
from
his
master
's
house
.
 
<EOS>
In
proof
of
his
really
being
the
person
he
represented
himself
,
Mr
Bumble
laid
upon
the
table
the
papers
he
had
brought
to
town
.
<EOS>
Folding
his
arms
again
,
he
then
awaited
Mr
Brownlow
's
observations
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
fear
it
is
all
too
true
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
sorrowfully
,
after
looking
over
the
papers
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
not
much
for
your
intelligence
;
but
I
would
gladly
have
given
you
treble
the
money
,
if
it
had
been
favourable
to
the
boy
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
is
not
improbable
that
if
Mr
Bumble
had
been
possessed
of
this
information
at
an
earlier
period
of
the
interview
,
he
might
have
imparted
a
very
different
colouring
to
his
little
history
.
<EOS>
It
was
too
late
to
do
it
now
,
however
;
so
he
shook
his
head
gravely
,
and
,
pocketing
the
five
guineas
,
withdrew
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Brownlow
paced
the
room
to
and
fro
for
some
minutes
;
evidently
so
much
disturbed
by
the
beadle
's
tale
,
that
even
Mr
Grimwig
forbore
to
vex
him
further
.
   
<EOS>
At
length
he
stopped
,
and
rang
the
bell
violently
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Bedwin
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
,
when
the
housekeeper
appeared
;
"
<EOS>
that
boy
,
Oliver
,
is
an
imposter
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
ca
n't
be
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
It
can
not
be
,
"
said
the
old
lady
energetically
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
he
is
,
"
retorted
the
old
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
by
ca
n't
be
?
 
<EOS>
We
have
just
heard
a
full
account
of
him
from
his
birth
;
and
he
has
been
a
thorough
-
paced
little
villain
,
all
his
life
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
never
will
believe
it
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
old
lady
,
firmly
.
"
<EOS>
Never
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
old
women
never
believe
anything
but
quack
-
doctors
,
and
lying
story
-
books
,
"
growled
Mr
Grimwig
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
knew
it
all
along
.
<EOS>
Why
did
n't
you
take
my
advise
in
the
beginning
;
you
would
if
he
had
n't
had
a
fever
,
I
suppose
,
eh
?
 
<EOS>
He
was
interesting
,
was
n't
he
?
 
<EOS>
Interesting
!
 
<EOS>
Bah
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
Mr
Grimwig
poked
the
fire
with
a
flourish
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
was
a
dear
,
grateful
,
gentle
child
,
sir
,
"
retorted
Mrs
Bedwin
,
indignantly
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
what
children
are
,
sir
;
and
have
done
these
forty
years
;
and
people
who
ca
n't
say
the
same
,
should
n't
say
anything
about
them
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
my
opinion
!
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
a
hard
hit
at
Mr
Grimwig
,
who
was
a
bachelor
.
 
<EOS>
As
it
extorted
nothing
from
that
gentleman
but
a
smile
,
the
old
lady
tossed
her
head
,
and
smoothed
down
her
apron
preparatory
to
another
speech
,
when
she
was
stopped
by
Mr
Brownlow
.
   
<EOS>
"
Silence
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
old
gentleman
,
feigning
an
anger
he
was
far
from
feeling
.
 
<EOS>
"
Never
let
me
hear
the
boy
's
name
again
.
 
<EOS>
I
rang
to
tell
you
that
.
 
<EOS>
Never
.
 
<EOS>
Never
,
on
any
pretence
,
mind
!
 
<EOS>
You
may
leave
the
room
,
Mrs
Bedwin
.
 
<EOS>
Remember
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
in
earnest
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
were
sad
hearts
at
Mr
Brownlow
's
that
night
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
's
heart
sank
within
him
,
when
he
thought
of
his
good
friends
;
it
was
well
for
him
that
he
could
not
know
what
they
had
heard
,
or
it
might
have
broken
outright
.
    
Chapter
08
.
<EOS>
How
Oliver
passed
his
time
in
the
improving
society
of
his
reputable
friends
.
 
<EOS>
About
noon
next
day
,
when
the
Dodger
and
Master
Bates
had
gone
out
to
pursue
their
customary
avocations
,
Mr
Fagin
took
the
opportunity
of
reading
Oliver
a
long
lecture
on
the
crying
sin
of
ingratitude
;
of
which
he
clearly
demonstrated
he
had
been
guilty
,
to
no
ordinary
extent
,
in
wilfully
absenting
himself
from
the
society
of
his
anxious
friends
;
and
,
still
more
,
in
endeavouring
to
escape
from
them
after
so
much
trouble
and
expense
had
been
incurred
in
his
recovery
.
<EOS>
Mr
Fagin
laid
great
stress
on
the
fact
of
his
having
taken
Oliver
in
,
and
cherished
him
,
when
,
without
his
timely
aid
,
he
might
have
perished
with
hunger
;
and
he
related
the
dismal
and
affecting
history
of
a
young
lad
whom
,
in
his
philanthropy
,
he
had
succoured
under
parallel
circumstances
,
but
who
,
proving
unworthy
of
his
confidence
and
evincing
a
desire
to
communicate
with
the
police
,
had
unfortunately
come
to
be
hanged
at
the
Old
Bailey
one
morning
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Fagin
did
not
seek
to
conceal
his
share
in
the
catastrophe
,
but
lamented
with
tears
in
his
eyes
that
the
wrong
-
headed
and
treacherous
behaviour
of
the
young
person
in
question
,
had
rendered
it
necessary
that
he
should
become
the
victim
of
certain
evidence
for
the
crown
:
which
,
if
it
were
not
precisely
true
,
was
indispensably
necessary
for
the
safety
of
him
(
Mr
Fagin
)
and
a
few
select
friends
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Fagin
concluded
by
drawing
a
rather
disagreeable
picture
of
the
discomforts
of
hanging
;
and
,
with
great
friendliness
and
politeness
of
manner
,
expressed
his
anxious
hopes
that
he
might
never
be
obliged
to
submit
Oliver
Twist
to
that
unpleasant
operation
.
   
<EOS>
Little
Oliver
's
blood
ran
cold
,
as
he
listened
to
the
Jew
's
words
,
and
imperfectly
comprehended
the
dark
threats
conveyed
in
them
.
 
<EOS>
That
it
was
possible
even
for
justice
itself
to
confound
the
innocent
with
the
guilty
when
they
were
in
accidental
companionship
,
he
knew
already
;
and
that
deeply
-
laid
plans
for
the
destruction
of
inconveniently
knowing
or
over
-
communicative
persons
,
had
been
really
devised
and
carried
out
by
the
Jew
on
more
occasions
than
one
,
he
thought
by
no
means
unlikely
,
when
he
recollected
the
general
nature
of
the
altercations
between
that
gentleman
and
Mr
Sikes
:
which
seemed
to
bear
reference
to
some
foregone
conspiracy
of
the
kind
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
glanced
timidly
up
,
and
met
the
Jew
's
searching
look
,
he
felt
that
his
pale
face
and
trembling
limbs
were
neither
unnoticed
nor
unrelished
by
that
wary
old
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
The
Jew
,
smiling
hideously
,
patted
Oliver
on
the
head
,
and
said
,
that
if
he
kept
himself
quiet
,
and
applied
himself
to
business
,
he
saw
they
would
be
very
good
friends
yet
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
taking
his
hat
,
and
covering
himself
with
an
old
patched
great
-
coat
,
he
went
out
,
and
locked
the
room
-
door
behind
him
.
   
<EOS>
And
so
Oliver
remained
all
that
day
,
and
for
the
greater
part
of
many
subsequent
days
,
seeing
nobody
,
between
early
morning
and
midnight
,
and
left
during
the
long
hours
to
commune
with
his
own
thoughts
.
 
<EOS>
Which
,
never
failing
to
revert
to
his
kind
friends
,
and
the
opinion
they
must
long
ago
have
formed
of
him
,
were
sad
indeed
.
   
<EOS>
After
the
lapse
of
a
week
or
so
,
the
Jew
left
the
room
-
door
unlocked
;
and
he
was
at
liberty
to
wander
about
the
house
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
very
dirty
place
.
 
<EOS>
The
rooms
upstairs
had
great
high
wooden
chimney
-
pieces
and
large
doors
,
with
panelled
walls
and
cornices
to
the
ceiling
;
which
,
although
they
were
black
with
neglect
and
dust
,
were
ornamented
in
various
ways
.
 
<EOS>
From
all
of
these
tokens
Oliver
concluded
that
a
long
time
ago
,
before
the
old
Jew
was
born
,
it
had
belonged
to
better
people
,
and
had
perhaps
been
quite
gay
and
handsome
:
 
dismal
and
dreary
as
it
looked
now
.
   
<EOS>
Spiders
had
built
their
webs
in
the
angles
of
the
walls
and
ceilings
;
and
sometimes
,
when
Oliver
walked
softly
into
a
room
,
the
mice
would
scamper
across
the
floor
,
and
run
back
terrified
to
their
holes
.
 
<EOS>
With
these
exceptions
,
there
was
neither
sight
nor
sound
of
any
living
thing
;
and
often
,
when
it
grew
dark
,
and
he
was
tired
of
wandering
from
room
to
room
,
he
would
crouch
in
the
corner
of
the
passage
by
the
street
-
door
,
to
be
as
near
living
people
as
he
could
;
and
would
remain
there
,
listening
and
counting
the
hours
,
until
the
Jew
or
the
boys
returned
.
   
<EOS>
In
all
the
rooms
,
the
mouldering
shutters
were
fast
closed
:
 
<EOS>
the
bars
which
held
them
were
screwed
tight
into
the
wood
;
the
only
light
which
was
admitted
,
stealing
its
way
through
round
holes
at
the
top
:
which
made
the
rooms
more
gloomy
,
and
filled
them
with
strange
shadows
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
back
-
garret
window
with
rusty
bars
outside
,
which
had
no
shutter
;
and
out
of
this
,
Oliver
often
gazed
with
a
melancholy
face
for
hours
together
;
but
nothing
was
to
be
descried
from
it
but
a
confused
and
crowded
mass
of
housetops
,
blackened
chimneys
,
and
gable
-
ends
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
indeed
,
a
grizzly
head
might
be
seen
,
peering
over
the
parapet
-
wall
of
a
distant
house
;
but
it
was
quickly
withdrawn
again
;
and
as
the
window
of
Oliver
's
observatory
was
nailed
down
,
and
dimmed
with
the
rain
and
smoke
of
years
,
it
was
as
much
as
he
could
do
to
make
out
the
forms
of
the
different
objects
beyond
,
without
making
any
attempt
to
be
seen
or
heard
,
---
which
he
had
as
much
chance
of
being
,
as
if
he
had
lived
inside
the
ball
of
St
Paul
's
Cathedral
.
   
<EOS>
One
afternoon
,
the
Dodger
and
Master
Bates
being
engaged
out
that
evening
,
the
first
-
named
young
gentleman
took
it
into
his
head
to
evince
some
anxiety
regarding
the
decoration
of
his
person
(
to
do
him
justice
,
this
was
by
no
means
an
habitual
weakness
with
him
)
;
and
,
with
this
end
and
aim
,
he
condescendingly
commanded
Oliver
to
assist
him
in
his
toilet
,
straightway
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
was
but
too
glad
to
make
himself
useful
;
too
happy
to
have
some
faces
,
however
bad
,
to
look
upon
;
too
desirous
to
conciliate
those
about
him
when
he
could
honestly
do
so
;
to
throw
any
objection
in
the
way
of
this
proposal
.
 
<EOS>
So
he
at
once
expressed
his
readiness
;
and
,
kneeling
on
the
floor
,
while
the
Dodger
sat
upon
the
table
so
that
he
could
take
his
foot
in
his
laps
,
he
applied
himself
to
a
process
which
Mr
Dawkins
designated
as
"
japanning
his
trotter
-
cases
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
phrase
,
rendered
into
plain
English
,
signifieth
,
cleaning
his
boots
.
   
<EOS>
Whether
it
was
the
sense
of
freedom
and
independence
which
a
rational
animal
may
be
supposed
to
feel
when
he
sits
on
a
table
in
an
easy
attitude
smoking
a
pipe
,
swinging
one
leg
carelessly
to
and
fro
,
and
having
his
boots
cleaned
all
the
time
,
without
even
the
past
trouble
of
having
taken
them
off
,
or
the
prospective
misery
of
putting
them
on
,
to
disturb
his
reflections
;
or
whether
it
was
the
goodness
of
the
tobacco
that
soothed
the
feelings
of
the
Dodger
,
or
the
mildness
of
the
beer
that
mollified
his
thoughts
;
he
was
evidently
tinctured
,
for
the
nonce
,
with
a
spice
of
romance
and
enthusiasm
,
foreign
to
his
general
nature
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
down
on
Oliver
,
with
a
thoughtful
countenance
,
for
a
brief
space
;
and
then
,
raising
his
head
,
and
heaving
a
gentle
sign
,
said
,
half
in
abstraction
,
and
half
to
Master
Bates
:
   
<EOS>
"
What
a
pity
it
is
he
is
n't
a
prig
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
said
Master
Charles
Bates
;
"
he
do
n't
know
what
's
good
for
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
Dodger
sighed
again
,
and
resumed
his
pipe
:
as
did
Charley
Bates
.
 
<EOS>
They
both
smoked
,
for
some
seconds
,
in
silence
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
you
do
n't
even
know
what
a
prig
is
?
"
said
the
Dodger
mournfully
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
know
that
,
"
replied
Oliver
,
looking
up
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
the
---
;
you
're
one
,
are
you
not
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Oliver
,
checking
himself
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
,
"
replied
the
Doger
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'd
scorn
to
be
anything
else
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Dawkins
gave
his
hat
a
ferocious
cock
,
after
delivering
this
sentiment
,
and
looked
at
Master
Bates
,
as
if
to
denote
that
he
would
feel
obliged
by
his

anything
to
the
contrary
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
,
"
repeated
the
Dodger
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
's
Charley
.
 
<EOS>
So
's
Fagin
.
<EOS>
So
's
Sikes
.
 
<EOS>
So
's
Nancy
.
 
<EOS>
So
's
Bet
.
 
<EOS>
So
we
all
are
,
down
to
the
dog
.
<EOS>
And
he
's
the
downiest
one
of
the
lot
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
the
least
given
to
peaching
,
"
added
Charley
Bates
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
would
n't
so
much
as

in
a
witness

,
for
fear

;
no
,

,

left

there

for
a

,
"
said

Dodger
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a
bit

it
,
"
observed
Charley
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
a
rum
dog
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
he
look
fierce
at
any
strange
cove
that
laughs
or
sings
when
he
's
in
company
!
"
pursued
the
Dodger
.
<EOS>
"
Wo

growl
at
all
,
when
he
hears

fiddle
playing
!
 
<EOS>
And
do

he
hate
other
dogs
as
ai
n't
of
his
breed
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
no
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
an
out
-
and
-
out
Christian
,
"
said
Charley
.
   
<EOS>
This
was
merely

as
a

to
the
animal
's

,
but

,

;

,

-

-

,
between

,
and
Mr
Sikes
'
dog
<EOS>
,

exist

of

.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
"
said
the
Dodger
,
recurring

the
point
from
which

had

:
with
that

of

which

.
 
<EOS>
"
This
has
n't
go
anything
to
do

young
Green
here
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No

,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
do

put

Fagin
,
Oliver
?
"
   
"
And
make

fortun
"
out

?
"
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so

able

,
and
do

gen
-

:
as
I

,
in

-
year
but
four
that

,
and

Tuesday
in

-

,
"

Bates
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do

like

,
"

Oliver
,
timidly
;
"
I
wish
they

let
me
go
.
 
<EOS>
I
---
I
---
would
rather
go
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
Fagin
would
RATHER
not
!
"
rejoined
Charley
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
knew
this
too
well
;
but
thinking
it
might
be
dangerous
to
express
his
feelings
more
openly
,
he
only
sighed
,
and
went
on
with
his
boot
-

.
   
<EOS>
"
Go
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed

Dodger
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
where
's
your
spirit
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do

you
take
any

?
 
<EOS>
Would
you
go
and
be

friends
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
blow
that
!
"
said
Master
Bates
:
drawing

,

into

,
"
that
's

mean
;
that

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
\
<EOS>
I
\
could

,
"
said

Dodger
,
with

.
   
<EOS>
"
You

,

,
"

Oliver

;
"
and

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
,
"

,

,
"
That
was
all
out

for
Fagin
,
'cause
the
traps
know
that
we
work

,

lucky
;
that

,

,
Charley
?
"
   
<EOS>
Master

nodded

,
and
would

,
but

Oliver
's
flight
came

,
that

got

with

,

,
and

:
and

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Look

!
"
said

Dodger
,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
's

!
 
<EOS>
What
's

odds
where

?
 
<EOS>
Here
,

;

where

.
 
<EOS>
You
wo
n't
,
wo

you
?
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
you
precious
flat
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
naughty
,
ai

,
Oliver
?
"
<EOS>
inquired

Bates
.
<EOS>
"
He
'll

,
wo

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Something
in

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
As

,

;

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
That

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,
Jack
!
   
<EOS>
I

as

'
ere

;
he
'll

the

me
<EOS>
,

.
"
 
<EOS>
Master
Charley
Bates
,

,

with

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
've
been
brought
up

,
"
said
the
Dodger
,
surveying
his
boots
with
much
satisfaction
when
Oliver

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Fagin
will
make

of

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
You
'd

begin
at

;
for
you
'll
come
to
the
trade
long
before
you
think
of

;
and
you
're
only
losing
time
,
Oliver
.
"
   
<EOS>
Master
Bates
backed
this

with
sundry

:
 
which
,
being

,
he

Mr
Dawkins
launched
into

of
the
numerous

the
life
they
led
,
interspersed
with
a
variety
of
hints
to
Oliver
that

he

,
would

to
secure

's
favour
without
more

,
by

.
   
<EOS>
"
And
always

this
in

pipe
,
Nolly
,
"

,
as

,
"
if

do

take
fogels

---
"
   
"
What

?
<EOS>
"

Bates
;
"
he
do

you

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
do

take
pocket
-

,
"
said

Dodger
,
reducing

's

,
"
some

;
so
that

that
lose

all

,
and

all
the

,

,
and
nobody
half
a
ha'p'orth
the
better
,
<EOS>
except

chaps
wot
gets

---
and
you
've

as
good
<EOS>
a

.
<EOS>
"
   
"
To

,

!
"
said

Jew
,
who

entered

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
all
lies
in
a
nutshell
<EOS>
my

;
in

,

's

.
 
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
 
<EOS>
He
understands
the

of
his
trade
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
old
man
rubbed
his
hands
gleefully
together
,
as
he
corroborated
the
Dodger
's
reasoning
in
these
terms
;
and
chuckled
with
delight
at
his
pupil
's
proficiency
.
   
<EOS>
The
conversation
proceeded
no
farther
at
this
time
,
for
the
Jew
had
returned
home
accompanied
by
Miss
Betsy
,
and
a
gentleman
whom
Oliver
had
never
seen
before
,
but
who
was
accosted
by
the
Dodger
as
Tom
Chitling
;
and
who
,
having
lingered
on
the
stairs
to
exchange
a
few
gallantries
with
the
lady
,
now
made
his
appearance
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Chitling
was
older
in
years
than
the
Dodger
:
having
perhaps
numbered
eighteen
winters
;
but
there
was
a
degree
of
deference
in
his
deportment
towards
that
young
gentleman
which
seemed
to
indicate
that
he
felt
himself
conscious
of
a
slight
inferiority
in
point
of
genius
and
professional
aquirements
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
small
twinkling
eyes
,
and
a
pock
-
marked
face
;
wore
a
fur
cap
,
a
dark
corduroy
jacket
,
greasy
fustian
trousers
,
and
an
apron
.
 
<EOS>
His
wardrobe
was
,
in
truth
,
rather
out
of
repair
;
but
he
excused
himself
to
the
company
by
stating
that
his
"
time
"
was
only
out
an
hour
before
;
and
that
,
in
consequence
of
having
worn
the
regimentals
for
six
weeks
past
,
he
had
not
been
able
to
bestow
any
attention
on
his
private
clothes
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Chitling
added
,
with
strong
marks
of
irritation
,
that
the
new
way
of
fumigating
clothes
up
yonder
was
infernal
unconstitutional
,
for
it
burnt
holes
in
them
,
and
there
was
no
remedy
against
the
County
.
 
<EOS>
The
same
remark
he
considered
to
apply
to
the
regulation
mode
of
cutting
the
hair
:
which
he
held
to
be
decidedly
unlawful
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Chitling
wound
up
his
observations
by
stating
that
he
had
not
touched
a
drop
of
anything
for
forty
-
two
moral
long
hard
-
working
days
;
and
that
he
"
wished
he
might
be
busted
if
he
warn't
as
dry
as
a
lime
-
basket
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Where
do
you
think
the
gentleman
has
come
from
,
Oliver
?
"
inquired
the
Jew
,
with
a
grin
,
as
the
other
boys
put
a
bottle
of
spirits
on
the
table
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
---
I
---
do
n't
know
,
sir
,
"
replied
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
's
that
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Tom
Chitling
,
casting
a
contemptuous
look
at
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
young
friend
of
mine
,
my
dear
,
"
replied
the
Jew
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
in
luck
,
then
,
"
said
the
young
man
,
with
a
meaning
look
at
Fagin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
where
I
came
from
,
young
'
un
;
you
'll
find
your
way
there
,
soon
enough
,
I
'll
bet
a
crown
!
"
   
<EOS>
At
this
sally
,
the
boys
laughed
.
 
<EOS>
After
some
more
jokes
on
the
same
subject
,
they
exchanged
a
few
short
whispers
with
Fagin
;
and
withdrew
.
   
<EOS>
After
some
words
apart
between
the
last
comer
and
Fagin
,
they
drew
their
chairs
towards
the
fire
;
and
the
Jew
,
telling
Oliver
to
come
and
sit
by
him
,
led
the
conversation
to
the
topics
most
calculated
to
interest
his
hearers
.
 
<EOS>
These
were
,
the
great
advantages
of
the
trade
,
the
proficiency
of
the
Dodger
,
the
amiability
of
Charley
Bates
,
and
the
liberality
of
the
Jew
himself
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
these
subjects
displayed
signs
of
being
thoroughly
exhausted
;
and
Mr
Chitling
did
the
same
:
 
for
the
house
of
correction
becomes
fatiguing
after
a
week
or
two
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Betsy
accordingly
withdrew
;
and
left
the
party
to
their
repose
.
   
<EOS>
From
this
day
,
Oliver
was
seldom
left
alone
;
but
was
placed
in
almost
constant
communication
with
the
two
boys
,
who
played
the
old
game
with
the
Jew
every
day
:
whether
for
their
own
improvement
or
Oliver
's
,
Mr
Fagin
best
knew
.
 
<EOS>
At
other
times
the
old
man
would
tell
them
stories
of
robberies
he
had
committed
in
his
younger
days
:
 
mixed
up
with
so
much
that
was
droll
and
curious
,
that
Oliver
could
not
help
laughing
heartily
,
and
showing
that
he
was
amused
in
spite
of
all
his
better
feelings
.
   
<EOS>
In
short
,
the
wily
old
Jew
had
the
boy
in
his
toils
.
 
<EOS>
Having
prepared
his
mind
,
by
solitude
and
gloom
,
to
prefer
any
society
to
the
companionship
of
his
own
sad
thoughts
in
such
a
dreary
place
,
he
was
now
slowly
instilling
into
his
soul
the
poison
which
he
hoped
would
blacken
it
,
and
change
its
hue
for
ever
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
19
.
<EOS>
In
which
a
notable
plan
is
discussed
and
determined
on
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
chill
,
damp
,
<EOS>
windy
night
,
when
the
Jew
:
buttoning
his
great
-
coat
tight
round
his
shrivelled
body
,
and
pulling
the
collar
up
over
his
ears
so
as
completely
to
obscure
the
lower
part
of
his
face
:
 
emerged
from
his
den
.
 
<EOS>
He
paused
on
the
step
as
the
door
was
locked
and
chained
behind
him
;
and
having
listened
while
the
boys
made
all
secure
,
and
until
their
retreating
footsteps
were
no
longer
audible
,
slunk
down
the
street
as
quickly
as
he
could
.
   
<EOS>
The
house
to
which
Oliver
had
been
conveyed
,
was
in
the
neighborhood
of
Whitechapel
.
 
<EOS>
The
Jew
stopped
for
an
instant
at
the
corner
of
the
street
;
and
,
glancing
suspiciously
round
,
crossed
the
road
,
and
struck
off
in
the
direction
of
the
Spitalfields
.
   
<EOS>
The
mud
lay
thick
upon
the
stones
,
and
a
black
mist
hung
over
the
streets
;
the
rain
fell
sluggishly
down
,
and
everything
felt
cold
and
clammy
to
the
touch
.
 
<EOS>
It
seemed
just
the
night
when
it
befitted
such
a
being
as
the
Jew
to
be
abroad
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
glided
stealthily
along
,
creeping
beneath
the
shelter
of
the
walls
and
doorways
,
the
hideous
old
man
seemed
like
some
loathsome
reptile
,
engendered
in
the
slime
and
darkness
through
which
he
moved
:
crawling
forth
,
by
night
,
in
search
of
some
rich
offal
for
a
meal
.
   
<EOS>
He
kept
on
his
course
,
through
many
winding
and
narrow
ways
,
until
he
reached
Bethnal
Green
;
then
,
turning
suddenly
off
to
the
left
,
he
soon
became
involved
in
a
maze
of
the
mean
and
dirty
streets
which
abound
in
that
close
and
densely
-
populated
quarter
.
   
<EOS>
The
Jew
was
evidently
too
familiar
with
the
ground
he
traversed
to
be
at
all
bewildered
,
either
by
the
darkness
of
the
night
,
or
the

of

way
.
 
<EOS>
He
hurried
through
several
alleys
and
streets
,
and
at
length
turned
into
one
,
lighted
only
by
a
single

at

end
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
door
of
a
house
in
this
street
,
he
knocked
;
having
exchanged
a
few

with
the
person

opened

,

walked
upstairs
.
   
<EOS>
A
dog
growled
as
he
touched
the
handle
of
a
room
-
door
;
and
a
man
's

demanded
who
was
there
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Only
me
,
Bill
;
only
me
,
my
dear
,
"
said
the
Jew
looking
in
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bring
in
your
body
then
,
"
said
Sikes
.
 
<EOS>
"
Lie
down
,
you
stupid

!
 
<EOS>
Do

you
know
the
devil
when
he
's
got
a
great
-
coat
on
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Apparently
,

dog
had

Mr
Fagin
's

;
for

Jew

,

,

:
 
wagging

,
to

.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
my
dear
,
"

Jew
.
<EOS>
---
"
Ah
!
Nancy
.
"
   
<EOS>
The

just

to

;
for

,

.
 
<EOS>
All

,

's

.
 
<EOS>
She

,

,
and

draw
up

,
without

about

:
 
<EOS>
for
it
was
a
cold
night
,
and
no
mistake
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
cold
,
Nancy

,
"
said

Jew
,
as

over

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
seems
to
go
right

,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
It

,

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Give

,

.
 
<EOS>
Burn

,

!
 
<EOS>
It

,

,

<EOS>
just

.
"
   
<EOS>
Nancy

:

,

.
 
<EOS>
Sikes

<EOS>
"
Quite

,

,

,
Bill
,
"

<EOS>
"
What
!
 
<EOS>
You

?
"
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Ugh
!
"
   
<EOS>
With

,

,

:
as

to

:
 
which

.
   
<EOS>
The
Jew
glanced
round
the
room
,
as

tossed
down
the
second

;
not
in

,
for
he
had
seen

often

;

.
<EOS>
It
was
a

,

to

;

than

,

"
life

"

over

.
   
<EOS>
"
There
,
"
said
Sikes
,

.
<EOS>
"
Now

'm

.
"
   
"
<EOS>
For

?
"

.
   
<EOS>

For

,

;

<EOS>

About

"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
But

DID

,
on

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

,
"

hands

his

,
"
it
's
a
sad
thing
,
my
dear
,
to
lose
so

when
we
had
set

upon

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
it
is
,
"
said
Mr
Sikes
.
 
<EOS>
"
Worse
luck
!
"
   
<EOS>
A
long

;
during
which
the
Jew
was
plunged
in
deep

,
with
his

perfectly

.
 
<EOS>
Sikes
eyed

from

.
 
<EOS>
Nancy
,
apparently

of
irritating

,

the
fire
,
as

to
all
that

.
   
<EOS>
"
Fagin
,
"

,

;
"
is
it
worth
fifty
shiners
<EOS>
extra
,
if

from

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said

Jew
,
as

.
   
<EOS>
"
Is

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,

,

"

<EOS>
"

,
"

<EOS>
Toby

,

.
 
<EOS>

;

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Which

<EOS>
"
Why
,
"

---
<EOS>
"
   
"
Yes
?
"

<EOS>
"
Umph
!
"
<EOS>

Bill

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

"
And

"

"

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
After

,

that

should

,

;

craftily

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

,

;

,

as

;
and

by

for

that
might

to
visit
him
<EOS>
:
it
being
understood
that
,
to
render

compact
in
this
respect
binding
,
any

by

on

to

confirmed
and

,

,
by

of
flash
Toby
Crackit
.
   
<EOS>
These
preliminaries
adjusted
,
Mr
Sikes
proceeded
to
drink

at
a
furious
rate
,
and
to
flourish
the
crowbar
in
an
alarming
manner
;
yelling
forth
,
at
the
same
time
,
most
unmusical
snatches
of
song
,
mingled
with
wild
execrations
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
in
a
fit
of
professional
enthusiasm
,
he
insisted
upon
producing
his
box
of
housebreaking
tools
:
 
which
he
had
no
sooner
stumbled
in
with
,
and
opened
for
the
purpose
of
explaining
the
nature
and
properties
of
the
various
implements
it
contained
,
and
the
peculiar
beauties
of
their
construction
,
than
he
fell
over
the
box
upon
the
floor
,
and
went
to
sleep
where
he
fell
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
-
night
,
Nancy
,
"
said
the
Jew
,
muffling
himself
up
as
before
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Their
eyes
met
,
and
the
Jew
scrutinised
her
,
narrowly
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
flinching
about
the
girl
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
as
true
and
earnest
in
the
matter
as
Toby
Crackit
himself
could
be
.
   
<EOS>
The
Jew
again
bade
her
good
-
night
,
and
,
bestowing
a
sly
kick
upon
the
prostrate
form
of
Mr
Sikes
while
her
back
was
turned
,
groped
downstairs
.
   
<EOS>
"
Always
the
way
!
<EOS>
"
muttered
the
Jew
to
himself
as
he
turned
homeward
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
worst
of
these
women
is
,
that
a
very
little
thing
serves
to
call
up
some
long
-
forgotten
feeling
;
and
,
the
best
of
them
is
,
that
it
never
lasts
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
 
<EOS>
The
man
against
the
child
,
for
a
bag
of
gold
!
"
   
<EOS>
Beguiling
the
time
with
these
pleasant
reflections
,
Mr
Fagin
wended
his
way
,
through
mud
and
mire
,
to
his
gloomy
abode
:
 
where
the
Dodger
was
sitting
up
,
impatiently
awaiting
his
return
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
Oliver
a
-
bed
?
 
<EOS>
I
want
to
speak
to
him
,
"
was
his
first
remark
as
they
descended
the
stairs
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hours
ago
,
"
replied
the
Dodger
,
throwing
open
a
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
he
is
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
boy
was
lying
,
fast
asleep
,
on
a
rude
bed
upon
the
floor
;
so
pale
with
anxiety
,
and
sadness
,
and
the
closeness
of
his
prison
,
that
he
looked
like
death
;
not
death
as
it
shows
in
shroud
and
coffin
,
but
in
the
guise
it
wears
when
life
has
just
departed
;
when
a
young
and
gentle
spirit
has
,
but
an
instant
,
fled
to
Heaven
,
and
the
gross
air
of
the
world
has
not
had
time
to
breathe
upon
the
changing
dust
it
hallowed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
now
,
"
said
the
Jew
,
turning
softly
away
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
To
-
morrow
.
"
    
Chapter
20
.
<EOS>
Wherein
Olver
is
delivered
over
to
Mr
William
Sikes
.
 
<EOS>
When
Oliver
awoke
in
the
morning
,
he
was
a
good
deal
surprised
to
find
that
a
new
pair
of
shoes
,
with
strong
thick
soles
,
had
been
placed
at
his
bedside
;
and
that
his
old
shoes
had
been
removed
.
<EOS>
At
first
,
he
was
pleased
with
the
discovery
:
hoping
that
it
might
be
the
forerunner
of
his
release
;
but
such
thoughts
were
quickly
dispelled
,
on
his
sitting
down
to
breakfast
along
with
the
Jew
,
who
told
him
,
in
a
tone
and
manner
which
increased
his
alarm
,
that
he
was
to
be
taken
to
the
residence
of
Bill
Sikes
that
night
.
   
<EOS>
"
To
---
to
---
stop
there
,
sir
?
"
asked
Oliver
,
anxiously
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
Not
to
stop
there
,
"
replied
the
Jew
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
should
n't
like
to
lose
you
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
be
afraid
,
Oliver
,
you
shall
come
back
to
us
again
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
 
<EOS>
We
wo
n't
be
so
cruel
as
to
send
you
away
,
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
no
,
no
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
old
man
,
who
was
stooping
over
the
fire
toasting
a
piece
of
bread
,
looked
round
as
he
bantered
Oliver
thus
;
and
chuckled
as
if
to
show
that
he
knew
he
would
still
be
very
glad
to
get
away
if
he
could
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
,
"
said
the
Jew
,
fixing
his
eyes
on
Oliver
,
"
you
want
to
know
what
you
're
going
to
Bill
's
for
---
-eh
,
my
dear
?
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver
coloured
,
involuntarily
,
to
find
that
the
old
thief
had
been
reading
his
thoughts
;
but
boldly
said
,
Yes
,
he
did
want
to
know
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
do
you
think
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Fagin
,
parrying
the
question
.
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
I
do
n't
know
,
sir
,
"
replied
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bah
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
Jew
,
turning
away
with
a
disappointed
countenance
from
a
close
perusal
of
the
boy
's
face
.
 
<EOS>
"
Wait
till
Bill
tells
you
,
then
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
Jew
seemed
much
vexed
by
Oliver
's
not
expressing
any
greater
curiosity
on
the
subject
;
but
the
truth
is
,
that
,
although
Oliver
felt
very
anxious
,
he
was
too
much
confused
by
the
earnest
cunning
of
Fagin
's
looks
,
and
his
own
speculations
,
to
make
any
further
inquiries
just
then
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
no
other
opportunity
:
 
for
the
Jew
remained
very
surly
and
silent
till
night
:
 
when
he
prepared
to
go
abroad
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
may
burn
a
candle
,
"
said
the
Jew
,
putting
one
upon
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
here
's
a
book
for
you
to
read
,
till
they
come
to
fetch
you
.
 
<EOS>
Good
-
night
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
-
night
!
"
replied
Oliver
,
softly
.
   
<EOS>
The
Jew
walked
to
the
door
:
looking
over
his
shoulder
at
the
boy
as
he
went
.
 
<EOS>
Suddenly
stopping
,
he
called
him
by
his
name
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
looked
up
;
the
Jew
,
pointing
to
the
candle
,
motioned
him
to
light
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
did
so
;
and
,
as
he
placed
the
candlestick
upon
the
table
,
saw
that
the
Jew
was
gazing
fixedly
at
him
,
with
lowering
and
contracted
brows
,
from
the
dark
end
of
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
"
Take
heed
,
Oliver
!
<EOS>
take
heed
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
old
man
,
shaking
his
right
hand
before
him
in
a
warning
manner
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
's
a
rough
man
,
and
thinks
nothing
of
blood
when
his
own
is
up
.
<EOS>
Whatever
falls
out
,
say
nothing
;
and
do
what
he
bids
you
.
 
<EOS>
Mind
!
"
 
<EOS>
Placing
a
strong
emphasis
on
the
last
word
,
he
suffered
his
features
gradually
to
resolve
themselves
into
a
ghastly
grin
,
and
,
nodding
his
head
,
left
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
leaned
his
head
upon
his
hand
when
the
old
man
disappeared
,
and
pondered
,
with
a
trembling
heart
,
on
the
words
he
had
just
heard
.
 
<EOS>
The
more
he
thought
of
the
Jew
's
admonition
,
the
more
he
was
at
a
loss
to
divine
its
real
purpose
and
meaning
.
   
<EOS>
He
could
think
of
no
bad
object
to
be
attained
by
sending
him
to
Sikes
,
which
would
not
be
equally
well
answered
by
his
remaining
with
Fagin
;
and
after
meditating
for
a
long
time
,
concluded
that
he
had
been
selected
to
perform
some
ordinary
menial
offices
for
the
housebreaker
,
until
another
boy
,
better
suited
for
his
purpose
could
be
engaged
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
too
well
accustomed
to
suffering
,
and
had
suffered
too
much
where
he
was
,
to
bewail
the
prospect
of
change
very
severely
.
 
<EOS>
He
remained
lost
in
thought
for
some
minutes
;
and
then
,
with
a
heavy
sigh
,
snuffed
the
candle
,
and
,
taking
up
the
book
which
the
Jew
had
left
with
him
,
began
to
read
.
   
<EOS>
He
turned
over
the
leaves
.
 
<EOS>
Carelessly
at
first
;
but
,
lighting
on
a
passage
which
attracted
his
attention
,
he
soon
became
intent
upon
the
volume
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
history
of
the
lives
and
trials
of
great
criminals
;
and
the
pages
were
soiled
and
thumbed
with
use
.
<EOS>
Here
,
he
read
of
dreadful
crimes
that
made
the
blood
run
cold
;
of
secret
murders
that
had
been
committed
by
the
lonely
wayside
;
of
bodies
hidden
from
the
eye
of
man
in
deep
pits
and
wells
:
which
would
not
keep
them
down
,
deep
as
they
were
,
but
had
yielded
them
up
at
last
,
after
many
years
,
and
so
maddened
the
murderers
with
the
sight
,
that
in
their
horror
they
had
confessed
their
guilt
,
and
yelled
for
the
gibbet
to
end
their
agony
.
 
<EOS>
Here
,
too
,
he
read
of
men
who
,
lying
in
their
beds
at
dead
of
night
,
had
been
tempted
(
so
they
said
)
and
led
on
,
by
their
own
bad
thoughts
,
to
such
dreadful
bloodshed
as
it
made
the
flesh
creep
,
and
the
limbs
quail
,
to
think
of
.
 
<EOS>
The
terrible
descriptions
were
so
real
and
vivid
,
that
the
sallow
pages
seemed
to
turn
red
with
gore
;
and
the
words
upon
them
,
to
be
sounded
in
his
ears
,
as
if
they
were
whispered
,
in
hollow
murmers
,
by
the
spirits
of
the
dead
.
   
<EOS>
In
a
paroxysm
of
fear
,
the
boy
closed
the
book
,
and
thrust
it
from
him
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
falling
upon
his
knees
,
he
prayed
Heaven
to
spare
him
from
such
deeds
;
and
rather
to
will
that
he
should
die
at
once
,
than
be
reserved
for
crimes
,
so
fearful
and
appaling
.
<EOS>
By
degrees
,
he
grew
more
calm
,
and
besought
,
in
a
low
and
broken
voice
,
that
he
might
be
rescued
from
his
present
dangers
;
and
that
if
any
aid
were
to
be
raised
up
for
a
poor
outcast
boy
who
had
never
known
the
love
of
friends
or
kindred
,
it
might
come
to
him
now
,
when
,
desolate
and
deserted
,
he
stood
alone
in
the
midst
of
wickedness
and
guilt
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
concluded
his
prayer
,
but
still
remained
with
his
head
buried
in
his
hands
,
when
a
rustling
noise
aroused
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
that
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
starting
up
,
and
catching
sight
of
a
figure
standing
by
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
's
there
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Me
.
 
<EOS>
Only
me
,
"
replied
a
tremulous
voice
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
raised
the
candle
above
his
head
:
and
looked
towards
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
Nancy
.
   
<EOS>
"
Put
down
the
light
,
"
said
the
girl
,
turning
away
her
head
.
<EOS>
"
It
hurts
my
eyes
.
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver
saw
that
she
was
very
pale
,
and
gently
inquired
if
she
were
ill
.
 
<EOS>
The
girl
threw
herself
into
a
chair
,
with
her
back
towards
him
:
 
and
wrung
her
hands
;
but
made
no
reply
.
   
<EOS>
"
God
forgive
me
!
"
<EOS>
she
cried
after
a
while
,
"
I
never
thought
of
this
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Has
anything
happened
?
"
asked
Oliver
.
 
<EOS>
"
Can
I
help
you
?
 
<EOS>
I
will
if
I
can
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
,
indeed
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
rocked
herself
to
and
fro
;
caught
her
throat
;
and
,
uttering
a
gurgling
sound
,
gasped
for
breath
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nancy
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Oliver
,
"
<EOS>
What
is
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
girl
beat
her
hands
upon
her
knees
,
and
her
feet
upon
the
ground
;
and
,
suddenly
stopping
,
drew
her
shawl
close
round
her
:
and
shivered
with
cold
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
stirred
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
Drawing
her
chair
close
to
it
,
she
sat
there
,
for
a
little
time
,
without
speaking
;
but
at
length
she
raised
her
head
,
and
looked
round
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
what
comes
over
me
sometimes
,
"
said
she
,
affecting
to
busy
herself
in
arranging
her
dress
;
"
it
's
this
damp
dirty
room
,
I
think
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
Nolly
,
dear
,
are
you
ready
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Am
I
to
go
with
you
?
"
asked
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
come
from
Bill
,
"
replied
the
girl
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
to
go
with
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
for
?
"
asked
Oliver
,
recoiling
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
for
?
"
echoed
the
girl
,
raising
her
eyes
,
and
averting
them
again
,
the
moment
they
encountered
the
boy
's
face
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
 
For
no
harm
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
believe
it
,
"
said
Oliver
:
 
who
had
watched
her
closely
.
   
<EOS>
"
Have
it
your
own
way
,
"
rejoined
the
girl
,
affecting
to
laugh
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
For
no
good
,
then
.
"
   
Oliver
could
see
that
he
had
some
power
over
the
girl
's
better
feelings
,
and
,
for
an
instant
,
thought
of
appealing
to
her
compassion
for
his
helpless
state
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
then
,
the
thought
darted
across
his
mind
that
it
was
barely
eleven
o'clock
;
and
that
many
people
were
still
in
the
streets
:
 
of
whom
surely
some
might
be
found
to
give
credence
to
his
tale
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
reflection
occured
to
him
,
he
stepped
forward
:
 
and
said
,
somewhat
hastily
,
that
he
was
ready
.
   
<EOS>
Neither
his
brief
consideration
,
nor
its
purport
,
was
lost
on
his
companion
.
 
<EOS>
She
eyed
him
narrowly
,
while
he
spoke
;
and
cast
upon
him
a
look
of
intelligence
which
sufficiently
showed
that
she
guessed
what
had
been
passing
in
his
thoughts
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
"
said
the
girl
,
stooping
over
him
,
and
pointing
to
the
door
as
she
looked
cautiously
round
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
ca
n't
help
yourself
.
<EOS>
I
have
tried
hard
for
you
,
but
all
to
no
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
hedged
round
and
round
.
 
<EOS>
If
ever
you
are
to
get
loose
from
here
,
this
is
not
the
time
.
"
   
<EOS>
Struck
by
the
energy
of
her
manner
,
Oliver
looked
up
in
her
face
with
great
surprise
.
 
<EOS>
She
seemed
to
speak
the
truth
;
her
countenance
was
white
and
agitated
;
and
she
trembled
with
very
earnestness
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
saved
you
from
being
ill
-
used
once
,
and
I
will
again
,
and
I
do
now
,
"
continued
the
girl
aloud
;
"
for
those
who
would
have
fetched
you
,
if
I
had
not
,
would
have
been
far
more
rough
than
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
promised
for
your
being
quiet
and
silent
;
if
you
are
not
,
you
will
only
do
harm
to
yourself
and
me
too
,
and
perhaps
be
my
death
.
 
<EOS>
See
here
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
borne
all
this
for
you
already
,
as
true
as
God
sees
me
show
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
pointed
,
hastily
,
to
some
livid
bruises
on
her
neck
and
arms
;
and
continued
,
with
great
rapidity
:
   
<EOS>
"
Remember
this
!
 
<EOS>
And
do
n't
let
me
suffer
more
for
you
,
just
now
.
<EOS>
If
I
could
help
you
,
I
would
;
but
I
have
not
the
power
.
 
<EOS>
They
do
n't
mean
to
harm
you
;
whatever
they
make
you
do
,
is
no
fault
of
yours
.
 
<EOS>
Hush
!
 
<EOS>
Every
word
from
you
is
a
blow
for
me
.
 
<EOS>
Give
me
your
hand
.
 
<EOS>
Make
haste
!
 
<EOS>
Your
hand
!
   
<EOS>
She
caught
the
hand
which
Oliver
instinctively
placed
in
hers
,
and
,
blowing
out
the
light
,
drew
him
after
her
up
the
stairs
.
<EOS>
The
door
was
opened
,
quickly
,
by
some
one
shrouded
in
the
darkness
,
and
was
as
quickly
closed
,
when
they
had
passed
out
.
 
<EOS>
A
hackney
-
cabriolet
was
in
waiting
;
with
the
same
vehemence
which
she
had
exhibited
in
addressing
Oliver
,
the
girl
pulled
him
in
with
her
,
and
drew
the
curtains
close
.
 
<EOS>
The
driver
wanted
no
directions
,
but
lashed
his
horse
into
full
speed
,
without
the
delay
of
an
instant
.
   
<EOS>
The
girl
still
held
Oliver
fast
by
the
hand
,
and
continued
to
pour
into
his
ear
,
the
warnings
and
assurances
she
had
already
imparted
.
 
<EOS>
All
was
so
quick
and
hurried
,
that
he
had
scarcely
time
to
recollect
where
he
was
,
or
how
he
came
there
,
when
to
carriage
stopped
at
the
house
to
which
the
Jew
's
steps
had
been
directed
on
the
previous
evening
.
   
<EOS>
For
one
brief
moment
,
Oliver
cast
a
hurried
glance
along
the
empty
street
,
and
a
cry
for
help
hung
upon
his
lips
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
girl
's
voice
was
in
his
ear
,
beseeching
him
in
such
tones
of
agony
to
remember
her
,
that
he
had
not
the
heart
to
utter
it
.
<EOS>
While
he
hesitated
,
the
opportunity
was
gone
;
he
was
already
in
the
house
,
and
the
door
was
shut
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
This
way
,
"
said
the
girl
,
releasing
her
hold
for
the
first
time
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bill
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hallo
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Sikes
:
appearing
at
the
head
of
the
stairs
,
with
a
candle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
That
's
the
time
of
day
.
 
<EOS>
Come
on
!
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
a
very
strong
expression
of
approbation
,
an
uncommonly
hearty
welcome
,
from
a
person
of
Mr
Sikes
'
temperament
.
 
<EOS>
Nancy
,
appearing
much
gratified
thereby
,
saluted
him
cordially
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bull's
-
eye
's
gone
home
with
Tom
,
"
observed
Sikes
,
as
he
lighted
them
up
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
'd
have
been
in
the
way
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
right
,
"
rejoined
Nancy
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
you
've
got
the
kid
,
"
said
Sikes
when
they
had
all
reached
the
room
:
closing
the
door
as
he
spoke
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
here
he
is
,
"
replied
Nancy
.
   
<EOS>
"
Did
he
come
quiet
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Sikes
.
   
<EOS>
"
Like
a
lamb
,
"
rejoined
Nancy
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
glad
to
hear
it
,
"
said
Sikes
,
looking
grimly
at
Oliver
;
"
for
the
sake
of
his
young
carcase
:
 
as
would
otherways
have
suffered
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
Come
here
,
young
'
un
;
and
let
me
read
you
a
lectur
'
,
which
is
as
well
got
over
at
once
.
"
   
<EOS>
Thus
addressing
his
new
pupil
,
Mr
Sikes
pulled
off
Oliver
's
cap
and
threw
it
into
a
corner
;
and
then
,
taking
him
by
the
shoulder
,
sat
himself
down
by
the
table
,
and
stood
the
boy
in
front
of
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Now
,
first
:
 
<EOS>
do
you
know
wot
<EOS>
this
is
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Sikes
,
taking
up
a
pocket
-
pistol
which
lay
on
the
table
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
replied
in
the
affirmative
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
then
,
look
here
,
"
continued
Sikes
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
powder
;
that
'
ere
's
a
bullet
;
and
this
is
a
little
bit
of
a
old
hat
for
waddin
'
.
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver
murmured
his
comprehension
of
the
different
bodies
referred
to
;
and
Mr
Sikes
proceeded
to
load
the
pistol
,
with
great
nicety
and
deliberation
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
it
's
loaded
,
"
said
Mr
Sikes
,
when
he
had
finished
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
I
see
it
is
,
sir
,
"
replied
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
"
said
the
robber
,
grasping
Oliver
's
wrist
,
and
putting
the
barrel
so
close
to
his
temple
that
they
touched
;
at
which
moment
the
boy
could
not
repress
a
start
;
"
if
you
speak
a
word
when
you
're
out
o
'
doors
with
me
,
except
when
I
speak
to
you
,
that
loading
will
be
in
your
head
without
notice
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
if
you
DO
make
up
your
mind
to
speak
without
leave
,
say
your
prayers
first
.
"
   
<EOS>
Having
bestowed
a
scowl
upon
the
object
of
this
warning
,
to
increase
its
effect
,
Mr
Sikes
continued
.
   
<EOS>
"
As
near
as
I
know
,
there
is
n't
anybody
as
would
be
asking
very
partickler
arter
<EOS>
you
,
if
you
WAS
disposed
of
;
so
I
need
n't
take
this
devil
-
and
-
all
of
trouble
to
explain
matters
to
you
,
if
it
warn't
<EOS>
for
you
own
good
.
 
<EOS>
D'ye
hear
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
short
and
the
long
of
what
you
mean
,
"
said
Nancy
:
 
speaking
very
emphatically
,
and
slightly
frowning
at
Oliver
as
if
to
bespeak
his
serious
attention
to
her
words
:
 
"
is
,
that
if
you
're
crossed
by
him
in
this
job
you
have
on
hand
,
you
'll
prevent
his
ever
telling
tales
afterwards
,
by
shooting
him
through
the
head
,
and
will
take
your
chance
of
swinging
for
it
,
as
you
do
for
a
great
many
other
things
in
the
way
of
business
,
every
month
of
your
life
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
it
!
"
<EOS>
observed
Mr
Sikes
,
approvingly
;
"
women
can
always
put
things
in
fewest
words
.
<EOS>
---
  
<EOS>
Except
when
it
's
blowing
up
;
and
then
they
lengthens
it
out
.
 
<EOS>
And
now
that
he
's
thoroughly
up
to
it
,
let
's
have
some
supper
,
and
get
a
snooze
before
starting
.
"
   
<EOS>
In
pursuance
of
this
request
,
Nancy
quickly
laid
the
cloth
;
disappearing
for
a
few
minutes
,
she
presently
returned
with
a
pot
of
porter
and
a
dish
of
sheep
's
heads
:
which
gave
occasion
to
several
pleasant
witticisms
on
the
part
of
Mr
Sikes
,
founded
upon
the
singular
coincidence
of
"
jemmies
"
being
a
can
name
,
common
to
them
,
and
also
to
an
ingenious
implement
much
used
in
his
profession
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
,
the
worthy
gentleman
,
stimulated
perhaps
by
the
immediate
prospect
of
being
on
active
service
,
was
in
great
spirits
and
good
humour
;
in
proof
whereof
,
it
may
be
here
remarked
,
that
he
humorously
drank
all
the
beer
at
a
draught
,
and
did
not
utter
,
on
a
rough
calculation
,
more
than
four
-
score
oaths
during
the
whole
progress
of
the
meal
.
   
<EOS>
Supper
being
ended
---
it
may
be
easily
conceived
that
Oliver
had
no
great
appetite
for
it
---
Mr
Sikes
disposed
of
a
couple
of
glasses
of
spirits
and
water
,
and
threw
himself
on
the
bed
;
ordering
Nancy
,
with
many
imprecations
in
case
of
failure
,
to
call
him
at
five
precisely
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
stretched
himself
in
his
clothes
,
by
command
of
the
same
authority
,
on
a
mattress
upon
the
floor
;
and
the
girl
,
mending
the
fire
,
sat
before
it
,
in
readiness
to
rouse
them
at
the
appointed
time
.
   
<EOS>
For
a
long
time
Oliver
lay
awake
,
thinking
it
not
impossible
that
Nancy
might
seek
that
opportunity
of
whispering
some
further
advice
;
but
the
girl
sat
brooding
over
the
fire
,
without
moving
,
save
now
and
then
to
trim
the
light
.
 
<EOS>
Weary
with
watching
and
anxiety
,
he
at
length
fell
asleep
.
   
<EOS>
When
he
awoke
,
the
table
was
covered
with
tea
-
things
,
and
Sikes
was
thrusting
various
articles
into
the
pockets
of
his
great
-
coat
,
which
hung
over
the
back
of
a
chair
.
 
<EOS>
Nancy
was
busily
engaged
in
preparing
breakfast
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
yet
daylight
;
for
the
candle
was
still
burning
,
and
it
was
quite
dark
outside
.
<EOS>
A
sharp
rain
,
too
,
was
beating
against
the
window
-
panes
;
and
the
sky
looked
black
and
cloudy
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
then
!
"
growled
Sikes
,
as
Oliver
started
up
;
"
half
-
past
five
!
 
<EOS>
Look
sharp
,
or
<EOS>
you
'll
get
no
breakfast
;
for
it
's
late
as
it
is
.
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver
was
not
long
in
making
his
toilet
;
having
taken
some
breakfast
,
he
replied
to
a
surly
inquiry
from
Sikes
,
by
saying
that
he
was
quite
ready
.
   
<EOS>
Nancy
,
scarcely
looking
at
the
boy
,
threw
him
a
handkerchief
to
tie
round
his
throat
;
Sikes
gave
him
a
large
rough
cape
to
button
over
his
shoulders
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
attired
,
he
gave
his
hand
to
the
robber
,
who
,
merely
pausing
to
show
him
with
a
menacing
gesture
that
he
had
that
same
pistol
in
a
side
-
pocket
of
his
great
-
coat
,
clasped
it
firmly
in
his
,
and
,
exchanging
a
farewell
with
Nancy
,
led
him
away
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
turned
,
for
an
instant
,
when
they
reached
the
door
,
in
the
hope
of
meeting
a
look
from
the
girl
.
 
<EOS>
But
she
had
resumed
her
old
seat
in
front
of
the
fire
,
and
sat
,
perfectly
motionless
before
it
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
21
.
<EOS>
The
expedition
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
cheerless
morning
when
they
got
into
the
street
;
blowing
and
raining
hard
;
and
the
clouds
looking
dull
and
stormy
.
 
<EOS>
The
night
had
been
very
wet
:
large
pools
of
water
had
collected
in
the
road
:
and
the
kennels
were
overflowing
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
faint
glimmering
of
the
coming
day
in
the
sky
;
but
it
rather
aggrevated
than
relieved
the
gloom
of
the
scene
:
 
the
sombre
light
only
serving
to
pale
that
which
<EOS>
the
street
lamps
afforded
,
without
shedding
any
warmer
or
brighter
tints
upon
the
wet
house
-
tops
,
and
dreary
streets
.
 
<EOS>
There
appeared
to
be
nobody
stirring
in
that
quarter
of
the
town
;
the
windows
of
the
houses
were
all
closely
shut
;
and
the
streets
through
which
they
passed
,
were
noiseless
and
empty
.
   
<EOS>
By
the
time
they
had
turned
into
the
Bethnal
Green
Road
,
the
day
had
fairly
begun
to
break
.
 
<EOS>
Many
of
the
lamps
were
already
extinguished
;
a
few
country
waggons
were
slowly
toiling
on
,
towards
London
;
now
and
then
,
a
stage
-
coach
,
covered
with
mud
,
rattled
briskly
by
:
the
driver
bestowing
,
as
he
passed
,
and
admonitory
lash
upon
the
heavy
waggoner
who
,
by
keeping
on
the
wrong
side
of
the
road
,
had
endangered
his
arriving
at
the
office
,
a
quarter
of
a
minute
after
his
time
.
 
<EOS>
The
public
-
houses
,
with
gas
-
lights
burning
inside
,
were
already
open
.
 
<EOS>
By
degrees
,
other
shops
began
to
be
unclosed
,
and
a
few
scattered
people
were
met
with
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
came
straggling
groups
of
labourers
going
to
their
work
;
then
,
men
and
women
with
fish
-
baskets
on
their
heads
;
donkey
-
carts
laden
with
vegetables
;
chaise
-
carts
filled
with
live
-
stock
or
whole
carcasses
of
meat
;
milk
-
women
with
pails
;
an
unbroken
concourse
of
people
,
trudging
out
with
various
supplies
to
the
eastern
suburbs
of
the
town
.
 
<EOS>
As
they
approached
the
City
,
the
noise
and
traffic
gradually
increased
;
when
they
threaded
the
streets
between
Shoreditch
and
Smithfield
,
it
had
swelled
into
a
roar
of
sound
and
bustle
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
as
light
as
it
was
likely
to
be
,
till
night
came
on
again
,
and
the
busy
morning
of
half
<EOS>
the
London
population
had
begun
.
   
<EOS>
Turning
down
Sun
Street
and
Crown
Street
,
and
crossing
Finsbury
square
,
Mr
Sikes
struck
,
by
way
of
Chiswell
Street
,
into
Barbican
:
thence
into
Long
Lane
,
and
so
into
Smithfield
;
from
which
latter
place
arose
a
tumult
of
discordant
sounds
that
filled
Oliver
Twist
with
amazement
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
market
-
morning
.
 
<EOS>
The
ground
was
covered
,
nearly
ankle
-
deep
,
with
filth
and
mire
;
a
thick
steam
,
perpetually
rising
from
the
reeking
bodies
of
the
cattle
,
and
mingling
with
the
fog
,
which
seemd
to
rest
upon
the
chimney
-
tops
,
hung
heavily
above
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
pens
in
the
centre
of
the
large
area
,
and
as
many
temporary
pens
as
could
be
crowded
into
the
vacant
space
,
were
filled
with
sheep
;
tied
up
to
posts
by
the
gutter
side
were
long
lines
of
beasts
and
oxen
,
three
or
four
deep
.
 
<EOS>
Countrymen
,
butchers
,
drovers
,
hawkers
,
boys
,
thieves
,
idlers
,
and
vagabonds
of
every
low
grade
,
were
mingled
together
in
a
mass
;
the
whistling
of
drovers
,
the
barking
dogs
,
the
bellowing
and
plunging
of
the
oxen
,
the
bleating
of
sheep
,
the
grunting
and
squeaking
of
pigs
,
the
cries
of
hawkers
,
the
shouts
,
oaths
,
and
quarrelling
on
all
sides
;
the
ringing
of
bells
and
roar
of
voices
,
that
issued
from
every
public
-
house
;
the
crowding
,
pushing
,
driving
,
beating
,
whooping
and
yelling
;
the
hideous
and
discordant
dim
that
resounded
from
every
corner
of
the
market
;
and
the
unwashed
,
unshaven
,
squalid
,
and
dirty
figues
constantly
running
to
and
fro
,
and
bursting
in
and
out
of
the
throng
;
rendered
it
a
stunning
and
bewildering
scene
,
which
quite
confounded
the
senses
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Sikes
,
dragging
Oliver
after
him
,
elbowed
his
way
through
the
thickest
of
the
crowd
,
and
bestowed
very
little
attention
on
the
numerous
sights
and
sounds
,
which
so
astonished
the
boy
.
 
<EOS>
He
nodded
,
twice
or
thrice
,
to
a
passing
friend
;
and
,
resisting
as
many
invitations
to
take
a
morning
dram
,
pressed
steadily
onward
,
until
they
were
clear
of
the
turmoil
,
and
had
made
their
way
through
Hosier
Lane
into
Holborn
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
young
'
un
!
"
said
Sikes
,
looking
up
at
the
clock
of
St
Andrew
's
Church
,
"
hard
upon
seven
!
<EOS>
you
must
step
out
.
 
<EOS>
Come
,
do
n't
lag
behind
already
,
Lazy
-
legs
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Sikes
accompanied
this
speech
with
a
jerk
at
his
little
companion
's
wrist
;
Oliver
,
quickening
his
pace
into
a
kind
of
trot
between
a
fast
walk
and
a
run
,
kept
up
with
the
rapid
strides
of
the
house
-
breaker
as
well
as
he
could
.
   
<EOS>
They
held
their
course
at
this
rate
,
until
they
had
passed
Hyde
Park
corner
,
and
were
on
their
way
to
Kensington
:
 
when
Sikes
relaxed
his
pace
,
until
an
empty
cart
which
was
at
some
little
distance
behind
,
came
up
.
 
<EOS>
Seeing
"
Hounslow
"
written
on
it
<EOS>
,
he
asked
the
driver
with
as
much
civility
as
he
could
assume
,
if
he
would
give
them
a
lift
as
far
as
Isleworth
.
   
<EOS>
"
Jump
up
,
"
said
the
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
that
your
boy
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
he
's
my
boy
,
"
replied
Sikes
,
looking
hard
at
Oliver
,
and
putting
his
hand
abstractedly
into
the
pocket
where
the
pistol
was
.
   
<EOS>
"
Your
father
walks
rather
too
quick
for
you
,
do
n't
he
,
my
man
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
the
driver
:
seeing
that
Oliver
was
out
of
breath
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a
bit
of
it
,
"
replied
Sikes
,
interposing
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
's
used
to
it
.
   
<EOS>
Here
,
take
hold
of
my
hand
,
Ned
.
 
<EOS>
In
with
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
Thus
addressing
Oliver
,
he
helped
him
into
the
cart
;
and
the
driver
,
pointing
to
a
heap
of
sacks
,
told
him
to
lie
down
there
,
and
rest
himself
.
   
<EOS>
As
they
passed
the
different
mile
-
stones
,
Oliver
wondered
,
more
and
more
,
where
his
companion
meant
to
take
him
.
 
<EOS>
Kensington
,
Hammersmith
,
Chiswick
,
Kew
Bridge
,
Brentford
,
were
all
passed
;
and
yet
they
went
on
as
steadily
as
if
they
had
only
just
begun
their
journey
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
they
came
to
a
public
-
house
called
the
Coach
and
Horses
;
a
little
way
beyond
which
,
another
road
appeared
to
run
off
.
 
<EOS>
And
here
,
the
cart
stopped
.
   
<EOS>
Sikes
dismounted
with
great
precipitation
,
holding
Oliver
by
the
hand
all
the
while
;
and
lifting
him
down
directly
,
bestowed
a
furious
look
upon
him
,
and
rapped
the
side
-
pocket
with
his
fist
,
in
a
significant
manner
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
-
bye
,
boy
,
"
said
the
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
sulky
,
"
replied
Sikes
,
giving
him
a
shake
;
"
he
's
sulky
.
 
<EOS>
A
young
dog
!
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
mind
him
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
I
!
"
rejoined
the
other
,
getting
into
his
cart
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
fine
day
,
after
all
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
he
drove
away
.
   
<EOS>
Sikes
waited
until
he
had
fairly
gone
;
and
then
,
telling
Oliver
he
might
look
about
him
if
he
wanted
,
once
again
led
him
onward
on
his
journey
.
   
<EOS>
They
turned
round
to
the
left
,
a
short
way
past
the
public
-
house
;
and
then
,
taking
a
right
-
hand
road
,
walked
on
for
a
long
time
:
passing
many
large
gardens
and
gentlemen
's
houses
on
both
sides
of
the
way
,
and
stopping
for
nothing
but
a
little
beer
,
until
they
reached
a
town
.
 
<EOS>
Here
against
the
wall
of
a
house
,
Oliver
saw
written
up
in
pretty
large
letters
,
"
Hampton
.
"
 
<EOS>
They
lingered
about
,
in
the
fields
,
for
some
hours
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
they
came
back
into
the
town
;
and
,
turning
into
an
old
public
-
house
with
a
defaced
sign
-
board
,
ordered
some
dinner
by
the
kitchen
fire
.
   
<EOS>
The
kitchen
was
an
old
,
low
-
roofed
room
;
with
a
great
beam
across
the
middle
of
the
ceiling
,
and
benches
,
with
high
backs
to
them
,
by
the
fire
;
on
which
were
seated
several
rough
men
in
smock
-
frocks
,
drinking
and
smoking
.
 
<EOS>
They
took
no
notice
of
Oliver
;
and
very
little
of
Sikes
;
and
,
as
Sikes
took
very
little
notice
of
the
,
he
and
his
young
comrade
sat
in
a
corner
by
themselves
,
without
being
much
troubled
by
their
company
.
   
<EOS>
They
had
some
cold
meat
for
dinner
,
and
sat
so
long
after
it
,
while
Mr
Sikes
indulged
himself
with
three
or
four
pipes
,
that
Oliver
began
to
feel
quite
certain
they
were
not
going
any
further
.
 
<EOS>
Being
much
tired
with
the
walk
,
and
getting
up
so
early
,
he
dozed
a
little
at
first
;
then
,
quite
overpowered
by
fatigue
and
the
fumes
of
the
tobacco
,
fell
asleep
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
quite
dark
when
he
was
awakened
by
a
push
from
Sikes
.
<EOS>
Rousing
himself
sufficiently
to
sit
up
and
look
about
him
,
he
found
that
worthy
in
close
fellowship
and
communication
with
a
labouring
man
,
over
a
pint
of
ale
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
,
you
're
going
on
to
Lower
Halliford
,
are
you
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Sikes
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
am
,
"
replied
the
man
,
who
seemed
a
little
the
worse
---
or
better
,
as
the
case
might
be
---
for
drinking
;
"
and
not
slow
about
it
neither
.
 
<EOS>
My
horse
has
n't
got
a
load
behind
him
going
back
,
as
he
had
coming
up
in
the
mornin
'
;
and
he
wo
n't
be
long
a
-
doing
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
Here
's
luck
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
Ecod
!
<EOS>
he
's
a
good
'
un
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Could
you
give
my
boy
and
me
a
lift
as
far
as
there
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
Sikes
,
pushing
the
ale
towards
his
new
friend
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
're
going
directly
,
I
can
,
"
replied
the
man
,
looking
out
of
the
pot
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
going
to
Halliford
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Going
on
to
Shepperton
,
"
replied
Sikes
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
your
man
,
as
far
as
I
go
,
"
replied
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
all
paid
,
Becky
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
the
other
gentleman
's
paid
,
"
replied
the
girl
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
!
"
said
the
man
,
with
tipsy
gravity
;
"
that
wo
n't
do
,
you
know
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
not
?
"
rejoined
Sikes
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
-
going
to
accommodate
us
,
and
wot
's
to
prevent
my
standing
treat
for
a
pint
or
so
,
in
return
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
stranger
reflected
upon
this
argument
,
with
a
very
profound
face
;
having
done
so
,
he
seized
Sikes
by
the
hand
:
 
and
declared
he
was
a
real
good
fellow
.
 
<EOS>
To
which
Mr
Sikes
replied
,
he
was
joking
;
as
,
if
he
had
been
sober
,
there
would
have
been
strong
reason
to
suppose
he
was
.
   
<EOS>
After
the
exchange
of
a
few
more
compliments
,
they
bade
the
company
good
-
night
,
and
went
out
;
the
girl
gathering
up
the
pots
and
glasses
as
they
did
so
,
and
lounging
out
to
the
door
,
with
her
hands
full
,
to
see
the
party
start
.
   
<EOS>
The
horse
,
whose
health
had
been
drunk
in
his
absence
,
was
standing
outside
:
 
<EOS>
ready
harnessed
to
the
cart
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
and
Sikes
got
in
without
any
further
ceremony
;
and
the
man
to
whom
he
belonged
,
having
lingered
for
a
minute
or
two
"
to
bear
him
up
,
"
and
to
defy
the
hostler
and
the
world
to
produce
his
equal
,
mounted
also
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
the
hostler
was
told
to
give
the
horse
his
head
;
and
,
his
head
being
given
him
,
he
made
a
very
unpleasant
use
of
it
:
 
tossing
it
into
the
air
with
great
disdain
,
and
running
into
the
parlour
windows
over
the
way
;
after
performing
those
feats
,
and
supporting
himself
for
a
short
time
on
his
hind
-
legs
,
he
started
off
at
great
speed
,
and
rattled
out
of
the
town
right
gallantly
.
   
<EOS>
The
night
was
very
dark
.
 
<EOS>
A
damp
mist
rose
from
the
river
,
and
the
marshy
ground
about
;
and
spread
itself
over
the
dreary
fields
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
piercing
cold
,
too
;
all
was
gloomy
and
black
.
<EOS>
Not
a
word
was
spoken
;
for
the
driver
had
grown
sleepy
;
and
Sikes
was
in
no
mood
to
lead
him
into
conversation
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
sat
huddled
together
,
in
a
corner
of
the
cart
;
bewildered
with
alarm
and
apprehension
;
and
figuring
strange
objects
in
the
gaunt
trees
,
whose
branches
waved
grimly
to
and
fro
,
as
if
in
some
fantastic
joy
at
the
desolation
of
the
scene
.
   
<EOS>
As
they
passed
Sunbury
Church
,
the
clock
struck
seven
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
light
in
the
ferry
-
house
window
opposite
:
 
which
streamed
across
the
road
,
and
threw
into
more
sombre
shadow
a
dark
yew
-
tree
with
graves
beneath
it
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
dull
sound
of
falling
water
not
far
off
;
and
the
leaves
of
the
old
tree
stirred
gently
in
the
night
wind
.
 
<EOS>
It
seemed
like
quiet
music
for
the
repose
of
the
dead
.
   
<EOS>
Sunbury
was
passed
through
,
and
they
came
again
into
the
lonely
road
.
 
<EOS>
Two
or
three
miles
more
,
and
the
cart
stopped
.
 
<EOS>
Sikes
alighted
,
took
Oliver
by
the
hand
,
and
they
once
again
walked
on
.
   
<EOS>
They
turned
into
no
house
at
Shepperton
,
as
the
weary
boy
had
expected
;
but
still
kept
walking
on
,
in
mud
and
darkness
,
through
gloomy
lanes
and
over
cold
open
wastes
,
until
they
came
within
sight
of
the
lights
of
a
town
at
no
great
distance
.
 
<EOS>
On
looking
intently
forward
,
Oliver
saw
that
the
water
was
just
below
them
,
and
that
they
were
coming
to
the
foot
of
a
bridge
.
   
<EOS>
Sikes
kept
straight
on
,
until
they
were
close
upon
the
bridge
;
then
turned
suddenly
down
a
bank
upon
the
left
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
water
!
<EOS>
"
thought
Oliver
,
turning
sick
with
fear
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
has
brought
me
to
this
lonely
place
to
murder
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
was
about
to
throw
himself
on
the
ground
,
and
make
one
struggle
for
his
young
life
,
when
he
saw
that
they
stood
before
a
solitary
house
:
all
ruinous
and
decayed
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
window
on
each
side
of
the
dilapidated
entrance
;
and
one
story
above
;
but
no
light
was
visible
.
 
<EOS>
The
house
was
dark
,
dismantled
:
and
the
all
appearance
,
uninhabited
.
   
<EOS>
Sikes
,
with
Oliver
's
hand
still
in
his
,
softly
approached
the
low
porch
,
and
raised
the
latch
.
 
<EOS>
The
door
yielded
to
the
pressure
,
and
they
passed
in
together
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
22
.
<EOS>
The
burglary
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hallo
!
"
cried
a
loud
,
hoarse
voice
,
as
soon
as
they
set
foot
in
the
passage
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
make
such
a
row
,
"
said
Sikes
,
bolting
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
Show
a
glim
,
Toby
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Aha
!
<EOS>
my
pal
!
"
cried
the
same
voice
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
glim
,
Barney
,
a
glim
!
<EOS>
Show
the
gentleman
in
,
Barney
;
wake
up
first
,
if
convenient
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
speaker
appeared
to
throw
a
boot

,
or
some
such
article
,
at
the
person
he
addressed
,
to
rouse

from
his

:
 
for
the
noise
of
a
wooden
body
,
falling
violently
,
was
heard
;
and
then
an
indistinct

,
as
of
a
man
between

and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
hear
?
"
cried

same
voice
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
's
Bill
Sikes
in
the
passage
with
nobody
to
do
the
civil
to
him
;
and
you
sleeping
there
,
as
if
you
took
laudanum
with
your

,
and
nothing
stronger
.
 
<EOS>
Are
you
any
fresher
now
,
or
do
you
want
the
iron
candlestick
to
wake
you
thoroughly
?
"
   
<EOS>
A
pair
of

shuffled
,
hastily
,
across

bare

of
the
room
,
as
this

was
put
;
and
there
issued
,
from
a

on
the

;
first
,
a

:
 
and
next
,
the
form
of
the
same

who
has
been
heretofore
described
as
labouring
under
the
infirmity
of
speaking
through
his
nose
,
and
officiating
as
waiter
at
the
public
-
house
on
Saffron

.
   
<EOS>
"
Bister
Sikes
!
"
exclaimed
Barney
,
with
real
or

joy
;
"
cub
i
d
,
sir
;
cub
<EOS>
i
d
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
!
<EOS>
you
get
on
first
,
"
said
Sikes
,
putting
Oliver
in

.
 
<EOS>
"
Quicker
!
<EOS>
or
I
shall
tread
upon

.
"
   
<EOS>
Muttering
a
curse
upon
his

,
Sikes
pushed
Oliver

;
and
they
entered
a
low

room
with

,
two

,

,

a
very

:
 
on

,

his

higher
than

,
a
man
was
reposing

full
length
,
smoking
a
long

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
dressed
in
a
smartly
-
cut
snuff

coat
,
with
large

;
an
orange

;
a

,

,

;
and

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Crackit
(
for
he
it
was
)
had
no
very
great
quantity
of
hair
,
either
upon
his
head
or

;
but
what
he
had
,
was
of
a
reddish

,
and
tortured
into
long

curls
,
through
which
he
occasionally
thrust
some
very
dirty

,
ornamented
with
large

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
trifle
above
the
middle
size
,
and
apparently
rather
weak
in
the
legs
;
but
this
circumstance
by
no

detracted
from
his
own
admiration
of
his
top
-
boots
,
which
he
contemplated
,
in
their
elevated

,
with
lively
satisfaction
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bill
,
my
boy
!
"
said
this
figure
,
turning
his

towards
the
door
,
"
I
'm
glad

see

.
 
<EOS>
I
was

you
'd
given
it
up
:
 
in
which
case
I
should
have
made
a

wentur
.
 
<EOS>
Hallo
!
"
   
<EOS>
Uttering

,
as

on
Oliver
,
Mr
Toby
Crackit

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
The
boy
.
 
<EOS>
Only
the
boy
!
"
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Wud
of
Bister
Fagid
's

,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Fagin
's
,

!
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Wot

,

'

!
 
<EOS>
His

'

.
"
   
<EOS>

There

"

<EOS>
"

"

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
Sit

,

,

;
for

to
-

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver

,

<EOS>
"
Here
,
"

,

,
 
"
Success
to

!
"
 
<EOS>
He

;
and
,

,

,

with

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Sikes
did

.
   
<EOS>
"
A

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
Down

,

<EOS>

"
   
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
This

,

(

,

.
 
<EOS>
Oliver

;

:
 
close

.
   
<EOS>
They

,

;
<EOS>
nobody

,

.
<EOS>
Oliver

:
 
imagining
