,
or

:
 
when

it
was

.
   
<EOS>
In

,
the

,

.
 
<EOS>
Sikes

,

;

,

<EOS>
"
Barkers

"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Here

"

,

.
<EOS>
"
You

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
All

!
"

<EOS>
"
The

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>

,

,

"
<EOS>

:
 
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>

All

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Bring

,

.
 
<EOS>
That
's

.
"
   
<EOS>
With

,

,
who
,

,

's

.
   
<EOS>
"
Now

!
"
said

,

.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
:
 
<EOS>
who
was
completely

by

,
and
the

,

which

:
 
put

.
   
<EOS>
"
Take

,
Toby
,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
Look
out
,
Barney
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
man
went
to
the
door
,
and
returned
to
announce
that
all
was
quiet
.
 
<EOS>
The
two
robbers
issued
forth
with
Oliver
between
them
.
<EOS>
Barney
,
having
made
all
fast
,
rolled
himself
up
as
before
,
and
was
soon
asleep
again
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
now
intensely
dark
.
 
<EOS>
The
fog
was
much
heavier
than
it
had
been
in
the
early
part
of
the
night
;
and
the

was
so
damp
,
that
,
although
no
rain
fell
,
Oliver
's
hair
and
eyebrows
,
within
a
few
minutes
after
leaving
the
house
,
had
become
stiff
with
the
half
-
frozen
moisture
that
was
floating
about
.
 
<EOS>
They
crossed
the
bridge
,
and
kept
on
towards
the
lights
which
he
had
seen
before
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
at
no
great
distance
off
;
and
,
as
they
walked
pretty
briskly
,
they
soon
arrived
at
Chertsey
.
   
<EOS>
"
Slap
through
the
town
,
"
whispered
Sikes
;
"
there
'll
be
nobody
in
the
way
,
to
-
night
,
to
see
us
.
"
   
<EOS>
Toby
acquiesced
;
and
they
hurried
through
the
main
street
of
the
little
town
,
which
at
that
late
hour
was
wholly
deserted
.
 
<EOS>
A
dim
light
shone
at
intervals
from
some
bed
-
room
window
;
and
the
hoarse
barking
of
dogs
occasionally
broke
the
silence
of
the
night
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
was
nobody
abroad
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
cleared
the
town
,
as
the
church
-
bell
struck
two
.
   
<EOS>
Quickening
their
pace
,
they
turned
up
a
road
upon
the
left
hand
.
<EOS>
After
walking
about
a
quarter
of
a
mile
,
they
stopped
before
a
detached
house
surrounded
by
a
wall
:
 
to
the
top
of
which
,
Toby
Crackit
,
scarcely
pausing
to
take
breath
,
climbed
in
a
twinkling
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
boy
next
,
"
said
Toby
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hoist
him
up
;
I
'll
catch
hold
of
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
Before
Oliver
had
time
to
look
round
,
Sikes
had
caught
him
under
the
arms
;
and
in
three
or
four
seconds
he
and
Toby
were
lying
on
the
grass
on
the
other
side
.
 
<EOS>
Sikes
followed
directly
.
 
<EOS>
And
they
stole
cautiously
towards
the
house
.
   
<EOS>
And
now
,
for
the
first
time
,
Oliver
,
well
-
nigh
mad
with
grief
and
terror
,
saw
that
housebreaking
and
robbery
,
if
not
murder
,
were
the
objects
of
the
expedition
.
 
<EOS>
He
clasped
his
hands
together
,
and
involuntarily
uttered
a
subdued
exclamation
of
horror
.
 
<EOS>
A
mist
came
before
his
eyes
;
the
cold
sweat
stood
upon
his
ashy
face
;
his
limbs
failed
him
;
and
he
sank
upon
his
knees
.
   
<EOS>
"
Get
up
!
"
<EOS>
murmured
Sikes
,
trembling
with
rage
,
and
drawing
the
pistol
from
his
pocket
;
"
Get
up
,
or
I
'll
strew
your
brains
upon
the
grass
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
for
God
's
sake
let
me
go
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Oliver
;
"
let
me
run
away
and
die
in
the
fields
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
never
come
near
London
;
never
,
never
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
pray
have
mercy
on
me
,
and
do
not
make
me
steal
.
 
<EOS>
For
the
love
of
all
the
bright
Angels
that
rest
in
Heaven
,
have
mercy
upon
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
man
to
whom
this
appeal
was
made
,
swore
a
dreadful
oath
,
and
had
cocked
the
pistol
,
when
Toby
,
striking
it
from
his
grasp
,
placed
his
hand
upon
the
boy
's
mouth
,
and
dragged
him
to
the
house
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
"
cried
the
man
;
"
it
wo
n't
answer
here
.
 
<EOS>
Say
another
word
,
and
I
'll
do
your
business
myself
with
a
crack
on
the
head
.
 
<EOS>
That
makes
no
noise
,
and
is
quite
as
certain
,
and
more
genteel
.
 
<EOS>
Here
,
Bill
,
wrench
the
shutter
open
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
game
enough
now
<EOS>
,
I
'll
engage
.
 
<EOS>
I
've
seen
older
hands
of
his
age
took
the
same
way
,
for
a
minute
or
two
,
on
a
cold
night
.
"
   
<EOS>
Sikes
,
invoking
terrific
imprecations
upon
Fagin
's
head
for
sending
Oliver
on
such
an
errand
,
plied
the
crowbar
vigorously
,
but
with
little
noise
.
 
<EOS>
After
some
delay
,
and
some
assistance
from
Toby
,
the
shutter
to
which
he
had
referred
,
swung
open
on
its
hinges
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
little
lattice
window
,
about
five
feet
and
a
half
above
the
ground
,
at
the
back
of
the
house
:
 
which
belonged
to
a
scullery
,
or
small
brewing
-
place
,
at
the
end
of
the
passage
.
 
<EOS>
The
aperture
was
so
small
,
that
the
inmates
had
probably
not
thought
it
worth
while
to
defend
it
more
securely
;
but
it
was
large
enough
to
admit
a
boy
of
Oliver
's
size
,
nevertheless
.
 
<EOS>
A
very
brief
exercise
of
Mr
Sike
's
art
,
sufficed
to
overcome
the
fastening
of
the
lattice
;
and
it
soon
stood
wide
open
also
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
listen
,
you
young
limb
,
"
whispered
Sikes
,
drawing
a
dark
lantern
from
his
pocket
,
and
throwing
the
glare
full
on
Oliver
's
face
;
"
I
'm
a
going
to
put
you
through
there
.
 
<EOS>
Take
this
light
;
go
softly
up
the
steps
<EOS>
straight
afore
you
,
and
along
the
little
hall
,
to
the
street
door
<EOS>
;
unfasten
it
,
and
let
us
in
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
a
bolt
at
the
top
,
you
wo
n't
be
able
to
reach
,
"
interposed
Toby
.
<EOS>
"
Stand
upon
one
of
the
hall
chairs
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
three
there
,
Bill
,
with
a
jolly
large
blue
unicorn
and
gold
pitchfork
on
'em
:
 
which
is
the
old
lady
's
arms
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Keep
quiet
,
ca
n't
you
?
"
<EOS>
replied
Sikes
,
with
a
threatening
look
.
"
<EOS>
The
room
-
door
is
open
,
is
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Wide
,
"
repied
Toby
,
after
peeping
in
to

.
<EOS>
"
The
game
of
that
is
,
that
they
always
leave
it
open
with
a
catch
,
so
that
the
dog
,
who
's
got
a
bed
in
here
,
may
walk
up
and
down
the
passage
when
he
feels
wakeful
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
Barney
'
ticed
him
away
to
-
night
.
 
<EOS>
So
neat
!
"
   
<EOS>
Although
Mr
Crackit
spoke
in
a
scarcely
audible
whisper
,
and
laughed
without
noise
,
Sikes
imperiously
commanded
him
to
be
silent
,
and
to
get
to
work
.
 
<EOS>
Toby
complied
,
by
first
producing
his
lantern
,
and
placing
it
on
the
ground
;
then
by
planting
himself
firmly
with
his
head
against
the
wall
beneath
the
window
,
and
his
hands
upon
his
knees
,
so
as
to
make
a
step
of
his
back
.
<EOS>
This
was
no
sooner
done
,
than
Sikes
,
mounting
upon
him
,
put
Oiver
gently
through
the
window
with
his
feet
first
;
and
,
without
leaving
hold
of
his
collar
,
planted
him
safely
on
the
floor
inside
.
   
<EOS>
"
Take
this
lantern
,
"
said
Sikes
,
looking
into
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
see
the
stairs
afore
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver
,
more
dead
than
alive
,
gasped
out
,
"
Yes
.
"
 
Sikes
,
pointing
to
the
street
-
door
with
the
pistol
-
barrel
,
briefly
advised
him
to
take
notice
that
he
was
within
shot
all
the
way
;
and
that
if
he
faltered
,
he
would
fall
dead
that
instant
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
done
in
a
minute
,
"
said
Sikes
,
in
the
same
low

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Directly
I
leave
go
of
you
,
do
your
work
.
 
<EOS>
Hark
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
that
?
"
whispered
the
other
man
.
   
<EOS>
They
listened
intently
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
"
said
Sikes
,
releasing
his
hold
of
Oliver
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
!
"
   
<EOS>
In
the
short
time
he
had
had
to
collect
his
senses
,
the
boy
had
firmly
resolved
that
,
whether
he
died
in
the
attempt
or
not
,
he
would
make
one
effort
to
dart
upstairs
from
the
hall
,
and
alarm
the
family
.
 
<EOS>
Filled
with
this
idea
,
he
advanced
at
once
,
but
stealthiy
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
back
!
"
<EOS>
suddenly
cried
Sikes
aloud
.
 
<EOS>
"
Back
!
<EOS>
back
!
"
   
<EOS>
Scared
by
the
sudden
breaking
of
the
dead
stillness
of
the
place
,
and
by
a
loud
cry
which
followed
it
,
Oliver
let
his
lantern
fall
,
and
knew
not
whether
to
advance
or
fly
.
   
<EOS>
The
cry
was
repeated
---
a
light
appeared
---
a
vision
of
two
terrified
half
-
dressed
men
at
the
top
of
the
stairs
swam
before
his
eyes
---
a
flash
---
a
loud
noise
---
a
smoke
---
a
crash
somewhere
,
but
where
he
knew
not
,
---
and
he
staggered
back
.
   
<EOS>
Sikes
had
disappeared
for
an
instant
;
but
he
was
up
again
,
and
had
him
by
the
collar
before
the
smoke
had
cleared
away
.
 
<EOS>
He
fired
his
own
pistol
after
the
men
,
who
were
already
retreating
;
and
dragged
the
boy
up
.
   
<EOS>
"
Clasp
your
arm
tighter
,
"
said
Sikes
,
as
he
drew
him
through
the
window
.
 
<EOS>
"
Give
me
a
shawl
here
.
 
<EOS>
They
've
hit
him
.
 
<EOS>
Quick
!
 
<EOS>
How
the
boy
bleeds
!
"
   
<EOS>
Then
came
the
loud
ringing
of
a
bell
,
mingled
with
the
noise
of
fire
-
arms
,
and
the
shouts
of
men
,
and
the
sensation
of
being
carried
over
uneven
ground
at
a
rapid
pace
.
 
<EOS>
And
then
,
the
noises
grew
confused
in
the
distance
;
and
a
cold
deadly
feeling
crept
over
the
boy
's
heart
;
and
he
saw
or
heard
no
more
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
23
.
<EOS>
Which
contains
the
substance
of
a
pleasant
conversation
between
Mr
Bumble
and
a
lady
;
and
shows
that
even
a
beadle
may
be
susceptible
on
some
points
.
 
<EOS>
The
night
was
bitter
cold
.
 
<EOS>
The
snow
lay
on
the
ground
,
frozen
into
a
hard
thick
crust
,
so
that
only
the
heaps
that
had
drifted
into
byways
and
corners
were
affected
by
the
sharp
wind
that
howled
abroad
:
 
which
,
as
if
expending
increased
fury
on
such
prey
as
it
found
,
caught
it
savagely
up
in
clouds
,
and
,
whirling
it
into
a
thousand
misty
eddies
,
scattered
it
in
air
.
 
<EOS>
Bleak
,
dark
,
and
piercing
cold
<EOS>
,
it
was
a
night
for
the
well
-
housed
and
fed
to
draw
round
the
bright
fire
and
thank
God
they
were
at
home
;
and
for
the
homeless
,
starving
wretch
to
lay
him
down
and
die
.
 
<EOS>
Many
hunger
-
worn
outcasts
close
their
eyes
in
our
bare
streets
,
at
such
times
,
who
,
let
their
crimes
have
been
what
they
may
,
can
hardly
open
them
in
a
more
bitter
world
.
   
<EOS>
Such
was
the
aspect
of
out
-
of
-
doors
affairs
,
when
Mr
Corney
,
the
matron
of
the
workhouse
to
which
our
readers
have
been
already
introduced
as
the
birthplace
of
Oliver
Twist
,
sat
herself
down
before
a
cheerful
fire
in
her
own
little
room
,
and
glanced
,
with
no
small
degree
of
complacency
,
at
a
small
round
table
:
 
on
which
stood
a
tray
of
corresponding
size
,
furnished
with
all
necessary
materials
for
the
most
grateful
meal
that
matrons
enjoy
.
 
<EOS>
In
fact
,
Mrs
Corney
was
about
to
solace
herself
with
a
cup
of
tea
.
<EOS>
As
she
glanced
from
the
table
to
the
fireplace
,
where
the
smallest
of
all
possible
kettles
was
singing
a
small
song
in
a
small
voice
,
her
inward
satisfaction
evidently
increased
,
---
so
much
so
,
indeed
,
that
Mrs
Corney
smiled
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
said
the
matron
,
leaning
her
elbow
on
the
table
,
and
looking
reflectively
at
the
fire
;
<EOS>
"
I
'm
sure
we
have
all
on
us
a
great
deal
to
be
grateful
for
!
 
<EOS>
A
great
deal
,
if
we
did
but
know
it
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Corney
shook
her
head
mournfully
,
as
if
deploring
the
mental
blindness
of
those
paupers
who
did
not
know
it
;
and
thrusting
a
silver
spoon
(
private
property
)
into
the
inmost
recesses
of
a
two
-
ounce
tin
tea
-
caddy
,
proceeded
to
make
the
tea
.
   
<EOS>
How
slight
a
thing
will
disturb
the
equanimity
of
our
frail
minds
!
 
<EOS>
The
black
teapot
,
being
very
small
and
easily
filled
,
ran
over
while
Mrs
Corney
was
moralising
;
and
the
water
slightly
scalded
Mrs
Corney
's
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
Drat
the
pot
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
worthy
matron
,
setting
it
down
very
hastily
on
the
hob
;
"
a
little
stupid
thing
,
that
only
holds
a
couple
of
cups
!
 
<EOS>
What
use
is
it
of
,
to
anybody
!
 
<EOS>
Except
,
"
said
Mrs
Corney
,
pausing
,
"
except
to
a
poor
desolate
creature
like
me
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
dear
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
these
words
,
the
matron
dropped
into
her
chair
,
and
,
once
more
resting
her
elbow
on
the
table
,
thought
of
her
solitary
fate
.
 
<EOS>
The
small
teapot
,
and
the
single
cup
,
had
awakened
in
her
mind
sad
recollections
of
Mr
Corney
(
who
had
not
been
dead
more
than
five
-
and
-
twenty
years
)
;
and
she
was
overpowered
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
never
get
another
!
"
said
Mrs
Corney
,
pettishly
;
"
I
shall
never
get
another
---
like
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
Whether
this
remark
bore
reference
to
the
husband
,
or
the

,
is
uncertain
.
 
<EOS>
It
might
have
been
the
latter
;
for
Mrs
Corney
looked
at
it
as
she
spoke
;
and
took
it
up
afterwards
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
just
tasted
her
first
cup
,
when
she
was
disturbed
by
a
soft
tap
at
the
room
-

.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
come
in
with
you
!
"
<EOS>
said
Mrs
Corney
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Some
of
the
old
women
dying
,
I
suppose
.
 
<EOS>
They
always
die
when
I
'm
at
meals
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
stand
there
,
letting
the
cold
air
in
,
do
n't
.
 
<EOS>
What
's
amiss
now
,
eh
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
ma'am
,
nothing
,
"
replied
a
man
's
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
"
exclaimed

,
in
a
much

,
"
is
that
Mr
Bumble
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
At
your
service
,
ma'am
,
"
said
Mr
Bumble
,
who
had
been
stopping
outside
to
rub

clean
,

off

;
and
who
now
made

,
bearing

in

and

.
 
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
shut
the
door
,
ma'am
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
lady
modestly
hesitated
to
reply
,
lest
there
should

any
impropriety
in
holding
an
interview
with
Mr
Bumble
,
with
closed
doors
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
taking
advantage
of
the
hesitation
,
and
being
very
cold
himself
,
shut
it
without
permission
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hard
weather
,
Mr
Bumble
,
"
said
the
matron
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hard
,
indeed
,
ma'am
,
"

the
beadle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Anti
-
porochial
weather
this
,
ma'am
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
given
away
,
Mrs
Corney
,
we
have

away

twenty

and

and
a
half
,
this

;

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of

.
 
<EOS>
When

,
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
?
<EOS>
"
said
the
matron
,
sipping

.
   
<EOS>
"
When
,
indeed
,
ma'am
!
"
rejoined
Mr
Bumble
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
here
's
one
man
that
,
in
consideraton
of
his
wife
and
large
family
,
has
a
quartern
loaf
and
a
good
pound
of
cheese
,
<EOS>
full
weight
.
 
<EOS>
Is
he
grateful
,
ma'am
?
 
<EOS>
Is
he
grateful
?
 
<EOS>
Not
a
copper
farthing
's
worth
of
it
!
 
<EOS>
What
does
he
do
,
ma'am
,
but
ask

a
few
coals
;
if
it
's
only
a
pocket

full
,
he

!
 
<EOS>
Coals
!
<EOS>
What
would
he
do
with
coals
?
 
<EOS>
Toast
his
cheese
with
'em
and
then
come
back
for

.
 
<EOS>
That
's
the
way
with
these
people
,
ma'am
;
give
'em
a
apron
full
of
coals
to
-

,
and

'll
come
back
for
another
,
the
day

to
-

,
as
brazen
as

.
"
   
<EOS>
The
matron
expressed
her
entire
concurrence
in
this
intelligible
simile
;
and
the
beadle
went
on
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
never
,
"
said
Mr
Bumble
,
"
see
anything
like
the
pitch
it
's
got
to
.
 
<EOS>
The
day
afore
yesterday
,
a
man
---
you
have
been
a
married
woman
,
ma'am
,
and
I
may
mention
it
to
you
---
a
man
,
with
hardly
a
rag
upon
his
back
<EOS>
(
here
Mrs
Corney
looked
at
the
floor
)
,
goes
to
our
overseer
's
door
when
he
has
got
company
coming
to

;
and
says
,
he
must
be

,
Mrs
Corney
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
would
n't
go
away
,
and
shocked
the
company
very
much
,
our
overseer
sent
him
out
a
pound
of
potatoes
and
half
a

.
 
<EOS>
"
My
heart
!
"
says
the
ungrateful
villain
,
"
what
's
the
use

THIS
to
me
?
 
<EOS>
You

!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Very
good
,
"

our
overseer
,
taking
'em
away

,
"
you
wo
n't

anything
else

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then

'll

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh

,
you
wo
n't
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
!
ha
!
 
<EOS>
That

!
 
<EOS>
So

Mr
Grannett
,
was

?
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,

,
"

,
"

;
and

DID

.
 
<EOS>
There

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
It

I

"

<EOS>
"
But

think
out
-
of
-
door
relief
a

,

,
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
?
 
<EOS>
You
're
a

,

.
 
<EOS>
Come
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Corney
,
"

,

,
"
out
-
of
-
door
relief
,
properly

,
ma'am
<EOS>
:
is

porochial

.
 
<EOS>
The

out
-
of
-

,

do

;

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
Betwixt

,

,
"

Bumble
,
"
<EOS>
that
's

;

,

owdacious

,

that

.
 
<EOS>
That

,
Mrs

,
all

.
<EOS>
But
,
however
,
"
said

,

,
"
these

,
ma'am
;
not

;
except
,

,

,

.
<EOS>
This

,

,

the
board
ordered

;
real
,

,

;
only

;

bell
,
and
no

!
"
   
<EOS>
Having

the
first

up
to

,
and
shaken
it
well
to
test

,
Mr
Bumble
placed

on

of
a
chest
of

;

the

in
which

had

;
put

carefully
in
his

;
and
took
up
his

,
as
if
to
go
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
'll
have
a
very
cold
walk
,
Mr
Bumble
,
"
said
the
matron
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
blows
,
ma'am
,
"
replied
Mr
Bumble
,
turning
up
his
coat
-
collar
,
"
enough
to
cut
one
's
ears
off
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
matron
looked
,
from
the
little
kettle
,
to
the
beadle
,
who
was
moving
towards
the
door
;
and
as
the
beadle
coughed
,
preparatory
to
bidding
her
good
-
night
,
bashfully
inquired
whether
---
whether
he
would
n't
take
a
cup
of
tea
?
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
instantaneously
turned
back
his
collar
again
;
laid
his
hat
and
stick
upon
a
chair
;
and
drew
another
chair
up
to
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
slowly
seated
himself
,
he
looked
at
the
lady
.
 
<EOS>
She
fixed
her
eyes
upon
the
little
teapot
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
coughed
again
,
and
slightly
smiled
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Corney
rose
to
get
another
cup
and
saucer
from
the
closet
.
<EOS>
As
she
sat
down
,
her

once
again
encountered
those
of
the
gallant
beadle
;
she
coloured
,
and
applied
herself
to
the
task
of
making

.
 
<EOS>
Again
Mr
Bumble
coughed
---
<EOS>
louder
this

than
he
had
coughed

.
   
<EOS>
"
Sweet
?
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
?
<EOS>
"

,

-

.
   
<EOS>
"
Very

,

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
He
fixed
his

on
Mrs
Corney
as

;
and
if

a
beadle
looked

,
Mr
Bumble
was
that
beadle
at

.
   
<EOS>
The
tea
was
made
,
and
handed
in

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
,
having
spread
a

over

to

the

of

,
began
to
eat
and

;

,

,

;
which
,

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
You

,

,

,
"

,

;
"

,

"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

,

ca

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very

,

,
"

,

;
"
so

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,

!
"

;
"
so

their
home

,

,
I
'm

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Corney
,

,

,

,

,
"
I

,

;

,

,

,

,

NOT

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Mr

!
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
of
no
use

,
ma'am
,
"
said

Bumble
,
slowly

with

which
made

doubly

;
"
I
would
drown

myself
,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then

're

,
"

,

's

;
"

-

.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Hard
-
hearted
,

?
"
said
Mr
Bumble
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hard
?
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
resigned
his
cup
without
another
word
;
squeezed
Mrs
Corney
's
little
finger
as
she
took
it
;
and
inflicting
two
open
-
handed
slaps
upon
his
laced
waistcoat
,
gave
a
mighty
sigh
,
and
hitched
his
chair
a
very
little
morsel
farther
from
the
fire
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
round
table
;
and
as
Mrs
Corney
and
Mr
Bumble
had
been
sitting
opposite
each
other
,
with
no
great
space
between
them
,
and
fronting
the
fire
,
it
will
be
seen
that
Mr
Bumble
,
in
receding
from
the
fire
,
and
still
keeping
at
the
table
,
increased
the
distance
between
himself
and
Mrs
Corney
;
which
proceeding
,
some
prudent
readers
will
doubtless
be
disposed
to
admire
,
and
to
consider
an
act
of
great
heroism
on
Mr
Bumble
's
part
:
 
he
being
in
some
sort
<EOS>
tempted
by
time
,
place
,
and
opportunity
,
to
give
utterance
to
certain
soft
nothings
,
which
however
well
they
may
become
the
lips
of
the
light
and
thoughtless
,
do
seem
immeasurably
beneath
the
dignity
of
judges
of
the
land
,
members
of

,

of
state
,
lord
