,
and
other
great
public
functionaries
,
but
more
particularly
beneath
the
stateliness
and
gravity
of
a
beadle
:
 
who
(
as
is
well
known
)
should
be
the
sternest
and
most
inflexible
among
them
all
.
   
<EOS>
Whatever
were
Mr
Bumble
's
intentions
,
however
(
<EOS>
and
no
doubt
they
were
of
the
best
)
<EOS>
:
it
unfortunately
happened
,
as
has
been
twice
before
remarked
,
that
the
table
was
a
round
one
;
consequently
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
,
moving
his
chair
by
little
and
little
,
soon
began
to
diminish
the
distance
between
himself
and
the
matron
;
and
,
continuing
to
travel
round
the
outer
edge
of
the
circle
,
brought
his
chair
,
in
time
,
close
to
that
in
which
the
matron
was
seated
.
   
<EOS>
Indeed
,
the
two
chairs
touched
;
and
when
they
did
so
,
Mr
Bumble
stopped
.
   
<EOS>
Now
,
if
the
matron
had
moved
her
chair
to
the
right
,
she
would
have
been
scorched
by
the
fire
;
and
if
to
the
left
,
she
must
have
fallen
into
Mr
Bumble
's
arms
;
so
(
being
a
discreet
matron
,
and
no
doubt
foreseeing
these
consequences
at
a
glance
)
<EOS>
she
remained
where
she
was
,
and
handed
Mr
Bumble
another
cup
of
tea
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hard
-
hearted
,
Mrs
Corney
?
"
said
Mr
Bumble
,
stirring
his
tea
,
and
looking
up
into
the
matron
's
face
;
"
are
YOU
hard
-
hearted
,
Mrs
Corney
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
"
exclaimed
the
matron
,
"
what
a
very
curious
question
from
a
single
man
.
 
<EOS>
What
can
you
want
to
know
for
,
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
beadle
drank
his
tea
to
the
last
drop
;
finished
a
piece
of
toast
;
whisked
the
crumbs
off
his
knees
;
wiped
his
lips
;
and
deliberately
kissed
the
matron
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Bumble
!
"
cried
that
discreet
lady
in
a
whisper
;
for
the
fright
was
so
great
,
that
she
had
quite
lost
her
voice
,
"
Mr
Bumble
,
I
shall
scream
!
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
made
no
reply
;
but
in
a
slow
and
dignified
manner
,
put
his
arm
round
the
matron
's
waist
.
   
<EOS>
As
the
lady
had
stated
her
intention
of
screaming
,
of
course
she
would
have
screamed
at
this
additional
boldness
,
but
that
the
exertion
was
rendered
unnecessary
by
a
hasty
knocking
at
the
door
:
 
which
was
no
sooner
heard
,
than
Mr
Bumble
darted
,
with
much
agility
,
to
the
wine
bottles
,
and
began
dusting
them
with
great
violence
:
 
while
the
matron
sharply
demanded
who
was
there
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
worthy
of
remark
,
as
a
curious
physical
instance
of
the
efficacy
of
a
sudden
surprise
in
counteracting
the
effects
of
extreme
fear
,
that
her
voice
had
quite
recovered
all
its
official
asperity
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
please
,
mistress
,
"
said
a
withered
old
female
pauper
,
hideously
ugly
:
 
putting
her
head
in
at
the
door
,
"
Old
Sally
is
a
-
going
fast
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
what
's
that
to
me
?
"
<EOS>
angrily
demanded
the
matron
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
keep
her
alive
,
can
I
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
mistress
,
"
replied
the
old
woman
,
"
nobody
can
;
she
's
far
beyond
the
reach
of
help
.
 
<EOS>
I
've
seen
a
many
people
die
;
<EOS>
little
babes
and
great
strong
men
;
and
I
know
when
death
's
a
-
coming
,
well
enough
.
 
<EOS>
But
she
's
troubled
in
her
mind
:
<EOS>
and
when
the
fits
are
not
on
her
,
---
and
that
's
not
often
,
for
she
is
dying
very
hard
,
---
she
says
she
has
got
something
to
tell
,
which
you
must
hear
.
 
<EOS>
She
'll
never
die
quiet
till
you
come
,
mistress
.
"
   
<EOS>
At
this
intelligence
,
the
worthy
Mrs
Corney
muttered
a
variety
of
invectives
against
old
women
who
could
n't
even
die
without
purposely
annoying
their
betters
;
and
,
muffling
herself
in
a
thick
shawl
which
she
hastily
caught
up
,
briefly
requested
Mr
Bumble
to
stay
till
she
came
back
,
lest
anything
particular
should
occur
.
 
<EOS>
Bidding
the
messenger
walk
fast
,
and
not
be
all
night
hobbling
up
the
stairs
,
she
followed
her
from
the
room
with
a
very
ill
grace
,
scolding
all
the
way
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
's
conduct
on
being
left
to
himself
,
was
rather
inexplicable
.
 
<EOS>
He
opened
the
closet
,
counted
the
teaspoons
,
weighed
the
sugar
-
tongs
,
closely
inspected
a
silver
milk
-
pot
to
ascertain
that
it
was
of
the
genuine
metal
,
and
,
having
satisfied
his
curiosity
on
these
points
,
put
on
his
cocked
hat
corner
-
wise
,
and
danced
with
much
gravity
four
distinct
times
round
the
table
.
   
<EOS>
Having
gone
through
this
very
extraordinary
performance
,
he
took
off
the
cocked
hat
again
,
and
,
spreading
himself
before
the
fire
with
his
back
towards
it
,
seemed
to
be
mentally
engaged
in
taking
an
exact
inventory
of
the
furniture
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
24
.
<EOS>
Treats
on
a
very
poor
subject
.
 
<EOS>
But
is
a
short
one
,
and
may
be
found
of
importance
in
this
history
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
no
unfit
messanger
of
death
,
who
had
disturbed
the
quiet
of
the
matron
's
room
.
 
<EOS>
Her
body
was
bent
by
age
;
her
limbs
trembled
with
palsy
;
her
face
,
distorted
into
a
mumbling
leer
,
resembled
more
the
grotesque
shaping
of
some
wild
pencil
,
than
the
work
of
Nature
's
hand
.
   
<EOS>
Alas
!
 
<EOS>
How
few
of
Nature
's
faces
are
left
alone
to
gladden
us
with
their
beauty
!
 
<EOS>
The
cares
,
and
sorrows
,
and
hungerings
,
of
the
world
,
change
them
as
they
change
hearts
;
and
it
is
only
when
those
passions
sleep
,
and
have
lost
their
hold
for
ever
,
that
the
troubled
clouds
pass
off
,
and
leave
Heaven
's
surface
clear
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
common
thing
for
the
countenances
of
the
dead
,
even
in
that
fixed
and
rigid
state
,
to
subside
into
the
long
-
forgotten
expression
of
sleeping
infancy
,
and
settle
into
the
very
look
of
early
life
;
so
calm
,
so
peaceful
,
do
they
grow
again
,
that
those
who
knew
them
in
their
happy
childhood
,
kneel
by
the
coffin
's
side
in
awe
,
and
see
the
Angel
even
upon
earth
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
crone
tottered
alone
the
passages
,
and
up
the
stairs
,
muttering
some
indistinct
answers
to
the
chidings
of
her
companion
;
being
at
length
compelled
to
pause
for
breath
,
she
gave
the
light
into
her
hand
,
and
remained
behind
to
follow
as
she
might
:
while
the
more
nimble
superior
made
her
way
to
the
room
where
the
sick
woman
lay
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
bare
garret
-
room
,
with
a
dim
light
burning
at
the
farther
end
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
another
old
woman
watching
by
the
bed
;
the
parish
apothecary
's
apprentice
was
standing
by
the
fire
,
making
a
toothpick
out
of
a
quill
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Cold
night
,
Mrs
Corney
,
"
said
this
young
gentleman
,
as
the
matron
entered
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Very
cold
,
indeed
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
mistress
,
in
her
most
civil
tones
,
and
dropping
a
curtsey
as
she
spoke
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
should
get
better
coals
out
of
your
contractors
,
"
said
the
apothecary
's
deputy
,
breaking
a
lump
on
the
top
of
the
fire
with
the
rusty
poker
;
"
these
are
not
at
all
the
sort
of
thing
for
a
cold
night
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
They
're
the
board
's
choosing
,
sir
,
"
returned
the
matron
.
<EOS>
"
The
least
they
could
do
,
would
be
to
keep
us
pretty
warm
:
 
for
our
places
are
hard
enough
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
conversation
was
here
interrupted
by
a
moan
from
the
sick
woman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
said
the
young
mag
,
turning
his
face
towards
the
bed
,
as
if
he
had
previously
quite
forgotten
the
patient
,
"
it
's
all
U*P
there
,
Mrs
Corney
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
,
is
it
,
sir
?
"
asked
the
matron
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
she
lasts
a
couple
of
hours
,
I
shall
be
surprised
.
"
said
the
apothecary
's
apprentice
,
intent
upon
the
toothpick
's
point
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
break
-
up
of
the
system
altogether
.
 
<EOS>
Is
she
dozing
,
old
lady
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
attendant
stooped
over
the
bed
,
to
ascertain
;
and
nodded
in
the
affirmative
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
perhaps
she
'll
go
off
in
that
way
,
if
you
do
n't
make
a
row
,
"
said
the
young
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
Put
the
light
on
the
floor
.
 
<EOS>
She
wo
n't
see
it
there
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
attendant
did
as
she
was
told
:
 
shaking
her
head
meanwhile
,
to
intimate
that
the
woman
would
not
die
so
easily
;
having
done
so
,
she
resumed
her
seat
by
the
side
of
the
other
nurse
,
who
had
by
this
time
returned
.
 
<EOS>
The
mistress
,
with
an
expression
of
impatience
,
wrapped
herself
in
her
shawl
,
and
sat
at
the
foot
of
the
bed
.
   
<EOS>
The
apothecary
's
apprentice
,
having
completed
the
manufacture
of
the
toothpick
,
planted
himself
in
front
of
the
fire
and
made
good
use
of
it
for
ten
minutes
or
so
:
 
when
apparently
growing
rather
dull
,
he
wished
Mrs
Corney
joy
of
her
job
,
and
took
himself
off
on
tiptoe
.
   
<EOS>
When
they
had
sat
in
silence
for
some
time
,
the
two
old
women
rose
from
the
bed
,
and
crouching
over
the
fire
,
held
out
their
withered
hands
to
catch
the
heat
.
 
<EOS>
The
flame
threw
a
ghastly
light
on
their
shrivelled
faces
,
and
made
their
ugliness
appear
terrible
,
as
,
in
this
position
,
they
began
to
converse
in
a
low
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
Did
she
say
any
more
,
Anny
dear
,
while
I
was
gone
?
"
inquired
the
messenger
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a
word
,
"
replied
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
plucked
and
tore
at
her
arms
for
a
little
time
;
but
I
held
her
hands
,
and
she
soon
dropped
off
.
 
<EOS>
She
has
n't
much
strength
in
her
,
so
I
easily
kept
her
quiet
.
 
<EOS>
I
ai
n't
so
weak
for
an
old
woman
,
although
I
am
on
parish
allowance
;
no
,
no
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Did
she
drink
the
hot
wine
the
doctor
said
she
was
to
have
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
the
first
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
tried
to
get
it
down
,
"
rejoined
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
her
teeth
were
tight
set
,
and
she
clenched
the
mug
so
hard
that
it
was
as
much
as
I
could
do
to
get
it
back
again
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
drank
it
;
and
it
did
me
good
!
"
   
<EOS>
Looking
cautiously
round
,
to
ascertain
that
they
were
not
overheard
,
the
two
hags
cowered
nearer
to
the
fire
,
and
chuckled
heartily
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
mind
the
time
,
"
said
the
first
speaker
,
"
when
she
would
have
done
the
same
,
and
made
rare
fun
of
it
afterwards
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
that
she
would
,
"
rejoined
the
other
;
"
she
had
a
merry
heart
.
   
<EOS>
A
many
,
many
,
beautiful
corpses
she
laid
out
,
as
nice
and
neat
as
waxwork
.
 
<EOS>
My
old
eyes
have
seen
them
---
ay
,
and
those
old
hands
touched
them
too
;
for
I
have
helped
her
,
scores
of
times
.
"
   
<EOS>
Stretching
forth
her
trembling
fingers
as
she
spoke
,
the
old
creature
shook
them
exultingly
before
her
face
,
and
fumbling
in
her
pocket
,
brought
out
an
old
time
-
discoloured
tin
snuff
-
box
,
from
which
she
shook
a
few
grains
into
the
outstretched
palm
of
her
companion
,
and
a
few
more
into
her
own
.
 
<EOS>
While
they
were
thus
employed
,
the
matron
,
who
had
been
impatiently
watching
until
the
dying
woman
should
awaken
from
her
stupor
,
joined
them
by
the
fire
,
and
sharply
asked
how
long
she
was
to
wait
?
   
<EOS>
"
Not
long
,
mistress
,
"
replied
the
second
woman
,
looking
up
into
her
face
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
have
none
of
us
long
to
wait
for
Death
.
 
<EOS>
Patience
,
patience
!
 
<EOS>
He
'll
be
here
soon
enough
for
us
all
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hold
your
tongue
,
you
doting
idiot
!
"
said
the
matron
sternly
.
<EOS>
"
You
,
Martha
,
tell
me
;
has
she
been
in
this
way
before
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Often
,
"
answered
the
first
woman
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
will
never
be
again
,
"
added
the
second
one
;
"
that
is
,
she
'll
never
wake
again
but
once
---
and
mind
,
mistress
,
that
wo
n't
be
for
long
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Long
or
short
,
"
said
the
matron
,
snappishly
,
"
she
wo
n't
find
me
here
when
she
does
wake
;
take
care
,
both
of
you
,
how
you
worry
me
again
for
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
no
part
of
my
duty
to
see
all
the
old
women
in
the
house
die
,
and
I
wo
n't
---
that
's
more
.
<EOS>
Mind
that
,
you
impudent
old
harridans
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
make
a
fool
of
me
again
,
I
'll
soon
cure
you
,
I
warrant
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
was
bouncing
away
,
when
a
cry
from
the
two
women
,
who
had
turned
towards
the
bed
,
caused
her
to
look
round
.
 
<EOS>
The
patient
had
raised
herself
upright
,
and
was
stretching
her
arms
towards
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
's
that
?
"
<EOS>
she
cried
,
in
a
hollow
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
,
hush
!
"
said
one
of
the
women
,
stooping
over
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
Lie
down
,
lie
down
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
never
lie
down
again
alive
!
"
<EOS>
said
the
woman
,
struggling
.
<EOS>
"
I
WILL
tell
her
!
 
<EOS>
Come
here
!
 
<EOS>
Nearer
!
 
<EOS>
Let
me
whisper
in
your
ear
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
clutched
the
matron
by
the
arm
,
and
forcing
her
into
a
chair
by
the
bedside
,
was
about
to
speak
,
<EOS>
when
looking
round
,
she
caught
sight
of
the
two
old
women
bending
forward
in
the
attitude
of
eager
listeners
.
   
<EOS>
"
Turn
them
away
,
"
said
the
woman
,
drowsily
;
"
make
haste
!
<EOS>
make
haste
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
two
old
crones
,
chiming
in
together
,
began
pouring
out
many
piteous
lamentations
that
the
poor
dear
was
too
far
gone
to
know
her
best
friends
;
and
were
uttering
sundry
protestations
that
they
would
never
leave
her
,
when
the
superior
pushed
them
from
the
room
,
closed
the
door
,
and
returned
to
the
bedside
.
 
<EOS>
On
being
excluded
,
the
old
ladies
changed
their
tone
,
and
cried
through
the
keyhole
that
old
Sally
was
drunk
;
which
,
indeed
,
was
not
unlikely
;
since
,
in
addition
to
a
moderate
dose
of
opium
prescribed
by
the
apothecary
,
she
was
labouring
under
the
effects
of
a
final
taste
of
gin
-
and
-
water
which
had
been
privily
administered
,
in
the
openness
of
their
hearts
,
by
the
worthy
old
ladies
themselves
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
listen
to
me
,
"
said
the
dying
woman
aloud
,
as
if
making
a
great
effort
to
revive
one
latent
spark
of
energy
.
 
<EOS>
"
In
this
very
room
---
in
this
very
bed
---
I
once
nursed
a
pretty
young
creetur
'
,
that
was
brought
into
the
house
with
her
feet
cut
and
bruised
with
walking
,
and
all
soiled
with
dust
and
blood
.
 
<EOS>
She
gave
birth
to
a
boy
,
and
died
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
think
---
<EOS>
what
was
the
year
again
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
the
year
,
"
said
the
impatient
auditor
;
"
what
about
her
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
"
murmured
the
sick
woman
,
relapsing
into
her
former
drowsy
state
,
"
what
about
her
?
<EOS>
---
what
about
---
<EOS>
I
know
!
<EOS>
"
she
cried
,
jumping
fiercely
up
:
her
face
flushed
,
and
her
eyes
starting
from
her
head
---
"
I
robbed
her
,
so
I
did
!
 
<EOS>
She
was
n't
cold
---
I
tell
you
she
was
n't
cold
,
when
I
stole
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Stole
what
,
for
God
's
sake
?
"
<EOS>
cried
the
matron
,
with
a
gesture
as
if
she
would
call
for
help
.
   
<EOS>
"
IT
!
"
replied
the
woman
,
laying
her
hand
over
the
other
's
mouth
.
<EOS>
"
The
only
thing
she
had
.
 
<EOS>
She
wanted
clothes
to
keep
her
warm
,
and
food
to
eat
;
but
she
had
kept
it
safe
,
and
had
it
in
her
bosom
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
gold
,
I
tell
you
!
 
<EOS>
Rich
gold
,
that
might
have
saved
her
life
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Gold
!
"
echoed
the
matron
,
bending
eagerly
over
the
woman
as
she
fell
back
.
 
<EOS>
"
Go
on
,
go
on
---
yest
---
<EOS>
what
of
it
?
 
<EOS>
Who
was
the
mother
?
   
<EOS>
When
was
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
charge
me
to
keep
it
safe
,
"
replied
the
woman
with
a
groan
,
"
and
trusted
me
as
the
only
woman
about
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
stole
it
in
my
heart
when
she
first
showed
it
me
hanging
round
her
neck
;
and
the
child
's
death
,
perhaps
,
is
on
me
besides
!
 
<EOS>
They
would
have
treated
him
better
,
if
they
had
known
it
all
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Known
what
?
"
asked
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
Speak
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
boy
grew
so
like
his
mother
,
"
said
the
woman
,
rambling
on
,
and
not
heeding
the
question
,
"
that
I
could
never
forget
it
when
I
saw
his
face
.
 
<EOS>
Poor
girl
!
<EOS>
poor
girl
!
 
<EOS>
She
was
so
young
,
too
!
<EOS>
Such
a
gentle
lamb
!
 
<EOS>
Wait
;
there
's
more
to
tell
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
told
you
all
,
have
I
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
replied
the
matron
,
inclining
her
head
to
catch
the
words
,
as
they
came
more
faintly
from
the
dying
woman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Be
quick
,
or
it
may
be
too
late
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
mother
,
"
said
the
woman
,
making
a
more
violent
effort
than
before
;
"
the
mother
,
when
the
pains
of
death
first
came
upon
her
,
whispered
in
my
ear
that
if
her
baby
was
born
alive
,
and
thrived
,
the
day
might
come
when
it
would
not
feel
so
much
disgraced
to
hear
its
poor
young
mother
named
.
"
<EOS>
And
oh
,
kind
Heaven
!
"
she
said
,
folding
her
thin
hands
together
,
"
whether
it
be
boy
or
girl
,
raise
up
some
friends
for
it
in
this
troubled
world
,
and
take
pity
upon
a
lonely
desolate
child
,
abandoned
to
its
mercy
!
"
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
boy
's
name
?
"
demanded
the
matron
.
   
<EOS>
"
They
CALLED
him
Oliver
,
"
replied
the
woman
,
feebly
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
gold
I
stole
was
---
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
---
what
?
<EOS>
"
cried
the
other
.
   
<EOS>
She
was
bending
eagerly
over
the
woman
to
hear
her
reply
;
but
drew
back
,
instinctively
,
as
she
once
again
rose
,
slowly
and
stiffly
,
into
a
sitting
posture
;
then
,
clutching
the
coverlid
with
both
hands
,
muttered
some
indistinct
sounds
in
her
throat
,
and
fell
lifeless
on
the
bed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stone
dead
!
"
<EOS>
said
one
of
the
old
women
,
hurrying
in
as
soon
as
the
door
was
opened
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
nothing
to
tell
,
after
all
,
"
rejoined
the
matron
,
walking
carelessly
away
.
   
<EOS>
The
two
crones
,
to
all
appearance
,
too
busily
occupied
in
the
preparations
for
their
dreadful
duties
to
make
any
reply
,
were
left
alone
,
hovering
about
the
body
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
25
.
<EOS>
Wherein
this
history
reverts
to
Mr
Fagin
and
company
.
 
<EOS>
While
these
things
were
passing
in
the
country
workhouse
,
Mr
Fagin
sat
in
the
old
den
---
the
same
from
which
Oliver
had
been
removed
by
the
girl
---
brooding
over
a
dull
,
smoky
fire
.
 
<EOS>
He
held
a
pair
of
bellows
upon
his
knee
,
with
which
he
had
apparently
been
endeavouring
to
rouse
it
into
more
cheerful
action
;
but
he
had
fallen
into
deep
thought
;
and
with
his
arms
folded
on
them
,
and
his
chin
resting
on
his
thumbs
,
fixed
his
eyes
,
abstractedly
,
on
the
rusty
bars
.
   
<EOS>
At
a
table
behind
him
sat
the
Artful
Dodger
,
Master
Charles
Bates
,
and
Mr
Chitling
:
<EOS>
all
intent
upon
a
game
of
whist
;
the
Artful
taking
dummy
against
Master
Bates
and
Mr
Chitling
.
 
<EOS>
The
countenance
of
the
first
-
named
gentleman
,
peculiarly
intelligent
at
all
times
,
acquired
great
additional
interest
from
his
close
observance
of
the
game
,
and
his
attentive
perusal
of
Mr
Chitling
's
hand
;
upon
which
,
from
time
to
time
,
as
occasion
served
,
he
bestowed
a
variety
of
earnest
glances
:
wisely
regulating
his
own
play
by
the
result
of
his
observations
upon
his
neighbour
's
cards
.
 
<EOS>
It
being
a
cold
night
,
the
Dodger
wore
his
hat
,
as
,
indeed
,
was
often
his
custom
within
doors
.
 
<EOS>
He
also
sustained
a
clay
pipe
between
his
teeth
,
which
he
only
removed
for
a
brief
space
when
he
deemed
it
necessary
to
apply
for
refreshment
to
a
quart
pot
upon
the
table
,
which
stood
ready
filled
with
gin
-
and
-
water
for
the
accommodation
of
the
company
.
   
<EOS>
Master
Bates
was
also
attentive
to
the
play
;
but
being
of
a
more
excitable
nature
than
his
accomplished
friend
,
it
was
observable
that
he
more
frequently
applied
himself
to
the
gin
-
and
-
water
,
and
moreover
indulged
in
many
jests
and
irrelevant
remarks
,
all
highly
unbecoming
a
scientific
rubber
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
,
the
Artful
,
presuming
upon
their
close
attachment
,
more
than
once
took
occasion
to
reason
gravely
with
his
companion
upon
these
improprieties
;
all
of
which
remonstrances
,
Master
Bates
received
in
extremely
good
part
;
merely
requesting
his
friend
to
be
"
blowed
,
"
or
to
insert
his
head
in
a
sack
,
or
replying
with
some
other
neatly
-
turned
witticism
of
a
similar
kind
,
the
happy
application
of
which
,
excited
considerable
admiration
in
the
mind
of
Mr
Chitling
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
remarkable
that
the
latter
gentleman
and
his
partner
invariably
lost
;
and
that
the
circumstance
,
so
far
from
angering
Master
Bates
,
appeared
to
afford
him
the
highest
amusement
,
<EOS>
inasmuch
as
he
laughed
most
uproariously
at
the
end
of
every
deal
,
and
protested
that
he
had
never
seen
such
a
jolly
game
in
all
his
born
days
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
two
doubles
and
the
rub
,
"
said
Mr
Chitling
,
with
a
very
long
face
,
as
he
drew
half
-
a
-
crown
from
his
waistcoat
-
pocket
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
never
see
such
a
feller
as
you
,
Jack
;
you
win
everything
.
 
<EOS>
Even
when
we
've
good
cards
,
Charley
and
I
ca
n't
make
nothing
of
'
em
.
"
   
<EOS>
Either
the
master
or
the
manner
of
this
remark
,
which
was
made
very
ruefully
,
delighted
Charley
Bates
so
much
,
that
his
consequent
shout
of
laughter
roused
the
Jew
from
his
reverie
,
and
induced
him
to
inquire
what
was
the
matter
.
   
<EOS>
"
Matter
,
Fagin
!
"
cried
Charley
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
wish
you
had
watched
the
play
.
 
<EOS>
Tommy
Chitling
has
n't
won
a
point
;
and
I
went
partners
with
him
against
the
Artfull
and
dumb
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
ay
!
"
said
the
Jew
,
with
a
grin
,
which
sufficiently
demonstrated
that
he
was
at
no
loss
to
understand
the
reason
.
<EOS>
"
Try
'em
again
,
Tom
;
try
'em
again
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
more
of
it
for
me
,
thank
'
ee
,
Fagin
,
"
replied
Mr
Chitling
;
"
I
've
had
enough
.
 
<EOS>
That
'
ere
Dodger
has
such
a
run
of
luck
that
there
's
no
standing
again
'
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
my
dear
,
"
replied
the
Jew
,
"
you
must
get
up
very
early
in
the
morning
,
to
win
against
the
Dodger
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Morning
!
"
said
Charley
Bates
;
"
you
must
put
your
boots
on
over
-
night
,
and
have
a
telescope
at
each
eye
,
and
a
opera
-
glass
between
your
shoulders
,
if
you
want
to
come
over
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dawkins
received
these
handsome
compliments
with
much
philosophy
,
and
offered
to
cut
any
gentleman
in
company
,
for
the
first
picture
-
card
,
at
a
shilling
at
a
time
.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
accepting
the
challenge
,
and
his
pipe
being
by
this
time
smoked
out
,
he
proceeded
to
amuse
himself
by
sketching
a
ground
-
plan
of
Newgate
on
the
table
with
the
piece
of
chalk
which
had
served
him
in
lieu
of
counters
;
whistling
,
meantime
,
with
peculiar
shrillness
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
precious
dull
you
are
,
Tommy
!
"
said
the
Dodger
,
stopping
short
when
there
had
been
a
long
silence
;
and
addressing
Mr
Chitling
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
think
he
's
thinking
of
,
Fagin
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
should
I
know
,
my
dear
?
<EOS>
"
replied
the
Jew
,
looking
round
as
he
plied
the
bellows
.
 
<EOS>
"
About
his
losses
,
maybe
;
or
the
little
retirement
in
the
country
that
he
's
just
left
,
eh
?
 
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
 
<EOS>
Is
that
it
,
my
dear
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a
bit
of
it
,
"
replied
the
Dodger
,
stopping
the
subject
of
discourse
as
Mr
Chitling
was
about
to
reply
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
YOU
say
,
Charley
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
\
<EOS>
I
\
<EOS>
should
say
,
"
replied
Master
Bates
,
with
a
grin
,
"
that
he
was
uncommon
sweet
upon
Betsy
.
 
<EOS>
See
how
he
's
a
-
blushing
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
my
eye
!
<EOS>
here
's
a
merry
-
go
-
rounder
!
 
<EOS>
Tommy
Chitling
's
in
love
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
Fagin
,
Fagin
!
<EOS>
what
a
spree
!
"
   
<EOS>
Thoroughly
overpowered
with
the
notion
of
Mr
Chitling
being
the
victim
of
the
tender
passion
,
Master
Bates
threw
himself
back
in
his
chair
with
such
violence
,
that
he
lost
his
balance
,
and
pitched
over
upon
the
floor
;
where
(
the
accident
abating
nothing
of
his
merriment
)
<EOS>
he
lay
at
full
length
until
his
laugh
was
over
,
when
he
resumed
his
former
position
,
and
began
another
laugh
.
   
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
him
,
my
dear
,
"
said
the
Jew
,
winking
at
Mr
Dawkins
,
and
giving
Master
Bates
a
reproving
tap
with
the
nozzle
of
the
bellows
.
 
<EOS>
"
Betsy
's
a
fine
girl
.
 
<EOS>
Stick
up
to
her
,
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
Stick
up
to
her
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
I
mean
to
say
,
Fagin
,
"
replied
Mr
Chitling
,
very
red
in
the
face
,
"
is
,
that
that
is
n't
anything
to
anybody
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
more
it
is
,
"
replied
the
Jew
;
"
Charley
will
talk
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
mind
him
,
my
dear
;
do
n't
mind
him
.
 
<EOS>
Betsy
's
a
fine
girl
.
 
<EOS>
Do
as
she
bids
you
,
Tom
,
and
you
will
make
your
fortune
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
I
DO
do
as
she
bids
me
,
"
replied
Mr
Chitling
;
"
I
should
n't
have
been
milled
,
if
it
had
n't
been
for
her
advice
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
turned
out
a
good
job
for
you
;
did
n't
it
,
Fagin
!
 
<EOS>
And
what
's
six
weeks
of
it
?
 
<EOS>
It
must
come
,
some
time
or
another
,
and
why
not
in
the
winter
time
when
you
do
n't
want
to
go
out
a
-
walking
so
much
;
eh
,
Fagin
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
to
be
sure
,
my
dear
,
"
replied
the
Jew
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
would
n't
mind
it
again
,
Tom
,
would
you
,
"
asked
the
Dodger
,
winking
upon
Charley
and
the
Jew
,
"
if
Bet
was
all
right
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
mean
to
say
that
I
should
n't
,
"
replied
Tom
,
angrily
.
<EOS>
"
There
,
now
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
Who
'll
say
as
much
as
that
,
I
should
like
to
know
;
eh
,
Fagin
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nobody
,
my
dear
,
"
replied
the
Jew
;
"
not
a
soul
,
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
one
of
'em
that
would
do
it
besides
you
;
not
one
of
'em
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
might
have
got
clear
off
,
if
I
'd
split
upon
her
;
might
n't
I
,
Fagin
?
"
<EOS>
angrily
pursued
the
poor
half
-
witted
dupe
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
word
from
me
would
have
done
it
;
would
n't
it
,
Fagin
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
it
would
,
my
dear
,
"
replied
the
Jew
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
I
did
n't
blab
it
;
did
I
,
Fagin
?
"
<EOS>
demanded
Tom
,
pouring
question
upon
question
with
great
volubility
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
to
be
sure
,
"
replied
the
Jew
;
"
you
were
too
stout
-
hearted
for
that
.
 
<EOS>
A
deal
too
stout
,
my
dear
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
I
was
,
"
rejoined
Tom
,
looking
round
;
"
and
if
I
was
,
what
's
to
laugh
at
,
in
that
;
eh
,
Fagin
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
Jew
,
perceiving
that
Mr
Chitling
was
considerably
roused
,
hastened
to
assure
him
that
nobody
was
laughing
;
and
to
prove
the
gravity
of
the
company
,
appealed
to
Master
Bates
,
the
principal
offender
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
unfortunately
,
Charley
,
in
opening
his
mouth
to
reply
that
he
was
never
more
serious
in
his
life
,
was
unable
to
prevent
the
escape
of
such
a
violent
roar
,
that
the
abused
Mr
Chitling
,
without
any
preliminary
ceremonies
,
rushed
across
the
room
and
aimed
a
blow
at
the
offender
;
who
,
being
skilful
in
evading
pursuit
,
ducked
to
avoid
it
,
and
chose
his
time
<EOS>
so
well
that
it
lighted
on
the
chest
of
the
merry
old
gentleman
,
and
caused
him
to
stagger
to
the
wall
,
where
he
stood
panting
for
breath
,
while
Mr
Chitling
looked
on
in
intense
dismay
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hark
!
"
cried
the
Dodger
at
this
moment
,
"
I
heard
the
tinkler
.
<EOS>
"
Catching
up
the
light
,
he
crept
softly
upstairs
.
   
<EOS>
The
bell
was
rung
again
,
with
some
impatience
,
while
the
party
were
in
darkness
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
short
pause
,
the
Dodger
reappeared
,
and
whispered
Fagin
mysteriously
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
!
"
cried
the
Jew
,
"
alone
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
Dodger
nodded
in
the
affirmative
,
and
,
shading
the
flame
of
the
candle
with
his
hand
,
gave
Charley
Bates
a
private
intimation
,
in
dumb
show
,
that
he
had
better
not
be
funny
just
then
.
 
<EOS>
Having
performed
this
friendly
office
,
he
fixed
his
eyes
on
the
Jew
's
face
,
and
awaited
his
directions
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
man
bit
his
yellow
fingers
,
and
meditated
for
some
seconds
;
his
face
working
with
agitation
the
while
,
as
if
he
dreaded
something
,
and
feared
to
know
the
worst
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
he
raised
his
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
is
he
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
.
   
<EOS>
The
Dodger
pointed
to
the
floor
above
,
and
made
a
gesture
,
as
if
to
leave
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
the
Jew
,
answering
the
mute
inquiry
;
"
bring
him
down
.
   
<EOS>
Hush
!
 
<EOS>
Quiet
,
Charley
!
 
<EOS>
Gently
,
Tom
!
 
<EOS>
Scarce
,
scarce
!
"
   
<EOS>
This
brief
direction
to
Charley
Bates
,
and
his
recent
antagonist
,
was
softly
and
immediately
obeyed
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
sound
of
their
whereabout
,
when
the
Dodger
descended
the
stairs
,
bearing
the
light
in
his
hand
,
and
followed
by
a
man
in
a
coarse
smock
-
frock
;
who
,
after
casting
a
hurried
glance
round
the
room
,
pulled
off
a
large
wrapper
which
had
concealed
the
lower
portion
of
his
face
,
and
disclosed
:
all
haggard
,
unwashed
,
and
unshorn
:
the
features
of
flash
Toby
Crackit
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
are
you
,
Faguey
?
"
said
this
worthy
,
nodding
to
the
Jew
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Pop
that
shawl
away
in
my
castor
,
Dodger
,
so
that
I
may
know
where
to
find
it
when
I
cut
;
that
's
the
time
of
day
!
 
<EOS>
You
'll
be
a
fine
young
cracksman
<EOS>
afore
the
old
file
now
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
With
these
words
he
pulled
up
the
smock
-
frock
;
and
,
winding
it
round
his
middle
,
drew
a
chair
to
the
fire
,
and
placed
his
feet
upon
the
hob
.
   
<EOS>
"
See
there
,
Faguey
,
"
he
said
,
pointing
disconsolately
to
his
top
boots
;
"
not
a
drop
of
Day
and
Martin
since
you
know
when
;
not
a
bubble
of
blacking
,
by
Jove
!
  
<EOS>
But
do
n't
look
at
me
in
that
way
,
man
.
 
<EOS>
All
in
good
time
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
talk
about
business
till
I
've
eat
and
drank
;
so
produce
the
sustainance
,
and
let
's
have
a
quiet
fill
-
out
for
the
first
time
these
three
days
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
Jew
motioned
to
the
Dodger
to
place
what
eatables
there
were
,
upon
the
table
;
and
,
seating
himself
opposite
the
housebreaker
,
waited
his
leisure
.
   
<EOS>
To
judge
from
appearances
,
Toby
was
by
no
means
in
a
hurry
to
open
the
conversation
.
 
<EOS>
At
first
,
the
Jew
contented
himself
with
patiently
watching
his
countenance
,
as
if
to
gain
from
its
expression
some
clue
to
the
intelligence
he
brought
;
but
in
vain
.
   
<EOS>
He
looked
tired
and
worn
,
but
there
was
the
same
complacent
repose
upon
his
features
that
they
always
wore
:
 
and
through
dirt
,
and
beard
,
and
whisker
,
there
still
shone
,
unimpaired
,
the
self
-
satisfied
smirk
of
flash
Toby
Crackit
.
<EOS>
Then
the
Jew
,
in
an
agony
of
impatience
,
watched
every
morsel
he
put
into
his
mouth
;
pacing
up
and
down
the
room
,
meanwhile
,
in
irrepressible
excitement
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
all
of
no
use
.
 
<EOS>
Toby
continued
to
eat
with
the
utmost
outward
indifference
,
until
he
could
eat
no
more
;
then
,
ordering
the
Dodger
out
,
he
closed
the
door
,
mixed
a
glass
of
spirits
and
water
,
and
composed
himself
for
talking
.
   
<EOS>
"
First
and
foremost
,
Faguey
,
"
said
Toby
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
!
"
interposed
the
Jew
,
drawing
up
his
chair
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Crackit
stopped
to
take
a
draught
of
spirits
and
water
,
and
to
declare
that
the
gin
was
excellent
;
then
placing
his
feet
against
the
low
mantelpiece
,
so
as
to
bring
his
boots
to
about
the
level
of
his
eye
,
he
quietly
resumed
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
First
and
foremost
,
Faguey
,
"
said
the
housebreaker
,
"
how
's
Bill
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
!
"
screamed
the
Jew
,
starting
from
his
seat
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
do
n't
mean
to
say
---
"
began
Toby
,
turning
pale
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mean
!
<EOS>
"
cried
the
Jew
,
stamping
furiously
on
the
ground
.
<EOS>
"
Where
are
they
?
 
<EOS>
Sikes
and
the
boy
!
 
<EOS>
Where
are
they
?
 
<EOS>
Where
have
they
been
?
 
<EOS>
Where
are
they
hiding
?
 
<EOS>
Why
have
they
not
been
here
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
crack
failed
,
"
said
Toby
faintly
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
it
,
"
replied
the
Jew
,
tearing
a
newspaper
from
his
pocket
and
pointing
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
more
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
They
fired
and
hit
the
boy
.
 
<EOS>
We
cut
over
the
fields
at
the
back
,
with
him
between
us
---
straight
as
the
crow
flies
---
through
hedge
and
ditch
.
 
<EOS>
They
gave
chase
.
 
<EOS>
Damme
!
<EOS>
the
whole
country
was
awake
,
and
the
dogs
upon
us
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
boy
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Bill
had
him
on
his
back
,
and
scudded
like
the
wind
.
 
<EOS>
We
stopped
to
take
him
between
us
;
his
head
hung
down
,
and
he
was
cold
.
<EOS>
They
were
close
upon
our
heels
;
every
man
for
himself
,
and
each
from
the
gallows
!
 
<EOS>
We
parted
company
,
and
left
the
youngster
lying
in
a
ditch
.
 
<EOS>
Alive
or
dead
,
that
's
all
I
know
about
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
Jew
stopped
to
hear
no
more
;
but
uttering
a
loud
yell
,
and
twining
his
hands
in
his
hair
,
rushed
from
the
room
,
and
from
the
house
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
26
.
<EOS>
In
which
a
mysterious
character
appears
upon
the
scene
;
and
many
things
,
inseparable
from
this
history
,
are
done
and
performed
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
man
had
gained
the
street
corner
,
before
he
began
to
recover
the
effect
of
Toby
Crackit
's
intelligence
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
relaxed
nothing
of
his
unusual
speed
;
but
was
still
pressing
onward
,
in
the
same
wild
and
disordered
manner
,
when
the
sudden
dashing
past
of
a
carriage
:
and
a
boisterous
cry
from
the
foot
passengers
,
who
saw
his
danger
:
 
drove
him
back
upon
the
pavement
.
 
<EOS>
Avoiding
,
as
much
as
was
possible
,
all
the
main
streets
,
and
skulking
only
through
the
by
-
ways
and
alleys
,
he
at
length
emerged
on
Snow
Hill
.
 
<EOS>
Here
he
walked
even
faster
than
before
;
nor
did
he
linger
until
he
had
again
turned
into
a
court
;
when
,
as
if
conscious
that
he
was
now
in
his
proper
element
,
he
fell
into
his
usual
shuffling
pace
,
and
seemed
to
breathe
more
freely
.
   
<EOS>
Near
to
the
spot
on
which
Snow
Hill
and
Holborn
Hill
meet
,
opens
,
upon
the
right
hand
as
you
come
out
of
the
City
,
a
narrow
and
dismal
alley
,
leading
to
Saffron
Hill
.
 
<EOS>
In
its
filthy
shops
are
exposed
for
sale
huge
bunches
of
second
-
hand
silk
handkerchiefs
,
of
all
sizes
and
patterns
;
for
here
reside
the
traders
who
purchase
them
from
pick
-
pockets
.
 
<EOS>
Hundreds
of
these
handkerchiefs
hang
dangling
from
pegs
outside
the
windows
or
flaunting
from
the
door
-
posts
;
and
the
shelves
,
within
,
are
piled
with
them
.
<EOS>
Confined
as
the
limits
of
Field
Lane
are
,
it
has
its
barber
,
its
coffee
-
shop
,
its
beer
-
shop
,
and
its
fried
-
fish
warehouse
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
commercial
colony
of
itself
:
 
the
emporium
of
petty
larceny
:
visited
at
early
morning
,
and
setting
-
in
of
dusk
,
by
silent
merchants
,
who
traffic
in
dark
back
-
parlours
,
and
who
go
as
strangely
as
they
come
.
 
<EOS>
Here
,
the
clothesman
,
the
shoe
-
vamper
,
and
the
rag
-
merchant
,
display
their
goods
,
as
sign
-
boards
to
the
petty
thief
;
here
,
stores
of
old
iron
and
bones
,
and
heaps
of
mildewy
fragments
of
woollen
-
stuff
and
linen
,
rust
and
rot
in
the
grimy
cellars
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
into
this
place
that
the
Jew
turned
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
well
known
to
the
sallow
denizens
of
the
lane
;
for
such
of
them
as
were
on
the
look
-
out
to
buy
or
sell
,
nodded
,
familiarly
,
as
he
passed
along
.
<EOS>
He
replied
to
their
salutations
in
the
same
way
;
but
bestowed
no
closer
recognition
until
he
reached
the
further
end
of
the
alley
;
when
he
stopped
,
to
address
a
salesman
of
small
stature
,
who
had
squeezed
as
much
of
his
person
into
a
child
's
chair
as
the
chair
would
hold
,
and
was
smoking
a
pipe
at
his
warehouse
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
the
sight
of
you
,
Mr
Fagin
,
would
cure
the
hoptalymy
!
"
said
this
respectable
trader
,
in
acknowledgment
of
the
Jew
's
inquiry
after
his
health
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
neighbourhood
was
a
little
too
hot
,
Lively
,
"
said
Fagin
,
elevating
his
eyebrows
,
and
crossing
his
hands
upon
his
shoulders
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
I
've
heerd
that
complaint
of
it
,
once
or
twice
before
,
"
replied
the
trader
;
"
but
it
soon
cools
down
again
;
do
n't
you
find
it
so
?
"
   
<EOS>
Fagin
nodded
in
the
affirmative
.
 
<EOS>
Pointing
in
the
direction
of
Saffron
Hill
,
he
inquired
whether
any
one
was
up
yonder
to
-
night
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
At
the
Cripples
?
"
inquired
the
man
.
   
<EOS>
The
Jew
nodded
.
   
<EOS>
"
Let
me
see
,
"
pursued
the
merchant
,
reflecting
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
there
's
some
half
-
dozen
of
'em
gone
in
,
that
I
knows
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
think
your
friend
's
there
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sikes
is
not
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
the
Jew
,
with
a
disappointed
countenance
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Non
istwentus
,
as
the
lawyers
say
,
"
replied
the
little
man
,
shaking
his
head
,
and
looking
amazingly
sly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
you
got
anything
in
my
line
to
-
night
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
to
-
night
,
"
said
the
Jew
,
turning
away
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
going
up
to
the
Cripples
,
Fagin
?
<EOS>
"
cried
the
little
man
,
calling
after
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Stop
!
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
mind
if
I
have
a
drop
there
with
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
But
as
the
Jew
,
looking
back
,
waved
his
hand
to
intimate
that
he
preferred
being
alone
;
and
,
moreover
,
as
the
little
man
could
not
very
easily
disengage
himself
from
the
chair
;
the
sign
of
the
Cripples
was
,
for
a
time
,
bereft
of
the
advantage
of
Mr
Lively
's
presence
.
 
<EOS>
By
the
time
he
had
got
upon
his
legs
,
the
Jew
had
disappeared
;
so
Mr
Lively
,
after
ineffectually
standing
on
tiptoe
,
in
the
hope
of
catching
sight
of
him
,
again
forced
himself
into
the
little
chair
,
and
,
exchanging
a
shake
of
the
head
with
a
lady
in
the
opposite
shop
,
in
which
doubt
and
mistrust
were
plainly
mingled
,
resumed
his
pipe
with
a
grave
demeanour
.
   
<EOS>
The
Three
Cripples
,
or
rather
the
Cripples
;
which
was
the
sign
by
which
the
establishment
was
familiarly
known
to
its
patrons
:
 
was
the
public
-
house
in
which
Mr
Sikes
and
his
dog
have
already
figured
.
 
<EOS>
Merely
making
a
sign
to
a
man
at
the
bar
,
Fagin
walked
straight
upstairs
,
and
opening
the
door
of
a
room
,
and
softly
insinuating
himself
into
the
chamber
,
looked
anxiously
about
:
shading
his
eyes
with
his
hand
,
as
if
in
search
of
some
particular
person
.
   
<EOS>
The
room
was
illuminated
by
two
gas
-
lights
;
the
glare
of
which
was
prevented
by
the
barred
shutters
,
and
closely
-
drawn
curtains
of
faded
red
,
from
being
visible
outside
.
 
<EOS>
The
ceiling
was
blackened
,
to
prevent
its
colour
from
being
injured
by
the
flaring
of
the
lamps
;
and
the
place
was
so
full
of
dense
tobacco
smoke
,
that
at
first
it
was
scarcely
possible
to
discern
anything
more
.
 
<EOS>
By
degrees
,
however
,
as
some
of
it
cleared
away
through
the
open
door
,
an
assemblage
of
heads
,
as
confused
as
the
noises
that
greeted
the
ear
,
might
be
made
out
;
and
as
the
eye
grew
more
accustomed
to
the
scene
,
the
spectator
gradually
became
aware
of
the
presence
of
a
numerous
company
,
male
and
female
<EOS>
,
crowded
round
a
long
table
:
at
the
upper
end
of
which
,
sat
a
chairman
with
a
hammer
of
office
in
his
hand
;
while
a
professional
gentleman
with
a
bluish
nose
,
and
his
face
tied
up
for
the
benefit
of
a
toothache
,
presided
at
a
jingling
piano
in
a
remote
corner
.
   
<EOS>
As
Fagin
stepped
softly
in
,
the
professional
gentleman
,
running
over
the
keys
by
way
of
prelude
,
occasioned
a
general
cry
of
order
for
a
song
;
which
having
subsided
,
a
young
lady
proceeded
to
entertain
the
company
with
a
ballad
in
four
verses
,
between
each
of
which
the
accompanyist
played
the
melody
all
through
,
as
loud
as
he
could
.
 
<EOS>
When
this
was
over
,
the
chairman
gave
a
sentiment
,
after
which
,
the
professional
gentleman
on
the
chairman
's
right
and
left
volunteered
a
duet
,
and
sang
it
,
with
great
applause
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
curious
to
observe
some
faces
which
stood
out
prominently
from
among
the
group
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
the
chairman
himself
,
(
the
landlord
of
the
house
,
)
a
coarse
,
rough
,
heavy
built
fellow
,
who
,
while
the
songs
were
proceeding
,
rolled
his
eyes
hither
and
thither
,
and
,
seeming
to
give
himself
up
to
joviality
,
had
an
eye
for
everything
that
was
done
,
and
an
ear
for
everything
that
was
said
---
and
sharp
ones
,
too
.
 
<EOS>
Near
him
were
the
singers
:
<EOS>
receiving
,
with
professional
indifference
,
the
compliments
of
the
company
,
and
applying
themselves
,
in
turn
,
to
a
dozen
proffered
glasses
of
spirits
and
water
,
tendered
by
their
more
boisterous
admirers
;
whose
countenances
,
expressive
of
almost
every
vice
in
almost
every
grade
,
irresistibly
attracted
the
attention
,
by
their
very
repulsiveness
.
 
<EOS>
Cunning
,
ferocity
,
and
drunkeness
in
all
its
stages
,
were
there
,
in
their
strongest
aspect
;
and
women
:
   
some
with
the
last
lingering
tinge
of
their
early
freshness
almost
fading
as
you
looked
:
 
others
with
every
mark
and
stamp
of
their
sex
utterly
beaten
out
,
and
presenting
but
one
loathsome
blank
of
profligacy
and
crime
;
some
mere
girls
,
others
but
young
women
,
and
none
past
the
prime
of
life
;
formed
the
darkest
and
saddest
portion
of
this
dreary
picture
.
   
<EOS>
Fagin
,
troubled
by
no
grave
emotions
,
looked
eagerly
from
face
to
face
while
these
proceedings
were
in
progress
;
but
apparently
without
meeting
that
of
which
he
was
in
search
.
<EOS>
Succeeding
,
at
length
,
in
catching
the
eye
of
the
man
who
occupied
the
chair
,
he
beckoned
to
him
slightly
,
and
left
the
room
,
as
quietly
as
he
had
entered
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
can
I
do
for
you
,
Mr
Fagin
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
the
man
,
as
he
followed
him
out
to
the
landing
.
 
<EOS>
"
Wo
n't
you
join
us
?
 
<EOS>
They
'll
be
delighted
,
every
one
of
'
em
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
Jew
shook
his
head
impatiently
,
and
said
in
a
whisper
,
"
Is
HE
here
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
the
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
no
news
of
Barney
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Fagin
.
   
<EOS>
"
None
,
"
replied
the
landlord
of
the
Cripples
;
for
it
was
he
.
"
<EOS>
He
wo
n't
stir
till
it
's
all
safe
.
 
<EOS>
Depend
on
it
,
they
're
on
the
scent
down
there
;
and
that
if
he
moved
,
he
'd
blow
upon
the
thing
at
once
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
all
right
enough
,
Barney
is
,
else
I
should
have
heard
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
pound
it
,
that
Barney
's
managing
properly
.
<EOS>
Let
him
alone
for
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Will
HE
be
here
to
-
night
?
"
<EOS>
asked
the
Jew
,
laying
the
same
emphasis
on
the
pronoun
as
before
.
   
<EOS>
"
Monks
,
do
you
mean
?
"
inquired
the
landlord
,
hesitating
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
"
said
the
Jew
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certain
,
"
replied
the
man
,
drawing
a
gold
watch
from
his
fob
;
"
I
expected
him
here
before
now
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
'll
wait
ten
minutes
,
he
'll
be
---
"
   
"
No
,
no
,
"
said
the
Jew
,
hastily
;
as
though
,
however
desirous
he
might
be
to
see
the
person
in
question
,
he
was
nevertheless
relieved
by
his
absence
.
 
<EOS>
"
Tell
him
I
came
here
to
see
him
;
and
that
he
must
come
to
me
to
-
night
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
say
to
-
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
is
not
here
,
to
-
morrow
will
be
time
enough
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
!
"
said
the
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
Nothing
more
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a
word
now
,
"
said
the
Jew
,
descending
the
stairs
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
"
said
the
other
,
looking
over
the
rails
,
and
speaking
in
a
hoarse
whisper
;
"
what
a
time
this
would
be
for
a
sell
!
 
<EOS>
I
've
got
Phil
Barker
here
:
<EOS>
so
drunk
,
that
a
boy
might
take
him
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
But
it
's
not
Phil
Barker
's
time
,
"
said
the
Jew
,
looking
up
.
   
<EOS>
"
Phil
has
something
more
to
do
,
before
we
can
afford
to
part
with
him
;
so
go
back
to
the
company
,
my
dear
,
and
tell
them
to
lead
merry
lives
---
WHILE
THEY
LAST
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
landlord
reciprocated
the
old
man
's
laugh
;
and
returned
to
his
guests
.
 
<EOS>
The
Jew
was
no
sooner
alone
,
than
his
countenance
resumed
its
former
expression
of
anxiety
and
thought
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
brief
reflection
,
he
called
a
hack
-
cabriolet
,
and
bade
the
man
drive
towards
Bethnal
Green
.
<EOS>
He
dismissed
him
within
some
quarter
of
a
mile
of
Mr
Sikes
's
residence
,
and
performed
the
short
remainder
of
the
distance
,
on
foot
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
muttered
the
Jew
,
as
he
knocked
at
the
door
,
"
if
there
is
any
deep
play
here
,
I
shall
have
it
out
of
you
,
my
girl
,
cunning
as
you
are
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
was
in
her
room
,
the
woman
said
.
 
<EOS>
Fagin
crept
softly
upstairs
,
and
entered
it
without
any
previous
ceremony
.
 
<EOS>
The
girl
was
alone
;
lying
with
her
head
upon
the
table
,
and
her
hair
straggling
over
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
has
been
drinking
,
"
thought
the
Jew
,
coolly
,
"
or
perhaps
she
is
only
miserable
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
old
man
turned
to
close
the
door
,
as
he
made
this
reflection
;
the
noise
thus
occasioned
,
roused
the
girl
.
 
<EOS>
She
eyed
his
crafty
face
narrowly
,
as
she
inquired
to
his
recital
of
Toby
Crackit
's
story
.
 
<EOS>
When
it
was
concluded
,
she
sank
into
her
former
attitude
,
but
spoke
not
a
word
.
 
<EOS>
She
pushed
the
candle
impatiently
away
;
and
once
or
twice
as
she
feverishly
changed
her
position
,
shuffled
her
feet
upon
the
ground
;
but
this
was
all
.
   
<EOS>
During
the
silence
,
the
Jew
looked
restlessly
about
the
room
,
as
if
to
assure
himself
that
there
were
no
appearances
of
Sikes
having
covertly
returned
.
 
<EOS>
Apparently
satisfied
with
his
inspection
,
he
coughed
twice
or
thrice
,
and
made
as
many
efforts
to
open
a
conversation
;
but
the
girl
heeded
him
no
more
than
if
he
had
been
made
of
stone
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
he
made
another
attempt
;
and
rubbing
his
hands
together
,
said
,
in
his
most
concilitory
tone
,
   
"
<EOS>
And
where
should
you
think
Bill
was
now
,
my
dear
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
girl
moaned
out
some
half
intelligible
reply
,
that
she
could
not
tell
;
and
seemed
,
from
the
smothered
noise
that
escaped
her
,
to
be
crying
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
the
boy
,
too
,
"
said
the
Jew
,
straining
his
eyes
to
catch
a
glimpse
of
her
face
.
 
<EOS>
"
Poor
leetle
child
!
 
<EOS>
Left
in
a
ditch
,
Nance
;
only
think
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
child
,
"
said
the
girl
,
suddenly
looking
up
,
"
is
better
where
he
is
,
than
among
us
;
and
if
no
harm
comes
to
Bill
from
it
,
I
hope
he
lies
dead
in
the
ditch
and
that
his
young
bones
may
rot
there
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
!
"
cried
the
Jew
,
in
amazement
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
I
do
,
"
returned
the
girl
,
meeting
his
gaze
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
glad
to
have
him
away
from
my
eyes
,
and
to
know
that
the
worst
is
over
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
bear
to
have
him
about
me
.
 
<EOS>
The
sight
of
him
turns
me
against
myself
,
and
all
of
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pooh
!
"
said
the
Jew
,
scornfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
're
drunk
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Am
I
?
"
<EOS>
cried
the
girl
bitterly
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
no
fault
of
yours
,
if
I
am
not
!
 
<EOS>
You
'd
never
have
me
anything
else
,
if
you
had
your
will
,
except
now
;
---
the
humour
does
n't
suit
you
,
does
n't
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
rejoined
the
Jew
,
furiously
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
does
not
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Change
it
,
then
!
<EOS>
"
responded
the
girl
,
with
a
laugh
.
   
<EOS>
"
Change
it
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
Jew
,
exasperated
beyond
all
bounds
by
his
companion
's
unexpected
obstinacy
,
and
the
vexation
of
the
night
,
"
I
WILL
change
it
!
 
<EOS>
Listen
to
me
,
you
drab
.
 
<EOS>
Listen
to
me
,
who
with
six
words
,
can
strangle
Sikes
as
surely
as
if
I
had
his
bull
's
throat
between
my
fingers
now
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
comes
back
,
and
leaves
the
boy
behind
him
;
if
he
gets
off
free
,
and
dead
or
alive
,
fails
to
restore
him
to
me
;
murder
him
yourself
if
you
would
have
him
escape
Jack
Ketch
.
 
<EOS>
And
do
it
the
moment
he
sets
foot
in
this
room
,
or
mind
me
,
it
will
be
too
late
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
all
this
?
"
<EOS>
cried
the
girl
involuntarily
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
?
"
pursued
Fagin
,
mad
with
rage
.
 
<EOS>
"
When
the
boy
's
worth
hundreds
of
pounds
to
me
,
am
I
to
lose
what
chance
threw
me
in
the
way
of
getting
safely
,
through
the
whims
of
a
drunken
gang
that
I
could
whistle
away
the
lives
of
!
 
<EOS>
And
me
bound
,
too
,
to
a
born
devil
that
only
wants
the
will
,
and
has
the
power
to
,
to
---
"
   
Panting
for
breath
,
<EOS>
the
old
man
stammered
for
a
word
;
and
in
that
instant
checked
the
torrent
of
his
wrath
,
and
changed
his
whole
demeanour
.
 
<EOS>
A
moment
before
,
his
clenched
hands
had
grasped
the
air
;
his
eyes
had
dilated
;
and
his
face
grown
livid
with
passion
;
but
now
,
he
shrunk
into
a
chair
,
and
,
cowering
together
,
trembled
with
the
apprehension
of
having
himself
disclosed
some
hidden
villainy
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
short
silence
,
he
ventured
to
look
round
at
his
companion
.
 
<EOS>
He
appeared
somewhat
reassured
,
on
beholding
her
in
the
same
listless
attitude
from
which
he
had
first
roused
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nancy
,
dear
!
"
croaked
the
Jew
,
in
his
usual
voice
.
 
<EOS>
"
Did
you
mind
me
,
dear
?
"
   
"
Do
n't
worry
me
now
,
Fagin
!
"
replied
the
girl
,
raising
her
head
languidly
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
Bill
has
not
done
it
this
time
,
he
will
another
.
<EOS>
He
has
done
many
a
good
job
for
you
,
and
will
do
many
more
when
he
can
;
and
when
he
ca
n't
he
wo
n't
;
so
no
more
about
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Regarding
this
boy
,
my
dear
?
"
said
the
Jew
,
rubbing
the
palms
of
his
hands
nervously
together
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
boy
must
take
his
chance
with
the
rest
,
"
interrupted
Nancy
,
hastily
;
"
and
I
say
again
<EOS>
,
I
hope
he
is
dead
,
and
out
of
harm
's
way
,
and
out
of
yours
,
---
that
is
,
if
Bill
comes
to
no
harm
.
 
<EOS>
And
if
Toby
got
clear
off
,
Bill
's
pretty
sure
to
be
safe
;
for
Bill
's
worth
two
of
Toby
any
time
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
about
what
I
was
saying
,
my
dear
?
"
observed
the
Jew
,
keeping
his
glistening
eye
steadily
upon
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Your
must
say
it
all
over
again
,
if
it
's
anything
you
want
me
to
do
,
"
rejoined
Nancy
;
"
and
if
it
is
,
you
had
better
wait
till
to
-
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
You
put
me
up
for
a
minute
;
but
now
I
'm
stupid
again
.
"
   
<EOS>
Fagin
put
several
other
questions
:
all
with
the
same
drift
of
ascertaining
whether
the
girl
had
profited
by
his
unguarded
hints
;
but
,
she
answered
them
so
readily
,
and
was
withal
so
utterly
unmoved
by
his
searching
looks
,
that
his
original
impression
of
her
being
more
than
a
trifle
in
liquor
,
was
confirmed
.
 
<EOS>
Nancy
,
indeed
,
was
not
exempt
from
a
failing
which
was
very
common
among
the
Jew
's
female
pupils
;
and
in
which
,
in
their
tenderer
years
,
they
were
rather
encouraged
than
checked
.
<EOS>
Her
disordered
appearance
,
and
a
wholesale
perfume
of
Geneva
which
pervaded
the
apartment
,
afforded
stong
confirmatory
evidence
of
the
justice
of
the
Jew
's
supposition
;
and
when
,
after
indulging
in
the
temporary
display
of
violence
above
described
,
she
subsided
,
first
into
dullness
,
and
afterwards
into
a
compound
of
feelings
:
<EOS>
under
the
influence
of
which
she
shed
tears
one
minute
,
and
in
the
next
gave
utterance
to
various
exclamations
of
"
Never
say
die
!
"
and
divers
calculations
as
to
what
might
be
the
amount
of
the
odds
so
long
as
a
lady
or
gentleman
was
happy
,
Mr
Fagin
,
who
had
had
considerable
experience
of
such
matters
in
his
time
,
saw
,
with
great
satisfaction
,
that
she
was
very
far
gone
indeed
.
   
<EOS>
Having
eased
his
mind
by
this
discovery
;
and
having
accomplished
his
twofold
object
of
imparting
to
the
girl
what
he
had
,
that
night
,
heard
,
and
of
ascertaining
,
with
his
own
eyes
,
that
Sikes
had
not
returned
,
Mr
Fagin
again
turned
his
face
homeward
:
leaving
his
young
friend
asleep
,
with
her
head
upon
the
table
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
within
an
hour
of
midnight
.
 
<EOS>
The
weather
being
dark
,
and
piercing
cold
,
he
had
no
great
temptation
to
loiter
.
 
<EOS>
The
sharp
wind
that
scoured
the
streets
,
seemed
to
have
cleared
them
of
passengers
,
as
of
dust
and
mud
,
for
few
people
were
abroad
,
and
they
were
to
all
appearance
hastening
fast
home
.
<EOS>
It
blew
from
the
right
quarter
for
the
Jew
,
however
,
and
straight
before
it
he
went
:
trembling
,
and
shivering
,
as
every
fresh
gust
drove
him
rudely
on
his
way
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
reached
the
corner
of
his
own
street
,
and
was
already
fumbling
in
his
pocket
for
the
door
-
key
,
when
a
dark
figure
emerged
from
a
projecting
entrance
which
lay
in
deep
shadow
,
and
,
crossing
the
road
,
glided
up
to
him
unperceived
.
   
<EOS>
"
Fagin
!
"
whispered
a
voice
close
to
his
ear
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
Jew
,
turning
quickly
round
,
"
is
that
---
"
   
"
Yes
!
<EOS>
"
interrupted
the
stranger
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
lingering
here
these
two
hours
.
 
<EOS>
Where
the
devil
have
you
been
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
On
your
business
,
my
dear
,
"
replied
the
Jew
,
glancing
uneasily
at
his
companion
,
and
slackening
his
pace
as
he
spoke
.
 
<EOS>
"
On
your
business
all
night
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
of
course
!
"
said
the
stranger
,
with
a
sneer
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
;
and
what
's
come
of
it
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
good
,
"
said
the
Jew
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
bad
<EOS>
,
I
hope
?
"
said
the
stranger
,
stopping
short
,
and
turning
a
startled
look
on
his
companion
.
   
<EOS>
The
Jew
shook
his
head
,
and
was
about
to
reply
,
when
the
stranger
,
interrupting
him
,
motioned
to
the
house
,
before
which
they
had
by
this
time
arrived
:
 
remarking
,
that
he
had
better
say
what
he
had
got
to
say
,
under
cover
:
 
for
his
blood
was
chilled
with
standing
about
so
long
,
and
the
wind
blew
through
him
.
   
<EOS>
Fagin
looked
as
if
he
could
have
willingly
excused
himself
from
taking
home
a
visitor
at
that
unseasonable
hour
;
and
,
indeed
,
muttered
something
about
having
no
fire
;
but
his
companion
repeating
his
request
in
a
peremptory
manner
,
he
unlocked
the
door
,
and
requested
him
to
close
it
softly
,
while
he
got
a
light
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
as
dark
as
the
grave
,
"
said
the
man
,
groping
forward
a
few
steps
.
 
<EOS>
"
Make
haste
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Shut
the
door
,
"
whispered
Fagin
from
the
end
of
the
passage
.
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
,
it
closed
with
a
loud
noise
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
was
n't
my
doing
,
"
said
the
other
man
,
feeling
his
way
.
<EOS>
"
The
wind
blew
it
to
,
or
it
shut
of
its
own
accord
:
one
or
the
other
.
<EOS>
Look
sharp
with
the
light
,
or
I
shall
knock
my
brains
out
against
something
in
this
confounded
hole
.
"
   
<EOS>
Fagin
stealthily
descended
the
kitchen
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
short
absence
,
he
returned
with
a
lighted
candle
,
and
the
intelligence
that
Toby
Crackit
was
asleep
in
the
back
room
below
,
and
that
the
boys
were
in
the
front
one
.
 
<EOS>
Beckoning
the
man
to
follow
him
,
he
led
the
way
upstairs
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
can
say
the
few
words
we
've
got
to
say
in
here
,
my
dear
,
"
said
the
Jew
,
throwing
open
a
door
on
the
first
floor
;
"
and
as
there
are
holes
in
the
shutters
,
and
we
never
show
lights
to
our
neighbours
,
we
'll
set
the
candle
on
the
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
There
!
"
   
With
those
words
,
the
Jew
,
stooping
down
,
placed
the
candle
on
an
upper
flight
of
stairs
,
exactly
opposite
to
the
room
door
.
 
<EOS>
This
done
,
he
led
the
way
into
the
apartment
;
which
was
destitute
of
all
movables
save
a
broken
arm
-
chair
,
and
an
old
couch
or
sofa
without
covering
,
which
stood
behind
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
this
piece
of
furniture
,
the
stranger
sat
himself
with
the
air
of
a
weary
man
;
and
the
Jew
,
drawing
up
the
arm
-
chair
opposite
,
they
sat
face
to
face
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
quite
dark
;
the
door
was
partially
open
;
and
the
candle
outside
,
threw
a
feeble
reflection
on
the
opposite
wall
.
   
<EOS>
They
conversed
for
some
time
in
whispers
.
 
<EOS>
Though
nothing
of
the
conversation
was
distinguishable
beyond
a
few
disjointed
words
here
and
there
,
a
listener
might
easily
have
perceived
that
Fagin
appeared
to
be
defending
himself
against
some
remarks
of
the
stranger
;
and
that
the
latter
was
in
a
state
of
considerable
irritation
.
 
<EOS>
They
might
have
been
talking
,
thus
,
for
a
quarter
of
an
hour
or
more
,
when
Monks
---
by
which
name
the
Jew
had
designated
the
strange
man
several
times
in
the
course
of
their
colloquy
---
said
,
raising
his
voice
a
little
,
   
"
I
tell
you
again
,
it
was
badly
planned
.
 
<EOS>
Why
not
have
kept
him
here
among
the
rest
,
and
made
a
sneaking
,
snivelling
pickpocket
of
him
at
once
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Only
hear
him
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
Jew
,
shrugging
his
shoulders
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
do
you
mean
to
say
you
could
n't
have
done
it
,
if
you
had
chosen
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
Monks
,
sternly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
n't
you
done
it
,
with
other
boys
,
scores
of
times
?
 
<EOS>
If
you
had
had
patience
for
a
twelvemonth
,
at
most
,
could
n't
you
have
got
him
convicted
,
and
sent
safely
out
of
the
kingdom
;
perhaps
for
life
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Whose
turn
would
that
have
served
,
my
dear
?
"
inquired
the
Jew
humbly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mine
,
"
replied
Monks
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
not
mine
,
"
said
the
Jew
,
submissively
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
might
have
become
of
use
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
When
there
are
two
parties
to
a
bargain
,
it
is
only
reasonable
that
the
interests
of
both
should
be
consulted
;
is
it
,
my
good
friend
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
then
?
"
demanded
Monks
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
saw
it
was
not
easy
to
train
him
to
the
business
,
"
replied
the
Jew
;
"
he
was
not
like
other
boys
in
the
same
circumstances
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Curse
him
,
no
!
"
<EOS>
muttered
the
man
,
"
or
he
would
have
been
a
thief
,
long
ago
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
had
no
hold
upon
him
to
make
him
worse
,
"
pursued
the
Jew
,
anxiously
watching
the
countenance
of
his
companion
.
 
<EOS>
"
His
hand
was
not
in
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
nothing
to
frighten
him
with
;
which
we
always
must
have
in
the
beginning
,
or
we
labour
in
vain
.
 
<EOS>
What
could
I
do
?
 
<EOS>
Send
him
out
with
the
Dodger
and
Charley
?
 
<EOS>
We
had
enough
of
that
,
at
first
,
my
dear
;
I
trembled
for
us
all
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
THAT
was
not
my
doing
,
"
observed
Monks
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
my
dear
!
"
renewed
the
Jew
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
I
do
n't
quarrel
with
it
now
;
because
,
if
it
had
never
happened
,
you
might
never
have
clapped
eyes
on
the
boy
to
notice
him
,
and
so
led
to
the
discovery
that
it
was
him
you
were
looking
for
.
 
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
I
got
him
back
for
you
by
means
of
the
girl
;
and
then
SHE
begins
to
favour
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Throttle
the
girl
!
"
said
Monks
,
impatiently
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
we
ca
n't
afford
to
do
that
just
now
,
my
dear
,
"
replied
the
Jew
,
smiling
;
"
and
,
besides
,
that
sort
of
thing
is
not
in
our
way
;
or
,
one
of
these
days
,
I
might
be
glad
to
have
it
done
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
what
these
girls
are
,
Monks
,
well
.
 
<EOS>
As
soon
as
the
boy
begins
to
harden
,
she
'll
care
no
more
for
him
,
than
for
a
block
of
wood
.
 
<EOS>
You
want
him
made
a
thief
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
is
alive
,
I
can
make
him
one
from
this
time
;
and
,
if
---
if
---
"
said
the
Jew
,
drawing
nearer
to
the
other
,
<EOS>
---
"
it
's
not
likely
,
mind
,
---
but
if
the
worst
comes
to
the
worst
,
and
he
is
dead
<EOS>
---
"
   
"
It
's
no
fault
of
mine
if
he
is
!
"
<EOS>
interposed
the
other
man
,
with
a
look
of
terror
,
and
clasping
the
Jew
's
arm
with
trembling
hands
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mind
that
.
 
<EOS>
Fagin
!
 
<EOS>
I
had
no
hand
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
Anything
but
his
death
,
I
told
you
from
the
first
.
 
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
shed
blood
;
it
's
always
found
out
,
and
haunts
a
man
besides
.
 
<EOS>
If
they
shot
him
dead
,
I
was
not
the
cause
;
do
you
hear
me
?
 
<EOS>
Fire
this
infernal
den
!
 
<EOS>
What
's
that
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
!
"
cried
the
Jew
,
grasping
the
coward
round
the
body
,
with
both
arms
,
as
he
sprung
to
his
feet
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
?
"
   
"
Yonder
!
<EOS>
replied
the
man
,
glaring
at
the
opposite
wall
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
shadow
!
 
<EOS>
I
saw
the
shadow
of
a
woman
,
in
a
cloak
and
bonnet
,
pass
along
the
wainscot
like
a
breath
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
Jew
released
his
hold
,
and
they
rushed
tumultuously
from
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
The
candle
,
wasted
by
the
draught
,
was
standing
where
it
had
been
placed
.
 
<EOS>
It
showed
them
only
the
empty
staircase
,
and
their
own
white
faces
.
 
<EOS>
They
listened
intently
:
 
a
profound
silence
reigned
throughout
the
house
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
your
fancy
,
"
said
the
Jew
,
taking
up
the
light
and
turning
to
his
companion
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
swear
I
saw
it
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Monks
,
trembling
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
bending
forward
when
I
saw
it
first
;
and
when
I
spoke
,
it
darted
away
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
Jew
glanced
contemptuously
at
the
pale
face
of
his
associate
,
and
,
telling
him
he
could
follow
,
if
he
pleased
,
ascended
the
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
They
looked
into
all
the
rooms
;
they
were
cold
,
bare
,
and
empty
.
 
<EOS>
They
descended
into
the
passage
,
and
thence
into
the
cellars
below
.
 
<EOS>
The
green
damp
hung
upon
the
low
walls
;
the
tracks
of
the
snail
and
slug
glistened
in
the
light
of
the
candle
;
but
all
was
still
as
death
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
think
now
?
"
said
the
Jew
,
when
they
had
regained
the
passage
.
 
<EOS>
"
Besides
ourselves
,
there
's
not
a
creature
in
the
house
except
Toby
and
the
boys
;
and
they
're
safe
enough
.
<EOS>
See
here
!
"
   
<EOS>
As
a
proof
of
the
fact
,
the
Jew
drew
forth
two
keys
from
his
pocket
;
and
explained
,
that
when
he
first
went
downstairs
,
he
had
locked
them
in
,
to
prevent
any
intrusion
on
the
conference
.
   
<EOS>
This
accumulated
testimony
effectually
staggered
Mr
Monks
.
<EOS>
His
protestations
had
gradually
become
less
and
less
vehement
as
they
proceeded
in
their
search
without
making
any
discovery
;
and
,
now
,
he
gave
vent
to
several
very
grim
laughs
,
and
confessed
it
could
only
have
been
his
excited
imagination
.
 
<EOS>
He
declined
any
renewal
of
the
conversation
,
however
,
for
that
night
:
 
suddenly
remembering
that
it
was
past
one
o'clock
.
 
<EOS>
And
so
the
amiable
couple
parted
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
27
.
<EOS>
Atones
for
the
unpoliteness
of
a
former
chapter
;
which
deserted
a
lady
,
most
unceremoniously
.
 
<EOS>
As
it
would
be
,
by
no
means
,
seemly
in
a
humble
author
to
keep
so
mighty
a
personage
as
a
beadle
waiting
,
with
his
back
to
the
fire
,
and
the
skirts
of
his
coat
gathered
up
under
his
arms
,
until
such
time
as
it
might
suit
his
pleasure
to
relieve
him
;
and
as
it
would
still
less
become
his
station
,
or
his
gallentry
to
involve
in
the
same
neglect
a
lady
on
whom
that
beadle
had
looked
with
an
eye
of
tenderness
and
affection
,
and
in
whose
ear
he
had
whispered
sweet
words
,
which
,
coming
from
such
a
quarter
,
might
well
thrill
the
bosom
of
maid
or
matron
of
whatsoever
degree
;
<EOS>
the
historian
whose
pen
traces
these
words
---
trusting
that
he
knows
his
place
,
and
that
he
entertains
a
becoming
reverence
for
those
upon
earth
to
whom
high
and
important
authority
is
delegated
---
hastens
to
pay
them
that
respect
which
their
position
demands
,
and
to
treat
them
with
all
that
duteous
ceremony
which
their
exalted
rank
,
and
(
by
consequence
)
great
virtues
,
imperatively
claim
at
his
hands
.
 
<EOS>
Towards
this
end
,
indeed
,
he
had
purposed
to
introduce
,
in
this
place
,
a
dissertation
touching
the
divine
right
of
beadles
,
and
elucidative
of
the
position
,
that
a
beadle
can
do
no
wrong
:
 
which
could
not
fail
to
have
been
both
pleasurable
and
profitable
to
the
right
-
minded
reader
but
which
he
is
unfortunately
compelled
,
by
want
of
time
and
space
,
to
postpone
to
some
more
convenient
and
fitting
opportunity
;
on
the
arrival
of
which
,
he
will
be
prepared
to
show
,
that
a
beadle
properly
constituted
:
 
that
is
to
say
,
a
parochial
beadle
,
attached
to
a
parochail
workhouse
,
and
attending
in
his
official
capacity
the
parochial
church
:
 
is
,
in
right
and
virtue
of
his
office
,
possessed
of
all
the
excellences
and
best
qualities
of
humanity
;
and
that
to
none
of
those
excellences
,
can
mere
companies
'
beadles
,
or
court
-
of
-
law
beadles
,
or
even
chapel
-
of
-
ease
beadles
(
save
the
last
,
and
they
in
a
very
lowly
and
inferior
degree
)
,
lay
the
remotest
sustainable
claim
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
had
re
-
counted
the
teaspoons
<EOS>
,
re
-
weighed
the
sugar
-
tongs
,
made
a
closer
inspection
of
the
milk
-
pot
,
and
ascertained
to
a
nicety
the
exact
condition
of
the
furniture
,
down
to
the
very
horse
-
hair
seats
of
the
chairs
;
and
had
repeated
each
process
full
half
a
dozen
times
;
before
he
began
to
think
that
it
was
time
for
Mrs
Corney
to
return
.
<EOS>
Thinking
begets
thinking
;
as
there
were
no
sounds
of
Mrs
Corney
's
approach
,
it
occured
to
Mr
Bumble
that
it
would
be
an
innocent
and
virtuous
way
of
spending
the
time
,
if
he
were
further
to
allay
his
curiousity
by
a
cursory
glance
at
the
interior
of
Mrs
Corney
's
chest
of
drawers
.
   
<EOS>
Having
listened
at
the
keyhole
,
to
assure
himself
that
nobody
was
approaching
the
chamber
,
Mr
Bumble
,
beginning
at
the
bottom
,
proceeded
to
make
himself
acquainted
with
the
contents
of
the
three
long
drawers
:
which
,
being
filled
with
various
garments
of
good
fashion
and
texture
,
carefully
preserved
between
two
layers
of
old
newspapers
,
speckled
with
dried
lavender
:
seemed
to
yield
him
exceeding
satisfaction
.
 
<EOS>
Arriving
,
in
course
of
time
,
at
the
right
-
hand
corner
drawer
(
in
which
was
the
key
)
,
and
beholding
therein
a
small
padlocked
box
,
which
,
being
shaken
,
gave
forth
a
pleasant
sound
,
as
of
the
chinking
of
coin
,
Mr
Bumble
returned
with
a
stately
walk
to
the
fireplace
;
and
,
resuming
his
old
attitude
,
said
,
with
a
grave
and
determined
air
,
"
I
'll
do
it
!
"
<EOS>
He
followed
up
this
remarkable
declaration
,
by
shaking
his
head
in
a
waggish
manner
for
ten
minutes
,
as
though
he
were
remonstrating
with
himself
for
being
such
a
pleasant
dog
;
and
then
,
he
took
a
view
of
his
legs
in
profile
,
with
much
seeming
pleasure
and
interest
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
still
placidly
engaged
in
this
latter
survey
,
when
Mrs
Corney
,
hurrying
into
the
room
,
threw
herself
,
in
a
breathless
state
,
on
a
chair
by
the
fireside
,
and
covering
her
eyes
with
one
hand
,
placed
the
other
over
her
heart
,
and
gasped
for
breath
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Corney
,
"
said
Mr
Bumble
,
stooping
over
the
matron
,
"
what
is
this
,
ma'am
?
 
<EOS>
Has
anything
happened
,
ma'am
?
 
<EOS>
Pray
answer
me
:
<EOS>
I
'm
on
---
on
---
"
Mr
Bumble
,
in
his
alarm
,
could
not
immediately
think
of
the
word
"
tenterhooks
,
"
so
he
said
"
broken
bottles
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Mr
Bumble
!
<EOS>
"
cried
the
lady
,
"
I
have
been
so
dreadfully
put
out
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Put
out
,
ma'am
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Mr
Bumble
;
"
who
has
dared
to
---
?
 
<EOS>
I
know
!
"
said
Mr
Bumble
,
checking

,
with
native

,
"
this
is
them
wicious
paupers
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
dreadful
to
think

!
"
said
the
lady
,
shuddering
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
DON'T
think
of

,
ma'am
,
"
rejoined

Bumble
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
help

,
"

lady
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
take
something
,
ma'am
,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
A
little

the
wine
?
"
   
"
Not
for
the
world
!
"

Mrs
Corney
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
could
n't
,
---
<EOS>
oh
!
 
<EOS>
The
top
shelf
in
the
right
-
hand
corner
---
<EOS>
oh
!
"
 
<EOS>
Uttering
these
words
,
the
good
lady
pointed
,
distractedly
,
to
the
cupboard
,
and
underwent
a
convulsion
from
internal
spasms
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
rushed
to
the
closet
;
and
,
snatching
a
pint
green
-
glass
bottle
from
the
shelf
thus
incoherently
indicated
,
filled
a
tea
-
cup
with
its
contents
,
and
held
it
to
the
lady
's
lips
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
better
now
,
"
said
Mrs
Corney
,
falling
back
,
after
drinking
half
of
it
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
raised
his
eyes
piously
to
the
ceiling
in
thankfulness
;
and
,
bringing
them
down
again
to
the
brim
of
the
cup
,
lifted
it
to
his
nose
.
   
<EOS>
"
Peppermint
,
"
exclaimed
Mrs
Corney
,
in
a
faint
voice
,
smiling
gently
on
the
beadle
as
she
spoke
.
 
<EOS>
"
Try
it
!
 
<EOS>
There
's
a
little
---
a
little
something
else
in
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
tasted
the
medicine
with
a
doubtful
look
;
smacked
his
lips
;
took
another
taste
;
and
put
the
cup
down
empty
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
very
comforting
,
"
said
Mrs
Corney
.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
much
so
indeed
,
ma'am
,
"
said
the
beadle
.
 
<EOS>
As
he

,
he
drew
a
chair

the
matron
,
and
tenderly
inquired
what
had
happened
to

.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
"
replied
Mrs
Corney
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
a
foolish
,
excitable
,
weak
creetur
.
"
   
"
<EOS>
Not
weak
,
ma'am
,
"
retorted
Mr
Bumble
,
drawing
his
chair
a
little
closer
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
a
weak
creetur
,
Mrs
Corney
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
are
all
weak
creeturs
,
"
said
Mrs
Corney
,
laying
down
a
general
principle
.
   
<EOS>
"
So
we
are
,
"
said
the
beadle
.
   
<EOS>
Nothing
was
said
on
either
side
,
for
a
minute
or
two
afterwards
.
<EOS>
By
the
expiration
of
that
time
,
Mr
Bumble
had
illustrated

position
by
removing
his
left
arm
from

back

Mrs
Corney
's
chair
,
where

had

,
to
Mrs
Corney
's
aprong
-
string
,
round
which
is
gradually
became

.
   
<EOS>
"
We
are
all
weak
creeturs
,
"
said
Mr
Bumble
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Corney
sighed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
sigh
,
Mrs
Corney
,
"
said
Mr
Bumble
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
help
it
,
"
said
Mrs
Corney
.
 
<EOS>
And
she
sighed
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
very
comfortable
room
,
ma'am
,
"
said

Bumble
looking
round
.
 
<EOS>
"
Another
room
,
and
this
,

,
would
be
a
complete
thing
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
But

two
,
ma'am
,
"

Mr
Bumble
,
in
soft

.
<EOS>
"
Eh
,
Mrs
Corney
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Corney
drooped
her
head
,
when
the
beadle
said
this
;
the
beadle
drooped
his
,
to
get

of
Mrs
Corney
's

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Corney
,
with

propriety
,
turned

,
and
released

to
get
at
her
pocket
-

;
but

of
Mr

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
board
allows

coals
,

,

?
"
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
candles
,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Coals
,

,

house
-
rent
free
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Mrs
Corney
,
what
an
Angel
you
are
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
lady
was
not
proof
against
this
burst
of

.
 
<EOS>
She
sank
into
Mr
Bumble
's

;
and
that

in

,
imprinted
a

upon
her
chaste

.
   
<EOS>
"
Such
porochial
perfection
!
"

Bumble
,

.
<EOS>
"
You
know
that
Mr
Slout
is
worse
to
-
night
,
my
fascinator
?
"
   
"
Yes
,
"

Mrs
Corney
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
He
ca
n't
live
a
week
,

doctor

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He

;
his

cause

;

.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,

,
what

!
 
<EOS>
What

a

and

!
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Corney
sobbed
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
little
word
?
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
The
one

,
little
,

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ye
---

---

!
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
One

,
"
pursued

beadle
;
"
compose

for

.
 
<EOS>
When
is
it
to
come
off
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Corney
twice
essayed
to

:
 
and
twice
failed
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
summoning
up

,
she
threw
her
arms

Mr
Bumble
's
neck
,
and
said
,
it
might
be
as
soon
as
ever
he
pleased
,
and
that
he
was
"
a
irresistible
duck
.
"
   
<EOS>
Matters
being
thus
amicably
and
satisfactorily
arranged
,
the
contract
was

in
another
teacupful
of
the
peppermint
mixture
;
which
was
rendered
the
more
necessary
,
by
the
flutter
and

of
the
lady
's

.
 
<EOS>
While
it
was
being
disposed
of
,
she
acquainted
Mr
Bumble
with
the
old
woman
's

.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
good
,
"
said
that

,

;
"
I
'll
call

Sowerberry
's
as

,
and

to
send
to
-
morrow

.
 
<EOS>
Was
it
that
as
frightened

,
love
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
was

anything

,
dear
,
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
must

something
,
love
,
"
urged

Bumble
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Wo
n't

tell

own
B
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not

,
"

;
"
one

.
 
<EOS>
After

're
married
,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
After
we
're
married
!
"

Mr
Bumble
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
n't
any
impudence
from
any
of
them
<EOS>
male
paupers
as
---
"
   
"
No
,
no
,
love
!
"
<EOS>
interposed
the
lady
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
thought
it
was
,
"
continued
Mr
Bumble
;
"
if
I
thought
as
any
one
of
'em
had
dared
to
lift
his
wulgar

to
that
lovely

---
"
   
"
They
would
n't
have
dared
to
do

,
love
,
"
responded

lady
.
   
<EOS>
"
They
had
better
not
!
"
said
Mr
Bumble
,
clenching
