fist
.
<EOS>
"
Let
me
see
any
man
,
porochial
or
extra
-
porochial
,
as
would
presume
to
do
it
;
and
I
can
tell
him
that
he
would
n't
do
it
a
second
time
!
"
   
<EOS>
Unembellished
by
any
violence
of
gesticulation
,
this
might
have
seemed
no
very
high
compliment
to
the
lady
's
charms
;
but
,
as
Mr
Bumble
accompanied
the
threat
with
many
warlike
gestures
,
she
was
much
touched
with
this
proof
of
his
devotion
,
and
protested
,
with
great
admiration
,
that
he
was
indeed
a
dove
.
   
<EOS>
The
dove
then
turned
up
his
coat
-
collar
,
and
put
on
his
cocked
hat
;
and
,
having
exchanged
a
long
and
affectionate
embrace
with
his
future
partner
,
once
again
braved
the
cold
wind
of
the
night
:
merely
pausing
,
for
a
few
minutes
,
in
the
male
paupers
'
ward
,
to
abuse
them
a
little
,
with
the
view
of
satisfying
himself
that
he
could
fill
the
office
of
workhouse
-
master
with
needful
acerbity
.
<EOS>
Assured
of
his
qualifications
,
Mr
Bumble
left
the
building
with
a
light
heart
,
and
bright
visions
of
his
future
promotion
:
 
which
served
to
occupy
his
mind
until
he
reached
the
shop
of
the
undertaker
.
   
<EOS>
Now
,
Mr
and
Mrs
Sowerberry
having
gone
out
to
tea
and
supper
:
and
Noah
Claypole
not
being
at
any
time
disposed
to
take
upon
himself
a
greater
amount
of
physical
exertion
than
is
necessary
to
a
convenient
performance
of
the
two
functions
of
eating
and
drinking
,
the
shop
was
not
closed
,
although
it
was
past
the
usual
hour
of
shutting
-
up
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
tapped
with
his
cane
on
the
counter
several
times
;
but
,
attracting
no
attention
,
and
beholding
a
light
shining
through
the
glass
-
window
of
the
little
parlour
at
the
back
of
the
shop
,
he
made
bold
to
peep
in
and
see
what
was
going
forward
;
and
when
he
saw
what
was
going
forward
,
he
was
not
a
little
surprised
.
   
<EOS>
The
cloth
was
laid
for
supper
;
the
table
was
covered
with
bread
and
butter
,
plates
and
glasses
;
a
porter
-
pot
and
a
wine
-
bottle
.
<EOS>
At
the
upper
end
of
the
table
,
Mr
Noah
Claypole
lolled
negligently
in
an
easy
-
chair
,
with
his
legs
thrown
over
one
of
the
arms
:
an
open
clasp
-
knife
in
one
hand
,
and
a
mass
of
buttered
bread
in
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
Close
beside
him
stood
Charlotte
,
opening
oysters
from
a
barrel
:
which
Mr
Claypole
condescended
to
swallow
,
with
remarkable
avidity
.
 
<EOS>
A
more
than
ordinary
redness
in
the
region
of
the
young
gentleman
's
nose
,
and
a
kind
of
fixed
wink
in
his
right
eye
,
denoted
that
he
was
in
a
slight
degree
intoxicated
;
these
symptoms
were
confirmed
by
the
intense
relish
with
which
he
took
his
oysters
,
for
which
nothing
but
a
strong
appreciation
of
their
cooling
properties
,
in
cases
of
internal
fever
,
could
have
sufficiently
accounted
.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
's
a
delicious
fat
one
,
Noah
,
dear
!
"
<EOS>
said
Charlotte
;
"
try
him
,
do
;
only
this
one
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
a
delicious
thing
is
a
oyster
!
"
<EOS>
remarked
Mr
Claypole
,
after
he
had
swallowed
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
a
pity
it
is
,
a
number
of
'em
should
ever
make
you
feel
uncomfortable
;
is
n't
it
,
Charlotte
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
quite
a
cruelty
,
"
said
Charlotte
.
   
<EOS>
"
So
it
is
,
"
acquiesced
Mr
Claypole
.
"
<EOS>
An't
<EOS>
yer
fond
of
oysters
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
overmuch
,
"
replied
Charlotte
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
like
to
see
you
eat
'em
,
<EOS>
Noah
dear
,
better
than
eating
'em
myself
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Lor
!
<EOS>
"
said
Noah
,
reflectively
;
"
how
queer
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Have
another
,
"
said
Charlotte
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
's
one
with
such
a
beautiful
,
delicate
beard
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
manage
any
more
,
"
said
Noah
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
very
sorry
.
 
<EOS>
Come
here
,
Charlotte
,
and
I
'll
kiss
yer
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
!
"
said
Mr
Bumble
,
bursting
into
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
"
Say
that
again
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
Charlotte
uttered
a
scream
,
and
hid
her
face
in
her
apron
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Claypole
,
without
making
any
further
change
in
his
position
than
suffering
his
legs
to
reach
the
ground
,
gazed
at
the
beadle
in
drunken
terror
.
   
<EOS>
"
Say
it
again
,
you
wile
,
owdacious
fellow
!
"
said
Mr
Bumble
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
How
dare
you
mention
such
a
thing
,
sir
?
 
<EOS>
And
how
dare
you
encourage
him
<EOS>
,
you
insolent
minx
?
 
<EOS>
Kiss
her
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Mr
Bumble
,
in
strong
indignation
.
 
<EOS>
"
Faugh
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
mean
to
do
it
!
"
<EOS>
said
Noah
,
blubbering
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
's
always
a
-
kissing
of
me
,
whether
I
like
it
,
or
not
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Noah
,
"
cried
Charlotte
,
reproachfully
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yer
are
;
yer
know
yer
are
!
"
retorted
Noah
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
's
always
a
-
doin
'
of
it
,
Mr
Bumble
,
sir
<EOS>
;
she
chucks
me
under
the
chin
,
please
,
sir
;
and
makes
all
manner
of
love
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Silence
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mr
Bumble
,
sternly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
yourself
downstairs
,
ma'am
.
 
<EOS>
Noah
,
you
shut
up
the
shop
;
say
another
word
till
your
master
comes
home
,
at
your
peril
;
and
,
when
he
does
come
home
,
tell
him
that
Mr
Bumble
said
he
was
to
send
a
old
woman
's
shell
after
breakfast
to
-
morrow
morning
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
hear
sir
?
 
<EOS>
Kissing
!
<EOS>
"
cried
Mr
Bumble
,
holding
up
his
hands
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
sin
and
wickedness
of
the
lower
orders
in
this
porochial
district
is
frightful
!
 
<EOS>
If
Parliament
do
n't
take
their
abominable
courses
under
consideration
,
this
country
's
ruined
,
and
the
character
of
the
peasantry
gone
for
ever
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
these
words
,
the
beadle
strode
,
with
a
lofty
and
gloomy
air
,
from
the
undertaker
's
premises
.
   
<EOS>
And
now
that
we
have
accompanied
him
so
far
on
his
road
home
,
and
have
made
all
necessary
preparations
for
the
old
woman
's
funeral
,
let
us
set
on
foot
a
few
inquires
after
young
Oliver
Twist
,
and
ascertain
whether
he
be
still
lying
in
the
ditch
where
Toby
Crackit
left
him
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
28
.
<EOS>
Looks
after
Oliver
,
and
proceeds
with
his
adventures
.
 
<EOS>
"
Wolves
tear
your
throats
!
"
<EOS>
muttered
Sikes
,
grinding
his
teeth
.
<EOS>
"
I
wish
I
was
among
some
of
you
;
you
'd
howl
the
hoarser
for
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
Sikes
growled
forth
this
imprecation
,
with
the
most
desperate
ferocity
that
his
desperate
nature
was
capable
of
,
he
rested
the
body
of
the
wounded
boy
across
his
bended
knee
;
and
turned
his
head
,
for
an
instant
,
to
look
back
at
his
pursuers
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
little
to
be
made
out
,
in
the
mist
and
darkness
;
but
the
loud
shouting
of
men
vibrated
through
the
air
,
and
the
barking
of
the
neighbouring
dogs
,
roused
by
the
sound
of
the
alarm
bell
,
resounded
in
every
direction
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stop
,
you
white
-
livered
hound
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
robber
,
shouting
after
Toby
Crackit
,
who
,
making
the
best
use
of
his
long
legs
,
was
already
ahead
.
 
<EOS>
"
Stop
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
repetition
of
the
word
,
brought
Toby
to
a
dead
stand
-
still
.
<EOS>
For
he
was
not
quite
satisfied
that
he
was
beyond
the
range
of
pistol
-
shot
;
and
Sikes
was
in
no
mood
to
be
played
with
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bear
a
hand
with
the
boy
,
"
cried
Sikes
,
beckoning
furiously
to
his
confederate
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
back
!
"
   
<EOS>
Toby
made
a
show
of
returning
;
but
ventured
,
in
a
low
voice
,
broken
for
want
of
breath
,
to
intimate
considerable
reluctance
as
he
came
slowly
along
.
   
<EOS>
"
Quicker
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Sikes
,
laying
the
boy
in
a
dry
ditch
at
his
feet
,
and
drawing
a
pistol
from
his
pocket
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
play
booty
with
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
At
this
moment
the
noise
grew
louder
.
 
<EOS>
Sikes
,
again
looking
round
,
could
discern
that
the
men
who
had
given
chase
were
already
climbing
the
gate
of
the
field
in
which
he
stood
;
and
that
a
couple
of
dogs
were
some
paces
in
advance
of
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
up
,
Bill
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Toby
;
"
drop
the
kid
,
and
show
'em
your
heels
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
parting
advice
,
Mr
Crackit
,
preferring
the
chance
of
being
shot
by
his
friend
,
to
the
certainty
of
being
taken
by
his
enemies
,
fairly
turned
tail
,
and
darted
off
at
full
speed
.
 
<EOS>
Sikes
clenched
his
teeth
;
took
one
look
around
;
threw
over
the
prostrate
form
of
Oliver
,
the
cape
in
which
he
had
been
hurriedly
muffled
;
ran
along
the
front
of
the
hedge
,
as
if
to
distract
the
attention
of
those
behind
,
from
the
spot
where
the
boy
lay
;
paused
,
for
a
second
,
before
another
hedge
which
met
it
at
right
angles
;
and
whirling
his
pistol
high
into
the
air
,
cleared
it
at
a
bound
,
and
was
gone
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ho
,
ho
,
there
!
"
cried
a
tremulous
voice
in
the
rear
.
"
<EOS>
Pincher
!
<EOS>
Neptune
!
 
<EOS>
Come
here
,
come
here
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
dogs
,
who
,
in
common
with
their
masters
,
seemed
to
have
no
particular
relish
for
the
sport
in
which
they
were
engaged
,
readily
answered
to
the
command
.
 
<EOS>
Three
men
,
who
had
by
this
time
advanced
some
distance
into
the
field
,
stopped
to
take
counsel
together
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
advice
,
or
,
leastways
<EOS>
,
I
should
say
,
my
ORDERS
,
is
,
"
said
the
fattest
man
of
the
party
,
"
that
we
"
mediately
go
home
again
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
agreeable
to
anything
which
is
agreeable
to
Mr
Giles
,
"
said
a
shorter
man
;
who
was
by
no
means
of
a
slim
figure
,
and
who
was
very
pale
in
the
face
,
and
very
polite
:
as
frightened
men
frequently
are
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
n't
wish
to
appear
ill
-
mannered
,
gentlemen
,
"
said
the
third
,
who
had
called
the
dogs
back
,
"
Mr
Giles
ought
to
know
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
"
replied
the
shorter
man
;
"
and
whatever
Mr
Giles
says
,
it
is
n't
our
place
to
contradict
him
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
I
know
my
sitiwation
!
 
<EOS>
Thank
my
stars
<EOS>
,
I
know
my
sitiwation
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
To
tell
the
truth
,
the
little
man
DID
seem
to
know
his
situation
,
and
to
know
perfectly
well
that
it
was
by
no
means
a
desirable
one
;
for
his
teeth
chattered
in
his
head
as
he
spoke
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
afraid
,
Brittles
,
"
said
Mr
Giles
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
an't
,
"
said
Brittles
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
,
"
said
Giles
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
falsehood
,
Mr
Giles
,
"
said
Brittles
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
lie
,
Brittles
,
"
said
Mr
Giles
.
   
<EOS>
Now
,
these
four
retorts
arose
from
Mr
Giles
's
taunt
;
and
Mr
Giles
's
taunt
had
arisen
from
his
indignation
at
having
the
responsibility
of
going
home
again
,
imposed
upon
himself
under
cover
of
a
compliment
.
 
<EOS>
The
third
man
brought
the
dispute
to
a
close
,
most
philosophically
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
tell
you
what
it
is
,
gentlemen
,
"
said
he
,
"
we
're
all
afraid
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Speak
for
yourself
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Giles
,
who
was
the
palest
of
the
party
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
I
do
,
"
replied
the
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
natural
and
proper
to
be
afraid
,
under
such
circumstances
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
am
I
,
"
said
Brittles
;
"
only
there
's
no
call
to
tell
a
man
he
is
,
so
bounceably
.
"
   
<EOS>
These
frank
admissions
softened
Mr
Giles
,
who
at
once
owned
that
HE
was
afraid
;
upon
which
,
they
all
three
faced
about
,
and
ran
back
again
with
the
completest
unanimity
,
until
Mr
Giles
(
who
had
the
shortest
wind
of
the
party
,
as
was
encumbered
with
a
pitchfork
)
<EOS>
most
handsomely
insisted
on
stopping
,
to
make
an
apology
for
his
hastiness
of
speech
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
it
's
wonderful
,
"
said
Mr
Giles
,
when
he
had
explained
,
"
what
a
man
will
do
,
when
his
blood
is
up
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
have
committed
murder
---
I
know
I
should
---
if
we
'd
caught
one
of
them
rascals
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
As
the
other
two
were
impressed
with
a
similar
presentiment
;
and
as
their
blood
,
like
his
,
had
all
gone
down
again
;
some
speculation
ensued
upon
the
cause
of
this
sudden
change
in
their
temperament
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
what
it
was
,
"
said
Mr
Giles
;
"
it
was
the
gate
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
n't
wonder
if
it
was
,
"
exclaimed
Brittles
,
catching
at
the
idea
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
may
depend
upon
it
,
"
said
Giles
,
"
that
that
gate
stopped
the
flow
of
the
excitement
.
 
<EOS>
I
felt
all
mine
suddenly
going
away
,
as
I
was
climbing
over
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
By
a
remarkable
coincidence
,
the
other
two
had
been
visited
with
the
same
unpleasant
sensation
at
that
precise
moment
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
quite
obvious
,
therefore
,
that
it
was
the
gate
;
especially
as
there
was
no
doubt
regarding
the
time
at
which
the
change
had
taken
place
,
because
all
three
remembered
that
they
had
come
in
sight
of
the
robbers
at
the
instant
of
its
occurance
.
   
<EOS>
This
dialogue
was
held
between
the
two
men
who
had
surprised
the
burglars
,
and
a
travelling
tinker
who
had
been
sleeping
in
an
outhouse
,
and
who
had
been
roused
,
together
with
his
two
mongrel
curs
,
to
join
in
the
pursuit
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Giles
acted
in
the
double
capacity
of
butler
and
steward
to
the
old
lady
of
the
mansion
;
Brittles
was
a
lad
of
all
-
work
:
who
,
having
entered
her
service
a
mere
child
,
was
treated
as
a
promising
young
boy
still
,
though
he
was
something
past
thirty
.
   
<EOS>
Encouraging
each
other
with
such
converse
as
this
;
but
,
keeping
very
close
together
,
notwithstanding
,
and
looking
apprehensively
round
,
whenever
a
fresh
gust
rattled
through
the
boughs
;
the
three
men
hurried
back
to
a
tree
,
behind
which
they
had
left
their
lantern
,
lest
its
light
should
inform
the
thieves
in
what
direction
to
fire
.
 
<EOS>
Catching
up
the
light
,
they
made
the
best
of
their
way
home
,
at
a
good
round
trot
;
and
long
after
their
dusky
forms
had
ceased
to
be
discernible
,
the
light
might
have
been
seen
twinkling
and
dancing
in
the
distance
,
like
some
exhalation
of
the
damp
and
gloomy
atmosphere
through
which
it
was
swiftly
borne
.
   
<EOS>
The
air
grew
colder
,
as
day
came
slowly
on
;
and
the
mist
rolled
along
the
ground
like
a
dense
cloud
of
smoke
.
 
<EOS>
The
grass
was
wet
;
the
pathways
,
and
low
places
,
were
all
mire
and
water
;
the
damp
breath
of
an
unwholesome
wind
went
languidly
by
,
with
a
hollow
moaning
.
 
<EOS>
Still
,
Oliver
lay
motionless
and
insensible
on
the
spot
where
Sikes
had
left
him
.
   
<EOS>
Morning
drew
on
apace
.
 
<EOS>
The
air
become
more
sharp
and
piercing
,
as
its
first
dull
hue
---
the
death
of
night
,
rather
than
the
birth
of
day
---
glimmered
faintly
in
the
sky
.
 
<EOS>
The
objects
which
had
looked
dim
and
terrible
in
the
darkness
,
grew
more
and
more
defined
,
and
gradually
resolved
into
their
familiar
shapes
.
 
<EOS>
The
rain
came
down
,
thick
and
fast
,
and
pattered
noisily
among
the
leafless
bushes
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
Oliver
felt
it
not
,
as
it
beat
against
him
;
for
he
still
lay
stretched
,
helpless
and
unconscious
,
on
his
bed
of
clay
.
   
<EOS>
At
length
,
a
low
cry
of
pain
broke
the
stillness
that
prevailed
;
and
uttering
it
,
the
boy
awoke
.
 
<EOS>
His
left
arm
,
rudely
bandaged
in
a
shawl
,
hung
heavy
and
useless
at
his
side
;
the
bandage
was
saturated
with
blood
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
so
weak
,
that
he
could
scarcely
raise
himself
into
a
sitting
posture
;
when
he
had
done
so
,
he
looked
feebly
round
for
help
,
and
groaned
with
pain
.
 
<EOS>
Trembling
in
every
joint
,
from
cold
and
exhaustion
,
he
made
an
effort
to
stand
upright
;
but
,
shuddering
from
head
to
foot
,
fell
prostrate
on
the
ground
.
   
<EOS>
After
a
short
return
of
the
stupor
in
which
he
had
been
so
long
plunged
,
Oliver
:
 
urged
by
a
creeping
sickness
at
his
heart
,
which
seemed
to
warn
him
that
if
he
lay
there
,
he
must
surely
die
:
 
got
upon
his
feet
,
and
essayed
to
walk
.
<EOS>
His
head
was
dizzy
,
and
he
staggered
to
and
from
like
a
drunken
man
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
kept
up
,
nevertheless
,
and
,
with
his
head
drooping
languidly
on
his
breast
,
went
stumbling
onward
,
he
knew
not
whither
.
   
<EOS>
And
now
,
hosts
of
bewildering
and
confused
ideas
came
crowding
on
his
mind
.
 
<EOS>
He
seemed
to
be
still
walking
between
Sikes
and
Crackit
,
who
were
angrily
disputing
---
for
the
very
words
they
said
,
sounded
in
his
ears
;
and
when
he
caught
his
own
attention
,
as
it
were
,
by
making
some
violent
effort
to
save
himself
from
falling
,
he
found
that
he
was
talking
to
them
.
<EOS>
Then
,
he
was
alone
with
Sikes
,
plodding
on
as
on
the
previous
day
;
and
as
shadowy
people
passed
them
,
he
felt
the
robber
's
grasp
upon
his
wrist
.
<EOS>
Suddenly
,
he
started
back
at
the
report
of
fire
-
arms
;
there
rose
into
the
air
,
loud
cries
and
shouts
;
lights
gleamed
before
his
eyes
;
all
was
noise
and
tumult
,
as
some
unseen
hand
bore
him
hurriedly
away
.
 
<EOS>
Through
all
these
rapid
visions
,
there
ran
an
undefined
,
uneasy
conscious
of
pain
,
which
wearied
and
tormented
him
incessantly
.
   
<EOS>
Thus
he
staggered
on
,
creeping
,
almost
mechanically
,
between
the
bars
of
gates
,
or
through
hedge
-
gaps
as
they
came
in
his
way
,
until
he
reached
a
road
.
 
<EOS>
Here
the
rain
began
to
fall
so
heavily
,
that
it
roused
him
.
   
<EOS>
He
looked
about
,
and
saw
that
at
no
great
distance
there
was
a
house
,
which
perhaps
he
could
reach
.
 
<EOS>
Pitying
his
condition
,
they
might
have
compassion
on
him
;
and
if
they
did
not
,
it
would
be
better
,
he
thought
,
to
die
near
human
beings
,
than
in
the
lonely
open
fields
.
 
<EOS>
He
summoned
up
all
his
strength
for
one
last
trial
,
and
bent
his
faltering
steps
towards
it
.
   
<EOS>
As
he
drew
nearer
to
this
house
,
a
feeling
come
over
him
that
he
had
seen
it
before
.
 
<EOS>
He
remembered
nothing
of
its
details
;
but
the
shape
and
aspect
of
the
building
seemed
familiar
to
him
.
   
<EOS>
That
garden
wall
!
 
<EOS>
On
the
grass
inside
,
he
had
fallen
on
his
knees
last
night
,
and
prayed
the
two
men
's
mercy
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
very
house
they
had
attempted
to
rob
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
felt
such
fear
come
over
him
when
he
recognised
the
place
,
that
,
for
the
instant
,
he
forgot
the
agony
of
his
wound
,
and
thought
only
of
flight
.
 
<EOS>
Flight
!
 
<EOS>
He
could
scarcely
stand
:
 
and
if
he
were
in
full
possession
of
all
the
best
powers
of
his
slight
and
youthful
frame
,
whither
could
he
fly
?
 
<EOS>
He
pushed
against
the
garden
-
gate
;
it
was
unlocked
,
and
swung
open
on
its
hinges
.
 
<EOS>
He
tottered
across
the
lawn
;
climbed
the
steps
;
knocked
faintly
at
the
door
;
and
,
his
whole
strength
failing
him
,
sunk
down
against
one
of
the
pillars
of
the
little
portico
.
   
<EOS>
It
happened
that
about
this
time
,
Mr
Giles
,
Brittles
,
and
the
tinker
,
were
recruiting
themselves
,
after
the
fatigues
and
terrors
of
the
night
,
with
tea
and
sundries
,
in
the
kitchen
.
 
<EOS>
Not
that
it
was
Mr
Giles
's
habit
to
admit
to
too
great
familiarity
the
humbler
servants
:
towards
whom
it
was
rather
his
wo
nt
to
deport
himself
with
a
lofty
affability
,
which
,
while
it
gratified
,
could
not
fail
to
remind
them
of
his
superior
position
in
society
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
death
,
fires
,
and
burglary
,
make
all
men
equals
;
so
Mr
Giles
sat
with
his
legs
stretched
out
before
the
kitchen
fender
,
leaning
his
left
arm
on
the
table
,
while
,
with
his
right
,
he
illustrated
a
circumstantial
and
minute
account
of
the
robbery
,
to
which
his
bearers
(
but
especially
the
cook
and
housemaid
,
who
were
of
the
party
)
listened
with
breathless
interest
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
about
half
-
past
tow
,
"
said
Mr
Giles
,
"
or
I
would
n't
swear
that
it
might
n't
have
been
a
little
nearer
three
,
when
I
woke
up
,
and
,
turning
round
in
my
bed
,
as
it
might
be
so
,
(
here
Mr
Giles
turned
round
in
his
chair
,
and
pulled
the
corner
of
the
table
-
cloth
over
him
to
imitate
bed
-
clothes
,
)
<EOS>
I
fancied
I
heerd
a
noise
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
At
this
point
of
the
narrative
the
cook
turned
pale
,
and
asked
the
housemaid
to
shut
the
door
:
who
asked
Brittles
,
who
asked
the
tinker
,
who
pretended
not
to
hear
.
   
<EOS>
"
---
Heerd
a
noise
,
"
continued
Mr
Giles
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
says
,
at
first
,
"
This
is
illusion
"
;
and
was
composing
myself
off
to
sleep
,
when
I
heerd
the
noise
again
,
distinct
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
sort
of
a
noise
?
"
asked
the
cook
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
kind
of
a
busting
noise
,
"
replied
Mr
Giles
,
looking
round
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
More
like
the
noise
of
powdering
a
iron
bar
on
a
nutmeg
-
grater
,
"
suggested
Brittles
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
,
when
you
HEERD
it
,
sir
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Giles
;
"
but
,
at
this
time
,
it
had
a
busting
sound
.
 
<EOS>
I
turned
down
the
clothes
"
;
continued
Giles
,
rolling
back
the
table
-
cloth
,
"
sat
up
in
bed
;
and
listened
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
cook
and
housemaid
simultaneously
ejaculated
"
Lor
!
"
and
drew
their
chairs
closer
together
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
heerd
it
now
,
quite
apparent
,
"
resumed
Mr
Giles
.
"
<EOS>
"
Somebody
,
"
I
says
,
"
is
forcing
of
a
door
,
or
window
;
what
's
to
be
done
?
<EOS>
I
'll
call
up
that
poor
lad
,
Brittles
,
and
save
him
from
being
murdered
in
his
bed
;
or
his
throat
,
"
I
says
,
"
may
be
cut
from
his
right
ear
to
his
left
,
without
his
ever
knowing
it
.
"
<EOS>
"
   
Here
,
all
eyes
were
turned
upon
Brittles
,
who
fixed
his
upon
the
speaker
,
and
stared
at
him
,
with
his
mouth
wide
open
,
and
his
face
expressive
of
the
most
unmitigated
horror
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
tossed
off
the
clothes
,
"
said
Giles
,
throwing
away
the
table
-
cloth
,
and
looking
very
hard
at
the
cook
and
housemaid
,
"
got
softly
out
of
bed
;
drew
on
a
pair
of
---
"
   
"
Ladies
present
,
Mr
Giles
,
"
murmured
the
tinker
.
   
<EOS>
"
---
Of
SHOES
,
sir
,
"
said
Giles
,
turning
upon
him
,
and
laying
great
emphasis
on
the
word
;
"
seized
the
loaded
pistol
that
always
goes
upstairs
with
the
plate
-
basket
;
and
walked
on
tiptoes
to
his
room
.
 
<EOS>
"
Brittles
,
"
I
says
,
when
I
had
woke
him
,
"
do
n't
be
frightened
!
"
<EOS>
"
   
"
So
you
did
,
"
observed
Brittles
,
in
a
low
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
We
're
dead
men
,
I
think
,
Brittles
,
"
I
says
,
"
continued
Giles
;
"
"
but
do
n't
be
frightened
.
"
<EOS>
"
   
"
WAS
he
frightened
?
"
asked
the
cook
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a
bit
of
it
,
"
replied
Mr
Giles
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
was
as
firm
---
ah
!
<EOS>
pretty
near
as
firm
as
I
was
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
have
died
at
once
<EOS>
,
I
'm
sure
,
if
it
had
been
me
,
"
observed
the
housemaid
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
woman
,
"
retorted
Brittles
,
plucking
up
a
little
.
   
<EOS>
"
Brittles
is
right
,
"
said
Mr
Giles
,
nodding
his
head
,
approvingly
;
"
from
a
woman
<EOS>
,
nothing
else
was
to
be
expected
.
<EOS>
We
,
being
men
,
took
a
dark
lantern
that
was
standing
on
Brittle
's
hob
,
and
groped
our
way
downstairs
in
the
pitch
dark
,
---
as
it
might
be
so
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Giles
had
risen
from
his
seat
,
and
taken
two
steps
with
his
eyes
shut
,
to
accompany
his
description
with
appropriate
action
,
when
he
started
violently
,
in
common
with
the
rest
of
the
company
,
and
hurried
back
to
his
chair
.
 
<EOS>
The
cook
and
housemaid
screamed
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
a
knock
,
"
said
Mr
Giles
,
assuming
perfect
serenity
.
<EOS>
"
Open
the
door
,
somebody
.
"
   
<EOS>
Nobody
moved
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
seems
a
strange
sort
of
a
thing
,
a
knock
coming
at
such
a
time
in
the
morning
,
"
said
Mr
Giles
,
surveying
the
pale
faces
which
surrounded
him
,
and
looking
very
blank
himself
;
"
but
the
door
must
be
opened
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
hear
,
somebody
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Giles
,
as
he
spoke
,
looked
at
Brittles
;
but
that
young
man
,
being
naturally
modest
,
probably
considered
himself
nobody
,
and
so
held
that
the
inquiry
could
not
have
any
application
to
him
;
at
all
events
,
he
tendered
no
reply
.
<EOS>
Mr
Giles
directed
an
appealing
glance
at
the
tinker
;
but
he
had
suddenly
fallen
asleep
.
 
<EOS>
The
women
were
out
of
the
question
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
Brittles
would
rather
open
the
door
,
in
the
presence
of
witnesses
,
"
said
Mr
Giles
,
after
a
short
silence
,
"
I
am
ready
to
make
one
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
am
I
,
"
said
the
tinker
,
waking
up
,
as
suddenly
as
he
had
fallen
asleep
.
   
<EOS>
Brittles
capitualated
on
these
terms
;
and
the
party
being
somewhat
re
-
assured
by
the
discovery
(
made
on
throwing
open
the
shutters
)
that
it
was
now
broad
day
,
took
their
way
upstairs
;
with
the
dogs
in
front
.
 
<EOS>
The
two
women
,
who
were
afraid
to
stay
below
,
brought
up
the
rear
.
 
<EOS>
By
the
advice
of
Mr
Giles
,
they
all
talked
very
loud
,
to
warn
any
evil
-
disposed
person
outside
,
that
they
were
strong
in
numbers
;
and
by
a
master
-
stoke
of
policy
,
originating
in
the
brain
of
the
same
ingenious
gentleman
,
the
dogs
'
tails
were
well
pinched
,
in
the
hall
,
to
make
them
bark
savagely
.
   
<EOS>
These
precautions
having
been
taken
,
Mr
Giles
held
on
fast
by
the
tinker
's
arm
(
to
prevent
his
running
away
,
as
he
pleasantly
said
)
,
and
gave
the
word
of
command
to
open
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
Brittles
obeyed
;
the
group
,
peeping
timorously
over
each
other
's
shoulders
,
beheld
no
more
formidable
object
than
poor
little
Oliver
Twist
,
speechless
and
exhausted
,
who
raised
his
heavy
eyes
,
and
mutely
solicited
their
compassion
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
boy
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Mr
Giles
,
valiantly
,
pushing
the
tinker
into
the
background
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
with
<EOS>
the
---
eh
?
---
Why
---
Brittles
---
look
here
---
do
n't
you
know
?
<EOS>
"
   
Brittles
,
who
had
got
behind
the
door
to
open
it
,
no
sooner
saw
Oliver
,
than
he
uttered
a
loud
cry
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Giles
,
seizing
the
boy
by
one
leg
and
one
arm
(
fortunately
not
the
broken
limb
)
lugged
him
straight
into
the
hall
,
and
deposited
him
at
full
length
on
the
floor
thereof
.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
he
is
!
"
<EOS>
bawled
Giles
,
calling
in
a
state
of
great
excitement
,
up
the
staircase
;
"
here
's
one
of
the
thieves
,
ma'am
!
<EOS>
Here
's
a
thief
,
miss
!
 
<EOS>
Wounded
,
miss
!
 
<EOS>
I
shot
him
,
miss
;
and
Brittles
held
the
light
.
"
   
"
<EOS>
---
In
a
lantern
,
miss
,
"
cried
Brittles
,
applying
one
hand
to
the
side
of
his
mouth
,
so
that
his
voice
might
travel
the
better
.
   
<EOS>
The
two
women
-
servants
ran
upstairs
to
carry
the
intelligence
that
Mr
Giles
had
captured
a
robber
;
and
the
tinker
busied
himself
in
endeavouring
to
restore
Oliver
,
lest
he
should
die
before
he
could
be
hanged
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
midst
of
all
this
noise
and
commotion
,
there
was
heard
a
sweet
female
voice
,
which
quelled
it
in
an
instant
.
   
<EOS>
"
Giles
!
"
whispered
the
voice
from
the
stair
-
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
here
,
miss
,
"
replied
Mr
Giles
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
frightened
,
miss
;
I
ai
n't
much
injured
.
 
<EOS>
He
did
n't
make
a
very
desperate
resistance
,
miss
!
 
<EOS>
I
was
soon
too
many
for
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
"
replied
the
young
lady
;
"
you
frighten
my
aunt
as
much
as
the
thieves
did
.
 
<EOS>
Is
the
poor
creature
much
hurt
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Wounded
desperate
,
miss
,
"
replied
Giles
,
with
indescribable
complacency
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
looks
as
if
he
was
a
-
going
,
miss
,
"
bawled
Brittles
,
in
the
same

as
before
.
 
<EOS>
"
Would
n't
you
like
to
come
and
look

,

,

case

should
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
,
pray
;
there
's
a
good
man
!
"
rejoined
the
lady
.
 
<EOS>
"
Wait
quietly
<EOS>
only
one
instant
,
while
I
speak
to
aunt
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
a
footstep
as
soft
and
gentle
as
the
voice
,
the
speaker
tripped
away
.
 
<EOS>
She
soon
returned
,
with
the
direction
that
the
wounded
person
was
to
be
carried
,
carefully
,
upstairs
to
Mr
Giles
's
room
;
and
that
Brittles
was
to
saddle
the
pony
and
betake
himself
instantly
to
Chertsey
:
 
from
which
place
,
he
was
to

,
with
all

,

doctor
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
wo
n't
you
take
one
look
at

,
first
,
miss
?
"
asked
Mr
Giles
,
with
as
much

as
if
Oliver
were
some
bird
of
rare

,
that
he
had

down
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
one
little

,
miss
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
now
,
for
the
world
,
"
replied

.
 
<EOS>
"
Poor
fellow
!
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
treat
him
kindly
,
Giles
for
my
sake
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
old
servant
looked
up
at
the
speaker
,
as
she
turned
away
,
with
a

as

.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
bending
over
Oliver
,
he

to
carry
him
upstairs
,
with
the
care
and

of
a
woman
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
29
.
<EOS>
Has
an
introductory
account
of
the
inmates
of
the
house
,
to
which
Oliver
resorted
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
handsome
room
:
 
though
its
furniture
had
rather
the
air
of
old
-
fashioned
comfort
,
than
of
modern
elegance
:
 
there
sat
two
ladies
at
a
well
-
spread
breakfast
-
table
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Giles
,
dressed
with
scrupulous
care
in
a
full
suit
of
black
,
was
in
attendance
upon
them
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
taken
his
station
some
half
-
way
between
the
side
-
board
and
the
breakfast
-
table
;
and
,
with
his
body
drawn
up
to
its
full
height
,
his
head
thrown
back
,
and
inclined
the
merest
trifle
on
one
side
,
his
left
leg
advanced
,
and
his
right
hand
thrust
into
his
waist
-
coat
,
while
his
left
hung
down
by
his
side
,
grasping
a
waiter
,
looked
like
one
who
laboured
under
a
very
agreeable
sense
of
his
own
merits
and
importance
.
   
<EOS>
Of
the
two
ladies
,
one
was
well
advanced
in
years
;
but
the
high
-
backed
oaken
chair
in
which
she
sat
,
was
not
more
upright
than
she
.
 
<EOS>
Dressed
with
the
utmost
nicety
and
precision
,
in
a
quaint
mixture
of
by
-
gone
costume
,
with
some
slight
concessions
to
the
prevailing
taste
,
which
rather
served
to
point
the
old
style
pleasantly
than
to
impair
its
effect
,
she
sat
,
in
a
stately
manner
,
with
her
hands
folded
on
the
table
before
her
.
 
<EOS>
Her
eyes
(
and
age
had
dimmed
but
little
of
their
brightness
)
were
attentively
upon
her
young
companion
.
   
<EOS>
The
younger
lady
was
in
the
lovely
bloom
and
spring
-
time
of
womanhood
;
at
that
age
,
when
,
if
ever
angels
be
for
God
's
good
purposes
enthroned
in
mortal
forms
,
they
may
be
,
without
impiety
,
supposed
to
abide
in
such
as
hers
.
   
<EOS>
She
was
not
past
seventeen
.
 
<EOS>
Cast
in
so
slight
and
exquisite
a
mould
;
so
mild
and
gentle
;
so
pure
and
beautiful
;
that
earth
seemed
not
her
element
,
nor
its
rough
creatures
her
fit
companions
.
 
<EOS>
The
very
intelligence
that
shone
in
her
deep
blue
eye
,
and
was
stamped
upon
her
noble
head
,
seemed
scarcely
of
her
age
,
or
of
the
world
;
and
yet
the
changing
expression
of
sweetness
and
good
humour
,
the
thousand
lights
that
played
about
the
face
,
and
left
no
shadow
there
;
above
all
,
the
smile
,
the
cheerful
,
happy
smile
,
were
made
for
Home
,
and
fireside
peace
and
happiness
.
   
<EOS>
She
was
busily
engaged
in
the
little
offices
of
the
table
.
<EOS>
Chancing
to
raise
her

as
the
elder

was
regarding
her
<EOS>
,
she
playfully
put
back
her

,
which
was
simply

on

;
and
threw
into
her

,
such

of

and
artless

,
that
blessed

might
have
smiled

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
Brittles
has

upwards

an

,

?
<EOS>
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
An

,

,
"

Giles
,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
He

always

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Brittles
always

,

,
"
replied
the
attendant
.
<EOS>
And

,

,

upwards
of
thirty
years
<EOS>
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
He
gets

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
It

if

,
"
said

young

,

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Giles
was
apparently

the

in
a
respectful
smile
himself
,
when
a
gig
drove

:
out

fat

,

:

,

house
by

,
burst

,

nearly

Giles

the

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
never
heard

thing
!
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Mrs
Maylie
---
bless
my
soul
---
in
the
silence
of
the
night
,
too
---
I
NEVER
heard
of
such
a
thing
!
"
   
<EOS>
With

,
the

shook

with
both

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
ought

;

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
did

send
?
 
<EOS>
Bless

,
my
man
should

;

;

;
or
<EOS>
anybody
,
I
'm

,

.
 
<EOS>
Dear
,

!
 
<EOS>
So

!
 
<EOS>
In

silence

the
night
,

!
"
   
<EOS>
The
doctor
seemed

by
the

robbery
having

,
and
attempted
in
the
night

;

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

,
Miss

,
"

"

---
"
   
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
very

,

,
"

,

"

,

aunt

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
to

,
"

"
<EOS>
so

.
 
<EOS>
That

,
Giles
,

.

<EOS>
Mr

,

,
blushed

red
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Honour
,
eh
?
"
said
the
doctor
;
"
well
,
I
do
n't

;
perhaps
it
's
as
honourable
to

in

,

.
 
<EOS>
Fancy
that
he
fired
in

air
,

've

,
Giles
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

,

light

,

;
but

.
   
<EOS>
"
Gad
,

's

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Where

?
 
<EOS>
Show

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
That

?
 
<EOS>
Well
,
I
could
n't

believed

!
"
   
<EOS>
Talking
all
the
way
,
he
followed
Mr
Giles
upstairs
;
and
while
he
is
going
upstairs
,
the
reader
may
be
informed
,
that
Mr
Losberne
,
a
surgeon
in
the

,
known
through

ten
miles
round

"
the
doctor
,
"
had
grown
fat
,
more
from
good
-

than

:
 
and

as
kind

,

an

,
as
will

,

.
   
<EOS>
The
doctor
was
absent
,
much

than
either

or

ladies
had

.
 
<EOS>
A
large
flat
box
was
fetched
out
of
the
gig
;
and
a

bell
was
rung
very

;
and

ran

stairs
perpetually
;
from
which
tokens
it
was
justly

that
something
important
was
going

.
 
<EOS>
At
length

returned
;
and
in

an

patient
;
looked
very

,
and
closed

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
very

,
Mrs
Maylie
,
"
said
the
doctor
,
standing
with

,
as

.
   
<EOS>
"
He

,

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

NOT

,

,
"
replied
the
doctor
;
"
though

n't

.
<EOS>
Have

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Nor

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

,

Giles
;
"
but
I
was

him
when
Doctor
Losberne
came

.
"
   
<EOS>
The

,
that
Mr
Giles
had
not
,
at

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Such

,
that

,
for

,
help

;

,
in

.
   
<EOS>
"
Rose
wished
to

man
,
"
said

,
"
but
I

n't

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Humph
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
There

nothing

.
 
<EOS>
Have

"
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

,
"

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
I

,
"

;
"

,
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
is
perfectly

.
<EOS>
Allow

---
Miss
Rose
,

?
 
<EOS>
Not
the
slightest
fear
<EOS>
,
I
pledge
you
my
honour
!
"
    
Chapter
30
.
<EOS>
Relates
what
Oliver
's
new
visitors
thought
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
With
many
loquacious
assurances
that
they
would
be
agreeably
surprised
in
the
aspect
of
the
criminal
,
the
doctor
drew
the
young
lady
's
arm
through
one
of
him
;
and
offering
his
disengaged
hand
to
Mrs
Maylie
,
led
them
,
with
much
ceremony
and
stateliness
,
upstairs
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
said
the
doctor
,
in
a
whisper
,
as
he
softly
turned
the
handle
of
a
bedroom
-
door
,
"
let
us
hear
what
you
think
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
not
been
shaved
very
recently
,
but
he
do
n't
look
at
all
ferocious
notwithstanding
.
 
<EOS>
Stop
,
though
!
 
<EOS>
Let
me
first
see
that
he
is
in
visiting
order
.
"
   
<EOS>
Stepping
before
them
,
he
looked
into
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
Motioning
them
to
advance
,
he
closed
the
door
when
they
had
entered
;
and
gently
drew
back
the
curtains
of
the
bed
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
it
,
in
lieu
of
the
dogged
,
black
-
visaged
ruffian
they
had
expected
to
behold
,
there
lay
a
mere
child
:
 
worn
with
pain
and
exhaustion
,
and
sunk
into
a
deep
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
His
wounded
arm
,
bound
and
splintered
up
,
was
crossed
upon
his
breast
;
his
head
reclined
upon
the
other
arm
,
which
was
half
hidden
by
his
long
hair
,
as
it
streamed
over
the
pillow
.
   
<EOS>
The
honest
gentleman
held
the
curtain
in
his
hand
,
and
looked
on
,
for
a
minute
or
so
,
in
silence
.
 
<EOS>
Whilst
he
was
watching
the
patient
thus
,
the
younger
lady
glided
softly
past
,
and
seating
herself
in
a
chair
by
the
bedside
,
gathered
Oliver
's
hair
from
his
face
.
 
<EOS>
As
she
stooped
over
him
,
her
tears
fell
upon
his
forehead
.
   
<EOS>
The
boy
stirred
,
and
smiled
in
his
sleep
,
as
though
these
marks
of
pity
and
compassion
had
awakened
some
pleasant
dream
of
a
love
and
affection
he
had
never
known
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
,
a
strain
of
gentle
music
,
or
the
rippling
of
water
in
a
silent
place
,
or
the
odour
of
a
flower
,
or
the
mention
of
a
familiar
word
,
will
sometimes
call
up
sudden
dim
remembrances
of
scenes
that
never
were
,
in
this
life
;
which
vanish
like
a
breath
;
which
some
brief
memory
of
a
happier
existence
,
long
gone
by
,
would
seem
to
have
awakened
;
which
no
voluntary
exertion
of
the
mind
can
ever
recall
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
can
this
mean
?
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
the
elder
lady
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
poor
child
can
never
have
been
the
pupil
of
robbers
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Vice
,
"
said
the
surgeon
,
replacing
the
curtain
,
"
takes
up
her
abode
in
many
temples
;
and
who
can
say
that
a
fair
outside
shell
not
enshrine
her
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
at
so
early
an
age
!
"
urged
Rose
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
young
lady
,
"
rejoined
the
surgeon
,
mournfully
shaking
his
head
;
"
crime
,
like
death
,
is
not
confined
to
the
old
and
withered
alone
.
 
<EOS>
The
youngest
and
fairest
are
too
often
its
chosen
victims
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
,
can
you
---
oh
!
can
you
really
believe
that
this
delicate
boy
has
been
the
voluntary
associate
of
the
worst
outcasts
of
society
?
"
said
Rose
.
   
<EOS>
The
surgeon
shook
his
head
,
in
a
manner
which
intimated
that
he
feared
it
was
very
possible
;
and
observing
that
they
might
disturb
the
patient
,
led
the
way
into
an
adjoining
apartment
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
even
if
he
has
been
wicked
,
"
pursued
Rose
,
"
think
how
young
he
is
;
think
that
he
may
never
have
known
a
mother
's
love
,
or
the
comfort
of
a
home
;
that
ill
-
usage
and
blows
,
or
the
want
of
bread
,
may
have
driven
him
to
herd
with
men
who
have
forced
him
to
guilt
.
 
<EOS>
Aunt
,
dear
aunt
,
for
mercy
's
sake
,
think
of
this
,
before
you
let
them
drag
this
sick
child
to
a
prison
,
which
in
any
case
must
be
the
grave
of
all
his
chances
of
amendment
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
as
you
love
me
,
and
know
that
I
have
never
felt
the
want
of
parents
in
your
goodness
and
affection
,
but
that
I
might
have
done
so
,
and
might
have
been
equally
helpless
and
unprotected
with
this
poor
child
,
have
pity
upon
him
before
it
is
too
late
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
love
,
"
said
the
elder
lady
,
as
she
folded
the
weeping
girl
to
her
bosom
,
"
do
you
think
I
would
harm
a
hair
of
his
head
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
no
!
"
replied
Rose
,
eagerly
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
surely
,
"
said
the
old
lady
;
"
my
days
are
drawing
to
their
close
:
 
and
may
mercy
be
shown
to
me
as
I
show
it
to
others
!
<EOS>
What
can
I
do
to
save
him
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Let
me
think
,
ma'am
,
"
said
the
doctor
;
"
let
me
think
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Losberne
thrust
his
hands
into
his
pockets
,
and
took
several
turns
up
and
down
the
room
;
often
stopping
,
and
balancing
himself
on
his
toes
,
and
frowning
frightfully
.
 
<EOS>
After
various
exclamations
of
"
I
've
got
it
now
"
and
"
no
,
I
have
n't
,
"
and
as
many
renewals
of
the
walking
and
frowning
,
he
at
length
made
a
dead
halt
,
and
spoke
as
follows
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
if
you
give
me
a
full
and
unlimited
commission
to
bully
Giles
,
and
that
little
boy
,
Brittles
,
I
can
manage
it
.
 
<EOS>
Giles
is
a
faithful
fellow
and
an
old
servant
,
I
know
;
but
you
can
make
it
up
to
him
in
a
thousand
ways
,
and
reward
him
for
being
such
a
good
shot
besides
.
 
<EOS>
You
do
n't
object
to
that
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Unless
there
is
some
other
way
of
preserving
the
child
,
"
replied
Mrs
Maylie
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
other
,
"
said
the
doctor
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
other
,
take
my
word
for
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
my
aunt
invests
you
with
full
power
,
"
said
Rose
,
smiling
through
her
tears
;
"
but
pray
do
n't
be
harder
upon
the
poor
fellows
than
is
indispensably
necessary
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
seem
to
think
,
"
retorted
the
doctor
,
"
that
everybody
is
disposed
to
be
hard
-
hearted
to
-
day
,
except
yourself
,
Miss
Rose
.
<EOS>
I
only
hope
,
for
the
sake
of
the
rising
male
sex
generally
,
that
you
may
be
found
in
as
vulnerable
and
soft
-
hearted
a
mood
by
the
first
eligible
young
fellow
who
appeals
to
your
compassion
;
and
I
wish
I
were
a
young
fellow
,
that
I
might
avail
myself
,
on
the
spot
,
of
such
a
favourable
opportunity
for
doing
so
,
as
the
present
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
as
great
a
boy
as
poor
Brittles
himself
,
"
returned
Rose
,
blushing
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
"
said
the
doctor
,
laughing
heartily
,
"
that
is
no
very
difficult
matter
.
 
<EOS>
But
to
return
to
this
boy
.
 
<EOS>
The
great
point
of
our
agreement
is
yet
to
come
.
 
<EOS>
He
will
wake
in
an
hour
or
so
<EOS>
,
I
dare
say
;
and
although
I
have
told
that
thick
-
headed
constable
-
fellow
downstairs
that
he
musn't
be
moved
or
spoken
to
,
on
peril
of
his
life
,
I
think
we
may
converse
with
him
without
danger
.
 
<EOS>
Now
I
make
this
stipulation
---
that
I
shall
examine
him
in
your
presence
,
and
that
,
if
,
from
what
he
says
,
we
judge
,
and
I
can
show
to
the
satisfaction
of
your
cool
reason
,
that
he
is
a
real
and
thorough
bad
one
(
which
is
more
than
possible
)
,
he
shall
be
left
to
his
fate
,
without
any
farther
interference
on
my
part
,
at
all
events
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
no
,
aunt
!
<EOS>
"
entreated
Rose
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
yes
,
aunt
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
doctor
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
is
a
bargain
?
;
   
"
He
can
not
be
hardened
in
vice
,
"
said
Rose
;
"
It
is
impossible
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
good
,
"
retorted
the
doctor
;
"
then
so
much
the
more
reason
for
acceding
to
my
proposition
.
"
   
<EOS>
Finally
the
treaty
was
entered
into
;
and
the
parties
thereunto
sat
down
to
wait
,
with
some
impatience
,
until
Oliver
should
awake
.
   
<EOS>
The
patience
of
the
two
ladies
was
destined
to
undergo
a
longer
trial
than
Mr
Losberne
had
led
them
to
expect
;
for
hour
after
hour
passed
on
,
and
still
Oliver
slumbered
heavily
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
evening
,
indeed
,
before
the
kind
-
hearted
doctor
brought
them
the
intelligence
,
that
he
was
at
length
sufficiently
restored
to
be
spoken
to
.
 
<EOS>
The
boy
was
very
ill
,
he
said
,
and
weak
from
the
loss
of
blood
;
but
his
mind
was
so
troubled
with
anxiety
to
disclose
something
,
that
he
deemed
it
better
to
give
him
the
opportunity
,
than
to
insist
upon
his
remaining
quiet
until
next
morning
:
which
he
should
otherwise
have
done
.
   
<EOS>
The
conference
was
a
long
one
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
told
them
all
his
simple
history
,
and
was
often
compelled
to
stop
,
by
pain
and
want
of
strength
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
solemn
thing
,
to
hear
,
in
the
darkened
room
,
the
feeble
voice
of
the
sick
child
recounting
a
weary
catalogue
of
evils
and
calamities
which
hard
men
had
brought
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
if
when
we
oppress
and
grind
our
fellow
-
creatures
,
we
bestowed
<EOS>
but
one
thought
on
the
dark
evidences
of
human
error
,
which
,
like
dense
and
heavy
clouds
,
are
rising
,
slowly
it
is
true
,
but
not
less
surely
,
to
Heaven
,
to
pour
their
after
-
vengeance
on
our
heads
;
if
we
heard
but
one
instant
,
in
imagination
,
the
deep
testimony
of
dead
men
's
voices
,
which
no
power
can
stifle
,
and
no
pride
shut
out
;
where
would
be
the
injury
and
injustice
,
the
suffering
,
misery
,
cruelty
,
and
wrong
,
that
each
day
's
life
brings
with
it
!
   
<EOS>
Oliver
's
pillow
was
smoothed
by
gentle
hands
that
night
;
and
loveliness
and
virtue
watched
him
as
he
slept
.
 
<EOS>
He
felt
calm
and
happy
,
and
could
have
died
without
a
murmur
.
   
<EOS>
The
momentous
interview
was
no
sooner
concluded
,
and
Oliver
composed
to
rest
again
,
than
the
doctor
,
after
wiping
his
eyes
,
and
condemning
them
for
being
weak
all
at
once
,
betook
himself
downstairs
to
open
upon
Mr
Giles
.
 
<EOS>
And
finding
nobody
about
the
parlours
,
it
occurred
to
him
,
that
he
could
perhaps
originate
the
proceedings
with
better
effect
in
the
kitchen
;
so
into
the
kitchen
he
went
.
   
<EOS>
There
were
assembled
,
in
that
lower
house
of
the
domestic
parliament
,
the
women
-
servants
,
Mr
Brittles
,
Mr
Giles
,
the
tinker
(
who
had
received
a
special
invitation
to
regale
himself
for
the
remainder
of
the
day
,
in
consideration
of
his
services
)
,
and
the
constable
.
 
<EOS>
The
latter
gentleman
had
a
large
staff
,
a
large
head
,
large
features
,
and
large
half
-
boots
;
and
he
looked
as
if
he
had
been
taking
a
proportionate
allowance
of
ale
---
as
indeed
he
had
.
   
<EOS>
The
adventures
of
the
previous
night
were
still
under
discussion
;
for
Mr
Giles
was
expatiating
upon
his
presence
of
mind
,
when
the
doctor
entered
;
Mr
Brittles
,
with
a
mug
of
ale
in
his
hand
,
was
corroborating
everything
,
before
his
superior
said
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sit
still
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
doctor
,
waving
his
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
sir
,
said
Mr
Giles
.
 
<EOS>
"
Misses
wished
some
ale
to
be
given
out
,
sir
;
and
as
I
felt
no
ways
inclined
for
my
own
little
room
,
sir
,
and
was
disposed
for
company
,
I
am
taking
mine
among
'em
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
Brittles
headed
a
low
murmur
,
by
which
the
ladies
and
gentlemen
generally
were
understood
to
express
the
gratification
they
derived
from
Mr
Giles
's
condescension
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Giles
looked
round
with
a
patronising
air
,
as
much
as
to
say
that
so
long
as
they
behaved
properly
,
he
would
never
desert
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
is
the
patient
to
-
night
,
sir
?
"
asked
Giles
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
-
so
"
;
returned
the
doctor
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
afraid
you
have
got
yourself
into
a
scrape
there
,
Mr
Giles
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
do
n't
mean
to
say
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Giles
,
trembling
,
"
that
he
's
going
to
die
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
thought
it
,
I
should
never
be
happy
again
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
n't
cut
a
boy
off
:
 
no
,
not
even
Brittles
here
;
not
for
all
the
plate
in
the
county
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
not
the
point
,
"
said
the
doctor
,
mysteriously
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Giles
,
are
you
a
Protestant
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
I
hope
so
,
"
faltered
Mr
Giles
,
who
had
turned
very
pale
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
what
are
YOU
,
boy
?
"
said
the
doctor
,
turning
sharply
upon
Brittles
.
   
<EOS>
"
Lord
bless
me
,
sir
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Brittles
,
starting
violently
;
"
I
'm
the
same
as
Mr
Giles
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
tell
me
this
,
"
said
the
doctor
,
"
both
of
you
,
both
of
you
!
<EOS>
Are
you
going
to
take
upon
yourselves
to
swear
,
that
that
boy
upstairs
is
the
boy
that
was
put
through
the
little
window
last
night
?
 
<EOS>
Out
with
it
!
 
<EOS>
Come
!
 
<EOS>
We
are
prepared
for
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
doctor
,
who
was
universally
considered
one
of
the
best
-
tempered
creatures
on
earth
,
made
this
demand
in
such
a
dreadful
tone
of
anger
,
that
Giles
and
Brittles
,
who
were
considerably
muddled
by
ale
and
excitement
,
stared
at
each
other
in
a
state
of
stupefaction
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pay
attention
to
the
reply
,
constable
,
will
you
?
"
said
the
doctor
,
shaking
his
forefinger
with
great
solemnity
of
manner
,
and
tapping
the
bridge
of
his
nose
with
it
,
to
bespeak
the
exercise
of
that
worthy
's
utmost
acuteness
.
<EOS>
"
Something
may
come
of
this
before
long
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
constable
looked
as
wise
as
he
could
,
and
took
up
his
staff
of
office
:
which
had
been
recling
indolently
in
the
chimney
-
corner
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
simple
question
of
identity
,
you
will
observe
,
"
said
the
doctor
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
what
it
is
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
constable
,
coughing
with
great
violence
;
for
he
had
finished
his
ale
in
a
hurry
,
and
some
of
it
had
gone
the
wrong
way
.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
's
the
house
broken
into
,
"
said
the
doctor
,
"
and
a
couple
of
men
catch
one
moment
's
glimpse
of
a
boy
,
in
the
midst
of
gunpowder
smoke
,
and
in
all
the
distraction
of
alarm
and
darkness
.
 
<EOS>
Here
's
<EOS>
a
boy
comes
to
that
very
same
house
,
next
morning
,
and
because
he
happens
to
have
his
arm
tied
up
,
these
men
lay
violent
hands
upon
him
---
by
doing
which
<EOS>
,
they
place
his
life
in
great
danger
---
and
swear
he
is
the
thief
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
the
question
is
,
whether
these
men
are
justified
by
the
fact
;
if
not
,
in
what
situation
do
they
place
themselves
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
constable
nodded
profoundly
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
,
if
that
was
n't
law
,
he
would
be
glad
to
know
what
was
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
ask
you
again
,
"
thundered
the
doctor
,
"
are
you
,
on
your
solemn
oaths
,
able
to
identify
that
boy
?
"
   
<EOS>
Brittles
looked
doubtfully
at
Mr
Giles
;
Mr
Giles
looked
doubtfully
at
Brittles
;
the
constable
put
his
hand
behind
his
ear
,
to
catch
the
reply
;
the
two
women
and
the
tinker
leaned
forward
to
listen
;
the
doctor
glanced
keenly
round
;
when
a
ring
was
heard
at
the
gate
,
and
at
the
same
moment
,
the
sound
of
wheels
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
the
runners
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Brittles
,
to
all
appearance
much
relieved
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
what
?
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
doctor
,
aghast
in
his
turn
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
Bow
Street
officers
,
sir
,
"
replied
Brittles
,
taking
up
a
candle
;
"
me
and
Mr
Giles
sent
for
'em
this
morning
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
?
"
cried
the
doctor
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
"
replied
Brittles
;
"
I
sent
a
message
up
by
the
coachman
,
and
I
only
wonder
they
were
n't
here
before
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
did
,
did
you
?
 
<EOS>
Then
confound
your
---
slow
coaches
down
here
;
that
's
all
,
"
said
the
doctor
,
walking
away
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
31
.
<EOS>
Involves
a
critical
position
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
's
that
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Brittles
,
opening
the
door
a
little
way
,
with
the
chain
up
,
and
peeping
out
,
shading
the
candle
with
his
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
Open
the
door
,
"
replied
a
man
outside
;
"
it
's
the
officers
from
Bow
Street
,
as
was
sent
to
to
-
day
.
"
   
<EOS>
Much
comforted
by
this
assurance
,
Brittles
opened
the
door
to
its
full
width
,
and
confronted
a
portly
man
in
a
great
-
coat
;
who
walked
in
,
without
saying
anything
more
,
and
wiped
his
shoes
on
the
mat
,
as
coolly
as
if
he
lived
there
.
   
<EOS>
"
Just
send
somebody
out
to
relieve
my
mate
,
will
you
,
young
man
?
"
said
the
officer
;
"
he
's
in
the
gig
,
a
-
minding
the
prad
.
 
<EOS>
Have
you
got
a
coach
"
us
here
,
that
you
could
put
it
up
in
,
for
five
or
ten
minutes
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Brittles
replying
in
the
affirmative
,
and
pointing
out
the
building
,
the
portly
man
stepped
back
to
the
garden
-
gate
,
and
helped
his
companion
to
put
up
the
gig
:
 
while
Brittles
lighted
them
,
in
a
state
of
great
admiration
.
 
<EOS>
This
done
,
they
returned
to
the
house
,
and
,
being
shown
into
a
parlour
,
took
off
their
great
-
coats
and
hats
,
and
showed
like
what
they
were
.
   
<EOS>
The
man
who
had
knocked
at
the
door
,
was
a
stout
personage
of
middle
height
,
aged
about
fifty
:
with
shiny
black
hair
,
cropped
pretty
close
;
half
-
whiskers
,
a
round
face
,
and
sharp
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
The
other
was
a
red
-
headed
,
bony
man
,
in
top
-
boots
;
with
a
rather
ill
-
favoured
countenance
,
and
a
turned
-
up
sinister
-
looking
nose
.
   
<EOS>
"
Tell
your
governor
that
Blathers
and
Duff
is
here
,
will
you
?
"
said
the
stouter
man
,
smoothing
down
his
hair
,
and
laying
a
pair
of
handcuffs
on
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
Good
-
evening
,
master
.
 
<EOS>
Can
I
have
a
word
or
two
with
you
in
private
,
if
you
please
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
addressed
to
Mr
Losberne
,
who
now
made
his
appearance
;
that
gentleman
,
motioning
Brittles
to
retire
,
brought
in
the
two
ladies
,
and
shut
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
the
lady
of
the
house
,
"
said
Mr
Losberne
,
motioning
towards
Mrs
Maylie
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Blathers
made
a
bow
.
 
<EOS>
Being
desired
to
sit
down
,
he
put
his
hat
on
the
floor
,
and
taking
a
chair
,
motioned
to
Duff
to
do
the
same
.
 
<EOS>
The
latter
gentleman
,
who
did
not
appear
quite
so
much
accustomed
to
good
society
,
or
quite
so
much
at
his
ease
in
it
---
one
of
the
two
---
seated
himself
,
after
undergoing
several
muscular
affections
of
the
limbs
,
and
the
head
of
his
stick
into
his
mouth
,
with
some
embarrassment
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
with
regard
to
this
here
robbery
,
master
,
"
said
Blathers
.
<EOS>
"
What
are
the
circumstances
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Losberne
,
who
appeared
desirous
of
gaining
time
,
recounted
them
at
great
length
,
and
with
much
circumlocution
.
 
<EOS>
Messrs.
Blathers
and
Duff
looked
very
knowing
meanwhile
,
and
occasionally
exchanged
a
nod
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
say
,
for
certain
,
till
I
see
the
work
,
of
course
,
"
said
Blathers
;
"
but
my
opinion
at
once
is
,
---
<EOS>
I
do
n't
mind
committing
myself
to
that
extent
,
---
that
this
was
n't
done
by
a
yokel
;
eh
,
Duff
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
Certainly
not
,
"
replied
Duff
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
,
translating
the
word
yokel
for
the
benefit
of
the
ladies
,
I
apprehend
your
meaning
to
be
,
that
this
attempt
was
not
made
by
a
countryman
?
"
said
Mr
Losberne
,
with
a
smile
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
it
,
master
,
"
replied
Blathers
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
all
about
the
robbery
,
is
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
All
,
"
replied
the
doctor
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
what
is
this
,
about
this
here
boy
that
the
servants
are
a
-
talking
on
?
"
said
Blathers
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
at
all
,
"
replied
the
doctor
.
 
<EOS>
"
One
of
the
frightened
servants
chose
to
take
it
into
his
head
,
that
he
had
something
to
do
with
this
attempt
to
break
into
the
house
;
but
it
's
nonsense
:
sheer
absurdity
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Wery
easy
disposed
of
,
if
it
is
,
"
remarked
Duff
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
he
says
is
quite
correct
,
"
observed
Blathers
,
nodding
his
head
in
a
confirmatory
way
,
and
playing
carelessly
with
the
handcuffs
,
as
if
they
were
a
pair
of
castanets
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
is
the
boy
?
   
<EOS>
What
account
does
he
give
of
himself
?
 
<EOS>
Where
did
he
come
from
?
<EOS>
He
did
n't
drop
out
of
the
clouds
,
did
he
,
master
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
not
,
"
replied
the
doctor
,
with
a
nervous
glance
at
the
two
ladies
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
his
whole
history
:
but
we
can
talk
about
that
presently
.
 
<EOS>
You
would
like
,
first
,
to
see
the
place
where
the
thieves
made
their
attempt
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
Certainly
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Blathers
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
had
better
inspect
the
premises
first
,
and
examine
the
servants
afterwards
.
<EOS>
That
's
the
usual
way
of
doing
business
.
"
   
<EOS>
Lights
were
then
procured
;
and
Messrs.
Blathers
and
Duff
,
attended
by
the
native
constable
,
Brittles
,
Giles
,
and
everybody
else
in
short
,
went
into
the
little
room
at
the
end
of
the
passage
and
looked
out
at
the
window
;
and
afterwards
went
round
by
way
of
the
lawn
,
and
looked
in
at
the
window
;
and
after
that
,
had
a
candle
handed
out
to
inspect
the
shutter
with
;
and
after
that
,
a
lantern
to
trace
the
footsteps
with
;
and
after
that
,
a
pitchfork
to
poke
the
bushes
with
.
 
<EOS>
This
done
,
amidst
the
breathless
interest
of
all
beholders
,
they
came
in
again
;
and
Mr
Giles
and
Brittles
were
put
through
a
melodramatic
representation
of
their
share
in
the
previous
night
's
adventures
:
which
they
performed
some
six
times
over
:
contradiction
each
other
,
in
not
more
than
one
important
respect
,
the
first
time
,
and
in
not
more
than
a
dozen
the
last
.
 
<EOS>
This
consummation
being
arrived
at
,
Blathers
and
Duff
cleared
the
room
,
and
held
a
long
council
together
,
compared
with
which
,
for
secrecy
and
solemnity
,
a
consultation
of
great
doctors
on
the
knottiest
point
in
medicine
,
would
be
mere
child
's
play
.
   
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
the
doctor
walked
up
and
down
the
next
room
in
a
very
uneasy
state
;
and
Mrs
Maylie
and
Rose
looked
on
,
with
anxious
faces
.
   
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
word
,
"
he
said
,
making
a
halt
,
after
a
great
number
of
very
rapid
turns
,
"
I
hardly
know
what
to
do
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Surely
,
"
said
Rose
,
"
the
poor
child
's
story
,
faithfully
repeated
to
these
men
,
will
be
sufficient
to
exonerate
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
doubt
it
,
my
dear
young
lady
,
"
said
the
doctor
,
shaking
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
it
would
exonerate
him
,
either
with
them
,
or
with
legal
functionaries
of
a
higher
grade
.
 
<EOS>
What
is
he
,
after
all
,
they
would
say
?
 
<EOS>
A
runaway
.
 
<EOS>
Judged
by
mere
worldly
considerations
and
probabilities
,
his
story
is
a
very
doubtful
one
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
believe
it
,
surely
?
"
<EOS>
interrupted
Rose
.
   
<EOS>
"
\
<EOS>
I
<EOS>
\
believe
it
,
strange
as
it
is
;
and
perhaps
I
may
be
an
old
fool
for
doing
so
,
"
rejoined
the
doctor
;
<EOS>
"
but
I
do
n't
think
it
is
exactly
the
tale
for
a
practical
police
-
officer
,
nevertheless
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
not
?
"
demanded
Rose
.
   
<EOS>
"
Because
,
my
pretty
cross
-
examiner
,
"
replied
the
doctor
:
"
because
,
viewed
with
their
eyes
,
there
are
many
ugly
points
about
it
;
he
can
only
prove
the
parts
that
look
ill
,
and
none
of
those
that
look
well
.
 
<EOS>
Confound
the
fellows
<EOS>
,
they
WILL
have
the
way
and
the
wherefore
,
and
will
take
nothing
for
granted
.
 
<EOS>
On
his
own
showing
,
you
see
,
he
has
been
the
companion
of
thieves
for
some
time
past
;
he
has
been
carried
to
a
police
-
officer
,
on
a
charge
of
picking
a
gentleman
's
pocket
;
he
has
been
taken
away
,
forcibly
,
from
that
gentleman
's
house
,
to
a
place
which
he
can
not
describe
or
point
out
,
and
of
the
situation
of
which
he
has
not
the
remotest
idea
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
brought
down
to
Chertsey
,
by
men
who
seem
to
have
taken
a
violent
fancy
to
him
,
whether
he
will
or
no
;
and
is
put
through
a
window
to
rob
a
house
;
and
then
,
just
at
the
very
moment
when
he
is
going
to
alarm
the
inmates
,
and
so
do
the
very
thing
that
would
set
him
all
to
rights
,
there
rushes
into
the
way
,
a
blundering
dog
of
a
half
-
bred
butler
,
and
shoots
him
!
<EOS>
As
if
on
purpose
to
prevent
his
doing
any
good
for
himself
!
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
see
all
this
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
see
it
,
of
course
,
"
replied
Rose
,
smiling
at
the
doctor
's
impetuosity
;
"
but
still
I
do
not
see
anything
in
it
,
to
criminate
the
poor
child
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
the
doctor
;
"
of
course
not
!
 
<EOS>
Bless
the
bright
eyes
of
your
sex
!
 
<EOS>
They
never
see
,
whether
for
good
or
bad
,
more
than
one
side
of
any
question
;
and
that
is
,
always
,
the
one
which
first
presents
itself
to
them
.
"
   
<EOS>
Having
given
vent
to
this
result
of
experience
,
the
doctor
put
his
hands
into
his
pockets
,
and
walked
up
and
down

room
with
even
greater
rapidity
than
before
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
more
I
think
of
it
,
"
said
the
doctor
,
"
<EOS>
the
more
I
see
that
it
will
occasion
endless
trouble
and
difficulty
if
we
put
these
men
in
possession
of
the
boy
's
real
story
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
certain
it
will
not
be
believed
;
and
even
if
they
can
do
nothing
to
him
in
the
end
,
still
the
dragging
it
forward
,
and
giving
publicity
to
all

doubts
that
will

cast
upon

,
must
interfere
,

,
with
your
benevolent
plan
of

from

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
what
is

?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Dear
,
dear
!
<EOS>
whyddid

send
for

people
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

!
<EOS>
"

Maylie
.
 
<EOS>
"
I

not

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
All
I
know

,
"
said

Losberne
,

,
"
that

.
 
<EOS>
The
object
is
a
good
one
,
and
that
must
be

.
 
<EOS>
The
boy
has
strong
symptoms
of
fever
upon

,
and
is
in
no

to

;

.
 
<EOS>
We
must

best

;
and
if
bad

,
it
is
no

ours
.
 
<EOS>
Come
in
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,

,
"

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
This
warn't

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
what
the

's

-

?
<EOS>
"
demanded

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
We

-
up

,

,
"

,

,

,
"

"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Wery

,

.

<EOS>
"
More

.
   
<EOS>
"
We

was

,
"

,

;
"
for
the
style

work

first
-
rate
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Wery
pretty

,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>

There

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

:

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

Why
,

,

!

<EOS>

<EOS>
Anythink

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

;

.
"
   
<EOS>
This

,

.
 
<EOS>
While

.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"

:

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

Family

.
 
<EOS>
Conkey

<EOS>
"

!
"

I

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Better

book
<EOS>
\
<EOS>
I
\

<EOS>

What

?
"
<EOS>

:
 
anxious

<EOS>
"

,

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
This
here
Conkey

---
"

<EOS>
Conkey

,

"
Of

.
 
<EOS>
"
Always

,

,

!
 
<EOS>
This
here
<EOS>
Conkey
Chickweed
,
miss
,
kept

-
house
over
Battlebridge
way
,
and
he
had
a

,
where
a
good

to
see

,

,

;
and
a
wery

the
sports

in
,
<EOS>
for
I
've
seen
'em
off'en
.
 
<EOS>
He
warn't
one

,
at
that

;

one

,

,

,

window
:
 
which

.
   
<EOS>
He
was
wery
quick
about

.
 
<EOS>
But
Conkey

,

;

arter

,

.
<EOS>
They

-

-

,

,

,

;

,
all

;

'em
.
 
<EOS>
However
,

;

,

,

Mr
Chickweed
,
licensed

,

among

;

,

I

n't

,

the

,

,
and

up

,
for

,
a

that
many

.
<EOS>
One

came

,

,

the

,

,

,

,

Jem
Spyers
in
<EOS>
(
Jem

)
,

.
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"

,
"
pass

,
"
 
<EOS>
"

n't

,

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"

"

;

.

<EOS>
Spyers

,

,

,

<EOS>

,

Here

!
<EOS>
Stop

!
 
<EOS>
Murder
!
"
 
<EOS>
Jem

,
a
-

.
 
<EOS>
Away

;

;

;

"
Thieves
!
"

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Spyers

;

;

"

?
"
 
<EOS>
"
D
---
 
me
!
"

,
"
I
've

!
"
 
<EOS>
It

,

warn't

,

.
<EOS>
Next

,

,

<EOS>

,

;

,

<EOS>
Off

;

!
 
<EOS>

,

;

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

Jem

?
"

;

.
   
<EOS>
"
Jem
Spyers
,
"
resumed

,
"

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
But
,

,

,

,

"
Chickweed

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

,

!
 
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If

"
returned
Mr
Blathers
.
 
<EOS>
Closely
following
Mr
Losberne
,
the
two
officers
ascended
to
Oliver
's
bedroom
;
<EOS>
Mr
Giles
preceding
the
party
,
with
a
lighted
candle
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
had
been
dozing
;
but
looked
worse
,
and
was
more
feverish
than
he
had
appeared
yet
.
 
<EOS>
Being
assisted
by
the
doctor
,
he
managed
to
sit
up
in
bed
for
a
minute
or
so
;
and
looked
at
the
strangers
without
at
all
understanding
what
was
going
forward
---
in
fact
,
without
seeming
to
recollect
where
he
was
,
or
what
had
been
passing
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
,
"
said
Mr
Losberne
,
speaking
softly
,
but
with
great
vehemence
notwithstanding
,
"
this
is
the
lad
,
who
,
being
accidentally
wounded
by
a
spring
-
gun
in
some
boyish
trespass
on
Mr
What
-
d'ye
-
call
-
him
's
grounds
,
at
the
back
here
,
comes
to
the
house
for
assistance
this
morning
,
and
is
immediately
laid
hold
of
and
maltreated
,
by
that
ingenious
gentleman
with
the
candle
in
his
hand
:
 
who
has
placed
his
life
in
considerable
danger
,
as
I
can
professionally
certify
.
"
   
<EOS>
Messrs.
Blathers
and
Duff
looked
at
Mr
Giles
,
as
he
was
thus
recommended
to
their
notice
.
 
<EOS>
The
bewildered
butler
gazed
from
them
towards
Oliver
,
and
from
Oliver
towards
Mr
Losberne
,
with
a
most
ludicrous
mixture
of
fear
and
perplexity
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
mean
to
deny
that
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
said
the
doctor
,
laying
Oliver
gently
down
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
all
done
for
the
---
for
the
best
,
sir
,
"
answered
Giles
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
I
thought
it
was
the
boy
,
or
I
would
n't
have
meddled
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
of
an
inhuman
disposition
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thought
it
was
what
boy
?
"
inquired
the
senior
officer
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
housebreaker
's
boy
,
sir
!
"
replied
Giles
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
---
they
certainly
had
a
boy
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
?
 
<EOS>
Do
you
think
so
now
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Blathers
.
   
<EOS>
"
Think
what
,
now
?
"
<EOS>
replied
Giles
,
looking
vacantly
at
his
questioner
.
   
<EOS>
"
Think
it
's
the
same
boy
,
Stupid
-
head
?
"
rejoined
Blathers
,
impatiently
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
;
I
really
do
n't
know
,
"
said
Giles
,
with
a
rueful
countenance
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
could
n't
swear
to
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
think
?
"
asked
Mr
Blathers
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
what
to
think
,
"
replied
poor
Giles
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
it
is
the
boy
;
indeed
,
I
'm
almost
certain
that
it
is
n't
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
it
ca
n't
be
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Has
this
man
been
a
-
drinking
,
sir
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Blathers
,
turning
to
the
doctor
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
a
precious
muddle
-
headed
chap
you
are
!
"
said
Duff
,
addressing
Mr
Giles
,
with
supreme
contempt
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Losberne
had
been
feeling
the
patient
's
pulse
during
this
short
dialogue
;
but
he
now
rose
from
the
chair
by
the
bedside
,
and
remarked
,
that
if
the
officers
had
any
doubts
upon
the
subject
,
they
would
perhaps
like
to
step
into
the
next
room
,
and
have
Brittles
before
them
.
   
<EOS>
Acting
upon
this
suggestion
,
they
adjourned
to
a
neighbouring
apartment
,
where
Mr
Brittles
,
being
called
in
,
involved
himself
and
his
respected
superior
in
such
a
wonderful
maze
of
fresh
contradictions
and
impossibilities
,
as
tended
to
throw
no
particular
light
on
anything
,
but
the
fact
of
his
own
strong
mystification
;
except
,
indeed
,
his
declarations
that
he
should
n't
know
the
real
boy
,
if
he
were
put
before
him
that
instant
;
that
he
had
only
taken
Oliver
to
be
he
,
because
Mr
Giles
had
said
he
was
;
and
that
Mr
Giles
had
,
five
minutes
previously
,
admitted
in
the
kitchen
,
that
he
begain
to
be
very
much
afraid
he
had
been
a
little
too
hasty
.
   
<EOS>
Among
other
ingenious
surmises
,
the
question
was
then
raised
,
whether
Mr
Giles
had
really
hit
anybody
;
and
upon
examination
of
the
fellow
pistol
to
that
which
he
had
fired
,
it
turned
out
to
have
no
more
destructive
loading
than
gunpowder
and
brown
paper
:
a
discovery
which
made
a
considerable
impression
on
everybody
but
the
doctor
,
who
had
drawn
the
ball
about
ten
minutes
before
.
<EOS>
Upon
no
one
,
however
,
did
it
make
a
greater
impression
than
on
Mr
Giles
himself
;
who
,
after
labouring
,
for
some
hours
,
under
the
fear
of
having
mortally
wounded
a
fellow
-
creature
,
eagerly
caught
at
this
new
idea
,
and
favoured
it
to
the
utmost
.
 
<EOS>
Finally
,
the
officers
,
without
troubling
themselves
very
much
about
Oliver
,
left
the
Chertsey
constable
in
the
house
,
and
took
up
their
rest
for
that
night
in
the
town
;
promising
to
return
the
next
morning
.
   
<EOS>
With
the
next
morning
,
there
came
a
rumour
,
that
two
men
and
a
boy
were
in
the
cage
at
Kingston
,
who
had
been
apprehended
over
night
under
suspicious
circumstances
;
and
to
Kingston
Messrs.
Blathers
and
Duff
journeyed
accordingly
.
<EOS>
The
suspicious
circumstances
,
however
,
resolving
themselves
,
on
investigation
,
into
the
one
fact
,
that
they
had
been
discovered
sleeping
under
a
haystack
;
which
,
although
a
great
crime
,
is
only
punishable
by
imprisonment
,
and
is
,
in
the
merciful
eye
of
the
English
law
,
and
its
comprehensive
love
of
all
the
King
's
subjects
,
held
to
be
no
satisfactory
proof
,
in
the
absence
of
all
other
evidence
,
that
the
sleeper
,
or
sleepers
,
have
committed
burglary
accompanied
with
violence
,
and
have
therefore
rendered
themselves
liable
to
the
punishment
of
death
;
Messrs.
Blathers
and
Duff
came
back
again
,
as
wise
as
they
went
.
   
<EOS>
In
short
,
after
some
more
examination
,
and
a
great
deal
more
conversation
,
a
neighbouring
magistrate
was
readily
induced
to
take
the
joint
bail
of
Mrs
Maylie
and
Mr
Losberne
for
Oliver
's
appearance
if
he
should
ever
be
called
upon
;
and
Blathers
and
Duff
,
being
rewarded
with
a
couple
of
guineas
,
returned
to
town
with
divided
opinions
on
the
subject
of
their
expedition
:
<EOS>
the
latter
gentleman
on
a
mature
consideration
of
all
the
circumstances
,
inclining
to
the
belief
that
the
burglarious
attempt
had
originated
with
the
Family
Pet
;
and
the
former
being
equally
disposed
to
concede
the
full
merit
of
it
to
the
great
Mr
Conkey
Chickweed
.
   
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
Oliver
gradually
throve
and
prospered
under
the
united
care
of
Mrs
Maylie
,
Rose
,
and
the
kind
-
hearted
Mr
Losberne
.
 
<EOS>
If
fervent
prayers
,
gushing
from
hearts
overcharged
with
gratitude
,
be
heard
in
heaven
---
and
if
they
be
not
,
what
prayers
are
!
<EOS>
---
the
blessings
which
the
orphan
child
called
down
upon
them
,
sunk
into
their
souls
,
diffusing
peace
and
happiness
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
32
.
<EOS>
Of
the
happy
life
Oliver
began
to
lead
with
his
kind
friends
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
's
ailings
were
neither
slight
nor
few
.
 
<EOS>
In
addition
to
the
pain
and
delay
attendant
on
a
broken
limb
,
his
exposure
to
the
wet
and
cold
had
brought
on
fever
and
ague
:
 
which
hung
about
him
for
many
weeks
,
and
reduced
him
sadly
.
<EOS>
But
,
at
length
,
he
began
,
by
slow
degrees
,
to
get
better
,
and
to
be
able
to
say
sometimes
,
<EOS>
in
a
few
tearful
words
,
how
deeply
he
felt
the
goodness
of
the
two
sweet
ladies
,
and
how
ardently
he
hoped
that
when
he
grew
strong
and
well
again
,
he
could
do
something
to
show
his
gratitude
;
only
something
,
which
would
let
them
see
the
love
and
duty
with
which
his
breast
was
full
;
something
,
however
slight
,
which
would
prove
to
them
that
their
gentle
kindness
had
not
been
cast
away
;
but
that
the
poor
boy
whom
their
charity
had
rescued
from
misery
,
or
death
,
was
eager
to
serve
them
with
his
whole
heart
and
soul
.
   
<EOS>
"
Poor
fellow
!
<EOS>
"
said
Rose
,
when
Oliver
had
been
one
day
feebly
endeavouring
to
utter
the
words
of
thankfulness
that
rose
to
his
pale
lips
;
"
you
shall
have
many
opportunities
of
serving
us
,
if
you
will
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
going
into
the
country
,
and
my
aunt
intends
that
you
shall
accompany
us
.
 
<EOS>
The
quiet
place
,
the
pure
air
,
and
all
the
pleasure
and
beauties
of
spring
,
will
restore
you
in
a
few
days
.
 
<EOS>
We
will
employ
you
in
a
hundred
ways
,
when
you
can
bear
the
trouble
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
trouble
!
"
cried
Oliver
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
<EOS>
dear
lady
,
if
I
could
but
work
for
you
;
if
I
could
only
give
you
pleasure
by
watering
your
flowers
,
or
watching
your
birds
,
or
running
up
and
down
the
whole
day
long
,
to
make
you
happy
;
what
would
I
give
to
do
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
shall
give
nothing
at
all
,
"
said
Miss
Maylie
,
smiling
;
"
for
,
as
I
told
you
before
,
we
shall
employ
you
in
a
hundred
ways
;
and
if
you
only
take
half
the
trouble
to
please
us
,
that
you
promise
now
,
you
will
make
me
very
happy
indeed
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Happy
,
ma'am
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Oliver
;
"
how
kind
of
you
to
say
so
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
will
make
me
happier
than
I
can
tell
you
,
"
replied
the
young
lady
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
think
that
my
dear
good
aunt
should
have
been
the
means
of
rescuing
any
one
from
such
sad
misery
as
you
have
described
to
us
,
would
be
an
unspeakable
pleasure
to
me
;
but
to
know
that
the
object
of
her
goodness
and
compassion
was
sincerely
grateful
and
attached
,
in
consequence
,
would
delight
me
,
more
than
you
can
well
imagine
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
understand
me
?
<EOS>
"
she
inquired
,
watching
Oliver
's
thoughtful
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
yes
,
ma'am
,
yes
!
"
replied
Oliver
eagerly
;
"
but
I
was
thinking
that
I
am
ungrateful
now
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
To
whom
?
"
inquired
the
young
lady
.
   
<EOS>
"
To
the
kind
gentleman
,
and
the
dear
old
nurse
,
who
took
so
much
care
of
me
before
,
"
rejoined
Oliver
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
they
knew
how
happy
I
am
,
they
would
be
pleased
,
I
am
sure
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
they
would
,
"
rejoined
Oliver
's
benefactress
;
"
and
Mr
Losberne
has
already
been
kind
enough
to
promise
that
when
you
are
well
enough
to
bear
the
journey
,
he
will
carry
you
to
see
them
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Has
he
,
ma'am
?
"
cried
Oliver
,
his
face
brightening
with
pleasure
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
what
I
shall
do
for
joy
when
I
see
their
kind
faces
once
again
!
"
   
<EOS>
In
a
short
time
Oliver
was
sufficiently
recovered
to
undergo
the
fatigue
of
this
expedition
.
 
<EOS>
One
morning
he
and
Mr
Losberne
set
out
,
accordingly
,
in
a
little
carriage
which
belonged
to
Mrs
Maylie
.
 
<EOS>
When
they
came
to
Chertsey
Bridge
,
Oliver
turned
very
pale
,
and
uttered
a
loud
exclamation
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
with
the
boy
?
"
cried
the
doctor
,
as
usual
,
all
in
a
bustle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
see
anything
---
hear
anything
---
feel
anything
---
eh
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
,
sir
,
"
cried
Oliver
,
pointing
out
of
the
carriage
window
.
<EOS>
"
That
house
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
well
,
what
of
it
?
 
<EOS>
Stop
coachman
.
 
<EOS>
Pull
up
here
,
"
cried
the
doctor
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
of
the
house
,
my
man
;
eh
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
thieves
---
the
house
they
took
me
to
!
"
whispered
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
devil
it
is
!
"
cried
the
doctor
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hallo
,
there
!
<EOS>
let
me
out
!
"
   
<EOS>
But
,
before
the
coachman
could
dismount
from
his
box
,
he
had
tumbled
out
of
the
coach
,
by
some
means
or
other
;
and
,
running
down
to
the
deserted
tenement
,
began
kicking
at
the
door
like
a
madman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Halloa
?
"
said
a
little
ugly
hump
-
backed
man
:
 
opening
the
door
so
suddenly
,
that
the
doctor
,
from
the
very
impetus
of
his
last
kick
,
nearly
fell
forward
into
the
passage
.
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
here
?
"
   
"
Matter
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
other
,
collaring
him
,
without
a
moment
's
reflection
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
good
deal
.
 
<EOS>
Robbery
is
the
matter
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
'll
be
Murder
the
matter
,
too
,
<EOS>
"
replied
the
hump
-
backed
man
,
coolly
,
"
if
you
do
n't
take
your
hands
off
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
hear
me
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hear
you
,
"
said
the
doctor
,
giving
his
captive
a
hearty
shake
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Where
's
---
confound
the
fellow
<EOS>
,
what
's
his
rascally
name
---
Sikes
;
that
's
it
.
 
<EOS>
Where
's
Sikes
,
you
thief
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
hump
-
backed
man
stared
,
as
if
in
excess
of
amazement
and
indignation
;
then
,
twisting
himself
,
dexterously
,
from
the
doctor
's
grasp
,
growled
forth
a
volley
of
horrid
oaths
,
and
retired
into
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
Before
he
could
shut
the
door
,
however
,
the
doctor
had
passed
into
the
parlour
,
without
a
word
of
parley
.
   
<EOS>
He
looked
anxiously
round
;
not
an
article
of
furniture
;
not
a
vestige
of
anything
,
animate
or
inanimate
;
not
even
the
position
of
the
cupboards
;
answered
Oliver
's
description
!
   
<EOS>
"
Now
!
"
said
the
hump
-
backed
man
,
who
had
watched
him
keenly
,
"
what
do
you
mean
by
coming
into
my
house
,
in
this
violent
way
?
<EOS>
Do
you
want
to
rob
me
,
or
to
murder
me
?
 
<EOS>
Which
is
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Did
you
ever
know
a
man
come
out
to
do
either
,
in
a
chariot
and
a
pair
,
you
ridiculous
old
vampire
?
"
said
the
irritable
doctor
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
want
,
then
?
"
demanded
the
hunchback
.
 
<EOS>
"
Will
you
take
yourself
off
,
before
I
do
you
a
mischief
?
 
<EOS>
Curse
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
As
soon
as
I
think
proper
,
"
said
Mr
Losberne
,
looking
into
the
other
parlour
;
which
,
like
the
first
,
bore
no
resemblance
whatever
to
Oliver
's
account
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
find
you
out
,
some
day
,
my
friend
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Will
you
?
"
sneered
the
ill
-
favoured
cripple
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
ever
want
me
,
I
'm
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
n't
lived
here
mad
and
all
alone
,
for
five
-
and
-
twenty
years
,
to
be
scared
by
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
shall
pay
for
this
;
you
shall
pay
for
this
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
so
saying
,
the
mis
-
shapen
little
demon
set
up
a
yell
,
and
danced
upon
the
ground
,
as
if
wild
with
rage
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stupid
enough
,
this
,
"
muttered
the
doctor
to
himself
;
"
the
boy
must
have
made
a
mistake
.
 
<EOS>
Here
!
 
<EOS>
Put
that
in
your
pocket
,
and
shut
yourself
up
again
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
these
words
he
flung
the
hunchback
a
piece
of
money
,
and
returned
to
the
carriage
.
   
<EOS>
The
man
followed
to
the
chariot
door
,
uttering
the
wildest
imprecations
and
curses
all
the
way
;
but
as
Mr
Losberne
turned
to
speak
to
the
driver
,
he
looked
into
the
carriage
,
and
eyed
Oliver
for
an
instant
with
a
glance
so
sharp
and
fierce
and
at
the
same
time
so
furious
and
vindictive
,
that
,
waking
or
sleeping
,
he
could
not
forget
it
for
months
afterwards
.
 
<EOS>
He
continued
to
utter
the
most
fearful
imprecations
,
until
the
driver
had
resumed
his
seat
;
and
when
they
were
once
more
on
their
way
,
they
could
see
him
some
distance
behind
:
beating
his
feet
upon
the
ground
,
and
tearing
his
hair
,
in
transports
of
real
or
pretended
rage
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
an
ass
!
"
said
the
doctor
,
after
a
long
silence
.
 
<EOS>
"
Did
you
know
that
before
,
Oliver
?
"
   
"
No
,
sir
.
"
   
"
Then
do
n't
forget
it
another
time
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
An
ass
,
"
said
the
doctor
again
,
after
a
further
silence
of
some
minutes
.
 
<EOS>
"
Even
if
it
had
been
the
right
place
,
and
the
right
fellows
had
been
there
,
what
could
I
have
done
,
single
-
handed
?
<EOS>
And
if
I
had
had
assistance
,
I
see
no
good
that
I
should
have
done
,
except
leading
to
my
own
exposure
,
and
an
unavoidable
statement
of
the
manner
in
which
I
have
hushed
up
this
business
.
<EOS>
That
would
have
served
me
right
,
though
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
always
involving
myself
in
some
scrape
or
other
,
by
acting
on
impulse
.
 
<EOS>
It
might
have
done
me
good
.
"
   
<EOS>
Now
,
the
fact
was
that
the
excellent
doctor
had
never
acted
upon
anything
but
impulse
all
through
his
life
,
and
if
was
no
bad
compliment
to
the
nature
of
the
impulses
which
governed
him
,
that
so
far
from
being
involved
in
any
peculiar
troubles
or
misfortunes
,
he
had
the
warmest
respect
and
esteem
of
all
who
knew
him
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
truth
must
be
told
,
he
was
a
little
out
of
temper
,
for
a
minute
or
two
,
at
being
disappointed
in
procuring
corroborative
evidence
of
Oliver
's
story
on
the
very
first
occasion
on
which
he
had
a
chance
of
obtaining
any
.
 
<EOS>
He
soon
came
round
again
,
however
;
and
finding
that
Oliver
's
replies
to
his
questions
,
were
still
as
straightforward
and
consistent
,
and
still
delivered
with
as
much
apparent
sincerity
and
truth
,
as
they
had
ever
been
,
he
made
up
his
mind
to
attach
full
credence
to
them
,
from
that
time
forth
.
   
<EOS>
As
Oliver
knew
the
name
of
the
street
in
which
Mr
Brownlow
resided
,
they
were
enabled
to
drive
straight
thither
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
coach
turned
into
it
,
his
heart
beat
so
violently
,
that
he
could
scarcely
draw
his
breath
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Now
,
my
boy
,
which
house
is
it
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Losberne
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
!
 
That
!
"
replied
Oliver
,
pointing
eagerly
out
of
the
window
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
white
house
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
make
haste
!
 
<EOS>
Pray
make
haste
!
<EOS>
I
feel
as
if
I
should
die
:
it
makes
me
tremble
so
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,
come
!
"
said
the
good
doctor
,
patting
him
on
the
shoulder
.
<EOS>
"
You
will
see
them
directly
,
and
they
will
be
overjoyed
to
find
you
safe
and
well
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
I
hope
so
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Oliver
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
were
so
good
to
me
;
so
very
,
very
good
to
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
coach
rolled
on
.
 
<EOS>
It
stopped
.
 
<EOS>
No
<EOS>
;
that
was
the
wrong
house
;
the
next
door
.
 
<EOS>
It
went
on
a
few
paces
,
and
stopped
again
.
<EOS>
Oliver
looked
up
at
the
windows
,
with
tears
of
happy
expectation
coursing
down
his
face
.
   
<EOS>
Alas
!
<EOS>
the
white
house
was
empty
,
and
there
was
a
bill
in
the
window
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
Let
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Knock
at
the
next
door
,
"
cried
Mr
Losberne
,
taking
Oliver
's
arm
in
his
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
has
become
of
Mr
Brownlow
,
who
used
to
live
in
the
adjoining
house
,
do
you
know
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
servant
did
not
know
;
but
would
go
and
inquire
.
 
<EOS>
She
presently
returned
,
and
said
,
that
Mr
Brownlow
had
sold
off
his
goods
,
and
gone
to
the
West
Indies
,
six
weeks
before
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
clasped
his
hands
,
and
sank
feebly
backward
.
   
<EOS>
"
Has
his
housekeeper
gone
too
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Losberne
,
after
a
moment
's
pause
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
"
;
replied
the
servant
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
old
gentleman
,
the
housekeeper
,
and
a
gentleman
who
was
a
friend
of
Mr
Brownlow
's
,
all
went
together
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
turn
towards
home
again
,
"
said
Mr
Losberne
to
the
driver
;
"
and
do
n't
stop
to
bait
the
horses
,
till
you
get
out
of
this
confounded
London
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
book
-
stall
keeper
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
said
Oliver
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
the
way
there
.
 
<EOS>
See
him
,
pray
,
sir
!
 
<EOS>
Do
see
him
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
poor
boy
,
this
is
disappointment
enough
for
one
day
,
"
said
the
doctor
.
 
<EOS>
"
Quite
enough
for
both
of
us
.
 
<EOS>
If
we
go
to
the
book
-
stall
keeper
's
,
we
shall
certainly
find
that
he
is
dead
,
or
has
set
his
house
on
fire
,
or
run
away
.
 
<EOS>
No
;
home
again
straight
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
in
obedience
to
the
doctor
's
impulse
,
home
they
went
.
   
<EOS>
This
bitter
disappointment
caused
Oliver
much
sorrow
and
grief
,
even
in
the
midst
of
his
happiness
;
for
he
had
pleased
himself
,
many
times
during
his
illness
,
with
thinking
of
all
that
Mr
Brownlow
and
Mrs
Bedwin
would
say
to
him
:
and
what
delight
it
would
be
to
tell
them
how
many
long
days
and
nights
he
had
passed
in
reflecting
on
what
they
had
done
for
him
,
and
in
bewailing
his
cruel
separation
from
them
.
<EOS>
The
hope
of
eventually
clearing
himself
with
them
,
too
,
and
explaining
how
he
had
been
forced
away
,
had
buoyed
him
up
,
and
sustained
him
,
under
many
of
his
recent
trials
;
and
now
,
the
idea
that
they
should
have
gone
so
far
,
and
carried
with
them
the
belief
that
the
was
an
impostor
and
a
robber
---
a
belief
which
might
remain
uncontradicted
to
his
dying
day
---
was
almost
more
than
he
could
bear
.
   
<EOS>
The
circumstance
occasioned
no
alteration
,
however
,
in
the
behaviour
of
his
benefactors
.
 
<EOS>
After
another
fortnight
,
when
the
fine
warm
weather
had
fairly
begun
,
and
every
tree
and
flower
was
putting
forth
its
young
leaves
and
rich
blossoms
,
they
made
preparations
for
quitting
the
house
at
Chertsey
,
for
some
months
.
   
<EOS>
Sending
the
plate
,
which
had
so
excited
Fagin
's
cupidity
,
to
the
banker
's
;
and
leaving
Giles
and
another
servant
in
care
of
the
house
,
they
departed
to
a
cottage
at
some
distance
in
the
country
,
and
took
Oliver
with
them
.
   
<EOS>
Who
can
describe
the
pleasure
and
delight
,
the
peace
of
mind
and
soft
tranquillity
,
the
sickly
boy
felt
in
the
balmy
air
,
and
among
the
green
hills
and
rich
woods
,
of
an
inland
village
!
 
<EOS>
Who
can
tell
how
scenes
of
peace
and
quietude
sink
into
the
minds
of
pain
-
worn
dwellers
in
close
and
noisy
places
,
and
carry
their
