own
freshness
,
deep
into
their
jaded
hearts
!
 
<EOS>
Men
who
have
lived
in
crowded
,
pent
-
up
streets
,
through
lives
of
toil
,
and
who
have
never
wished
for
change
;
men
,
to
whom
custom
has
indeed
been
second
nature
,
and
who
have
come
almost
to
love
each
brick
and
stone
that
formed
the
narrow
boundaries
of
their
daily
walks
;
even
they
,
with
the
hand
of
death
upon
them
,
have
been
known
to
yearn
at
last
for
one
short
glimpse
of
Nature
's
face
;
and
,
carried
far
from
the
scenes
of
their
old
pains
and
pleasures
,
have
seemed
to
pass
at
once
into
a
new
state
of
being
.
 
<EOS>
Crawling
forth
,
from
day
to
day
,
to
some
green
sunny
spot
,
they
have
had
such
memories
wakened
up
within
them
by
the
sight
of
the
sky
,
and
hill
and
plain
,
and
glistening
water
,
that
a
foretaste
of
heaven
itself
has
soothed
their
quick
decline
,
and
they
have
sunk
into
their
tombs
,
as
peacefully
as
the
sun
whose
setting
they
watched
from
their
lonely
chamber
window
but
a
few
hours
before
,
faded
from
their
dim
and
feeble
sight
!
 
<EOS>
The
memories
which
peaceful
country
scenes
call
up
,
are
not
of
this
world
,
nor
of
its
thoughts
and
hopes
.
 
<EOS>
Their
gentle
influence
may
teach
us
how
to
weave
fresh
garlands
for
the
graves
of
those
we
loved
:
 
may
purify
our
thoughts
,
and
bear
down
before
it
old
enmity
and
hatred
;
but
beneath
all
this
,
there
lingers
,
in
the
least
reflective
mind
,
a
vague
and
half
-
formed
consciousness
of
having
held
such
feelings
long
before
,
in
some
remote
and
distant
time
,
which
calls
up
solemn
thoughts
of
distant
times
to
come
,
and
bends
down
pride
and
worldliness
beneath
it
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
lovely
spot
to
which
they
repaired
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
,
whose
days
had
been
spent
among
squalid
crowds
,
and
in
the
midst
of
noise
and
brawling
,
seemed
to
enter
on
a
new
existence
there
.
 
<EOS>
The
rose
and
honeysuckle
clung
to
the
cottage
walls
;
the
ivy
crept
round
the
trunks
of
the
trees
;
and
the
garden
-
flowers
perfumed
the
air
with
delicious
odours
.
 
<EOS>
Hard
by
,
was
a
little
churchyard
;
not
crowded
with
tall
unsightly
gravestones
,
but
full
of
humble
mounds
,
covered
with
fresh
turf
and
moss
:
beneath
which
,
the
old
people
of
the
village
lay
at
rest
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
often
wandered
here
;
and
,
thinking
of
the
wretched
grave
in
which
his
mother
lay
,
would
sometimes
sit
him
down
and
sob
unseen
;
but
,
when
he
raised
his
eyes
to
the
deep
sky
overhead
,
he
would
cease
to
think
of
her
as
lying
in
the
ground
,
and
would
weep
for
her
,
sadly
,
but
without
pain
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
happy
time
.
 
<EOS>
The
days
were
peaceful
and
serene
;
the
nights
brought
with
them
neither
fear
nor
care
;
no
languishing
in
a
wretched
prison
,
or
associating
with
wretched
men
;
nothing
but
pleasant
and
happy
thoughts
.
 
<EOS>
Every
morning
he
went
to
a
white
-
headed
old
gentleman
,
who
lived
near
the
little
church
:
who
taught
him
to
read
better
,
and
to
write
:
 
and
who
spoke
so
kindly
,
and
took
such
pains
,
that
Oliver
could
never
try
enough
to
please
him
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
he
would
walk
with
Mrs
Maylie
and
Rose
,
and
hear
them
talk
of
books
;
or
perhaps
sit
near
them
,
in
some
shady
place
,
and
listen
whilst
the
young
lady
read
:
which
he
could
have
done
,
until
it
grew
too
dark
to
see
the
letters
.
<EOS>
Then
,
he
had
his
own
lesson
for
the
next
day
to
prepare
;
and
at
this
,
he
would
work
hard
,
in
a
little
room
which
looked
into
the
garden
,
till
evening
came
slowly
on
,
when
the
ladies
would
walk
out
again
,
and
he
with
them
:
 
listening
with
such
pleasure
to
all
they
said
:
 
and
so
happy
if
they
wanted
a
flower
that
he
could
climb
to
reach
,
or
had
forgotten
anything
he
could
run
to
fetch
:
that
he
could
never
be
quick
enought
about
it
.
<EOS>
When
it
became
quite
dark
,
and
they
returned
home
,
the
young
lady
would
sit
down
to
the
piano
,
and
play
some
pleasant
air
,
or
sing
,
in
a
low
and
gentle
voice
,
some
old
song
which
it
pleased
her
aunt
to
hear
.
<EOS>
There
would
be
no
candles
lighted
at
such
times
as
these
;
and
Oliver
would
sit
by
one
of
the
windows
,
listening
to
the
sweet
music
,
in
a
perfect
rapture
.
   
<EOS>
And
when
Sunday
came
,
how
differently
the
day
was
spent
,
from
any
way
in
which
he
had
ever
spent
it
yet
!
<EOS>
and
how
happily
too
;
like
all
the
other
days
in
that
most
happy
time
!
 
<EOS>
There
was
the
little
church
,
in
the
morning
,
with
the
green
leaves
fluttering
at
the
windows
:
 
the
birds
singing
without
:
 
and
the
sweet
-
smelling
air
stealing
in
at
the
low
porch
,
and
filling
the
homely
building
with
its
fragrance
.
<EOS>
The
poor
people
were
so
neat
and
clean
,
and
knelt
so
reverently
in
prayer
,
that
it
seemed
a
pleasure
,
not
a
tedious
duty
,
their
assembling
there
together
;
and
though
the
singing
might
be
rude
,
it
was
real
,
and
sounded
more
musical
(
to
Oliver
's
ears
at
least
)
than
any
he
had
ever
heard
in
church
before
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
there
were
the
walks
as
usual
,
and
many
calls
at
the
clean
houses
of
the
labouring
men
;
and
at
night
,
Oliver
read
a
chapter
or
two
from
the
Bible
,
which
he
had
been
studying
all
the
week
,
and
in
the
performance
of
which
duty
he
felt
more
proud
and
pleased
,
than
if
he
had
been
the
clergyman
himself
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
morning
,
Oliver
would
be
a
-
foot
by
six
o'clock
,
roaming
the
fields
,
and
plundering
the
hedges
,
far
and
wide
,
for
nosegays
of
wild
flowers
,
with
which
he
would
return
laden
,
home
;
and
which
it
took
great
care
and
consideration
to
arrange
,
to
the
best
advantage
,
for
the
embellishment
of
the
breakfast
-
table
.
<EOS>
There
was
fresh
groundsel
,
too
,
for
Miss
Maylie
's
birds
,
with
which
Oliver
,
who
had
been
studying
the
subject
under
the
able
tuition
of
the
village
clerk
,
would
decorate
the
cages
,
in
the
most
approved
taste
.
<EOS>
When
the
birds
were
made
all
spruce
and
smart
for
the
day
,
there
was
usually
some
little
commission
of
charity
to
execute
in
the
village
;
or
,
failing
that
,
there
was
rare
cricket
-
playing
,
sometimes
,
on
the
green
;
or
,
failing
that
,
there
was
always
something
to
do
in
the
garden
,
or
about
the
plants
,
to
which
Oliver
(
who
had
studied
this
science
also
,
under
the
same
master
,
who
was
a
gardener
by
trade
,
)
applied
himself
with
hearty
good
-
will
,
until
Miss
Rose
made
her
appearance
:
 
when
there
were
a
thousand
commendations
to
be
bestowed
on
all
he
had
done
.
   
<EOS>
So
three
months
glided
away
;
three
months
which
,
in
the
life
of
the
most
blessed
and
favoured
of
mortals
,
might
have
been
unmingled
happiness
,
and
which
,
in
Oliver
's
were
true
felicity
.
<EOS>
With
the
purest
and
most
amiable
generousity
on
one
side
;
and
the
truest
,
warmest
,
soul
-
felt
gratitude
on
the
other
;
it
is
no
wonder
that
,
by
the
end
of
that
short
time
,
Oliver
Twist
had
become
completely
domesticated
with
the
old
lady
and
her
niece
,
and
that
the
fervent
attachment
of
his
young
and
sensitive
heart
,
was
repaid
by
their
pride
in
,
and
attachment
to
,
himself
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
33
.
<EOS>
Wherein
the
happiness
of
Oliver
and
his
friends
,
experiences
a
sudden
check
.
 
<EOS>
Spring
flew
swiftly
by
,
and
summer
came
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
village
had
been
beautiful
at
first
it
was
now
in
the
full
glow
and
luxuriance
of
its
richness
.
 
<EOS>
The
great
trees
,
which
had
looked
shrunken
and
bare
in
the
earlier
months
,
had
now
burst
into
strong
life
and
health
;
and
stretching
forth
their
green
arms
over
the
thirsty
ground
,
converted
open
and
naked
spots
into
choice
nooks
,
where
was
a
deep
and
pleasant
shade
from
which
to
look
upon
the
wide
prospect
,
steeped
in
sunshine
,
which
lay
stretched
beyond
.
 
<EOS>
The
earth
had
donned
her
mantle
of
brightest
green
;
and
shed
her
richest
perfumes
abroad
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
prime
and
vigour
of
the
year
;
all
things
were
glad
and
flourishing
.
   
<EOS>
Still
,
the
same
quiet
life
went
on
at
the
little
cottage
,
and
the
same
cheerful
serenity
prevailed
among
its
inmates
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
had
long
since
grown
stout
and
healthy
;
but
health
or
sickness
made
no
difference
in
his
warm
feelings
of
a
great
many
people
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
still
the
same
gentle
,
attached
,
affectionate
creature
that
he
had
been
when
pain
and
suffering
had
wasted
his
strength
,
and
when
he
was
dependent
for
every
slight
attention
,
and
comfort
on
those
who
tended
him
.
   
<EOS>
One
beautiful
night
,
when
they
had
taken
a
longer
walk
than
was
customary
with
them
:
 
for
the
day
had
been
unusually
warm
,
and
there
was
a
brilliant
moon
,
and
a
light
wind
had
sprung
up
,
which
was
unusually
refreshing
.
 
<EOS>
Rose
had
been
in
high
spirits
,
too
,
and
they
had
walked
on
,
in
merry
conversation
,
until
they
had
far
exceeded
their
ordinary
bounds
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Maylie
being
fatigued
,
they
returned
more
slowly
home
.
 
<EOS>
The
young
lady
merely
throwing
off
her
simple
bonnet
,
sat
down
to
the
piano
as
usual
.
 
<EOS>
After
running
abstractedly
over
the
keys
for
a
few
minutes
,
she
fell
into
a
low
and
very
solemn
air
;
and
as
she
played
it
,
they
heard
a
sound
as
if
she
were
weeping
.
   
<EOS>
"
Rose
,
my
dear
!
"
said
the
elder
lady
.
   
<EOS>
Rose
made
no
reply
,
but
played
a
little
quicker
,
as
though
the
words
had
roused
her
from
some
painful
thoughts
.
   
<EOS>
"
Rose
,
my
love
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mrs
Maylie
,
rising
hastily
,
and
bending
over
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
this
?
 
<EOS>
In
tears
!
 
<EOS>
My
dear
child
,
what
distresses
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
aunt
;
nothing
,
"
replied
the
young
lady
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
what
it
is
;
I
ca
n't
describe
it
;
but
I
feel
---
"
   
"
Not
ill
,
my
love
?
"
<EOS>
interposed
Mrs
Maylie
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
no
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
not
ill
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Rose
:
<EOS>
shuddering
as
though
some
deadly
chillness
were
passing
over
her
,
while
she
spoke
;
"
I
shall
be
better
presently
.
 
<EOS>
Close
the
window
,
pray
!
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver
hastened
to
comply
with
her
request
.
 
<EOS>
The
young
lady
,
making
an
effort
to
recover
her
cheerfulness
,
strove
to
play
some
livelier
tune
;
but
her
fingers
dropped
powerless
over
the
keys
.
<EOS>
Covering
her
face
with
her
hands
,
she
sank
upon
a
sofa
,
and
gave
vent
to
the
tears
which
she
was
now
unable
to
repress
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
child
!
"
said
the
elderly
lady
,
folding
her
arms
about
her
,
"
I
never
saw
you
so
before
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
would
not
alarm
you
if
I
could
avoid
it
,
"
rejoined
Rose
;
"
but
indeed
I
have
tried
very
hard
,
and
can
not
help
this
.
<EOS>
I
fear
I
AM
ill
,
aunt
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
She
was
,
indeed
;
for
,
when
candles
were
brought
,
they
saw
that
in
the
very
short
time
which
had
elapsed
since
their
return
home
,
the
hue
of
her
countenance
had
changed
to
a
marble
whiteness
.
<EOS>
Its
expression
had
lost
nothing
of
its
beauty
;
but
it
was
changed
;
and
there
was
an
anxious
haggard
look
about
the
gentle
face
,
which
it
had
never
worn
before
.
 
<EOS>
Another
minute
,
and
it
was
suffused
with
<EOS>
a
crimson
flush
:
 
and
a
heavy
wildness
came
over
the
soft
blue
eye
.
 
<EOS>
Again
this
disappeared
,
like
the
shadow
thrown
by
a
passing
cloud
;
and
she
was
once
more
deadly
pale
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
,
who
watched
the
old
lady
anxiously
,
observed
that
she
was
alarmed
by
these
appearances
;
and
so
in
truth
,
was
he
;
but
seeing
that
she
affected
to
make
light
of
them
,
he
endeavoured
to
do
the
same
,
and
they
so
far
succeeded
,
that
when
Rose
was
persuaded
by
her
aunt
to
retire
for
the
night
,
she
was
in
better
spirits
;
and
appeared
even
in
better
health
:
 
assuring
them
that
she
felt
certain
she
should
rise
in
the
morning
,
quite
well
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
,
"
said
Oliver
,
when
Mrs
Maylie
returned
,
"
that
nothing
is
the
matter
?
 
<EOS>
She
do
n't
look
well
to
-
night
,
but
---
"
   
<EOS>
The
old
lady
motioned
to
him
not
to
speak
;
and
sitting
herself
down
in
a
dark
corner
of
the
room
,
remained
silent
for
some
time
.
   
<EOS>
At
length
,
she
said
,
in
a
trembling
voice
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
not
,
Oliver
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
very
happy
with
her
for
some
years
:
 
too
happy
,
perhaps
.
 
<EOS>
It
may
be
time
that
I
should
meet
with
some
misfortune
;
but
I
hope
it
is
not
this
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
?
"
inquired
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
heavy
blow
,
"
said
the
old
lady
,
"
of
losing
the
dear
girl
who
has
so
long
been
my
comfort
and
happiness
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
God
forbid
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Oliver
,
hastily
.
   
<EOS>
"
Amen
to
that
,
my
child
!
"
said
the
old
lady
,
wringing
her
hands
.
   
<EOS>
"
Surely
there
is
no
danger
of
anything
so
dreadful
?
"
said
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
Two
hours
ago
,
she
was
quite
well
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
is
very
ill
now
,
"
rejoined
Mrs
Maylies
;
"
and
will
be
worse
,
I
am
sure
.
 
<EOS>
My
dear
,
dear
Rose
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
what
shall
I
do
without
her
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
gave
way
to
such
great
grief
,
that
Oliver
,
suppressing
his
own
emotion
,
ventured
to
remonstrate
with
her
;
and
to
beg
,
earnestly
,
that
,
for
the
sake
of
the
dear
young
lady
herself
,
she
would
be
more
calm
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
consider
,
ma'am
,
"
said
Oliver
,
as
the
tears
forced
themselves
into
his
eyes
,
despite
of
his
efforts
to
the
contrary
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
consider
how
young
and
good
<EOS>
she
is
,
and
what
pleasure
and
comfort
she
gives
to
all
about
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
---
certain
---
<EOS>
quite
certain
---
that
,
for
your
sake
,
who
are
so
good
yourself
;
and
for
her
own
;
and
for
the
sake
of
all
she
makes
so
happy
;
she
will
not
die
.
 
<EOS>
Heaven
will
never
let
her
die
so
young
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
"
said
Mrs
Maylie
,
laying
her
hand
on
Oliver
's
head
.
<EOS>
"
You
think
like
a
child
,
poor
boy
.
 
<EOS>
But
you
teach
me
my
duty
,
notwithstanding
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
forgotten
it
for
a
moment
,
Oliver
,
but
I
hope
I
may
be
pardoned
,
for
I
am
old
,
and
have
seen
enough
of
illness
and
death
to
know
the
agony
of
separation
from
the
objects
of
our
love
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
seen
enough
,
too
,
to
know
that
it
is
not
always
the
youngest
and
best
who
are
spared
to
those
that
love
them
;
but
this
should
give
us
comfort
in
our
sorrow
;
for
Heaven
is
just
;
and
such
things
teach
us
,
impressively
,
that
there
is
a
brighter
world
than
this
;
and
that
the
passage
to
it
is
speedy
.
 
<EOS>
God
's
will
be
done
!
 
<EOS>
I
love
her
;
and
He
know
how
well
!
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver
was
surprised
to
see
that
as
Mrs
Maylie
said
these
words
,
she
checked
her
lamentations
as
though
by
one
effort
;
and
drawing
herself
up
as
she
spoke
,
became
composed
and
firm
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
still
more
astonished
to
find
that
this
firmness
lasted
;
and
that
,
under
all
the
care
and
watching
which
ensued
,
Mrs
Maylie
was
every
ready
and
collected
:
performing
all
the
duties
which
had
devolved
upon
her
,
steadily
,
and
,
to
all
external
appearances
,
even
cheerfully
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
was
young
,
and
did
not
know
what
strong
minds
are
capable
of
,
under
trying
circumstances
.
 
<EOS>
How
should
he
,
when
their
possessors
so
seldom
know
themselves
?
   
<EOS>
An
anxious
night
ensued
.
 
<EOS>
When
morning
came
,
Mrs
Maylie
's
predictions
were
but
too
well
verified
.
 
<EOS>
Rose
was
in
the
first
stage
of
a
high
and
dangerous
fever
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
must
be
active
,
Oliver
,
and
not
give
way
to
useless
grief
,
"
said
Mrs
Maylie
,
laying
her
finger
on
her
lip
,
as
she
looked
steadily
into
his
face
;
"
this
letter
must
be
sent
,
with
all
possible
expedition
,
to
Mr
Losberne
.
 
<EOS>
It
must
be
carried
to
the
market
-
town
:
which
is
not
more
than
four
miles
off
,
by
the
footpath
across
the
field
:
 
and
thence
dispatched
,
by
an
express
on
horseback
,
straight
to
Chertsey
.
<EOS>
The
people
at
the
inn
will
undertake
to
do
this
:
and
I
can
trust
to
you
to
see
it
done
,
I
know
.
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver
could
make
no
reply
,
but
looked
his
anxiety
to
be
gone
at
once
.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
is
another
letter
,
"
said
Mrs
Maylie
,
pausing
to
reflect
;
"
but
whether
to
send
it
now
,
or
wait
until
I
see
how
Rose
goes
on
,
I
scarcely
know
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
not
forward
it
,
unless
I
feared
the
worst
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
for
Chertsey
,
too
,
ma'am
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Oliver
;
impatient
to
execute
his
commission
,
and
holding
out
his
trembling
hand
for
the
letter
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
the
old
lady
,
giving
it
to
him
mechanically
.
<EOS>
Oliver
glanced
at
it
,
and
saw
that
it
was
directed
to
Harry
Maylie
,
Esquire
,
at
some
great
lord
's
house
in
the
country
;
where
,
he
could
not
make
out
.
   
<EOS>
"
Shall
it
go
,
ma'am
?
"
asked
Oliver
,
looking
up
,
impatiently
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
not
,
"
replied
Mrs
Maylie
,
taking
it
back
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
wait
until
to
-
morrow
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
these
words
,
she
gave
Oliver
her
purse
,
and
he
started
off
,
without
more
delay
,
at
the
greatest
speed
he
could
muster
.
   
<EOS>
Swiftly
he
ran
across
the
fields
,
and
down
the
little
lanes
which
sometimes
divided
them
:
<EOS>
now
almost
hidden
by
the
high
corn
on
either
side
,
and
now
emerging
on
an
open
field
,
where
the
mowers
and
haymakers
were
busy
at
their
work
:
 
nor
did
he
stop
once
,
save
now
and
then
,
for
a
few
seconds
,
to
recover
breath
,
until
he
came
,
in
a
great
heat
,
and
covered
with
dust
,
on
the
little
market
-
place
of
the
market
-
town
.
   
<EOS>
Here
he
paused
,
and
looked
about
for
the
inn
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
a
white
bank
,
and
a
red
brewery
,
and
a
yellow
town
-
hall
;
and
in
one
corner
there
was
a
large
house
,
with
all
the
wood
about
it
painted
green
:
 
before
which
was
the
sign
of
"
The
George
.
"
 
<EOS>
To
this
he
hastened
,
as
soon
as
it
caught
his
eye
.
   
<EOS>
He
spoke
to
a
postboy
who
was
dozing
under
the
gateway
;
and
who
,
after
hearing
what
he
wanted
,
referred
him
to
the
ostler
;
who
after
hearing
all
he
had
to
say
again
,
referred
him
to
the
landlord
;
who
was
a
tall
gentleman
in
a
blue
neckcloth
,
a
white
hat
,
drab
breeches
,
and
boots
with
tops
to
match
,
leaning
against
a
pump
by
the
stable
-
door
,
picking
his
teeth
with
a
silver
toothpick
.
   
<EOS>
This
gentleman
walked
with
much
deliberation
into
the
bar
to
make
out
the
bill
:
 
which
took
a
long
time
making
out
:
 
and
after
it
was
ready
,
and
paid
,
a
horse
had
to
be
saddled
,
and
a
man
to
be
dressed
,
which
took
up
ten
good
minutes
more
.
 
<EOS>
Meanwhile
Oliver
was
in
such
a
desperate
state
of
impatience
and
anxiety
,
that
he
felt
as
if
he
could
have
jumped
upon
the
horse
himself
,
and
galloped
away
,
full
tear
,
to
the
next
stage
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
all
was
ready
;
and
the
little
parcel
having
been
handed
up
,
with
many
injunctions
and
entreaties
for
its
speedy
delivery
,
the
man
set
spurs
to
his
horse
,
and
rattling
over
the
uneven
paving
of
the
market
-
place
,
was
out
of
the
town
,
and
galloping
along
the
turnpike
-
road
,
in
a
couple
of
minutes
.
   
<EOS>
As
it
was
something
to
feel
certain
that
assistance
was
sent
for
,
and
that
no
time
had
been
lost
,
Oliver
hurried
up
the
inn
-
yard
,
with
a
somewhat
lighter
heart
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
turning
out
of
the
gateway
when
he
accidentally
stumbled
against
a
tall
man
wrapped
in
a
cloak
,
who
was
at
that
moment
coming
out
of
the
inn
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hah
!
"
cried
the
man
,
fixing
his
eyes
on
Oliver
,
and
suddenly
recoiling
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
the
devil
's
this
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
sir
,
"
said
Oliver
;
"
I
was
in
a
great
hurry
to
get
home
,
and
did
n't
see
you
were
coming
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Death
!
<EOS>
"
muttered
the
man
to
himself
,
glaring
at
the
boy
with
his
large
dark
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
would
have
thought
it
!
<EOS>
Grind
him
to
ashes
!
   
<EOS>
He
'd
start
up
from
a
stone
coffin
,
to
come
in
my
way
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
,
"
stammered
Oliver
,
confused
by
the
strange
man
's
wild
look
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
hope
I
have
not
hurt
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Rot
you
!
"
<EOS>
murmured
the
man
,
in
a
horrible
passion
;
between
his
clenched
teeth
;
"
if
I
had
only
had
the
courage
to
say
the
word
,
I
might
have
been
free
of
you
in
a
night
.
 
<EOS>
Curses
on
your
head
,
and
black
death
on
your
heart
,
you
imp
!
 
<EOS>
What
are
you
doing
here
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
man
shook
his
fist
,
as
he
uttered
these
words
incoherently
.
<EOS>
He
advanced
towards
Oliver
,
as
if
with
the
intention
of
aiming
a
blow
at
him
,
but
fell
violently
on
the
ground
:
 
writhing
and
foaming
,
in
a
fit
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
gazed
,
for
a
moment
,
at
the
struggles
of
the
madman
<EOS>
(
for
such
he
supposed
him
to
be
)
;
and
then
darted
into
the
house
for
help
.
 
<EOS>
Having
seen
him
safely
carried
into
the
hotel
,
he
turned
his
face
homewards
,
running
as
fast
as
he
could
,
to
make
up
for
lost
time
:
 
and
recalling
with
a
great
deal
of
astonishment
and
some
fear
,
the
extraordinary
behaviour
of
the
person
from
whom
he
had
just
parted
.
   
<EOS>
The
circumstance
did
not
dwell
in
his
recollection
long
,
however
:
   
for
when
he
reached
the
cottage
,
there
was
enough
to
occupy
his
mind
,
and
to
drive
all
considerations
of
self
completely
from
his
memory
.
   
<EOS>
Rose
Maylie
had
rapidly
grown
worse
;
before
mid
-
night
she
was
delirious
.
 
<EOS>
A
medical
practitioner
,
who
resided
on
the
spot
,
was
in
constant
attendance
upon
her
;
and
after
first
seeing
the
patient
,
he
had
taken
Mrs
Maylie
aside
,
and
pronounced
her
disorder
to
be
one
of
a
most
alarming
nature
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In
fact
,
"
he
said
,
"
it
would
be
little
short
of
a
miracle
,
if
she
recovered
.
"
   
<EOS>
How
often
did
Oliver
start
from
his
bed
that
night
,
and
stealing
out
,
with
noiseless
footstep
,
to
the
staircase
,
listen
for
the
slightest
sound
from
the
sick
chamber
!
 
<EOS>
How
often
did
a
tremble
shake
his
frame
,
and
cold
drops
of
terror
start
upon
his
brow
,
when
a
sudden
trampling
of
feet
caused
him
to
fear
that
something
too
dreadful
to
think
of
,
had
even
then
occurred
!
 
<EOS>
And
what
had
been
the
fervency
of
all
the
prayers
he
had
ever
muttered
,
compared
with
those
he
poured
forth
,
now
,
in
the
agony
and
passion
of
his
supplication
for
the
life
and
health
of
the
gentle
creature
,
who
was
tottering
on
the
deep
grave
's
verge
!
   
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
the
suspense
,
the
fearful
,
acute
suspense
,
of
standing
idly
by
while
the
life
of
one
we
dearly
love
,
is
trembling
in
the
balance
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
the
racking
thoughts
that
crowd
upon
the
mind
,
and
<EOS>
make
the
heart
beat
violently
,
and
the
breath
come
thick
,
by
the
force
of
the
images
they
conjure
up
before
it
;
the
DESPERATE
ANXIETY
TO
BE
DOING
SOMETHING
to
relieve
the
pain
,
or
lessen
the
danger
,
which
we
have
no
power
to
alleviate
;
the
sinking
of
soul
and
spirit
,
which
the
sad
remembrance
of
our
helplessness
produces
;
what
tortures
can
equal
these
;
what
reflections
or
endeavours
can
,
in
the
full
tide
and
fever
of
the
time
,
allay
them
!
   
<EOS>
Morning
came
;
and
the
little
cottage
was
lonely
and
still
.
<EOS>
People
spoke
in
whispers
;
anxious
faces
appeared
at
the
gate
,
from
time
to
time
;
women
and
children
went
away
in
tears
.
<EOS>
All
the
livelong
day
,
and
for
hours
after
it
had
grown
dark
,
Oliver
paced
softly
up
and
down
the
garden
,
raising
his
eyes
every
instant
to
the
sick
chamber
,
and
shuddering
to
see
the
darkened
window
,
looking
as
if
death
lay
stretched
inside
.
 
<EOS>
Late
that
night
,
Mr
Losberne
arrived
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
hard
,
"
said
the
good
doctor
,
turning
away
as
he
spoke
;
"
so
young
;
so
much
beloved
;
but
there
is
very
little
hope
.
"
   
<EOS>
Another
morning
.
 
<EOS>
The
sun
shone
brightly
;
as
brightly
as
if
it
looked
upon
no
misery
or
care
;
and
,
with
every
leaf
and
flower
in
full
bloom
about
her
;
with
life
,
and
health
,
and
sounds
and
sights
of
joy
,
surrounding
her
on
every
side
:
the
fair
young
creature
lay
,
wasting
fast
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
crept
away
to
the
old
churchyard
,
and
sitting
down
on
one
of
the
green
mounds
,
wept
and
prayed
for
her
,
in
silence
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
such
peace
and
beauty
in
the
scene
;
so
much
of
brightness
and
mirth
in
the
sunny
landscape
;
such
blithesome
music
in
the
songs
of
the
summer
birds
;
such
freedom
in
the
rapid
flight
of
the
rook
,
careering
overhead
;
so
much
of
life
and
joyousness
in
all
;
that
,
when
the
boy
raised
his
aching
eyes
,
and
looked
about
,
the
thought
instinctively
occurred
to
him
,
that
this
was
not
a
time
for
death
;
that
Rose
could
surely
never
die
when
humbler
<EOS>
things
were
all
so
glad
and
gay
;
that
graves
were
for
cold
and
cheerless
winter
:
 
not
for
sunlight
and
fragrance
.
<EOS>
He
almost
thought
that
shrouds
were
for
the
old
and
shrunken
;
and
that
they
never
wrapped
the
young
and
graceful
form
in
their
ghastly
folds
.
   
<EOS>
A
knell
from
the
church
bell
broke
harshly
on
these
youthful
thoughts
.
 
<EOS>
Another
!
 
<EOS>
Again
!
 
<EOS>
It
was
tolling
for
the
funeral
service
.
 
<EOS>
A
group
of
humble
mourners
entered
the
gate
:
wearing
white
favours
;
for
the
corpse
was
young
.
 
<EOS>
They
stood
uncovered
by
a
grave
;
and
there
was
a
mother
---
a
mother
once
---
among
the
weeping
train
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
sun
shone
brightly
,
and
the
birds
sang
on
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
turned
homeward
,
thinking
on
the
many
kindnesses
he
had
received
from
the
young
lady
,
and
wishing
that
the
time
could
come
again
,
that
he
might
never
cease
showing
her
how
grateful
and
attached
he
was
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
no
cause
for
self
-
reproach
on
the
score
of
neglect
,
or
want
of
thought
,
for
he
had
been
devoted
to
her
service
;
and
<EOS>
yet
a
hundred
little
occasions
rose
up
before
him
,
on
which
he
fancied
he
might
have
been
more
zealous
,
and
more
earnest
,
and
wished
he
had
been
.
 
<EOS>
We
need
be
careful
how
we
deal
with
those
about
us
,
when
every
death
carries
to
some
small
circle
of
survivors
,
thoughts
of
so
much
omitted
,
and
so
little
done
---
of
so
many
things
forgotten
,
and
so
many
more
which
might
have
been
repaired
!
 
<EOS>
There
is
no
remorse
so
deep
as
that
<EOS>
which
is
unavailing
;
if
we
would
be
spared
its
tortures
,
let
us
remember
this
,
in
time
.
   
<EOS>
When
he
reached
home
<EOS>
Mrs
Maylie
was
sitting
in
the
little
parlour
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
's
heart
sand
at
sight
of
her
;
for
she
had
never
left
the
bedside
of
her
niece
;
and
he
trembled
to
think
what
change
could
have
driven
her
away
.
 
<EOS>
He
learnt
that
she
had
fallen
into
a
deep
sleep
,
from
which
she
would
waken
,
either
to
recovery
and
life
,
or
to
bid
them
farewell
,
and
die
.
   
<EOS>
They
sat
,
listening
,
and
afraid
to
speak
,
for
hours
.
 
<EOS>
The
untasted
meal
was
removed
,
with
looks
which
showed
that
their
thoughts
were
elsewhere
,
they
watched
the
sun
as
he
sank
lower
and
lower
,
and
,
at
length
,
cast
over
sky
and
earth
those
brilliant
hues
which
herald
his
departure
.
 
<EOS>
Their
quick
ears
caught
the
sound
of
an
approaching
footstep
.
 
<EOS>
They
both
involuntarily
darted
to
the
door
,
as
Mr
Losberne
entered
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
of
Rose
?
"
cried
the
old
lady
.
 
<EOS>
"
Tell
me
at
once
!
 
<EOS>
I
can
bear
it
;
anything
but
suspense
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
,
tell
me
!
<EOS>
in
the
name
of
Heaven
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
must
compose
yourself
,
"
said
the
doctor
supporting
her
.
"
<EOS>
Be
calm
,
my
dear
ma'am
,
pray
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Let
me
go
,
in
God
's
name
!
 
<EOS>
My
dear
child
!
 
<EOS>
She
is
dead
!
<EOS>
She
is
dying
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
cried
the
doctor
,
passionately
.
 
<EOS>
"
As
He
is
good
and
merciful
,
she
will
live
to
bless
us
all
,
for
years
to
come
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
lady
fell
upon
her
knees
,
and
tried
to
fold
her
hands
together
;
but
the
energy
which
had
supported
her
so
long
,
fled
up
to
Heaven
with
her
first
thanksgiving
;
and
she
sank
into
the
friendly
arms
which
were
extended
to
receive
her
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
34
.
<EOS>
Contains
some
introductory
particulars
relative
to
a
young
gentleman
who
now
arrives
upon
the
scene
;
and
a
new
adventure
which
happened
to
Oliver
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
almost
too
much
happiness
to
bear
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
felt
stunned
and
stupefied
by
the
unexpected
intelligence
;
he
could
not
weep
,
or
speak
,
or
rest
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
scarcely
the
power
of
understanding
anything
that
had
passed
,
until
,
after
a
long
ramble
in
the
quiet
evening
air
,
a
burst
of
tears
came
to
his
relief
,
and
he
seemed
to
awaken
,
all
at
once
,
to
a
full
sense
of
the
joyful
change
that
had
occurred
,
and
the
almost
insupportable
load
of
anguish
which
had
been
taken
from
his
breast
.
   
<EOS>
The
night
was
fast
closing
in
,
when
he
returned
homeward
:
 
<EOS>
laden
with
flowers
which
he
had
culled
,
with
peculiar
care
,
for
the
adornment
of
the
sick
chamber
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
walked
briskly
along
the
road
,
he
heard
behind
him
,
the
noise
of
some
vehicle
,
approaching
at
a
furious
pace
.
 
<EOS>
Looking
round
,
he
saw
that
it
was
a
post
-
chaise
,
driven
at
great
speed
;
and
as
the
horses
were
galloping
,
and
the
road
was
narrow
,
he
stood
leaning
against
a
gate
until
it
should
have
passed
him
.
   
<EOS>
As
it
dashed
on
,
Oliver
caught
a
glimpse
of
a
man
in
a
white
nitecap
,
whose
face
seemed
familiar
to
him
,
although
his
view
was
so
brief
that
he
could
not
identify
the
person
.
 
<EOS>
In
another
second
or
two
,
the
nightcap
was
thrust
out
of
the
chaise
-
window
,
and
a
stentorian
voice
bellowed
to
the
driver
to
stop
:
 
<EOS>
which
he
did
,
as
soon
as
he
could
pull
up
his
horses
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
the
nightcap
once
again
appeared
:
and
the
same
voice
called
Oliver
by
his
name
.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
!
"
cried
the
voice
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oliver
,
what
's
the
news
?
 
<EOS>
Miss
Rose
!
<EOS>
Master
O
-
li
-
ver
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
is
you
,
Giles
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Oliver
,
running
up
to
the
chaise
-
door
.
   
<EOS>
Giles
popped
out
his
nightcap
again
,
preparatory
to
making
some
reply
,
when
he
was
suddenly
pulled
back
by
a
young
gentleman
who
occupied
the
other
corner
of
the
chaise
,
and
who
eagerly
demanded
what
was
the
news
.
   
<EOS>
"
In
a
word
!
"
cried
the
gentleman
,
"
Better
or
worse
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Better
---
much
better
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Oliver
,
hastily
.
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
Heaven
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
sure
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Quite
,
sir
,
"
replied
Oliver
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
change
took
place
only
a
few
hours
ago
;
and
Mr
Losberne
says
,
that
all
danger
is
at
an
end
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
gentleman
said
not
another
word
,
but
,
opening
the
chaise
-
door
,
leaped
out
,
and
taking
Oliver
hurriedly
by
the
arm
,
led
him
aside
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
quite
certain
?
 
<EOS>
There
is
no
possibility
of
any
mistake
on
your
part
,
my
boy
,
is
there
?
"
demanded
the
gentleman
in
a
tremulous
voice
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
deceive
me
,
by
awakening
hopes
that
are
not
to
be
fulfilled
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
would
not
for
the
world
,
sir
,
"
replied
Oliver
.
 
<EOS>
"
Indeed
you
may
believe
me
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Losberne
's
words
were
,
that
she
would
live
to
bless
us
all
for
many
years
to
come
.
 
<EOS>
I
heard
him
say
so
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
The
tears
stood
in
Oliver
's
eyes
as
he
recalled
the
scene
which
was
the
beginning
of
so
much
happiness
;
and
the
gentleman
turned
his
face
away
,
and
remained
silent
,
for
some
minutes
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
thought
he
heard
him
sob
,
more
than
once
;
but
he
feared
to
interrupt
him
by
any
fresh
remark
---
for
he
could
well
guess
what
his
feelings
were
---
and
so
stood
apart
,
feigning
to
be
occupied
with
his
nosegay
.
   
<EOS>
All
this
time
,
Mr
Giles
,
with
the
white
nightcap
on
,
had
been
sitting
on
the
steps
of
the
chaise
,
supporting
an
elbow
on
each
knee
,
and
wiping
his
eyes
with
a
blue
cotton
pocket
-
handkerchief
<EOS>
dotted
with
white
spots
.
 
<EOS>
That
the
honest
fellow
had
not
been
feigning
emotion
,
was
abundently
demonstrated
by
the
very
red
eyes
with
which
he
regarded
the
young
gentleman
,
when
he
turned
round
and
addressed
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
you
had
better
go
on
to
my
mother
's
in
the
chaise
,
Giles
,
"
said
he
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
would
rather
walk
slowly
on
,
so
as
to
gain
a
little
time
before
I
see
her
.
 
<EOS>
You
can
say
I
am
coming
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
Mr
Harry
,
"
said
Giles
:
 
giving
a
final
polish
to
his
ruffled
countenance
with
the
handkerchief
;
"
but
if
you
would
leave
the
postboy
to
say
that
,
I
should
be
very
much
obliged
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
n't
be
proper
for
the
maids
to
see
me
in
this
state
,
sir
;
I
should
never
have
any
more
authority
with
them
if
they
did
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
rejoined
Harry
Maylie
,
smiling
,
"
you
can
do
as
you
like
.
<EOS>
Let
him
go
on
with
the
luggage
,
if
you
wish
it
,
and
do
you
follow
with
us
.
 
<EOS>
Only
first
exchange
that
nightcap
for
some
more
appropriate
covering
,
or
we
shall
be
taken
for
madmen
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Giles
,
reminded
of
his
unbecoming
costume
,
snatched
off
and
pocketed
his
nightcap
;
and
substituted
a
hat
,
of
grave
and
sober
shape
,
which
he
took
out
of
the
chaise
.
 
<EOS>
This
done
,
the
postboy
drove
off
;
Giles
,
Mr
Maylie
,
and
Oliver
,
followed
at
their
leisure
.
   
<EOS>
As
they
walked
along
,
Oliver
glanced
from
time
to
time
with
much
interest
and
curiosity
at
the
new
comer
.
 
<EOS>
He
seemed
about
five
-
and
-
twenty
years
of
age
,
and
was
of
the
middle
height
;
his
countenance
was
frank
and
handsome
;
and
his
demeanor
easy
and
prepossessing
.
 
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
the
difference
between
youth
and
age
,
he
bore
so
strong
a
likeness
to
the
old
lady
,
that
Oliver
would
have
had
no
great
difficulty
in
imagining
their
relationship
,
if
he
had
not
already
spoken
of
her
as
his
mother
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Maylie
was
anxiously
waiting
to
receive
her
son
when
he
reached
the
cottage
.
 
<EOS>
The
meeting
did
not
take
place
without
great
emotion
on
both
sides
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mother
!
"
whispered
the
young
man
;
"
why
did
you
not
write
before
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
did
,
"
replied
Mrs
Maylie
;
"
but
,
on
reflection
,
I
determined
to
keep
back
the
letter
until
I
had
heard
Mr
Losberne
's
opinion
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
why
,
"
said
the
young
man
,
"
why
run
the
chance
of
that
occurring
which
so
nearly
happened
?
 
<EOS>
If
Rose
had
---
I
can
not
utter
that
word
now
---
if
this
illness
had
terminated
differently
,
how
could
you
ever
have
forgiven
yourself
!
 
<EOS>
How
could
I
ever
have
know
happiness
again
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
that
HAD
been
the
case
,
Harry
,
"
said
Mrs
Maylie
,
"
<EOS>
I
fear
your
happiness
would
have
been
effectually
blighted
,
and
that
your
arrival
here
,
a
day
sooner
or
a
day
later
,
would
have
been
of
very
,
very
little
import
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
who
can
wonder
if
it
be
so
,
mother
?
<EOS>
"
rejoined
the
young
man
;
"
or
why
should
I
say
,
IF
?
---
<EOS>
It
is
---
<EOS>
it
is
---
you
know
it
,
<EOS>
mother
---
you
must
know
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
that
she
deserves
the
best
and
purest
love
the
heart
of
man
can
offer
,
"
said
Mrs
Maylie
;
<EOS>
"
I
know
that
the
devotion
and
affection
of
her
nature
require
no
ordinary
return
,
but
one
that
shall
be
deep
and
lasting
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
did
not
feel
this
,
and
know
,
besides
,
that
a
changed
behaviour
in
one
she
loved
would
break
her
heart
,
I
should
not
feel
my
task
so
difficult
of
performance
,
or
have
to
encounter
so
many
struggles
in
my
own
bosom
,
when
I
take
what
seems
to
me
to
be
the
strict
line
of
duty
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
unkind
,
mother
,
"
said
Harry
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
still
suppose
that
I
am
a
boy
ignorant
of
my
own
mind
,
and
mistaking
the
impulses
of
my
own
soul
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
my
dear
son
,
"
returned
Mrs
Maylie
,
laying
her
hand
upon
his
shoulder
,
"
<EOS>
that
youth
has
many
generous
impulses
which
do
not
last
;
and
that
among
them
are
some
,
which
,
being
gratified
,
become
only
the
more
fleeting
.
 
<EOS>
Above
all
,
I
think
"
said
the
lady
,
fixing
her
eyes
on
her
son
's
face
,
"
that
if
an
enthusiastic
,
ardent
,
and
ambitious
man
marry
a
wife
on
whose
name
there
is
a
stain
,
which
,
though
it
originate
in
no
fault
of
hers
,
may
be
visited
by
cold
and
sordid
people
upon
her
,
and
upon
his
children
also
:
and
,
in
exact
proportion
to
his
success
in
the
world
,
be
cast
in
his
teeth
,
and
made
the
subject
of
sneers
against
him
:
 
he
may
,
no
matter
how
generous
and
good
his
nature
,
one
day
repent
of
the
connection
he
formed
in
early
life
.
 
<EOS>
And
she
may
have
the
pain
of
knowing
that
he
does
so
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mother
,
"
said
the
young
man
,
impatiently
,
"
he
would
be
a
selfish
brute
,
unworthy
alike
of
the
name
of
man
and
of
the
woman
you
describe
,
who
acted
thus
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
think
so
now
,
Harry
,
"
replied
his
mother
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
ever
will
!
"
said
the
young
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
mental
agony
I
have
suffered
,
during
the
last
two
days
,
wrings
from
me
the
avowal
to
you
of
a
passion
which
,
as
you
well
know
,
is
not
one
of
yesterday
,
nor
one
I
have
lightly
formed
.
 
<EOS>
On
Rose
,
sweet
,
gentle
girl
!
<EOS>
my
heart
is
set
,
as
firmly
as
ever
heart
of
man
was
set
on
woman
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
thought
,
<EOS>
no
view
,
no
hope
in
life
,
beyond
her
;
and
if
you
oppose
me
in
this
great
stake
,
you
take
my
peace
and
happiness
in
your
hands
,
and
cast
them
to
the
wind
.
 
<EOS>
Mother
,
think
better
of
this
,
and
of
me
,
and
do
not
disregard
the
happiness
of
which
you
seem
to
think
so
little
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Harry
,
"
said
Mrs
Maylie
,
"
it
is
because
I
think
so
much
of
warm
and
sensitive
hearts
,
that
I
would
spare
them
from
being
wounded
.
   
<EOS>
But
we
have
said
enough
,
and
more
than
enough
,
on
this
matter
,
just
now
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Let
it
rest
with
Rose
,
then
,
"
interposed
Harry
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
will
not
press
these
overstrained
opinions
of
yours
,
so
far
,
as
to
throw
any
obstacle
in
my
way
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
,
"
rejoined
Mrs
Maylie
;
"
but
I
would
have
you
consider
---
"
   
"
I
HAVE
considered
!
<EOS>
"
was
the
impatient
reply
;
"
Mother
,
I
have
considered
,
years
and
years
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
considered
,
ever
since
I
have
been
capable
of
serious
reflection
.
 
<EOS>
My
feelings
remain
unchanged
,
as
they
ever
will
;
and
why
should
I
suffer
the
pain
of
a
delay
in
giving
them
vent
,
which
can
be
productive
of
no
earthly
good
?
 
<EOS>
No
!
 
<EOS>
Before
I
leave
this
place
,
Rose
shall
hear
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
shall
,
"
said
Mrs
Maylie
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
something
in
your
manner
,
which
would
almost
imply
that
she
will
hear
me
coldly
,
mother
,
"
said
the
young
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
coldly
,
"
rejoined
the
old
lady
;
"
far
from
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
then
?
"
urged
the
young
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
has
formed
no
other
attachment
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
indeed
,
"
replied
his
mother
;
"
you
have
,
or
I
mistake
,
too
strong
a
hold
on
her
affections
already
.
 
<EOS>
What
I
would
say
,
"
resumed
the
old
lady
,
stopping
her
son
as
he
was
about
to
speak
,
"
is
this
.
 
<EOS>
Before
you
stake
your
all
on
this
chance
;
before
you
suffer
yourself
to
be
carried
to
the
highest
point
of
hope
;
reflect
for
a
few
moments
,
my
dear
child
,
on
Rose
's
history
,
and
consider
what
effect
the
knowledge
of
her
doubtful
birth
may
have
on
her
decision
:
 
devoted
as
she
is
to
us
,
with
all
the
intensity
of
her
noble
mind
,
and
with
that
perfect
sacrifice
of
self
which
,
in
all
matters
,
great
or
trifling
,
has
always
been
her
characteristic
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
I
leave
you
to
discover
,
"
replied
Mrs
Maylie
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
must
go
back
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
God
bless
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
see
you
again
to
-
night
?
"
said
the
young
man
,
eagerly
.
   
<EOS>
"
By
and
by
,
"
replied
the
lady
;
"
when
I
leave
Rose
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
will
tell
her
I
am
here
?
"
said
Harry
.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
,
"
replied
Mrs
Maylie
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
say
how
anxious
I
have
been
,
and
how
much
I
have
suffered
,
and
how
I
long
to
see
her
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
not
refuse
to
do
this
,
mother
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
the
old
lady
;
"
I
will
tell
her
all
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
pressing
her
son
's
hand
,
affectionately
,
she
hastened
from
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Losberne
and
Oliver
had
remained
at
another
end
of
the
apartment
while
this
hurried
conversation
was
proceeding
.
 
<EOS>
The
former
now
held
out
his
hand
to
Harry
Maylie
;
and
hearty
salutations
were
exchanged
between
them
.
 
<EOS>
The
doctor
then
communicated
,
in
reply
to
multifarious
questions
from
his
young
friend
,
a
precise
account
of
his
patient
's
situation
;
which
was
quite
as
consolatory
and
full
of
promise
,
as
Oliver
's
statement
had
encouraged
him
to
hope
;
and
to
the
whole
of
which
,
Mr
Giles
,
who
affected
to
be
busy
about
the
luggage
,
listened
with
greedy
ears
.
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
shot
anything
particular
,
lately
,
Giles
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
the
doctor
,
when
he
had
concluded
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
particular
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Giles
,
colouring
up
to
the
eyes
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nor
catching
any
thieves
,
nor
identifying
any
house
-
breakers
?
"
said
the
doctor
.
   
<EOS>
"
None
at
all
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Giles
,
with
much
gravity
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
"
said
the
doctor
,
"
I
am
sorry
to
hear
it
,
because
you
do
that
sort
of
thing
admirably
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
,
how
is
Brittles
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
boy
is
very
well
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Giles
,
recovering
his
usual
tone
of
patronage
;
"
and
sends
his
respectful
duty
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
well
,
"
said
the
doctor
.
 
<EOS>
"
Seeing
you
here
,
reminds
me
,
Mr
Giles
,
that
on
the
day
before
that
on
which
I
was
called
away
so
hurriedly
,
I
executed
,
at
the
request
of
your
good
mistress
,
a
small
commission
in
your
favour
.
 
<EOS>
Just
step
into
this
corner
a
moment
,
will
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Giles
walked
into
the
corner
with
much
importance
,
and
some
wonder
,
and
was
honoured
with
a
short
whispering
conference
with
the
doctor
,
on
the
termination
of
which
,
he
made
a
great
many
bows
,
and
retired
with
steps
of
unusual
stateliness
.
 
<EOS>
The
subject
matter
of
this
conference
was
not
disclosed
in
the
parlour
,
but
the
kitchen
was
speedily
enlightened
concerning
it
;
for
Mr
Giles
walked
straight
thither
,
and
having
called
for
a
mug
of
ale
,
announced
,
with
an
air
of
majesty
,
which
was
highly
effective
,
that
it
had
pleased
his
mistress
,
in
consideration
of
his
gallant
behaviour
on
the
occasion
of
that
attempted
robbery
,
to
depost
,
in
the
local
savings
-
bank
,
the
sum
of
five
-
and
-
twenty
pounds
,
for
his
sole
use
and
benefit
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
,
the
two
women
-
servants
lifted
up
their
hands
and
eyes
,
and
supposed
that
Mr
Giles
,
pulling
out
his
shirt
-
frill
,
replied
,
"
No
,
no
"
;
and
that
if
they
observed
that
he
was
at
all
haughty
to
his
inferiors
,
he
would
thank
them
to
tell
him
so
.
 
<EOS>
And
then
he
made
a
great
many
other
remarks
,
no
less
illustrative
of
his
humility
,
which
were
received
with
equal
favour
and
applause
,
and
were
,
withal
,
as
original
and
as
much
to
the
purpose
,
as
the
remarks
of
great
men
commonly
are
.
   
<EOS>
Above
stairs
,
the
remainder
of
the
evening
passed
cheerfully
away
;
for
the
doctor
was
in
high
spirits
;
and
however
fatigued
or
thoughtful
<EOS>
Harry
Maylie
might
have
been
at
first
,
he
was
not
proof
against
the
worthy
gentleman
's
good
humour
,
which
displayed
itself
in
a
great
variety
of
sallies
and
professional
recollections
,
and
an
abundance
of
small
jokes
,
which
struck
Oliver
as
being
the
drollest
things
he
had
ever
heard
,
and
caused
him
to
laugh
proportionately
;
to
the
evident
satisfaction
of
the
doctor
,
who
laughed
immoderately
at
himself
,
and
made
Harry
laugh
almost
as
heartily
,
by
the
very
force
of
sympathy
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
they
were
as
pleasant
a
party
as
,
under
the
circumstances
,
they
could
well
have
been
;
and
it
was
late
before
they
retired
,
with
light
and
thankful
hearts
,
to
take
that
rest
of
which
,
after
the
doubt
and
suspense
they
had
recently
undergone
,
they
stood
much
in
need
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
rose
next
morning
,
in
better
heart
,
and
went
about
his
usual
occupations
,
with
more
hope
and
pleasure
than
he
had
known
for
many
days
.
 
<EOS>
The
birds
were
once
more
hung
out
,
to
sing
,
in
their
old
places
;
and
the
sweetest
wild
flowers
that
could
be
found
,
were
once
more
gathered
to
gladden
Rose
with
their
beauty
.
<EOS>
The
melancholy
which
had
seemed
to
the
sad
eyes
of
the
anxious
boy
to
hang
,
for
days
past
,
over
every
object
,
beautiful
as
all
were
,
was
dispelled
by
magic
.
 
<EOS>
The
dew
seemed
to
sparkle
more
brightly
on
the
green
leaves
;
the
air
to
rustle
among
them
with
a
sweeter
music
;
and
the
sky
itself
to
look
more
blue
and
bright
.
<EOS>
Such
is
the
influence
which
the
condition
of
our
own
thoughts
,
exercise
,
even
over
the
appearance
of
external
objects
.
 
<EOS>
Men
who
look
on
nature
,
and
their
fellow
-
men
,
and
cry
that
all
is
dark
and
gloomy
,
are
in
the
right
;
but
the
sombre
colours
are
reflections
from
their
own
jaundiced
eyes
and
hearts
.
 
<EOS>
The
real
hues
are
delicate
,
and
need
a
clearer
vision
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
worthy
of
remark
,
and
Oliver
did
not
fail
to
note
it
at
the
time
,
that
his
morning
expeditions
were
no
longer
made
alone
.
<EOS>
Harry
Maylie
,
after
the
very
first
morning
when
he
met
Oliver
coming
laden
home
,
was
seized
with
such
a
passion
for
flowers
,
and
displayed
such
a
taste
in
their
arrangement
,
as
left
his
young
companion
far
behind
.
 
<EOS>
If
Oliver
were
behindhand
in
these
respects
,
he
knew
where
the
best
were
to
be
found
;
and
morning
after
morning
they
scoured
the
country
together
,
and
brought
home
the
fairest
that
blossomed
.
 
<EOS>
The
window
of
the
young
lady
's
chamber
was
opened
now
;
for
she
loved
to
feel
the
rich
summer
air
stream
in
,
and
revive
her
with
its
freshness
;
but
there
always
stood
in
water
,
just
inside
the
lattice
,
one
particular
little
bunch
,
which
was
made
up
with
great
care
,
every
morning
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
could
not
help
noticing
that
the
withered
flowers
were
never
thrown
away
,
although
the
little
vase
was
regularly
replenished
;
nor
,
could
he
help
observing
,
that
whenever
the
doctor
came
into
the
garden
,
he
invariably
cast
his
eyes
up
to
that
particular
corner
,
and
nodded
his
head
most
expressively
,
as
he
set
forth
on
his
morning
's
walk
.
 
<EOS>
Pending
these
observations
,
the
days
were
flying
by
;
and
Rose
was
rapidly
recovering
.
   
<EOS>
Nor
did
Oliver
's
time
hang
heavy
on
his
hands
,
although
the
young
lady
had
not
yet
left
her
chamber
,
and
there
were
no
evening
walks
,
save
now
and
then
,
for
a
short
distance
,
with
Mrs
Maylie
.
   
<EOS>
He
applied
himself
,
with
redoubled
assiduity
,
to
the
instructions
of
the
white
-
headed
old
gentleman
,
and
laboured
so
hard
that
his
quick
progress
surprised
even
himself
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
while
he
was
engaged
in
this
pursuit
,
that
he
was
greatly
startled
and
distressed
by
a
most
unexpected
occurence
.
   
<EOS>
The
little
room
in
which
he
was
accustomed
to
sit
,
when
busy
at
his
books
,
was
on
the
ground
-
floor
,
at
the
back
of
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
quite
a
cottage
-
room
,
with
a
lattice
-
window
:
around
which
were
clusters
of
jessamine
and
honeysuckle
,
that
crept
over
the
casement
,
and
filled
the
place
with
their
delicious
perfume
.
 
<EOS>
It
looked
into
a
garden
,
whence
a
wicket
-
gate
opened
into
a
small
paddock
;
all
beyond
,
was
fine
meadow
-
land
and
wood
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
other
dwelling
near
,
in
that
direction
;
and
the
prospect
it
commanded
was
very
extensive
.
   
<EOS>
One
beautiful
evening
,
when
the
first
shades
of
twilight
were
beginning
to
settle
upon
the
earth
,
Oliver
sat
at
this
window
,
intent
upon
his
books
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
been
poring
over
them
for
some
time
;
and
,
as
the
day
had
been
uncommonly
sultry
,
and
he
had
exerted
himself
a
great
deal
,
<EOS>
it
it
<EOS>
no
disparagement
to
the
authors
<EOS>
,
whoever
they
may
have
been
,
to
say
,
that
gradually
and
by
slow
degrees
,
he
fell
asleep
.
   
<EOS>
There
is
a
kind
of
sleep
that
steals
upon
us
sometimes
,
which
,
while
it
holds
the
body
prisoner
,
does
not
free
the
mind
from
a
sense
of
things
about
it
,
and
enable
it
to
ramble
at
its
pleasure
.
 
<EOS>
So
far
as
an
overpowering
heaviness
,
a
prostration
of
strength
,
and
an
utter
inability
to
control
our
thoughts
or
power
of
motion
,
can
be
called
sleep
,
this
is
it
;
and
yet
,
we
have
a
consciousness
of
all
that
is
going
on
about
us
,
and
,
if
we
dream
at
such
a
time
,
<EOS>
words
which
are
really
spoken
,
or
sounds
which
really
exist
at
the
moment
,
accommodate
themselves
with
surprising
readiness
to
our
visions
,
until
reality
and
imagination
become
so
strangely
blended
that
it
is
afterwards
almost
matter
of
impossibility
to
separate
the
two
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
is
this
,
the
most
striking
phenomenon
indcidental
to
such
a
state
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
an
undoubted
fact
,
that
although
our
senses
of
touch
and
sight
be
for
the
time
dead
,
yet
our
sleeping
thoughts
,
and
the
visionary
scenes
that
pass
before
us
,
will
be
influenced
and
materially
influenced
,
by
the
MERE
SILENT
PRESENCE
of
some
external
object
;
which
may
not
have
been
near
us
when
we
closed
our
eyes
:
 
and
of
whose
vicinity
we
have
had
no
waking
consciousness
.
   
<EOS>
Oliver
knew
,
perfectly
well
,
that
he
was
in
his
own
little
room
;
that
his
books
were
lying
on
the
table
before
him
;
that
the
sweet
air
was
stirring
among
the
creeping
plants
outside
.
 
<EOS>
And
yet
he
was
asleep
.
 
<EOS>
Suddenly
,
the
scene
changed
;
the
air
became
close
and
confined
;
and
he
thought
,
with
a
glow
of
terror
,
that
he
was
in
the
Jew
's
house
again
.
<EOS>
There
sat
the
hideous
old
man
,
in
his
accustomed
corner
,
pointing
at
him
,
and
whispering
to
another
man
,
with
his
face
averted
,
who
sat
beside
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
,
my
dear
!
"
<EOS>
he
thought
he
heard
the
Jew
say
;
"
it
is
he
,
sure
enough
.
 
<EOS>
Come
away
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
!
"
<EOS>
the
other
man
seemed
to
answer
;
"
could
I
mistake
him
,
think
you
?
 
<EOS>
If
a
crowd
of
ghosts
were
to
put
themselves
into
his
exact
shape
,
and
he
stood
amongst
them
,
there
is
something
that
would
tell
me
how
to
point
him
out
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
buried
him
fifty
feet
deep
,
and
took
me
across
his
grave
,
I
fancy
<EOS>
I
should
know
,
if
there
was
n't
a
mark
above
it
,
that
he
lay
buried
there
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
man
seemed
to
say
this
,
with
such
dreadful
hatred
,
that
Oliver
awoke
with
the
fear
,
and
started
up
.
   
<EOS>
Good
Heaven
!
 
<EOS>
what
was
that
,
which
sent
the
blood
tingling
to
his
heart
,
and
deprived
him
of
his
voice
,
and
of
power
to
move
!
<EOS>
There
---
there
---
at
the
window
---
close
before
him
---
so
close
,
that
he
could
have
almost
touched
him
before
he
started
back
:
 
with
his
eyes
peering
into
the
room
,
and
meeting
his
:
 
there
stood
the
Jew
!
 
<EOS>
And
beside
him
,
white
with
rage
or
fear
,
or
both
,
were
the
scowling
features
of
the
man
who
had
accosted
him
in
the
inn
-
yard
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
but
an
instant
,
a
glance
,
a
flash
,
before
his
eyes
;
and
they
were
gone
.
 
<EOS>
But
they
had
recognised
him
,
and
he
them
;
and
their
look
was
as
firmly
impressed
upon
his
memory
,
as
if
it
had
been
deeply
carved
in
stone
,
and
set
before
him
from
his
birth
.
<EOS>
He
stood
transfixed
for
a
moment
;
then
,
leaping
from
the
window
into
the
garden
,
called
loudly
for
help
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
35
.
<EOS>
Containing
the
unsatisfactory
result
of
Oliver
's
adventure
;
and
a
conversation
of
some
importance
between
harry
maylie
and
rose
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
inmates
of
the
house
,
attracted
by
Oliver
's
cries
,
hurried
to
the
spot
from
which
they
proceeded
,
they
found
him
,
pale
and
agitated
,
pointing
in
the
direction
of
the
meadows
behind
the
house
,
and
scarcely
able
to
articulate
the
words
,
"
The
Jew
!
<EOS>
the
Jew
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Giles
was
at
a
loss
to
comprehend
what
this
outcry
meant
;
but
Harry
Maylie
,
whose
perceptions
were
something
quicker
,
and
who
had
heard
Oliver
's
history
from
his
mother
,
understood
it
at
once
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
direction
did
he
take
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
,
catching
up
a
heavy
stick
which
was
standing
in
a
corner
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
,
"
replied
Oliver
,
pointing
out
the
course
the
man
had
taken
;
"
I
missed
them
in
an
instant
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
,
they
are
in
the
ditch
!
"
said
Harry
.
 
<EOS>
"
Follow
!
 
<EOS>
And
keep
as
near
me
,
as
you
can
.
"
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
sprang
over
the
hedge
,
and
darted
off
with
a
speed
which
rendered
it
matter
of
exceeding
difficulty
for
the
others
to
keep
near
him
.
   
<EOS>
Giles
followed
as
well
as
he
could
;
and
Oliver
followed
too
;
and
in
the
course
of
a
minute
or
two
,
Mr
Losberne
,
who
had
been
out
walking
,
and
just
then
returned
,
tumbled
over
the
hedge
after
them
,
and
picking
himself
up
with
more
agility
than
he
could
have
been
supposed
to
possess
,
struck
into
the
same
course
at
no
contemptible
speed
,
shouting
all
the
while
,
most
prodigiously
,
to
know
what
was
the
matter
.
   
<EOS>
On
they
all
went
;
nor
stopped
they
once
to
breathe
,
until
the
leader
,
striking
off
into
an
angle
of
the
field
indicated
by
Oliver
,
began
to
search
,
narrowly
,
the
ditch
and
hedge
adjoining
;
which
afforded
time
for
the
remainder
of
the
party
to
come
up
;
and
for
Oliver
to
communicate
to
Mr
Losberne
the
circumstances
that
had
led
to
so
vigorous
a
pursuit
.
   
<EOS>
The
search
was
all
in
vain
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
not
even
the
traces
of
recent
footsteps
,
to
be
seen
.
 
<EOS>
They
stood
now
,
on
the
summit
of
a
little
hill
,
commanding
the
open
fields
in
every
direction
for
three
or
four
miles
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
the
village
in
the
hollow
on
the
left
;
but
,
in
order
to
gain
that
,
after
pursuing
the
track
Oliver
had
pointed
out
,
the
men
must
have
made
a
circuit
of
open
ground
,
which
it
was
impossible
they
could
have
accomplished
in
so
short
a
time
.
 
<EOS>
A
thick
wood
skirted
the
meadow
-
land
in
another
direction
;
but
they
could
not
have
gained
that
covert
for
the
same
reason
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
must
have
been
a
dream
,
Oliver
,
"
said
Harry
Maylie
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
no
,
indeed
,
sir
,
"
replied
Oliver
,
shuddering
at
the
very
recollection
of
the
old
wretch
's
countenance
;
"
I
saw
him
too
plainly
for
that
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
them
both
,
as
plainly
as
I
see
you
now
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Who
was
the
other
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Harry
and
Mr
Losberne
,
together
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
very
same
man
I
told
you
of
,
who
came
so
suddenly
upon
me
at
the
inn
,
"
said
Oliver
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
had
our
eyes
fixed
full
upon
each
other
;
and
I
could
swear
to
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
They
took
this
way
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
Harry
:
 
"
are
you
sure
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
As
I
am
that
the
men
were
at
the
window
,
"
replied
Oliver
,
pointing
down
,
as
he
spoke
,
to
the
hedge
which
divided
the
cottage
-
garden
from
the
meadow
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
tall
man
leaped
over
,
just
there
;
and
the
Jew
,
running
a
few
paces
to
the
right
,
crept
through
that
gap
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
two
gentlemen
watched
Oliver
's
earnest
face
,
as
he
spoke
,
and
looking
from
him
to
each
other
,
seemed
to
fell
satisfied
of
the
accuracy
of
what
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
Still
,
in
no
direction
were
there
any
appearances
of
the
trampling
of
men
in
hurried
flight
.
 
<EOS>
The
grass
was
long
;
but
it
was
trodden
down
nowhere
,
save
where
their
own
feet
had
crushed
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
sides
and
brinks
of
the
ditches
were
of
damp
clay
;
but
in
no
one
place
could
they
discern
the
print
of
men
's
shoes
,
or
the
slightest
mark
which
would
indicate
that
any
feet
had
pressed
the
ground
for
hours
before
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
strange
!
"
said
Harry
.
   
<EOS>
"
Strange
?
"
echoed
the
doctor
.
 
<EOS>
"
Blathers
and
Duff
,
themselves
,
could
make
nothing
of
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
the
evidently
useless
nature
of
their
search
,
they
did
not
desist
until
the
coming
on
of
night
rendered
its
further
prosecution
hopeless
;
and
even
then
,
they
gave
it
up
with
reluctance
.
 
<EOS>
Giles
was
dispatched
to
the
different
ale
-
houses
in
the
village
,
furnished
with
the
best
description
Oliver
could
give
of
the
appearance
and
dress
of
the
strangers
.
 
<EOS>
Of
these
,
the
Jew
was
,
at
all
events
,
sufficiently
remarkable
to
be
remembered
,
supposing
he
had
been
seen
drinking
,
or
loitering
about
;
but
Giles
returned
without
any
intelligence
,
calculated
to
dispel
or
lessen
the
mystery
.
   
<EOS>
On
the
next
day
,
fresh
search
was
made
,
and
the
inquiries
renewed
;
but
with
no
better
success
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
day
following
,
Oliver
and
Mr
Maylie
repaired
to
the
market
-
town
,
in
the
hope
of
seeing
or
hearing
something
of
the
men
there
;
but
this
effort
was
equally
fruitless
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
few
days
,
the
affair
began
to
be
forgotten
,
as
most
affairs
are
,
when
wonder
,
having
no
fresh
food
to
support
it
,
dies
away
of
itself
.
   
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
Rose
was
rapidly
recovering
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
left
her
room
:
was
able
to
go
out
;
and
mixing
once
more
with
the
family
,
carried
joy
into
the
hearts
of
all
.
   
<EOS>
But
,
although
this
happy
change
had
a
visible
effect
on
the
little
circle
;
and
although
cheerful
voices
and
merry
laughter
were
once
more
heard
in
the
cottage
;
there
was
at
times
,
an
unwonted
restraint
upon
some
there
:
 
even
upon
Rose
herself
:
which
Oliver
could
not
fail
to
remark
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Maylie
and
her
son
were
often
closeted
together
for
a
long
time
;
and
more
than
once
Rose
appeared
with
traces
of
tears
upon
her
face
.
 
<EOS>
After
Mr
Losberne
had
fixed
a
day
for
his
departure
to
Chertsey
,
these
symptoms
increased
;
and
it
became
evident
that
something
was
in
progress
which
affected
the
peace
of
the
young
lady
,
and
of
somebody
else
besides
.
   
<EOS>
At
length
,
one
morning
,
when
Rose
was
alone
in
the
breakfast
-
parlour
,
Harry
Maylie
entered
;
and
,
with
some
hesitation
,
begged
permission
to
speak
with
her
for
a
few
moments
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
few
---
a
very
few
---
will
suffice
,
Rose
,
"
said
the
young
man
,
drawing
his
chair
towards
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
I
shall
have
to
say
,
has
already
presented
itself
to
your
mind
;
the
most
cherished
hopes
of
my
heart
are
not
unknown
to
you
,
though
from
my
lips
you
have
not
heard
them
stated
.
"
   
<EOS>
Rose
had
been
very
pale
from
the
moment
of
his
entrance
;
but
that
might
have
been
the
effect
of
her
recent
illness
.
 
<EOS>
She
merely
bowed
;
and
bending
over
some
plants
that
stood
near
,
waited
in
silence
for
him
to
proceed
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
---
I
---
ought
to
have
left
here
,
before
,
"
said
Harry
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
should
,
indeed
,
"
replied
Rose
.
 
<EOS>
"
Forgive
me
for
saying
so
,
but
I
wish
you
had
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
brought
here
,
by
the
most
dreadful
and
agonising
of
all
apprehensions
,
"
said
the
young
man
;
"
the
fear
of
losing
the
one
dear
being
on
whom
my
every
wish
and
hope
are
fixed
.
 
<EOS>
You
had
been
dying
;
trembling
between
earth
and
heaven
.
 
<EOS>
We
know
that
when
the
young
,
the
beautiful
,
and
good
,
are
visited
with
sickness
,
their
pure
spirits
insensibly
turn
towards
their
bright
home
of
lasting
rest
;
we
know
,
Heaven
help
us
!
<EOS>
that
the
best
and
fairest
of
our
kind
,
too
often
fade
in
blooming
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
were
tears
in
the
eyes
of
the
gentle
girl
,
as
these
words
were
spoken
;
and
when
one
fell
upon
the
flower
over
which
she
bent
,
and
glistened
brightly
in
its
cup
,
making
it
more
beautiful
,
it
seemed
as
though
the
outpouring
of
her
fresh
young
heart
,
claimed
kindred
naturally
,
with
the
loveliest
things
in
nature
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
creature
,
"
continued
the
young
man
,
passionately
,
"
a
creature
as
fair
and
innocent
of
guile
as
one
of
God
's
own
angels
,
fluttered
between
life
and
death
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
who
could
hope
,
when
the
distant
world
to
which
she
was
akin
,
half
opened
to
her
view
,
that
she
would
return
to
the
sorrow
and
calamity
of
this
!
 
<EOS>
Rose
,
Rose
,
to
know
that
you
were
passing
away
like
some
soft
shadow
,
which
a
light
from
above
,
casts
upon
the
earth
;
to
have
no
hope
that
you
would
be
spared
to
those
who
linger
here
;
hardly
to
know
a
reason
why
you
should
be
;
to
feel
that
you
belonged
to
that
bright
sphere
whither
so
many
of
the
fairest
and
the
best
have
winged
their
early
flight
;
and
yet
to
pray
,
amid
all
these
consolations
,
that
you
might
be
restored
to
those
who
loved
you
---
these
were
distractions
almost
too
great
to
bear
.
<EOS>
They
were
mine
,
by
day
and
night
;
and
with
them
,
came
such
a
rushing
torrent
of
fears
,
and
apprehensions
,
and
selfish
regrets
,
lest
you
should
die
,
and
never
know
how
devotedly
I
loved
you
,
as
almost
bore
down
sense
and
reason
in
its
course
.
 
<EOS>
You
recovered
.
<EOS>
Day
by
day
,
and
almost
hour
by
hour
,
some
drop
of
health
came
back
,
and
mingling
with
the
spent
and
feeble
stream
of
life
which
circulated
languidly
within
you
,
swelled
it
again
to
a
high
and
rushing
tide
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
watched
you
change
almost
from
death
,
to
life
,
with
eyes
that
turned
blind
with
their
eagerness
and
deep
affection
.
<EOS>
Do
not
tell
me
that
you
wish
I
had
lost
this
;
for
it
has
softened
my
heart
to
all
mankind
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
did
not
mean
that
,
"
said
Rose
,
weeping
;
"
I
only
wish
you
had
left
here
,
that
you
might
have
turned
to
high
and
noble
pursuits
again
;
to
pursuits
well
worthy
of
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
pursuit
more
worthy
of
me
:
 
more
worthy
of
the
highest
nature
that
exists
:
 
than
the
struggle
to
win
such
a
heart
as
yours
,
"
said
the
young
man
,
taking
her
hand
.
<EOS>
"
Rose
,
my
own
dear
Rose
!
 
<EOS>
For
years
---
for
years
---
I
have
loved
you
;
hoping
to
win
my
way
to
fame
,
and
then
come
proudly
home
and
tell
you
it
had
been
pursued
only
for
you
to
share
;
thinking
,
in
my
daydreams
,
how
I
would
remind
you
,
in
that
happy
moment
,
of
the
many
silent
tokens
I
had
given
of
a
boy
's
attachment
,
and
claim
your
hand
,
as
in
redemption
of
some
old
mute
contract
that
had
been
sealed
between
us
!
 
<EOS>
That
time
has
not
arrived
;
but
here
,
with
not
fame
won
,
and
no
young
vision
realised
<EOS>
,
I
offer
you
the
heart
so
long
your
own
,
and
stake
my
all
upon
the
words
with
which
you
greet
the
offer
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Your
behaviour
has
ever
been
kind
and
noble
.
"
<EOS>
said
Rose
,
mastering
the
emotions
by
which
she
was
agitated
.
 
<EOS>
"
As
you
believe
that
I
am
not
insensible
or
ungrateful
,
so
hear
my
answer
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
,
that
I
may
endeavour
to
deserve
you
;
it
is
,
dear
Rose
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
,
"
replied
Rose
,
"
that
you
must
endeavour
to
forget
me
;
not
as
your
old
and
dearly
-
attached
companion
,
for
that
would
wound
me
deeply
;
but
,
as
the
object
of
your
love
.
 
<EOS>
Look
into
the
world
;
think
how
many
hearts
you
would
be
proud
to
gain
,
are
there
.
<EOS>
Confide
some
other
passion
to
me
,
if
you
will
;
I
will
be
the
truest
,
warmest
,
and
most
faithful
friend
you
have
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
pause
,
during
which
,
Rose
,
who
had
covered
her
face
with
one
hand
,
gave
free
vent
to
her
tears
.
 
<EOS>
Harry
still
retained
the
other
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
your
reasons
,
Rose
,
"
he
said
,
at
length
,
in
a
low
voice
;
"
your
reasons
for
this
decision
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
a
right
to
know
them
,
"
rejoined
Rose
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
can
say
nothing
to
alter
my
resolution
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
duty
that
I
must
perform
.
 
<EOS>
I
owe
it
,
alike
to
others
,
and
to
myself
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
yourself
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Harry
.
 
<EOS>
I
owe
it
to
myself
,
that
I
,
a
friendless
,
portionless
,
girl
,
with
a
blight
upon
my
name
,
should
not
give
your
friends
reason
to
suspect
that
I
had
sordidly
yielded
to
your
first
passion
,
and
fastened
myself
,
a
clog
,
on
all
your
hopes
and
projects
.
 
<EOS>
I
owe
it
to
you
and
yours
,
to
prevent
you
from
opposing
,
in
the
warmth
of
your
generous
nature
,
this
great
obstacle
to
your
progress
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
your
inclinations
chime
with
your
sense
of
duty
---
"
Harry
began
.
   
<EOS>
"
They
do
not
,
"
replied
Rose
,
colouring
deeply
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
you
return
my
love
?
"
said
Harry
.
 
<EOS>
"
Say
but
<EOS>
that
,
dear
Rose
;
say
but
that
;
and
soften
the
bitterness
of
this
hard
disappointment
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
could
have
done
so
,
without
doing
heavy
wrong
to
him
I
loved
,
"
rejoined
Rose
,
<EOS>
"
I
could
have
---
"
   
"
Have
received
this
declaration
very
differently
?
"
said
Harry
.
<EOS>
"
Do
not
conceal
that
from
me
,
at
least
,
Rose
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
could
,
"
said
Rose
.
 
<EOS>
"
Stay
!
"
<EOS>
she
added
,
disengaging
her
hand
,
"
why
should
we
prolong
this
painful
interview
?
 
<EOS>
Most
painful
to
me
,
and
yet
productive
of
lasting
happiness
,
notwithstanding
;
for
it
WILL
be
happiness
to
know
that
I
once
held
the
high
place
in
your
regard
which
I
now
occupy
,
and
every
triumph
you
achieve
in
life
will
animate
me
with
new
fortitude
and
firmness
.
 
<EOS>
Farewell
,
Harry
!
 
<EOS>
As
we
have
met
to
-
day
,
we
meet
no
more
;
but
in
other
relations
than
those
in
which
this
conversation
have
placed
us
,
we
may
be
long
and
happily
entwined
;
and
may
every
blessing
that
the
prayers
of
a
true
and
earnest
heart
can
call
down
from
the
source
of
all
truth
and
sincerity
,
cheer
and
prosper
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Another
word
,
Rose
,
"
said
Harry
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
reason
in
your
own
words
.
 
<EOS>
From
your
own
lips
,
let
me
hear
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
prospect
before
you
,
"
answered
Rose
,
firmly
,
"
is
a
brilliant
one
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
honours
to
which
great
talents
and
powerful
connections
can
help
men
in
public
life
,
are
in
store
for
you
.
<EOS>
But
those
connections
are
proud
;
and
I
will
neither
mingle
with
such
as
may
hold
in
scorn
the
mother
who
gave
me
life
;
nor
bring
disgrace
or
failure
on
the
son
of
her
who
has
so
well
supplied
that
mother
's
place
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
word
,
"
said
the
young
lady
,
turning
away
,
as
her
temporary
firmness
forsook
her
,
"
there
is
a
stain
upon
my
name
,
which
the
world
visits
on
innocent
heads
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
carry
it
into
no
blood
but
my
own
;
and
the
reproach
shall
rest
alone
on
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
One
word
more
,
Rose
.
 
<EOS>
Dearest
Rose
!
<EOS>
one
more
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Harry
,
throwing
himself
before
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
I
had
been
less
---
less
fortunate
,
the
world
would
call
it
---
if
some
obscure
and
peaceful
life
had
been
my
destiny
---
if
I
had
been
poor
,
sick
,
helpless
---
would
you
have
turned
from
me
then
?
 
<EOS>
Or
has
my
probable
advancement
to
riches
and
honour
,
given
this
scruple
birth
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
Do
not
press
me
to
reply
,
"
answered
Rose
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
question
does
not
arise
,
and
never
will
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
unfair
,
almost
unkind
,
to
urge
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
your
answer
be
what
I
almost
dare
to
hope
it
is
,
"
retorted
Harry
,
"
it
will
shed
a
gleam
of
happiness
upon
my
lonely
way
,
and
light
the
path
before
me
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
an
idle
thing
to
do
so
much
,
by
the
utterance
of
a
few
brief
words
,
for
one
who
loves
you
beyond
all
else
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
Rose
:
in
the
name
of
my
ardent
and
enduring
attachment
;
in
the
name
of
all
I
have
suffered
for
you
,
and
all
you
doom
me
to
undergo
;
answer
me
this
one
question
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
,
if
your
lot
had
been
differently
cast
,
"
rejoined
Rose
;
"
if
you
had
been
even
a
little
,
but
not
so
far
,
above
me
;
if
I
could
have
been
a
help
and
comfort
to
you
in
any
humble
scene
of
peace
and
retirement
,
and
not
a
blot
and
drawback
in
ambitious
and
distinguished
crowds
;
I
should
have
been
spared
this
trial
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
every
reason
to
be
happy
,
very
happy
,
now
;
but
then
,
Harry
,
I
own
<EOS>
I
should
have
been
happier
.
"
   
<EOS>
Busy
recollections
of
old
hopes
,
cherished
as
a
girl
,
long
ago
,
crowded
into
the
mind
of
Rose
,
while
making
this
avowal
;
but
they
brought
tears
with
them
,
as
old
hopes
will
when
they
come
back
withered
;
and
they
relieved
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
help
this
weakness
,
and
it
makes
my
purpose
stronger
,
"
said
Rose
,
extending
her
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
must
leave
you
now
,
indeed
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
ask
one
promise
,
"
said
Harry
.
 
<EOS>
"
Once
,
and
only
once
more
,
---
say
within
a
year
,
but
it
may
be
much
sooner
,
---
I
may
speak
to
you
again
on
this
subject
,
for
the
last
time
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
to
press
me
to
alter
my
right
determination
,
"
replied
Rose
,
with
a
melancholy
smile
;
"
it
will
be
useless
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Harry
;
"
to
hear
you
repeat
it
,
if
you
will
---
finally
repeat
it
!
 
<EOS>
I
will
lay
at
your
feet
,
<EOS>
whatever
of
station
of
fortune
I
may
possess
;
and
if
you
still
adhere
to
your
present
resolution
,
will
not
seek
,
by
word
or
act
,
to
change
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
let
it
be
so
,
"
rejoined
Rose
;
"
it
is
but
one
pang
the
more
,
and
by
that
time
I
may
be
enabled
to
bear
it
better
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
extended
her
hand
again
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
young
man
caught
her
to
his
bosom
;
and
imprinting
one
kiss
on
her
beautiful
forehead
,
hurried
from
the
room
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
36
.
<EOS>
Is
a
very
short
one
,
and
may
appear
of
no
great
importance
in
its
place
,
but
it
should
be
read
notwithstanding
,
as
a
sequel
to
the
last
,
and
a
key
to
one
that
will
follow
when
its
time
arrives
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
you
are
resolved
to
be
my
travelling
companion
this
morning
;
eh
?
<EOS>
"
said
the
doctor
,
as
Harry
Maylie
joined
him
and
Oliver
at
the
breakfast
-
table
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
are
not
in
the
same
mind
or
intention
two
half
-
hours
together
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
will
tell
me
a
different
tale
one
of
these
days
,
"
said
Harry
,
colouring
without
any
perceptible
reason
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
I
may
have
good
cause
to
do
so
,
"
replied
Mr
Losberne
;
"
though
I
confess
I
do
n't
think
I
shall
.
 
<EOS>
But
yesterday
morning
you
had
made
up
your
mind
,
in
a
great
hurry
,
to
stay
here
,
and
to
accompany
your
mother
,
like
a
dutiful
son
,
to
the
sea
-
side
.
<EOS>
Before
noon
,
you
announce
that
you
are
going
to
do
me
the
honour
of
accompanying
me
as
far
as
I
go
,
on
your
road
to
London
.
 
<EOS>
And
at
night
,
you
urge
me
,
with
great
mystery
,
to
start
before
the
ladies
are
stirring
;
the
consequence
of
which
is
,
that
young
Oliver
here
is
pinned
down
to
his
breakfast
when
he
ought
to
be
ranging
the
meadows
after
botanical
phenomena
of
all
kinds
.
<EOS>
Too
bad
,
is
n't
it
,
Oliver
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
have
been
very
sorry
not
to
have
been
at
home
when
you
and
Mr
Maylie
went
away
,
sir
,
"
rejoined
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
a
fine
fellow
,
"
said
the
doctor
;
"
you
shall
come
and
see
me
when
you
return
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
to
speak
seriously
,
Harry
;
has
any
communication
from
the
great
nobs
produced
this
sudden
anxiety
on
your
part
to
be
gone
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
great
nobs
,
"
replied
Harry
,
"
<EOS>
under
which
designation
,
I
presume
,
you
include
my
most
stately
uncle
,
have
not
communicated
with
me
at
all
,
since
I
have
been
here
;
nor
,
at
this
time
of
the
year
,
is
it
likely
that
anything
would
occur
to
render
necessary
my
immediate
attendance
among
them
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
said
the
doctor
,
"
you
are
a
queer
fellow
.
 
<EOS>
But
of
course
they
will
get
you
into
parliament
at
the
election
before
Christmas
,
and
these
sudden
shiftings
and
changes
are
no
bad
preparation
for
political
life
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
something
in
that
.
 
<EOS>
Good
training
is
always
desirable
,
whether
the
race
be
for
place
,
cup
,
or
sweepstakes
.
"
   
<EOS>
Harry
Maylie
looked
as
if
he
could
have
followed
up
this
short
dialogue
by
one
or
two
remarks
that
would
have
staggered
the
doctor
not
a
little
;
but
he
contented
himself
with
saying
,
"
We
shall
see
,
"
and
pursued
the
subject
no
farther
.
 
<EOS>
The
post
-
chaise
drove
up
to
the
door
shortly
afterwards
;
and
Giles
coming
in
for
the
luggage
,
the
good
doctor
bustled
out
,
to
see
it
packed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oliver
,
"
said
Harry
Maylie
,
in
a
low
voice
,
"
let
me
speak
a
word
with
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver
walked
into
the
window
-
recess
to
which
Mr
Maylie
beckoned
him
;
much
surprised
at
the
mixture
of
sadness
and
boisterous
spirits
,
which
his
whole
behaviour
displayed
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
can
write
well
now
?
<EOS>
"
said
Harry
,
laying
his
hand
upon
his
arm
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
so
,
sir
,
"
replied
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
not
be
at
home
again
,
perhaps
for
some
time
;
I
wish
you
would
write
to
me
---
say
once
a
fort
-
night
:
 
<EOS>
every
alternate
Monday
:
to
the
General
Post
Office
in
London
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
certainly
,
sir
;
I
shall
be
proud
to
do
it
,
"
exclaimed
Oliver
,
greatly
delighted
with
the
commission
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
to
know
how
---
how
my
mother
and
Miss
Maylie
are
,
"
said
the
young
man
;
"
and
you
can
fill
up
a
sheet
by
telling
me
what
walks
you
take
,
and
what
you
talk
about
,
and
whether
she
---
they
,
I
mean
---
seem
happy
and
quite
well
.
<EOS>
You
understand
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
quite
,
sir
,
quite
,
"
replied
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
would
rather
you
did
not
mention
it
to
them
,
"
said
Harry
,
hurrying
over
his
words
;
"
because
it
might
make
my
mother
anxious
to
write
to
me
oftener
,
and
it
is
a
trouble
and
worry
to
her
.
<EOS>
Let
is
be
a
secret
between
you
and
me
;
and
mind
you
tell
me
everything
!
 
<EOS>
I
depend
upon
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver
,
quite
elated
and
honoured
by
a
sense
of
his
importance
,
faithfully
promised
to
be
secret
and
explicit
in
his
communications
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Maylie
took
leave
of
him
,
with
many
assurances
of
his
regard
and
protection
.
   
<EOS>
The
doctor
was
in
the
chaise
;
Giles
(
who
,
it
had
been
arranged
,
should
be
left
behind
)
held
the
door
open
in
his
hand
;
and
the
women
-
servants
were
in
the
garden
,
looking
on
.
 
<EOS>
Harry
cast
one
slight
glance
at
the
latticed
window
,
and
jumped
into
the
carriage
.
   
<EOS>
"
Drive
on
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
"
hard
,
fast
,
full
gallop
!
 
<EOS>
Nothing
short
of
flying
will
keep
pace
with
me
,
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Halloa
!
"
cried
the
doctor
,
letting
down
the
front
glass
in
a
great
hurry
,
and
shouting
to
the
postillion
;
"
something
very
short
of
flyng
will
keep
pace
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
hear
?
"
   
<EOS>
Jingling
and
clattering
,
till
distance
rendered
its
noise
inaudible
,
and
its
rapid
progress
only
perceptible
to
the
eye
,
the
vehicle
wound
its
way
along
the
road
,
almost
hidden
in
a
cloud
of
dust
:
now
wholly
disappearing
,
and
now
becoming
visible
again
,
as
intervening
objects
,
or
the
intricacies
of
the
way
,
permitted
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
until
even
the
dusty
cloud
was
no
longer
to
be
seen
,
that
the
gazers
dispersed
.
   
<EOS>
And
there
was
one
looker
-
on
,
who
remained
with
eyes
fixed
upon
the
spot
where
the
carriage
had
disappeared
,
long
after
it
was
many
miles
away
;
for
,
behind
the
white
curtain
which
had
shrouded
her
from
view
when
Harry
raised
his
eyes
towards
the
window
,
sat
Rose
herself
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
seems
in
high
spirits
and
happy
,
"
she
said
,
at
length
.
<EOS>
"
I
feared
for
a
time
he
might
be
otherwise
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
mistaken
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
very
,
very
glad
.
"
   
<EOS>
Tears
are
signs
of
gladness
as
well
as
grief
;
but
those
which
coursed
down
Rose
's
face
,
as
she
sat
pensively
at
the
window
,
still
gazing
in
the
same
direction
,
seemed
to
tell
more
of
sorrow
than
of
joy
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
37
.
<EOS>
In
which
the
reader
may
perceive
a
contrast
,
not
uncommon
in
matrimonial
cases
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
sat
in
the
workhouse
parlour
,
with
his
eyes
moodily
fixed
on
the
cheerless
grate
,
whence
,
as
it
was
summer
time
,
no
brighter
gleam
proceeded
,
than
the
reflection
of
certain
sickly
rays
of
the
sun
,
which
were
sent
back
from
its
cold
and
shining
surface
.
 
<EOS>
A
paper
fly
-
cage
dangled
from
the
ceiling
,
to
which
he
occasionally
raised
his
eyes
in
gloomy
thought
;
and
,
as
the
heedless
insects
hovered
round
the
gaudy
net
-
work
,
Mr
Bumble
would
heave
a
deep
sigh
,
while
a
more
gloomy
shadow
overspread
his
countenance
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
was
meditating
;
it
might
be
that
the
insects
brought
to
mind
,
some
painful
passage
in
his
own
past
life
.
   
<EOS>
Nor
was
Mr
Bumble
's
gloom
the
only
thing
calculated
to
awaken
a
pleasing
melancholy
in
the
bosom
of
a
spectator
.
<EOS>
There
were
not
wanting
other
appearances
,
and
those
closely
connected
with
his
own
person
,
which
announced
that
a
great
change
had
taken
place
in
the
position
of
his
affairs
.
 
<EOS>
The
laced
coat
,
and
the
cocked
hat
<EOS>
;
where
were
they
?
 
<EOS>
He
still
wore
knee
-
breeches
,
and
dark
cotton
stockings
on
his
nether
limbs
;
but
they
were
not
THE
breeches
.
 
<EOS>
The
coat
was
wide
-
skirted
;
and
in
that
respect
like
THE
coat
,
but
,
oh
how
different
!
 
<EOS>
The
mighty
cocked
hat
was
replaced
by
a
modest
round
one
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
was
no
longer
a
beadle
.
   
<EOS>
There
are
some
promotions
in
life
,
which
,
independent
of
the
more
substantial
rewards
they
offer
,
require
peculiar
value
and
dignity
from
the
coats
and
waistcoats
connected
with
them
.
 
<EOS>
A
field
-
marshal
has
his
uniform
;
a
bishop
his
silk
apron
;
a
counsellor
his
silk
gown
;
a
beadle
his
cocked
hat
.
 
<EOS>
Strip
the
bishop
of
his
apron
,
or
the
beadle
of
his
hat
and
lace
<EOS>
;
what
are
they
?
 
<EOS>
Men
.
 
<EOS>
Mere
men
.
 
<EOS>
Dignity
,
and
even
holiness
too
,
sometimes
,
are
more
questions
of
coat
and
waistcoat
than
some
people
imagine
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumle
had
married
Mrs
Corney
,
and
was
master
of
the
workhouse
.
 
<EOS>
Another
beadle
had
come
into
power
.
 
<EOS>
On
him
the
cocked
hat
,
gold
-
laced
coat
,
and
staff
,
had
all
three
descended
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
to
-
morrow
two
months
it
was
done
!
"
said
Mr
Bumble
,
with
a
sigh
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
seems
a
age
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
might
have
meant
that
he
had
concentrated
a
whole
existence
of
happiness
into
the
short
space
of
eight
weeks
;
but
the
sigh
---
there
was
a
vast
deal
of
meaning
in
the
sigh
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
sold
myself
,
"
said
Mr
Bumble
,
pursuing
the
same
train
of
relection
,
"
for
six
teaspoons
,
a
pair
of
sugar
-
tongs
,
and
a
milk
-
pot
;
with
a
small
quantity
of
second
-
hand
