,
and
twenty
pound
in
money
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
very
reasonable
.
 
<EOS>
Cheap
,
dirt
cheap
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Cheap
!
"
cried
a
shrill
voice
in
Mr
Bumble
's
ear
:
<EOS>
"
you
would
have
been
dear
at
any
price
;
and
dear
enough
I
paid
for
you
,
Lord
above
knows
that
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
turned
,
and
encountered
the
face
of
his
interesting
consort
,
who
,
imperfectly
comprehending
the
few
words
she
had
overheard
of
his
complaint
,
had
hazarded
the
foregoing
remark
at
a
venture
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Bumble
,
ma'am
!
"
said
Mr
Bumble
,
with
a
sentimental
sternness
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
cried
the
lady
.
   
<EOS>
"
Have
the
goodness
to
look
at
me
,
"
said
Mr
Bumble
,
fixing
his
eyes
upon
her
.
 
<EOS>
(
If
she
stands
such
a
eye
as
that
,
"
said
Mr
Bumble
to
himself
,
"
she
can
stand
anything
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
eye
I
never
knew
to
fail
with
paupers
.
 
<EOS>
If
it
fails
with
her
,
my
power
is
gone
.
"
)
   
<EOS>
Whether
an
exceedingly
small
expansion
of
eye
be
sufficient
to
quell
paupers
,
who
,
being
lightly
fed
,
are
in
no
very
high
condition
;
or
whether
the
late
Mrs
Corney
was
particularly
proof
against
eagle
glances
;
are
matters
of
opinion
.
 
<EOS>
The
matter
of
fact
,
is
,
that
the
matron
was
in
no
way
overpowered
by
Mr
Bumble
's
scowl
,
but
,
on
the
contrary
,
treated
it
with
great
disdain
,
and
even
raised
a
laugh
threreat
,
which
sounded
as
though
it
were
genuine
.
   
<EOS>
On
hearing
this
most
unexpected
sound
,
Mr
Bumble
looked
,
first
incredulous
,
and
afterwards
amazed
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
relapsed
into
his
former
state
;
nor
did
he
rouse
himself
until
his
attention
was
again
awakened
by
the
voice
of
his
partner
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
going
to
sit
snoring
there
,
all
day
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mrs
Bumble
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
going
to
sit
here
,
as
long
as
I
think
proper
,
ma'am
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Bumble
;
"
and
although
I
was
NOT
snoring
,
I
shall
snore
,
gape
,
sneeze
,
laugh
,
or
cry
,
as
the
humour
strikes
me
;
such
being
my
prerogative
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Your
PREROGATIVE
!
"
<EOS>
sneered
Mrs
Bumble
,
with
ineffable
contempt
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
said
the
word
,
ma'am
,
"
said
Mr
Bumble
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
prerogative
of
a
man
is
to
command
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
what
's
the
prerogative
of
a
woman
,
in
the
name
of
Goodness
?
<EOS>
"
cried
the
relict
of
Mr
Corney
deceased
.
   
<EOS>
"
To
obey
,
ma'am
,
"
thundered
Mr
Bumble
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
late
unfortunate
husband
should
have
taught
it
you
;
and
then
,
perhaps
,
he
might
have
been
alive
now
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
he
was
,
poor
man
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Bumble
,
seeing
at
a
glance
,
that
the
decisive
moment
had
now
arrived
,
and
that
a
blow
struck
for
the
mastership
on
one
side
or
other
,
must
necessarily
be
final
and
conclusive
,
no
sooner
heard
this
allusion
to
the
dead
and
gone
,
than
she
dropped
into
a
chair
,
and
with
a
loud
scream
that
Mr
Bumble
was
a
hard
-
hearted
brute
,
fell
into
a
paroxysm
of
tears
.
   
<EOS>
But
,
tears
were
not
the
things
to
find
their
way
to
Mr
Bumble
's
soul
;
his
heart
was
waterproof
.
 
<EOS>
Like
washable
beaver
hats
that
improve
with
rain
,
his
nerves
were
rendered
stouter
and
more
vigorous
,
by
showers
of
tears
,
which
,
being
tokens
of
weakness
,
and
so
far
tacit
admissions
of
his
own
power
,
please
and
exalted
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
eyed
his
good
lady
with
looks
of
great
satisfaction
,
and
begged
,
in
an
encouraging
manner
,
that
she
should
cry
her
hardest
:
 
the
exercise
being
looked
upon
,
by
the
faculty
,
as
strongly
conducive
to
health
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
opens
the
lungs
,
washes
the
countenance
,
exercises
the
eyes
,
and
softens
down
the
temper
,
"
said
Mr
Bumble
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
cry
away
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
he
discharged
himself
of
this
pleasantry
,
Mr
Bumble
took
his
hat
from
a
peg
,
and
putting
it
on
,
rather
rakishly
,
on
one
side
,
as
a
man
might
,
who
felt
he
had
asserted
his
superiority
in
a
becoming
manner
,
thrust
his
hands
into
his
pockets
,
and
sauntered
towards
the
door
,
with
much
ease
and
waggishness
depicted
in
his
whole
appearance
.
   
<EOS>
Now
,
Mrs
Corney
that
was
,
had
tried
the
tears
,
because
they
were
less
troublesome
than
a
manual
assault
;
but
,
she
was
quite
prepared
to
make
trial
of
the
latter
mode
of
proceeding
,
as
Mr
Bumble
was
not
long
in
discovering
.
   
<EOS>
The
first
proof
he
experienced
of
the
fact
,
was
conveyed
in
a
hollow
sound
,
immediately
succeeded
by
the
sudden
flying
off
of
his
hat
to
the
opposite
end
of
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
This
preliminary
proceeding
laying
bare
his
head
,
the
expert
lady
,
clasping
him
tightly
round
the
throat
with
one
hand
,
inflicted
a
shower
of
blows
(
dealt
with
singular
vigour
and
dexterity
)
upon
it
with
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
This
done
,
she
created
a
little
variety
by
scratching
his
face
,
and
tearing
his
hair
;
and
,
having
,
by
this
time
,
inflicted
as
much
punishment
as
she
deemed
necessary
for
the
offence
<EOS>
,
she
pushed
him
over
a
chair
,
which
was
luckily
well
situated
for
the
purpose
:
 
and
defied
him
to
talk
about
his
prerogative
again
,
if
he
dared
.
   
<EOS>
"
Get
up
!
"
said
Mrs
Bumble
,
in
a
voice
of
command
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
take
yourself
away
from
here
,
unless
you
want
me
to
do
something
desperate
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
rose
with
a
very
rueful
countenance
:
 
wondering
much
what
something
desperate
might
be
.
 
<EOS>
Picking
up
his
hat
,
he
looked
towards
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
going
?
"
demanded
Mr
Bumble
.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
my
dear
,
certainly
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Bumble
,
making
a
quicker
motion
towards
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
intend
to
---
I
'm
going
,
my
dear
!
 
<EOS>
You
are
so
very
violent
,
<EOS>
that
really
I
---
"
   
At
this
instant
,
Mrs
Bumble
stepped
hastily
forward
to
replace
the
carpet
,
which
had
been
kicked
up
in
the
scuffle
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
immediately
darted
out
of
the
room
,
without
bestowing
another
thought
on
his
unfinished
sentence
:
 
leaving
the
late
Mrs
Corney
in
full
possession
of
the
field
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
was
fairly
taken
by
surprise
,
and
fairly
beaten
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
decided
propensity
for
bullying
:
 
<EOS>
derived
no
inconsiderable
pleasure
from
the
exercise
of
petty
cruelty
;
and
,
consequently
,
was
(
it
is
needless
to
say
)
a
coward
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
by
no
means
a
disparagement
to
his
character
;
for
many
official
personages
,
who
are
held
in
high
respect
and
admiration
,
are
the
victims
of
similar
infirmities
.
 
<EOS>
The
remark
is
made
,
indeed
,
rather
in
his
favour
than
otherwise
,
and
with
a
view
of
impressing
the
reader
with
a
just
sense
of
his
qualifications
for
office
.
   
<EOS>
But
,
the
measure
of
his
degradation
was
not
yet
full
.
 
<EOS>
After
making
a
tour
of
the
house
,
and
thinking
,
for
the
first
time
,
that
the
poor
-
laws
really
were
too
hard
on
people
;
and
that
men
who
ran
away
from
their
wives
,
leaving
them
chargeable
to
the
parish
,
ought
,
in
justice
to
be
visited
with
no
punishment
at
all
,
but
rather
rewarded
as
meritorious
individuals
who
had
suffered
much
;
Mr
Bumble
came
to
a
room
where
some
of
the
female
paupers
were
usually
employed
in
washing
the
parish
linen
:
 
when
the
sound
of
voices
in
conversation
,
now
proceeded
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hem
!
"
said
Mr
Bumble
,
summoning
up
all
his
native
dignity
.
<EOS>
"
These
women
at
least
shall
continue
to
respect
the
prerogative
.
<EOS>
Hallo
!
<EOS>
hallo
there
!
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
mean
by
this
noise
,
you
hussies
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
With
these
words
,
Mr
Bumble
opened
the
door
,
and
walked
in
with
a
very
fierce
and
angry
manner
:
 
which
was
at
once
exchanged
for
a
most
humiliated
and
cowering
air
,
as
his
eyes
unexpectedly
rested
on
the
form
of
his
lady
wife
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
,
"
said
Mr
Bumble
,
"
I
did
n't
know
you
were
here
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Did
n't
know
I
was
here
!
"
repeated
Mrs
Bumble
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
YOU
do
here
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
thought
they
were
talking
rather
too
much
to
be
doing
their
work
properly
,
my
dear
,
"
replied
Mr
Bumble
:
 
glancing
distractedly
at
a
couple
of
old
women
at
the
wash
-
tub
,
who
were
comparing
notes
of
admiration
at
the
workhouse
-
master
's
humility
.
   
<EOS>
"
YOU
thought
they
were
talking
too
much
?
"
said
Mrs
Bumble
.
<EOS>
"
What
business
is
it
of
yours
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
my
dear
---
"
urged
Mr
Bumble
submissively
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
business
is
it
of
yours
?
"
demanded
Mrs
Bumble
,
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
very
true
,
you
're
matron
here
,
my
dear
,
"
submitted
Mr
Bumble
;
"
but
I
thought
you
might
n't
be
in
the
way
just
then
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
tell
you
<EOS>
what
,
Mr
Bumble
,
"
returned
his
lady
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
do
n't
want
any
of
your
interference
.
 
<EOS>
You
're
a
great
deal
too
fond
of
poking
your
nose
into
things
that
do
n't
concern
you
,
making
everybody
in
the
house
laugh
,
the
moment
your
back
is
turned
,
and
making
yourself
look
like
a
fool
every
hour
in
the
day
.
 
<EOS>
Be
off
;
come
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
,
seeing
with
excruciating
feelings
,
the
delight
of
the
two
old
paupers
,
who
were
tittering
together
most
rapturously
,
hesitated
for
an
instant
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Bumble
,
whose
patience
brooked
no
delay
,
caught
up
a
bowl
of
soap
-
suds
,
and
motioning
him
towards
the
door
,
ordered
him
instantly
to
depart
,
on
pain
of
receiving
the
contents
upon
his
portly
person
.
   
<EOS>
What
could
Mr
Bumble
do
?
 
<EOS>
He
looked
dejectedly
round
,
and
slunk
away
;
and
,
as
he
reached
the
door
,
the
titterings
of
the
paupers
broke
into
a
shrill
chuckle
of
irrepressible
delight
.
 
<EOS>
It
wanted
but
<EOS>
this
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
degraded
in
their
eyes
;
he
had
lost
caste
and
station
before
the
very
paupers
;
he
had
fallen
from
all
the
height
and
pomp
of
beadleship
,
to
the
lowest
depth
of
the
most
snubbed
hen
-
peckery
.
   
<EOS>
"
All
in
two
months
!
"
said
Mr
Bumble
,
filled
with
dismal
thoughts
.
 
<EOS>
"
Two
months
!
 
<EOS>
No
more
than
two
months
ago
,
I
was
not
only
my
own
master
,
but
everybody
else
's
,
so
far
as
the
porochial
workhouse
was
concerned
,
and
now
!
<EOS>
---
"
   
It
was
too
much
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
boxed
the
ears
of
the
boy
who
opened
the
gate
for
him
(
for
he
had
reached
the
portal
in
his
reverie
)
;
and
walked
,
distractedly
,
into
the
street
.
   
<EOS>
He
walked
up
one
street
,
and
down
another
,
until
exercise
had
abated
the
first
passion
of
his
grief
;
and
then
the
revulsion
of
feeling
made
him
thirsty
.
 
<EOS>
He
passed
a
great
many
public
-
houses
;
but
,
at
length
paused
before
one
in
a
by
-
way
,
whose
parlour
,
as
he
gathered
from
a
hasty
peep
over
the
blinds
,
was
deserted
,
save
by
one
solitary
customer
.
 
<EOS>
It
began
to
rain
,
heavily
,
at
the
moment
.
 
<EOS>
This
determined
him
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
stepped
in
;
and
ordering
something
to
drink
,
as
he
passed
the
bar
,
entered
the
apartment
into
which
he
had
looked
from
the
street
.
   
<EOS>
The
man
who
was
seated
there
,
was
tall
and
dark
,
and
wore
a
large
cloak
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
the
air
of
a
stranger
;
and
seemed
,
by
a
certain
haggardness
in
his
look
,
as
well
as
by
the
dusty
soils
on
his
dress
,
to
have
travelled
some
distance
.
 
<EOS>
He
eyed
Bumble
askance
,
as
he
entered
,
but
scarcely
deigned
to
nod
his
head
in
acknowledgment
of
his
salutation
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
had
quite
dignity
enough
for
two
;
supposing
even
that
the
stranger
had
been
more
familiar
:
 
<EOS>
so
he
drank
his
gin
-
and
-
water
in
silence
,
and
read
the
paper
with
great
show
of
pomp
and
circumstance
.
   
<EOS>
It
so
happened
,
however
:
as
it
will
happen
very
often
,
when
men
fall
into
company
under
such
circumstances
:
 
that
Mr
Bumble
felt
,
every
now
and
then
,
a
powerful
inducement
,
which
he
could
not
resist
,
to
steal
a
look
at
the
stranger
:
 
and
that
whenever
he
did
so
,
he
withdrew
his
eyes
,
in
some
confusion
,
to
find
that
the
stranger
was
at
that
moment
stealing
a
look
at
him
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
's
awkwardness
was
enhanced
by
the
very
remarkable
expression
of
the
stranger
's
eye
,
which
was
keen
and
bright
,
but
shadowed
by
a
scowl
of
distrust
and
suspicion
,
unlike
anything
he
had
ever
observed
before
,
and
repulsive
to
behold
.
   
<EOS>
When
they
had
encountered
each
other
's
glance
several
times
in
this
way
,
the
stranger
,
in
a
harsh
,
deep
voice
,
broke
silence
.
   
<EOS>
"
Were
you
looking
for
me
,
"
he
said
,
"
when
you
peered
in
at
the
window
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
that
I
am
aware
of
,
unless
you
're
Mr
 
---
"
 
<EOS>
Here
Mr
Bumble
stopped
short
;
for
he
was
curious
to
know
the
stranger
's
name
,
and
thought
in
his
impatience
,
he
might
supply
the
blank
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
see
you
were
not
,
"
said
the
stranger
;
and
expression
of
quiet
sarcasm
playing
about
his
mouth
;
"
or
you
have
known
my
name
.
 
<EOS>
You
do
n't
know
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
recommend
you
not
to
ask
for
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
meant
no
harm
,
young
man
,
"
observed
Mr
Bumble
,
majestically
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
have
done
none
,
"
said
the
stranger
.
   
<EOS>
Another
silence
succeeded
this
short
dialogue
:
 
which
was
again
broken
by
the
stranger
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
seen
you
before
,
I
think
?
"
said
he
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
were
differently
dressed
at
that
time
,
and
I
only
passed
you
in
the
street
,
but
I
should
know
you
again
.
 
<EOS>
You
were
beadle
here
,
once
;
were
you
not
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
,
"
said
Mr
Bumble
,
in
some
surprise
;
"
porochial
beadle
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Just
so
,
"
rejoined
the
other
,
nodding
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
in
that
character
I
saw
you
.
 
<EOS>
What
are
you
now
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Master
of
the
workhouse
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Bumble
,
slowly
and
impressively
,
to
check
any
undue
familiarity
the
stranger
might
otherwise
assume
.
 
<EOS>
"
Master
of
the
workhouse
,
young
man
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
the
same
eye
to
your
own
interest
,
that
you
always
had
,
I
doubt
not
?
"
resumed
the
stranger
,
looking
keenly
into
Mr
Bumble
's
eyes
,
as
he
raised
them
in
astonishment
at
the
question
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
scruple
to
answer
freely
,
man
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
you
pretty
well
,
you
see
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
,
a
married
man
,
"
replied
Mr
Bumble
,
shading
his
eyes
with
his
hand
,
and
surveying
the
stranger
,
from
head
to
foot
,
in
evident
perplexity
,
"
is
not
more
averse
to
turning
an
honest
penny
when
he
can
,
than
a
single
one
.
 
<EOS>
Porochial
officers
are
not
so
well
paid
that
they
can
afford
to
refuse
any
little
extra
fee
,
when
it
comes
to
them
in
a
civil
and
proper
manner
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
stranger
smiled
,
and
nodded
his
head
again
:
as
much
to
say
,
he
had
not
mistaken
his
man
;
then
rang
the
bell
.
   
<EOS>
"
Fill
this
glass
again
,
"
he
said
,
<EOS>
handing
Mr
Bumble
's
empty
tumbler
to
the
landlord
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
it
be
strong
and
hot
.
 
<EOS>
You
like
it
<EOS>
so
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
Not
too
strong
,
"
replied
Mr
Bumble
,
with
a
delicate
cough
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
understand
what
that
means
,
landlord
!
"
said
the
stranger
,
drily
.
   
<EOS>
The
host
smiled
,
disappeared
,
and
shortly
afterwards
returned
with
a
steaming
jorum
:
of
which
,
the
first
gulp
brought
the
water
into
Mr
Bumble
's
eyes
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
listen
to
me
,
"
said
the
stranger
,
after
closing
the
door
and
window
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
came
down
to
this
place
,
to
-
day
,
to
find
you
out
;
and
,
by
one
of
those
chances
which
the
devil
throws
in
the
way
of
his
friends
sometimes
,
you
walked
into
the
very
room
I
was
sitting
in
,
while
you
were
uppermost
in
my
mind
.
 
<EOS>
I
want
some
information
from
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
ask
you
to
give
it
for
mothing
,
slight
as
it
is
.
 
<EOS>
Put
up
that
,
to
begin
with
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
,
he
pushed
a
couple
of
sovereigns
across
the
table
to
his
companion
,
carefully
,
as
though
unwilling
that
the
chinking
of
money
should
be
heard
without
.
 
<EOS>
When
Mr
Bumble
had
scrupulously
examined
the
coins
,
to
see
that
they
were
genuine
,
and
had
put
them
up
,
with
much
satisfaction
,
in
his
waistcoat
-
pocket
,
he
went
on
:
   
"
<EOS>
Carry
your
memory
back
---
let
me
see
---
twelve
years
,
last
winter
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
long
time
,
"
said
Mr
Bumble
.
 
<EOS>
"
Very
good
.
 
<EOS>
I
've
done
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
scene
,
the
workhouse
.
"
   
"
Good
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
the
time
,
night
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
the
place
,
the
crazy
hole
,
wherever
it
was
,
in
which
miserable
drabs
brought
forth
the
life
and
health
so
often
denied
to
themselves
---
gave
birth
to
puling
children
for
the
parish
to
rear
;
and
hid
their
shame
,
rot
'em
in
the
grave
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
lying
-
in
room
<EOS>
,
I
suppose
?
"
said
Mr
Bumble
,
not
quite
following
the
stranger
's
excited
description
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
the
stranger
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
boy
was
born
there
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
many
boys
,
"
observed
Mr
Bumble
,
shaking
his
head
,
despondingly
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
murrain
on
the
young
devils
!
<EOS>
"
cried
the
stranger
;
"
I
speak
of
one
;
a
meek
-
looking
,
pale
-
faced
boy
,
who
was
apprenticed
down
here
,
to
a
coffin
-
maker
---
I
wish
he
had
made
his
coffin
,
and
screwed
his
body
in
it
---
and
who
afterwards
ran
away
to
London
,
as
it
was
supposed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
mean
Oliver
!
 
<EOS>
Young
Twist
!
<EOS>
"
said
Mr
Bumble
;
"
I
remember
him
,
of
course
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
n't
a
obstinater
young
rascal
---
<EOS>
"
   
"
It
's
not
of
him
I
want
to
hear
;
I
've
heard
enough
of
him
,
"
said
the
stranger
,
stopping
Mr
Bumble
in
the
outset
of
a
tirade
on
the
subject
of
poor
Oliver
's
vices
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
of
a
woman
;
the
hag
that
nursed
his
mother
.
 
<EOS>
Where
is
she
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Where
is
she
?
"
said
Mr
Bumble
,
whom
the
gin
-
and
-
water
had
rendered
facetious
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
would
be
hard
to
tell
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
no
midwifery
there
<EOS>
,
whichever
place
she
's
gone
to
;
so
I
suppose
she
's
out
of
employment
,
anyway
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
?
"
demanded
the
stranger
,
sternly
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
she
died
last
winter
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Bumble
.
   
<EOS>
The
man
looked
fixedly
at
him
when
he
had
given
this
information
,
and
although
he
did
not
withdraw
his
eyes
for
some
time
afterwards
,
his
gaze
gradually
became
vacant
and
abstracted
,
and
he
seemed
lost
in
thought
.
 
<EOS>
For
some
time
,
he
appeared
doubtful
whether
he
ought
to
be
relieved
or
disappointed
by
the
intelligence
;
but
at
length
he
breathed
more
freely
;
and
withdrawing
his
eyes
,
observed
that
it
was
no
great
matter
.
 
<EOS>
With
that
he
rose
,
as
if
to
depart
.
   
<EOS>
But
Mr
Bumble
was
cunning
enough
;
and
he
at
once
saw
that
an
opportunity
was
opened
,
for
the
lucrative
disposal
of
some
secret
in
the
possession
of
his
better
half
.
 
<EOS>
He
well
remembered
the
night
of
old
Sally
's
death
,
which
the
occurrences
of
that
day
had
given
him
good
reason
to
recollect
,
as
the
occasion
on
which
he
had
proposed
to
Mrs
Corney
;
and
although
that
lady
had
never
confided
to
him
the
disclosure
of
which
she
had
been
the
solitary
witness
,
he
had
heard
enough
to
know
that
it
related
to
something
that
had
occurred
in
the
old
woman
's
attendance
,
as
workhouse
nurse
,
upon
the
young
mother
of
Oliver
Twist
.
 
<EOS>
Hastily
calling
this
circumstance
to
mind
,
he
informed
the
stranger
,
with
an
air
of
mystery
,
that
one
woman
had
been
closeted
with
the
old
harridan
shortly
before
she
died
;
and
that
she
could
,
as
he
had
reason
to
believe
,
throw
some
light
on
the
subject
of
his
inquiry
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
can
I
find
her
?
"
said
the
stranger
,
thrown
off
his
guard
;
and
plainly
showing
that
all
his
fears
(
whatever
they
were
)
were
aroused
afresh
by
the
intelligence
.
   
<EOS>
"
Only
through
me
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Bumble
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
?
"
cried
the
stranger
,
hastily
.
   
<EOS>
"
To
-
morrow
,
"
rejoined
Bumble
.
   
<EOS>
"
At
nine
in
the
evening
,
"
said
the
stranger
,
producing
a
scrap
of
paper
,
and
writing
down
upon
it
,
an
obscure
address
by
the
water
-
side
,
in
characters
that
betrayed
his
agitation
;
"
at
nine
in
the
evening
,
bring
her
to
me
there
.
 
<EOS>
I
need
n't
tell
you
to
be
secret
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
your
interest
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
these
words
,
he
led
the
way
to
the
door
,
after
stopping
to
pay
for
the
liquor
that
had
been
drunk
.
 
<EOS>
Shortly
remarking
that
their
roads
were
different
,
he
departed
,
without
more
ceremony
than
an
emphatic
repetition
of
the
hour
of
appointment
for
the
following
night
.
   
<EOS>
On
glancing
at
the
address
,
the
parochial
functionary
observed
that
it
contained
no
name
.
 
<EOS>
The
stranger
had
not
gone
far
,
so
he
made
after
him
to
ask
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
want
?
"
cried
the
man
.
<EOS>
turning
quickly
round
,
as
Bumble
touched
him
on
the
arm
.
 
<EOS>
"
Following
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Only
to
ask
a
question
,
"
said
the
other
,
pointing
to
the
scrap
of
paper
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
name
am
I
to
ask
for
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Monks
!
"
rejoined
the
man
;
and
strode
hastily
,
away
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
38
.
<EOS>
Containing
an
account
of
what
passed
between
Mr
and
Mrs
Bumble
,
and
Mr
Monks
,
at
their
nocturnal
interview
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
dull
,
close
,
overcast
summer
evening
.
 
<EOS>
The
clouds
,
which
had
been
threatening
all
day
,
spread
out
in
a
dense
and
sluggish
mass
of
vapour
,
already
yielded
large
drops
of
rain
,
and
seemed
to
presage
a
violent
thunder
-
storm
,
when
Mr
and
Mrs
Bumble
,
turning
out
of
the
main
street
of
the
town
,
directed
their
course
towards
a
scattered
little
colony
of
ruinous
houses
,
distant
from
it
<EOS>
some
mile
and
a
-
half
,
or
thereabouts
,
and
erected
on
a
low
unwholesome
swamp
,
bordering
upon
the
river
.
   
<EOS>
They
were
both
wrapped
in
old
and
shabby
outer
garments
,
which
might
,
perhaps
,
serve
the
double
purpose
of
protecting
their
persons
from
the
rain
,
and
sheltering
them
from
observation
.
 
<EOS>
The
husband
carried
a
lantern
,
from
which
,
however
,
no
light
yet
shone
;
and
trudged
on
,
a
few
paces
in
front
,
as
though
---
the
way
being
dirty
---
to
give
his
wife
the
benefit
of
treading
in
his
heavy
footprints
.
 
<EOS>
They
went
on
,
in
profound
silence
;
every
now
and
then
,
Mr
Bumble
relaxed
his
pace
,
and
turned
his
head
as
if
to
make
sure
that
his
helpmate
was
following
;
then
,
discovering
that
she
was
close
at
his
heels
,
he
mended
his
rate
of
walking
,
and
proceeded
,
at
a
considerable
increase
of
speed
,
towards
their
place
of
destination
.
   
<EOS>
This
was
far
from
being
a
place
of
doubtful
character
;
for
it
had
long
been
known
as
the
residence
of
none
but
low
ruffians
,
who
,
under
various
pretences
of
living
by
their
labour
,
subsisted
chiefly
on
plunder
and
crime
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
collection
of
mere
hovels
:
 
some
,
hastily
built
with
loose
bricks
:
others
,
of
old
worm
-
eaten
ship
-
timber
:
jumbled
together
without
any
attempt
at
order
or
arrangement
,
and
planted
,
for
the
most
part
,
within
a
few
feet
of
the
river
's
bank
.
 
<EOS>
A
few
leaky
boats
drawn
up
on
the
mud
,
and
made
fast
to
the
dwarf
wall
which
skirted
it
:
 
and
here
and
there
an
oar
or
coil
of
rope
:
 
appeared
,
at
first
,
to
indicate
that
the
inhabitants
of
these
miserable
cottages
pursued
some
avocation
on
the
river
;
but
a
glance
at
the
shattered
and
useless
condition
of
the
articles
thus
displayed
,
would
have
led
a
passer
-
by
,
without
much
difficulty
,
to
the
conjecture
that
they
were
disposed
there
,
rather
for
the
preservation
of
appearances
,
than
with
any
view
to
their
being
actually
employed
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
heart
of
this
cluster
of
huts
;
and
skirting
the
river
,
which
its
upper
stories
overhung
;
stood
a
large
building
,
formerly
used
as
a
manufactory
of
some
kind
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
,
in
its
day
,
probably
furnished
employment
to
the
inhabitants
of
the
surrounding
tenements
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
had
long
since
gone
to
ruin
.
 
<EOS>
The
rat
,
the
worm
,
and
the
action
of
the
damp
,
had
weakened
and
rotted
the
piles
on
which
it
stood
;
and
a
considerable
portion
of
the
building
had
already
sunk
down
into
the
water
;
while
the
remainder
,
tottering
and
bending
over
the
dark
stream
,
seemed
to
wait
a
favourable
opportunity
of
following
its
old
companion
,
and
involving
itself
in
the
same
fate
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
before
this
ruinous
building
that
the
worthy
couple
paused
,
as
the
first
peal
of
distant
thunder
reverberated
in
the
air
,
and
the
rain
commenced
pouring
violently
down
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
place
should
be
somewhere
here
,
"
said
Bumble
,
consulting
a
scrap
of
paper
he
held
in
his
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
Halloa
there
!
"
cried
a
voice
from
above
.
   
<EOS>
Following
the
sound
,
Mr
Bumble
raised
his
head
and
descried
a
man
looking
out
of
a
door
,
breast
-
high
,
on
the
second
story
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stand
still
,
a
minute
,
"
cried
the
voice
;
"
I
'll
be
with
you
directly
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
which
the
head
disappeared
,
and
the
door
closed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
that
the
man
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Mr
Bumble
's
good
lady
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
nodded
in
the
affirmative
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
,
mind
what
I
told
you
,
"
said
the
matron
:
"
and
be
careful
to
say
as
little
as
you
can
,
or
you
'll
betray
us
at
once
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
,
who
had
eyed
the
building
with
very
rueful
looks
,
was
apparently
about
to
express
some
doubts
relative
to
the
advisability
of
proceeding
any
further
with
the
enterprise
just
then
,
when
he
was
prevented
by
the
appearance
of
Monks
:
who
opened
a
small
door
,
near
which
they
stood
,
and
beckoned
them
inwards
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
in
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
impatiently
,
stamping
his
foot
upon
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
keep
me
here
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
woman
,
who
had
hesitated
at
first
,
walked
boldly
in
,
without
any
other
invitation
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
,
who
was
ashamed
or
afraid
to
lag
behind
,
followed
:
 
obviously
very
ill
at
ease
and
with
scarcely
any
of
that
remarkable
dignity
which
was
usually
his
chief
characteristic
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
the
devil
made
you
stand
lingering
there
,
in
the
wet
?
"
said
Monks
,
turning
round
,
and
addressing
Bumble
,
after
he
had
bolted
the
door
behind
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
---
we
were
only
cooling
ourselves
,
"
stammered
Bumble
,
looking
apprehensively
about
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Cooling
yourselves
!
"
<EOS>
retorted
Monks
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
all
the
rain
that
ever
fell
,
or
ever
will
fall
,
will
put
as
much
of
hell
's
fire
out
,
as
a
man
can
carry
about
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
You
wo
n't
cool
yourself
so
easily
;
do
n't
think
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
this
agreeable
speech
,
Monks
turned
short
upon
the
matron
,
and
bent
his
gaze
upon
her
,
till
even
she
,
who
was
not
easily
cowed
,
was
fain
to
withdraw
her
eyes
,
and
turn
them
them
towards
the
ground
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
the
woman
,
is
it
?
"
demanded
Monks
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hem
!
 
<EOS>
That
is
the
woman
,
"
replied
Mr
Bumble
,
mindful
of
his
wife
's
caution
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
think
women
never
can
keep
secrets
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
said
the
matron
,
interposing
,
and
returning
,
as
she
spoke
,
the
searching
look
of
Monks
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
they
will
always
keep
ONE
till
it
's
found
out
,
"
said
Monks
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
what
may
that
be
?
"
asked
the
matron
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
loss
of
their
own
good
name
,
"
replied
Monks
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
,
by
the
same
rule
,
if
a
woman
's
a
party
to
a
secret
that
might
hang
or
transport
her
,
I
'm
not
afraid
of
her
telling
it
to
anybody
;
not
I
!
 
<EOS>
Do
you
understand
,
mistress
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
rejoined
the
matron
,
slightly
colouring
as
she
spoke
.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
you
do
n't
!
"
said
Monks
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
should
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
Bestowing
something
half
-
way
between
a
smile
and
a
frown
upon
his
two
companions
,
and
again
beckoning
them
to
follow
him
,
the
man
hastened
across
the
apartment
,
which
was
of
considerable
extent
,
but
low
in
the
roof
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
preparing
to
ascend
a
steep
staircase
,
or
rather
ladder
,
leading
to
another
floor
of
warehouses
above
:
 
when
a
bright
flash
of
lightning
streamed
down
the
aperture
,
and
a
peal
of
thunder
followed
,
which
shook
the
crazy
building
to
its
centre
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hear
it
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
shrinking
back
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hear
it
!
 
<EOS>
Rolling
and
crashing
on
as
if
it
echoed
through
a
thousand
caverns
where
the
devils
were
hiding
from
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
hate
the
sound
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
remained
silent
for
a
few
moments
;
and
then
,
removing
his
hands
suddenly
from
his
face
,
showed
,
to
the
unspeakable
discomposure
of
Mr
Bumble
,
that
it
was
much
distorted
and
discoloured
.
   
<EOS>
"
These
fits
come
over
me
,
now
and
then
,
"
said
Monks
,
observing
his
alarm
;
"
and
thunder
sometimes
brings
them
on
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
mind
me
now
;
it
's
all
over
for
this
once
.
"
   
<EOS>
Thus
speaking
,
he
led
the
way
up
the
ladder
;
and
hastily
closing
the
window
-
shutter
of
the
room
into
which
it
led
,
lowered
a
lantern
which
hung
at
the
end
of
a
rope
and
pulley
passed
through
one
of
the
heavy
beams
in
the
ceiling
:
 
and
which
cast
a
dim
light
upon
an
old
table
and
three
chairs
that
were
placed
beneath
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
said
Monks
,
when
they
had
all
three
seated
themselves
,
"
the
sooner
we
come
to
our
business
,
the
better
for
all
.
 
<EOS>
The
woman
know
what
it
is
,
does
she
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
question
was
addressed
to
Bumble
;
but
his
wife
anticipated
the
reply
,
by
intimating
that
she
was
perfectly
acquainted
with
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
is
right
in
saying
that
you
were
with
this
hag
the
night
she
died
;
and
that
she
told
you
something
---
"
   
"
About
the
mother
of
the
boy
you
named
,
"
replied
the
matron
interrupting
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
first
question
is
,
of
what
nature
was
her
communication
?
"
said
Monks
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
second
,
"
observed
the
woman
with
much
deliberation
.
<EOS>
"
The
first
is
,
what
may
the
communication
be
worth
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Who
the
devil
can
tell
that
,
without
knowing
of
what
kind
it
is
?
"
asked
Monks
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nobody
better
than
you
<EOS>
,
I
am
persuaded
,
"
answered
Mrs
Bumble
:
who
did
not
want
for
spirit
,
as
her
yoke
-
fellow
could
abundantly
testify
.
   
<EOS>
"
Humph
!
"
said
Monks
significantly
,
and
with
a
look
of
eager
inquiry
;
"
there
may
be
money
's
worth
to
get
,
eh
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
there
may
,
"
was
the
composed
reply
.
   
<EOS>
"
Something
that
was
taken
from
her
,
"
said
Monks
.
 
<EOS>
"
Something
that
she
wore
.
 
<EOS>
Something
that
---
"
   
"
You
had
better
bid
,
"
interrupted
Mrs
Bumble
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
heard
enough
,
already
,
to
assure
me
that
you
are
the
man
I
ought
to
talk
to
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
,
who
had
not
yet
been
admitted
by
his
better
half
into
any
greater
share
of
the
secret
than
he
had
originally
possessed
,
listened
to
this
dialogue
with
outstretched
neck
and
distended
eyes
:
 
which
he
directed
towards
his
wife
and
Monks
,
by
turns
,
in
undisguised
astonishment
;
increased
,
if
possible
,
when
the
latter
sternly
demanded
,
what
sum
was
required
for
the
disclosure
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
it
worth
to
you
?
"
<EOS>
asked
the
woman
,
as
collectedly
as
before
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
may
be
nothing
;
it
may
be
twenty
pounds
,
"
replied
Monks
.
<EOS>
"
Speak
out
,
and
let
me
know
which
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Add
five
pounds
to
the
sum
you
have
named
;
give
me
five
-
and
-
twenty
pounds
in
gold
,
"
said
the
woman
;
"
and
I
'll
tell
you
all
I
know
.
 
<EOS>
Not
before
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Five
-
and
-
twenty
pounds
!
"
exclaimed
Monks
,
drawing
back
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
spoke
as
plainly
as
I
could
,
"
replied
Mrs
Bumble
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
a
large
sum
,
either
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a
large
sum
for
a
paltry
secret
,
that
may
be
nothing
when
it
's
told
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Monks
impatiently
;
"
and
which
has
been
lying
dead
for
twelve
years
past
or
more
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Such
matters
keep
well
,
and
,
like
good
wine
,
often
double
their
value
in
course
of
time
,
"
answered
the
matron
,
still
preserving
the
resolute
indifference
she
had
assumed
.
 
<EOS>
"
As
to
lying
dead
,
there
are
those
who
will
lie
dead
for
twelve
thousand
years
to
come
,
or
twelve
million
,
for
anything
you
or
<EOS>
I
know
,
who
will
tell
strange
tales
at
last
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
if
I
pay
it
for
nothing
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Monks
,
hesitating
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
can
easily
take
it
away
again
,
"
replied
the
matron
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
but
a
woman
;
alone
here
;
and
unprotected
.
"
   
"
Not
alone
,
my
dear
,
nor
unprotected
,
neither
,
"
submitted
Mr
Bumble
,
in
a
voice
tremulous
with
fear
:
"
\
I
\
am
here
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
And
besides
,
"
said
Mr
Bumble
,
his
teeth
chattering
as
he
spoke
,
"
<EOS>
Mr
Monks
is
too
much
of
a
gentleman
to
attempt
any
violence
on
porochial
persons
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Monks
is
aware
that
I
am
not
a
young
man
,
my
dear
,
and
also
that
I
am
a
little
run
to
seed
,
as
I
may
say
;
bu
he
has
heerd
:
 
I
say
I
have
no
doubt
Mr
Monks
has
heerd
,
my
dear
:
 
that
I
am
a
very
determined
officer
,
with
very
uncommon
strength
,
if
I
'm
once
roused
.
 
<EOS>
I
only
want
a
little
rousing
;
that
's
all
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
Mr
Bumble
spoke
,
he
made
a
melancholy
feint
of
grasping
his
lantern
with
fierce
determination
;
and
plainly
showed
,
by
the
alarmed
expression
of
every
feature
,
that
he
DID
want
a
little
rousing
,
and
not
a
little
,
prior
to
making
any
very
warlike
demonstration
:
unless
,
indeed
,
against
paupers
,
or
other
person
or
persons
trained
down
for
the
purpose
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
fool
,
"
said
Mrs
Bumble
,
in
reply
;
"
and
had
better
hold
your
tongue
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
had
better
have
cut
it
out
,
before
he
came
,
if
he
ca
n't
speak
in
a
lower
tone
,
"
said
Monks
,
grimly
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
!
 
<EOS>
He
's
your
husband
,
eh
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
my
husband
!
"
tittered
the
matron
,
parrying
the
question
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
thought
as
much
,
when
you
came
in
,
"
rejoined
Monks
,
marking
the
angry

which
the

darted
at

she

.
 
<EOS>
"
So
much
the
better
;
I
have
less
hesitation
in
dealing
with
two
people
,
when
I
find
that
there
's
only
one
will
between
them
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
in
earnest
.
 
<EOS>
See
here
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
thrust
his
hand
into
a
side

pocket
;
and
producing
a
canvas
bag
,
told
out
twenty
-
five
sovereigns
on
the
table
,
and
pushed
them
over
to
the
woman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
he
said
,
"
gather
them
up
;
and
when
this
cursed
peal
of
thunder
,
which
I
feel
is
coming
up
to
break
over
the
house
-
top
,
is
gone
,
let
's
hear
your
story
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
thunder
,
which
seemed
in
fact
much
nearer
,
and
to
shiver
and
break
almost
over
their
heads
,
having
subsided
,
Monks
,
raising
his
face
from
the
table
,
bent
forward
to
listen
to
what
the
woman
should
say
.
 
<EOS>
The
faces
of
the
three
nearly
touched
,
as
the
two
men
leant
over
the
small
table
in
their
eagerness
to
hear
,
and
the
woman
also
leant
forward
to
render
her
whisper
audible
.
 
<EOS>
The
sickly
rays
of
the
suspended
lantern
falling
directly
upon
them
,
aggravated
the
paleness
and
anxiety
of
their
countenances
:
which
,
encircled
by
the
deepest
gloom
and
darkness
,
looked
ghastly
in
the
extreme
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
this
woman
,
that
we
called
old
Sally
,
died
,
"
the
matron
began
,
"
she
and
I
were
alone
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Was
there
no
one
by
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Monks
,
in
the
same
hollow

;
"
No
sick
wretch
or
idiot
in
some
other
bed
?
 
<EOS>
No
one
who
could
hear
,
and
might
,
by
possibility
,
understand
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a
soul
,
"
replied
the
woman
;
"
we
were
alone
.
 
<EOS>
\
<EOS>
I
\
stood
alone
beside
the
body
when
death
came
over
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
,
"
said
Monks
,
regarding
her
attentively
.
 
<EOS>
"
Go
on
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
spoke
of
a
young
creature
,
"
resumed
the
matron
,
"
who
had
brought
a
child
into
the
world
some
years
before
;
not
merely
in
the
same
room
,
but
in
the
same
bed
,
in
which
she
then
lay
dying
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ay
?
<EOS>
"
said
Monks
,
with
quivering

,
and

over
his

,
"
Blood
!
 
<EOS>
How
things
come
about
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
child
was
the
one
you
named
to
him
last
night
,
"
said
the
matron
,
nodding

;
"
the
mother
this
nurse
had
robbed
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In
life
?
"
asked
Monks
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In
death
,
"
replied
the
woman
,
with
something
like

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
She
stole
from
the
corpse
,
when
it

hardly

one
,
that
which
the
dead

had
prayed
her
,

,
to
keep
for
the
infant
's

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
sold
it
,
"
cried
Monks
,
with
desperate

;
"
did
she
sell
it
?
 
<EOS>
Where
?
 
<EOS>
When
?
 
<EOS>
To
whom
?
 
<EOS>
How
long
before
?
"
   
"
As
she
told
me
,
with
great

,
that
she
had
done
this
,
"
said
the
matron
,
"
she
fell
back
and
died
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Without
saying
more
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Monks
,
in
a

which
,

,
seemed
only
the
more

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
lie
!
<EOS>
I
'll
not
be
played
with
.
 
<EOS>
She
said
more
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
tear
the
life
out
of
you
both
,
but
I
'll
know
what
it
was
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
did
n't
utter
another
word
,
"
said
the
woman
,
to
all
appearance
unmoved
(
as
Mr
Bumble
was
very
far

)
by
the
strange
man
's
violence
;
"
but
she
clutched
my
gown
,
violently
,
with
one
hand
,
which
was
partly
closed
;
and
when
I
saw
that
she
was
dead
,
and
so
removed
the
hand
by
force
<EOS>
,
I
found
it
clasped
a
scrap
of
dirty
paper
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Which
contained
---
"
interposed
Monks
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
"
replied
the
woman
;
"
it
was
a
pawnbroker
's
duplicate
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
For
what
?
"
demanded
Monks
.
   
<EOS>
"
In
good
time
I
'll
tell
you
.
"
said
the
woman
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
judge
that
she
had
kept
the
trinket
,
for
some
time
,
in
the
hope
of
turning
it
to
better
account
;
and
then
had
pawned
it
;
and
had
saved
or

together
money
to
pay
the
pawnbroker
's
interest
year
by
year
,
and
prevent
its
running
out
;
so
that
if
anything
came
of

,
it
could
still

.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
had
come
of
it
;
and
,
as
I
tell

,
she
died
with

,

,
in

.
 
<EOS>
The
time
was
out
in
two
days
;
I
thought
something
might
one
day
come
of
it
too
;
and
so
redeemed
the
pledge
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Where
is

now
?
"
asked

quickly
.
   
<EOS>
"
THERE
,
"
replied
the
woman
.
 
<EOS>
And
,
as
if

to
be
relieved
of
it
,
she
hastily
threw
upon
the
table
a
small
kid
bag
scarcely
large
enough
for
a
French
watch
,
which
Monks
pouncing

,
tore

with

.
 
<EOS>
It
contained
a
little
gold
locket
:
in
which
were
two
locks

,
and
a
plain

-

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
has
the

"
Agnes
"
engraved
on

,
"
said

woman
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
a
blank
left
for

;
and
then
follows
the
date
;
which
is
within
a
year
before
the
child
was
born
.
 
<EOS>
I
found
out
that
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
this
is
all
?
"
said
Monks
,
after

of

little

.
   
<EOS>
"
All
,
"
replied
the
woman
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
drew
a
long
breath
,
as
if
he
were
glad
to
find
that
the
story
was
over
,
and
no
mention
made
of
taking
the
five
-
and
-
twenty
pounds
back
again
;
and
now
he
took
courage
to
wipe
the
perspiration
which
had
been
trickling
over
his
nose
,
unchecked
,
during
the
whole
of
the
previous

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
nothing
of
the
story
,
beyond
what
I
can
guess
at
,
"
said
his
wife
addressing
Monks
,
after
a
short

;
"
and
I
want
to
know
nothing
;
for
it
's
safer
<EOS>
not
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
may
ask
you
two
questions
,
<EOS>
may
I
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
may
ask
,
"
said
Monks
,
with
some
show
of
surprise
;
"
but
whether
I
answer
or
not
is
another
question
.
"
   
"
---
Which
makes
three
,
"
observed
Mr
Bumble
,
essaying
a
stroke
of
facetiousness
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
that
what
you
expected
to
get
from
me
?
"
demanded
the
matron
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
,
"
replied
Monks
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
other
question
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
propose
to
do
with
it
?
 
<EOS>
Can
it
be
used
against
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Never
,
"
rejoined
Monks
;
"
nor
against
me
either
.
 
<EOS>
See
here
!
 
<EOS>
But
do
n't
move
a
step
forward
,
or
your
life
is
not
worth
a
bulrush
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
these
words
,
he
suddenly
wheeled
the
table
aside
,
and
pulling
an
iron
ring
in
the
boarding
,
threw
back
a
large
trap
-
door
which
opened
close
at
Mr
Bumble
's
feet
,
and
caused
that
gentleman
to
retire
several
paces
backward
,
with
great
precipitation
.
   
<EOS>
"
Look
down
,
"
said
Monks
,
lowering
the
lantern
into
the
gulf
.
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
fear
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
have
let
you
down
,
quietly
enough
,
when
you
were
seated
over
it
,
if
that
had
been
my
game
.
"
   
<EOS>
Thus
encouraged
,
the
matron
drew
near
to
the
brink
;
and
even
Mr
Bumble
himself
,
impelled
by
curiousity
,
ventured
to
do
the
same
.
<EOS>
The
turbid
water
,
swollen
by
the
heavy
rain
,
was
rushing
rapidly
on
below
;
and
all
other
sounds
were
lost
in
the
noise
of
its
plashing
and
eddying
against
the
green
and
slimy
piles
.
 
<EOS>
There
had
once
been
a
water
-
mill
beneath
;
the
tide
foaming
and
chafing
round
the
few
rotten
stakes
,
and
fragments
of
machinery
that
yet
remained
,
seemed
to
dart
onward
,
with
a
new
impulse
,
when
freed
from
the
obstacles
which
had
unavailingly
attempted
to
stem
its
headlong
course
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
flung
a
man
's
body
down
there
,
where
would
it
be
to
-
morrow
morning
?
"
said
Monks
,
swinging
the
lantern
to
and
fro
in
the
dark
well
.
   
<EOS>
"
Twelve
miles
down
the
river
,
and
cut
to
pieces
besides
,
"
replied
Bumble
,
recoiling
at
the
thought
.
   
<EOS>
Monks
drew
the
little
packet
from
his
breast
,
where
he
had
hurriedly
thrust
it
;
and
tying
it
to
a
leaden
weight
,
which
had
formed
a
part
of
some
pulley
,
and
was
lying
on
the
floor
,
dropped
it
into
the
stream
.
 
<EOS>
It
fell
straight
,
and
true
as
a
die
;
clove
the
water
with
a
scarcely
audible
splash
;
and
was
gone
.
   
<EOS>
The
three
looking
into
each
other
's
faces
,
seemed
to
breathe
more
freely
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
!
"
said
Monks
,
closing
the
trap
-
door
,
which
fell
heavily
back
into
its
former
position
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
the
sea
ever
gives
up
its
dead
,
as
books
say
it
will
,
it
will
keep
its
gold
and
silver
to
itself
,
and
that
trash
among
it
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
nothing
more
to
say
,
and
may
break
up
our
pleasant
party
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
By
all
means
,
"
observed
Mr
Bumble
,
with
great
alacrity
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
'll
keep
a
quiet
tongue
in
your
head
,
will
you
?
"
said
Monks
,
with
a
threatening
look
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
afraid
of
your
wife
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
may
depend
upon
me
,
young
man
,
"
answered
Mr
Bumble
,
bowing
himself
gradually
towards
the
ladder
,
with
excessive
politeness
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
On
everybody
's
account
,
young
man
;
on
my
own
,
you
know
,
Mr
Monks
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
,
for
your
sake
,
to
hear
it
,
"
remarked
Monks
.
<EOS>
"
Light
your
lantern
!
 
<EOS>
And
get
away
from
here
as
fast
as
you
can
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
fortunate
that
the
conversation
terminated
at
this
point
,
or
Mr
Bumble
,
who
had
bowed
himself
to
within
six
inches
of
the
ladder
,
would
infallibly
have
pitched
headlong
into
the
room
below
.
 
<EOS>
He
lighted
his
lantern
from
that
which
Monks
had
detached
from
the
rope
,
and
now
carried
in
his
hand
;
and
making
no
effort
to
prolong
the
discourse
,
descended
in
silence
,
followed
by
his
wife
.
 
<EOS>
Monks
brought
up
the
rear
,
after
pausing
on
the
steps
to
satisfy
himself
that
there
were
no
other
sounds
to
be
heard
than
the
beating
of
the
rain
without
,
and
the
rushing
of
the
water
.
   
<EOS>
They
traversed
the
lower
room
,
slowly
,
and
with
caution
;
for
Monks
started
at
every
shadow
;
and
Mr
Bumble
,
holding
his
lantern
a
foot
above
the
ground
,
walked
not
only
with
remarkable
care
,
but
with
a
marvellously
light
step
for
a
gentleman
of
his
figure
:
 
looking
nervously
about
him
for
hidden
trap
-
doors
.
 
<EOS>
The
gate
at
which
they
had
entered
,
was
softly
unfastened
and
opened
by
Monks
;
merely
exchanging
a
nod
with
their
mysterious
acquaintance
,
the
married
couple
emerged
into
the
wet
and
darkness
outside
.
   
<EOS>
They
were
no
sooner
gone
,
than
Monks
,
who
appeared
to
entertain
an
invincible
repugnance
to
being
left
alone
,
<EOS>
called
to
a
boy
who
had
been
hidden
somewhere
below
.
<EOS>
Bidding
him
go
first
,
and
bear
the
light
,
he
returned
to
the
chamber
he
had
just
quitted
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
39
.
<EOS>
Introduces
some
respectable
characters
with
whom
the
reader
is
already
acquainted
,
and
shows
how
Monks
and
the
Jew
laid
their
worthy
heads
together
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
evening
following
that
upon
which
the
three
worthies
mentioned
in
the
last
chapter
,
disposed
of
their
little
matter
of
business
as
therein
narrated
,
Mr
William
Sikes
,
awakening
from
a
nap
,
drowsily
growled
forth
an
inquiry
what
time
of
night
it
was
.
   
<EOS>
The
room
in
which
Mr
Sikes
propounded
this
question
,
was
not
one
of
those
he
had
tenanted
,
previous
to
the
Chertsey
expedition
,
although
it
was
in
the
same
quarter
of
the
town
,
and
was
situated
at
no
great
distance
from
his
former
lodgings
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
,
in
appearance
,
so
desirable
a
habitation
as
his
old
quarters
:
 
<EOS>
being
a
mean
and
badly
-
furnished
apartment
,
of
very
limited
size
;
lighted
only
by
one
small
window
in
the
shelving
roof
,
and
abutting
on
a
close
and
dirty
lane
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
were
there
wanting
other
indications
of
the
good
gentleman
's
having
gone
down
in
the
world
of
late
:
 
for
a
great
scarcity
of
furniture
,
and
total
absence
of
comfort
,
together
with
the
disappearance
of
all
such
small
moveables
as
spare
clothes
and
linen
,
bespoke
a
state
of
extreme
poverty
;
while
the
meagre
and
attenuated
condition
of
Mr
Sikes
himself
would
have
fully
confirmed
these
symptoms
,
if
they
had
stood
in
any
need
of
corroboration
.
   
<EOS>
The
housebreaker
was
lying
on
the
bed
,
wrapped
in
his
white
great
-
coat
,
by
way
of
dressing
-
gown
,
and
displaying
a
set
of
features
in
no
degree
improved
by
the
cadaverous
hue
of
illness
,
and
the
addition
of
a
soiled
nightcap
,
and
a
stiff
,
black
beard
of
a
week
's
growth
.
 
<EOS>
The
dog
sat
at
the
bedside
:
 
now
eyeing
his
master
with
a
wistful
look
,
and
now
pricking
his
ears
,
and
uttering
a
low
growl
as
some
noise
in
the
street
,
or
in
the
lower
part
of
the
house
,
attracted
his
attention
.
 
<EOS>
Seated
by
the
window
,
busily
engaged
in
patching
an
old
waistcoat
which
formed
a
portion
of
the
robber
's
ordinary
dress
,
was
a
female
:
 
so
pale
and
reduced
with
watching
and
privation
,
that
there
would
have
been
considerable
difficulty
in
recognising
her
as
the
same
Nancy
who
has
already
figured
in
this
tale
,
but
for
the
voice
in
which
she
replied
to
Mr
Sikes
's
question
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
long
gone
seven
,
"
said
the
girl
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
feel
to
-
night
,
Bill
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
As
weak
as
water
,
"
replied
Mr
Sikes
,
with
an
imprecation
on
his
eyes
and

.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
;
lend
us
a
hand
,
and
let
me
get
off
this
thundering
bed
anyhow
.
"
   
<EOS>
Illness
had
not
improved
Mr
Sikes
's
temper
;
for
,
as
the
girl
raised
him
up
and
led
him
to
a
chair
,
he
muttered
various

on
her
awkwardnewss
,
and
struck
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Whining
are
you
?
"
said
Sikes
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
!
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
stand
snivelling
there
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
ca
n't
do
anything
better
than
that
,
cut
off
altogether
.
 
<EOS>
D'ye
hear
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hear
you
,
"
replied
the
girl
,
turning
her
face
aside
,
and
forcing
a

.
 
<EOS>
"
What
fancy
have
you
got
in
your

now
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
you
've
thought
better
of
it
,
have
you
?
"
<EOS>
growled
Sikes
,
marking
the
tear
which
trembled
in

.
 
<EOS>
"
All
the
better
for
you
,
you
have
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
do
n't
mean
to
say
,
you
'd

hard
upon
me
to
-
night
,
Bill
,
"
said
the
girl
,
laying
her
hand
upon

.
   
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
cried
Mr
Sikes
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
not
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Such
a
number
of
nights
,
"
said
the
girl
,
with
a
touch
of
woman
's
tenderness
,
which
communicated
something
like

of
tone
,
even
to

:
"
such
a
number

nights
as
I
've
been
patient

,
nursing

for

,
as

had
been

child
:
and
this
the
first

I
've
seen

like

;
you
would

have
served
me
as
you
did
just

,

'd
thought

,
would
you
?
 
<EOS>
Come
,
come
;
say

would
n't
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,

,
"
rejoined

,
"
I

n't
.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
damme
,
now
,
the
girls
's
whining
again
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
nothing
,
"
said
the
girl
,
throwing
herself
into
a
chair
.
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
seem
to
mind
me
.
 
<EOS>
It
'll
soon
be
over
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
'll
be
over
?
"
demanded
Mr
Sikes
in
a
savage
voice
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
foolery
are
you
up
to
,
now
,
again
?
 
<EOS>
Get
up
and
bustle
about
,
and
do
n't
come
over
me
with
your
woman
's
nonsense
.
"
   
<EOS>
At
any
other
time
,
this
remonstrance
,
and
the
tone
in
which
it
was
delivered
,
would
have
had
the
desired
effect
;
but
the
girl
being
really
weak
and
exhausted
,
dropped
her
head
over
the
back
of
the
chair
,
and
fainted
,
before
Mr
Sikes
could
get
out
a
few
of
the
appropriate
oaths
with
which
,
on
similar

,
he
was
accustomed
to
garnish
his

.
 
<EOS>
Not
knowing
,
very
well
,
what
to
do
,
in
this
uncommon
emergency
;
for
Miss
Nancy
's
hysterics
were
usually
of
that
violent
kind
which
the
patient
fights
and
struggles
out
of
,
without
much
assistance
;
Mr
Sikes
tried
a
little
blasphemy
:
and
finding
that
mode
of
treatment
wholly
ineffectual
,
called
for
assistance
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
here
,
my
dear
?
"
said
Fagin
,
looking
in
.
   
<EOS>
"
Lend
a
hand
to
the
girl
,
ca
n't
you
?
"
<EOS>
replied
Sikes
impatiently
.
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
stand
chattering
and
grinning
at
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
an
exclamation
of
surprise
,
Fagin
hastened
to
the
girl
's
assistance
,
while
Mr
John
Dawkins
(
otherwise
the
Artful
Dodger
)
,
who
had
followed
his
venerable
friend
into
the
room
,
hastily
deposited
on
the
floor
a
bundle
with
which
he
was
laden
;
and
snatching
a
bottle
from
the
grasp
of
Master
Charles
Bates
who
came
close
at
his
heels
,
uncorked
it
in
a
twinkling
with
his
teeth
,
and
poured
a
portion
of
its
contents
down
the
patient
's
throat
:
 
previously
taking
a
taste
,
himself
,
to
prevent
mistakes
.
   
<EOS>
"
Give
her
a
whiff
of
fresh
air
with
the
bellows
,
Charley
,
"
said
Mr
Dawkins
;
"
and
you
slap
her
hands
,
Fagin
,
while
Bill
undoes
the
petticuts
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
These
united
restoratives
,
administered
with
great
energy
:
especially
that
department
consigned
to
Master
Bates
,
who
appeared
to
consider
his
share
in
the
proceedings
,
a
piece
of
unexampled
pleasantry
:
 
were
not
long
in
producing
the
desired
effect
.
 
<EOS>
The
girl
gradually
recovered
her
senses
;
and
,
staggering
to
a
chair
by
the
bedside
,
hid
her
face
upon

:
 
leaving
Mr
Sikes
to
confront
the
new

,
in
some

at
their
unlooked
-
for

.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
evil
wind
has
blowed
you
here
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
Fagin
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
evil
wind
at
all
,
my
dear
,
for
evil
winds
blow
nobody
any
good
;
and
I
've
brought
something
good
with
me
,
that
you
'll
be
glad
to
see
.
 
<EOS>
Dodger
,
my
dear
,
open
the
bundle
;
and
give
Bill
the
little
trifles
that
we
spent
all
our
money
on
,
this
morning
.
"
   
<EOS>
In
compliance
with
Mr
Fagin
's
request
,
the
Artful
untied
this

,
which
was
of
large

,
and
formed
of
an
old

-

;
and

it

,
one

,
to
Charley
Bates
:
who
placed

on
the

,
with
various

on
their
rarity

.
   
<EOS>
"
Sitch
a
rabbit
pie
,
Bill
,
"
exclaimed

,
disclosing

;
"
sitch
delicate
creeturs
,
with
sitch

,
Bill
,
that
the
wery
bones
melt
in

,
and
there
's
no

to
pick
'em
;
half

seven

,
<EOS>
so

strong
that

,

blow

tea
-

;
a

that

,
afore

sitch

,
---
<EOS>
oh

!
 
<EOS>
Two

-

;
pound

fresh
;

Glo'ster
;
and
,

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
Uttering

,

produced
,

,

,

;

,

from

:
 
which

down

's

.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
"
said
Fagin
,
rubbing

.
<EOS>
"
You
'll

,
Bill
;
you

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
!
"
<EOS>

;
"
I
might

done

,

,

'd

.
 
<EOS>
What

,

,

<EOS>
"
Only

!

"
<EOS>
And
us

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The

,
"

a

,

,

,

'

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

"

,

"

<EOS>
He

"

stage
that

,

<EOS>
"
Hold

din
,
"

,

dog

:
   
still

.
 
<EOS>
"
What

,

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
away

London
,
a

,

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
And

?
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
What

other

you

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
could
n't

,
Bill
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca

into

long

before
company
;
but
I
could
n't
help
it
,
upon
my

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Upon
your
what
?
"
growled
Sikes
,
with

.
"
<EOS>
Here
!
<EOS>
Cut

off
a

,

,
to

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do

be

,

,
"
urged
Fagin
,
submissively
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
never
forgot
you
,
Bill
;
never
once
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
!
 
<EOS>
I
'll
pound
it
that
you
han't
,
"
replied
Sikes
,
with
a
bitter
grin
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
've
been
scheming
and
plotting
away
,
every
hour
that
I
have
laid
shivering
and
burning
here
;
and
Bill
was
to
do
this
;
and
Bill
was
to
do
that
;
and
Bill
was
to
do
it
all
,
<EOS>
dirt
cheap
,
as
soon
as
he
got
well
:
and
was
quite
poor
enough
for
your
work
.
<EOS>
If
it
had
n't
been
for
the
girl
,
I
might
have
died
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
now
,
Bill
,
"
remonstrated
Fagin
,
eagerly
catching
at
the
word
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
it
had
n't
been
for
the
girl
!
 
<EOS>
Who
but
poor
<EOS>
ould
<EOS>
Fagin
was
the
means
of
your
having
such
a
handy
girl
about
you
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
says
true
enough
there
!
"
<EOS>
said
Nancy
,
coming
hastily
forward
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Let
him
be
;
let
him
be
.
"
   
<EOS>
Nancy
's
appearance
gave
a
new
turn
to
the
conversation
;
for
the
boys
,
receiving
a
sly
wink
from
the
wary
old
Jew
,
began
to
ply
her
with
liquor
:
of
which
,
however
,
she
took
very
sparingly
;
while
Fagin
,
assuming
an
unusual
flow
of
spirits
,
gradually
brought
Mr
Sikes
into
a
better
temper
,
by
affecting
to
regard
his
threats
as
a
little
pleasant
banter
;
and
,
moreover
,
by
laughing
very
heartily
at
one
or
two
rough
jokes
,
which
,
after
repeated
applications
to
the
spirit
-
bottle
,
he
condescended
to
make
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
very
well
,
"
said
Mr
Sikes
;
"
but
I
must
have
some
blunt
from
you
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
n't
a
piece
of
coin
about
me
,
"
replied
the
Jew
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
you
've
got
lots
at
home
,
"
retorted
Sikes
;
"
and
I
must
have
some
from
there
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Lots
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Fagin
,
holding
up
is
hands
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
n't
so
much
as
would
---
"
   
"
I
do
n't
know
how
much
you
've
got
,
and
I
dare
say
you
hardly
know
yourself
,
as
it
would
take
a
pretty
long
time
to
count
it
,
"
said
Sikes
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
must
have
some
to
-
night
;
and
that
's
flat
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
"
said
Fagin
,
with
a
sigh
,
"
I
'll
send
the
Artful
round
presently
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
wo
n't
do
nothing
of
the
kind
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Sikes
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
Artful
's
a
deal
too
artful
,
and
would
forget
to
come
,
or
lose
his
way
,
or
get
dodged
by
traps
and
so
be
perwented
,
or
anything
for
an
excuse
,
if
you
put
him
up
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
Nancy
shall
go
to
the
ken
and
fetch
it
,
to
make
all
sure
;
and
I
'll
lie
down
and
have
a
snooze
while
she
's
gone
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
After
a
great
deal
of
haggling
and
squabbling
,
Fagin
beat
down
the
amount
of
the
required
advance
from
five
pounds
to
three
pounds
four
and
sixpence
:
protesting
with
many
solemn
asseverations
that
that
would
only
leave
him
eighteen
-
pence
to
keep
house
with
;
Mr
Sikes
sullenly
remarking
that
if
he
could
n't
get
any
more
he
must
accompany
him
home
;
with
the
Dodger
and
Master
Bates
put
the
eatables
in
the
cupboard
.
 
<EOS>
The
Jew
then
,
taking
leave
of
his
affectionate
friend
,
returned
homeward
,
attended
by
Nancy
and
the
boys
:
 
<EOS>
Mr
Sikes
,
meanwhile
,
flinging
himself
on
the
bed
,
and
composing
himself
to
sleep
away
the
time
until
the
young
lady
's
return
.
   
<EOS>
In
due
course
,
they
arrived
at
Fagin
's
abode
,
where
they
found
Toby
Crackit
and
Mr
Chitling
intent
upon
their
fifteenth
game
at
cribbage
,
which
it
is
scarcely
necessary
to
say
the
latter
gentleman
lost
,
and
with
it
,
his
fifteenth
and
last
sixpence
:
much
to
the
amusement
of
his
young
friends
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Crackit
,
apparently
somewhat
ashamed
at
being
found
relaxing
himself
with
a
gentleman
so
much
<EOS>
his
inferior
in
station
and
mental
endowments
,
yawned
,
and
inquiring
after
Sikes
,
took
up
his
hat
to
go
.
   
<EOS>
"
Has
nobody
been
,
Toby
?
"
asked
Fagin
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a
living
leg
,
"
answered
Mr
Crackit
,
pulling
up
his
collar
;
"
it
's
been
as
dull
as
swipes
.
 
<EOS>
You
ought
to
stand
something
handsome
,
Fagin
,
to
recompense
me
for
keeping
house
so
long
.
<EOS>
Damme
,
I
'm
as
flat
as
a
juryman
;
and
should
have
gone
to
sleep
,
as
fast
as
Newgate
,
if
I
had
n't
had
the
good
natur
"
to
amuse
this
youngster
.
 
<EOS>
Horrid
dull
,
I
'm
blessed
if
I
an't
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
these
and
other
ejaculations
of
the
same
kind
,
Mr
Toby
Crackit
swept
up
his
winnings
,
and
crammed
them
into
his
waistcoat
pocket
with
a
haughty
air
,
as
though
such
small
pieces
of
silver
were
wholly
beneath
the
consideration
of
a
man
of
his
figure
;
this
done
,
he
swaggered
out
of
the
room
,
with
so
much
elegance
and
gentility
,
that
Mr
Chitling
,
bestowing
numerous
admiring

on
his
legs
and
boots
till
they
were
out
of
sight
,
assured
the
company
that
he
considered
his
acquaintance
cheap
at
fifteen
sixpences
an
interview
,
and
that
he
did
n't
value
his
losses
the
snap
of
his
little
finger
.
   
<EOS>
"
Wot
a
rum
chap
you
are
,
Tom
!
"
said
Master
Bates
,
highly
amused
by
this
declaration
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a
bit
of
it
,
"
replied
Mr
Chitling
.
 
<EOS>
"
Am
I
,
Fagin
?
"
   
"
A
very
clever
fellow
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Fagin
,
patting
him
on
the
shoulder
,
and
winking
to

other

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
Mr
Crackit
is
a
heavy
swell
;
an't
he
,
Fagin
?
"
asked
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
doubt
at
all
of
that
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
it
is
a
creditable
thing
to
have
his
acquaintance
;
an't
it
,
Fagin
?
<EOS>
"
pursued
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Very
much
so
,
indeed
,
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
They
're
only
jealous
,
Tom
,
because
he
wo
n't
give
it
to
them
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Tom
,
triumphantly
,
"
that
's
where
it
is
!
 
<EOS>
He
has
cleaned
me
out
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
can
go
and
earn
some
more
,
when
I
like
;
ca
n't
I
,
Fagin
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
you
can
,
and
the
sooner
you
go
the
better
,
Tom
;
so
make

at

,
and
do
n't

any
more

.
 
<EOS>
Dodger
!
   
Charley
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
time
you
were
on
the
lay
.
 
<EOS>
Come
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
near
ten
,
and
nothing
done
yet
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
In
obedience
to
this
hint
,
the
boys
,
nodding
to
Nancy
,
took
up
their
hats
,
and
left
the
room
;
the
Dodger
and
his
vivacious
friend
indulging
,
as
they
went
,
in
many

at
the
expense
of
Mr
Chitling
;
in
whose
conduct
,
it
is
but
justice
to
say
,
there
was
nothing
very
conspicuous
or
peculiar
:
 
inasmuch
as
there
are
a
great
number
of
spirited
young
bloods
upon
town
,
who
pay
a
much
higher
price
than
Mr
Chitling
for
being
seen
in
good
society
:
 
and
a
great
number
of
fine
gentlemen
(
composing
the
good
society
aforesaid
)
who
established
their
reputation
upon
very
much
the
same
footing
as
flash
Toby
Crackit
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
said
Fagin
,
when
they
had
left
the
room
,
"
I
'll
go
and
get
you
that
cash
,
Nancy
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
only
the
key
of
a
little
cupboard
where
I
keep
a
few
odd
things
the
boys
get
,
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
lock
up
my
money
,
for
I
've
got
none
to
lock
up
,
<EOS>
my
dear
---
ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
---
none
to
lock
up
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
poor
trade
,
Nancy
,
and
no
thanks
;
but
I
'm
fond
of
seeing
the
young
people
about
me
;
and
I
bear
it
all
<EOS>
,
I
bear
it
all
.
 
<EOS>
Hush
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
hastily
concealing
the
key
in
his
breast
;
"
who
's
that
?
 
<EOS>
Listen
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
girl
,
who
was
sitting
at
the
table
with
her
arms
folded
,
appeared
in
no
way
interested
in
the
arrival
:
or
to
care
whether
the
person
,
whoever
he
was
,
came
or
went
:
 
until
the
murmur
of
a
man
's
voice
reached
her
ears
.
 
<EOS>
The
instant
<EOS>
she
caught
the
sound
,
she
tore
off
her
bonnet
and
shawl
,
with
the
rapidity
of
lightning
,
and
thrust
them
under
the
table
.
<EOS>
The
Jew
,
turning
round
immediately
afterwards
,
she
muttered
a
complaint
of
the
heat
:
 
in
a
tone
of
languor
that
contrasted
,
very
remarkably
,
with
the
extreme
haste
and
violence
of
this
action
:
 
which
,
however
,
had
been
unobserved
by
Fagin
,
who
had
his
back
towards
her
at
the
time
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bah
!
"
<EOS>
he
whispered
,
as
though
nettled
by
the
interruption
;
"
it
's
the
man
I
expected
before
;
he
's
coming
downstairs
.
 
<EOS>
Not
a
word
about
the
money
while
he
's
here
,
Nance
.
 
<EOS>
He
wo
n't
stop
long
.
 
<EOS>
Not
ten
minutes
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Laying
his
skinny
forefinger
upon
his
lip
,
the
Jew
carried
a
candle
to
the
door
,
as
a
man
's
step
was
heard
upon
the
stairs
without
.
 
<EOS>
He
reached
it
,
at
the
same
moment
as
the
visitor
,
who
,
coming
hastily
into
the
room
,
was
close
upon
the
girl
before
he
observed
her
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
Monks
.
   
<EOS>
"
Only
one
of
my
young
people
,
"
said
Fagin
,
observing
that
Monks
drew
back
,
on
beholding
a
stranger
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
move
,
Nancy
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
girl
drew
closer
to
the
table
,
and
glancing
at
Monks
with
an
air
of
careless
levity
,
withdrew
her
eyes
;
but
as
he
turned
towards
Fagin
,
she
stole
another
look
;
so
keen
and
searching
,
and
full
of
purpose
,
that
if
there
had
been
any
bystander
to
observe
the
change
,
he
could
hardly
have
believed
the
two
looks
to
have
proceeded
from
the
same
person
.
   
<EOS>
"
Any
news
?
"
inquired
Fagin
.
   
<EOS>
"
Great
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
---
and
---
good
?
"
asked
Fagin
,
hesitating
as
though
he
feared
to
vex
the
other
man
by
being
too
sanguine
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
bad
,
any
way
,
"
replied
Monks
with
a
smile
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
prompt
enough
this
time
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
have
a
word
with
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
girl
drew
closer
to
the
table
,
and
made
no
offer
to
leave
the
room
,
although
she
could
see
that
Monks
was
pointing
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
The
Jew
:
 
perhaps
fearing
she
might
say
something
aloud
about
the
money
,
if
he
endeavoured
to
get
rid
of
her
:
 
pointed
upward
,
and
took
Monks
out
of
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
that
infernal
hole
we
were
in
before
,
"
she
could
hear
the
man
say
as
they
went
upstairs
.
 
<EOS>
Fagin
laughed
;
and
making
some
reply
which
did
not
reach
her
,
seemed
,
by
the
creaking
of
the
boards
,
to
lead
his
companion
to
the
second
story
.
   
<EOS>
Before
the
sound
of
their
footsteps
had
ceased
to
echo
through
the
house
,
the
girl
had
slipped
off
her
shoes
;
and
drawing
her
gown
loosely
over
her
head
,
and
muffling
her
arms
in
it
,
stood
at
the
door
,
listening
with
breathless
interest
.
 
<EOS>
The
moment
the
noise
ceased
,
she
glided
from
the
room
;
ascended
the
stairs
with
incredible
softness
and
silence
;
and
was
lost
in
the
gloom
above
.
   
<EOS>
The
room
remained
deserted
for
a
quarter
of
an
hour
or
more
;
the
girl
glided
back
with
the
same
unearthly
tread
;
and
,
immediately
afterwards
,
the
two
men
were
heard
descending
.
 
<EOS>
Monks
went
at
once
into
the
street
;
and
the
Jew
crawled
upstairs
again
for
the
money
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
returned
,
the
girl
was
adjusting
her
shawl
and
bonnet
,
as
if
preparing
to
be
gone
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Nance
!
,
"
exclaimed
the
Jew
,
starting
back
as
he
put
down
the
candle
,
"
how
pale
you
are
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pale
!
"
echoed
the
girl
,
shading
her
eyes
with
her
hands
,
as
if
to
look
steadily
at
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Quite
horrible
.
 
<EOS>
What
have
you
been
doing
to
yourself
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
that
I
know
of
,
except
sitting
in
this
close
place
for
I
do
n't
know
how
long
and
all
,
"
replied
the
girl
carelessly
.
<EOS>
"
Come
!
 
<EOS>
Let
me
get
back
;
that
's
a
dear
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
a
sigh
for
every
piece
of
money
,
Fagin
told
the
amount
into
her
hand
.
 
<EOS>
They
parted
without
more
conversation
,
merely
interchanging
a
"
good
-
night
.
"
   
<EOS>
When
the
girl
got
into
the
open
street
,
she
sat
down
upon
a
doorstep
;
and
seemed
,
for
a
few
moments
,
wholly
bewildered
and
unable
to
pursue
her
way
.
 
<EOS>
Suddenly
she
arose
;
and
hurrying
on
,
in
a
direction
quite
opposite
to
that
in
which
Sikes
was
awaiting
her
returned
,
quickened
her
pace
,
until
it
gradually
resolved
into
a
violent
run
.
 
<EOS>
After
completely
exhausting
herself
,
she
stopped
to
take
breath
:
 
and
,
as
if
suddenly
recollecting
herself
,
and
deploring
her
inability
to
do
something
she
was
bent
upon
,
wrung
her
hands
,
and
burst
into
tears
.
   
<EOS>
It
might
be
that
her
tears
relieved
her
,
or
that
she
felt
the
full
hopelessness
of
her
condition
;
but
she
turned
back
;
and
hurrying
with
nearly
as
great
rapidity
in
the
contrary
direction
;
partly
to
recover
lost
time
,
and
partly
to
keep
pace
with
the
violent
current
of
her
own
thoughts
:
 
soon
reached
the
dwelling
where
she
had
left
the
housebreaker
.
   
<EOS>
If
she
betrayed
any
agitation
,
when
she
presented
herself
to
Mr
Sikes
,
he
did
not
observe
it
;
for
merely
inquiring
if
she
had
brought
the
money
,
and
receiving
a
reply
in
the
affirmative
,
he
uttered
a
growl
of
satisfaction
,
and
replacing
his
head
upon
the
pillow
,
resumed
the
slumbers
which
her
arrival
had
interrupted
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
fortunate
for
her
that
the
possession
of
money
occasioned
him
so
much
employment
next
day
in
the
way
of
eating
and
drinking
;
and
withal
had
so
beneficial
an
effect
in
smoothing
down
the
asperities
of
his
temper
;
that
he
had
neither
time
nor
inclination
to
be
very
critical
upon
her
behaviour
and
deportment
.
 
<EOS>
That
she
had
all
the
abstracted
and
nervous
manner
of
one
who
is
on
the
eve
of
some
bold
and
hazardous
step
,
which
it
has
required
no
common
struggle
to
resolve
upon
,
would
have
been
obvious
to
the
lynx
-
eyed
Fagin
,
who
would
most
probably
have
taken
the
alarm
at
once
;
but
Mr
Sikes
lacking
the
niceties
of
discrimination
,
and
being
troubled
with
no
more
subtle
misgivings
than
those
which
resolve
themselves
into
a
dogged
roughness
of
behaviour
towards
everybody
;
and
being
,
furthermore
,
in
an
unusually
amiable
condition
,
as
has
been
already
observed
;
saw
nothing
unusual
in
her
demeanor
,
and
indeed
,
troubled
himself
so
little
about
her
,
that
,
had
her
agitation
been
far
more
perceptible
than
it
was
,
it
would
have
been
very
unlikely
to
have
awakened
his
suspicions
.
   
<EOS>
As
that
day
closed
in
,
the
girl
's
excitement
increased
;
and
,
when
night
came
on
,
and
she
sat
by
,
watching
until
the
housebreaker
should
drink
himself
asleep
,
there
was
an
unusual
paleness
in
her
cheek
,
and
a
fire
in
her
eye
,
that
even
Sikes
observed
with
astonishment
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Sikes
being
weak
from
the
fever
,
was
lying
in
bed
,
taking
hot
water
with
his
gin
to
render
it
less
inflammatory
;
and
had
pushed
his
glass
towards
Nancy
to
be
replenished
for
the
third
or
fourth
time
,
when
these
symptoms
first
struck
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
burn
my
body
!
"
<EOS>
said
the
man
,
raising
himself
on
his
hands
as
he
stared
the
girl
in
the
face
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
look
like
a
corpse
come
to
life
again
.
 
<EOS>
What
's
the
matter
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Matter
!
"
replied
the
girl
.
 
<EOS>
"
Nothing
.
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
look
at
me
so
hard
for
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
foolery
is
this
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
Sikes
,
grasping
her
by
the
arm
,
and
shaking
her
roughly
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
?
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
mean
?
 
<EOS>
What
are
you
thinking
of
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of
many
things
,
Bill
,
"
replied
the
girl
,
shivering
,
and
as
she
did
so
,
pressing
her
hands
upon
her
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
,
Lord
!
 
<EOS>
What
odds
in
that
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
tone
of
forced
gaiety
in
which
the
last
words
were
spoken
,
seemd
to
produce
a
deeper
impression
on
Sikes
than
the
wild
and
rigid
look
which
had
preceded
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
wot
<EOS>
it
is
,
"
said
Sikes
;
"
if
you
have
n't
caught
the
fever
,
and
got
it
comin
'
<EOS>
on
,
now
,
there
's
something
more
than
usual
in
the
wind
,
and
something
dangerous
too
.
 
<EOS>
You
're
not
a
-
going
to
---
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
damme
!
<EOS>
you
would
n't
do
that
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
what
?
"
<EOS>
asked
the
girl
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
ai
n't
,
"
said
Sikes
,
fixing
his
eyes
upon
her
,
and
muttering
the
words
to
himself
;
"
there
ai
n't
a
stauncher
-
hearted
gal
going
,
or
I
'd
have
cut
her
throat
three
months
ago
.
 
<EOS>
She
's
got
the
fever
coming
on
;
that
's
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
Fortifying
himself
with
this
assurance
,
Sikes
drained
the
glass
to
the
bottom
,
and
then
,
with
many
grumbling
oaths
,
called
for
his
physic
.
 
<EOS>
The
girl
jumped
up
,
with
great
alacrity
;
poured
it
quickly
out
,
but
with
her
back
towards
him
;
and
held
the
vessel
to
his
lips
,
while
he
drank
off
the
contents
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
said
the
robber
,
"
come
and
sit
aside
of
me
,
and
put
on
your
own
face
;
or
I
'll
alter
it
so
,
that
you
wo
n't
know
it
agin
when
you
do
want
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
girl
obeyed
.
 
<EOS>
Sikes
,
locking
her
hand
in
his
,
fell
back
upon
the
pillow
:
turning
his
eyes
upon
her
face
.
 
<EOS>
They
closed
;
opened
again
;
closed
once
more
;
again
opened
.
 
<EOS>
He
shifted
his
position
restlessly
;
and
,
after
dozing
again
,
and
again
,
for
two
or
three
minutes
,
and
as
often
springing
up
with
a
look
of
terror
,
and
gazing
vacantly
about
him
,
was
suddenly
stricken
,
as
it
were
,
while
in
the
very
attitude
of
rising
,
into
a
deep
and
heavy
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
The
grasp
of
his
hand
relaxed
;
the
upraised
arm
fell
languidly
by
his
side
;
and
he
lay
like
one
in
a
profound
trance
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
laudanum
has
taken
effect
at
last
,
"
murmured
the
girl
,
as
she
rose
from
the
bedside
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
may
be
too
late
,
even
now
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
hastily
dressed
herself
in
her
bonnet
and
shawl
:
 
looking
fearfully
round
,
from
time
to
time
,
as
if
,
despite
the
sleeping
draught
,
she
expected
every
moment
to
feel
the
pressure
of
Sikes
's
heavy
hand
upon
her
shoulder
;
then
,
stooping
softly
over
the
bed
,
she
kissed
the
robber
's
lips
;
and
then
opening
and
closing
the
room
-
door
with
noiseless
touch
,
hurried
from
the
house
.
   
<EOS>
A
watchman
was
crying
half
-
past
nine
,
down
a
dark
passage
through
which
she
had
to
pass
,
in
gaining
the
main
thoroughfare
.
   
<EOS>
"
Has
it
long
gone
the
half
-
hour
?
"
<EOS>
asked
the
girl
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
'll
strike
the
hour
in
another
quarter
,
"
said
the
man
:
raising
his
lantern
to
her
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
can
not
get
there
in
less
than
an
hour
or
more
,
"
muttered
Nancy
:
 
<EOS>
brushing
swiftly
past
him
,
and
gliding
rapidly
down
the
street
.
   
<EOS>
Many
of
the
shops
were
already
closing
in
the
back
lanes
and
avenues
through
which
she
tracked
her
way
,
in
making
from
Spitalfields
towards
the
West
-
End
of
London
.
 
<EOS>
The
clock
struck
ten
,
increasing
her
impatience
.
 
<EOS>
She
tore
along
the
narrow
pavement
:
 
<EOS>
elbowing
the
passengers
from
side
to
side
;
and
darting
almost
under
the
horses
'
heads
,
crossed
crowded
streets
,
where
clusters
of
persons
were
eagerly
watching
their
opportunity
to
do
the
like
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
woman
is
mad
!
"
said
the
people
,
turning
to
look
after
her
as
she
rushed
away
.
   
<EOS>
When
she
reached
the
more
wealthy
quarter
of
the
town
,
the
streets
were
comparatively
deserted
;
and
here
her
headlong
progress
excited
a
still
greater
curiosity
in
the
stragglers
whom
she
hurried
past
.
 
<EOS>
Some
quickened
their
pace
behind
,
as
though
to
see
whither
she
was
hastening
at
such
an
unusual
rate
;
and
a
few
made
head
upon
her
,
and
looked
back
,
surprised
at
her
undiminished
speed
;
but
they
fell
off
one
by
one
;
and
when
she
neared
her
place
of
destination
,
she
was
alone
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
family
hotel
in
a
quiet
but
handsome
street
near
Hyde
Park
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
brilliant
light
of
the
lamp
which
burnt
before
its
door
,
guided
her
to
the
spot
,
the
clock
struck
eleven
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
loitered
for
a
few
paces
as
though
irresolute
,
and
making
up
her
mind
to
advance
;
but
the
sound
determined
her
,
and
she
stepped
into
the
hall
.
 
<EOS>
The
porter
's
seat
was
vacant
.
 
<EOS>
She
looked
round
with
an
air
of
incertitude
,
and
advanced
towards
the
stairs
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
young
woman
!
"
said
a
smartly
-
dressed
female
,
looking
out
from
a
door
behind
her
,
"
who
do
you
want
here
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
lady
who
is
stopping
in
this
house
,
"
answered
the
girl
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
lady
!
<EOS>
"
was
the
reply
,
accompanied
with
a
scornful
look
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
lady
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Maylie
,
"
said
Nancy
.
   
<EOS>
The
young
woman
,
who
had
by
this
time
,
noted
her
appearance
,
replied
only
by
a
look
of
virtuous
disdain
;
and
summoned
a
man
to
answer
her
.
 
<EOS>
To
him
,
Nancy
repeated
her
request
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
name
am
I
to
say
?
"
asked
the
waiter
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
of
no
use
saying
any
,
"
replied
Nancy
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Nor
business
?
"
said
the
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
nor
that
neither
,
"
rejoined
the
girl
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
must
see
the
lady
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Come
!
"
<EOS>
said
the
man
,
pushing
her
towards
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
None
of
this
.
 
<EOS>
Take
yourself
off
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
carried
out
if
I
go
!
"
said
the
girl
violently
;
"
and
I
can
make
that
a
job
that
two
of
you
wo
n't
like
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
Is
n't
there
anybody
here
,
"
she
said
,
looking
round
,
"
that
will
see
a
simple
message
carried
for
a
poor
wretch
like
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
This
appeal
produced
an
effect
on
a
good
-
tempered
-
faced
man
-
cook
,
who
with
some
of
the
other
servants
was
looking
on
,
and
who
stepped
forward
to
interfere
.
   
<EOS>
"
Take
it
up
for
her
,
Joe
;
ca
n't
you
?
"
said
this
person
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
good
?
"
replied
the
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
suppose
the
young
lady
will
see
such
as
her
;
do
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
This
allusion
to
Nancy
's
doubtful
character
,
raised
a
vast
quantity
of
chaste
wrath
in
the
bosoms
of
four
housemaids
,
who
remarked
,
with
great
fervour
,
that
the
creature
was
a
disgrace
to
her
sex
;
and
strongly
advocated
her
being
thrown
,
ruthlessly
,
into
the
kennel
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
what
you
like
with
me
,
"
said
the
girl
,
turning
to
the
men
again
;
"
but
do
what
I
ask
you
first
,
and
I
ask
you
to
give
this
message
for
God
Almighty
's
sake
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
soft
-
hearted
cook
added
his
intercession
,
and
the
result
was
that
the
man
who
had
first
appeared
undertook
its
delivery
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
it
to
be
?
"
said
the
man
,
with
one
foot
on
the
stairs
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
a
young
woman
earnestly
asks
to
speak
to
Miss
Maylie
alone
,
"
said
Nancy
;
"
and
that
if
the
lady
will
only
hear
the
first
word
she
has
to
say
,
she
will
know
whether
to
hear
her
business
,
or
to
have
her
turned
out
of
doors
as
an
impostor
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
"
said
the
man
,
"
you
're
coming
it
strong
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
give
the
message
,
"
said
the
girl
firmly
;
"
and
let
me
hear
the
answer
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
man
ran
upstairs
.
 
<EOS>
Nancy
remained
,
pale
and
almost
breathless
,
listening
with
quivering
lip
to
the
very
audible
expressions
of
scorn
,
of
which
the
chaste
housemaids
were
very
prolific
;
and
of
which
they
became
still
more
so
,
when
the
man
returned
,
and
said
the
young
woman
was
to
walk
upstairs
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
no
good
being
proper
in
this
world
,
"
said
the
first
housemaid
.
   
<EOS>
"
Brass
can
do
better
than
the
gold
what
has
stood
the
fire
,
"
said
the
second
.
   
<EOS>
The
third
contented
herself
with
wondering
"
what
ladies
was
made
of
"
;
and
the
fourth
took
the
first
in
a
quartette
of
"
Shameful
!
"
<EOS>
with
which
the
Dianas
concluded
.
   
<EOS>
Regardless
of
all
this
:
for
she
had
weightier
matters
at
heart
:
Nancy
followed
the
man
,
with
trembling
limbs
,
to
a
small
ante
-
chamber
,
lighted
by
a
lamp
from
the
ceiling
.
<EOS>
Here
he
left
her
,
and
retired
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
40
.
<EOS>
A
strange
interview
,
which
is
a
sequel
to
the
last
chamber
.
 
<EOS>
The
girl
's
life
had
been
squandered
in
the
streets
,
and
among
the
most
noisome
of
the
stews
and
dens
of
London
,
but
there
was
something
of
the
woman
's
original
nature
left
in
her
still
;
and
when
she
heard
a
light
step
approaching
the
door
opposite
to
that
by
which
she
had
entered
,
and
thought
of
the
wide
contrast
which
the
small
room
would
in
another
moment
contain
,
she
felt
burdened
with
the
sense
of
her
own
deep
shame
,
and
shrunk
as
though
she
could
scarcely
bear
the
presence
of
her
with
whom
she
had
sought
this
interview
.
   
<EOS>
But
struggling
with
these
better
feelings
was
pride
,
---
the
vice
of
the
lowest
and
most
debased
creatures
no
less
than
of
the
high
and
self
-
assured
.
 
<EOS>
The
miserable
companion
of
thieves
and
ruffians
,
the
fallen
outcast
of
low
haunts
,
the
associate
of
the
scourings
of
the
jails
and
hulks
,
living
within
the
shadow
of
the
gallows
itself
,
---
even
this
degraded
being
felt
too
proud
to
betray
a
feeble
gleam
of
the
womanly
feeling
which
she
thought
a
weakness
,
but
which
alone
connected
her
with
that
humanity
,
of
which
her
wasting
life
had
obliterated
so
many
,
many
traces
when
a
very
child
.
   
<EOS>
She
raised
her
eyes
sufficiently
to
observe
that
the
figure
which
presented
itself
was
that
of
a
slight
and
beautiful
girl
;
then
,
bending
them
on
the
ground
,
she
tossed
her
head
with
affected
carelessness
as
she
said
:
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
hard
matter
to
get
to
see
you
,
lady
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
had
taken
offence
,
and
gone
away
,
as
many
would
have
done
,
you
'd
have
been
sorry
for
it
one
day
,
and
not
without
reason
either
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
sorry
if
any
one
has
behaved

you
,
"
replied
Rose
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
think
of
that
.
 
<EOS>
Tell
me
why
you
wished
to

me
.
<EOS>
I
am
the
person
you
inquired
for
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
kind
tone
of
this

,
the

,
the

,
the

,
took

girl
completely
by

,
and
she

into

.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
lady
,
lady
!
"
<EOS>
she

,

,
"

there

more

,
there
would

fewer

,
---
there
would
---
there

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sit

,
"

Rose
,

<EOS>
"

I

.
 
<EOS>
Sit

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Let

"

,

"
and
do
not

<EOS>
It
is

.
 
<EOS>
Is
---
<EOS>
is
---
that

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"

Rose

<EOS>
"

?
"
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

"
I

<EOS>
I

"
   
<EOS>
"
You
!
"

<EOS>
"
I
,

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

never

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

.

<EOS>
"
I
pity

!
"
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
It

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Heaven

"

<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
But

,

.
 
<EOS>

?

<EOS>
"
No
,
"

.

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
A

.

"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Last

.
 
<EOS>
Again

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
The

"
<EOS>
So

"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

Back

<EOS>

<EOS>
no

"

"

<EOS>
Oh
!
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
He
