so
cruel
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
possible
,
"
cried
Rose
,
"
that
for
such
a
man
as
this
,
you
can
resign
every
future
hope
,
and
the
certainty
of
immediate
rescue
?
 
<EOS>
It
is
madness
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
what
it
is
,
"
answered
the
girl
;
<EOS>
"
I
only
know
that
it
is
so
,
and
not
with
me
alone
,
but
with
hundreds
of
others
as
bad
and
wretched
as
myself
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
go
back
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
it
is
God
's
wrath
for
the
wrong
I
have
done
,
I
do
not
know
;
but
I
am
drawn
back
to
him
through
every
suffering
and
ill
usage
;
and
I
should
be
,
I
believe
,
if
I
knew
that
I
was
to
die
by
his
hand
at
last
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
am
I
to
do
?
"
said
Rose
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
not
let
you
depart
from
me
thus
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
should
,
lady
,
and
<EOS>
I
know
you
will
,
"
rejoined
the
girl
,
rising
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
will
not
stop
my
going
because
I
have
trusted
in
your
goodness
,
and
forced
no
promise
from
you
,
as
I
might
have
done
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of
what
use
,
then
,
is
the
communication
you
have
made
?
"
said
Rose
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
mystery
must
be
investigated
,
or
how
will
its
disclosure
to
me
,
benefit
Oliver
,
whom
you
are
anxious
to
serve
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
must
have
some
kind
gentleman
about
you
that
will
hear
it
as
a
secret
,
and
advise
you
what
to
do
,
"
rejoined
the
girl
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
where
can
I
find
you
again
when
it
is
necessary
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Rose
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
seek
to
know
where
these
dreadful
people
live
,
but
where
will
you
be
walking
or
passing
at
any
settled
period
from
this
time
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Will
you
promise
me
that
you
will
have
my
secret
strictly
kept
,
and
come
alone
,
or
with
the
only
other
person
that
knows
it
;
and
that
I
shall
not
be
watched
or
followed
?
"
asked
the
girl
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
promise
you
solemnly
,
"
answered
Rose
.
   
<EOS>
"
Every
Sunday
night
,
from
eleven
until
the
clock
strikes
twelve
,
"
said
the
girl
without
hesitation
,
"
I
will
walk
on
London
Bridge
if
I
am
alive
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Stay
another
moment
,
"
interposed
Rose
,
as
the
girl
moved
hurriedly
towards
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
Think
once
again
on
your
own
condition
,
and
the
opportunity
you
have
of
escaping
from
it
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
a
claim
on
me
:
 
not
only
as
the
voluntary
bearer
of
this
intelligence
,
but
as
a
woman
lost
almost
beyond
redemption
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
return
to
this
gang
of
robbers
,
and
to
this
man
,
when
a
word
can
save
you
?
 
<EOS>
What
fascination
is
it
that
can
take
you
back
,
and
make
you
cling
to
wickedness
and
misery
?
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
is
there
no
chord
in
your
heart
that
I
can
touch
!
 
<EOS>
Is
there
nothing
left
,
to
which
I
can
appeal
against
this
terrible
infatuation
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
When
ladies
as
young
,
and
good
,
and
beautiful
as
you
are
,
"
replied
the
girl
steadily
,
"
give
away
your
hearts
,
love
will
carry
you
all
lengths
---
even
such
as
you
,
who
have
home
,
friends
,
other
admirers
,
everything
,
to
fill
them
.
 
<EOS>
When
such
as
I
,
who
have
no
certain
roof
but
the
coffinlid
,
and
no
friend
in
sickness
or
death
but
the
hospital
nurse
,
set
our
rotten
hearts
on
any
man
,
and
let
him
fill
the
place
that
has
been
a
blank
through
all
our
wretched
lives
,
who
can
hope
to
cure
us
?
 
<EOS>
Pity
us
,
lady
---
pity
us
for
having
only
one
feeling
of
the
woman
left
,
and
for
having
that
turned
,
by
a
heavy
judgment
,
from
a
comfort
and
a
pride
,
into
a
new
means
of
violence
and
suffering
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
will
,
"
said
Rose
,
after
a
pause
,
"
take
some
money
from
me
,
which
may
enable
you
to
live
without
dishonesty
---
at
all
events
until
we
meet
again
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
Not
a
penny
,
"
replied
the
girl
,
waving
her
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
not
close
your
heart
against
all
my
efforts
to
help
you
,
"
said
Rose
,
stepping
gently
forward
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
wish
to
serve
you
indeed
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
would
serve
me
best
,
lady
,
"
replied
the
girl
,
wringing
her
hands
,
"
if
you
could
take
my
life
at
once
;
for
I
have
felt
more
grief
to
think
of
what
I
am
,
to
-
night
,
than
I
ever
did
before
,
and
it
would
be
something
not
to
die
in
the
hell
in
which
I
have
lived
.
 
<EOS>
God
bless
you
,
sweet
lady
,
and
send
as
much
happiness
on
your
head
as
I
have
brought
shame
on
mine
!
"
   
<EOS>
Thus
speaking
,
and
sobbing
aloud
,
the
unhappy
creature
turned
away
;
while
Rose
Maylie
,
overpowered
by
this
extraordinary
interview
,
which
had
more
the
semblance
of
a
rapid
dream
than
an
actual
occurance
,
sank
into
a
chair
,
and
endeavoured
to
collect
her
wandering
thoughts
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
41
.
<EOS>
Containing
fresh
discoveries
,
and
showing
that
suprises
,
like
misfortunes
,
seldom
come
alone
.
 
<EOS>
Her
situation
was
,
indeed
,
one
of
no
common
trial
and
difficulty
.
   
<EOS>
While
she
felt
the
most
eager
and
burning
desire
to
penetrate
the
mystery
in
which
Oliver
's
history
was
enveloped
,
she
could
not
but
hold
sacred
the
confidence
which
the
miserable
woman
with
whom
she
had
just
conversed
,
had
reposed
in
her
,
as
a
young
and
guileless
girl
.
 
<EOS>
Her
words
and
manner
had
touched
Rose
Maylie
's
heart
;
and
,
mingled
with
her
love
for
her
young
charge
,
and
scarcely
less
intense
in
its
truth
and
fervour
,
was
her
fond
wish
to
win
the
outcast
back
to
repentance
and
hope
.
   
<EOS>
They
purposed
remaining
in
London
only
three
days
,
prior
to
departing
for
some
weeks
to
a
distant
part
of
the
coast
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
now
midnight
of
the
first
day
.
 
<EOS>
What
course
of
action
could
she
determine
upon
,
which
could
be
adopted
in
eight
-
and
-
forty
hours
?
<EOS>
Or
how
could
she
postpone
the
journey
without
exciting
suspicion
?
   
<EOS>
Mr
Losberne
was
with
them
,
and
would
be
for
the
next
two
days
;
but
Rose
was
too
well
acquainted
with
the
excellent
gentleman
's
impetuosity
,
and
foresaw
too
clearly
the
wrath
with
which
,
in
the
first
explosion
of
his
indignation
,
he
would
regard
the
instrument
of
Oliver
's
recapture
,
to
trust
him
with
the
secret
,
when
her
representations
in
the
girl
's
behalf
could
be
seconded
by
no
experienced
person
.
 
<EOS>
These
were
all
reasons
for
the
greatest
caution
and
most
circumspect
behaviour
in
communicating
it
to
Mrs
Maylie
,
whose
first
impulse
would
infallibly
be
to
hold
a
conference
with
the
worthy
doctor
on
the
subject
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
resorting
to
any
legal
adviser
,
even
if
she
had
known
how
to
do
so
,
it
was
scarcely
to
be
thought
of
,
for
the
same
reason
.
 
<EOS>
Once
the
thought
occurred
to
her
of
seeking
assistance
from
Harry
;
but
this
awakened
the
recollection
of
their
last
parting
,
and
it
seemed
unworthy
of
her
to
call
him
back
,
when
---
the
tears
rose
to
her
eyes
as
she
pursued
this
train
of
reflection
---
he
might
have
by
this
time
learnt
to
forget
her
,
and
to
be
happier
away
.
   
<EOS>
Disturbed
by
these
different
reflections
;
inclining
now
to
one
course
and
then
to
another
,
and
again
recoiling
from
all
,
as
each
successive
consideration
presented
itself
to
her
mind
;
Rose
passed
a
sleepless
and
anxious
night
.
 
<EOS>
After
more
communing
with
herself
next
day
,
she
arrived
at
the
desperate
conclusion
of
consulting
Harry
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
it
be
painful
to
him
,
"
she
thought
,
"
to
come
back
here
,
how
painful
it
will
be
to
me
!
 
<EOS>
But
perhaps
he
will
not
come
;
he
may
write
,
or
he
may
come
himself
,
and
studiously
abstain
from
meeting
me
---
he
did
when
he
went
away
.
 
<EOS>
I
hardly
thought
he
would
;
but
it
was
better
for
us
both
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
here
Rose
dropped
the
pen
,
and
turned
away
,
as
though
the
very
paper
which
was
to
be
her
messenger
should
not
see
her
weep
.
   
<EOS>
She
had
taken
up
the
same
pen
,
and
laid
it
down
again
fifty
times
,
and
had
considered
and
reconsidered
the
first
line
of
her
letter
without
writing
the
first
word
,
when
Oliver
,
who
had
been
walking
in
the
streets
,
with
Mr
Giles
for
a
body
-
guard
,
entered
the
room
in
such
breathless
haste
and
violent
agitation
,
as
seemed
to
betoken
some
new
cause
of
alarm
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
makes
you
look
so
flurried
?
"
asked
Rose
,
advancing
to
meet
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hardly
know
how
;
I
feel
as
if
I
should
be
choked
,
"
replied
the
boy
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
!
 
<EOS>
To
think
that
I
should
see
him
at
last
,
and
you
should
be
able
to
know
that
I
have
told
you
the
truth
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
never
thought
you
had
told
us
anything
but
the
truth
,
"
said
Rose
,
soothing
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
what
is
this
?
<EOS>
---
of
whom
do
you
speak
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
seen
the
gentleman
,
"
replied
Oliver
,
scarcely
able
to
articulate
,
"
the
gentleman
who
was
so
good
to
me
---
<EOS>
Mr
Brownlow
,
that
we
have
so
often
talked
about
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Where
?
"
asked
Rose
.
   
<EOS>
"
Getting
out
of
a
coach
,
"
replied
Oliver
,
shedding
tears
of
delight
,
"
and
going
into
a
house
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
n't
speak
to
him
<EOS>
---
I
could
n't
speak
to
him
,
for
he
did
n't
see
me
,
and
I
trembled
so
,
that
I
was
not
able
to
go
up
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
Giles
asked
,
for
me
,
whether
he
lived
there
,
and
they
said
he
did
.
 
<EOS>
Look
here
,
"
said
Oliver
,
opening
a
scrap
of
paper
,
"
<EOS>
here
it
is
;
here
's
where
he
lives
---
I
'm
going
there
directly
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
dear
me
,
dear
me
!
 
<EOS>
What
shall
I
do
when
I
come
to
see
him
and
hear
him
speak
again
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
her
attention
not
a
little
distracted
by
these
and
a
great
many
other
incoherent
exclamations
of
joy
,
Rose
read
the
address
,
which
was
Craven
Street
,
in
the
Strand
.
 
<EOS>
She
very
soon
determined
upon
turning
the
discovery
to
account
.
   
<EOS>
"
Quick
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
Tell
them
to
fetch
a
hackney
-
coach
,
and
be
ready
to
go
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
take
you
there
directly
,
without
a
minute
's
loss
of
time
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
only
tell
my
aunt
that
we
are
going
out
for
an
hour
,
and
be
ready
as
soon
as
you
are
.
"
   
<EOS>
Oliver
needed
no
prompting
to
despatch
,
and
in
little
more
than
five
minutes
they
were
on
their
way
to
Craven
Street
.
 
<EOS>
When
they
arrived
there
,
Rose
left
Oliver
in
the
coach
,
under
pretence
of
preparing
the
old
gentleman
to
receive
him
;
and
sending
up
her
card
by
the
servant
,
requested
to
see
Mr
Brownlow
on
very
pressing
business
.
 
<EOS>
The
servant
soon
returned
,
to
beg
that
she
would
walk
upstairs
;
and
following
him
into
an
upper
room
,
Miss
Maylie
was
presented
to
an
elderly
gentleman
of
benevolent
appearance
,
in
a
bottle
-
green
coat
.
 
<EOS>
At
no
great
distance
from
whom
,
was
seated
another
old
gentleman
,
in
nankeen
breeches
and
gaiters
;
who
did
not
look
particularly
benevolent
,
and
who
was
sitting
with
his
hands
clasped
on
the
top
of
a
thick
stick
,
and
his
chin
propped
thereupon
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
,
"
said
the
gentleman
,
in
the
bottle
-
green
coat
,
hastily
rising
with
great
politeness
,
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
young
lady
---
<EOS>
I
imagined
it
was
some
importunate
person
who
<EOS>
---
I
beg
you
will
excuse
me
.
 
<EOS>
Be
seated
,
pray
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Brownlow
,
I
believe
,
sir
?
"
said
Rose
,
glancing
from
the
other
gentleman
to
the
one
who
had
spoken
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
is
my
name
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
my
friend
,
Mr
Grimwig
.
 
<EOS>
Grimwig
,
will
you
leave
us
for
a
few
minutes
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
believe
,
"
interposed
Miss
Maylie
,
"
that
at
this
period
of
our
interview
,
I
need
not
give
that
gentleman
the
trouble
of
going
away
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
am
correctly
informed
,
he
is
cognizant
of
the
business
on
which
I
wish
to
speak
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Brownlow
inclined
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Grimwig
,
who
had
made
one
very
stiff
bow
,
and
risen
from
his
chair
,
made
another
very
stiff
bow
,
and
dropped
into
it
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
surprise
you
very
much
,
<EOS>
I
have
no
doubt
,
"
said
Rose
,
naturally
embarrassed
;
"
<EOS>
but
you
once
showed
great
benevolence
and
goodness
to
a
very
dear
young
friend
of
mine
,
and
I
am
sure
you
will
take
an
interest
in
hearing
of
him
again
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
Indeed
!
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oliver
Twist
you
knew
him
as
,
"
replied
Rose
.
   
<EOS>
The
words
no
sooner
escaped
her
lips
,
than
Mr
Grimwig
,
who
had
been
affecting
to
dip
into
a
large
book
that
lay
on
the
table
,
upset
it
with
a
great
crash
,
and
falling
back
in
his
chair
,
discharged
from
his
features
every
expression
but
one
of
unmitigated
wonder
,
and
indulged
in
a
prolonged
and
vacant
stare
;
then
,
as
if
ashamed
of
having
betrayed
so
much
emotion
,
he
jerked
himself
,
as
it
were
,
by
a
convulsion
into
his
former
attitude
,
and
looking
out
straight
before
him
emitted
a
long
deep
whistle
,
which
seemed
,
at
last
,
not
to
be
discharged
on
empty
air
,
but
to
die
away
in
the
innermost
recesses
of
his
stomach
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Browlow
was
no
less
surprised
,
although
his
astonishment
was
not
expressed
in
the
same
eccentric
manner
.
 
<EOS>
He
drew
his
chair
nearer
to
Miss
Maylie
's
,
and
said
,
   
"
<EOS>
Do
me
the
favour
,
my
dear
young
lady
,
to
leave
entirely
out
of
the
question
that
goodness
and
benevolence
of
which
you
speak
,
and
of
which
nobody
else
knows
anything
;
and
if
you
have
it
in
your
power
to
produce
any
evidence
which
will
alter
the
unfavourable
opinion
I
was
once
induced
to
entertain
of
that
poor
child
,
in
Heaven
's
name
put
me
in
possession
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
bad
one
!
 
<EOS>
I
'll
eat
my
head
if
he
is
not
a
bad
one
,
"
growled
Mr
Grimwig
,
speaking
by
some
ventriloquial
power
,
without
moving
a
muscle
of
his
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
a
child
of
a
noble
nature
and
a
warm
heart
,
"
said
Rose
,
colouring
;
"
and
that
Power
which
has
thought
fit
to
try
him
beyond
his
years
,
has
planted
in
his
breast
affections
and
feelings
which
would
do
honour
to
many
who
have
numbered
his
days
six
times
over
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
only
sixty
-
one
,
"
said
Mr
Grimwig
,
with
the
same
rigid
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
,
as
the
devil
's
in
it
if
this
Oliver
is
not
twelve
years
old
at
least
,
I
do
n't
see
the
application
of
that
remark
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Do
not
heed
my
friend
,
Miss
Maylie
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
;
"
he
does
not
mean
what
he
says
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
he
does
,
"
growled
Mr
Grimwig
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
he
does
not
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
,
obviously
rising
in
wrath
as
he
spoke
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
'll
eat
his
head
,
if
he
does
n't
,
"
growled
Mr
Grimwig
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
would
deserve
to
have
it
knocked
off
,
if
he
does
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
he
'd
uncommonly
like
to
see
any
man
offer
to
do
it
,
"
responded
Mr
Grimwig
,
knocking
his
stick
upon
the
floor
.
   
<EOS>
Having
gone
thus
far
,
the
two
old
gentlemen
severally
took
snuff
,
and
afterwards
shook
hands
,
according
to
their
invariable
custom
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Miss
Maylie
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
,
"
to
return
to
the
subject
in
which
your
humanity
is
so
much
interested
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
let
me
know
what
intelligence
you
have
of
this
poor
child
:
 
allowing
me
to
promise
that
I
exhausted
every
means
in
my
power
of
discovering
him
,
and
that
since
I
have
been
absent
from
this
country
,
my
first
impression
that
he
had
imposed
upon
me
,
and
had
been
persuaded
by
his
former
associates
to
rob
me
,
has
been
considerably
shaken
.
"
   
<EOS>
Rose
,
who
had
had
time
to
collect
her
thoughts
,
at
once
related
,
in
a
few
natural
words
,
all
that
had
befallen
Oliver
since
he
left
Mr
Brownlow
's
house
;
reserving
Nancy
's
information
for
that
gentleman
's
private
ear
,
and
concluding
with
the
assurance
that
his
only
sorrow
,
for
some
months
past
,
had
been
not
being
able
to
meet
with
his
former
benefactor
and
friend
.
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
God
!
"
<EOS>
said
the
old
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
great
happiness
to
me
,
great
happiness
.
 
<EOS>
But
you
have
not
told
me
where
he
is
now
,
Miss
Maylie
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
pardon
my
finding
fault
with
you
,
---
<EOS>
but
why
not
have
brought
him
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
waiting
in
a
coach
at
the
door
,
"
replied
Rose
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
At
this
door
!
"
cried
the
old
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
With
which
he
hurried
out
of
the
room
,
down
the
stairs
,
up
the
coachsteps
,
and
into
the
coach
,
without
another
word
.
   
<EOS>
When
the
room
-
door
closed
behind
him
,
Mr
Grimwig
lifted
up
his
head
,
and
converting
one
of
the
hind
legs
of
his
chair
into
a
pivot
,
described
three
distinct
circles
with
the
assistance
of
his
stick
and
the
table
;
stitting
in
it
all
the
time
.
 
<EOS>
After
performing
this
evolution
,
he
rose
and
limped
as
fast
as
he
could
up
and
down
the
room
at
least
a
dozen
times
,
and
then
stopping
suddenly
before
Rose
,
kissed
her
without
the
slightest
preface
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
as
the
young
lady
rose
in
some
alarm
at
this
unusual
proceeding
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
afraid
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
old
enough
to
be
your
grandfather
.
 
<EOS>
You
're
a
sweet
girl
.
 
<EOS>
I
like
you
.
 
<EOS>
Here
they
are
!
"
   
<EOS>
In
fact
,
as
he
threw
himself
at
one
dexterous
dive
into
his
former
seat
,
Mr
Brownlow
returned
,
accompanied
by
Oliver
,
whom
Mr
Grimwig
received
very
graciously
;
and
if
the
gratification
of
that
moment
had
been
the
only
reward
for
all
her
anxiety
and
care
in
Oliver
's
behalf
,
Rose
Maylie
would
have
been
well
repaid
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
somebody
else
who
should
not
be
forgotten
,
by
the
bye
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
,
ringing
the
bell
.
 
<EOS>
"
Send
Mrs
Bedwin
here
,
if
you
please
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
old
housekeeper
answered
the
summons
with
all
dispatch
;
and
dropping
a
curtsey
at
the
door
,
waited
for
orders
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
get
blinder
every
day
,
Bedwin
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
,
rather
testily
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
that
I
do
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
old
lady
.
 
<EOS>
"
People
's
eyes
,
at
my
time
of
life
,
do
n't
improve
with
age
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
could
have
told
you
that
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Brownlow
;
"
but
put
on
your
glasses
,
and
see
if
you
ca
n't
find
out
what
you
were
wanted
for
,
will
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
old
lady
began
to
rummage
in
her
pocket
for
her
spectacles
.
<EOS>
But
Oliver
's
patience
was
not
proof
against
this
new
trial
;
and
yielding
to
his
first
impulse
,
he
sprang
into
her
arms
.
   
<EOS>
"
God
be
good
to
me
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
old
lady
,
embracing
him
;
"
it
is
my
innocent
boy
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
old
nurse
!
<EOS>
"
cried
Oliver
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
would
come
back
---
I
knew
he
would
,
"
said
the
old
lady
,
holding
him
in
her
arms
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
well
he
looks
,
and
how
like
a
gentleman
's
son
he
is
dressed
again
!
 
<EOS>
Where
have
you
been
,
this
long
,
long
while
?
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
the
same
sweet
face
,
but
not
so
pale
;
the
same
soft
eye
,
but
not
so
sad
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
never
forgotten
them
or
his
quiet
smile
,
but
have
seen
them
every
day
,
side
by
side
with
those
of
my
own
dear
children
,
dead
and
gone
since
I
was
a
lightsome
young
creature
.
"
 
<EOS>
Running
on
thus
,
and
now
holding
Oliver
from
her
to
mark
how
he
had
grown
,
now
clasping
him
to
her
and
passing
her
fingers
fondly
through
his
hair
,
the
good
soul
laughed
and
wept
upon
his
neck
by
turns
.
   
<EOS>
Leaving
her
and
Oliver
to
compare
notes
at
leisure
,
Mr
Brownlow
led
the
way
into
another
room
;
and
there
,
heard
from
Rose
a
full
narration
of
her
interview
with
Nancy
,
which
occasioned
him
no
little
surprise
and
perplexity
.
 
<EOS>
Rose
also
explained
her
reasons
for
not
confiding
in
her
friend
Mr
Losberne
in
the
first
instance
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
gentleman
considered
that
she
had
acted
prudently
,
and
readily
undertook
to
hold
solemn
conference
with
the
worthy
doctor
himself
.
 
<EOS>
To
afford
him
an
early
opportunity
for
the
execution
of
this
design
,
it
was
arranged
that
he
should
call
at
the
hotel
at
eight
o'clock
that
evening
,
and
that
in
the
meantime
Mrs
Maylie
should
be
cautiously
informed
of
all
that
had
occurred
.
 
<EOS>
These
preliminaries
adjusted
,
Rose
and
Oliver
returned
home
.
   
<EOS>
Rose
had
by
no
means
overrated
the
measure
of
the
good
doctor
's
wrath
.
 
<EOS>
Nancy
's
history
was
no
sooner
unfolded
to
him
,
than
he
poured
forth
a
shower
of
mingled
threats
and
execrations
;
threatened
to
make
her
the
first
victim
of
the
combined
ingenuity
of
Messrs.
Blathers
and
Duff
;
and
actually
put
on
his
hat
preparatory
to
sallying
forth
to
obtain
the
assistance
of
those
worthies
.
 
<EOS>
And
,
doubtless
,
he
would
,
in
this
first
outbreak
,
have
carried
the
intention
into
effect
without
a
moment
's
consideration
of
the
consequences
,
if
he
had
not
been
restrained
,
in
part
,
by
corresponding
violence
on
the
side
of
Mr
Brownlow
,
who
was
himself
of
an
irascible
temperament
,
and
party
by
such
arguments
and
representations
as
seemed
best
calculated
to
dissuade
him
from
his
hotbrained
purpose
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
what
the
devil
is
to
be
done
?
"
said
the
impetuous
doctor
,
when
they
had
rejoined
the
two
ladies
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
we
to
pass
a
vote
of
thanks
to
all
these
vagabonds
,
male
and
female
,
and
beg
them
to
accept
a
hundred
pounds
,
or
so
,
apiece
,
as
a
trifling
mark
of
our
esteem
,
and
some
slight
acknowledgment
of
their
kindness
to
Oliver
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
exactly
that
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Brownlow
,
laughing
;
"
but
we
must
proceed
gently
and
with
great
care
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Gentleness
and
care
,
"
exclaimed
the
doctor
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'd
send
them
one
and
all
to
---
"
   
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
where
,
"
interposed
Mr
Brownlow
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
reflect
whether
sending
them
anywhere
is
likely
to
attain
the
object
we
have
in
view
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
object
?
<EOS>
"
asked
the
doctor
.
   
<EOS>
"
Simply
,
the
discovery
of
Oliver
's
parentage
,
and
regaining
for
him
the
inheritance
of
which
,
if
this
story
be
true
,
he
has
been
fraudulently
deprived
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
said
Mr
Losberne
,
cooling
himself
with
his
pocket
-
handkerchief
;
"
I
almost
forgot
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
"
pursued
Mr
Brownlow
;
"
placing
this
poor
girl
entirely
out
of
the
question
,
and
supposing
it
were
possible
to
bring
these
scoundrels
to
justice
without
compromising
her
safety
,
what
good
should
we
bring
about
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hanging
a
few
of
them
at
least
,
in
all
probability
,
"
suggested
the
doctor
,
"
and
transporting
the
rest
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
good
,
"
replied
Mr
Brownlow
,
smiling
;
"
but
no
doubt
they
will
bring
that
about
for
themselves
in
the
fulness
of
time
,
and
if
we
step
in
to
forestall
them
,
it
seems
to
me
that
we
shall
be
performing
a
very
Quixotic
act
,
in
direct
opposition
to
our
own
interest
---
or
at
least
to
Oliver
's
,
which
is
the
same
thing
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
?
"
inquired
the
doctor
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Thus
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
quite
clear
that
we
shall
have
extreme
difficulty
in
getting
to
the
bottom
of
this
mystery
,
unless
we
can
bring
this
man
,
Monks
,
upon
his
knees
.
 
<EOS>
That
can
only
be
done
by
stratagem
,
and
by
catching
him
when
he
is
not
surrounded
by
these
people
.
 
<EOS>
For
<EOS>
,
suppose
he
were
apprehended
,
we
have
no
proof
against
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
not
even
(
so
far
as
we
know
,
or
as
the
facts
appear
to
us
)
concerned
with
the
gang
in
any
of
their
robberies
.
<EOS>
If
he
were
not
discharged
,
it
is
very
unlikely
that
he
could
receive
any
further
punishment
than
being
committed
to
prison
as
a
rogue
and
vagabond
;
and
of
course
ever
afterwards
his
mouth
would
be
so
obstinately
closed
that
he
might
as
well
,
for
our
purposes
,
be
deaf
,
dumb
,
blind
,
and
an
idiot
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
,
"
said
the
doctor
impetuously
,
"
I
put
it
to
you
again
,
whether
you
think
it
reasonable
that
this
promise
to
the
girl
should
be
considered
binding
;
a
promise
made
with
the
best
and
kindest
intentions
,
but
really
<EOS>
---
"
   
"
Do
not
discuss
the
point
,
my
dear
young
lady
,
pray
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
,
interrupting
Rose
as
she
was
about
to
speak
.
<EOS>
"
The
promise
shall
be
kept
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
think
it
will
,
in
the
slightest
degree
,

our

.
 
<EOS>
But
,
before
we
can
resolve
upon
any

,
it
will
be
necessary
to
see
the
girl
;
to
ascertain

her
whether
she
will
point
out
this
Monks
,
on
the

that
he
is
to

,

not

;
or
,

,
to

such

,
as

to
identify

.
 
<EOS>
She
can
not

seen
until
next
Sunday
night
;
this
is
Tuesday
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
suggest
that
in
the
meantime
,
we
remain

quiet
,
and
keep
these

secret
even

Oliver

.
"
   
<EOS>
Although
Mr
Loseberne
received
with
many

a

a
delay

five

,
he

;

,

's

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

like
,
"

"

Grimwig
.
 
<EOS>
He

,

,
and
might
prove

;
I

,

,

,

"
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
We

,
"

,
"

?
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

's
---

,
"

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
Rose
blushed

,
but

to
this

(
possibly

)
;
and
Harry
Maylie
and
Mr

were

.
   
<EOS>
"
We
stay

,

,
"
said

,
"
while
there

.
 
<EOS>
I
will

nor

in

of
the
object
in
which
we
are
all
so

,

,

,

that
any

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
And

,
a

that

's

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Believe

,

,
for

,

and

.
 
<EOS>
Come
!
 
<EOS>
Supper
has

,

young
Oliver
,

,
will

,
by

,
that

wearied
of

,

.
"
   
<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Losberne
followed
,
leading
Rose
;
and
the
council
was
,
for
the
present
,
effectually
broken

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
42
.
<EOS>
An
old
acquaintance
of
Oliver
's
,
exhibiting
decided
marks
of
genius
,
becomes
a
public
character
in
the
metropolis
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
the
night
when
Nancy
,
having
lulled
Mr
Sikes
to
sleep
,
hurried
on
her
self
-
imposed
mission
to
Rose
Maylie
,
there
advanced
towards
London
,
by
the
Great
North
Road
,
two
persons
,
upon
whom
it
is
expedient
that
this
history
should
bestow
some
attention
.
   
<EOS>
They
were
a
man
and
woman
;
or
perhaps
they
would
be
better
described
as
a
male
and
female
:
 
for
the
former
<EOS>
was
one
of
those
long
-
limbed
,
knock
-
kneed
,
shambling
,
bony
people
,
to
whom
it
is
difficult
to
assign
any
precise
age
,
---
looking
as
they
do
,
when
they
are
yet
boys
,
like
undergrown
men
,
and
when
they
are
almost
men
,
like
overgrown
boys
.
 
<EOS>
The
woman
was
young
,
but
of
a
robust
and
hardy
make
,
as
she
need
have
been
to
bear
the
weight
of
the
heavy
bundle
which
was
strapped
to
her
back
.
 
<EOS>
Her
companion
was
not
encumbered
with
much
luggage
,
as
there
merely
dangled
from
a
stick
which
he
carried
over
his
shoulder
,
a
small
parcel
wrapped
in
a
common
handkerchief
,
and
apparently
light
enough
.
 
<EOS>
This
circumstance
,
added
to
the
length
of
his
legs
,
which
were
of
unusual
extent
,
enabled
him
with
much
ease
to
keep
some
half
-
dozen
paces
in
advance
of
his
companion
,
to
whom
he
occasionally
turned
with
an
impatient

of
the
head
:
 
as
if
reproaching
her
tardiness
,
and
urging
her
to
greater
exertion
.
   
<EOS>
Thus
,
they
had
toiled
along
the
dusty
road
,
taking
little
heed
of
any
object
within
sight
,
save
when
they
stepped
aside
to
allow
a
wider
passage
for
the
mail
-
coaches
which
were
whirling
out
of
town
,
until
they
passed
through
Highgate
archway
;
when
the
foremost

stopped
and
called

to

,
   
"
Come
on
,
ca
n't
yer
?
 
<EOS>
What
a
lazybones
yer
are
,
Charlotte
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
heavy
load
,
I
can

,
"
said
the
female
,
coming

,
almost

.
   
<EOS>
"
Heavy
!
 
<EOS>
What
are
yer
talking
about
?
 
<EOS>
What
are
yer
made
for
?
<EOS>
"

male

,
changing

own

as

,
to

.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
there
yer
are
,

!
   
<EOS>
Well
,
if
yer
ai
n't
enough
to

's

out
,
I
do
n't

what
is
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is

?
"

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Much

!
 
<EOS>
Yer
<EOS>
as

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

!
 
<EOS>
Those

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
They

,

"

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

;

;
"

,

,
<EOS>

yer

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
As

red

,

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

?
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Near
,

"

.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
There
!
 
<EOS>
Not

;
so
do

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
When

,

,

,

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

,

,

,

,

<EOS>
"

!
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
'

,

;

,

,
the
wrong

,

,
yer'd

,

.
 
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

ai

,
"

;
"

.
 
<EOS>
You

<EOS>

<EOS>

Yer

"

.
   
<EOS>

,
Noah

"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Did

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
;
you

,

like

,

,
"
said

,
chucking

,
and

.
   
<EOS>
This
was
indeed
the
case
;
but
as
it
was
not
Mr
Claypole
's
habit
to
repose
a
blind

in

,
it
should

observed
,
in
justice
to
that

,
that
he
had
trusted
Charlotte
to
this

,
in
order
that
,
if
they
were

,
the
money
might
be
found
on
her
:
 
which
would
leave
him
an
opportunity
of
asserting
his

of
any
theft
,
and
would
greatly
facilitate
his
chances
of

.
 
<EOS>
Of
course
,
he
entered
at
this
juncture
,
into
no
explanation
of
his
motives
,
and
they
walked
on
very
lovingly
together
.
   
<EOS>
In
pursuance
of
this
cautious
plan
,
Mr
Claypole
went
on
,
without
halting
,
until
he
arrived
at
the
Angel
at
Islington
,
where
he
wisely
judged
,
from
the
crowd
of
passengers
and
numbers
of
vehicles
,
that
London
began
in
earnest
.
 
<EOS>
Just
pausing
to
observe
which
appeared
the
most
crowded
streets
,
and
consequently
the
most
to
be
avoided
,
he
crossed
into
Saint
John
's
Road
,
and
was
soon
deep
in
the
obscurity
of
the
intricate
and
dirty
ways
,
which
,
lying
between
Gray
's
Inn
Lane
and
Smithfield
,
render
that
part
of
the
town
one
of
the
lowest
and
worst
that
improvement
has
left
in
the
midst
of
London
.
   
<EOS>
Through
these
streets
,
Noah
Claypole
walked
,
dragging
Charlotte
after
him
;
now
stepping
into
the
kennel
to
embrace
at
a
glance
the
whole
external
character
of
some
small
public
-
house
;
now
jogging
on
again
,
as
some
fancied
appearance
induced
him
to
believe
it
too
public
for
his
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
he
stopped
in
front
of
one
,
more
humble
in
appearance
and
more
dirty
than
any
he
had
yet
seen
;
and
,
having
crossed
over
and
surveyed
it
from
the
opposite

,
graciously
announced
his
intention
of
putting
up
there
,
for
the
night
.
   
<EOS>
"
So
give
us
the
bundle
,
"
said
Noah
,
unstrapping
it
from
the
woman
's
shoulders
,
and
slinging
it
over
his
own
;
"
and
do
n't
yer
speak
,
except
when
yer
spoke
to
.
 
<EOS>
What
's
the
name
of
the
house
---
t
-
h
-
r
---
<EOS>
three
<EOS>
what
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Cripples
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Three
Cripples
,
"

Noah
,
"
and

sign

.
 
<EOS>
Now
,

!
 
<EOS>
Keep
close

,

come
along
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
these

,
he
pushed
the
rattling
door
with
his
shoulder
,
and
entered
the
house
,
followed
by
his

.
   
<EOS>
There
was
nobody
in
the
bar
but
a
young
Jew
,
who
,
with
his
two
elbows
on
the
counter
,
was
reading

dirty

.
<EOS>
He
stared
very
hard
at
Noah
,
and
Noah
stared
very
hard
at
him
.
   
<EOS>
If
Noah
had
been
attired
in
his
charity
-
boy
's
dress
,
there
might
have
been
some

for
the
Jew
opening

so

;
but
as

had

,

,
there
seemed

for
his

-

.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
this
the
Three
Cripples
?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
That
is
the
dabe
of
this
'
ouse
,
"
replied
the
Jew
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
gentleman
we
met
on
the
road
,
coming
up
from
the
country
,
recommended
us
here
,
"
said
Noah
,
nudging
Charlotte
,
perhaps
to
call
her
attention
to
this
most
ingenious
device
for
attracting
respect
,
and
perhaps
to
warn
her
to
betray
no
surprise
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
want
to
sleep
here
to
-
night
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I'b
dot
certaid
<EOS>
you
cad
,
"
said
Barney
,
who
was
the
attendant
sprite
;
"
but
I
'll
idquire
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Show
us
the
tap
,
and
give
us
a
bit
of
cold
meat
and
a
drop
of
beer
while
yer
inquiring
,
will
yer
?
"
said
Noah
.
   
<EOS>
Barney
complied
by
ushering
them
into
a
small
back
-
room
,
and
setting
the
required
viands
before
them
;
having
done
which
,
he
informed
the
travellers
that
they
could
be
lodged
that
night
,
and
left
the
amiable
couple
to
their
refreshment
.
   
<EOS>
Now
,
this
back
-
room
was
immediately
behind
the
bar
,
and
some
steps
lower
,
so
that
any
person
connected
with
the
house
,
undrawing
a
small
curtain
which
concealed
a
single
pane
of
glass
fixed
in
the
wall
of
the
last
-
named
apartment
,
about
five
feet
from
its

,
could
not
only
look
down
upon
any
guests
in
the
back
-
room
without
any
great
hazard
of
being
observed
(
the
glass
being
in
a
dark
angle
of
the
wall
,
between
which
and
a
large
upright
beam
the
observer
had
to
thrust
himself
)
,
but
could
,
by
applying
his
ear
to
the
partition
,
ascertain
with
tolerable

,
their
subject
of
conversation
.
 
<EOS>
The
landlord
of
the
house
had
not
withdrawn
his
eye
from
this
place
of
espial
for
five
minutes
,
and
Barney
had
only
just

from
making
the
communication
above
related
,
when
Fagin
,
in
the

of
his

's

,
came
into

to

.
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
"
said
Barney
:
 
<EOS>
"
stradegers
i
<EOS>
d
the
next
roob
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Strangers
!
"
repeated
the
old
man
in
a

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
Ad
rub
uds
too
,
"
added
Barney
.
 
<EOS>
"
Frob
the
cuttry
,
but
subthig
in
your
way
,
or
I'b
bistaked
.
"
   
<EOS>
Fagin
appeared
to
receive
this
communication
with
great
interest
.
   
<EOS>
Mounting
a
stool
,
he
cautiously
applied
his
eye
to
the
pane
of
glass
,
from
which
secret
post
he
could
see
Mr
Claypole
taking
cold
beef
from
the
dish
,
and
porter
from
the
pot
,
and
administering
homoepathic
doses
of
both
to
Charlotte
,
who
sat
patiently
by
,
eating
and
drinking
at

.
   
<EOS>
"
Aha
!
"
<EOS>
he
whispered
,
looking
round
to
Barney
,
"
I
like
that
fellow
's
looks
.
 
<EOS>
He
'd
be
of
use
to
us
;
he
knows
how
to
train
the
girl
already
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
make
as
much
noise
as
a
mouse
,
my
dear
,
and
let
me
hear
'em
talk
---
let
me
hear
'
em
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
again
applied
his
eye
to
the
glass
,
and
turning
his

to
the
partition
,
listened
attentively
:
 
with
a
subtle
and
eager
look
upon
his

,
that
might
have
appertained
to
some
old

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
I
mean
to
be
a

,
"
said
Mr
Claypole
,
kicking
out

,
and

a

,
the

of
which
Fagin
had
arrived
too
late
to
hear
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
more
jolly
old
coffins
,
Charlotte
,
but
a
gentleman
's
life
for
me
:
 
and
,
if
yer
like
,
yer
shall
be
a
lady
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
that
well
enough
,
dear
,
"
replied
Charlotte
;
"
but
tills
ai
n't
to
be
emptied
every
day
,
and
people
to
get
clear
off
after

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Tills
be
blowed
!
"
said
Mr
Claypole
;
"
there
's
more
things
besides
tills
to
be
emptied
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Pockets
,
women
's
ridicules
,
houses
,
mail
-
coaches
,
banks
!
"
said
Mr
Claypole
,
rising
with

.
   
<EOS>
"
But
you
ca
n't
do
all
that
,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
look
out
to

as

,
"
replied
Noah
.
 
<EOS>
"
They

able

.
<EOS>
Why
,
you
yourself
are
worth

women
;
I
never
see
such

sly
and
deceitful
creetur
as
yer

when
I

yer
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Lor
,
how
nice

is
to
hear

!
"
exclaimed
Charlotte
,
imprinting
a
kiss
upon
his
ugly

.
   
<EOS>
"
There
,
that
'll
do
:
 
<EOS>
do
n't
yer

too
affectionate
,
in
case
<EOS>
I
'm
cross
with
yer
,
"
said
Noah
,
disengaging
himself
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
to
be
the
captain
of
some
band
,
and
have
the
whopping
of
'em
,
and
follering
'em
about
,

.
 
<EOS>
That
would
suit
me
,
if
there
was
good

;
and
if
we
could
only
get
in
with
some

this

,
I
say
it
would
be
cheap
at
that

-

you
've

,
---
especially
as
we
do
n't

well
know
how
to
get

of

ourselves
.
"
   
<EOS>
After
expressing
this
opinion
,
Mr
Claypole
looked
into

porter
-

with
an

of
deep
wisdom
;
and
having
well
shaken
its
contents
,
nodded

to
Charlotte
,
and
took
a

,
wherewith
he
appeared
greatly

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
meditating
another
,
when
the
sudden

of

,
and

,
interrupted

.
   
<EOS>
The
stranger
was
Mr
Fagin
.
 
<EOS>
And
very
amiable
he
looked
,
and
a
very
low

he
made
,
as
he
advanced
,
and
setting
himself
down
at
the

,
ordered
something
to
drink
of
the
grinning
Barney
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
pleasant
night
,
sir
,
but
cool
for
the

year
,
"
said
Fagin
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
From
the
country
,
I
see
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
yer
see
that
?
"
asked
Noah
Claypole
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
have
not
so
much

as
that

London
,
"

,
pointing
from

's

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Yer
a

,
"

Noah
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ha
!
ha
!
<EOS>
only
hear

,
Charlotte
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
one
need

sharp
in

,

,
"

Jew
,

;
"
and
that
's
the

.
"
   
<EOS>
Fagin
followed

by

the

of

with
his
right

,
---
a

which
Noah

to

,
though
not

,
in

of

own
nose
not

large

for

.
 
<EOS>
However
,
Mr
Fagin
seemed
to
interpret

as
expressing
a
perfect

with
his
opinion
,
and
put
about
the
liquor
which
Barney
reappeared
with
,
in

.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
stuff
that
,
"
observed
Mr
Claypole
,
smacking

.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
!
"
said
Fagin
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
man
need

always
emptying
a

,
or
a
pocket
,
or
a

's
reticule
,
or
a

,
or
a
mail

,
or
a

,
if

regularly
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

no

from

than

in

,
and
looked
from

with

of
ashy

and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
!
ha
!
<EOS>
it

that
heard
you
by

.
<EOS>
It

very

me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't

,
"

,
no

,

"

;
yer've

,
Charlotte
,
<EOS>
yer
know

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No

's

,

,

,
"

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
In

?
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In

,
"

;
"
and
so

.
 
<EOS>
You
've
hit
the
right
nail
upon
the

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
There

;
that

,

I

.
 
<EOS>
And
I

you

the
young
woman
;
so
I
've
said
the
word
,
and
you
may
make
your

.
"
   
<EOS>
Noah

's

might

after
this

,
but

certainly

;
for

,
into

:
 
eyeing

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
tell
you
more
,
"
said
Fagin
,
after
he
had
reassured

girl
,
by

.
<EOS>
"
I
have
got
a
friend
that
I
think
can
gratify
your
darling

,
and
put
you
in
the

,
where

the

think

you

,
and
be

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yer
speak
as
if
yer
were
in

,
"

Noah
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
advantage
would
it
be
to
me
to

anything
else
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Fagin
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
!
 
<EOS>
Let
me

word
with
you

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
no

to

,
"

,
getting

abroad

.
<EOS>
"
She
'll
take
the
luggage
upstairs
the

.
 
<EOS>
Charlotte
,
see
to
them
bundles
.
"
   
<EOS>
This

,
which
had

with

,
was

without
the

;
and

while
Noah

.
   
<EOS>
"
She
's
kept

well
under
,
ai

?
"
<EOS>
he

as

:
 
in

a

.
   
<EOS>
"
Quite
perfect
,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
You
're

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I

I

,

,
"

Noah
.
<EOS>
"
But
,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,

?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
If

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is

;
that

!
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
top
of
the
tree
;
employs
a
power
of

;
has
the
very
best
society
in
the

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Regular
town
-
maders
?
"
asked
Mr
Claypole
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a

among

;
and
<EOS>
I

'd

,

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Should
I
have

?
"

,

-

.
   
<EOS>
"
It

n't
possibly

done
without
,
"

Fagin
,
in

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Twenty
pound
,

---
it
's

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
when

's
in

ca
n't

,
"
retorted
Fagin
.
<EOS>
"
Number
and
date
taken
,
I

?
 
<EOS>
Payment
stopped
at
the
Bank
?
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
not

.
 
<EOS>
It
'll
have
to
go
abroad
,
and

in

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
When
could
I
see
him
?
"
asked
Noah

.
   
<EOS>
"
To
-
morrow

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Where
?
"
   
"
Here
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Um
!
"
said
Noah
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
wages
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

nothing

than
a
lifer
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
by
lagging
and
a
lifer
?
"
demanded
Mr
Bolter
.
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
good
of
talking
in
that
way
to
me
;
why
do
n't
yer
speak
so
as
I
can
understand
yer
?
"
   
<EOS>
Fagin
was
about
to
translate
these
mysterious
expressions
into
the
vulgar
tongue
;
and
,
being
interpreted
,
Mr
Bolter
would
have
been
informed
that
they
represented
that
combination
of
words
,
"
transportation
for
life
,
"
when
the
dialogue
was
cut
short
by
the
entry
of
Master
Bates
,
with
his
hands
in
his
breeches
-
pockets
,
and
his
face
twisted
into
a
look
of
semi
-
comical
woe
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
up
,
Fagin
,
"
said
Charley
,
when
he
and
his
new
companion
had
been
made
known
to
each
other
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
They
've
found
the
gentleman
as
owns
the
box
;
two
or
three
more
's
a
coming
to
"
dentify
him
;
and
the
Artful
's
booked
for
a
passage
out
,
"
replied
Master
Bates
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
must
have
a
full
suit
of
mourning
,
Fagin
,
and
a
hatband
,
to
wisit
him
in
,
afore
he
sets
out
upon
his
travels
.
 
<EOS>
To
think
of
Jack
Dawkins
---
<EOS>
lummy
Jack
---
the
Dodger
---
the
Artful
Dodger
---
going
abroad
for
a
common
twopenny
-
halfpenny
sneeze
-
box
!
 
<EOS>
I
never
thought
he
'd
a
done
it
under
a
gold
watch
,
chain
,
and
seals
,
at
the
lowest
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
why
did
n't
he
rob
some
rich
old
gentleman
of
all
his
walables
,
and
go
out
as
a
gentleman
,
and
not
like
a
common
prig
,
without
no
honour
nor
glory
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
this
expression
of
feeling
for
his
unfortunate
friend
,
Master
Bates
sat
himself
on
the
nearest
chair
with
an
aspect
of
chagrin
and
despondency
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
talk
about
his
having
neither
honour
nor
glory
for
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Fagin
,
darting
an
angry
look
at
his
pupil
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Was
n't
he
always
the
top
-
sawyer
among
you
all
!
 
<EOS>
Is
there
one
of
you
that
could
touch
him
or
come
near
him
on
any
scent
!
 
<EOS>
Eh
?
"
   
"
Not
one
,
"
replied
Master
Bates
,
in
a
voice
rendered
husky
by
regret
;
"
not
one
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
what
do
you
talk
of
?
"
replied
Fagin
angrily
;
"
what
are
you
blubbering
for
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
'Cause
it
is
n't
on
the
rec
-
ord
,
is
it
?
"
said
Charley
,
chafed
into
perfect
defiance
of
his
venerable
friend
by
the
current
of
his
regrets
;
"
'cause
it
ca
n't
come
out
in
the
'
dictment
;
'cause
nobody
will
never
know
half
of
what
he
was
.
 
<EOS>
How
will
he
stand
in
the
Newgate
Calendar
?
 
<EOS>
P'raps
not
be
there
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
my
eye
,
my
eye
,
wot
a
blow
it
is
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
!
ha
!
<EOS>
"
cried
Fagin
,
extending
his
right
hand
,
and
turning
to
Mr
Bolter
in
a
fit

chuckling
which
shook
him
as
though
he
had
the
palsy
;
"
see
what
a
pride
they
take
in
their
profession
,
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
Ai
n't
it
beautiful
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bolter
nodded
assent
,
and
Fagin
,
after
contemplating
the
grief
of
Charley
Bates
for
some
seconds
with
evident
satisfaction
,
stepped
up
to
that
young
gentleman
and
patted
him
on
the
shoulder
.
   
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
,
Charley
,
"
said
Fagin
soothingly
;
"
it
'll
come
out
,
it
'll
be
sure
to
come
out
.
 
<EOS>
They
'll
all
know
what
a
clever
fellow
he
was
;
he
'll
show
it
himself
,
and
not
disgrace
his
old
pals
and
teachers
.
 
<EOS>
Think
how
young
he
is
too
!
 
<EOS>
What
a
distinction
,
Charley
,
to
be
lagged
at
his
time
of
life
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
it
is
a
honour
that
is
!
"
<EOS>
said
Charley
,
a
little
consoled
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
shall
have
all
he
wants
,
"
continued
the
Jew
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
shall
be
kept
in
the
Stone
Jug
,
Charley
,
like
a
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
Like
a
gentleman
!
 
<EOS>
With
his
beer
every
day
,
and
money
in
his
pocket
to
pitch
and
toss
with
,
if
he
ca
n't
spend
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
shall
he
though
?
"
cried
Charley
Bates
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ay
,
that
he
shall
,
"
replied
Fagin
,
"
and
we
'll
have
a
big
-
wig
,
Charley
:
 
one
that
's
got
the
greatest
gift
of
the
gab
:
 
to
carry
on
his
defence
;
and
he
shall
make
a
speech
for
himself
too
,
if
he
likes
;
and
we
'll
read
it
all
in
the
papers
---
<EOS>
"
Artful
Dodger
---
shrieks
of
laughter
---
here
the
court
was
convulsed
"
---
eh
,
Charley
,
eh
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
!
ha
!
laughed
Master
Bates
,
"
what
a
lark
that
would
be
,
would
n't
it
,
Fagin
?
 
<EOS>
I
say
,
how
the
Artful
would
bother
'em
would

he
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Would
!
"
cried
Fagin
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
shall
---
he
will
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
to
be
sure
,
so
he
will
,
"
repeated
Charley
,
rubbing
his
hands
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
see
him
now
,
"
cried
the
Jew
,
bending
his

upon
his
pupil
.
   
<EOS>
"
So
do
I
,
"
cried
Charley
Bates
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ha
!
ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
so
do
I.
 
I
see
it
all
afore
me
,
upon
my
soul
I
do
,
Fagin
.
 
<EOS>
What
a
game
!
 
<EOS>
What
a
regular
game
!
 
<EOS>
All
the
big
-
wigs
trying
to
look
solemn
,
and
Jack
Dawkins
addressing
of
'em
as
intimate
and
comfortable
as
if
he
was
the
judge
's
own
son
making
a
speech
arter
dinner
---
ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
"
   
<EOS>
In
fact
,
Mr
Fagin
had
so
well
humoured
his
young
friend
's
eccentric
disposition
,
that
Master
Bates
,
who
had
at
first
been
disposed
to
consider
the
imprisoned
Dodger
rather
in
the
light
of
a
victim
,
now
looked
upon
him
as
the
chief
actor
in
a
scene
of
most
uncommon
and
exquisite
humour
,
and
felt
quite
impatient
for
the
arrival
of
the
time
when
his
old
companion
should
have
so
favourable
an
opportunity
of
displaying
his
abilities
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
must
know
how
he
gets
on
to
-
day
,
by
some
handy
means
or
other
,
"
said
Fagin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
think
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
go
?
"
asked
Charley
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
for
the
world
,
"
replied
Fagin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
mad
,
my
dear
,
stark
mad
,
that
you
'd
walk
into
the
very
place
where
---
No
,
Charley
,
no
.
<EOS>
One
is
enough
to
lose
at
a
time
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
mean
to
go
yourself
,
I
suppose
?
"
said
Charley
with
a
humorous
leer
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
would
n't
quite
fit
,
"
replied
Fagin
shaking
his
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
why
do
n't
you
send
this
new
cove
?
"
asked
Master
Bates
,
laying
his
hand
on
Noah
's
arm
.
 
<EOS>
"
Nobody
knows
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
if
he
did
n't
mind
---
"
observed
Fagin
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mind
!
"
<EOS>
interposed
Charley
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
should
he
have
to
mind
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Really
nothing
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Fagin
,
turning
to
Mr
Bolter
,
"
really
nothing
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
I
dare
say
about
that
,
yer
know
,
"
observed
Noah
,
backing
towards
the
door
,
and
shaking

with

sober

.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
---
none
of
that
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
not
in
my
department
,
that
ai
n't
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Wot
department
has
he
got
,
Fagin
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Master
Bates
,
surveying
Noah
's
lank
form
with
much
disgust
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
cutting
away
when
there
's
anything
wrong
,
and
the
eating
all
the
wittles
when
there
's
everything
right
;
is
that
his
branch
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
,
"
retorted
Mr
Bolter
;
"
and
do
n't
yer
take
liberties
with
yer
superiors
,
little
boy
,
or
yer'll
find
yerself
in
the
wrong
shop
.
"
   
<EOS>
Master
Bates
laughed
so
vehemently
at
this
magnificent
threat
,
that
it
was
some
time
before
Fagin
could
interpose
,
and
represent
to
Mr
Bolter
that
he
incurred
no
possible
danger
in
visiting
the
police
-
office
;
that
,
inasmuch
as
no
account
of
the
little
affair
in
which
he
had
engaged
,
nor
any
description
of
his
person
,
had
yet
been
forwarded
to
the
metropolis
,
it
was
very
probable
that
he
was
not
even
suspected
of
having
resorted
to
it
for
shelter
;
and
that
,
if
he
were
properly
disguised
,
it
would
be
as
safe
a
spot
for
him
to
visit
as
any
in
London
,
inasmuch
as
it
would
be
,
of
all
places
,
the
very
last
,
to
which
he
could
be
supposed
likely
to
resort
of
his
own
free
will
.
   
<EOS>
Persuaded
,
in
part
,
by
these
representations
,
but
overborne
in
a
much
greater
degree
by
his
fear
of
Fagin
,
Mr
Bolter
at
length
consented
,
with
a
very
bad
grace
,
to
undertake
the
expedition
.
<EOS>
By
Fagin
's
directions
,
he
immediately
substituted
for
his
own
attire
,
a
waggoner
's
frock
,
velveteen
breeches
,
and
leather
leggings
:
 
all
of
which
articles
the
Jew
had
at
hand
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
likewise
furnished
with
a
felt
hat
well
garnished
with
turnpike
tickets
;
and
a
carter
's
whip
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
equipped
,
he
was
to
saunter
into
the
office
,
<EOS>
as
some
country
fellow
from
Covent
Garden
market
might
be
supposed
to
do
for
the
gratification
of
his
curiousity
;
and
as
he
was
as
awkward
,
ungainly
,
and
raw
-
boned
a
fellow
as
need
be
,
Mr
Fagin
had
no
fear
but
that
he
would
look
the
part
to
perfection
.
   
<EOS>
These
arrangements
completed
,
he
was
informed
of
the
necessary
signs
and
tokens
by
which
to
recognise
the
Artful
Dodger
,
and
was
conveyed
by
Master
Bates
through
dark
and
winding
ways
to
within
a
very
short
distance
of
Bow
Street
.
<EOS>
Having
described
the
precise
situation
of
the
office
,
and
accompanied
it
with
copious
directions
how
he
was
to
walk
straight
up
the
passage
,
and
when
he
got
into
the
side
,
and
pull
off
his
hat
as
he
went
into
the
room
,
Charley
Bates
bade
him
hurry
on
alone
,
and
promised
to
bide
his
return
on
the
spot
of
their
parting
.
   
<EOS>
Noah
Claypole
,
or
Morris
Bolter
as
the
reader
pleases
,
punctually
followed
the
directions
he
had
received
,
which
---
Master
Bates
being
pretty
well
acquainted
with
the
locality
---
were
so
exact
that
he
was
enabled
to
gain
the
magisterial
presence
without
asking
any
question
,
or
meeting
with
any
interruption
by
the
way
.
   
<EOS>
He
found
himself
jostled
among
a
crowd
of
people
,
chiefly
women
,
who
were
huddled
together
in
a
dirty
frowsy
room
,
at
the
upper
end
of
which
was
a
raised
platform
railed
off
from
the
rest
,
with
a
dock
for
the
prisoners
on
the
left
hand
against
the
wall
,
a
box
for
the
witnesses
in
the
middle
,
and
a
desk
for
the
magistrates
on
the
right
;
the
awful
locality
last
named
,
being
screened
off
by
a
partition
which
concealed
the
bench
from
the
common
gaze
,
and
left
the
vulgar
to
imagine
(
if
they
could
)
the
full
majesty
of
justice
.
   
<EOS>
There
were
only
a
couple
of
women
in
the
dock
,
who
were
nodding
to
their
admiring
friends
,
while
the
clerk
read
some
depositions
to
a
couple
of
policemen
and
a
man
in
plain
clothes
who
leant
over
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
A
jailer
stood
reclining
against
the
dock
-
rail
,
tapping
his
nose
listlessly
with
a
large
key
,
except
when
he
repressed
an
undue
tendency
to
conversation
among
the
idlers
,
by
proclaiming
silence
;
or
looked
sternly
up
to
bid
some
woman
<EOS>
"
Take
that
baby
out
,
"
when
the
gravity
of
justice
was
disturbed
by
feeble
cries
,
half
-
smothered
in
the
mother
's
shawl
,
from
some
meagre
infant
.
 
<EOS>
The
room
smelt
close
and
unwholesome
;
the
walls
were
dirt
-
discoloured
;
and
the
ceiling
blackened
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
an
old
smoky
bust
over
the
mantel
-
shelf
,
and
a
dusty
clock
above
the
dock
---
<EOS>
the
only
thing
present
,
that
seemed
to
go
on
as
it
ought
;
for
depravity
,
or
poverty
,
or
an
habitual
acquaintance
with
both
,
had
left
a
taint
on
all
the
animate
matter
,
hardly
less
unpleasant
than
the
thick
greasy
scum
on
every
inaminate
object
that
frowned
upon
it
.
   
<EOS>
Noah
looked
eagerly
about
him
for
the
Dodger
;
but
although
there
were
several
women
who
would
have
done
very
well
for
that
distinguished
character
's
mother
or
sister
,
and
more
than
one
man
who
might
be
supposed
to
bear
a
strong
resemblance
to
his
father
,
nobody
at
all
answering
the
description

him
of
Mr
Dawkins
was

.
 
<EOS>
He

;

.
   
<EOS>
Having

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

had
prudently

,

.
   
<EOS>
The

,

that

was
doing

to
his
bringing
-
up
,
and
establishing
for

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
44
.
<EOS>
The
time
arrives
for
Nancy
to
redeem
her
pledge
to
Rose
Maylie
.
<EOS>
She
fails
.
 
<EOS>
Adept
as
she
was
,
in
all
the
arts
of
cunning
and
dissimulation
,
the
girl
Nancy
could
not
wholly
conceal
the
effect
which
the
knowledge
of
the
step
she
had
taken
,
wrought
upon
her
mind
.
 
<EOS>
She
remembered
that
both
the
crafty
Jew
and
the
brutal
Sikes
had
confided
to
her
schemes
,
which
had
been
hidden
from
all
others
:
in
the
full
confidence
that
she
was
trustworthy
and
beyond
the
reach
of
their
suspicion
.
 
<EOS>
Vile
as
those
schemes
were
,
desperate
as
were
their
originators
,
and
bitter
as
were
her
feelings
towards
Fagin
,
who
had
led
her
,
step
by
step
,
deeper
and
deeper
down
into
an
abyss
of
crime
and
misery
,
<EOS>
whence
was
no
escape
;
still
,
there
were
times
when
,
even
towards
him
,
she
felt
some
relenting
,
lest
her
disclosure
should
bring
him
within
the
iron
grasp
he
had
so
long
eluded
,
and
he
should
fall
at
last
---
richly
as
he
merited
such
a
fate
---
by
her
hand
.
   
<EOS>
But
,
these
were
the
mere
wanderings
of
a
mind
unwholly
to
detach
itself
from
old
companions
and
associations
,
though
enabled
to
fix
itself
steadily
on
one
object
,
and
resolved
not
to
be
turned
aside
by
any
consideration
.
 
<EOS>
Her
fears
for
Sikes
would
have
been
more
powerful
inducements
to
recoil
while
there
was
yet
time
;
but
she
had
stipulated
that
her
secret
should
be
rigidly
kept
,
she
had
dropped
no
clue
which
could
lead
to
his
discovery
,
she
had
refused
,
even
for
his
sake
,
a
refuge
from
all
the
guilt
and
wretchedness
that
encompasses
her
---
and
what
more
could
she
do
!
<EOS>
She
was
resolved
.
   
<EOS>
Though
all
her
mental
struggles
terminated
in
this
conclusion
,
they
forced
themselves
upon
her
,
again
and
again
,
and
left
their
traces
too
.
 
<EOS>
She
grew
pale
and
thin
,
even
within
a
few
days
.
 
<EOS>
At
times
,
she
took
no
heed
of
what
was
passing
before
her
,
or
no
part
in
conversations
where
once
,
she
would
have
been
the
loudest
.
 
<EOS>
At
other
times
,
she
laughed
without
merriment
,
and
was
noisy
without
a
moment
afterwards
---
she
sat
silent
and
dejected
,
brooding
with
her
head
upon
her
hands
,
while
the
very
effort
by
which
she
roused
herself
,
told
,
more
forcibly
than
even
these
indications
,
that
she
was
ill
at
ease
,
and
that
her
thoughts
were
occupied
with
matters
very
different
and
distant
from
those
in
the
course
of
discussion
by
her
companions
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
Sunday
night
,
and
the
bell
of
the
nearest
church
struck
the
hour
.
 
<EOS>
Sikes
and
the
Jew
were

,
but
they
paused
to

.
 
<EOS>
The
girl
looked
up

the
low

,
and
listened
too
.
 
<EOS>
Eleven
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

this

,
"

,

"
Dark

<EOS>

.

"

.

<EOS>
"
Nance
.

?
<EOS>
"
   
"

.

"

?

.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
hear
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know

,
"
replied

girl
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
I
do
,
"
said
Sikes
,

<EOS>
"
Nowhere
.
 
<EOS>
Sit

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

'm

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

<EOS>
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

in

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
you
wo
n't

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
With

,

There
,
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
What

,

?
 
<EOS>
Do

<EOS>
"

"

---

Fagin
<EOS>
,
"
she

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

something

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
!
"

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Do

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Hear

!
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
Aye
!
 
<EOS>
And

as'll

.
 
<EOS>
Wot

,

!
 
<EOS>
Wot

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Let

,
"

girl

,

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Get

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
---

---
<EOS>
Never
---

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
Sikes

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
She

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

.

"
Whew
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Wot

!
"
   
<EOS>

,

,

.

"

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

"

,

<EOS>
Fagin

.
   
<EOS>
"
She

,

,

;

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
We

poor

,

,

,

;

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
That

,

,

<EOS>
"
Hush
!
"
   
<EOS>

Fagin

.
<EOS>

Sikes
that

<EOS>

"

,
"

.

<EOS>

If

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
worse

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
She

,

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
Fagin
walked
towards
his
home
,
intent
upon
the
thoughts
that
were
working
within
his
brain
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
conceived
the
idea
---
not
from
what
had
just
passed
though
that
had
tended
to
confirm
him
,
but
slowly
and
by
degrees
---
that
Nancy
,
wearied
of
the
housebreaker
's
brutality
,
had
conceived
an
attachment
for
some
new
friend
.
 
<EOS>
Her
altered
manner
,
her
repeated
absences
from
home
alone
,
her
comparative
indifference
to
the
interests
of
the
gang
for
which
she
had
once
been
so
zealous
,
and
,
added
to
these
,
her
desperate
impatience
to
leave
home
that
night
at
a
particular
hour
,
all
favoured
the
supposition
,
and
rendered
it
,
to
him
at
least
,
almost
matter
of
certainty
.
 
<EOS>
The
object
of
this
new
liking
was
not
among
his
myrmidons
.
 
<EOS>
He
would
be
a
valuable
acquisition
with
such
an
assistant
as
Nancy
,
and
must
(
thus
Fagin
argued
)
be
secured
without
delay
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
another
,
and
a
darker
object
,
to
be
gained
.
 
<EOS>
Sikes
knew
too
much
,
and
his
ruffian
taunts
had
not
galled
Fagin
the
less
,
because
the
wounds
were
hidden
.
 
<EOS>
The
girl
must
know
,
well
,
that
if
she
shook
him
off
,
she
could
never
be
safe
from
his
fury
,
and
that
it
would
be
surely
wreaked
---
to
the
maiming
of
limbs
,
or
perhaps
the
loss
of
life
---
on
the
object
of
her
more
recent

.
   
<EOS>
"
With
a
little
persuasion
,
"
thought
Fagin
,
"
what
more
likely
than
that
she
would
consent
to
poison
him
?
 
<EOS>
Women
have
done
such
things
,
and
worse
,
to
secure
the
same
object
before
now
.
 
<EOS>
There
would
be
the
dangerous
villain
:
 
<EOS>
the
man
I
hate
:
 
gone
;
another
secured
in
his
place
;
and
my
influence
over
the
girl
,
with
a
knowledge
of
this
crime
to
back
it
,
unlimited
.
"
   
<EOS>
These
things
passed
through
the
mind
of
Fagin
,
during
the
short
time
he
sat
alone
,
in
the
housebreaker
's
room
;
and
with
them
uppermost
in
his
thoughts
,
he
had
taken
the
opportunity
afterwards
afforded
him
,
of
sounding
the
girl
in
the
broken
hints
he
threw
out
at

.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
expression
of
surprise
,
no
assumption
of
an
inability
to
understand
his
meaning
.
 
<EOS>
The
girl
clearly
comprehended
it
.
 
<EOS>
Her
glance
at
parting
showed
THAT
.
   
<EOS>
But
perhaps
she
would
recoil
from
a
plot
to
take
the
life
of
Sikes
,
and
that
was
one
of
the
chief
ends
to
be
attained
.
<EOS>
"
How
,
"
thought
Fagin
,
as
he
crept
homeward
,
"
can
I
increase
my
influence
with
her
?
 
<EOS>
what
new
power
can
I
acquire
?
"
   
<EOS>
Such
brains
are
fertile
in
expedients
.
 
<EOS>
If
,
without
extracting
a
confession
from
herself
,
he
laid
a
watch
,
discovered
the
object
of
her
altered

,
and
threatened
to
reveal
the
whole
history
to
Sikes
(
of
whom
she
stood
in
no
common
fear
)
unless
she
entered
into
his
designs
,
could
he
not
secure
her
compliance
?
   
<EOS>
"
I
can
,
"
said
Fagin
,
almost
aloud
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
durst
not
refuse
me
then
.
 
<EOS>
Not
for
her
life
,
not
for
her
life
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
it
all
.
 
<EOS>
The
means
are
ready
,
and
shall
be
set
to
work
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
have
you
yet
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
cast
back
a
dark
look
,
and
a
threatening
motion
of
the
hand
,
towards
the
spot
where
he
had
left
the
bolder
villian
;
and
went
on
his
way
:
 
<EOS>
busying
his
bony
hands
in
the
folds
of
his
tattered
garment
,
which
he
wrenched
tightly
in
his
grasp
,
as
though
there
were
a
hated
enemy
crushed
with
every
motion
of
his
fingers
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
45
.
<EOS>
Noah
Claypole
is
employed
by
fagin
on
a
secret
mission
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
man
was
up
,
betimes
,
next
morning
,
and
waited
impatiently
for
the
appearance
of
his
new
associate
,
who
after
a
delay
that
seemed
interminable
,
at
length
presented
himself
,
and
commenced
a
voracious
assault
on
the
breakfast
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bolter
,
"
said
Fagin
,
drawing
up
a
chair
and
seating
himself
opposite
Morris
Bolter
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
here
I
am
,
"
returned
Noah
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
?
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
yer
ask
me
to
do
anything
till
I
have
done
eating
.
<EOS>
That
's
a
great
fault
in
this
place
.
 
<EOS>
Yer
never
get
time
enough
over
yer
meals
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
can
talk
as
you
eat
,
ca
n't
you
?
"
said
Fagin
,
cursing
his
dear
young
friend
's
greediness
from
the
very
bottom
of
his
heart
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
yes
,
I
can
talk
.
 
<EOS>
I
get
on
better
when
I
talk
,
"
said
Noah
,
cutting
a
monstrous
slice
of
bread
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
's
Charlotte
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Out
,
"
said
Fagin
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
sent
her
out
this
morning
with
the
other
young
woman
,
because
I
wanted
us
to
be
alone
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
said
Noah
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
wish
yer'd
ordered
her
to
make
some
buttered
toast
first
.
 
<EOS>
Well
.
 
<EOS>
Talk
away
.
 
<EOS>
Yer
wo
n't
interrupt
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
seemed
,
indeed
,
no
great
fear
of
anything
interrupting
him
,
as
he
had
evidently
sat
down
with
a
determination
to
do
a
great
deal
of
business
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
did
well
yesterday
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Fagin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Beautiful
!
 
<EOS>
Six
shillings
and
ninepence
halfpenny
on
the
very
first
day
!
 
<EOS>
The
kinchin
lay
will
be
a
fortune
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
forget
to
add
three
pint
-
pots
and
a
milk
-
can
,
"
said
Mr
Bolter
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
The
pint
-
pots
were
great
strokes
of
genius
:
but
the
milk
-
can
was
a
perfect
masterpiece
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pretty
well
,
I
think
,
for
a
beginner
,
"
remarked
Mr
Bolter
complacently
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
pots
I
took
off
airy
railings
,
and
the
milk
-
can
was
standing
by
itself
outside
a
public
-
house
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
it
might
get
rusty
with
the
rain
,
or
catch
cold
,
yer
know
.
 
<EOS>
Eh
?
 
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
"
   
<EOS>
Fagin
affected
to
laugh
very
heartily
;
and
Mr
Bolter
having
had
his
laugh
out
,
took
a
series
of
large
bites
,
which
finished
his
first
hunk
of
bread
and
butter
,
and
assisted
himself
to
a
second
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
want
you
,
Bolter
,
"
said
Fagin
,
leaning
over
the
table
,
"
to
do
a
piece
of
work
for
me
,
my
dear
,
that
needs
great
care
and
caution
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
"
rejoined
Bolter
,
"
do
n't
yer
go
shoving
me
into
danger
,
or
sending
me
any
more
o
'
yer
police
-
offices
.
<EOS>
That
do
n't
suit
me
,
that
do
n't
;
and
so
I
tell
yer
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
not
the
smallest
danger
in
it
---
not
the
very
smallest
,
"
said
the
Jew
;
"
it
's
only
to
dodge
a
woman
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
An
old
woman
?
"
demanded
Mr
Bolter
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
young
one
,
"
replied
Fagin
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
can
do
that
pretty
well
,
I
know
,
"
said
Bolter
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
was
a
regular
cunning
sneak
when
I
was
at
school
.
 
<EOS>
What
am
I
to
dodge
her
for
?
 
<EOS>
Not
to
---
"
   
"
Not
to
do
anything
,
but
to
tell
me
where
she
goes
,
who
she
sees
,
and
,
if
possible
,
what

;
to
remember
the
street
,
if
it
is
a

,
or
the
house
,
if
it
is
a
house
;
and
to
bring
me
back
all
the

you
can
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
'll
yer
give
me
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Noah
,
setting
down
his
cup
,
and
looking
his
employer
,
eagerly
,
in
the
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
If
you
do
it
well
,
a
pound
,
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
One
pound
,
"
said
Fagin
,
wishing
to
interest
him
in
the
scent
as
much
as
possible
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
that
's
what
I
never
gave
yet
,
for
any
job
of
work
where
there
was
n't
valuable
consideration
to
be
gained
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Who
is
she
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Noah
.
   
<EOS>
"
One
of
us
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
Lor
!
"
cried
Noah
,
curling
up
his
nose
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yer
doubtful
of
her
,
are
yer
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
had
found
out
some
new
friends
,
my
dear
,
and
I
must
know
who
they
are
,
"
replied
Fagin
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
see
,
"
said
Noah
.
 
<EOS>
"
Just
to
have
the
pleasure
of
knowing
them
,
if
they
're
respectable
people
,
eh
?
 
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
I
'm
your
man
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
knew
you
would
be
,
"
cried
Fagin
,
eleated
by
the
success
of
his

.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
,
of
course
,
"
replied
Noah
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
is
she
?
<EOS>
Where
am
I
to
wait
for

?
 
<EOS>
Where
am
I
to

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
All
that
,
my
dear
,
you

.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
point
her
out
at
the

,
"
said
Fagin
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
keep
ready
,
and
leave
the
rest
to
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
That
night
,
and
the
next
,
and
the
next
again
,
the
spy
sat
booted
and
equipped
in
his
carter
's
dress
:
 
ready
to
turn
out
at
a
word
from
Fagin
.
 
<EOS>
Six
nights
passed
---
six
long
weary
nights
---
and
on
each
,
Fagin
came
home
with
a
disappointed
face
,
and
briefly
intimated
that
it
was
not
yet
time
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
seventh
,
he
returned
earlier
,
and
with
an
exultation
he
could
not
conceal
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
Sunday
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
goes
abroad
to
-
night
,
"
said
Fagin
,
"
and
on
the
right
errand
,
I
'm
sure
;
for
she
has
been
alone
all
day
,
and
the
man
she
is
afraid
of
will
not
be
back
much
before
daybreak
.
 
<EOS>
Come
with
me
.
<EOS>
Quick
!
"
   
<EOS>
Noah
started
up
without
saying
a
word
;
for
the
Jew
was
in
a
state
of
such
intense
excitement
that
it
infected
him
.
 
<EOS>
They
left
the
house
stealthily
,
and
hurrying
through
a
labyrinth
of
streets
,
arrived
at
length
before
a
public
-
house
,
which
Noah
recognised
as
the
same
in
which
he
had
slept
,
on
the
night
of
his
arrival
in
London
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
past
eleven
o'clock
,
and
the
door
was
closed
.
 
<EOS>
It
opened
softly
on
its
hinges
as
Fagin
gave
a
low
whistle
.
<EOS>
They
entered
,
without
noise
;
and
the
door
was
closed
behind
them
.
   
<EOS>
Scarcely
venturing
to
whisper
,
but
substituting
dumb
show
for
words
,
Fagin
,
and
the
young
Jew
who
had
admitted
them
,
pointed
out
the
pane
of
glass
to
Noah
,
and
signed
to
him
to
climb
up
and
observe
the
person
in
the
adjoining
room
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
that
the
woman
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
,
scarcely
above
his
breath
.
   
<EOS>
Fagin
nodded
yes
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
see
her
face
well
,
"
whispered
Noah
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
is
looking
down
,
and
the
candle
is
behind
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stay
there
<EOS>
,
"
whispered
Fagin
.
 
<EOS>
He
signed
to
Barney
,
who
withdrew
.
 
<EOS>
In
an
instant
,
the
lad
entered
the
room
adjoining
,
and
,
under
pretence
of
snuffing
the
candle
,
moved
it
in
the
required
position
,
and
,
speaking
to
the
girl
,
caused
her
to
raise
her
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
see
her
now
,
"
cried
the
spy
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Plainly
?
"
   
"
I
should
know
her
among
a
thousand
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
hastily
descended
,
as
the
room
-
door
opened
,
and
the
girl
came
out
.
 
<EOS>
Fagin
drew
him
behind
a
small
partition
which
was
curtained
off
,
and
they
held
their
breaths
as
she
passed
within
a
few
feet
of
their
place
of
concealment
,
and
emerged
by
the
door
at
which
they
had
entered
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hist
!
"
cried
the
lad
who
held
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dow
.
"
   
<EOS>
Noah
exchanged
a
look
with
Fagin
,
and
darted
out
.
   
<EOS>
"
To
the
left
,
"
whispered
the
lad
;
"
take
the
left
had
,
and
keep
od
the
other
side
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
did
so
;
and
,
by
the
light
of
the
lamps
,
saw
the
girl
's
retreating
figure
,
already
at
some
distance
before
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
advanced
as
near
as
he
considered
prudent
,
and
kept
on
the
opposite
side
of
the
street
,
the
better
to
observe
her
motions
.
<EOS>
She
looked
nervously
round
,
twice
or
thrice
,
and
once
stopped
to
let
two
men
who
were
following
close
behind
her
,
pass
on
.
 
<EOS>
She
seemed
to
gather
courage
as
she
advanced
,
and
to
walk
with
a
steadier
and
firmer
step
.
 
<EOS>
The
spy
preserved
the
same
relative
distance
between
them
,
and
followed
:
 
with
his
eye
upon
her
.
    
Chapter
46
.
<EOS>
The
appointment
kept
.
 
<EOS>
The
church
clocks
chimed
three
quarters
past
eleven
,
as
two
figures
emerged
on
London
Bridge
.
 
<EOS>
One
,
which
advanced
with
a
swift
and
rapid
step
,
was
that
of
a
woman
who
looked
eagerly
about
her
as
though
in
quest
of
some
expected
object
;
the
other
figure
was
that
of
a
man
,
who
slunk
along
in
the
deepest
shadow
he
could
find
,
and
,
at
some
distance
,
accommodated
his
pace
to
hers
:
 
stopping
when
she
stopped
:
 
and
as
she
moved
again
,
creeping
stealthily
on
:
 
but
never
allowing
himself
,
in
the
ardour
of
his
pursuit
,
to
gain
upon
her
footsteps
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
,
they
crossed
the
bridge
,
from
the
Middlesex
to
the
Surrey
shore
,
when
the
woman
,
apparently
disappointed
in
her
anxious
scrutiny
of
the
foot
-
passengers
,
turned
back
.
 
<EOS>
The
movement
was
sudden
;
but
he
who
watched
her
,
was
not
thrown
off
his
guard
by
it
;
for
,
shrinking
into
one
of
the
recesses
which
surmount
the
piers
of
the
bridge
,
and
leaning
over
the
parapet
the
better
to
conceal
his
figure
,
he
suffered
her
to
pass
on
the
opposite
pavement
.
<EOS>
When
she
was
about
the
same
distance
in
advance
as
she
had
been
before
,
he
slipped
quietly
down
,
and
followed
her
again
.
<EOS>
At
nearly
the
centre
of
the
bridge
,
she
stopped
.
 
<EOS>
The
man
stopped
too
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
very
dark
night
.
 
<EOS>
The
day
had
been
unfavourable
,
and
at
that
hour
and
place
there
were
few
people
stirring
.
<EOS>
Such
as
there
were
,
hurried
quickly
past
:
 
very
possibly
without
seeing
,
but
certainly
without
noticing
,
either
the
woman
,
or
the
man
who
kept
her
in
view
.
 
<EOS>
Their
appearance
was
not
calculated
to
attract
the
importunate
regards
of
such
of
London
's
destitute
population
,
as
chanced
to
take
their
way
over
the
bridge
that
night
in
search
of
some
cold
arch
or
doorless
hovel
wherein
to
lay
their
heads
;
they
stood
there
in
silence
:
 
neither
speaking
nor
spoken
to
,
by
any
one
who
passed
.
   
<EOS>
A
mist
hung
over
the
river
,
deepening
the
red
glare
of
the
fires
that
burnt
upon
the
small
craft
moored
off
the
different
wharfs
,
and
rendering
darker
and
more
indistinct
the
murky
buildings
on
the
banks
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
smoke
-
stained
storehouses
on
either
side
,
rose
heavy
and
dull
from
the
dense
mass
of
roofs
and
gables
,
and
frowned
sternly
upon
water
too
black
to
reflect
even
their
lumbering
shapes
.
<EOS>
The
tower
of
old
Saint
Saviour
's
Church
,
and
the
spire
of
Saint
Magnus
,
so
long
the
giant
-
warders
of
the
ancient
bridge
,
were
visible
in
the
gloom
;
but
the
forest
of
shipping
below
bridge
,
and
the
thickly
scattered
spires
of
churches
above
,
were
nearly
all
hidden
from
sight
.
   
<EOS>
The
girl
had
taken
a
few
restless
turns
to
and
fro
---
closely
watched
meanwhile
by
her
hidden
observer
---
when
the
heavy
bell
of
St
Paul
's
tolled
for
the
death
of
another
day
.
 
<EOS>
Midnight
had
come
upon
the
crowded
city
.
 
<EOS>
The
palace
,
the
night
-
cellar
,
the
jail
,
the
madhouse
:
 
the
chambers
of
birth
and
death
,
of
health
and
sickness
,
the
rigid
face
of
the
corpse
and
the
calm
sleep
of
the
child
:
 
midnight
was
upon
them
all
.
   
<EOS>
The
hour
had
not
struck
two
minutes
,
when
a
young
lady
,
accompanied
by
a
grey
-
haired
gentleman
,
alighted
from
a
hackney
-
carriage
within
a
short
distance
of
the
bridge
,
and
,
having
dismissed
the
vehicle
,
walked
straight
towards
it
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
scarcely
set
foot
upon
its
pavement
,
when
the
girl
started
,
and
immediately
made
towards
them
.
   
<EOS>
They
walked
onward
,
looking
about
them
with
the
air
of
persons
who
entertained
some
very
slight
expectation
which
had
little
chance
of
being
realised
,
when
they
were
suddenly
joined
by
this
new
associate
.
 
<EOS>
They
halted
with
an
exclamation
of
surprise
,
but
suppressed
it
immediately
;
for
a
man
in
the
garments
of
a
countryman
came
close
up
---
brushed
against
them
,
indeed
---
at
that
precise
moment
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
here
,
"
said
Nancy
hurriedly
,
"
I
am
afraid
to
speak
to
you
here
.
 
<EOS>
Come
away
---
out
of
the
public
road
---
down
the
steps
yonder
!
"
   
<EOS>
As
she
uttered
these
words
,
and
indicated
,
with
her
hand
,
the
direction
in
which
she
wished
them
to
proceed
,
the
countryman
looked
round
,
and
roughly
asking
what
they
took
up
the
whole
pavement
for
,
passed
on
.
   
<EOS>
The
steps
to
which
the
girl
had
pointed
,
were
those
which
,
on
the
Surrey
bank
,
and
on
the
same
side
of
the
bridge
as
Saint
Saviour
's
Church
,
form
a
landing
-
stairs
from
the
river
.
 
<EOS>
To
this
spot
,
the
man
bearing
the
appearance
of
a
countryman
,
hastened
unobserved
;
and
after
a
moment
's
survey
of
the
place
,
he
began
to
descend
.
   
<EOS>
These
stairs
are
a
part
of
the
bridge
;
they
consist
of
three
flights
.
 
<EOS>
Just
below
the
end
of
the
second
,
going
down
,
the
stone
wall
on
the
left
terminates
in
an
ornamental
pilaster
facing
towards
the
Thames
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
point
the
lower
steps
widen
:
 
so
that
a
person
turning
that
angle
of
the
wall
,
is
necessarily
unseen
by
any
others
on
the
stairs
who
chance
to
be
above
him
,
if
only
a
step
.
<EOS>
The
countryman
looked
hastily
round
,
when
he
reached
this
point
;
and
as
there
seemed
no
better
place
of
concealment
,
and
,
the
tide
being
out
,
there
was
plenty
of
room
,
he
slipped
aside
,
with
his
back
to
the
pilaster
,
and
there
waited
:
 
pretty
certain
that
they
would
come
no
lower
,
and
that
even
if
he
could
not
hear
what
was
said
,
he
could
follow
them
again
,
with
safety
.
   
<EOS>
So
tardily
stole
the
time
in
this
lonely
place
,
and
so
eager
was
the
spy
to
penetrate
the
motives
of
an
interview
so
different
from
what
he
had
been
led
to
expect
,
that
he
more
than
once
gave
the
matter
up
for
lost
,
and
persuaded
himself
,
either
that
they
had
stopped
far
above
,
or
had
resorted
to
some
entirely
different
spot
to
hold
their
mysterious
conversation
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
on
the
point
of
emerging
from
his
hiding
-
place
,
and
regaining
the
road
above
,
when
he
heard
the
sound
of
footsteps
,
and
directly
afterwards
of
voices
almost
close
at
his
ear
.
   
<EOS>
He
drew
himself
straight
upright
against
the
wall
,
and
,
scarcely
breathing
,
listened
attentively
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
far
enough
,
"
said
a
voice
,
which
was
evidently
that
of
the
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
suffer
the
young
lady
to
go
any
farther
.
 
<EOS>
Many
people
would
have
distrusted
you
too
much
to
have
come
even
so
far
,
but
you
see
I
am
willing
to
humour
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
humour
me
!
"
cried
the
voice
of
the
girl
whom
he
had
followed
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
considerate
,
indeed
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
To
humour
me
!
 
<EOS>
Well
,
well
,
it
's
no
matter
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
for
what
,
"
said
the
gentleman
in
a
kinder
tone
,
"
for
what
purpose
can
you
have
brought
us
to
this
strange
place
?
 
<EOS>
Why
not
have
let
me
speak
to
you
,
above
there
,
where
it
is
light
,
and
there
is
something
stirring
,
instead
of
bringing
us
to
this
dark
and
dismal
hole
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
told
you
before
,
"
replied
Nancy
,
"
that
I
was
afraid
to
speak
to
you
there
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
why
it
is
,
"
said
the
girl
,
shuddering
,
"
<EOS>
but
I
have
such
a
fear
and
dread
upon
me
to
-
night
that
I
can
hardly
stand
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
fear
of
what
?
<EOS>
"
asked
the
gentleman
,
who
seemed
to
pity
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
scarcely
know
of
what
,
"
replied
the
girl
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
wish
I
did
.
<EOS>
Horrible
thoughts
of
death
,
and
shrouds
with
blood
upon
them
,
and
a
fear
that
has
made
me
burn
as
if
I
was
on
fire
,
have
been
upon
me
all
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
reading
a
book
to
-
night
,
to
wile
the
time
away
,
and
the
same
things
came
into
the
print
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Imagination
,
"
said
the
gentleman
,
soothing
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
imagination
,
"
replied
the
girl
in
a
hoarse
voice
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
swear
I
saw
"
coffin
"
written
in
every
page
of
the
book
in
large
black
letters
,
---
aye
,
and
they
carried
one
close
to
me
,
in
the
streets
to
-
night
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
nothing
unusual
in
that
,
"
said
the
gentleman
.
<EOS>
"
They
have
passed
me
often
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
REAL
ONES
,
"
rejoined
the
girl
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
was
not
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
something
so
uncommon
in
her
manner
,
that
the
flesh
of
the
concealed
listener
crept
as
he
heard
the
girl
utter
these
words
,
and
the
blood
chilled
within
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
never
experienced
a
greater
relief
than
in
hearing
the
sweet
voice
of
the
young
lady
as
she
begged
her
to
be
calm
,
and
not
allow
herself
to
become
the
prey
of
such
fearful
fancies
.
   
<EOS>
"
Speak
to
her
kindly
,
"
said
the
young
lady
to
her
companion
.
"
<EOS>
Poor
creature
!
 
<EOS>
She
seems
to
need
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Your
haughty
religious
people
would
have
held
their
heads
up
to
see
me
as
I
am
to
-
night
,
and
preached
of
flames
and
vengeance
,
"
cried
the
girl
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
dear
lady
,
why
ar'n't
those
who
claim
to
be
God
's
own
folks
as
gentle
and
as
kind
to
us
poor
wretches
as
you
,
who
,
having
youth
,
and
beauty
,
and
all
that
they
have
lost
<EOS>
,
might
be
a
little
proud
instead
of
so
much
humbler
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
said
the
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
Turk
turns
his
face
,
after
washing
it
well
,
to
the
East
,
when
he
says
his
prayers
;
these
good
people
,
after
giving
their
faces
such
a
rub
against
the
World
as
to
take
the
smiles
off
,
turn
with
no
less
regularity
,
to
the
darkest
side
of
Heaven
.
 
<EOS>
Between
the
Mussulman
and
the
Pharisee
,
commend
me
to
the
first
!
"
   
<EOS>
These
words
appeared
to
be
addressed
to
the
young
lady
,
and
were
perhaps
uttered
with
the
view
of
afffording
Nancy
time
to
recover
herself
.
 
<EOS>
The
gentleman
,
shortly
afterwards
,
addressed
himself
to
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
were
not
here
last
Sunday
night
,
"
he
said
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
could
n't
come
,
"
replied
Nancy
;
"
I
was
kept
by
force
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
By
whom
?
"
   
"
Him
that
I
told
the
young
lady
of
before
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
were
not
suspected
of
holding
any
communication
with
anybody
on
the
subject
which
has
brought
us
here
to
-
night
,
I
hope
?
"
asked
the
old
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
the
girl
,
shaking
her
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
very
easy
for
me
to
leave
him
unless
he
knows
why
;
I
could
n't
give
him
a
drink
of
laudanum
before
I
came
away
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Did
he
awake
before
you
returned
?
"
inquired
the
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
;
and
neither
he
nor
any
of
them
suspect
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
,
"
said
the
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
listen
to
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
ready
,
"
replied
the
girl
,
as
he
paused
for
a
moment
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
young
lady
,
"
the
gentleman
began
,
"
has
communicated
to
me
,
and
to
some
other
friends
who
can
be
safely
trusted
,
what
you
told
her
nearly
a
fortnight
since
.
 
<EOS>
I
confess
to
you
that
I
had
doubts
,
at
first
,
whether
you
were
to
be
implicitly
relied
upon
,
but
now
I
firmly
believe
you
are
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
,
"
said
the
girl
earnestly
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
repeat
that
I
firmly
believe
it
.
 
<EOS>
To
prove
to
you
that
I
am
disposed
to
trust
you
,
I
tell
you
without
reserve
,
that
we
propose
to
extort
the
secret
,
whatever
it
may

,
from
the
fear
of
this
man
Monks
.
 
<EOS>
But
if
---
if
---
"
said
the
gentleman
,
"
he
can
not

secured
,
or
,
if

,
can
not

acted

as
we

,
you
must
deliver
up
the
Jew
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Fagin
,
"
cried
the
girl
,
recoiling
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
man
must
be
delivered
up
by
you
,
"
said
the
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
do
it
!
 
<EOS>
I
will
never
do
it
!
"
<EOS>
replied
the
girl
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Devil
that
he
is
,
and
worse
than
devil
as
he
has
been
to
me
,
I
will
never
do
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
will
not
?
"
said
the
gentleman
,
who
seemed
fully
prepared
for
this
answer
.
   
<EOS>
"
Never
!
"
returned
the
girl
.
   
<EOS>
"
Tell
me
why
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
For
one
reason
,
"
rejoined
the
girl
firmly
,
"
for
one

,
that
the
lady
knows
and
will
stand
by
me
in
,
<EOS>
I
know
she
will
,
for
I
have
her

:
 
and
for
this

,
besides
,
that
,
bad
life
as
he
has
led
,
I
have
led
a
bad

;
there
are
many

us
who
have
kept

,
and
I
'll

,
<EOS>
who
might
---
any

---
have
turned
upon
me
,
but
did

,
bad

they

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
,
"
said
the
gentleman
,

,

"
put
Monks

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

?
"
   
"
I

that

,

truth

,
there

;
there
must

Oliver

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
,
"

"
this

.
 
<EOS>
In

I

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Have

the

's

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
,
"
replied
Rose
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
true
and
faithful

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Monks
would
never
learn
how
you
knew
what
you
do
?
"
said
the
girl
,
after
a

.
   
<EOS>
"
Never
,
"
replied
the
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
intelligence
should
be
brought
to
bear
upon
him
,
that
he
could
never
even

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
a
liar
,
and
among
liars
from
a
little
child
,
"
said
the
girl
after
another
interval
of
