,
"
but
I
will
take
your
words
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
After
receving
an
assurance
from
both
,
that
she
might
safely
do
so
<EOS>
,
she
proceeded
in
a
voice
so
low
that
it
was
often
difficult
for
the
listener
to
discover
even
the
purport
of
what
she
said
,
to
describe
,
by
name
and
situation
,
the
public
-
house
whence
she
had
been
followed
that
night
.
 
<EOS>
From
the
manner
in
which
she
occasionally
paused
,
it
appeared
as
if
the
gentleman
were
making
some
hasty
notes
of
the
information
she
communicated
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
had
thoroughly
explained
the
localities
of
the
place
,
the
best
position
from
which
to
watch
it
without
exciting
observation
,
and
the
night
and
hour
on
which
Monks
was
most
in
the
habit
of
frequenting
it
,
she
seemed
to
consider
for
a
few
moments
,
for
the
purpose
of
recalling
his
features
and
appearances
more
forcibly
to
her
recollection
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
tall
,
"
said
the
girl
,
"
and
a
strongly
made
man
,
but
not
stout
;
he
has
a
lurking
walk
;
and
as
he
walks
,
constantly
looks
over
his
shoulder
,
first
on
one
side
,
and
then
on
the
other
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
forget
that
,
for
his
eyes
are
sunk
in
his
head
so
much
deeper
than
any
other
man
's
,
that
you
might
almost
tell
him
by
that
alone
.
 
<EOS>
His
face
is
dark
,
like
his
hair
and
eyes
;
and
,
although
he
ca
n't
be
more
than
six
or
eight
and
twenty
,
withered
and
haggard
.
<EOS>
His
lips
are
often
discoloured
and
disfigured
with
the
marks
of
teeth
;
for
he
has
desperate
fits
,
and
sometimes
even
bites
his
hands
and
covers
them
with
wounds
---
why
did
you
start
?
"
said
the
girl
,
stopping
suddenly
.
   
<EOS>
The
gentleman
replied
,
in
a
hurried
manner
,
that
he
was
not
conscious
of
having
done
so
,
and
begged
her
to
proceed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Part
of
this
,
"
said
the
girl
,
"
I
have
drawn
out
from
other
people
at
the
house
<EOS>
I
tell
you
of
,
for
I
have
only
seen
him
twice
,
and
both
times
he
was
covered
up
in
a
large
cloak
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
that
's
all
I
can
give
you
to
know
him
by
.
 
<EOS>
Stay
though
,
"
she
added
.
 
<EOS>
"
Upon
his
throat
:
 
so
high
that
you
can
see
a
part
of
it
below
his
neckerchief
when
he
turns
his
face
:
 
<EOS>
there
is
---
"
   
"
A
broad
red
mark
,
like
a
burn
or
scald
?
"
<EOS>
cried
the
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
's
this
?
"
said
the
girl
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
know
him
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
young
lady
uttered
a
cry
of
surprise
,
and
for
a
few
moments
they
were
so
still
that
the
listener
could
distinctly
hear
them
breathe
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
do
,
"
said
the
gentleman
,
breaking

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
by
your
description
.
 
<EOS>
We
shall
see
.
 
<EOS>
Many
people
are
singularly
like
each
other
.
 
<EOS>
It
may
not
be
the
same
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
he
expressed
himself
to
this
effect
,
with
assumed
carelessness
,
he
took
a
step
or
two
nearer
the
concealed
spy
,
as
the
latter
could
tell
from
the
distinctness
with
which
he
heard
him
mutter
,
"
It
must
be
he
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
he
said
,
returning
:
 
<EOS>
so
it
seemed
by
the
sound
:
 
to
the
spot
where
he
had
stood
before
,
"
you
have
given
us
most
valuable

,
young
woman
,
and
I
wish
you
to
be
the
better
for
it
.
<EOS>
What
can
I
do
to
serve
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
"
replied
Nancy
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
will
not
persist
in
saying
that
,
"
rejoined
the
gentleman
,
with
a
voice
and
emphasis
of
kindness
that
might
have
touched
a
much
harder
and
more
obdurate

.
<EOS>
"
Think
now
.
 
<EOS>
Tell
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
sir
,
"
rejoined
the
girl
,
weeping
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
can
do
nothing
to
help
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
past
all
hope
,
indeed
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
put
yourself
beyond
its
pale
,
"
said
the
gentleman
.
<EOS>
"
The
past
has
been
a
dreary
waste
with
you
,
of
youthful
energies
mis
-
spent
,
and
<EOS>
such
priceless
treasures
lavished
,
as
the
Creator
bestows
<EOS>
but
once
and
never
grants
again
,
but
,
for
the
future
,
you
may
hope
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
say
that
it
is
in
our
power
to
offer
you
peace
of
heart
and
mind
,
<EOS>
for
that
must
come
as
you
seek
it
;
but
a
quiet
asylum
,
either
in
England
,
or
,
if
you
fear
to
remain
here
,
in
some

,
it
is
not
only
within
the
compass
of
our
ability
but
our
most
anxious
wish
to
secure
you
.
<EOS>
Before
the
dawn
of
morning
,
before
this
river
wakes
to
the
first

of
day
-
light
,
you
shall
be
placed
as
entirely
beyond
the
reach
of
your
former

,
and

as
utter
an
absence
of
all
trace
behind

,
as
if
you

to

from
the
earth
this

.
 
<EOS>
Come
!
 
<EOS>
I
would
not
have
you
go
back
to
exchange
one
word
with
any
old
companion
,
or
take
one
look
at
any
old
haunt
,
or
breathe
the
very
air
which
is
pestilence
and
death
to

.
 
<EOS>
Quit
them
all
,
while
there
is
time
and
opportunity
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
will
be
persuaded
now
,
"

the
young

.
 
<EOS>
"
She
hesitates
,
I
am
sure
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
fear
not
,
my
dear
,
"
said
the
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
sir
,
I
do
not
,
"
replied
the
girl
,
after
a
short

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
chained
to
my
old
life
.
 
<EOS>
I
loathe
and
hate
it
now
,
<EOS>
but
I
can
not

.
 
<EOS>
I
must
have
gone
too
far
to
turn
back
,
---
<EOS>
and
yet
I
do
n't

,
for
if
you
had
spoken

me
so
,
some

,
I

.
 
<EOS>
But
,
"
she

,
looking

,
"
this
fear
comes
over
me
again
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
go
home
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Home
!
"
repeated
the
young
lady
,
with
great
stress
upon

word
.
   
<EOS>
"
Home
,
lady
,
"
rejoined
the
girl
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
such
a
home
as
I
have
raised
for
myself
with
the
work

my
whole
life
.
 
<EOS>
Let
us
part
.
<EOS>
I
shall
be
watched
or

.
 
<EOS>
Go
!
 
<EOS>
Go
!
 
<EOS>
If
I

done
you
any

all
I
ask
is
,
that
you
leave
me
,
and
let

alone
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
useless
,
"
said
the
gentleman
,
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
We
compromise
her
safety
,
perhaps
,
by
staying
here
.
 
<EOS>
We
may
have
detained
her
longer
than
she
expected
already
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
yes
,
"

girl
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
,
"
cried
the
young
lady
.
 
<EOS>
"
can
be
the
end
of
this
poor
creature
's
life
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
!
"
repeated
the
girl
.
 
<EOS>
"
Look
before
you
,
lady
.
 
<EOS>
Look
at
that
dark
water
.
 
<EOS>
How
many
times
do
you
read
of
such
as
I
who
spring
into
the

,
and
leave
no
living

,
to
care
for
,
or
bewail

.
 
<EOS>
It
may

years
hence
,
or
it

,
but
I
shall
come
to

last
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Do
not
speak
thus
,
pray
,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
will
never

,
dear

,
and

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Good
-

,
good
-

!
"
   
<EOS>
The
gentleman
turned

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
This
purse
,
"

young

.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
it
for
my

,

you
may

some

in
an

and

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
replied
the
girl
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
done
this
for

.
 
<EOS>
Let

that
to
think

.
 
<EOS>
And
yet
---
give

something
that
you
have

:
 
<EOS>
I
should
like
to

something
---
<EOS>
no
,
no
,

---
<EOS>
your

---
anything
that
I
can

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
There
.
 
<EOS>
Bless

!
 
<EOS>
God

.
<EOS>
Good
-
night
,
good
-
night
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
violent
agitation
of
the
girl
,
and
the
apprehension
of
some
discovery
which
would
subject
her
to
ill
-
usage
and

,
seemed
to
determine
the
gentleman
to
leave
her
,
as
she
requested
.
   
<EOS>
The
sound
of
retreating
footsteps
were
audible
and
the
voices
ceased
.
   
<EOS>
The
two
figures
of
the
young
lady
and
her
companion
soon
afterwards
appeared
upon
the
bridge
.
 
<EOS>
They
stopped
at
the
summit
of
the
stairs
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hark
!
"
cried
the
young
lady
,
listening
.
 
<EOS>
"
Did
she
call
!
 
<EOS>
I
thought
I
heard
her
voice
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
my
love
,
"
replied
Mr
Brownlow
,
looking
sadly
back
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
She
has
not
moved
,
and
will
not
till
we
are
gone
.
"
   
<EOS>
Rose
Maylie
lingered
,
but
the
old
gentleman
drew
her
arm
through
his
,
and
led
her
,
with
gentle
force
,
away
.
 
<EOS>
As
they
disappeared
,
the
girl
sunk
down
nearly
at
her
full
length
upon
one
of
the
stone
stairs
,
and
vented
the
anguish
of
her
heart
in
bitter
tears
.
   
<EOS>
After
a
time
she
arose
,
and
with
feeble
and
tottering
steps
ascended
the
street
.
 
<EOS>
The
astonished
listener
remained
motionless
on
his
post
for
some
minutes
afterwards
,
and
having
ascertained
,
with
many
cautious
glances
round
him
,
that
he
was
again
alone
,
crept
slowly
from
his
hiding
-
place
,
and
returned
,
stealthily
and
in
the
shade
of
the
wall
,
in
the
same
manner
as
he
had
descended
.
   
<EOS>
Peeping
out
,
more
than
once
,
when
he
reached
the
top
,
to
make
sure
that
he
was
unobserved
,
Noah
Claypole
darted
away
at
his
utmost
speed
,
and
made
for
the
Jew
's
house
as
fast
as
his
legs
would
carry
him
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
47
.
<EOS>
Fatal
consequences
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
nearly
two
hours
before
day
-
break
;
that
time
which
in
the
autumn
of
the
year
,
may
be
truly
called
the
dead
of
night
;
when
the
streets
are
silent
and
deserted
;
when
even
sounds
appear
to
slumber
,
and
profligacy
and
riot
have
staggered
home
to
dream
;
it
was
at
this
still
and
silent
hour
,
that
Fagin
sat
watching
in
his
old
lair
,
with
face
so
distorted
and
pale
,
and
eyes
so
red
and
blood
-
shot
,
that
he
looked
less
like
a
man
,
than
like
some
hideous
phantom
,
moist
from
the
grave
,
and
worried
by
an
evil
spirit
.
   
<EOS>
He
sat
crouching
over
a
cold
hearth
,
wrapped
in
an
old
torn
coverlet
,
with
his
face
turned
towards
a
wasting
candle
that
stood
upon
a
table
by
his
side
.
 
<EOS>
His
right
hand
was
raised
to
his
lips
,
and
as
,
absorbed
in
thought
,
he
hit
his
long
black
nails
<EOS>
,
he
disclosed
among
his
toothless
gums
a
few
such
fangs
as
should
have
been
a
dog
's
or
rat
's
.
   
<EOS>
Stretched
upon
a
mattress
on
the
floor
,
lay
Noah
Claypole
,
fast
asleep
.
 
<EOS>
Towards
him
the
old
man
sometimes
directed
his
eyes
for
an
instant
,
and
then
brought
them
back
again
to
the
candle
;
which
with
a
long
-
burnt
wick
drooping
almost
double
,
and
hot
grease
falling
down
in
clots
upon
the
table
,
plainly
showed
that
his
thoughts
were
busy
elsewhere
.
   
<EOS>
Indeed
they
were
.
 
<EOS>
Mortification
at
the
overthrow
of
his
notable
scheme
<EOS>
;
hatred
of
the
girl
who
had
dared
to
palter
with
strangers
;
and
utter
distrust
of
the
sincerity
of
her
refusal
to
yield
him
up
;
bitter
disappointment
at
the
loss
of
his
revenge
on
Sikes
;
the
fear
of
detection
,
and
ruin
,
and
death
;
and
a
fierce
and
deadly
rage
kindled
by
all
;
these
were
the
passionate
considerations
which
,
following
close
upon
each
other
with
rapid
and
ceaseless
whirl
,
shot
through
the
brain
of
Fagin
,
as
every
evil
thought
and
blackest
purpose
lay
working
at
his
heart
.
   
<EOS>
He
sat
without
changing
his
attitude
in
the
least
,
or
appearing
to
tkae
the
smallest
heed
of
time
,
until
his
quick
ear
seemed
to
be
attracted
by
a
footstep
in
the
street
.
   
<EOS>
"
At
last
,
"
he
muttered
,
wiping
his
dry
and
fevered
mouth
.
"
<EOS>
At
last
!
"
   
The
bell
rang
gently
as
he
spoke
.
 
<EOS>
He
crept
upstairs
to
the
door
,
and
presently
returned
accompanied
by
a
man
muffled
to
the
chin
,
who
carried
a
bundle
under
one
arm
.
<EOS>
Sitting
down
and
throwing
back
his
outer
coat
,
the
man
displayed
the
burly
frame
of
Sikes
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
!
"
he
said
,
laying
the
bundle
on
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
care
of
that
,
and
do
the
most
you
can
with
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
been
trouble
enough
to
get
;
I
thought
I
should
have
been
here
,
three
hours
ago
.
"
   
<EOS>
Fagin
laid
his
hand
upon
the
bundle
,
and
locking
it
in
the
cupboard
,
sat
down
again
without
speaking
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
did
not
take
his
eyes
off
the
robber
,
for
an
instant
,
during
this
action
;
and
now
that
they
sat
over
against
each
other
,
face
to
face
,
he
looked
fixedly
at
him
,
with
his
lips
quivering
so
violently
,
and
his
face
so
altered
by
the
emotions
which
had
mastered
him
,
that
the
housebreaker
involuntarily
drew
back
his
chair
,
and
surveyed
him
with
a
look
of
real
affright
.
   
<EOS>
"
Wot
now
?
"
cried
Sikes
.
 
<EOS>
"
Wot
do
you
look
at
a
man
so
for
?
"
   
<EOS>
Fagin
raised
his
right
hand
,
and
shook
his
trembling
forefinger
in
the
air
;
but
his
passion
was
so
great
,
that
the
power
of
speech
was
for
the
moment
gone
.
   
<EOS>
"
Damme
!
"
said
Sikes
,
feeling
in
his
breast
with
a
look
of
alarm
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
's
gone
mad
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
look
to
myself
here
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
rejoined
Fagin
,
finding
his
voice
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
---
you
're
not
the
person
,
Bill
.
 
<EOS>
I
've
no
---
<EOS>
no
fault
to
find
with
you
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
you
have
n't
,
have
n't
you
?
"
said
Sikes
,
looking
sternly
at
him
,
and
ostentatiously
passing
a
pistol
into
a
more
convenient
pocket
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
lucky
---
for
one
of
us
.
 
<EOS>
Which
one
that
is
,
do
n't
matter
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
've
got
that
to
tell
you
,
Bill
,
"
said
Fagin
,
drawing
his
chair
nearer
,
"
will
make
you
worse
than
me
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
?
"
returned
the
robber
with
an
incredulous
air
.
 
<EOS>
"
Tell
away
!
<EOS>
Look
sharp
,
or
Nance
will
think
I
'm
lost
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Lost
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Fagin
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
has
pretty
well
settled
that
,
in
her
own
mind
,
already
.
"
   
<EOS>
Sikes
looked
with
an
aspect
of
great
perplexity
into
the
Jew
's
face
,
and
reading
no
satisfactory
explanation
of
the
riddle
there
,
clenched
his
coat
collar
in
his
huge
hand
and
shook
him
soundly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Speak
,
will
you
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
;
"
or
if
you
do
n't
,
it
shall
be
for
want
of
breath
.
 
<EOS>
Open
your
mouth
and
say
wot
<EOS>
you
've
got
to
say
in
plain
words
.
 
<EOS>
Out
with
it
,
you
thundering
old
cur
,
out
with
it
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Suppose
that
lad
that
's
laying
there
---
"
Fagin
began
.
   
<EOS>
Sikes
turned
round
to
where
Noah
was
sleeping
,
as
if
he
had
not
previously
observed
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
resuming
his
former
position
.
   
<EOS>
"
Suppose
that
lad
,
"
pursued
Fagin
,
"
was
to
peach
---
to
blow
upon
us
all
---
first
seeking
out
the
right
folks
for
the
purpose
,
and
then
having
a
meeting
with
'em
in
the
street
to
paint
our
likenesses
,
describe
every
mark
that
they
might
know
us
by
,
and
the
crib
where
we
might
be
most
easily
taken
.
 
<EOS>
Suppose
he
was
to
do
all
this
,
and
besides
to
blow
upon
a
plant
we
've
all
been
in
,
more
or
less
---
of
his
own
fancy
;
not
grabbed
,
trapped
,
tried
,
earwigged
by
the
parson
and
brought
to
it
on
bread
and
water
,
---
<EOS>
but
of
his
own
fancy
;
to
please
his
own
taste
;
stealing
out
at
nights
to
find
those
most
interested
against
us
,
and
peaching
to
them
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
hear
me
?
"
cried
the
Jew
,
his
eyes
flashing
with
rage
.
 
<EOS>
"
Suppose
he
did
all
this
,
what
then
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
then
!
"
replied
Sikes
;
with
a
tremendous
oath
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
he
was
left
alive
till
I
came
,
I
'd
grind
his
skull
under
the
iron
heel
of
my
boot
into
as
many
grains
as
there
are
hairs
upon
his
head
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
if
I
did
it
!
"
cried
Fagin
almost
in
a
yell
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
,
that
knows
so
much
,
and
could
hang
so
many
besides
myself
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
"
replied
Sikes
,
clenching
his
teeth
and
turning
white
at
the
mere
suggestion
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'd
do
something
in
the
jail
that
'
ud
get
me
put
in
irons
;
and
if
I
was
tried
along
with
you
,
I
'd
fall
upon
you
with
them
in
the
open
court
,
and
beat
your
brains
out
afore
the
people
.
<EOS>
I
should
have
such
strength
,
"
muttered
the
robber
,
poising
his
brawny
arm
,
"
that
I
could
smash
your
head
as
if
a
loaded
waggon
had
gone
over
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
would
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Would
I
!
"
said
the
housebreaker
.
 
<EOS>
"
Try
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
it
was
Charley
,
or
the
Dodger
,
or
Bet
,
or
---
"
   
"
I
do
n't
care
who
,
"
replied
Sikes
impatiently
.
 
<EOS>
"
Whoever
it
was
,
I
'd
serve
them
the
same
.
"
   
<EOS>
Fagin
looked
hard
at
the
robber
;
and
,
motioning
him
to
be
silent
,
stooped
over
the
bed
upon
the
floor
,
and
shook
the
sleeper
to
rouse
him
.
 
<EOS>
Sikes
leant
forward
in
his
chair
:
 
looking
on
with
his
hands
upon
his
knees
,
as
if
wondering
much
what
all
this
questioning
and
preparation
was
to
end
in
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Bolter
,
Bolter
!
 
<EOS>
Poor
lad
!
<EOS>
"
said
Fagin
,
looking
up
with
an
expression
of
devilish
anticipation
,
and
speaking
slowly
and
with
marked
emphasis
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
's
tired
---
tired
with
watching
for
her
so
long
,
---
watching
for
her
,
Bill
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Wot
d'ye
mean
?
<EOS>
"
asked
Sikes
,
drawing
back
.
   
<EOS>
Fagin
made
no
answer
,
but
bending
over
the
sleeper
again
,
hauled
him
into
a
sitting
posture
.
 
<EOS>
When
his
assumed
name
had
been
repeated
several
times
,
Noah
rubbed
his
eyes
,
and
,
giving
a
heavy

,
looked
sleepily
about
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Tell
me
that
again
---
once
again
,
just
for
him
to
hear
,
"
said
the
Jew
,
pointing
to
Sikes
as

.
   
<EOS>
"
Tell
yer
what
?
"
<EOS>
asked
the
sleepy
Noah
,
shaking
himself
pettishy
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
about
---
NANCY
,
"
said
Fagin
,
clutching
Sikes
by
the
wrist
,
as
if
to
prevent
his
leaving
the
house
before
he
had
heard
enough
.
<EOS>
"
You
followed
her
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
   
"
<EOS>
To
London
Bridge
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Where
she
met
two
people
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
she
did
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
gentleman
and
a
lady
that
she
had
gone
to
of
her
own
accord
before
,
who
asked
her
to
give
up
all
her
pals
,
and
Monks

,
which
she
did
---
and
to
describe

,
which
she
did
---
and
to

what

was
that
we
meet
at
,
and
go
to
,
which
she
did
---
and
where

could
be
best
watched
from
,
which
she

---
and
what

the

went
there
,

.
 
<EOS>
She
did
all
this
.
 
<EOS>
She
told

all
every

without
a

,
without
a

---
<EOS>
she
did
---
did
she
not
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Fagin
,
half
mad
with

.
   
<EOS>
"
All
right
,
"
replied
Noah
,
scratching

.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
just
what
it
was
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
did
they
say
,
about

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
About
last
Sunday
!
"
replied
Noah
,
considering
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
I
told
yer
that
before
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Again
.
 
<EOS>
Tell
it
again
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Fagin
,
tightening

on
Sikes
,
and

other

,
as
the

flew

.
   
<EOS>
"
They
asked
her
,
"
said
Noah
,
who
,

,

who
Sikes

,
"
they

why

did

,
last

,

.
 
<EOS>
She
said

could
n't
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
---

?
 
<EOS>
Tell

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Because

was
forcibly
kept

Bill
,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
What

?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
What
more
of
the
man
she
had
told

of
before
?
 
<EOS>
Tell
him
that
,
tell

that
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
that
she
could
n't
very

out

doors
unless
he
knew
where
she
was

,
"

;
"
and
so
<EOS>
the
first

went
to
see
the
lady
<EOS>
,
she
---
ha
!
ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
it

,
that

---
she
gave

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hell
's
fire
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Sikes
,
breaking

from

Jew
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
go
!
"
   
<EOS>
Flinging
the
old
man
from

,
he
rushed
from

room
,
and
darted
,
wildly

,
up

stairs
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bill
,
Bill
!
"
cried
Fagin
,
following
him

.
 
<EOS>
"
A
word
.
<EOS>
Only
a
word
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
word
would
not
have
been
exchanged
,
but
that
the
housebreaker
was
unable
to
open
the
door
:
 
on
which
he
was
expending
fruitless
oaths
and
violence
,
when
the
Jew
came
panting
up
.
   
<EOS>
"
Let
me
out
,
"
said
Sikes
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
speak
to
me
;
it
's
not
safe
.
<EOS>
Let
me
out
,
I
say
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hear
me
speak
a
word
,
"
rejoined
Fagin
,
laying
his
hand
upon
the
lock
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
wo
n't
be
---
"
   
"
Well
,
"
replied
the
other
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
wo
n't
be
---
too
---
violent
,
Bill
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
day
was
breaking
,
and
there
was
light
enough
for
the
men
to
see
each
other
's
faces
.
 
<EOS>
They
exchanged
one
brief
glance
;
there
was
a
fire
in
the
eyes
of
both
,
which
could
not
be
mistaken
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
mean
,
"
said
Fagin
,
showing
that
he
felt
all
disguise
was
now
useless
,
"
not
too
violent
for
safety
.
 
<EOS>
Be
crafty
,
Bill
,
and
not
too
bold
.
"
   
<EOS>
Sikes
made
no
reply
;
but
,
pulling
open
the
door
,
of
which
Fagin
had
turned
the
lock
,
dashed
into
the
silent
streets
.
   
<EOS>
Without
one
pause
,
or
moment
's
consideration
;
without
once
turning
his
head
to
the
right
or
left
,
or
raising
his
eyes
to
the
sky
,
or
lowering
them
to
the
ground
,
but
looking
straight
before
him
with
savage
resolution
:
 
his
teeth
so
tightly
compressed
that
the
strained
jaw
seemed
starting
through
his
skin
;
the
robber
held
on
his
headlong
course
,
nor
muttered
a
word
,
nor
relaxed
a
muscle
,
until
he
reached
his
own
door
.
 
<EOS>
He
opened
it
,
softly
,
with
a
key
;
strode
lightly
up
the
stairs
;
and
entering
his
own
room
,
double
-
locked
the
door
,
and
lifting
a
heavy
table
against
it
,
drew
back
the
curtain
of
the
bed
.
   
<EOS>
The
girl
was
lying
,
half
-
dressed
,
upon
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
roused
her
from
her
sleep
,
for
she
raised
herself
with
a
hurried
and
startled
look
.
   
<EOS>
"
Get
up
!
"
said
the
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
you
,
Bill
!
"
said
the
girl
,
with
an
expression
of
pleasure
at
his
return
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
,
"
was
the
reply
.
 
<EOS>
"
Get
up
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
candle
burning
,
but
the
man
hastily
drew
it
from
the
candlestick
,
and
hurled
it
under
the
grate
.
 
<EOS>
Seeing
the
faint
light
of
early
day
without
,
the
girl
rose
to
undraw
the
curtain
.
   
<EOS>
"
Let
it
be
,
"
said
Sikes
,
thrusting
his
hand
before
her
.
<EOS>
"
There
's
enough
light
for
wot
<EOS>
I
've
got
to
do
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Bill
,
"
said
the
girl
,
in
the
low
voice
of
alarm
,
"
why
do
you
look
like
that
at
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
robber
sat
regarding
her
,
for
a
few
seconds
,
with
dilated
nostrils
and
heaving
breast
;
and
then
,
grasping
her
by
the
head
and
throat
,
dragged
her
into
the
middle
of
the
room
,
and
looking
once
towards
the
door
,
placed
his
heavy
hand
upon
her
mouth
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bill
,
Bill
!
"
gasped
the
girl
,
wrestling
with
the
strength
of
mortal
fear
,
---
<EOS>
"
I
---
I
wo
n't
scream
or
cry
---
not
once
<EOS>
---
hear
me
---
speak
to
me
---
tell
me
what
I
have
done
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
know
,
you
she
devil
!
"
returned
the
robber
,
suppressing
his
breath
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
were
watched
to
-
night
;
every
word
you
said
was
heard
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
spare
my
life
for
the
love
of
Heaven
,
as
I
spared
yours
,
"
rejoined
the
girl
,
clinging
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Bill
,
dear
Bill
,
you
can
not
have
the
heart
to
kill
me
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
think
of
all
I
have
given
up
,
only
this
one
night
,
for
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
SHALL
have
time
to
think
,
and
save
yourself
this
crime
;
I
will
not
loose
my
hold
,
you
can
not
throw
me
off
.
 
<EOS>
Bill
,
Bill
,
for
dear
God
's
sake
,
for
your
own
,
for
mine
,
stop
before
you
spill
my
blood
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
true
to
you
,
upon
my
guilty
soul
I
have
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
man
struggled
violently
,
to
release
his
arms
;
but
those
of
the
girl
were
clasped
round
his
,
and
tear
her
as
he
would
,
he
could
not
tear
them
away
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bill
,
"
cried
the
girl
,
striving
to
lay
her
head
upon
his
breast
,
"
the
gentleman
and
<EOS>
that
dear
lady
,
told
me
to
-
night
of
a
home
in
some
foreign
country
where
I
could
end
my
days
in
solitude
and
peace
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
see
them
again
,
and
beg
them
,
on
my
knees
,
to
show
the
same
mercy
and
goodness
to
you
;
and
let
us
both
leave
this
dreadful
place
,
and
far
apart
lead
better
lives
,
and
forget
how
we
have
lived
,
except
in
prayers
,
and
never
see
each
other
more
.
<EOS>
It
is
never
too
late
to
repent
.
 
<EOS>
They
told
me
so
---
<EOS>
I
feel
it
now
---
but
we
must
have
time
---
a
little
,
little
time
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
housebreaker
freed
one
arm
,
and
grasped
his
pistol
.
<EOS>
The
certainty
of
immediate
detection
if
he
fired
,
flashed
across
his
mind
even
in
the
midst
of
his
fury
;
and
he
beat
it
twice
with
all
the
force
he
could
summon
,
upon
the
upturned
face
that
almost
touched
his
own
.
   
<EOS>
She
staggered
and
fell
:
 
<EOS>
nearly
blinded
with
the
blood
that
rained
down
from
a
deep
gash
in
her
forehead
;
but
raising
herself
,
with
difficulty
,
on
her
knees
,
drew
from
her
bosom
a
white
handkerchief
---
Rose
Maylie
's
own
---
and
holding
it
up
,
in
her
folded
hands
,
as
high
towards
Heaven
as
her
feeble
strength
would
allow
,
breathed
one
prayer
for
mercy
to
her
Maker
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
ghastly
figure
to
look
upon
.
 
<EOS>
The
murderer
staggering
backward
to
the
wall
,
and
shutting
out
the
sight
with
his
hand
,
seized
a
heavy
club
and
struck
her
down
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
48
.
<EOS>
The
flight
of
Sikes
.
 
<EOS>
Of
all
bad
deeds
that
,
under
cover
of
the
darkness
,
had
been
committed
with
wide
London
's
bounds
since
night
hung
over
it
,
that
was
the
worst
.
 
<EOS>
Of
all
the
horrors
that
rose
with
an
ill
scent
upon
the
morning
air
<EOS>
,
that
was
the
foulest
and
most
cruel
.
   
<EOS>
The
sun
---
the
bright
sun
,
that
brings
back
,
not
light
alone
,
but
new
life
,
and
hope
,
and
freshness
to
man
<EOS>
---
burst
upon
the
crowded
city
in
clear
and
radiant
glory
.
 
<EOS>
Through
costly
-
coloured
glass
and
paper
-
mended
window
,
through
cathedral
dome
and
rotten
crevice
,
it
shed
its
equal
ray
.
 
<EOS>
It
lighted
up
the
room
where
the
murdered
woman
lay
.
 
<EOS>
It
did
.
 
<EOS>
He
tried
to
shut
it
out
,
but
it
would
stream
in
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
sight
had
been
a
ghastly
one
in
the
dull
morning
,
what
was
it
,
now
,
in
all
that
brilliant
light
!
   
<EOS>
He
had
not
moved
;
he
had
been
afraid
to
stir
.
 
<EOS>
There
had
been
a
moan
and
motion
of
the
hand
;
and
,
with
terror
added
to
rage
,
he
had
struck
and
struck
again
.
 
<EOS>
Once
he
threw
a
rug
over
it
;
but
it
was
worse
to
fancy
the
eyes
,
and
imagine
them
moving
towards
him
,
than
to
see
them
glaring
upward
,
as
if
watching
the
reflection
of
the
pool
of
gore
that
quivered
and
danced
in
the
sunlight
on
the
ceiling
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
plucked
it
off
again
.
 
<EOS>
And
there
was
the
body
---
mere
flesh
and
blood
,
nor
more
---
but
such
flesh
,
and
so
much
blood
!
   
<EOS>
He
struck
a
light
,
kindled
a
fire
,
and
thrust
the
club
into
it
.
<EOS>
There
was
hair
upon
the
end
,
which
blazed
and
shrunk
into
a
light
cinder
,
and
,
caught
by
the
air
,
whirled
up
the
chimney
.
 
<EOS>
Even
that
frightened
him
,
sturdy
as
he
was
;
but
he
held
the
weapon
till
it
broke
,
and
then
piled
it
on
the
coals
to
burn
away
,
and
smoulder
into
ashes
.
 
<EOS>
He
washed
himself
,
and
rubbed
his
clothes
;
there
were
spots
that
would
not
be
removed
,
but
he
cut
the
pieces
out
,
and
burnt
them
.
 
<EOS>
How
those
stains
were
dispersed
about
the
room
!
 
<EOS>
The
very
feet
of
the
dog
were
bloody
.
   
<EOS>
All
this
time
he
had
,
never
once
,
turned
his
back
upon
the
corpse
;
no
,
not
for
a
moment
.
 
<EOS>
Such
preparations
completed
,
he
moved
,
backward
,
towards
the
door
:
 
dragging
the
dog
with
him
,
lest
he
should
soil
his
feet
anew
and
carry
out
new
evidence
of
the
crime
into
the
streets
.
<EOS>
He
shut
the
door
softly
,
locked
it
,
took
the
key
,
and
left
the
house
.
   
<EOS>
He
crossed
over
,
and
glanced
up
at
the
window
,
to
be
sure
that
nothing
was
visible
from
the
outside
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
the
curtain
still
drawn
,
which
she
would
have
opened
to
admit
the
light
she
never
saw
again
.
 
<EOS>
It
lay
nearly
under
there
.
 
<EOS>
HE
knew
that
.
 
<EOS>
God
,
how
the
sun
poured
down
upon
the
very
spot
!
   
<EOS>
The
glance
was
instantaneous
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
relief
to
have
got
free
of
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
He
whistled
on
the
dog
,
and
walked
rapidly
away
.
   
<EOS>
He
went
through
Islington
;
strode
up
the
hill
at
Highgate
on
which
stands
the
stone
in
honour
of
Whittington
;
turned
down
to
Highgate
Hill
,
unsteady
of
purpose
,
and
uncertain
where
to
go
;
struck
off
to
the
right
again
,
almost
as
soon
as
he
began
to
descend
it
;
and
taking
the
foot
-
path
across
the
fields
,
skirted
Caen
Wood
,
and
so
came
on
Hampstead
Heath
.
 
<EOS>
Traversing
the
hollow
by
the
Vale
of
Heath
,
he
mounted
the
opposite
bank
,
and
crossing
the
road
which
joins
the
villages
of
Hampstead
and
Highgate
,
made
along
the
remaining
portion
of
the
heath
to
the
fields
at
North
End
,
in
one
of
which
he
laid
himself
down
under
a
hedge
,
and
slept
.
   
<EOS>
Soon
he
was
up
again
,
and
away
,
---
not
far
into
the
country
,
but
back
towards
London
by
the
high
-
road
---
then
back
again
---
then
over
another
part
of
the
same
ground
as
he
already
traversed
---
then
wandering
up
and
down
in
fields
,
and
lying
on
ditches
'
brinks
to
rest
,
and
starting
up
to
make
for
some
other
spot
,
and
do
the
same
,
and
ramble
on
again
.
   
<EOS>
Where
could
he
go
<EOS>
,
that
was
near
and
not
too
public
,
to
get
some
meat
and
drink
?
 
<EOS>
Hendon
.
 
<EOS>
That
was
a
good
place
,
not
far
off
,
and
out
of
most
people
's
way
.
 
<EOS>
Thither
he
directed
his
steps
,
---
running
sometimes
,
and
sometimes
,
with
a
strange
perversity
,
loitering
at
a
snail
's
pace
,
or
stopping
altogether
and
idly
breaking
the
hedges
with
a
stick
.
 
<EOS>
But
when
he
got
there
,
all
the
people
he
met
---
the
very
children
at
the
doors
---
seemed
to
view
him
with
suspicion
.
 
<EOS>
Back
he
turned
again
,
without
the
courage
to
purchase
bit
or
drop
,
though
he
had
tasted
no
food
for
many
hours
;
and
once
more
he
lingered
on
the
Heath
,
uncertain
where
to
go
.
   
<EOS>
He
wandered
over
miles
and
miles
of
ground
,
and
still
came
back
to
the
old
place
.
 
<EOS>
Morning
and
noon
had
passed
,
and
the
day
was
on
the
wane
,
and
still
he
rambled
to
and
fro
,
and
up
and
down
,
and
round
and
round
,
and
still
lingered
about
the
same
spot
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
he
got
away
,
and
shaped
his
course
for
Hatfield
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
nine
o'clock
at
night
,
when
the
man
,
quite
tired
out
,
and
the
dog
,
limping
and
lame
from
the
unaccustomed
exercise
,
turned
down
the
hill
by
the
church
of
the
quiet
village
,
and
plodding
along
the
little
street
,
crept
into
a
small
public
-
house
,
whose
scanty
light
had
guided
them
to
the
spot
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
fire
in
the
tap
-
room
,
and
some
country
-
labourers
were
drinking
before
it
.
   
<EOS>
They
made
room
for
the
stranger
,
but
he
sat
down
in
the
furthest
corner
,
and
ate
and
drank
alone
,
or
rather
with
his
dog
:
 
to
whom
he
cast
a
morsel
of
food
from
time
to
time
.
   
<EOS>
The
conversation
of
the
men
assembled
here
,
turned
upon
the
neighboring
land
,
and
farmers
;
and
when
those
topics
were
exhausted
,
upon
the
age
of
some
old
man
who
had
been
buried
on
the
previous
Sunday
;
the
young
men
present
considering
him
very
old
,
and
the
old
men
present
declaring
him
to
have
been
quite
young
---
not
older
,
one
white
-
haired
grandfather
said
,
than
he
was
---
with
ten
or
fifteen
year
of
life
in
him
at
least
---
if
he
had
taken
care
;
if
he
had
taken
care
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
to
attract
attention
,
or
excite
alarm
in
this
.
<EOS>
The
robber
,
after
paying
his
reckoning
,
sat
silent
and
unnoticed
in
his
corner
,
and
had
almost
dropped
asleep
,
when
he
was
half
wakened
by
the
noisy
entrance
of
a
new
comer
.
   
<EOS>
This
was
an
antic
fellow
,
half
pedlar
and
half
mountebank
,
who
travelled
about
the
country
on
foot
to
vend
hones
,
stops
,
razors
,
washballs
,
harness
-
paste
,
medicine
for
dogs
and
horses
,
cheap
perfumery
,
cosmetics
,
and
such
-
like
wares
,
which
he
carried
in
a
case
slung
to
his
back
.
 
<EOS>
His
entrance
was
the
signal
for
various
homely
jokes
with
the
countrymen
,
which
slackened
not
until
he
had
made
his
supper
,
and
opened
his
box
of
treasures
,
when
he
ingeniously
contrived
to
unite
business
with
amusement
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
what
be
that
stoof
?
 
<EOS>
Good
to
eat
,
Harry
?
"
asked
a
grinning
countryman
,
pointing
to
some
composition
-
cakes
in
one
corner
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
,
"
said
the
fellow
,
producing
one
,
"
this
is
the
infallible
and
invaluable
composition
for
removing
all
sorts
of
stain
,
rust
,
dirt
,
mildew
,
spick
,
speck
,
spot
,
or
spatter
,
from
silk
,
satin
,
linen
,
cambrick
,
cloth
,
crape
,
stuff
,
carpet
,
merino
,
muslin
,
bombazeen
,
or
woollen
stuff
.
 
<EOS>
Wine
-
stains
,
fruit
-
stains
,
beer
-
stains
,
water
-
stains
,
paint
-
stains
,
pitch
-
stains
,
any
stains
,
all
come
out
at
one
rub
with
the
infallible
and
invaluable
composition
.
 
<EOS>
If
a
lady
stains
her
honour
,
she
has
only
need
to
swallow
one
cake
<EOS>
and
she
's
cured
at
once
---
<EOS>
for
it
's
poison
.
 
<EOS>
If
a
gentleman
wants
to
prove
this
,
he
has
only
need
to
bolt
one
little
square
,
and
he
has
put
it
beyond
question
---
<EOS>
for
it
's
quite
as
satisfactory
as
a

-
bullet
,
and
a
great
deal
nastier
in
the
flavour
,
consequently
the
more
credit
in
taking
it
.
 
<EOS>
One
penny
a
square
.
 
<EOS>
With
all
these
virtues
,
one
penny
a
square
!
"
   
<EOS>
There
were
two
buyers
directly
,
and
more
of
the
listeners
plainly
hesitated
.
 
<EOS>
The
vendor
observing
this
,
increased
in
loquacity
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
It
's
all
bought
up
as
fast
as
it
can
be
made
,
"
said
the
fellow
.
<EOS>
"
There
are
fourteen
water
-
mills
,
six
steam
-

,
and
a
galvanic
battery
,
always
a
-
working
upon
it
,
and
they
ca
n't
make
it
fast
enough
,
though
the
men
work
so
hard
that
they
die
off
,
and
the
widows
is
pensioned
directly
,
with
twenty
pound
a
-
year
for

the
children
,
and

.
 
<EOS>
One
penny
a
square
!
 
<EOS>
Two
half
-
pence
is
all
the
same
,
and
four
farthings
is
received
with
joy
.
 
<EOS>
One
penny
a
square
!
<EOS>
Wine
-
stains
,
fruit
-
stains
,
beer
-
stains
,
water
-
stains
,
paint
-
stains
,
pitch
-
stains
,
mud
-
stains
,
blood
-
stains
!
 
<EOS>
Here
is
a
stain
upon
the
hat
of
a
gentleman
in
company
,
that
I
'll
take
clean
out
,
before
he
can
order
me
a

of

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hah
!
"
cried
Sikes
starting
up
.
 
<EOS>
"
Give
that
back
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
take
it
clean
out
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
man
,
winking
to
the
company
,
"
before
you
can
come
across
the
room
to
get
it
.
<EOS>
Gentlemen
all
,
observe
the
dark
stain
upon
this
gentleman
's
hat
,
no
wider
than
a
shilling
,
but
thicker
than
a
half
-
crown
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
it
is
a
wine
-
stain
,
fruit
-
stain
,
beer
-
stain
,
water
-
stain
,
paint
-
stain
,
pitch
-
stain
,
mud
-
stain
,
or
blood
-
stain
---
"
   
The
man
got
no
further
,
for
Sikes
with
a
hideous
imprecation
overthrew
the
table
,
and
tearing
the
hat
from
him
,
burst
out
of
the
house
.
   
<EOS>
With
the
same
perversity
of
feeling
and
irresolution
that
had
fastened
upon
him
,
despite
himself
,
all
day
,
the
murderer
,
finding
that
he
was
not
followed
,
and
that
they
most
probably
considered
him
some
drunken
sullen
fellow
,
turned
back
up
the
town
,
and
getting
out
of
the
glare
of
the
lamps
of
a
stage
-
coach
that
was
standing
in
the
street
,
was
walking
past
,
when
he
recognised
the
mail
from
London
,
and
saw
that
it
was
standing
at
the
little
post
-
office
.
 
<EOS>
He
almost
knew
what
was
to
come
;
but
he
crossed
over
,
and
listened
.
   
<EOS>
The
guard
was
standing
at
the
door
,
waiting
for
the
letter
-
bag
.
<EOS>
A
man
,
dressed
like
a
game
-
keeper
,
came
up
at
the
moment
,
and
he
handed
him
a
basket
which
lay
ready
on
the
pavement
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
for
your
people
,
"
said
the
guard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,
look
alive
in
there
,
will
you
.
 
<EOS>
Damn
<EOS>
that
'
ere
bag
,
it
warn't
<EOS>
ready
night
afore
last
;
this
wo
n't
do
,
you
know
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Anything
new
up
in
town
,
Ben
?
"
asked
the
game
-
keeper
,
drawing
back
to
the
window
-
shutters
,
the
better
to
admire
the
horses
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
nothing
that
I
knows
on
,
"
replied
the
man
,
pulling
on
his
gloves
.
 
<EOS>
"
Corn
's
up
a
little
.
 
<EOS>
I
heerd
talk
of
a
murder
,
too
,
down
<EOS>
Spitalfields
way
,
<EOS>
but
I
do
n't
reckon
much
upon
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
that
's
quite
true
,
"
said
a
gentleman
inside
,
who
was
looking
out
of
the
window
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
a
dreadful
murder
it
was
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Was
it
,
sir
?
"
rejoined
the
guard
,
touching
his
hat
.
 
<EOS>
"
Man
or
woman
,
pray
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
woman
,
"
replied
the
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
supposed
---
"
   
"
Now
,
Ben
,
"
replied
the
coachman
impatiently
.
   
<EOS>
"
Damn
that
'
ere
bag
,
"
said
the
guard
;
"
are
you
gone
to
sleep
in
there
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Coming
!
"
cried
the
office
keeper
,
running
out
.
   
<EOS>
"
Coming
,
"
growled
the
guard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
and
so
's
the
young
'
ooman
of
property
that
's
going
to
take
a
fancy
to
me
,
but
I
do
n't
know
when
.
 
<EOS>
Here
,
give
hold
.
 
<EOS>
All
ri
---
ight
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
horn
sounded
a
few
cheerful
notes
,
and
the
coach
was
gone
.
   
<EOS>
Sikes
remained
standing
in
the
street
,
apparently
unmoved
by
what
he
had
just
heard
,
and
agitated
by
no
stronger
feeling
than
a
doubt
where
to
go
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
he
went
back
again
,
and
took
the
road
which
leads
from
Hatfield
to
St
Albans
.
   
<EOS>
He
went
on
doggedly
;
but
as
he
left
the
town
behind
him
,
and
plunged
into
the
solitude
and
darkness
of
the
road
,
he
felt
a
dread
and
awe
creeping
upon
him
which
shook
him
to
the
core
.
<EOS>
Every
object
before
him
,
substance
or
shadow
,
still
or
moving
,
took
the
semblance
of
some
fearful
thing
;
but
these
fears
were
nothing
compared
to
the
sense
that
haunted
him
of
that
morning
's
ghastly
figure
following
at
his
heels
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
trace
its
shadow
in
the
gloom
,
supply
the
smallest
item
of
the
outline
,
and
note
how
stiff
and
solemn
it
seemed
to
stalk
along
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
hear
its
garments
rustling
in
the
leaves
,
and
every
breath
of
wind
came
laden
with
that
last
low
cry
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
stopped
it
did
the
same
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
ran
,
it
followed
---
not
running
too
:
 
that
would
have
been
a
relief
:
 
but
like
a
corpse
endowed
with
the
mere
machinery
of
life
,
and
borne
on
one
slow
melancholy
wind
that
never
rose
or
fell
.
   
<EOS>
At
times
,
he
turned
,
with
desperate
determination
,
resolved
to
beat
this
phantom
off
,
though
it
should
look
him
dead
;
but
the
hair
rose
on
his
head
,
and
his
blood
stood
still
,
for
it
had
turned
with
him
and
was
behind
him
then
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
kept
it
before
him
that
morning
,
but
it
was
behind
now
---
always
.
 
<EOS>
He
leaned
his
back
against
a
bank
,
and
felt
that
it
stood
above
him
,
visibly
out
against
the
cold
night
-
sky
.
 
<EOS>
He
threw
himself
upon
the
road
---
on
his
back
upon
the
road
.
 
<EOS>
At
his
head
it
stood
,
silent
,
erect
,
and
still
---
<EOS>
a
living
grave
-
stone
,
with
its
epitaph
in
blood
.
   
<EOS>
Let
no
man
talk
of
murderers
escaping
justice
,
and
hint
that
Providence
must
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
twenty
score
of
violent
deaths
in
one
long
minute
of
that
agony
of
fear
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
shed
in
a
field
he
passed
,
that
offered
shelter
for
the
night
.
 
<EOS>
Before
the
door
,
were
three
tall
poplar
trees
,
which
made
it
very
dark
within
;
and
the
wind
moaned
through
them
with
a
dismal
wail
.
 
<EOS>
He
COULD
NOT
walk
on
,
till
daylight
came
again
;
and
here
he
stretched
himself
close
to
the
wall
---
to
undergo
new
torture
.
   
<EOS>
For
now
,
a
vision
came
before
him
,
as
constant
and
more
terrible
than
that
from
which
he
had
escaped
.
 
<EOS>
Those
widely
staring
eyes
,
so
lustreless
and
so
glassy
,
that
he
had
better
borne
to
see
them
than
think
upon
them
,
appeared
in
the
midst
of
the
darkness
:
light
in
themselves
,
but
giving
light
to
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
but
two
,
but
they
were
everywhere
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
shut
out
the
sight
,
there
came
the
room
with
every
well
-
known
object
---
some
,
indeed
,
that
he
would
have
forgotten
,
if
he
had
gone
over
its
contents
from
memory
---
each
in
its
accustomed
place
.
 
<EOS>
The
body
was
in
ITS
place
,
and
its
eyes
were
as
he
saw
them
when
he
stole
away
.
 
<EOS>
He
got
up
,
and
rushed
into
the
field
without
.
 
<EOS>
The
figure
was
behind
him
.
<EOS>
He
re
-
entered
the
shed
,
and
shrunk
down
once
more
.
 
<EOS>
The
eyes
were
there
,
before
he
had
laid
himself
along
.
   
<EOS>
And
here
he
remained
in
such
terror
as
none
<EOS>
but
he
can
know
,
trembling
in
every
limb
,
and
<EOS>
the
cold
sweat
starting
from
every
pore
,
when
suddenly
there
arose
upon
the
night
-
wind
the
noise
of
distant
shouting
,
and
the
roar
of
voices
mingled
in
alarm
and
wonder
.
 
<EOS>
Any
sound
of
men
in
that
lonely
place
,
even
though
it
conveyed
a
real
cause
of
alarm
,
was
something
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
regained
his
strength
and
energy
at
the
prospect
of
personal
danger
;
and
springing
to
his
feet
,
rushed
into
the
open
air
.
   
<EOS>
The
broad
sky
seemed
on
fire
.
 
<EOS>
Rising
into
the
air
with
showers
of
sparks
,
and
rolling
one
above
the
other
,
were
sheets
of
flame
,
lighting
the
atmosphere
for
miles
round
,
and
driving
clouds
of
smoke
in
the
direction
where
he
stood
.
 
<EOS>
The
shouts
grew
louder
as
new
voices
swelled
the
roar
,
and
he
could
hear
the
cry
of
Fire
!
<EOS>
mingled
with
the
ringing
of
an
alarm
-
bell
,
the
fall
of
heavy
bodies
,
and
the
crackling
of
flames
as
they
twined
round
some
new
obstacle
,
and
shot
aloft
as
though
refreshed
by
food
.
 
<EOS>
The
noise
increased
as
he
looked
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
people
there
---
men
and
women
---
light
,
bustle
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
like
new
life
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
darted
onward
---
straight
,
headlong
---
dashing
through
brier
and
brake
,
and
leaping
gate
and
fence
as
madly
as
his
dog
,
who
careered
with
loud
and
sounding
bark
before
him
.
   
<EOS>
He
came
upon
the
spot
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
half
-
dressed
figures
tearing
to
and
fro
,
some
endeavouring
to
drag
the
frightened
horses
from
the
stables
,
others
driving
the
cattle
from
the
yard
and
out
-
houses
,
and
others
coming
laden
from
the
burning
pile
,
amidst
a
shower
of
falling
sparks
,
and
the
tumbling
down
of
red
-
hot
beams
.
 
<EOS>
The
apertures
,
where
doors
and
windows
stood
an
hour
ago
,
disclosed
a
mass
of
raging
fire
;
walls
rocked
and
crumbled
into
the
burning
well
;
the
molten
lead
and
iron
poured
down
,
white
hot
,
upon
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
Women
and
children
shrieked
,
and
men
encouraged
each
other
with
noisy
shouts
and
cheers
.
 
<EOS>
The
clanking
of
the
engine
-
pumps
,
and
the
spirting
and
hissing
of
the
water
as
it
fell
upon
the
blazing
wood
,
added
to
the
tremendous
roar
.
 
<EOS>
He
shouted
,
too
,
till
he
was
hoarse
;
and
flying
from
memory
and
himself
,
plunged
into
the
thickest
of
the
throng
.
 
<EOS>
Hither
and
thither
<EOS>
he
dived
that
night
:
 
now
working
at
the
pumps
,
and
now
hurrying
through
the
smoke
and
flame
,
but
never
ceasing
to
engage
himself
wherever
noise
and
men
were
thickest
.
 
<EOS>
Up
and
down
the
ladders
,
upon
the
roofs
of
buildings
,
over
floors
that
quaked
and
trembled
with
his
weight
,
under
the
lee
of
falling
bricks
and
stones
,
in
every
part
of
that
great
fire
was
he
;
but
he
bore
a
charmed
life
,
and
had
neither
scratch
nor
bruise
,
nor
weariness
nor
thought
,
till
morning
dawned
again
,
and
only
smoke
and
blackened
ruins
remained
.
   
<EOS>
This
mad
excitement
over
<EOS>
,
there
returned
,
with
ten
-
fold
force
,
the
dreadful
consciousness
of
his
crime
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
suspiciously
about
him
,
for
the
men
were
conversing
in
groups
,
and
he
feared
to
be
the
subject
of
their
talk
.
 
<EOS>
The
dog
obeyed
the
significant
beck
of
his
finger
,
and
they
drew
off
,
stealthily
,
together
.
 
<EOS>
He
passed
near
an
engine
where
some
men
were
seated
,
and
they
called
to
him
to
share
in
their
refreshment
.
 
<EOS>
He
took
some
bread
and
meat
;
and
as
he
drank
a
draught
of
beer
,
heard
the
firemen
,
who
were
from
London
,
talking
about
the
murder
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
has
gone
to
Birmingham
,
they
say
,
"
said
one
:
 
"
but
they
'll
have
him
yet
,
for
the
scouts
are
out
,
and
by
to
-
morrow
night
there
'll
be
a
cry
all
through
the
country
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
He
hurried
off
,
and
walked
till
he
almost
dropped
upon
the
ground
;
then
lay
down
in
a
lane
,
and
had
a
long
,
but
broken
and
uneasy
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
He
wandered
on
again
,
irresolute
and
undecided
,
and
oppressed
with
the
fear
of
another
solitary
night
.
   
<EOS>
Suddenly
,
he
took
the
desperate
resolution
to
going
back
to
London
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
somebody
to
speak
to
there
,
at
all
event
,
"
he
thought
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
good
hiding
-
place
,
too
.
 
<EOS>
They
'll
never
expect
to
nab
me
there
,
after
this
country
scent
.
 
<EOS>
Why
ca
n't
I
lie
by
for
a
week
or
so
,
and
,
forcing
blunt
from
Fagin
,
get
abroad
to
France
?
 
<EOS>
Damme
,
I
'll
risk
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
acted
upon
this
impluse
without
delay
,
and
choosing
the
least
frequented
roads
<EOS>
began
his
journey
back
,
resolved
to
lie
concealed
within
a
short
distance
of
the
metropolis
,
and
,
entering
it
at
dusk
by
a
circuitous
route
,
to
proceed
straight
to
that
part
of
it
which
he
had
fixed
on
for
his
destination
.
   
<EOS>
The
dog
,
though
.
 
<EOS>
If
any
description
of
him
were
out
,
it
would
not
be
forgotten
that
the
dog
was
missing
,
and
had
probably
gone
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
This
might
lead
to
his
apprehension
as
he
passed
along
the
streets
.
 
<EOS>
He
resolved
to
drown
him
,
and
walked
on
,
looking
about
for
a
pond
:
 
picking
up
a
heavy
stone
and
tying
it
to
his
handerkerchief
as
he
went
.
   
<EOS>
The
animal
looked
up
into
his
master
's
face
while
these
preparations
were
making
;
whether
his
instinct
apprehended
something
of
their
purpose
,
or
the
robber
's
sidelong
look
at
him
was
sterner
than
ordinary
,
he
skulked
a
little
farther
in
the
rear
than
usual
,
and
cowered
as
he
came
more
slowly
along
.
 
<EOS>
When
his
master
halted
at
the
brink
of
a
pool
,
and
looked
round
to
call
him
,
he
stopped
outright
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
hear
me
call
?
 
<EOS>
Come
here
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Sikes
.
   
<EOS>
The
animal
came
up
from
the
very
force
of
habit
;
but
as
Sikes
stooped
to
attach
the
handkerchief
to
his
throat
,
he
uttered
a
low
growl
and
started
back
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
back
!
"
<EOS>
said
the
robber
.
   
<EOS>
The
dog
wagged
his
tail
,
but
moved
not
.
 
<EOS>
Sikes
made
a
running
noose
and
called
him
again
.
   
<EOS>
The
dog
advanced
,
retreated
,
paused
an
instant
,
and
scoured
away
at
his
hardest
speed
.
   
<EOS>
The
man
whistled
again
and
again
,
and
sat
down
and
waited
in
the
expectation
that
he
would
return
.
 
<EOS>
But
no
dog
appeared
,
and
at
length
he
resumed
his
journey
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
49
.
<EOS>
Monks
and
Mr
Brownlow
at
length
meet
.
 
<EOS>
Their
conversation
,
and
the
intelligence
that
interrupts
it
.
  
<EOS>
The
twilight
was
beginning
to
close
in
,
when
Mr
Brownlow
alighted
from
a
hackney
-
coach
at
his
own
door
,
and
knocked
softly
.
 
<EOS>
The
door
being
opened
,
a
sturdy
man
got
out
of
the
coach
and
stationed
himself
on
one
side
of
the
steps
,
while
another
man
,
who
had
been
seated
on
the
box
,
dismounted
too
,
and
stood
upon
the
other
side
.
 
<EOS>
At
a
sign
from
Mr
Brownlow
,
they
helped
out
a
third
man
,
and
taking
him
between
them
,
hurried
him
into
the
house
.
<EOS>
This
man
was
Monks
.
   
<EOS>
They
walked
in
the
same
manner
up
the
stairs
without
speaking
,
and
Mr
Brownlow
,
preceding
them
,
led
the
way
into
a
back
-
room
.
<EOS>
At
the
door
of
this
apartment
,
Monks
,
who
had
ascended
with
evident
reluctance
,
stopped
.
 
<EOS>
The
two
men
looked
at
the
old
gentleman
as
if
for
instructions
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
knows
the
alternative
,
"
said
Mr
Browlow
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
he
hesitates
or
moves
a
finger
but
as
you
bid
him
,
drag
him
into
the
street
,
call
for
the
aid
of
the
police
,
and
impeach
him
as
a
felon
in
my
name
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
dare
you
say
this
of
me
?
"
asked
Monks
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
dare
you
urge
me
to
it
,
young
man
?
<EOS>
"
replied
Mr
Brownlow
,
confronting
him
with
a
steady
look
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
mad
enough
to
leave
this
house
?
 
<EOS>
Unhand
him
.
 
<EOS>
There
,
sir
.
<EOS>
You
are
free
to
go
,
and
we
to
follow
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
warn
you
,
by
all
I
hold
most
solemn
and
most
sacred
,
that
instant
will
have
you
apprehended
on
a
charge
of
fraud
and
robbery
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
resolute
and
immoveable
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
are
determined
to
be
the
same
,
your
blood
be
upon
your
own
head
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
By
what
authority
am
I
kidnapped
in
the
street
,
and
brought
here
by
these
dogs
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Monks
,
looking
from
one
to
the
other
of
the
men
who
stood
beside
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
By
mine
,
"
replied
Mr
Brownlow
.
 
<EOS>
"
Those
persons
are
indemnified
by
me
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
complain
of
being
deprived
of
your
liberty
---
you
had
power
and
opportunity
to
retrieve
it
as
you
came
along
,
but
you
deemed
it
advisable
to
remain
quiet
---
<EOS>
I
say
again
,
throw
yourself
for
protection
on
the
law
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
appeal
to
the
law
too
;
but
when
you
have
gone
too
far
to
recede
,
do
not
sue
to
me
for
leniency
,
when
the
power
will
have
passed
into
other
hands
;
and
do
not
say
I
plunged
you
down
the
gulf
into
which
you
rushed
,
yourself
.
"
   
<EOS>
Monks
was
plainly
disconcerted
,
and
alarmed
besides
.
 
<EOS>
He
hesitated
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
will
decide
quickly
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
,
with
perfect
firmness
and
composure
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
wish
me
to
prefer
my
charges
publicly
,
and
consign
you
to
a
punishment
the
extent
of
which
,
although
I
can
,
with
a
shudder
,
foresee
,
I
can
not
control
,
once
more
,
I
say
,
for
you
know
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
If
not
,
and
you
appeal
to
my
forbearance
,
and
the
mercy
of
those
you
have
deeply
injured
,
seat
yourself
,
without
a
word
,
in
that
chair
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
waited
for
you
two
whole
days
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Monks
muttered
some
unintelligible
words
,
but
wavered
still
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
will
be
prompt
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
word
from
me
,
and
the
alternative
has
gone
for
ever
.
"
   
<EOS>
Still
the
man
hesitated
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
the
inclination
to
parley
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
,
"
and
,
<EOS>
as
I
advocate
the
dearest
interests
of
others
,
I
have
not
the
right
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
there
---
"
demanded
Monks
with
a
faltering
tongue
,
---
"
is
there
---
no
middle
course
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
None
.
"
   
<EOS>
Monks
looked
at
the
old
gentleman
,
with
an
anxious
eye
;
but
,
reading
in
his
countenance
nothing
but
severity
and
determination
,
walked
into
the
room
,
and
,
shrugging
his
shoulders
,
sat
down
.
   
<EOS>
"
Lock
the
door
on
the
outside
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
to
the
attendants
,
"
and
come
when
I
ring
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
The
men
obeyed
,
and
the
two
were
left
alone
together
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
pretty
treatment
,
sir
,
"
said
Monks
,
throwing
down
his
hat
and
cloak
,
"
from
my
father
's
oldest
friend
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
because
I
was
your
father
's
oldest
friend
,
young
man
,
"
returned
Mr
Brownlow
;
"
it
is
because
the
hopes
and
wishes
of
young
and
happy
years
were
bound
up
with
him
,
and
that
fair
creature
of
his
blood
and
kindred
who
rejoined
her
God
in
youth
,
and
left
me
here
a
solitary
,
lonely
man
:
 
<EOS>
it
is
because
he
knelt
with
me
beside
his
only
sisters
'
death
-
bed
when
he
was
yet
a
boy
,
on
the
morning
that
would
---
but
Heaven
willed
otherwise
---
have
made
her
my
young
wife
;
it
is
because
my
seared
heart
clung
to
him
,
from
that
time
forth
,
through
all
his
trials
and
errors
,
till
he
died
;
it
is
because
old
recollections
and
associations
filled
my
heart
,
and
even
the
sight
of
you
brings
with
it
old
thoughts
of
him
;
it
is
because
of
all
these
things
that
I
am
moved
to
treat
you
gently
now
---
yes
,
Edward
Leeford
,
even
now
---
and
blush
for
your
unworthiness
who
bear
the
name
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
has
the
name
to
do
with
it
?
"
asked
the
other
,
after
contemplating
,
half
in
silence
,
and
half
in
dogged
wonder
,
the
agitation
of
his
companion
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
name
to
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
"
replied
Mr
Brownlow
,
"
nothing
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
was
HERS
,
and
even
at
this
distance
of
time
brings
back
to
me
,
an
old
man
,
the
glow
and
thrill
which
I
once
felt
,
only
to
hear
it
repeated
by
a
stranger
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
very
glad
you
have
changed
it
---
<EOS>
very
---
very
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
all
mighty
fine
,
"
said
Monks
(
to
retain
his
assumed
designation
)
after
a
long
silence
,
during
which
he
had
jerked
himself
in
sullen
defiance
to
and
fro
,
and
Mr
Brownlow
had
sat
,
shading
his
face
with
his
hand
.
<EOS>
"
But
what
do
you
want
with
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
a
brother
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
,
rousing
himself
:
 
"
a
brother
,
the
whisper
of
whose
name
in
your
ear
when
I
came
behind
you
in
the
street
,
was
,
in
itself
,
almost
enough
to
make
you
accompany
me
hither
,
in
wonder
and
alarm
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
brother
,
"
replied
Monks
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
know
I
was
an
only
child
.
 
<EOS>
Why
do
you
talk
to
me
of
brothers
?
 
<EOS>
You
know
that
,
as
well
as
I.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Attend
to
what
I
do
know
,
and
you
may
not
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
interest
you
by
and
by
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
that
of
the
wretched
marriage
,
into
which
family
pride
,
and
the
most
sordid
and
narrowest
of
all
ambition
,
forced
your
unhappy
father
when
a
mere
boy
,
you
were
the
sole
and
most
unnatural
issue
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
care
for
hard
names
,
"
interrupted
Monks
with
a
jeering
laugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
know
the
fact
,
and
that
's
enough
for
me
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
I
also
know
,
"
pursued
the
old
gentleman
,
"
the
misery
,
the
slow
torture
,
the
protracted
anguish
of
that
ill
-
assorted
union
.
<EOS>
I
know
how
listlessly
and
wearily
each
of
that
wretched
pair
dragged
on
their
heavy
chain
through
a
world
that
was
poisoned
to
them
both
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
how
cold
formalities
were
succeeded
by
open
taunts
;
how
indifference
gave
place
to
dislike
,
dislike
to
hate
,
and
hate
to
loathing
,
until
at
last
they
wrenched
the
clanking
bond
asunder
,
and
retiring
a
wide
space
apart
,
carried
each
a
galling
fragment
,
of
which
nothing
but
death
could
break
the
rivets
,
to
hide
it
in
new
society
beneath
the
gayest
looks
they
could
assume
.
 
<EOS>
Your
mother
succeeded
;
she
forgot
it
soon
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
rusted
and
cankered
at
your
father
's
heart
for
years
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
they
were
separated
,
"
said
Monks
,
"
and
what
of
that
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
When
they
had
been
separated
for
some
time
,
"
returned
Mr
Brownlow
,
"
and
your
mother
,
wholly
given
up
to
continental
frivolities
,
had
utterly
forgotten
the
young
husband
<EOS>
ten
good
years
her
junior
,
who
,
with
prospects
blighted
,
lingered
on
at
home
,
he
fell
among
new
friends
.
 
<EOS>
This
circumstance
,
at
least
,
you
know
already
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
I
,
"
said
Monks
,
turning
away
his
eyes
and
beating
his
foot
upon
the
ground
,
as
a
man
who
is
determined
to
deny
everything
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Not
I.
"
   
"
Your
manner
,
no
less
than
your
actions
,
assures
me
that
you
have
never
forgotten
it
,
or
ceased
to
think
of
it
with
bitterness
,
"
returned
Mr
Brownlow
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
speak
of
fifteen
years
ago
,
when
you
were
not
more
than
eleven
years
old
,
and
your
father
but
one
-
and
-
thirty
---
for
he
was
<EOS>
,
I
repeat
,
<EOS>
a
boy
,
when
HIS
father
ordered
him
to
marry
.
<EOS>
Must
I
go
back
to
events
which
cast
a
shade
upon
the
memory
of
your
parent
,
or
will
you
spare
it
,
and
disclose
to
me
the
truth
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
nothing
to
disclose
,
"
rejoined
Monks
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
must
talk
on
if
you
will
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
These
new
friends
,
then
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
,
"
were
a
naval
officer
retired
from
active
service
,
whose
wife
had
died
some
half
-
a
-
year
before
,
and
left
him
with
two
children
---
there
had
been
more
,
but
,
of
all
their
family
,
happily
but
two
survived
.
<EOS>
They
were
both
daughters
;
one
a
beautiful
creature
of
nineteen
,
and
the
other
a
mere
child
of
two
or
three
years
old
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
this
to
me
?
"
asked
Monks
.
   
<EOS>
"
They
resided
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
,
without
seeming
to
hear
the
interruption
,
"
in
a
part
of
the
country
to
which
your
father
in
his
wandering
had
repaired
,
and
where
he
had
taken
up
his
abode
.
<EOS>
Acquaintance
,
intimacy
,
friendship
,
fast
followed
on
each
other
.
<EOS>
Your
father
was
gifted
as
few
men
are
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
his
sister
's
soul
and
person
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
old
officer
knew
him
more
and
more
,
he
grew
to
love
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
that
it
had
ended
there
.
 
<EOS>
His
daughter
did
the
same
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
gentleman
paused
;
Monks
was
biting
his
lips
,
with
his
eyes
fixed
upon
the
floor
;
seeing
this
,
he
immediately
resumed
:
   
<EOS>
"
The
end
of
a
year
found
him
contracted
,
solemnly
contracted
,
to
that
daughter
;
the
object
of
the
first
,
true
,
ardent
,
only
passion
of
a
guileless
girl
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Your
tale
is
of
the
longest
,
"
observed
Monks
,
moving
restlessly
in
his
chair
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
true
tale
of
grief
and
trial
,
and
sorrow
,
young
man
,
"
returned
Mr
Brownlow
,
"
and
such
tales
usually
are
;
if
it
were
one
of
unmixed
joy
and
happiness
,
it
would
be
very
brief
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
one
of
those
rich
relations
to
strengthen
whose
interest
and
importance
your
father
had
been
sacrificed
,
as
others
are
often
---
it
is
no
uncommon
case
---
died
,
and
to
repair
the
misery
he
had
been
instrumental
in
occasioning
,
left
him
his
panacea
for
all
griefs
---
Money
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
necessary
that
he
should
immediately
repair
to
Rome
,
whither
this
man
had
sped
for
health
,
and
where
he
had
died
,
leaving
his
affairs
in
great
confusion
.
 
<EOS>
He
went
;
was
seized
with
mortal
illness
there
;
was
followed
,
the
moment
the
intelligence
reached
Paris
,
by
your
mother
who
carried
you
with
her
;
he
died
the
day
after
her
arrival
,
leaving
no
will
---
NO
WILL
---
so
that
the
whole
property
fell
to
her
and
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
At
this
part
of
the
recital
Monks
held
his
breath
,
and
listened
with
a
face
of
intense
eagerness
,
though
his
eyes
were
not
directed
towards
the
speaker
.
 
<EOS>
As
Mr
Brownlow
paused
,
he
changed
his
position
with
the
air
of
one
who
has
experienced
a
sudden
relief
,
and
wiped
his
hot
face
and
hands
.
   
<EOS>
"
Before
he
went
abroad
,
and
as
he
passed
through
London
on
his
way
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
,
slowly
,
and
fixing
his
eyes
upon
the
other
's
face
,
"
he
came
to
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
never
heard
of
that
,
"
interrupted
MOnks
in
a
tone
intended
to
appear
incredulous
,
but
savouring
more
of
disagreeable
surprise
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
came
to
me
,
and
left
with
me
,
among
some
other
things
,
a
picture
---
a
portrait
painted
by
himself
---
a
likeness
of
this
poor
girl
---
which
he
did
not
wish
to
leave
behind
,
and
could
not
carry
forward
on
his
hasty
journey
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
worn
by
anxiety
and
remorse
almost
to
a
shadow
;
talked
in
a
wild
,
distracted
way
,
of
ruin
and
dishonour
worked
by
himself
;
confided
to
me
his
intention
to
convert
his
whole
property
,
at
any
loss
,
into
money
,
and
,
having
settled
on
his
wife
and
you
a
portion
of
his
recent
acquisition
,
to
fly
the
country
---
I
guessed
too
well
<EOS>
he
would
not
fly
alone
---
and
never
see
it
more
.
 
<EOS>
Even
from
me
,
his
old
and
early
friend
,
whose
strong
attachment
had
taken
root
in
the
earth
that
covered
one
most

to
both
---
even
from
me
he

,
promising

write

me
all
,
and
after
that
to
see
me
once

,
for
the
last

on
earth
.
<EOS>
Alas
!
 
<EOS>
THAT
was
the

.
 
<EOS>
I
had
no
letter
,
and
I
never

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

"

,

,
to
the

his
---
<EOS>
I

the
term
the

,

---
of

,
resolved
that
if

were

that

.
 
<EOS>

;

.
 
<EOS>
Why
,

,

"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
When

"

<EOS>

:
 
a

What
?

"

<EOS>

"

.
 
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

---
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

's

.
 
<EOS>
Write

.

<EOS>
But

.
 
<EOS>
Which

?

.
 
<EOS>

.
"
   
<EOS>
The

;

wholly

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
50
.
<EOS>
The
pursuit
and
escape
.
 
<EOS>
Near
to
that
part
of
the
Thames
on
which
the
church
at
Rotherhithe
abuts
,
where
the
buildings
on
the
banks
are
dirtiest
and
the
vessels
on
the
river
blackest
with
the
dust
of
colliers
and
the
smoke
of
close
-
built
low
-
roofed
houses
,
there
exists
the
filthiest
,
the
strangest
,
the
most
extraordinary
of
the
many
localities
that
are
hidden
in
London
,
wholly
unknown
,
even
by
name
,
to
the
great
mass
of
its
inhabitants
.
   
<EOS>
To
reach
this
place
,
the
visitor
has
to
penetrate
through
a
maze
of
close
,
narrow
,
and
muddy
streets
,
thronged
by
the
rougest
and
poorest
of
waterside
people
,
and
devoted
to
the
traffic
they
may
be
supposed
to
occasion
.
 
<EOS>
The
cheapest
and
<EOS>
least
delicate
provisions
are
heaped
in
the
shops
;
the
coarsest
and
commonest
articles
of
wearing
apparel
dangle
at
the
salesman
's
door
,
and
stream
from
the
house
-
parapet
and
windows
.
 
<EOS>
Jostling
with
unemployed
labourers
of
the
lowest
class
,
ballast
-
heavers
,
coal
-
whippers
,
brazen
women
,
ragged
children
,
and
the
raff
and
refuse
of
the
river
,
he
makes
his
way
with
difficulty
along
,
assailed
by
offensive
sights
and
smells
from
the
narrow
alleys
which
branch
off
on
the
right
and
left
,
and
deafened
by
the
clash
of
ponderous
waggons
that
bear
great
piles
of
merchandise
from
the
stacks
of
warehouses
that
rise
from
every
corner
.
 
<EOS>
Arriving
,
at
length
,
in
streets
remoter
and
less
-
frequented
than
those
through
which
he
has
passed
,
he
walks
beneath
tottering
house
-
fronts
projecting
over
the
pavement
,
dismantled
walls
that
seem
to
totter
as
he
passes
,
<EOS>
chimneys
half
crushed
half
<EOS>
hesitating
to
fall
,
windows
guarded
by
rusty
iron
bars
that
time
and
dirt
have
almost
eaten
away
,
every
imaginable
sign
of
desolation
and
neglect
.
   
<EOS>
In
such
a
neighborhood
,
beyond
Dockhead
in
the
Borough
of
Southwark
,
stands
Jacob
's
Island
,
surrounded
by
a
muddy
ditch
,
six
or
eight
feet
deep
and
fifteen
or
twenty
wide
when
the
tide
is
in
,
once
called
Mill
Pond
,
but
known
in
the
days
of
this
story
as
Folly
Ditch
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
creek
or
inlet
from
the
Thames
,
and
can
always
be
filled
at
high
water
by
opening
the
sluices
at
the
Lead
Mills
from
which
it
took
its
old
name
.
 
<EOS>
At
such
times
,
a
stranger
,
looking
from
one
of
the
wooden
bridges
thrown
across
it
at
Mill
Lane
,
will
see
the
inhabitants
of
the
houses
on
either
side
lowering
from
their
back
doors
and
windows
,
buckets
,
pails
,
domestic
utensils
of
all
kinds
,
in
which
to
haul
the
water
up
;
and
when
his
eye
is
turned
from
these
operations
to
the
houses
themselves
,
his
utmost
astonishment
will
be
excited
by
the
scene
before
him
.
 
<EOS>
Crazy
wooden
galleries
common
to
the
backs
of
half
a
dozen
houses
,
with
holes
from
which
to
look
upon
the
slime
beneath
;
windows
,
broken
and
patched
,
with
poles
thrust
out
,
on
which
to
dry
the
linen
that
is
never
there
;
rooms
so
small
,
so
filthy
,
so
confined
,
that
the
air
would
seem
too
tainted
even
for
the
dirt
and
squalor
which
they
shelter
;
<EOS>
wooden
chambers
thrusting
themselves
out
above
the
mud
,
and
threatening
to
fall
into
it
---
as
some
have
done
;
dirt
-
besmeared
walls
and
decaying
foundations
;
every
repulsive
lineament
of
poverty
,
every
loathsome
indication
of
filth
,
rot
,
and
garbage
;
all
these
ornament
the
banks
of
Folly
Ditch
.
   
<EOS>
In
Jacob
's
Island
,
the
warehouses
are
roofless
and
empty
;
the
walls
are
crumbling
down
;
the
windows
are
windows
no
more
;
the
doors
are
falling
into
the
streets
;
the
chimneys
are
blackened
,
but
they
yield
no
smoke
.
 
<EOS>
Thirty
or
forty
years
ago
,
before
losses
and
chancery
suits
came
upon
it
,
it
was
a
thriving
place
;
but
now
it
is
a
desolate
island
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
The
houses
have
no
owners
;
they
are
broken
open
,
and
entered
upon
by
those
who
have
the
courage
;
and
there
they
live
,
and
there
they
die
.
 
<EOS>
They
must
have
powerful
motives
for
a
secret
residence
,
or
be
reduced
to
a
destitute
condition
indeed
,
who
seek
a
refuge
in
Jacob
's
Island
.
   
<EOS>
In
an
upper
room
of
one
of
these
houses
---
a
detached
house
of
fair
size
,
ruinous
in
other
respects
,
but
strongly
defended
at
door
and
window
:
 
of
which
house
the
back
commanded
the
ditch
in
manner
already
described
---
there
were
assembled
three
men
,
who
,
regarding
each
other
every
now
and
then
with
looks
expressive
of
perplexity
and
expectation
,
sat
for
some
time
in
profound
and
gloomy
silence
.
 
<EOS>
One
of
these
was
Toby
Crackit
,
another
Mr
Chitling
,
and
the
third
a
robber
of
fifty
years
,
whose
nose
had
been
almost
beaten
in
,
in
some
old
scuffle
,
and
whose
face
bore
a
frightful
scar
which
might
probably
be
traced
to
the
same
occasion
.
 
<EOS>
This
man
was
a
returned
transport
,
and
his
name
was
Kags
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
wish
,
"
said
Toby
turning
to
Mr
Chitling
,
"
<EOS>
that
you
had
picked
out
some
other
crig
when
the
two
old
ones
got
too
warm
,
and
had
not
come
here
,
my
fine
feller
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
did
n't
you
,
blunder
-
head
!
"
said
Kags
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
I
thought
you
'd
have
been
a
little
more
glad
to
see
me
than
this
,
"
replied
Mr
Chitling
,
with
a
melancholy
air
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
look'e
,
young
gentleman
,
"
said
Toby
,
"
when
a
man
keeps
himself
so
very
ex
-
clusive
as
I
have
done
,
and
by
that
means
has
a
snug
house
over
his
head
with
nobody
a
prying
and
smelling
about
it
,
it
's
rather
a
startling
thing
to
have
the
honour
of
a
wisit
from
a
young
gentleman
(
however
respectable
and
pleasant
a
person
he
may
be
to
play
cards
with
at
conweniency
)
<EOS>
circumstanced
as
you
are
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Especially
,
when
the
exclusive
young
man
has
got
a
friend
stopping
with
him
,
that
's
arrived
sooner
than
was
expected
from
foreign
parts
,
and
is
too
modest
to
want
to
be
presented
to
the
Judges
on
his
return
,
"
added
Mr
Kags
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
short
silence
,
after
which
Toby
Crackit
,
seeming
to
abandon
as
hopeless
any
further
effort
to
maintain
his
usual
devil
-
may
-
care
swagger
,
turned
to
Chitling
and
said
,
   
"
<EOS>
When
was
Fagin
took
then
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Just
at
dinner
-
time
---
two
o'clock
this
afternoon
.
 
<EOS>
Charley
<EOS>
and
I
made
our
lucky
up
the
wash
-
us
chimney
,
and
Bolter
got
into
the
empty
water
-
butt
,
head
downwards
;
but
his
legs
were
so
precious
long
that
they
stuck
out
at
the
top
,
and
so
they
took
him
too
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
Bet
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Poor
Bet
!
 
<EOS>
She
went
to
see
the
Body
,
to
speak
to
who
it
was
,
"
replied
Chitling
,
his
countenance
falling
more
and
more
,
"
and
went
off
mad
,
screaming
and
raving
,
and
beating
her
head
against
the
boards
;
so
they
put
a
strait
-
weskut
on
her
and
took
her
to
the
hospital
---
<EOS>
and
there
she
is
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Wot
's
come
of
young
Bates
?
"
demanded
Kags
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
hung
about
,
not
to
come
over
here
afore
dark
,
but
he
'll
be
here
soon
,
"
replied
Chitling
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
's
nowhere
else
to
go
to
now
,
for
the
people
at
the
Cripples
are
all
in
custody
,
and
the
bar
of
the
ken
---
I
went
up
there
and
see
it
with
my
own
eyes
---
is
filled
with
traps
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
smash
,
"
observed
Toby
,
biting
his
lips
.
<EOS>
"
There
's
more
than
one
will
go
with
this
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
sessions
are
on
,
"
said
Kags
:
 
<EOS>
"
if
they
get
the
inquest
over
,
and
Bolter
turns
King
's
evidence
:
 
as
of
course
he
will
,
from
what
he
's
said
already
:
 
they
can
prove
Fagin
an
accessory
before
the
fact
,
and
get
the
trial
on
on
Friday
,
and
he
'll
swing
in
six
days
from
this
,
by
G
---
 
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
should
have
heard
the
people
groan
,
"
said
Chitling
;
<EOS>
"
the
officers
fought
like
devils
,
or
they
'd
have
torn
him
away
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
down
once
,
but
they
made
a
ring
round
him
,
and
fought
their
way
along
.
 
<EOS>
You
should
have
seen
how
he
looked
about
him
,
all
muddy
and
bleeding
,
and
clung
to
them
as
if
they
were
his
dearest
friends
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
see
'em
now
,
not
able
to
stand
upright
with
the
pressing
of
the
mob
,
and
draggin
him
along
amongst
'em
;
I
can
see
the
people
jumping
up
,
one
behind
another
,
and
snarling
with
their
teeth
and
making
at
him
;
I
can
see
the
blood
upon
his
hair
and
beard
,
and
hear
the
cries
with
which
the
women
worked
themselves
into
the
centre
of
the
crowd
at
the
street
corner
,
and
swore
they
'd
tear
his
heart
out
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
horror
-
stricken
witness
of
this
scene
pressed
his
hands
upon
his
ears
,
and
with
his
eyes
closed
got
up
and
paced
violently
to
and
fro
,
like
one
distracted
.
   
<EOS>
While
he
was
thus
engaged
,
and
the
two
men
sat
by
in
silence
with
their
eyes
fixed
upon
the
floor
,
a
pattering
noise
was
heard
upon
the
stairs
,
and
Sikes
's
dog
bounded
into
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
They
ran
to
the
window
,
downstairs
,
and
into
the
street
.
 
<EOS>
The
dog
had
jumped
in
at
an
open
window
;
he
made
no
attempt
to
follow
them
,
nor
was
his
master
to
be
seen
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
meaning
of
this
?
"
said
Toby
when
they
had
returned
.
<EOS>
"
He
ca
n't
be
coming
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
---
<EOS>
I
---
hope
not
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
he
was
coming
here
,
he
'd
have
come
with
the
dog
,
"
said
Kags
,
stooping
down
to
examine
the
animal
,
who
lay
panting
on
the
floor
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
!
 
<EOS>
Give
us
some
water
for
him
;
he
has
run
himself
faint
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
drunk
it
all
up
,
every
drop
,
"
said
Chitling
after
watching
the
dog
some
time
in
silence
.
 
<EOS>
"
Covered
with
mud
---
lame
---
half
blind
---
he
must
have
come
a
long
way
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Where
can
he
have
come
from
!
"
exclaimed
Toby
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
's
been
to
the
other
kens
of
course
,
and
finding
them
filled
with
strangers
come
on
here
,
where
he
's
been
many
a
time
and
often
.
 
<EOS>
But
where
can
he
have
come
from
first
,
and
how
comes
he
here
alone
without
the
other
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
"
---
(
none
of
them
called
the
murderer
by
his
old
name
)
---
"
He
ca
n't
have
made
away
with
himself
.
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
think
?
"
said
Chitling
.
   
<EOS>
Toby
shook
his
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
he
had
,
"
said
Kags
,
"
the
dog
'
ud
want
to
lead
us
away
to
where
he
did
it
.
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
he
's
got
out
of
the
country
,
and
left
the
dog
behind
.
 
<EOS>
He
must
have
given
him
the
slip
somehow
,
or
he
would
n't
be
so
easy
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
solution
,
appearing
the
most
probable
one
,
was
adopted
as
the
right
;
the
dog
,
creeping
under
a
chair
,
coiled
himself
up
to
sleep
,
without
more
notice
from
anybody
.
   
<EOS>
It
being
now
dark
,
the
shutter
was
closed
,
and
a
candle
lighted
and
placed
upon
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
The
terrible
events
of
the
last
two
days
had
made
a
deep
impression
on
all
three
,
increased
by
the
danger
and
uncertainty
of
their
own
position
.
 
<EOS>
They
drew
their
chairs
closer
together
,
starting
at
every
sound
.
 
<EOS>
They
spoke
little
,
and
that
in
whispers
,
and
were
as
silent
and
awe
-
stricken
as
if
the
remains
of
the
murdered
woman
lay
in
the
next
room
.
   
<EOS>
They
had
sat
thus
,
some
time
,
when
suddenly
was
heard
a
hurried
knocking
at
the
door
below
.
   
<EOS>
"
Young
Bates
,
"
said
Kags
,
looking
angrily
round
,
to
check
the
fear
he
felt
himself
.
   
<EOS>
The
knocking
came
again
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
it
was
n't
he
.
 
<EOS>
He
never
knocked
like
that
.
   
<EOS>
Crackit
went
to
the
window
,
and
shaking
all
over
,
drew
in
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
need
to
tell
them
who
it
was
;
his
pale
face
was
enough
.
 
<EOS>
The
dog
too
was
on
the
alert
in
an
instant
,
and
ran
whining
to
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
must
let
him
in
,
"
he
said
,
taking

.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
n't

any
help
for
it
?
"
asked
the
other
man
in
a

.
   
<EOS>
"
None
.
 
<EOS>
He
MUST
come
in
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
leave
us
in
the
dark
,
"
said
Kags
,
taking
down

from
the
chimney
-
piece
,
and
lighting

,
with
such
a
trembling
hand
that
the
knocking
was
twice
repeated
before
he
had
finished
.
   
<EOS>
Crackit
went
down
to
the
door
,
and
returned
followed
by
a
man
with
the
lower
part
of
his
face
buried
in
