handkerchief
,
and
another
tied
over
his
head
under
his
hat
.
 
<EOS>
He
drew
them
slowly
off
.
 
<EOS>
Blanched
face
,
sunken
eyes
,
hollow
cheeks
,
beard
of
three
days
'
growth
,
wasted
flesh
,
short
thick
breath
;
it
was
the
very
ghost
of
Sikes
.
   
<EOS>
He
laid
his
hand
upon
a
chair
which
stood
in
the
middle
of
the
room
,
but
shuddering
as
he
was
about
to
drop
into
it
,
and
seeming
to
glance
over
his
shoulder
,
dragged
it
back
close
to
the
wall
---
as
close
as
it
would
go
---
and
ground
it
against
it
---
and
sat
down
.
   
<EOS>
Not
a
word
had
been
exchanged
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
from
one
to
another
in
silence
.
 
<EOS>
If
an
eye
were
furtively
raised
and
met
his
,
it
was
instantly
averted
.
 
<EOS>
When
his
hollow
voice
broke
silence
,
they
all
three
started
.
 
<EOS>
They
seemed
never
to
have
heard
its
tones
before
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
came
that
dog
here
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Alone
.
 
<EOS>
Three
hours
ago
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
-
night
's
paper
says
that
Fagin
's
took
.
 
<EOS>
Is
it
true
,
or
a
lie
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
True
.
"
   
<EOS>
They
were
silent
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
Damn
you
all
!
"
said
Sikes
,
passing
his
hand
across
his
forehead
.
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
nothing
to
say
to
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
an
uneasy
movement
among
them
,
but
nobody
spoke
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
that
keep
this
house
,
"
said
Sikes
,
turning
his
face
to
Crackit
,
"
do
you
mean
to
sell
me
,
or
to
let
me
lie
here
till
this
hunt
is
over
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
may
stop
here
,
if
you
think
it
safe
,
"
returned
the
person
addressed
,
after
some
hesitation
.
   
<EOS>
Sikes
carried
his
eyes
slowly
up
the
wall
behind
him
:
 
rather
trying
to
turn
his
head
than
actually
doing
it
:
 
and
said
,
"
Is
---
it
---
the
body
---
<EOS>
is
it
buried
?
"
   
<EOS>
They
shook
their
heads
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
is
n't
it
!
"
<EOS>
he
retorted
with
the
same
glance
behind
him
.
"
<EOS>
Wot
do
they
keep
such
ugly
things
above
the
ground
for
?
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Who
's
that
knocking
?
"
   
<EOS>
Crackit
intimated
,
by
a
motion
of
his
hand
as
he
left
the
room
,
that
there
was
nothing
to
fear
;
and
directly
came
back
with
Charley
Bates
behind
him
.
 
<EOS>
Sikes
sat
opposite
the
door
,
so
that
the
moment
the
boy
entered
the
room
he
encountered
his
figure
.
   
<EOS>
"
Toby
,
"
said
the
boy
falling
back
,
as
Sikes
turned
his
eyes
towards
him
,
"
why
did
n't
you
tell
me
this
,
downstairs
?
"
   
<EOS>
There
had
been
something
so
tremendous
in
the
shrinking
off
of
the
three
,
that
the
wretched
man
was
willing
to
propitiate
even
this
lad
.
 
<EOS>
Accordingly
he
nodded
,
and
made
as
though
he
would
shake
hands
with
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Let
me
go
into
some
other
room
,
"
said
the
boy
,
retreating
still
farther
.
   
<EOS>
"
Charley
!
"
said
Sikes
,
stepping
forward
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
---
do
n't
you
know
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
come
nearer
me
,
"
answered
the
boy
,
still
retreating
,
and
looking
,
with
horror
in
his
eyes
,
upon
the
murderer
's
face
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
monster
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
man
stopped
half
-
way
,
and
they
looked
at
each
other
;
but
Sikes
's
eyes
sunk
gradually
to
the
ground
.
   
<EOS>
"
Witness
you
three
,
"
cried
the
boy
shaking
his
clenched
fist
,
and
becoming
more
and
more
excited
as
he
spoke
.
<EOS>
"
Witness
you
three
---
I
'm
not
afraid
of
him
---
if
they
come
here
after
him
,
I
'll
give
him
up
;
I
will
.
 
<EOS>
I
tell
you
out
at
once
.
 
<EOS>
He
may
kill
me
for
it
if
he
likes
,
or
if
he
dares
,
but
if
I
am
here
I
'll
give
him
up
.
 
<EOS>
I
'd
give
him
up
if
he
was
to
be
boiled
alive
.
 
<EOS>
Murder
!
<EOS>
Help
!
 
<EOS>
If
there
's
the
pluck
of
a
man
among
you
three
,
you
'll
help
me
.
 
<EOS>
Murder
!
 
<EOS>
Help
!
 
<EOS>
Down
with
him
!
"
   
<EOS>
Pouring
out
these
cries
,
and
accompanying
them
with
violent
gesticulation
,
the
boy
actually
threw
himself
,
single
-
handed
,
upon
the
strong
man
,
and
in
the
intensity
of
his
energy
and
the
suddenness
of
his
surprise
,
brought
him
heavily
to
the
ground
.
   
<EOS>
The
three
spectators
seemed
quite
stupefied
.
 
<EOS>
They
offered
no
interference
,
and
the
boy
and
man
rolled
on
the
ground
together
;
the
former
,
heedless
of
the
blows
that
showered
upon
him
,
wrenching
his
hands
tighter
and
tighter
in
the
garments
about
the
murderer
's
breast
,
and
never
ceasing
to
call
for
help
with
all
his
might
.
   
<EOS>
The
contest
,
however
,
was
too
unequal
to
last
long
.
 
<EOS>
Sikes
had
him
down
,
and
his
knee
was
on
his
throat
,
when
Crackit
pulled
him
back
with
a
look
of
alarm
,
and
pointed
to
the
window
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
lights
gleaming
below
,
voices
in
loud
and
earnest
conversation
,
the
tramp
of
hurried
footsteps
---
endless
<EOS>
they
seemed
in
number
---
crossing
the
nearest
wooden
bridge
.
 
<EOS>
One
man
on
horseback
seemed
to
be
among
the
crowd
;
for
there
was
the
noise
of
hoofs
rattling
on
the
uneven
pavement
.
 
<EOS>
The
gleam
of
lights
increased
;
the
footsteps
came
more
thickly
and
noisily
on
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
came
a
loud
knocking
at
the
door
,
and
then
a
hoarse
murmur
from
such
a
multitude
of
angry
voices
as
would
have
made
the
boldest
quail
.
   
<EOS>
"
Help
!
"
shrieked
the
boy
in
a
voice
that
rent
the
air
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
here
!
 
<EOS>
Break
down
the
door
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
In
the
King
's
name
,
"
cried
the
voices
without
;
and
the
hoarse
cry
arose
again
,
but
louder
.
   
<EOS>
"
Break
down
the
door
!
"
screamed
the
boy
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
they
'll
never
open
it
.
 
<EOS>
Run
straight
to
the
room
where
the
light
is
.
<EOS>
Break
down
the
door
!
"
   
<EOS>
Strokes
,
thick
and
heavy
,
rattled
upon
the
door
and
lower
window
-
shutters
as
he
ceased
to
speak
,
and
a
loud
huzzah
burst
from
the
crowd
;
giving
the
listener
,
for
the
first
time
,
some
adequate
idea
of
its
immense
extent
.
   
<EOS>
"
Open
the
door
of
some
place
where
I
can
lock
this
screeching
Hell
-
babe
,
"
cried
Sikes
fiercely
;
running
to
and
fro
,
and
dragging
the
boy
,
now
,
as
easily
as
if
he
were
an
empty
sack
.
"
<EOS>
That
door
.
 
<EOS>
Quick
!
"
 
<EOS>
He
flung
him
in
,
bolted
it
,
and
turned
the
key
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
the
downstairs
door
fast
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Double
-
locked
and
chained
,
"
replied
Crackit
,
who
,
with
the
other
two
men
,
still
remained
quite
helpless
and
bewildered
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
panels
---
are
they
strong
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Lined
with
sheet
-
iron
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
the
windows
too
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
and
the
windows
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Damn
you
!
"
cried
the
desperate
ruffian
,
throwing
up
the
sash
and
menacing
the
crowd
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
your
worst
!
 
<EOS>
I
'll
cheat
you
yet
!
"
   
<EOS>
Of
all
the
terrific
yells
that
ever
fell
on
mortal
ears
,
none
could
exceed
the
cry
of
the
infuriated
throng
.
 
<EOS>
Some
shouted
to
those
who
were
nearest
to
set
the
house
on
fire
;
others
roared
to
the
officers
to
shoot
him
dead
.
 
<EOS>
Among
them
all
,
none
showed
such
fury
as
the
man
on
horseback
,
who
,
throwing
himself
out
of
the
saddle
,
and
bursting
through
the
crowd
as
if
he
were
parting
water
,
cried
,
beneath
the
window
,
in
a
voice
that
rose
above
all
others
,
"
Twenty
guineas
to
the
man
who
brings
a
ladder
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
nearest
voices
took
up
the
cry
,
and
hundreds
echoed
it
.
 
<EOS>
Some
called
for
ladders
,
some
for
sledge
-
hammers
;
some
ran
with
torches
to
and
fro
as
if
to
seek
them
,
and
still
came
back
and
roared
again
;
some
spent
their
breath
in
impotent
curses
and
execrations
;
some
pressed
forward
with
the
ecstasy
of
madmen
,
and
thus
impeded
the
progress
of
those
below
;
some
among
the
boldest
attempted
to
climb
up
by
the
water
-
spout
and
crevices
in
the
wall
;
and
all
waved
to
and
fro
,
in
the
darkness
beneath
,
like
a
field
of
corn
moved
by
an
angry
wind
:
 
and
joined
from
time
to
time
in
one
loud
furious
roar
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
tide
,
"
cried
the
murderer
,
as
he
staggered
back
into
the
room
,
and
shut
the
faces
out
,
"
the
tide
was
in
as
I
came
up
.
<EOS>
Give
me
a
rope
,
a
long
rope
.
 
<EOS>
They
're
all
in
front
.
 
<EOS>
I
may
drop
into
the
Folly
Ditch
,
and
clear
off
that
way
.
 
<EOS>
Give
me
a
rope
,
or
I
shall
do
three
more
murders
and
kill
myself
.
   
<EOS>
The
panic
-
stricken
men
pointed
to
where
such
articles
were
kept
;
the
murderer
,
hastily
selecting
the
longest
and
strongest
cord
,
hurried
up
to
the
house
-
top
.
   
<EOS>
All
the
window
in
the
rear
of
the
house
had
been
long
ago
bricked
up
,
except
one
small
trap
in
the
room
where
the
boy
was
locked
,
and
that
was
too
small
even
for
the
passage
of
his
body
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
from
this
aperture
,
he
had
never
ceased
to
call
on
those
without
,
to
guard
the
back
;
and
thus
,
when
the
murderer
emerged
at
last
on
the
house
-
top
by
the
door
in
the
roof
,
a
loud
shout
proclaimed
the
fact
to
those
in
front
,
who
immediately
began
to
pour
round
,
pressing
upon
each
other
in
an
unbroken
stream
.
   
<EOS>
He
planted
a
board
,
which
he
had
carried
up
with
him
for
the
purpose
,
so
firmly
against
the
door
that
it
must
be
matter
of
great
difficulty
to
open
it
from
the
inside
;
and
creeping
over
the
tiles
,
looked
over
the
low
parapet
.
   
<EOS>
The
water
was
out
,
and
the
ditch
a
bed
of
mud
.
   
<EOS>
The
crowd
had
been
hushed
during
these
few
moments
,
watching
his
motions
and
doubtful
of
his
purpose
,
but
the
instant
they
perceived
it
and
knew
it
was
defeated
,
they
raised
a
cry
of
triumphant
execration
to
which
all
their
previous
shouting
had
been
whispers
.
 
<EOS>
Again
and
again
it
rose
.
 
<EOS>
Those
who
were
at
too
great
a
distance
to
know
its
meaning
,
took
up
the
sound
;
it
echoed
and
re
-
echoed
;
it
seemed
as
though
the
whole
city
had
poured
its
population
out
to
curse
him
.
   
<EOS>
On
pressed
the
people
from
the
front
---
on
,
on
,
on
,
in
a
strong
struggling
current
of
angry
faces
,
with
here
and
there
a
glaring
torch
to
lighten
them
up
,
and
show
them
out
in
all
their
wrath
and
passion
.
 
<EOS>
The
houses
on
the
opposite
side
of
the
ditch
had
been
entered
by
the
mob
;
sashes
were
thrown
up
,
or
torn
bodily
out
;
there
were
tiers
and
tiers
of
faces
in
every
window
;
cluster
upon
cluster
of
people
clinging
to
every
house
-
top
.
 
<EOS>
Each
little
bridge
<EOS>
(
and
there
were
three
in
sight
)
bent
beneath
the
weight
of
the
crowd
upon
it
.
 
<EOS>
Still
the
current
poured
on
to
find
some
nook
or
hole
from
which
to
vent
their
shouts
,
and
only
for
an
instant
<EOS>
see
the
wretch
.
   
<EOS>
"
They
have
him
now
,
"
cried
a
man
on
the
nearest
bridge
.
<EOS>
"
Hurrah
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
crowd
grew
light
with
uncovered
heads
;
and
again
the
shout
uprose
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
give
fifty
pounds
,
"
cried
an
old
gentleman
from
the
same
quarter
,
"
to
the
man
who
takes
him
alive
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
remain
here
,
till
he
come
to
ask
me
for
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
another
roar
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
moment
the
word
was
passed
among
the
crowd
that
the
door
was
forced
at
last
,
and
that
he
who
had
first
called
for
the
ladder
had
mounted
into
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
The
stream
abruptly
turned
,
as
this
intelligence
ran
from
mouth
to
mouth
;
and
the
people
at
the
windows
,
seeing
those
upon
the
bridges
pouring
back
,
quitted
their
stations
,
and
running
into
the
street
,
joined
the
concourse
that
now
thronged
pell
-
mell
to
the
spot
they
had
left
:
 
each
man
crushing
and
striving
with
his
neighbor
,
and
all
panting
with
impatience
to
get
near
the
door
,
and
look
upon
the
criminal
as
the
officers
brought
him
out
.
<EOS>
The
cries
and
shrieks
of
those
who
were
pressed
almost
to
suffocation
,
or
trampled
down
and
trodden
under
foot
in
the
confusion
,
were
dreadful
;
the
narrow
ways
were
completely
blocked
up
;
and
at
this
time
,
between
the
rush
of
some
to
regain
the
space
in
front
of
the
house
,
and
the
unavailing
struggles
of
others
to
extricate
themselves
from
the
mass
,
the
immediate
attention
was
distracted
from
the
murderer
,
although
the
universal
eagerness
for
his
capture
was
,
if
possible
,
increased
.
   
<EOS>
The
man
had
shrunk
down
,
thoroughly
quelled
by
the
ferocity
of
the
crowd
,
and
the
impossibility
of
escape
;
but
seeing
this
sudden
change
with
no
less
rapidity
than
it
had
occurred
,
he
sprang
upon
his
feet
,
determined
to
make
one
last
effort
for
his
life
by
dropping
into
the
ditch
,
and
,
at
the
risk
of
being
stifled
,
endeavouring
to
creep
away
in
the
darkness
and
confusion
.
   
<EOS>
Roused
into
new
strength
and
energy
,
and
stimulated
by
the
noise
within
the
house
which
announced
that
an
entrance
had
really
been
effected
,
he
set
his
foot
against
the
stack
of
chimneys
,
fastened
one
end
of
the
rope
tightly
and
firmly
round
it
,
and
with
the
other
made
a
strong
running
noose
by
the
aid
of
his
hands
and
teeth
almost
in
a
second
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
let
himself
down
by
the
cord
to
within
a
less
distance
of
the
ground
than
his
own
height
,
and
had
his
knife
ready
in
his
hand
to
cut
it
then
and
drop
.
   
<EOS>
At
the
very
instant
when
he
brought
the
loop
over
his
head
previous
to
slipping
it
beneath
his
arm
-
pits
,
and
when
the
old
gentleman
before
-
mentioned
(
who
had
clung
so
tight
to
the
railing
of
the
bridge
as
to
resist
the
force
of
the
crowd
,
and
retain
his
position
)
earnestly
warned
those
about
him
that
the
man
was
about
to
lower
himself
down
---
at
that
very
instant
the
murderer
,
looking
behind
him
on
the
roof
,
threw
his
arms
above
his
head
,
and
uttered
a
yell
of
terror
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
eyes
again
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
in
an
unearthly
screech
.
   
<EOS>
Staggering
as
if
struck
by
lightning
,
he
lost
his
balance
and
tumbled
over
the
parapet
.
 
<EOS>
The
noose
was
on
his
neck
.
<EOS>
It
ran
up
with
his
weight
,
tight
as
a
bow
-
string
,
and
swift
as
the
arrow
it
speeds
.
 
<EOS>
He
fell
for
five
-
and
-
thirty
feet
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
sudden
jerk
,
a
terrific
convulsion
of
the
limbs
;
and
there
he
hung
,
with
the
open
knife
clenched
in
his
stiffening
hand
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
chimney
quivered
with
the
shock
,
but
stood
it
bravely
.
<EOS>
The
murderer
swung
lifeless
against
the
wall
;
and
the
boy
,
thrusting
aside
the
dangling
body
which
obscured
his
view
,
called
to
the
people
to
come
and
take
him
out
,
for
God
's
sake
.
   
<EOS>
A
dog
,
which
had
lain
concealed
till
now
,
ran
backwards
and
forwards
on
the
parapet
with
a
dismal
howl
,
and
collecting
himself
for
a
spring
,
jumped
for
the
dead
man
's
shoulders
.
<EOS>
Missing
his
aim
,
he
fell
into
the
ditch
,
turning
completely
over
as
he
went
;
and
striking
his
head
against
a
stone
,
dashed
out
his
brains
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
51
.
<EOS>
Affording
an
explanation
of
more
mysteries
than
one
,
and
comprehending
a
proposal
of
marriage
with
no
word
of
settlement
or
pin
-
money
.
 
<EOS>
The
events
narrated
in
the
last
chapter
were
yet
but
two
days
old
,
when
Oliver
found
himself
,
at
three
o'clock
in
the
afternoon
,
in
a
travelling
-
carriage
rolling
fast
towards
his
native
town
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Maylie
,
and
Rose
,
and
Mrs
Bedwin
,
and
the
good
doctor
were
with
him
:
 
and
Mr
Brownlow
followed
in
a
post
-
chaise
,
accompanied
by
one
other
person
whose
name
had
not
been
mentioned
.
   
<EOS>
They
had
not
talked
much
upon
the
way
;
for
Oliver
was
in
a
flutter
of
agitation
and
uncertainty
which
deprived
him
of
the
power
of
collecting
his
thoughts
,
and
almost
of
speech
,
and
appeared
to
have
scarcely
less
effect
on
his
companions
,
who
shared
it
,
in
at
least
an
equal
degree
.
 
<EOS>
He
and
the
two
ladies
had
been
very
carefully
made
acquainted
by
Mr
Brownlow
with
the
nature
of
the
admissions
which
had
been
forced
from
Monks
;
and
although
they
knew
that
the
object
of
their
present
journey
was
to
complete
the
work
which
had
been
so
well
begun
,
still
the
whole
matter
was
enveloped
in
enough
of
doubt
and
mystery
to
leave
them
in
endurance
of
the
most
intense
suspense
.
   
<EOS>
The
same
kind
friend
had
,
with
Mr
Losberne
's
assistance
,
cautiously
stopped
all
channels
of
communication
through
which
they
could
receive
intelligence
of
the
dreadful
occurrences
that
so
recently
taken
place
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
quite
true
,
"
he
said
,
"
that
they
must
know
them
before
long
,
but
it
might
be
at
a
better
time
than
the
present
,
and
it
could
not
be
at
a
worse
.
"
 
<EOS>
So
,
they
travelled
on
in
silence
:
 
<EOS>
each
busied
with
reflections
on
the
object
which
had
brought
them
together
:
 
and
no
one
disposed
to
give
utterance
to
the
thoughts
which
crowded
upon
all
.
   
<EOS>
But
if
Oliver
,
under
these
influences
,
had
remained
silent
while
they
journeyed
towards
his
birth
-
place
by
a
road
he
had
never
seen
,
how
the
whole
current
of
his
recollections
ran
back
to
old
times
,
and
what
a
crowd
of
emotions
were
wakened
up
in
his
breast
,
when
they
turned
into
that
which
he
had
traversed
on
foot
:
 
a
poor
houseless
,
wandering
boy
,
without
a
friend
to
help
him
,
or
a
roof
to
shelter
his
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
See
there
,
there
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Oliver
,
eagerly
clasping
the
hand
of
Rose
,
and
pointing
out
at
the
carriage
window
<EOS>
;
"
that
's
the
stile
I
came
over
;
there
are
the
hedges
I
crept
behind
,
for
fear
any
one
should
overtake
me
and
force
me
back
!
 
<EOS>
Yonder
is
the
path
across
the
fields
,
leading
to
the
old
house
where
I
was
a
little
child
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
Dick
,
Dick
,
my
dear
old
friend
,
if
I
could
only
see
you
now
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
will
see
him
soon
,
"
replied
Rose
,
gently
taking
his
folded
hands
between
her
own
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
shall
tell
him
how
happy
you
are
,
and
how
rich
you
have
grown
,
and
that
in
all
your
happiness
you
have
none
so
great
as
the
coming
back
to
make
him
happy
too
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
yes
,
"
said
Oliver
,
"
and
<EOS>
we
'll
---
we
'll
take
him
away
from
here
,
and
have
him
clothed
and
taught
,
and
send
him
to
some
quiet
country
place
where
he
may
grow
strong
and
well
,
---
shall
we
?
"
   
<EOS>
Rose
nodded
"
yes
,
"
for
the
boy
was
smiling
through
such
happy
tears
that
she
could
not
speak
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
will
be
kind
and
good
to
him
,
for
you
are
to
every
one
,
"
said
Oliver
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
will
make
you
cry
,
I
know
,
to
hear
what
he
can
tell
;
but
never
mind
,
never
mind
<EOS>
,
it
will
be
all
over
,
and
you
will
smile
again
---
I
know
that
too
---
to
think
how
changed
he
is
;
you
did
the
same
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
"
God
bless
you
"
to
me
when
I
ran
away
,
"
cried
the
boy
with
a
burst
of
affectionate
emotion
;
"
<EOS>
and
I
will
say
"
God
bless
you
"
now
,
and
show
him
how
I
love
him
for
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
As
they
approached
the
town
,
and
at
length
drove
through
its
narrow
streets
,
it
became
matter
of
no
small
difficulty
to
restrain
the
boy
within
reasonable
bounds
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
Sowerberry
's
the
undertaker
's
just
as
it
used
to
be
,
only
smaller
and
less
imposing
in
appearance
than
he
remembered
it
---
there
were
all
the
well
-
known
shops
and
houses
,
with
almost
every
one
of
which
he
had
some
slight
incident
connected
---
there
was
Gamfield
's
cart
,
the
very
cart
he
used
to
have
,
standing
at
the
old
public
-
house
door
---
there
was
the
workhouse
,
the
dreary
prison
of
his
youthful
days
,
with
its
dismal
windows
frowning
on
the
street
---
there
was
the
same
lean
porter
standing
at
the
gate
,
at
sight
of
whom
Oliver
involuntarily
shrunk
back
,
and
then
laughed
at
himself
for
being
so
foolish
,
then
cried
,
then
laughed
again
---
there
were
scores
of
faces
at
the
doors
and
windows
that
he
knew
quite
well
---
there
was
nearly
everything
as
if
he
had
left
it
but
yesterday
,
and
all
his
recent
life
had
been
but
a
happy
dream
.
   
<EOS>
But
it
was
pure
,
earnest
,
joyful
reality
.
 
<EOS>
They
drove
straight
to
the
door
of
the
chief
hotel
(
which
Oliver
used
to
stare
up
at
,
with
awe
,
and
think
a
mighty
palace
,
but
which
had
somehow
fallen
off
in
grandeur
and
size
)
;
and
here
was
Mr
Grimwig
all
ready
to
receive
them
,
kissing
the
young
lady
,
and
the
old
one
too
,
when
they
got
out
of
the
coach
,
as
if
he
were
the
grandfather
of
the
whole
party
,
all
smiles
and
kindness
,
and
not
offering
to
eat
his
head
---
<EOS>
no
,
not
once
;
not
even
when
he
contradicted
a
very
old
postboy
about
the
nearest
road
to
London
,
and
maintained
he
knew
it
best
,
though
he
had
only
come
that
way
once
,
and
that
time
fast
asleep
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
dinner
prepared
,
and
there
were
bedrooms
ready
,
and
everything
was
arranged
as
if
by
magic
.
   
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
all
this
,
when
the
hurry
of
the
first
half
-
hour
was
over
,
the
same
silence
and
constraint
prevailed
that
had
marked
their
journey
down
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Brownlow
did
not
join
them
at
dinner
,
but
remained
in
a
separate
room
.
 
<EOS>
The
two
other
gentlemen
hurried
in
and
out
with
anxious
faces
,
and
,
during
the
short
intervals
when
they
were
present
,
conversed
apart
.
 
<EOS>
Once
,
Mrs
Maylie
was
called
away
,
and
after
being
absent
for
nearly
an
hour
,
returned
with
eyes
swollen
with
weeping
.
 
<EOS>
All
these
things
made
Rose
and
Oliver
,
who
were
not
in
any
new
secrets
,
nervous
and
uncomfortable
.
 
<EOS>
They
sat
wondering
,
in
silence
;
or
,
if
they
exchanged
a
few
words
,
spoke
in
whispers
,
as
if
they
were
afraid
to
hear
the
sound
of
their
own
voices
.
   
<EOS>
At
length
,
when
nine
o'clock
had
come
,
and
they
began
to
think
they
were
to
hear
no
more
that
night
,
Mr
Losberne
and
Mr
Grimwig
entered
the
room
,
followed
by
Mr
Brownlow
and
a
man
whom
Oliver
almost
shrieked
with
surprise
to
see
;
for
they
told
him
it
was
his
brother
,
and
it
was
the
same
man
he
had
met
at
the
market
-
town
,
and
seen
looking
in
with
Fagin
at
the
window
of
his
little
room
.
 
<EOS>
Monks
cast
a
look
of
hate
,
which
,
even
then
,
he
could
not
dissemble
,
at
the
astonished
boy
,
and
sat
down
near
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Brownlow
,
who
had
papers
in
his
hand
,
walked
to
a
table
near
which
Rose
and
Oliver
were
seated
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
painful
task
,
"
said
he
,
"
but
these
declarations
,
which
have
been
signed
in
London
before
many
gentlemen
,
must
be
substance
repeated
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
have
spared
you
the
degradation
,
but
we
must
hear
them
from
your
own
lips
before
we
part
,
and
you
know
why
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Go
on
,
"
said
the
person
addressed
,
turning
away
his
face
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Quick
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
almost
done
enough
,
I
think
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
keep
me
here
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
This
child
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
,
drawing
Oliver
to
him
,
and
laying
his
hand
upon

head
,
"
is
your
half
-
brother
;
the
illegitimate
son
of
your
father
,
my
dear
friend
Edwin
Leeford
,
by
poor
young
Agnes
Fleming
,
who
died
in
giving
him
birth
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Monks
,
scowling
at
the
trembling
boy
:
 
the
beating
of
whose
heart
he
might
have
heard
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
is
the
bastard
child
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
term
you
use
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
,
sternly
,
"
is
a
reproach
to
those
long
since
passed
beyong
the
feeble
censure
of
the
world
.
<EOS>
It
reflects
disgrace
on
no
one
living
,
except
you
who
use
it
.
<EOS>
Let
that
pass
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
born
in
this
town
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
In
the
workhouse
of
this
town
,
"
was
the
sullen
reply
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
the
story
there
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
pointed
impatiently
to
the
papers
as
he
spoke
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
must
have
it
here
,
too
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
,
looking
round
upon
the
listeners
.
   
<EOS>
"
Listen
then
!
 
<EOS>
You
!
"
returned
Monks
.
 
<EOS>
"
His
father
being
taken
ill
at
Rome
,
was
joined
by
his
wife
,
my
mother
,
from
whom
he
had
been
long
separated
,
who
went
from
Paris
and
took
me
with
her
---
to
look
after
his
property
,
for
what
I
know
,
for
she
had
no
great
affection
for
him
,
nor
he
for
her
.
 
<EOS>
He
knew
nothing
of
us
,
for
his
senses
were
gone
,
and
he
slumbered
on
till
next
day
,
when
he
died
.
 
<EOS>
Among
the
papers
in
his
desk
,
were
two
,
dated
on
the
night
his
illness
first
came
on
,
directed
to
yourself
"
;
he
addressed
himself
to
Mr
Brownlow
;
"
and
enclosed
in
a
few
short
lines
to
you
,
with
an
intimation
on
the
cover
of
the
package
that
it
was
not
to
be
forwarded
till
after
he
was
dead
.
 
<EOS>
One
of
these
papers
was
a
letter
to
this
girl
Agnes
;
the
other
a
will
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
of
the
letter
?
"
asked
Mr
Brownlow
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
letter
?
---
<EOS>
A
sheet
of
paper
crossed
and
crossed
again
,
with
a
penitent
confession
,
and
prayers
to
God
to
help
her
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
palmed
a
tale
on
the
girl
that
some
secret
mystery
---
to
be
explained
one
day
---
prevented
his
marrying
her
just
then
;
and
so
she
had
gone
on
,
trusting
patiently
to
him
,
until
she
trusted
too
far
,
and
lost
what
none
could
ever
give
her
back
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
,
at
that
time
,
within
a
few
months
of
her
confinement
.
 
<EOS>
He
told
her
all
he
had
meant
to
do
,
to
hide
her
shame
,
if
he
had
lived
,
and
prayed
her
,
if
he
died
,
not
to
curse
him
memory
,
or
think
the
consequences
of
their
sin
would
be
visited
on
her
or
their
young
child
;
for
all
the
guilt
was
his
.
 
<EOS>
He
reminded
her
of
the
day
he
had
given
her
the
little
locket
and
the
ring
with
her
christian
name
engraved
upon
it
,
and
a
blank
left
for
that
which
he
hoped
one
day
to
have
bestowed
upon
her
---
prayed
her
yet
to
keep
it
,
and
wear
it
next
her
heart
,
as
she
had
done
before
---
and
then
ran
on
,
wildly
,
in
the
same
words
,
over
and
over
again
,
as
if
he
had
gone
distracted
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
he
had
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
will
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
,
as
Oliver
's
tears
fell
fast
.
   
<EOS>
Monks
was
silent
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
will
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
,
speaking
for
him
,
"
was
in
the
same
spirit
as
the
letter
.
 
<EOS>
He
talked
of
miseries
which
his
wife
had
brought
upon
him
;
of
the
rebellious
disposition
,
vice
,
malice
,
and
premature
bad
passions
of
you
his
only
son
,
who
had
been
trained
to
hate
him
;
and
left
you
,
and
your
mother
,
each
an
annuity
of
eight
hundred
pounds
.
 
<EOS>
The
bulk
of
his
property
he
divided
into
two
equal

---
one
for
Agnes
Fleming
,
and
the
other
for
their
child
,
it
it
should
be
born
alive
,
and
ever
come
of
age
.
 
<EOS>
If
it
were
a
girl
,
it
was
to
inherit
the
money
unconditionally
;
but
if
a
boy
,
only
on
the
stipulation
that
in
his
minority
he
should
never
have
stained
his
name
with
any
public

of
dishonour
,

,

,
or
wrong
.
 
<EOS>
He
did
this
,
he
said
,
to
mark
his
confidence
in
the
other
,
and
his
conviction
---
only

by
approaching
death
---
that
the
child
would
share
her
gentle
heart
,
and
noble
nature
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
were
disappointed
in
this
expectation
,
then
the
money
was
to
come
to
you
:
 
for
then
,
and
not
till
then
,
<EOS>
when
both
children
were
equal
,
would
he
recognise
your
prior
claim
upon
his
purse
,
who
had
none
upon
his
heart
,
but
had
,
from

,
repulsed

with

and

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
mother
,
"
said

,
in

,
"
did
what
a
woman
should
have

.
 
<EOS>
She
burnt
this
will
.
 
<EOS>
The
letter
never
reached
its
destination
;
but
that
,
and
other
proofs
,
she
kept
,
in
case
they

to
lie

.
 
<EOS>
The
girl
's
father
had
the
truth
from
her
with
every

that
her
violent
hate
---
I
love
her
for
it
now
---
could
add
.
 
<EOS>
Goaded
by

and

he
fled
with

into
a

corner
of
Wales
,
changing
his
very
name
that
his

might
never

of

;
and
here
,
no
great
while
<EOS>
afterwards
,

.
 
<EOS>
The
girl
had

,
in
secret
,
some

;
he
had

,

,

;
it

,
<EOS>

that

had
destroyed
herself
,
to
hide
her

and
his
,
that
his
old

broke
.
"
   
<EOS>
There

,
until
Mr
Brownlow
took

.
   
<EOS>
"
Years
after
this
,
"
he

,
"
this
man
's
---
Edward
Leeford
's
---
mother
came
to

.
 
<EOS>
He
had
left
her
,
when
only
eighteen
;
robbed
her
of

and

;
gambled
,
squandered
,
forged
,
and
fled
to
London
:
 
where
for
two
years
he
had
associated
with
the
lowest

.
 
<EOS>
She
was
sinking
under
a
painful
and
incurable
disease
,
and
wished
to
recover
him
before
she
died
.
 
<EOS>
Inquiries
were
set
on
foot
,
and
strict
searches
made
.
<EOS>
They
were
unavailing
for
a
long

,
but
ultimately

;
and
he
went
back

to

.
   
<EOS>
"
There

,
"

,
"
after

;
and
,
on

of

---
though

need
not

left

,
for
I

inherited

.
 
<EOS>
She
would
not

that
the
girl

,
and

child

,
but
was

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

down
;
never

;

;

the

,

that

will
by

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
She

.
   
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
I

;
and
,

for

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
As

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The

?

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

"

,
who
reared
it
as
their
own
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Go
on
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
,
signing
to
Mrs
Maylie
to
approach
.
<EOS>
"
Go
on
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
could
n't
find
the
spot
to
which
these
people
had
repaired
,
"
said
Monks
,
"
but
where
friendship
fails
,
hatred
will
often
force
a
way
.
 
<EOS>
My
mother
found
it
,
after
a
year
of
cunning
search
---
ay
,
and
found
the
child
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
took
it
,
did
she
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
The
people
were
poor
and
began
to
sicken
---
at
least
the
man
did
---
of
their
fine
humanity
;
so
she
left

with
them
,
giving

of
money
which
would
not

,
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
She
did
n't
quite
rely
,
however
,
on
their
discontent
and
poverty
for
the
child
's

,
but
told
the
history
of
the
sister
's
shame
,
with
such

as
suited

;
bade

take
good

of
the
child
,
for
she
came
of
bad
blood
;
;
and
told

she
was
illegitimate
,
and
sure
to
go
wrong
at
one

or

.
 
<EOS>
The
circumstances
countenanced
all
this
;
the
people
believed
it
;
and
there
the
child
dragged
on
an
existence
,
miserable
enough
even
to

us
,
until
a

,

,
then
,
at
Chester
,
saw
the
girl
by

,
pitied
her
,
and
took
her
home
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
some
cursed
spell
,
I
think
,
against
us
;
for
in
spite
of
all
our

she
remained
there
and
was
happy
.
 
<EOS>
I
lost
sight
of
her
,
two
or

years
ago
,
and

no

until
a

back
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
see

now
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
Leaning
on
your
arm
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
not
the
less
my

,
"
cried
Mrs
Maylie
,

girl
in

;
"
not
the
less

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
My

,
my

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The

"

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The

.
 
<EOS>
My

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
borne
more
,

,

"

,

<EOS>
"

,

!
 
<EOS>
See

---
<EOS>
look
,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not

,
"

Oliver
,

;
"
I
'll
never

aunt
---
sister
,
my
own

,
that
something
taught

to
love
so

!
 
<EOS>
Rose
,
dear
,
darling
Rose
!
"
   
<EOS>
Let
the

which

,
and
the
broken

which

in

long

between

,
be

.
 
<EOS>
A
father
,
sister
,
and

,
were

,
and

,
in

.
 
<EOS>
Joy

were

in
the

;
but
there
were
no

:
 
<EOS>
for
even

itself

so

,
and

,
that
it

a

,
and
lost

.
   
<EOS>
They
were
a
long
,

alone
.
 
<EOS>
A

at
the
door
,
at
length
announced
that
some
one
was
without
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
opened
it
,
glided

,
and
gave
place
to
Harry
Maylie
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
it
all
,
"
he

,

lovely
girl
.
"
<EOS>
Dear
Rose
,
I
know

all
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
not

,
"
he

"
nor

to

,

---

.
 
<EOS>
Do

that
I

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Stay
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
DO

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
All
.
 
<EOS>
You

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not

,
"

"

,

.
<EOS>
I

I

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

,

,
<EOS>
as

?
 
<EOS>

,
"

,
"

<EOS>
;

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
disclosure
of
to

,
"
---
Harry

.
   
<EOS>
"
The

to

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

"

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

;
"
I

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then

?
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And

!
 
<EOS>
What

!
"
<EOS>
cried

.
<EOS>
"
That
a
sense

his
deep

that
he

---
there
,

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not

,

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
My

,

,

,
feeling
:
 
every

:
 
have

.
 
<EOS>
I
offer

,

,
no

among

;
no

,

by
aught

;
but

---

---
<EOS>

,

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

!
<EOS>
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
mean
<EOS>
but

---
<EOS>
that

,

to

;

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
This

.
 
<EOS>
Those

this
,
have
shrunk

you
,
and
proved
you
so

.
 
<EOS>
Such

:
 
such

of

:
 
as
smiled
upon
me
then
,
look
coldly

;
but
there
are
smiling

and

in
England
's

;
and
by
one

---
mine
,
Rose
,

!
<EOS>
---
there
stands

rustic

which
you
can
make

,
than
all

,

.
 
<EOS>
This
is
my
rank
and
station
now
,
and
here

lay

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
trying
thing
waiting

,
"
said
Mr
Grimwig
,

,
and

.
   
<EOS>
Truth

tell
,

had

.
 
<EOS>
Neither
Mrs
Maylie
,
nor
Harry
,
nor
Rose
(
who

)
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

-

,
"
said

Grimwig
,
"
for

.
 
<EOS>
I

take
the

,
if

,
of

the
bride
that
is
to
be
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Grimwig
lost
no

in
carrying
this
notice
into
effect
upon
the
blushing
girl
;
and
the
example
,
being

,
was

both

the

:
 
some

affirm
that
Harry
Maylie
had

observed

,

,
in

;
but
the
best

consider
this
downright

:
 
he
being
young

.
   
<EOS>
"
Oliver
,
my
child
,
"
said
Mrs
Maylie
,
"
where
have
you
been
,
<EOS>
and
why
do

?
 
<EOS>
There
are
tears
stealing
down
your
face
at
this

.
 
<EOS>
What
is
the
matter
?
"
   
<EOS>
It
is
a
world
of
disappointment
:
 
often
to
the
hopes
we
most
cherish
,
and
hopes
that
do
our
nature
the
greatest
honour
.
   
<EOS>
Poor
Dick
was
dead
!
    
<EOS>
Chapter
52
.
<EOS>
Fagin
's
last
night
alive
.
 
<EOS>
The
court
was
paved
,
from
floor
to
roof
,
with
human
faces
.
<EOS>
Inquisitive
and
eager
eyes
peered
from
every
inch
of
space
.
<EOS>
From
the
rail
before
the
dock
,
away
into
the
sharpest
angle
of
the
smallest
corner
in
the
galleries
,
all
looks
were
fixed
upon
one
man
---
Fagin
.
 
<EOS>
Before
him
and
behind
:
 
above
,
below
,
on
the
right
and
on
the
left
:
 
he
seemed
to
stand
surrounded
by
a
firmament
,
all
bright
with
gleaming
eyes
.
   
<EOS>
He
stood
there
,
in
all
this
glare
of
living
light
,
with
one
hand
resting
on
the
wooden
slab
before
him
,
the
other
held
to
his
ear
,
and
his
head
thrust
forward
to
enable
him
to
catch
with
greater
distinctness
every
word
that
fell
from
the
presiding
judge
,
who
was
delivering
his
charge
to
the
jury
.
 
<EOS>
At
times
,
he
turned
his
eyes
sharply
upon
them
to
observe
the
effect
of
the
slightest
featherweight
in
his
favour
;
and
when
the
points
against
him
were
stated
with
terrible
distinctness
,
looked
towards
his
counsel
,
in
mute
appeal
that
he
would
,
even
then
,
urge
something
in
his
behalf
.
 
<EOS>
Beyond
these
manifestations
of
anxiety
,
he
stirred
not
hand
or
foot
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
scarcely
moved
since
the
trial
began
;
and
now
that
the
judge
ceased
to
speak
,
he
still
remained
in
the
same
strained
attitude
of
close
attention
,
with
his
gaze
ben
on
him
,
as
though
he
listened
still
.
   
<EOS>
A
slight
bustle
in
the
court
,
recalled
him
to
himself
.
 
<EOS>
Looking
round
,
he
saw
that
the
juryman
had
turned
together
,
to
consider
their
verdict
.
 
<EOS>
As
his
eyes
wandered
to
the
gallery
,
he
could
see
the
people
rising
above
each
other
to
see
his
face
:
 
some
hastily
applying
their
glasses
to
their
eyes
:
 
and
others
whispering
their
neighbours
with
looks
expressive
of
abhorrence
.
 
<EOS>
A
few
there
were
,
who
seemed
unmindful
of
him
,
and
looked
only
to
the
jury
,
in
impatient
wonder
how
they
could
delay
.
 
<EOS>
But
in
no
one
face
---
not
even
among
the
women
,
of
whom
there
were
many
there
---
could
he
read
the
faintest
sympathy
with
himself
,
or
any
feeling
but
one
of
all
-
absorbing
interest
that
he
should
be
condemned
.
   
<EOS>
As
he
saw
all
this
in
one
bewildered
glance
,
the
deathlike
stillness
came
again
,
and
looking
back
<EOS>
he
saw
that
the
jurymen
had
turned
towards
the
judge
.
 
<EOS>
Hush
!
   
<EOS>
They
only
sought
permission
to
retire
.
   
<EOS>
He
looked
,
wistfully
,
into
their
faces
,
one
by
one
when
they
passed
out
,
as
though
to
see
which
way
the
greater
number
leant
;
but
that
was
fruitless
.
 
<EOS>
The
jailed
touched
him
on
the
shoulder
.
<EOS>
He
followed
mechanically
to
the
end
of
the
dock
,
and
sat
down
on
a
chair
.
 
<EOS>
The
man
pointed
it
out
,
or
he
would
not
have
seen
it
.
   
<EOS>
He
looked
up
into
the
gallery
again
.
 
<EOS>
Some
of
the
people
were
eating
,
and
some
fanning
themselves
with
handkerchiefs
;
for
the
crowded
place
was
very
hot
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
one
young
man
sketching
his
face
in
a
little
note
-
book
.
 
<EOS>
He
wondered
whether
it
was
like
,
and
looked
on
when
the
artist
broke
his
pencil
-
point
,
and
made
another
with
his
knife
,
as
any
idle
spectator
might
have
done
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
same
way
,
when
he
turned
his
eyes
towards
the
judge
,
his
mind
began
to
busy
itself
with
the
fashion
of
his
dress
,
and
what
it
cost
,
and
how
he
put
it
on
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
an
old
fat
gentleman
on
the
bench
,
too
,
who
had
gone
out
,
some
half
an
hour
before
,
and
now
come
back
.
 
<EOS>
He
wondered
within
himself
whether
this
man
had
been
to
get
his
dinner
,
what
he
had
had
,
and
where
he
had
had
it
;
and
pursued
this
train
of
careless
thought
until
some
new
object
caught
his
eye
and
roused
another
.
   
<EOS>
Not
that
,
all
this
time
,
his
mind
was
,
for
an
instant
,
free
from
one
oppressive
overwhelming
sense
of
the
grave
that
opened
at
his
feet
;
it
was
ever
present
to
him
,
but
in
a
vague
and
general
way
,
and
he
could
not
fix
his
thoughts
upon
it
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
,
even
while
he
trembled
,
and
turned
burning
hot
at
the
idea
of
speedy
death
,
he
fell
to
counting
the
iron
spikes
before
him
,
and
wondering
how
the
head
of
one
had
been
broken
off
,
and
whether
they
would
mend
it
,
or
leave
it
as
it
was
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
he
thought
of
all
the
horrors
of
the
gallows
and
the
scaffold
---
and
stopped
to
watch
a
man
sprinkling
the
floor
to
cool
it
---
and
then
went
on
to
think
again
.
   
<EOS>
At
length
there
was
a
cry
of
silence
,
and
a
breathless
look
from
all
towards
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
The
jury
returned
,
and
passed
him
close
.
<EOS>
He
could
glean
nothing
from
their
faces
;
they
might
as
well
have
been
of
stone
.
 
<EOS>
Perfect
stillness
ensued
---
not
a
rustle
---
not
a
breath
---
Guilty
.
   
<EOS>
The
building
rang
with
a
tremendous
shout
,
and
another
,
and
another
,
and
<EOS>
then
it
echoed
loud
groans
,
that
gathered
strength
as
they
swelled
out
,
like
angry
thunder
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
peal
of
joy
from
the
populace
outside
,
greeting
the
news
that
he
would
die
on
Monday
.
   
<EOS>
The
noise
subsided
,
and
he
was
asked
if
he
had
anything
to
say
why
sentence
of
death
should
not
be
passed
upon
him
.
<EOS>
He
had
resumed
his
listening
attitude
,
and
looked
intently
at
his
questioner
while
the
demand
was
made
;
but
it
was
twice
repeated
before
he
seemed
to
hear
it
,
and
then
he
only
muttered
that
he
was
an
old
man
---
an
old
man
---
and
<EOS>
so
,
dropping
into
a
whisper
,
was
silent
again
.
   
<EOS>
The
judge
assumed
the
black
cap
,
and
the
prisoner
still
stood
with
the
same
air
and
gesture
.
 
<EOS>
A
woman
in
the
gallery
,
uttered
some
exclamation
,
called
forth
by
this
dread
solemnity
;
he
looked
hastily
up
as
if
angry
at
the
interruption
,
and
bent
forward
yet
more
attentively
.
 
<EOS>
The
address
was
solemn
and
impressive
;
the
sentence
fearful
to
hear
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
stood
,
like
a
marble
figure
,
without
the
motion
of
a
nerve
.
 
<EOS>
His
haggard
face
was
still
thrust
forward
,
<EOS>
his
under
-
jaw
hanging
down
,
and
his
eyes
staring
out
before
him
,
when
the
jailer
put
his
hand
upon
his
arm
,
and
beckoned
him
away
.
 
<EOS>
He
gazed
stupidly
about
him
for
an
instant
,
and
obeyed
.
   
<EOS>
They
led
him
through
a
paved
room
under
the
court
,
where
some
prisoners
were
waiting
till
their
turns
came
,
and
others
were
talking
to
their
friends
,
who
crowded
round
a
grate
which
looked
into
the
open
yard
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
nobody
there
to
speak
to
HIM
;
but
,
as
he
passed
,
the
prisoners
fell
back
to
render
him
more
visible
to
the
people
who
were
clinging
to
the
bars
:
 
and
they
assailed
him
with
opprobrious
names
,
and
screeched
and
hissed
.
 
<EOS>
He
shook
his
fist
,
and
would
have
spat
upon
them
;
but
his
conductors
hurried
him
on
,
through
a
gloomy
passage
lighted
by
a
few
dim
lamps
,
into
the
interior
of
the
prison
.
   
<EOS>
Here
,
he
was
searched
,
that
he
might
not
have
about
him
the
means
of
anticipating
the
law
;
this
ceremony
performed
,
they
led
him
to
one
of
the
condemned
cells
,
and
left
him
there
---
alone
.
   
<EOS>
He
sat
down
on
a
stone
bench
opposite
the
door
,
which
served
for
seat
and
bedstead
;
and
casting
his
blood
-
shot
eyes
upon
the
ground
,
tried
to
collect
his
thoughts
.
<EOS>
After
awhile
,
he
began
to
remember
a
few
disjointed
fragments
of
what
the
judge
had
said
:
though
it
had
seemed
to
him
,
at
the
time
,
that
he
could
not
hear
a
word
.
 
<EOS>
These
gradually
fell
into
their
proper
places
,
and
by
degrees
suggested
more
:
 
so
that
in
a
little
time
he
had
the
whole
,
almost
as
it
was
delivered
.
 
<EOS>
To
be
hanged
by
the
neck
,
till
he
was
dead
<EOS>
---
that
was
the
end
.
 
<EOS>
To
be
hanged
by
the
neck
till
he
was
dead
.
   
<EOS>
As
it
came
on
very
dark
,
he
began
to
think
of
all
the
men
he
had
known
who
had
died
upon
the
scaffold
;
some
of
them
through
his
means
.
 
<EOS>
They
rose
up
,
in
such
quick
succession
,
that
he
could
hardly
count
them
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
seen
some
of
them
die
,
---
and
had
joked
too
,
because
they
died
with
prayers
upon
their
lips
.
 
<EOS>
With
what
a
rattling
noise
the
drop
went
down
;
and
how
suddenly
they
changed
,
from
strong
and
vigorous
men
to
dangling
heaps
of
clothes
!
   
<EOS>
Some
of
them
might
have
inhabited
that
very
cell
---
sat
upon
that
very
spot
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
very
dark
;
why
did
n't
they
bring
a
light
?
 
<EOS>
The
cell
had
been
built
for
many
years
.
 
<EOS>
Scores
of
men
must
have
passed
their
last
hours
there
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
like
sitting
in
a
vault
strewn
with
dead
bodies
---
the
cap
,
the
noose
,
the
pinioned
arms
,
the
faces
that
he
knew
,
even
beneath
that
hideous
veil
.
<EOS>
---
Light
,
light
!
   
<EOS>
At
length
,
when
his
hands
were
raw
with
beating
against
the
heavy
door
and
walls
,
two
men
appeared
:
 
<EOS>
one
bearing
a
candle
,
which
he
thrust
into
an
iron
candlestick
fixed
against
the
wall
:
 
the
other
dragging
in
a
mattress
on
which
to
pass
the
night
;
for
the
prisoner
was
to
be
left
alone
no
more
.
   
<EOS>
Then
came
the
night
---
dark
,
dismal
,
silent
night
.
 
<EOS>
Other
watchers
are
glad
to
hear
this
church
-
clock
strike
,
for
they
tell
of
life
and
coming
day
.
 
<EOS>
To
him
they
brought
despair
.
 
<EOS>
The
boom
of
every
iron
bell
came
laden
with
the
one
,
deep
,
hollow
sound
---
Death
.
<EOS>
What
availed
the
noise
and
bustle
of
cheerful
morning
,
which
penetrated
even
there
,
to
him
?
 
<EOS>
It
was
another
form
of
knell
,
with
mockery
added
to
the
warning
.
   
<EOS>
The
day
passed
off
.
 
<EOS>
Day
?
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
day
;
it
was
gone
as
soon
as
come
---
and
night
came
on
again
;
night
so
long
,
and
yet
so
short
;
long
in
its
dreadful
silence
,
and
short
in
its
fleeting
hours
.
 
<EOS>
At
one
time
he
raved
and
blasphemed
;
and
at
another
howled
and
tore
his
hair
.
 
<EOS>
Venerable
men
of
his
own
persuasion
had
come
to
pray
beside
him
,
but
he
had
driven
them
away
with
curses
.
 
<EOS>
They
renewed
their
charitable
efforts
,
and
he
beat
them
off
.
   
<EOS>
Saturday
night
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
only
one
night
more
to
live
.
 
<EOS>
And
as
he
thought
of
this
,
the
day
broke
---
Sunday
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
not
until
the
night
of
this
last
awful
day
,
that
a
withering
sense
of
his
helpless
,
desperate
state
came
in
its
full
intensity
upon
his
blighted
soul
;
not
that
he
had
ever
held
any
defined
or
positive
hope
of
mercy
,
but
that
he
had
never
been
able
to
consider
more
than
the
dim
probability
of
dying
so
soon
.
<EOS>
He
had
spoken
little
to
either
of
the
two
men
,
who
relieved
each
other
in
their
attendance
upon
him
;
and
they
,
for
their
parts
,
made
no
effort
to
rouse
his
attention
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
sat
there
,
awake
,
but
dreaming
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
he
started
up
,
every
minute
,
and
with
gasping
mouth
and
burning
skin
,
hurried
to
and
fro
,
in
such
a
paroxysm
of
fear
and
wrath
that
even
they
---
used
to
such
sights
---
recoiled
from
him
with
horror
.
 
<EOS>
He
grew
so
terrible
,
at
last
,
in
all
the
tortures
of
his
evil
conscience
,
that
one
man
could
not
bear
to
sit
there
,
eyeing
him
alone
;
and
so
the
two
kept
watch
together
.
   
<EOS>
He
cowered
down
upon
his
stone
bed
,
and
thought
of
the
past
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
wounded
with
some
missiles
from
the
crowd
on
the
day
of
his
capture
,
and
his
head
was
bandaged
with
a
linen
cloth
.
 
<EOS>
His
red
hair
hung
down
upon
his
bloodless
face
;
his
beard
was
torn
,
and
twisted
into
knots
;
his
eyes
shone
with
a
terrible
light
;
his
unwashed
flesh
crackled
with
the
fever
that
burnt
him
up
.
<EOS>
Eight
---
nine
---
then
.
 
<EOS>
If
it
was
not
a
trick
to
frighten
him
,
and
those
were
the
real
hours
treading
on
each
other
's
heels
,
where
would
he
be
,
when
they
came
round
again
!
 
<EOS>
Eleven
!
 
<EOS>
Another
struck
,
before
the
voice
of
the
previous
hour
had
ceased
to
vibrate
.
 
<EOS>
At
eight
,
he
would
be
the
only
mourner
in
his
own
funeral
train
;
at
eleven
---
    
Those
dreadful
walls
of
Newgate
,
which
have
hidden
so
much
misery
and
such
unspeakable
anguish
,
not
only
from
the
eyes
,
but
,
too
often
,
and
too
long
,
from
the
thoughts
,
of
men
,
never
held
so
dread
a
spectacle
as
that
.
 
<EOS>
The
few
who
lingered
as
they
passed
,
and
wondered
what
the
man
was
doing
who
was
to
be
hanged
to
-
morrow
,
would
have
slept
but
ill
that
night
,
if
they
could
have
seen
him
.
   
<EOS>
From
early
in
the
evening
until
nearly
midnight
,
little
groups
of
two
and
three
presented
themselves
at
the
lodge
-
gate
,
and
inquired
,
with
anxious
faces
,
whether
any
reprieve
had
been
received
.
 
<EOS>
These
being
answered
in
the
negative
,
communicated
the
welcome
intelligence
to
clusters
in
the
street
,
who
pointed
out
to
one
another
the
door
from
which
he
must
come
out
,
and
showed
where
the
scaffold
would
be
built
,
and
,
walking
with
unwilling
steps
away
,
turned
back
to
conjure
up
the
scene
.
 
<EOS>
By
degrees
they
fell
off
,
one
by
one
;
and
,
for
an
hour
,
in
the
dead
of
night
,
the
street
was
left
to
solitude
and
darkness
.
   
<EOS>
The
space
before
the
prison
was
cleared
,
and
a
few
strong
barriers
,
painted
black
,
had
been
already
thrown
across
the
road
to
break
the
pressure
of
the
expected
crowd
,
when
Mr
Brownlow
and
Oliver
appeared
at
the
wicket
,
and
presented
an
order
of
admission
to
the
prisoner
,
signed
by
one
of
the
sheriffs
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
immediately
admitted
into
the
lodge
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
the
young
gentleman
to
come
too
,
sir
?
"
said
the
man
whose
duty
it
was
to
conduct
them
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
a
sight
for
children
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
indeed
,
my
friend
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Brownlow
;
"
but
my
business
with
this
man
is
intimately
connected
with
him
;
and
as
this
child
has
seen
him
in
the
full
career
of
his
success
and
villainy
,
I
think
it
as
well
---
even
at
the
cost
of
some
pain
and
fear
---
that
he
should
see
him
now
.
"
   
<EOS>
These
few
words
had
been
said
apart
,
so
as
to
be
inaudible
to
Oliver
.
 
<EOS>
The
man
touched
his
hat
;
and
glancing
at
Oliver
with
some
curiousity
,
opened
another
gate
,
opposite
to
that
by
which
they
had
entered
,
and
led
them
on
,
through
dark
and
winding
ways
,
towards
the
cells
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
,
"
said
the
man
,
stopping
in
a
gloomy
passage
where
a
couple
of
workmen
were
making
some
preparations
in
profound
silence
---
"
this
is
the
place
he
passes
through
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
step
this
way
,
you
can
see
the
door
he
goes
out
at
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
led
them
into
a
stone
kitchen
,
fitted
with
coppers
for
dressing
the
prison
food
,
and
pointed
to
a
door
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
an
open
grating
above
it
,
throught
which
came
the
sound
of
men
's
voices
,
mingled
with
the
noise
of
hammering
,
and
the
throwing
down
of
boards
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
putting
up
the
scaffold
.
   
<EOS>
From
this
place
,
they
passed
through
several
strong
gates
,
opened
by
other
turnkeys
from
the
inner
side
;
and
,
having
entered
an
open
yard
,
ascended
a
flight
of
narrow
steps
,
and
came
into
a
passage
with
a
row
of
strong
doors
on
the
left
hand
.
 
<EOS>
Motioning
them
to
remain
where
they
were
,
the
turnkey
knocked
at
one
of
these
with
his
bunch
of
keys
.
<EOS>
The
two
attendants
,
after
a
little
whispering
,
came
out
into
the
passage
,
stretching
themselves
as
if
glad
of
the
temporary
relief
,
and
motioned
the
visitors
to
follow
the
jailer
into
the
cell
.
 
<EOS>
They
did
so
.
   
<EOS>
The
condemned
criminal
was
seated
on
his
bed
,
rocking
himself
from
side
to
side
,
with
a
countenance
more
like
that
of
a
snared
beast
than
the
face
of
a
man
.
 
<EOS>
His
mind
was
evidently
wandering
to
his
old
life
,
for
he
continued
to
mutter
,
without
appearing
conscious
of
their
presence
otherwise
than
as
a
part
of
his
vision
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
boy
,
Charley
---
well
done
---
"
he
mumbled
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oliver
,
too
,
ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
 
<EOS>
Oliver
too
---
quite
the
gentleman
now
<EOS>
---
quite
the
---
take
that
boy
away
to
bed
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
jailer
took
the
disengaged
hand
of
Oliver
;
and
,
whispering
him
not
to
be
alarmed
,
looked
on
without
speaking
.
   
<EOS>
"
Take
him
away
to
bed
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Fagin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
hear
me
,
some
of
you
?
 
<EOS>
He
has
been
the
---
<EOS>
the
---
somehow
the
cause
of
all
this
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
worth
the
money
to
bring
him
up
to
it
---
<EOS>
Bolter
's
throat
,
Bill
<EOS>
;
never
mind
the
girl
---
<EOS>
Bolter
's
throat
as
deep
as
you
can
cut
.
 
<EOS>
Saw
his
head
off
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Fagin
,
"
said
the
jailer
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
me
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
Jew
,
falling
instantly
,
into
the
attitude
of
listening
he
had
assumed
upon
his
trial
.
 
<EOS>
"
An
old
man
,
my
Lord
;
a
very
old
,
old
man
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Here
,
"
said
the
turnkey
,
laying
his
hand
upon
his
breast
to
keep
him
down
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
's
somebody
wants
to
see
you
,
to
ask
you
some
questions
,
I
suppose
.
 
<EOS>
Fagin
,
Fagin
!
 
<EOS>
Are
you
a
man
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
sha
n't
be
one
long
,
"
he
replied
,
looking
up
with
a
face
retaining
no
human
expression
but
rage
and
terror
.
 
<EOS>
"
Strike
them
all
dead
!
 
<EOS>
What
right
have
they
to
butcher
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
he
caught
sight
of
Oliver
and
Mr
Brownlow
.
<EOS>
Shrinking
to
the
furthest
corner
of
the
seat
,
he
demanded
to
know
what
they
wanted
there
.
   
<EOS>
"
Steady
,
"
said
the
turnkey
,
still
holding
him
down
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,
sir
,
tell
him
what
you
want
.
 
<EOS>
Quick
,
if
you
please
,
for
he
grows
worse
as
the
time
gets
on
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
some
papers
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
advancing
,
"
which
were
placed
in
your
hands
,
for
better
security
,
by
a
man
called
Monks
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
a
lie
together
,
"
replied
Fagin
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
n't
one
---
not
one
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
For
the
love
of
God
,
"
said
Mr
Brownlow
solemnly
,
"
do
not
say
that
now
,
upon
the
very
verge
of
death
;
but
tell
me
where
they
are
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
that
Sikes
is
dead
;
that
Monks
has
confessed
;
that
there
is
no
hope
of
any
further
gain
.
 
<EOS>
Where
are
those
papers
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oliver
,
"
cried
Fagin
,
beckoning
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
,
here
!
<EOS>
Let
me
whisper
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
afraid
,
"
said
Oliver
in
a
low
voice
,
as
he
relinquished
Mr
Brownlow
's
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
papers
,
"
said
Fagin
,
drawing
Oliver
towards
him
,
"
are
in
a
canvas
bag
,
in
a
hole
a
little
way
up
the
chimney
in
the
top
front
-
room
.
 
<EOS>
I
want
to
talk
to
you
,
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
I
want
to
talk
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
yes
,
"
returned
Oliver
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
say
a
prayer
.
 
<EOS>
Do
!
 
<EOS>
Let
me
say
one
prayer
.
 
<EOS>
Say
only
one
,
upon
your
knees
,
with
me
,
and
we
will
talk
till
morning
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Outside
,
outside
,
"
replied
Fagin
,
pushing
the
boy
before
him
towards
the
door
,
and
looking
vacantly
over
his
head
.
<EOS>
"
Say
I
've
gone
to
sleep
---
they
'll
believe
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
can
get
me
out
,
if
you
take
me
so
.
 
<EOS>
Now
then
,
now
then
!
"
   
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
God
forgive
this
wretched
man
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
boy
with
a
burst
of
tears
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
right
,
that
's
right
,
"
said
Fagin
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
'll
help
us
on
.
<EOS>
This
door
first
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
shake
and
tremble
,
as
we
pass
the
gallows
,
do
n't
you
mind
,
but
hurry
on
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
now
,
now
!
<EOS>
"
   
"
Have
you
nothing
else
to
ask
him
,
sir
?
"
inquired
the
turnkey
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
other
question
,
"
replied
Mr
Brownlow
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
I
hoped
we
could
recall
him
to
a
sense
of
his
position
---
"
   
"
Nothing
will
do
that
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
man
,
shaking
his
head
.
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
leave
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
door
of
the
cell
opened
,
and
the
attendants
returned
.
   
<EOS>
"
Press
on
,
press
on
,
"
cried
Fagin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Softly
,
but
not
so
slow
.
<EOS>
Faster
,
faster
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
men
laid
hands
upon
him
,
and
disengaging
Oliver
from
his
grasp
,
held
him
back
.
 
<EOS>
He
struggled
with
the
power
of
desperation
,
for
an
instant
;
and
then
sent
up
cry
upon
cry
that
penetrated
even
those
massive
walls
,
and
rang
in
their
ears
until
they
reached
the
open
yard
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
some
time
before
they
left
the
prison
.
 
<EOS>
Oliver
nearly
swooned
after
this
frightful
scene
,
and
was
so
weak
that
for
an
hour
or
more
,
he
had
not
the
strength
to
walk
.
   
<EOS>
Day
was
dawning
when
they
again
emerged
.
 
<EOS>
A
great
multitude
had
already
assembled
;
the
windows
were
filled
with
people
,
smoking
and
playing
cards
to
beguile
the
time
;
the
crowd
were
pushing
,
quarrelling
,
joking
.
 
<EOS>
Everything
told
of
life
and
animation
,
but
one
dark
cluster
of
objects
in
the
centre
of
all
---
<EOS>
the
black
stage
,
the
cross
-
beam
,
the
rope
,
and
all
the
hideous
apparatus
of
death
.
    
Chapter
53
.
<EOS>
And
last
.
 
<EOS>
The
fortunes
of
those
who
have
figured
in
this
tale
are
nearly
closed
.
 
<EOS>
The
little
that
remains
to
their
historian
to
relate
,
is
told
in
few
and
simple
words
.
   
<EOS>
Before
three
months
had
passed
,
Rose
Fleming
and
Harry
Maylie
were
married
in
the
village
church
which
was
henceforth
to
be
the
scene
of
the
young
clergyman
's
labours
;
on
the
same
day
they
entered
into
possession
of
their
new
and
happy
home
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Maylie
took
up
her
abode
with
her
son
and
daughter
-
in
-
law
,
to
enjoy
,
during
the
tranquil
remainder
of
her
days
,
the
greatest
felicity
that
age
and
worth
can
know
---
the
contemplation
of
the
happiness
of
those
on
whom
the
warmest
affections
and
tenderest
cares
of
a
well
-
spent
life
,
have
been
unceasingly
bestowed
.
   
<EOS>
It
appeared
,
on
full
and
careful
investigation
,
that
if
the
wreck
of
property
remaining
in
the
custody
of
Monks
(
which
had
never
prospered
either
in
his
hands
or
in
those
of
his
mother
)
were
equally
divided
between
himself
and
Oliver
,
it
would
yield
,
to
each
,
little
more
than
three
thousand
pounds
.
 
<EOS>
By
the
provisions
of
his
father
's
will
,
Oliver
would
have
been
entitled
to
the
whole
;
but
Mr
Brownlow
,
unwilling
to
deprive
the
elder
son
of
the
opportunity
of
retrieving
his
former
vices
and
pursuing
an
honest
career
,
proposed
this
mode
of
distribution
,
to
which
his
young
charge
joyfully
acceded
.
   
<EOS>
Monks
,
still
bearing
that
assumed
name
,
retired
with
his
portion
to
a
distant
part
of
the
New
World
;
where
,
having
quickly
squandered
it
,
he
once
more
fell
into
his
old
courses
,
and
,
after
undergoing
a
long
confinement
for
some
fresh
act
of
fraud
and
knavery
,
at
length
sunk
under
an
attack
of
his
old
disorder
,
and
died
in
prison
.
 
<EOS>
As
far
from
home
,
died
the
chief
remaining
members
of
his
friend
Fagin
's
gang
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Brownlow
adopted
Oliver
as
his
son
.
 
<EOS>
Removing
with
him
and
the
old
housekeeper
to
within
a
mile
of
the
parsonage
-
house
,
where
his
dear
friends
resided
,
he
gratified
the
only
remaining
wish
of
Oliver
's
warm
and
earnest
heart
,
and
thus
linked
together
a
little
society
,
whose
condition
approached
as
nearly
to
one
of
perfect
happiness
as
can
ever
be
known
in
this
changing
world
.
   
<EOS>
Soon
after
the
marriage
of
the
young
people
,
the
worthy
doctor
returned
to
Chertsey
,
where
,
bereft
of
the
presence
of
his
old
friends
,
he
would
have
been
discontented
if
his
temperament
had
admitted
of
such
a
feeling
;
and
would
have
turned
quite
peevish
if
he
had
known
how
.
 
<EOS>
For
two
or
three
months
,
he
contented
himself
with
hinting
that
he
feared
the
air
began
to
disagree
with
him
;
then
,
finding
that
the
place
really
no
longer
was
,
to
him
,
what
it
had
been
,
he
settled
his
business
on
his
assistant
,
took
a
bachelor
's
cottage
outside
the
village
of
which
his
young
friend
was
pastor
,
and
instantaneously
recovered
.
 
<EOS>
Here
he
took
to
gardening
,
planting
,
fishing
,
carpentering
,
and
various
other
pursuits
of
a
similar
kind
:
 
all
undertaken
with
his
characteristic
impetuosity
.
 
<EOS>
In
each
and
all
he
has
since
become
famous
throughout
the
neighborhood
,
as
a
most
profound
authority
.
   
<EOS>
Before
his
removal
,
he
had
managed
to
contract
a
strong
friendship
for
Mr
Grimwig
,
which
that
eccentric
gentleman
cordially
reciprocated
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
accordingly
visited
by
Mr
Grimwig
a
great
many
times
in
the
course
of
the
year
.
 
<EOS>
On
all
such
occasions
,
Mr
Grimwig
plants
,
fishes
,
and
carpenters
,
with
great
ardour
;
doing
everything
in
a
very
singular
and
unprecedented
manner
,
but
always
maintaining
with
his
favourite
asseveration
,
that
his
mode
is
the
right
one
.
 
<EOS>
On
Sundays
,
he
never
fails
to
criticise
the
sermon
to
the
young
clergyman
's
face
:
 
always
informing
Mr
Losberne
,
in
strict
confidence
afterwards
,
that
he
considers
it
an
excellent
performance
,
but
deems
it
as
well
not
to
say
so
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
standing
and
very
favourite
joke
,
for
Mr
Brownlow
to
rally
him
on
his
old
prophecy
concerning
Oliver
,
and
to
remind
him
of
the
night
on
which
they
sat
with
the
watch
between
them
,
waiting
his
return
;
but
Mr
Grimwig
contends
that
he
was
right
in
the
main
,
and
,
in
proof
thereof
,
remarks
that
Oliver
did
not
come
back
after
all
;
which
always
calls
forth
a
laugh
on
his
side
,
and
increases
his
good
humour
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Noah
Claypole
:
 
<EOS>
receiving
a
free
pardon
from
the
Crown
in
consequence
of
being
admitted
approver
against
Fagin
:
 
and
considering
his
profession
not
altogether
as
safe
a
one
as
he
could
wish
:
 
was
,
for
some
little
time
,
at
a
loss
for
the
means
of
a
livelihood
,
not
burdened
with
too
much
work
.
 
<EOS>
After
some
consideration
,
he
went
into
business
as
an
Informer
,
in
which
calling
he
realises
a
genteel
subsistence
.
 
<EOS>
His
plan
is
,
to
walk
out
once
a
week
during
church
time
attended
by
Charlotte
in
respectable
attire
.
 
<EOS>
The
lady
faints
away
at
the
doors
of
charitable
publicans
,
and
the
gentleman
being
accommodated
with
three
-
penny
worth
of
brandy
to
restore
her
,
lays
an
information
next
day
,
and
pockets
half
the
penalty
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
Mr
Claypole
faints
himself
,
but
the
result
is
the
same
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
and
Mrs
Bumble
,
deprived
of
their
situations
,
were
gradually
reduced
to
great
indigence
and
misery
,
and
finally
became
paupers
in
that
very
same
workhouse
in
which
they
had
once
lorded
it
over
others
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bumble
has
been
heard
to
say
,
that
in
this
reverse
and
degradation
,
he
has
not
even
spirits
to
be
thankful
for
being
separated
from
his
wife
.
   
<EOS>
As
to
Mr
Giles
and
Brittles
,
they
still
remain
in
their
old
posts
,
although
the
former
is
bald
,
and
the
last
-
named
boy
quite
grey
.
 
<EOS>
They
sleep
at
the
parsonage
,
but
divide
their
attentions
so
equally
among
its
inmates
,
and
Oliver
and
Mr
Brownlow
,
and
Mr
Losberne
,
that
to
this
day
the
villagers
have
never
been
able
to
discover
to
which
establishment
they
properly
belong
.
   
<EOS>
Master
Charles
Bates
,
appalled
by
Sikes
's
crime
,
fell
into
a
train
of
reflection
whether
an
honest
life
was
not
,
after
all
,
the
best
.
 
<EOS>
Arriving
at
the
conclusion
that
it
certainly
was
,
he
turned
his
back
upon
the
scenes
of
the
past
,
resolved
to
amend
it
in
some
new
sphere
of
action
.
 
<EOS>
He
struggled
hard
,
and
suffered
much
,
for
some
time
;
but
,
having
a
contented
disposition
,
and
a
good
purpose
,
succeeded
in
the
end
;
and
,
from
being
a
farmer
's
drudge
,
and
a
carrier
's
lad
,
he
is
now
the
merriest
young
grazier
in
all
Northamptonshire
.
   
<EOS>
And
now
,
the
hand
that
traces
these
words
,
falters
,
as
it
approaches
the
conclusion
of
its
task
;
and
would
weave
,
for
a
little
longer
space
,
the
thread
of
these
adventures
.
   
<EOS>
I
would
fain
linger
yet
with
a
few
of
those
among
whom
I
have
so
long
moved
,
and
share
their
happiness
by
endeavouring
to
depict
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
show
Rose
Maylie
in
all
the
bloom
and
grace
of
early
womanhood
,
shedding
on
her
secluded
path
in
life
soft
and
gentle
light
,
that
fell
on
all
who
trod
it
with
her
,
and
shone
into
their
hearts
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
paint
her
the
life
and
joy
of
the
fire
-
side
circle
and
the
lively
summer
group
;
I
would
follow
her
through
the
sultry
fields
at
noon
,
and
hear
the
low
tones
of
her
sweet
voice
in
the
moonlit
evening
walk
;
I
would
watch
her
in
all
her
goodness
and
charity
abroad
,
and
the
smiling
untiring
discharge
of
domestic
duties
at
home
;
I
would
paint
her
and
her
dead
sister
's
child
happy
in
their
love
for
one
another
,
and
passing
whole
hours
together
in
picturing
the
friends
whom
they
had
so
sadly
lost
;
I
would
summon
before
me
,
once
again
,
<EOS>
those
joyous
little
faces
that
clustered
round
her
knee
,
and
listen
to
their
merry
prattle
;
I
would
recall
the
tones
of
that
clear
laugh
,
and
conjure
up
the
sympathising
tear
that
glistened
in
the
soft
blue
eye
.
 
<EOS>
These
,
and
a
thousand
looks
and
smiles
,
and
turns
<EOS>
fo
thought
and
speech
<EOS>
---
I
would
fain
recall
them
every
one
.
   
<EOS>
How
Mr
Brownlow
went
on
,
from
day
to
day
,
filling
the
mind
of
his
adopted
child
with
stores
of
knowledge
,
and
becoming
attached
to
him
,
more
and
more
,
as
his
nature
developed
itself
,
and
showed
the
thriving
seeds
of
all
he
wished
him
to
become
<EOS>
---
how
he
traced
in
him
new
traits
of
his
early
friend
,
that
awakened
in
his
own
bosom
old
remembrances
,
melancholy
and
yet
sweet
and
soothing
---
how
the
two
orphans
,
tried
by
adversity
,
remembered
its
lessons
in
mercy
to
others
,
and
mutual
love
,
and
fervent
thanks
to
Him
who
had
protected
and
preserved
them
---
these
are
all
matters
which
need
not
to
be
told
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
said
that
they
were
truly
happy
;
and
without
strong
affection
and
humanity
of
heart
,
and
gratitude
to
that
Being
whose
code
is
Mercy
,
and
whose
great
attribute
is
Benevolence
to
all
things
that
breathe
,
happiness
can
never
be
attained
.
   
<EOS>
Within
the
altar
of
the
old
village
church
there
stands
a
white
marble
tablet
,
which
bears
as
yet
<EOS>
but
one
word
:
 
"
AGNES
.
"
 
<EOS>
There
is
no
coffin
in
that
tomb
;
and
may
it
be
many
,
many
years
,
before
another
name
is
placed
above
it
!
 
<EOS>
But
,
if
the
spirits
of
the
Dead
ever
come
back
to
earth
,
to
visit
spots
hallowed
by
the
love
---
the
love
beyond
the
grave
---
of
those
whom
they
knew
in
life
,
I
believe
that
the
shade
of
Agnes
sometimes
hovers
round
that
solemn
nook
.
<EOS>
I
believe
it
none
the
less
because
that
nook
is
in
a
Church
,
and
she
was
weak
and
erring
.
    
<EOS>
